summary: Smith demonstrates the original weight-denomination correspondence across European currencies: the French livre, English pound, and Scottish pound all represented actual pounds of silver, and all three nations' pennies contained a real pennyweight.
distilled: European currencies originally shared a common standard: the French livre, English pound, and Scottish pound each contained an actual pound of silver.
notes: Pan-European monetary standards -- the Troyes fair as a standardizing institution. Original equivalence of English, French, and Scottish pounds. The penny as 1/240th of a pound. Cross-reference with 1.4.12-1.4.13 on subsequent debasement.

refashioned: The shilling also appears to have originally denoted a weight. An ancient statute of Henry III states that when wheat is at twelve shillings per quarter, a farthing loaf shall weigh eleven shillings and fourpence. However, the relationship between the shilling and the penny or pound was not always constant. During the first French dynasty, the sou or shilling variously contained five, twelve, twenty, or forty pennies. Among the Anglo-Saxons, a shilling sometimes contained only five pennies and may have been equally variable. From Charlemagne onward in France, and from William the Conqueror onward in England, the ratio of twelve pence to a shilling and twenty shillings to a pound became fixed -- though the actual metal content of each has changed enormously. In every country, I believe, the greed and dishonesty of rulers has gradually reduced the real quantity of metal in their coins, abusing the trust of their subjects.
elegant: The shilling was originally a weight, but its relationship to other denominations was unstable -- the French sou contained 5, 12, 20, or 40 pennies at various times. From Charlemagne and William the Conqueror onward, the 12-pence-to-a-shilling ratio stabilized, but the actual metal content was steadily debased. In every country, rulers' greed has gradually reduced the real metal in coins.
summary: Smith traces the shilling's history from a unit of weight with variable penny equivalence to a fixed denomination. He identifies a universal pattern: rulers everywhere have gradually debased their currency, reducing the actual metal content while maintaining nominal denominations.
distilled: Rulers in every country have progressively debased their coinage, reducing real metal content while maintaining nominal denominations -- a universal pattern of monetary fraud.
notes: Currency debasement as a universal historical phenomenon -- Smith identifies sovereign dishonesty as the constant. Variable shilling-penny ratios show early monetary instability. The stabilization under Charlemagne and William I created the modern pound-shilling-pence system. Cross-reference with 1.4.13 for specific debasement data.

refashioned: The Roman as was eventually reduced to one twenty-fourth of its original value, weighing only half an ounce instead of a full pound. The English pound and penny now contain only about a third of their original silver. The Scottish pound and penny have fallen to roughly one thirty-sixth, and the French pound and penny to about one sixty-sixth of their original value. Through these operations, rulers were able to appear to pay their debts with less silver than originally owed. But this was only an appearance -- their creditors were effectively defrauded of part of what was due to them. All other debtors in the state enjoyed the same privilege, paying old debts with the new, debased coins.
elegant: The Roman as fell to 1/24th of its original weight. The English pound retains about 1/3rd of its original silver, the Scottish 1/36th, the French 1/66th. Debasement let rulers appear to honor debts while actually paying less silver, defrauding creditors. All debtors gained the same privilege of repaying old debts in debased currency.
summary: Smith quantifies historical currency debasement: the Roman as lost 96% of its metal, the English pound 67%, the Scottish 97%, and the French 98%. Debasement was essentially sovereign fraud that benefited all debtors at creditors' expense.
distilled: Currency debasement -- reducing coins to fractions of their original metal content -- was sovereign fraud that systematically transferred wealth from creditors to debtors.
notes: Quantified debasement data across civilizations. The pattern is universal and always favors debtors (especially the sovereign, the largest debtor). This is an early analysis of inflation as a hidden tax. Cross-reference with 1.4.12 on the universal pattern of sovereign debasement and 1.4.14 on consequences.

refashioned: Such debasements have therefore always favored debtors and ruined creditors, sometimes producing greater upheavals in private fortunes than the worst public disasters. It is through this process that money has become, in all civilized nations, the universal instrument of commerce, by means of which goods of all kinds are bought, sold, and exchanged for one another.
elegant: Currency debasement always enriches debtors and ruins creditors, sometimes causing greater upheaval in private fortunes than the worst public calamities. Through this turbulent history, money became the universal medium of commerce in all civilized nations.
summary: Smith concludes that currency debasement has historically caused enormous redistributions of wealth from creditors to debtors. Despite this troubled history, money became the universal instrument of commerce.
distilled: Currency debasement has historically devastated creditors while enriching debtors, yet money remains the universal medium of commerce.
notes: Distributional consequences of debasement -- wealth transfer from creditors to debtors. Smith emphasizes the severity: worse than public calamities. Transitional paragraph leading to the theory of value (1.4.15-1.4.18). Cross-reference with 1.4.13 on specific debasement data.

refashioned: The next question is: what rules do people naturally follow when exchanging goods for money or for each other? These rules determine what we call the relative or exchangeable value of goods. The word 'value' has two distinct meanings. Sometimes it means the usefulness of an object -- its value in use. Other times it means the purchasing power that possessing an object provides -- its value in exchange. Things with the greatest value in use often have little or no value in exchange, and vice versa. Nothing is more useful than water, but it will buy almost nothing. A diamond has virtually no practical use, but an enormous quantity of other goods can be obtained in exchange for it.
elegant: What rules govern exchange values? The word 'value' has two meanings: value in use (utility) and value in exchange (purchasing power). These often diverge dramatically. Water is supremely useful but nearly worthless in exchange. Diamonds are practically useless but enormously valuable in trade.
summary: Smith introduces the distinction between value in use (utility) and value in exchange (purchasing power), illustrating with the famous water-diamond paradox: water is essential but cheap; diamonds are useless but expensive.
distilled: Value in use and value in exchange are distinct -- water is invaluable in use but worthless in exchange; diamonds are the reverse.
notes: The water-diamond paradox -- one of the most famous puzzles in economics, not fully resolved until the marginal revolution of the 1870s (Jevons, Menger, Walras). Smith's distinction between use-value and exchange-value was adopted by Ricardo, Marx, and the entire classical tradition. Cross-reference with 1.5.1 on labor as the measure of exchange value.

refashioned: To investigate the principles governing exchangeable value, I will attempt to show, first, what is the real measure of this exchangeable value -- in other words, what constitutes the real price of all commodities.
elegant: To investigate exchangeable value, the first question is: what is its real measure -- what constitutes the true price of all commodities?
summary: Smith outlines the first of three questions he will address: what is the real measure of exchangeable value?
distilled: The first question of value theory: what is the real measure of a commodity's exchangeable value?
notes: Roadmap for Chapters 5-7. First question: the measure of value (Chapter 5). Cross-reference with 1.4.17 for questions two and three.

refashioned: Second, what are the different components that make up this real price? And third, what circumstances cause these components to rise above or fall below their natural or ordinary level -- in other words, what causes the market price of commodities to diverge from what may be called their natural price?
elegant: Second: what components make up the real price? Third: what causes market prices to diverge from their natural level?
summary: Smith outlines the second and third questions of his value theory: the components of price and the causes of market price deviations from natural price.
distilled: The remaining questions of value theory: what composes price, and what causes market prices to deviate from natural prices?
notes: Second question: components of price (Chapter 6 -- wages, profit, rent). Third question: market vs. natural price (Chapter 7). These three questions structure the entire analytical framework of Book I.

refashioned: I will explain these three subjects as fully and clearly as I can in the following three chapters. I must earnestly ask for the reader's patience with details that may sometimes seem tediously thorough, and for their attention to ideas that may remain somewhat obscure even after my best efforts at explanation. I would rather risk being tedious than fail to be clear. And after my utmost efforts at clarity, some difficulty may remain in a subject that is, by its very nature, highly abstract.
elegant: The following three chapters address these questions. The reader's patience is needed for occasionally tedious detail, and their attention for inherently abstract material. Clarity is worth the risk of tedium on a subject that is abstract by nature.
summary: Smith prepares the reader for the complex analysis ahead, asking for patience with detailed exposition and attention to abstract reasoning, preferring thoroughness over brevity.
distilled: Smith asks the reader's patience for the detailed, abstract analysis of value theory that follows, preferring clarity over brevity.
notes: Methodological aside -- Smith acknowledges the difficulty of his subject and his preference for thoroughness. This was a common 18th-century rhetorical convention. Concludes Chapter 4 and transitions to Chapter 5's labor theory of value.

refashioned: A person is rich or poor according to how well they can afford life's necessities, comforts, and pleasures. But once the division of labor is established, one's own labor provides only a tiny fraction of these. The rest must come from others' labor, and one's wealth depends on how much of that labor one can command or purchase. The value of any commodity to someone who intends to exchange it rather than use it equals the quantity of labor it enables them to buy or command. Labor, therefore, is the real measure of the exchangeable value of all commodities.
elegant: Wealth means the ability to enjoy life's necessities and comforts. After the division of labor, most of these come from others' work. A commodity's value to its owner equals the labor it can command in exchange. Labor is therefore the real measure of all exchangeable value.
summary: Smith establishes labor as the fundamental measure of value. Since the division of labor means we depend on others' work for most of what we need, a commodity's real value equals the quantity of others' labor it can purchase.
distilled: Labor is the real measure of exchangeable value -- a commodity is worth the amount of others' labor it can command.
notes: Labor theory of value -- Smith's central proposition in Chapter 5. Labor as the universal measure, distinct from money price. This influenced Ricardo and Marx profoundly, though they developed it in different directions. Cross-reference with 1.4.15 on the water-diamond paradox and 1.5.2 on labor as 'original purchase money.'

refashioned: The real price of everything -- what it truly costs the person who wants to acquire it -- is the toil and trouble of acquiring it. What anything is really worth to someone who wants to sell or exchange it is the toil and trouble it can save them and impose on others. What is bought with money or goods is purchased by labor just as surely as what we produce by our own effort. Money and goods merely spare us that effort; they contain the value of a certain quantity of labor, which we exchange for what we suppose to contain an equal quantity. Labor was the first price, the original purchase money paid for everything. The world's wealth was not originally bought with gold or silver, but with labor. Its value to anyone who wishes to exchange it for something new is precisely equal to the quantity of labor it enables them to buy or command.
elegant: The real cost of anything is the toil of acquiring it. What anything is worth is the toil it saves you and imposes on others. Money and goods are just stored labor exchanged for equal labor. Labor was the first price -- the original purchase money for all wealth. The world was bought not with gold or silver but with work.
summary: Smith argues that the true cost of any good is the labor required to acquire it, and its true worth is the labor it commands in exchange. Labor is the 'original purchase money' -- all wealth was first acquired through work, not through gold or silver.
distilled: Labor is the original purchase money for everything -- the real cost of any good is the toil required to obtain it.
notes: Labor as 'original purchase money' -- a foundational metaphor. Smith equates real cost with effort and real value with command over labor. This 'labor commanded' theory differs subtly from Ricardo's 'labor embodied' theory. Cross-reference with 1.5.1 and 1.5.3 on wealth as command over labor.

refashioned: Wealth, as Hobbes says, is power. But acquiring or inheriting a fortune does not necessarily bring political or military power. The fortune may provide the means to acquire such power, but mere possession does not guarantee it. The power that wealth directly and immediately confers is the power to purchase command over labor, or over the products of labor available in the market. One's fortune is greater or less precisely in proportion to this power -- the quantity of other people's labor, or equivalently the products of their labor, that it enables one to buy or command. The exchangeable value of anything must always equal exactly the extent of this purchasing power over labor.
elegant: Hobbes says wealth is power, but a fortune confers no political power directly. What it does confer is purchasing power over labor and its products. One's fortune precisely equals the amount of others' labor it can command. Every commodity's exchangeable value equals this purchasing power.
summary: Smith qualifies Hobbes: wealth is power, but only as purchasing power over labor. A fortune does not automatically bring political power; it directly provides command over the labor and products of others, and this command is the precise measure of its value.
distilled: Wealth is purchasing power over others' labor -- a fortune's value equals exactly the quantity of labor it can command.
notes: Smith engaging with Hobbes on wealth and power. The distinction between political power and economic power (command over labor). This frames the labor theory of value in terms of social relationships -- wealth as command over others' time and effort. Cross-reference with 1.5.1-1.5.2.

refashioned: Although labor is the real measure of all exchangeable value, it is not how value is commonly estimated. Comparing two different quantities of labor is often difficult. Time spent on two different kinds of work does not alone determine their relative value -- the difficulty endured and the skill required must also be considered. There may be more labor in one hour of hard work than in two hours of easy work; or in one hour applying a trade that took ten years to learn than in a month at a simple job. But there is no precise way to measure either hardship or skill. In practice, exchange values are adjusted for these factors, but not through any exact calculation -- instead through the haggling and bargaining of the market, which achieves a rough equality sufficient for everyday commerce.
elegant: Though labor is the real measure of value, comparing different types of labor is difficult. Time alone is insufficient -- hardship and skill matter too. An hour of hard work may contain more labor than two hours of easy work. In practice, the market adjusts for these differences not through precise measurement but through haggling and bargaining, achieving rough equality sufficient for commerce.
summary: Smith acknowledges a practical difficulty with the labor theory of value: different kinds of labor vary in difficulty and skill, making direct comparison impossible. The market resolves this through bargaining rather than precise measurement.
distilled: Comparing different types of labor is impractical, so the market uses bargaining rather than precise calculation to establish rough equivalences.
notes: The heterogeneity-of-labor problem -- a fundamental challenge to the labor theory of value that Smith acknowledges but cannot fully resolve. The 'higgling and bargaining of the market' as a practical solution anticipates the subjective theory of value. Cross-reference with 1.6.2 on skill-adjusted labor costs.

refashioned: Moreover, commodities are far more frequently exchanged for other commodities than for labor directly. It is therefore more natural to estimate a commodity's value in terms of other commodities rather than the labor it could purchase. Most people understand what a quantity of a particular commodity means more readily than what a quantity of labor means. A commodity is a concrete, tangible thing; labor is an abstract concept which, though it can be made intelligible enough, is not nearly as intuitive.
elegant: Commodities are exchanged for other commodities far more often than for labor directly, so it feels more natural to measure value in goods rather than labor. A quantity of goods is tangible and obvious; a quantity of labor is abstract and less intuitive.
summary: Smith explains why labor is not used as a practical measure of value despite being the theoretically correct one: goods are exchanged for other goods far more often than for labor, and quantities of goods are more intuitively understood than quantities of labor.
distilled: People naturally measure value in commodities rather than labor because goods are tangible while labor is abstract.
notes: Practical vs. theoretical measures of value. Smith acknowledges the gap between his theoretical conclusion (labor as true measure) and everyday practice (commodity-for-commodity comparison). This leads to the discussion of money as a practical value measure in 1.5.6.

refashioned: Once barter gives way to monetary exchange, each commodity is traded for money more frequently than for any other good. The butcher rarely brings meat directly to the baker or brewer to swap for bread or beer. Instead, he sells meat at the market for money and then uses that money to buy bread and beer. The money price he receives determines how much bread and beer he can subsequently purchase. It is therefore more natural for him to think of his meat's value in terms of money -- the commodity he directly exchanges it for -- than in bread and beer, which he can obtain only through money as an intermediary. He says his meat is worth threepence or fourpence a pound, not that it is worth three or four pounds of bread or three or four quarts of beer. Thus the exchangeable value of every commodity comes to be estimated by its money price rather than by the labor or other goods it might command.
elegant: Once money replaces barter, everything is priced in money rather than other goods. The butcher sells meat for money, then buys bread and beer -- so he naturally thinks of meat's value in money terms. He says his meat costs threepence a pound, not three pounds of bread. Money becomes the universal measure of exchangeable value in practice.
summary: Smith explains how money became the practical standard of value. Since goods are sold for money before being exchanged for other goods, people naturally express all values in monetary terms rather than in quantities of labor or other commodities.
distilled: Money became the practical measure of value because all goods are first exchanged for money, making monetary prices the natural way to express value.
notes: Money as numeraire -- the practical measure displacing labor as the theoretical measure. The butcher example revisited (compare with 1.2.5). Money prices are convenient but, as Smith will argue, unreliable over long periods due to changes in money's own value (1.5.7-1.5.9).

refashioned: Gold and silver, however, vary in value like any other commodity -- sometimes cheaper, sometimes dearer, sometimes easier and sometimes harder to obtain. The quantity of labor that a given amount of gold or silver can purchase depends on the productivity of the mines known at the time. The discovery of the abundant American mines in the sixteenth century reduced the value of gold and silver in Europe to roughly a third of their previous level. Since it cost less labor to bring these metals from mine to market, they could command less labor once there. This was perhaps the greatest such revolution in value, but it is by no means the only one history records.
elegant: Gold and silver fluctuate in value like any commodity, depending on the productivity of known mines. The discovery of American mines in the sixteenth century reduced European gold and silver values to about a third of their former level -- less labor to produce meant less labor commanded. This was history's greatest monetary value revolution, but not the only one.
summary: Smith argues that gold and silver are unreliable measures of value because they fluctuate depending on mine productivity. The American discoveries cut European precious metal values by two-thirds, demonstrating that money itself is an unstable standard.
distilled: Gold and silver are unreliable value measures because their own value fluctuates -- the American mine discoveries cut their European value by two-thirds.
notes: Instability of metallic money's value -- the Price Revolution of the 16th century as the primary example. Mine productivity determines metal value, which determines money's purchasing power. This undermines money as a long-term value standard. Cross-reference with 1.5.8-1.5.9 on labor as the only stable measure.

refashioned: Just as a measuring unit that keeps changing in size -- a foot, fathom, or handful that varies -- can never accurately measure other quantities, a commodity that fluctuates in its own value can never reliably measure the value of other things. Equal quantities of labor, however, can be said to have equal value to the laborer at all times and places. In a normal state of health, strength, and spirits, with ordinary skill, a worker must always sacrifice the same portion of ease, liberty, and happiness in performing a given amount of work.
elegant: A measure that keeps changing size cannot accurately measure anything. Gold and silver change in value, but labor does not -- equal labor always costs the worker the same sacrifice of ease, liberty, and happiness, regardless of time or place.
summary: Smith argues that labor is the only stable measure of value because, unlike gold and silver, the subjective cost of labor to the worker remains constant across all times and places.
distilled: Labor is the only stable measure of value because its subjective cost to the worker -- the sacrifice of ease, liberty, and happiness -- never changes.
notes: Labor as invariable standard -- a crucial but debatable claim. Smith grounds value in the subjective disutility of work (sacrifice of ease and happiness), which he asserts is constant. This 'real cost' view differs from both the market-price approach and the later utility-based approach. Cross-reference with 1.5.9.

refashioned: The price the laborer pays in effort is always the same, regardless of how much he receives in return. Sometimes those goods are greater in quantity, sometimes less -- but it is their value that varies, not the value of the labor that purchases them. At all times and places, what is expensive is what costs much labor to obtain, and what is cheap is what requires little labor. Labor alone, never varying in its own value, is the only ultimate and real standard by which the value of all commodities can at all times and places be estimated and compared.
elegant: The worker's sacrifice is constant; only the goods received in return vary. What is expensive always costs much labor; what is cheap costs little. Labor, never varying in its own value, is the only universal standard for measuring and comparing commodity values across all times and places.
summary: Smith concludes that labor is the sole invariable standard of value. The goods labor can buy fluctuate, but the effort labor represents remains constant, making it the only reliable basis for comparing values across different times and places.
distilled: Labor is the only invariable measure of value -- what changes is the goods it buys, never the effort it represents.
notes: The invariance claim -- controversial but central to Smith's theory. The distinction between labor's constant 'real' value (subjective effort) and the variable goods it commands. This undergirds the entire price theory. Cross-reference with 1.5.10 on real vs. nominal price.

refashioned: Labor measures the real price of commodities; money measures only their nominal price. Yet although equal quantities of labor are always of equal value to the laborer, they may appear to be of different value to the employer. He sometimes pays more goods and sometimes fewer for the same labor, so the price of labor seems to him to fluctuate like anything else. It appears expensive in one case and cheap in another. In reality, however, it is the goods that are cheap or dear, not the labor.
elegant: Labor is the real price; money the nominal price. To the employer, labor seems to vary in value -- sometimes costing more goods, sometimes fewer. But it is the goods that change in value, not the labor. The worker's effort is constant; only its purchasing power fluctuates.
summary: Smith distinguishes real price (measured in labor) from nominal price (measured in money). What appears to the employer as fluctuating labor costs is actually fluctuating commodity values -- the effort of labor itself remains constant.
distilled: Real price is measured in labor, nominal price in money -- apparent labor price fluctuations actually reflect changing goods values.
notes: Real vs. nominal price -- a fundamental distinction in economics. The employer's perspective creates the illusion that labor's value changes, but Smith insists the variation is in goods, not labor. Cross-reference with 1.5.11 on labor's real and nominal price.

refashioned: In common usage, therefore, labor can be said to have both a real and a nominal price, just like commodities. Its real price consists in the quantity of necessities and comforts given in exchange for it; its nominal price, in the quantity of money. A laborer is rich or poor, well or badly compensated, in proportion to the real price of their labor, not the nominal price.
elegant: Labor, like commodities, has a real price (the necessities and comforts it buys) and a nominal price (the money received). A worker's true compensation is the real price -- what their wages actually purchase, not the money amount.
summary: Smith applies the real/nominal distinction to labor itself. A worker's true compensation is measured by the real goods and comforts their wages can buy, not by the nominal money amount received.
distilled: A worker's true compensation is the real purchasing power of their wages, not the nominal money amount.
notes: Real vs. nominal wages -- still a critical distinction in labor economics and policy debates. Inflation erodes nominal wages; real wages measure actual living standards. Cross-reference with 1.5.10 and 1.5.12.

refashioned: The distinction between real and nominal price is not merely theoretical -- it has considerable practical importance. The same real price always represents the same value, but the same nominal price can represent very different values due to fluctuations in gold and silver. When a landed estate is sold with a perpetual rent reserved, if the rent is fixed in money, its real value is exposed to two kinds of erosion: first, changes in the actual metal content of coins of the same denomination; and second, changes in the purchasing power of equal quantities of gold and silver over time.
elegant: The real/nominal distinction has practical consequences. A perpetual money rent faces two erosion risks: coins may contain less metal over time (debasement), and equal quantities of gold and silver may buy less (depreciation). The same nominal rent can thus represent vastly different real values.
summary: Smith demonstrates the practical importance of the real/nominal price distinction. A perpetual rent fixed in money is vulnerable to two forms of erosion: currency debasement (less metal per coin) and depreciation of precious metals' purchasing power.
distilled: Fixed money rents face double erosion: currency debasement reduces the metal per coin, and precious metal depreciation reduces each unit's purchasing power.
notes: Practical consequences of nominal price instability -- directly relevant to contracts, pensions, and fixed incomes. The two erosion channels (debasement and depreciation) are analytically distinct. Cross-reference with 1.4.12-1.4.13 on debasement history and 1.5.13-1.5.14 on ongoing depreciation.

refashioned: Rulers and sovereign states have frequently found it in their temporary interest to reduce the pure metal in their coins, but they have seldom found reason to increase it. Consequently, the metal content of coins in virtually every nation has been almost continually shrinking and hardly ever growing. Such changes therefore tend almost always to reduce the value of rents fixed in money.
elegant: Rulers have always been tempted to reduce the metal in coins but never to increase it. Coin metal content has therefore shrunk almost continuously in every nation, steadily eroding the value of fixed money rents.
summary: Smith observes that sovereigns have a persistent incentive to debase currency but never to strengthen it, creating a one-directional ratchet that steadily erodes fixed monetary obligations.
distilled: Currency debasement is a one-way ratchet -- rulers always reduce coin metal content, never increase it, steadily eroding fixed money values.
notes: The debasement ratchet -- asymmetric sovereign incentives. Rulers gain from debasement (reducing real debt) but not from the reverse. This one-directional pressure is an early insight into inflationary bias in monetary policy. Cross-reference with 1.4.12-1.4.13.

refashioned: The discovery of the American mines reduced the value of gold and silver in Europe. This decline is commonly supposed -- though without certain proof, I believe -- to be continuing gradually and likely to persist for a long time. If so, such changes are more likely to diminish than to increase the value of a money rent, even one stipulated in a fixed weight of pure silver rather than a nominal coin amount.
elegant: The American mines reduced European gold and silver values, a decline commonly thought to be ongoing. If so, even rents fixed in actual ounces of pure silver -- not just nominal coin -- will continue to lose real value over time.
summary: Smith notes that the ongoing influx of American precious metals is believed to be continuously reducing gold and silver's value, meaning even rents denominated in actual metal weight, not just coin denominations, will tend to lose purchasing power.
distilled: Even rents fixed in pure metal weight lose value if the ongoing influx from American mines continues depressing gold and silver prices.
notes: Quantity theory implications -- increased metal supply reduces metal's value regardless of coinage denomination. Smith is cautious ('without any certain proof') about whether this trend is continuing. Cross-reference with 1.5.7 on the Price Revolution and 1.5.15 on corn as an alternative measure.

refashioned: Rents reserved in grain have held their value far better than those reserved in money, even where the currency denomination has remained unchanged. Under Elizabeth I, it was enacted that a third of all college lease rents should be paid in grain, either in kind or at current market prices. The money from this grain-rent, though originally just a third of the total, now typically yields almost twice as much as the other two-thirds combined, according to Dr. Blackstone. The old money rents of colleges must therefore have sunk to roughly a fourth of their original value -- they are now worth little more than a quarter of the grain they once could buy. Since the reign of Philip and Mary, the English coin's denomination has changed little, and the same pounds, shillings, and pence have contained nearly the same quantity of pure silver. This erosion of college money rents is therefore entirely attributable to the decline in silver's value.
elegant: Grain rents have preserved value far better than money rents. Under Elizabeth I, colleges reserved a third of rents in grain. That grain-third now yields nearly double the money-thirds combined -- the money rents have sunk to about a quarter of their original value. Since coin denomination barely changed since Philip and Mary, this erosion is entirely due to silver's declining value.
summary: Smith demonstrates that grain-denominated rents preserved their value while money rents lost roughly three-quarters of theirs over the same period. Since English coin denominations barely changed, the erosion was entirely due to falling silver values, not debasement.
distilled: Grain rents preserved their value while college money rents lost three-quarters of theirs, entirely due to silver's declining purchasing power.
notes: Empirical evidence for silver depreciation vs. grain stability. The Elizabethan college lease statute as a natural experiment. Dr. Blackstone (Commentaries on the Laws of England) as source. This supports grain as a better long-term value measure than silver. Cross-reference with 1.5.17 on grain vs. silver as value measures.

refashioned: When silver's declining value combines with reductions in the actual silver content of coins, the loss to money-rent holders is even greater. In Scotland, where coin denomination changes were much larger than in England, and in France, where they were larger still, some ancient rents of originally considerable value have been reduced to virtually nothing.
elegant: When silver depreciation and currency debasement combine, the loss is devastating. In Scotland and France, where debasement was far greater than in England, some ancient rents of substantial original value have been reduced to almost nothing.
summary: Smith shows that the combined effects of silver depreciation and coin debasement can be devastating. In Scotland and France, where both factors were severe, formerly valuable rents became virtually worthless.
distilled: The combination of silver depreciation and coin debasement reduced some formerly substantial Scottish and French rents to virtually nothing.
notes: Compounding effects -- depreciation plus debasement is worse than either alone. Scotland and France as extreme cases vs. England's relative stability. Cross-reference with 1.4.13 on debasement ratios and 1.5.15 on English depreciation alone.

refashioned: Equal quantities of labor will, over long periods, be more closely matched by equal quantities of grain -- the worker's basic subsistence -- than by equal quantities of gold, silver, or perhaps any other commodity. Equal quantities of grain will therefore more nearly represent equal real values over time, enabling the holder to purchase or command roughly the same quantity of others' labor. This holds more nearly than for almost any other commodity, though not exactly -- the real price of labor varies depending on whether society is advancing, stagnant, or declining. Every other commodity's ability to purchase labor at any given time depends on how much grain it can buy at that time. A rent reserved in grain is therefore exposed only to fluctuations in how much labor a given amount of grain can purchase. A rent in any other commodity faces this variation plus the additional variation in how much grain that commodity can buy.
elegant: Over long periods, equal grain quantities match equal labor values more closely than equal quantities of gold, silver, or any other commodity. This is because grain is the laborer's basic subsistence. Grain-denominated rents face only one source of variation -- how much labor grain commands. Rents in other commodities face that variation plus fluctuations in their own grain-purchasing power.
summary: Smith argues that grain is the best practical long-term proxy for labor value because it represents the worker's subsistence. Grain rents face only one source of variation (labor's grain-price), while other commodity rents face that plus their own grain-price fluctuation.
distilled: Grain is the best long-term proxy for labor value because as the basic subsistence commodity, its real value fluctuates less than gold, silver, or any other good.
notes: Grain as the best practical value standard -- a key argument for the 'corn model' later central to Ricardo. The subsistence-wage connection links grain prices to labor costs. The single vs. double variation argument is analytically clean. Cross-reference with 1.5.18 on short-term vs. long-term measures and 1.5.19 for the summary.

refashioned: However, while a grain rent varies much less than a money rent from century to century, it varies much more from year to year. The money price of labor, as I will show later, does not fluctuate with annual grain prices but adjusts to the average or ordinary price of grain. This average grain price is regulated by the value of silver -- by the richness or barrenness of the mines supplying the metal. Silver's value rarely changes much from year to year but may shift significantly from century to century. During periods when silver's value is stable, the average money price of grain and of labor may also remain steady for half a century or more. Meanwhile, the actual grain price in any given year may double or halve -- fluctuating, for example, from twenty-five to fifty shillings per quarter. When grain hits the high price, a grain rent's real value doubles, because money wages (and most other prices) hold steady during these short-term fluctuations.
elegant: Grain rents are more stable over centuries but more volatile year to year. Money wages track average grain prices, not annual fluctuations -- and average grain prices follow silver's value, which is stable for decades. So when a bad harvest doubles the grain price, a grain rent's real value doubles too, since money wages and most prices stay fixed in the short term. Silver is the better short-term measure; grain the better long-term one.
summary: Smith identifies an important asymmetry: grain rents are stable over centuries but volatile year-to-year, while money values are the reverse. Money wages adjust to average grain prices (which follow silver values) but not to annual harvest fluctuations, making grain rents volatile in the short term.
distilled: Grain is a better value measure over centuries while silver is better year-to-year, because wages track average grain prices, not annual harvest fluctuations.
notes: Short-term vs. long-term value measures -- a nuanced distinction. Money wages are 'sticky' relative to annual grain price fluctuations but adjust to long-term trends. This anticipates the modern distinction between real and nominal wage stickiness. Cross-reference with 1.5.17 and 1.5.19 for the complete argument.

refashioned: Labor, therefore, is clearly the only universal and truly accurate measure of value -- the only standard by which we can compare the values of different commodities across all times and places. We cannot estimate real value over centuries by quantities of silver, nor over years by quantities of grain. But by quantities of labor, we can estimate value with the greatest accuracy both from century to century and from year to year. Over centuries, grain is a better measure than silver, because equal grain quantities will command more nearly the same labor. Over years, silver is the better measure, because equal silver quantities will more nearly command the same labor.
elegant: Labor is the only universal and accurate measure of value, valid across all times and places. Silver fails over centuries; grain fails over years. But labor works for both. Over centuries, grain approximates labor better than silver. Over years, silver approximates labor better than grain.
summary: Smith concludes that labor is the only measure of value valid across all time horizons. For century-to-century comparisons, grain is the best practical proxy; for year-to-year, silver serves better. But only labor itself is universally accurate.
distilled: Labor is the only universal value measure -- grain approximates it best over centuries, silver over years, but only labor itself is accurate across all time scales.
notes: Synthesis of the value-measurement argument. The hierarchy: labor (universal) > grain (long-term) > silver (short-term). This elegant resolution of the measurement problem structures the rest of Smith's price analysis. Cross-reference with 1.5.8-1.5.9 on labor's invariance and 1.5.17-1.5.18 on the grain-silver comparison.

refashioned: In practice, however, the distinction between real and nominal price matters mainly for perpetual rents and very long leases, not for ordinary buying and selling. At the same time and place, real and nominal prices are in exact proportion to one another. The more money you get for a commodity in the London market, for example, the more labor it will enable you to purchase at that time and place. At the same time and place, therefore, money is the exact measure of real exchangeable value. But this holds only at the same time and place.
elegant: The real/nominal distinction matters for long-term contracts, not everyday transactions. At the same time and place, real and nominal prices are perfectly proportional -- more money means more labor commanded. Money is an exact value measure, but only at a given moment and location.
summary: Smith clarifies that for ordinary transactions at a given time and place, money perfectly measures real value. The real/nominal distinction matters only for long-term contracts, since money's value changes over time and between locations.
distilled: At the same time and place, money is a perfectly accurate measure of real value -- the real/nominal distinction matters only across time or distance.
notes: Scope limitation of the real/nominal distinction. Money works perfectly for spot transactions but fails for intertemporal or interlocal comparisons. This is a practical concession that makes money prices usable for everyday analysis. Cross-reference with 1.5.21 on interlocal differences.

refashioned: At distant places, there is no consistent relationship between real and money prices. Yet the merchant transporting goods between locations considers only the money price -- the difference between what he pays in silver at one place and what he receives at another. Half an ounce of silver in Canton, China, may command more labor and more goods than a full ounce in London. A commodity selling for half an ounce at Canton may therefore be worth more in real terms to its owner there than one selling for a full ounce in London is to its London owner. But if a London merchant can buy at Canton for half an ounce what he sells in London for a full ounce, he gains a hundred percent on the transaction regardless. It does not matter to him that half an ounce in Canton commands more labor than an ounce in London. An ounce in London gives him double what half an ounce would have done in Canton, and that is all he needs.
elegant: At distant places, real and money prices diverge -- half an ounce of silver buys more in Canton than a full ounce in London. But the merchant cares only about money profit: buying at half an ounce in Canton and selling at one ounce in London yields 100% gain regardless of real purchasing power differences.
summary: Smith shows that merchants rationally ignore real price differences between locations, focusing only on nominal price arbitrage. Even though silver buys more in Canton than London, a 100% money profit is a 100% money profit regardless.
distilled: Merchants focus on nominal price differences between locations, not real purchasing power differences -- money profit is what drives trade.
notes: Arbitrage and purchasing power parity. Smith recognizes PPP differences (silver buys more in Canton) but shows they are irrelevant to trade decisions, which are driven by nominal arbitrage. This anticipates the law of one price and PPP theory. Cross-reference with 1.5.20 on money as a local measure.

refashioned: Since it is the nominal or money price of goods that ultimately determines whether purchases and sales are prudent, and thereby governs almost all of commercial life, it is no wonder that money price receives far more attention than real price. In a work like this, however, it is sometimes useful to compare the different real values of a commodity at different times and places -- the different degrees of command over others' labor it may have conferred. For such comparisons, we should look not at the different quantities of silver it sold for, but at the different quantities of labor those silver amounts could have purchased. Since the actual price of labor at distant times and places can seldom be known precisely, grain prices -- though not always exactly proportional to labor prices -- are generally the closest available approximation. We must often content ourselves with grain prices as our proxy for labor values. I will have occasion to make several such comparisons hereafter.
elegant: Money price dominates practical commerce, which is why it receives more attention than real price. But for comparing values across time and place, we need labor quantities, not silver quantities. Since historical labor prices are rarely known, grain prices serve as the best available proxy -- not perfect, but the closest approximation. This proxy will be used throughout the work.
summary: Smith explains his methodology: while money prices govern everyday commerce, historical value comparisons require labor measures. Since labor prices are rarely recorded, he will use grain prices as the best available proxy throughout his analysis.
distilled: Money prices govern commerce in practice, but grain prices serve as the best available proxy for labor values in historical comparisons.
notes: Methodological statement -- grain prices as the practical tool for historical value comparisons. This establishes the analytical method used throughout The Wealth of Nations. Cross-reference with 1.5.17-1.5.19 on the theoretical justification for grain as a labor proxy.

refashioned: As industry advanced, commercial nations found it convenient to coin several different metals: gold for large payments, silver for moderate purchases, and copper or another base metal for the smallest transactions. They have always, however, treated one metal as the primary measure of value. This preference generally went to whichever metal they first used as money. Having begun with it as their standard when they had no other currency, they generally continued using it even after the original necessity had passed.
elegant: Commercial nations coined multiple metals for different transaction sizes -- gold for large, silver for moderate, copper for small -- but always designated one as the primary value standard. This was typically whichever metal they first used as money, a choice that persisted long after the original reason disappeared.
summary: Smith explains bimetallism: nations coined multiple metals for different transaction sizes but designated one as the primary standard of value, typically the metal first adopted as money, which retained its privileged status through institutional inertia.
distilled: Nations used multiple metals as money but always designated one as the primary standard, typically the metal first adopted, retained through institutional inertia.
notes: Bimetallic and polymetallic monetary systems. Path dependence in monetary standards -- the first metal adopted tends to remain the standard. Gold for large transactions, silver for moderate, copper for small. Cross-reference with 1.5.24-1.5.25 on specific national examples.

refashioned: The Romans reportedly had nothing but copper money until five years before the First Punic War, when they first coined silver. Copper therefore remained the measure of value in that republic. All Roman accounts appear to have been kept, and all estates valued, in asses or sestertii. The as was always a copper coin. The sestertius, meaning two and a half asses, was originally a silver coin, yet its value was expressed in copper. At Rome, someone deeply in debt was said to have a great deal of other people's copper.
elegant: Romans used only copper money until five years before the First Punic War. Copper therefore remained their value standard -- accounts were kept in asses (copper coins), and even the sestertius (a silver coin meaning 'two and a half asses') was valued in copper terms. Heavy debtors were said to owe much 'other people's copper.'
summary: Smith illustrates monetary path dependence with Rome: having started with copper, Romans continued measuring all values in copper terms even after introducing silver coinage. The sestertius, though silver, was defined by its copper equivalent.
distilled: Rome's copper monetary standard persisted even after silver coinage was introduced, illustrating how the first-adopted metal retains standard status.
notes: Roman monetary system as example of path dependence. Copper as the original and persistent standard. Pliny as source. The sestertius etymology (2.5 asses) shows copper-denominated accounting. Cross-reference with 1.5.23 on first-mover advantage in monetary standards.

refashioned: The northern nations that established themselves on the ruins of the Roman Empire appear to have used silver money from the beginning of their settlements, knowing neither gold nor copper coins for several centuries afterward. England had silver coins in Saxon times but saw little gold coinage until Edward III and no copper until James I. In England, therefore, and I believe in all other modern European nations, all accounts are kept and all values computed in silver. When we describe someone's fortune, we rarely mention guineas but instead state the number of pounds sterling we suppose it would fetch.
elegant: Northern European nations used silver from their earliest settlements. England had silver under the Saxons, gold only from Edward III, copper from James I. Silver therefore became the accounting standard throughout modern Europe -- fortunes are expressed in pounds sterling, not guineas.
summary: Smith shows that modern European nations, having adopted silver money first, established silver as their accounting standard. England is the prime example: silver preceded gold coinage by centuries, making the pound sterling the universal unit of account.
distilled: Silver became modern Europe's accounting standard because northern European nations adopted silver money first, centuries before gold or copper coinage.
notes: European silver standard -- path dependence continuing from 1.5.23-1.5.24. Saxon silver, Edward III's gold, James I's copper. The pound sterling as the unit of account regardless of which metal is physically used. Cross-reference with 1.5.26-1.5.28 on legal tender and bimetallic regulation.

refashioned: Originally, in all countries, legal tender could be made only in the coin of whichever metal was considered the standard of value. In England, gold was not legal tender for a long time after it was coined. The exchange rate between gold and silver was not fixed by law but left to the market. If a debtor offered payment in gold, the creditor could refuse it or accept it at whatever rate the two parties could agree upon. Copper is not currently legal tender except as change for small silver coins.
elegant: Originally, only the standard metal was legal tender. In England, gold was not legal tender for a long time after its introduction -- gold-silver exchange rates were set by the market, and creditors could refuse gold. Copper remains legal tender only for making change.
summary: Smith explains that legal tender status originally belonged only to the standard metal. Gold in England was not legal tender despite being coined, and its value relative to silver was determined by market bargaining, not law.
distilled: Legal tender originally applied only to the standard metal -- gold coins could be refused by creditors, with exchange rates set by market bargaining.
notes: Legal tender laws and monetary standards. Market-determined vs. legally fixed bimetallic ratios. The distinction between coins as money and coins as legal tender. Cross-reference with 1.5.27 on the transition to regulated ratios.

refashioned: In this situation, the distinction between the standard metal and the non-standard one was more than nominal. Over time, however, as people became familiar with using different metals in coinage and better understood their relative values, most countries found it convenient to fix the ratio by law -- declaring, for example, that a guinea of a certain weight and fineness should exchange for twenty-one shillings. Under such a regulated ratio, the distinction between the standard metal and the non-standard one becomes little more than a nominal difference.
elegant: When metal ratios were market-determined, the standard/non-standard distinction was substantive. But as nations fixed the ratio by law -- a guinea equals twenty-one shillings -- the distinction became essentially nominal.
summary: Smith traces the evolution from market-determined to legally fixed bimetallic ratios. Once the law fixes the exchange rate between gold and silver coins, the distinction between the standard and non-standard metal becomes merely nominal.
distilled: Fixing the gold-silver ratio by law made the distinction between standard and non-standard monetary metal essentially nominal.
notes: Evolution of bimetallic regulation. Market-determined to legally fixed ratios. The guinea at 21 shillings. Gresham's Law implications -- when legal and market ratios diverge, the undervalued metal disappears from circulation. Cross-reference with 1.5.28 on what happens when the fixed ratio changes.

refashioned: However, whenever the regulated ratio is changed, this distinction becomes substantive again. If the guinea's legal value were reduced to twenty shillings or raised to twenty-two, most payments (being denominated in silver) would require the same amount of silver but different amounts of gold. Silver would appear more stable than gold -- silver would seem to measure gold's value rather than the reverse. This appearance, however, would be entirely due to the convention of keeping accounts in silver rather than gold. If accounts and promissory notes were denominated in gold, the opposite would appear true: gold would seem stable and silver variable. A banker's note for fifty guineas would still be payable in fifty guineas regardless of the ratio change -- the gold amount stays the same while the silver equivalent shifts. If gold-denominated accounting became general, gold rather than silver would be considered the standard.
elegant: If the guinea's legal value changes, silver appears stable and gold variable -- but only because accounts are kept in silver. If accounts were kept in gold, gold would appear stable and silver variable. A 50-guinea note remains 50 guineas regardless; only the silver equivalent changes. The apparent standard depends entirely on which metal denominates accounts, not on any inherent stability.
summary: Smith demonstrates that the apparent stability of the monetary standard is an artifact of accounting convention. If accounts are kept in silver, silver appears stable when the gold ratio changes, and vice versa. There is no inherent superiority of one metal over the other.
distilled: Which metal appears to be the stable monetary standard depends entirely on which metal denominates accounts, not on any inherent property.
notes: Accounting conventions and monetary perception -- a subtle and important point. The apparent stability of the standard metal is an illusion created by denomination choice. Mr. Drummond's notes as a practical example. Cross-reference with 1.5.29 on which metal actually regulates value.

refashioned: In reality, under any fixed ratio, the most precious metal regulates the value of the entire coinage. Twelve copper pence contain about half a pound of low-quality copper, worth perhaps sevenpence as raw metal. But since the law says twelve pence equal a shilling, they circulate as worth a shilling. Even before the recent gold coin reform in Great Britain, gold coins were generally less degraded below their standard weight than silver coins. Yet twenty-one worn shillings were considered equivalent to a guinea. The recent reforms brought gold coins close to their standard weight, and the rule that public offices accept gold only by weight should maintain this standard. Silver coins, however, remain in their worn, degraded state -- yet twenty-one of these degraded shillings are still considered equal to an excellent guinea.
elegant: Under a fixed ratio, the most precious metal sets the value of all coinage. Twelve copper pence worth sevenpence as metal circulate as a shilling because law says so. Similarly, twenty-one worn silver shillings equal one guinea because gold -- the more precious metal -- regulates the system. After Britain's gold coin reform restored gold's standard weight, even degraded silver circulates at face value because its worth is pegged to sound gold.
summary: Smith explains that the most precious metal effectively regulates the entire monetary system under a fixed ratio. Base metals circulate above their intrinsic value because of their legal equivalence to precious metals. Britain's gold coin reform demonstrated this: improved gold coins raised the effective value of even degraded silver coins.
distilled: Under a fixed exchange ratio, the most precious metal regulates the value of all coins, causing base metals to circulate above their intrinsic worth.
notes: Precious metal regulation of the monetary system. Overvalued copper and undervalued silver in English coinage. The 1774 gold coin recoinage as a case study. Token money theory -- base coins circulate by legal equivalence to precious metal, not by intrinsic value. Cross-reference with 1.5.30-1.5.33 on practical implications.

refashioned: The reform of the gold coin clearly raised the value of the silver coin exchangeable for it. At the English Mint, a pound weight of gold is coined into forty-four and a half guineas, which at twenty-one shillings per guinea equals forty-six pounds, fourteen shillings, and sixpence. An ounce of gold coin is therefore worth three pounds, seventeen shillings, and tenpence halfpenny in silver. Since England charges no seignorage or duty on coinage, anyone bringing a pound of standard gold bullion to the Mint receives a pound of gold coin in return without deduction. Three pounds, seventeen shillings, and tenpence halfpenny per ounce is therefore called the Mint price of gold -- the quantity of gold coin the Mint gives in return for standard gold bullion.
elegant: The gold coin reform raised silver coin values. At the Mint, a pound of gold becomes 44.5 guineas (46 pounds, 14 shillings, 6 pence), making an ounce of gold coin worth 3 pounds, 17 shillings, 10.5 pence. With no seignorage charged, the Mint returns exactly a pound of coin for a pound of bullion. The Mint price of gold is thus 3 pounds, 17 shillings, 10.5 pence per ounce.
summary: Smith explains the English Mint's gold pricing. A pound of gold becomes 44.5 guineas, making the Mint price 3 pounds 17 shillings 10.5 pence per ounce. Since England charges no seignorage, bullion and coin contain identical gold weights.
distilled: The English Mint price of gold is 3 pounds, 17 shillings, 10.5 pence per ounce, with no seignorage deducted from bullion brought for coining.
notes: English Mint operations and pricing. Free coinage (no seignorage) means the Mint price equals the bullion's coin equivalent. The specific figures (44.5 guineas per pound, 3:17:10.5 per ounce) are the foundation for understanding bullion-coin price relationships in 1.5.31-1.5.32.

refashioned: Before the gold coin reform, the market price of standard gold bullion had been above three pounds eighteen shillings, sometimes three pounds nineteen shillings, and frequently four pounds per ounce -- sums that, in the worn and degraded gold coin, seldom contained more than an ounce of standard gold anyway. Since the reform, the market price seldom exceeds three pounds seventeen shillings sevenpence. Before the reform, the market price was always above the Mint price; since the reform, it has been constantly below it. This market price is the same whether paid in gold or silver coin. The gold coin reform therefore raised not only the value of gold coin but also that of silver coin relative to gold bullion, and probably relative to all other commodities too -- though other commodity prices are influenced by so many factors that the effect may not be clearly visible.
elegant: Before the gold reform, gold bullion's market price exceeded the Mint price (often reaching 4 pounds per ounce in degraded coin). After reform, it fell below the Mint price (around 3:17:7). Since market prices are the same in gold or silver coin, the reform raised both gold and silver coin values relative to bullion and probably to all commodities.
summary: Smith compares gold bullion prices before and after the gold coin reform. Previously above the Mint price, the market price fell below it after reform, demonstrating that sound coinage raised the purchasing power of both gold and silver coins.
distilled: The gold coin reform pushed bullion's market price below the Mint price, raising the purchasing power of both gold and silver coinage.
notes: Empirical evidence for the reform's effects. Market price above Mint price indicates degraded coin; below indicates sound coin. The reform's spillover effect on silver coin value demonstrates the precious-metal-regulation principle from 1.5.29. Cross-reference with 1.5.30 on Mint pricing and 1.5.32 on silver.

refashioned: At the English Mint, a pound of standard silver bullion is coined into sixty-two shillings, making the Mint price of silver five shillings and twopence per ounce. Before the gold coin reform, the market price of silver bullion ranged from five shillings fourpence to five shillings eightpence per ounce, with five shillings sevenpence being the most common price. Since the reform, it has fallen to between five shillings threepence and five shillings fivepence, rarely exceeding the latter. Though the market price of silver bullion has fallen considerably since the gold reform, it has not fallen as low as the Mint price.
elegant: The Mint coins a pound of silver into 62 shillings (5 shillings 2 pence per ounce). Before the gold reform, silver bullion traded at 5s 4d to 5s 8d (commonly 5s 7d). Since the reform, it has fallen to 5s 3d to 5s 5d -- lower, but still above the Mint price.
summary: Smith details silver bullion prices: the Mint price is 5s 2d per ounce, but the market price, though reduced by the gold reform from around 5s 7d to about 5s 4d, remains above the Mint price -- unlike gold, where the market price fell below it.
distilled: Silver bullion's market price fell after the gold reform but remains above the Mint price, unlike gold bullion which fell below its Mint price.
notes: Asymmetric response of gold vs. silver bullion to the gold reform. Silver's market price exceeding its Mint price indicates silver is undervalued in the coinage relative to gold. This is the core of the bimetallic problem. Cross-reference with 1.5.33 on the underlying ratio issue.

refashioned: In the English coinage, copper is rated well above its real value and silver somewhat below it. In European markets, and in both French and Dutch coinage, an ounce of fine gold exchanges for about fourteen ounces of fine silver. In English coinage, it exchanges for about fifteen ounces -- more silver than gold is worth by the common European standard. But just as the high copper coin price has not raised copper bar prices, the low silver coin rate has not depressed silver bullion prices. Silver bullion maintains its proper market ratio to gold because the same arbitrage forces apply.
elegant: English coinage overvalues copper and undervalues silver. In European markets, one ounce of gold equals about 14 ounces of silver; in English coin, it equals about 15 -- overvaluing gold relative to the continental standard. Yet bullion prices are unaffected: silver bars maintain their proper ratio to gold regardless of coin valuations, just as copper bars ignore the high copper coin rate.
summary: Smith identifies a misalignment in English coinage: silver is undervalued relative to gold compared to European market rates. Yet this distortion does not affect bullion prices, because market forces maintain the proper ratio regardless of legal coin valuations.
distilled: English coinage undervalues silver relative to gold compared to European market rates, but bullion market arbitrage prevents this from distorting actual metal prices.
notes: Bimetallic ratio mismatch -- England's 15:1 vs. Europe's 14:1 gold-silver ratio. Gresham's Law implications: the undervalued metal (silver) tends to leave circulation. Bullion market arbitrage as a corrective mechanism. Cross-reference with 1.5.29 on precious metal regulation and 1.5.34-1.5.35 on reform proposals.

refashioned: After the silver coin reform under William III, silver bullion's price remained above the Mint price. John Locke attributed this to the permission to export silver bullion while prohibiting export of silver coin, arguing that this made bullion demand exceed coin demand. But surely far more people need silver coin for everyday domestic buying and selling than need bullion for export. A similar permission exists today for gold bullion export, with gold coin export prohibited, yet gold bullion has fallen below the Mint price. The real explanation is that silver was then, as now, undervalued in English coinage relative to gold, and gold coin regulated the real value of the entire currency. Since the silver reform did not then reduce bullion prices to the Mint level, it is unlikely that another silver reform would do so now.
elegant: After William III's silver reform, silver bullion stayed above the Mint price. Locke blamed bullion export permissions, but gold bullion -- under identical export rules -- fell below its Mint price. The real cause is silver's undervaluation in English coin: gold regulates the system. A new silver reform alone would not solve this.
summary: Smith refutes Locke's explanation for silver bullion's premium over the Mint price. The true cause is silver's undervaluation relative to gold in English coinage, which means gold coins regulate the entire system's value. Reforming silver coinage alone would not eliminate the bullion premium.
distilled: Silver bullion stays above the Mint price not because of export rules, as Locke claimed, but because silver is undervalued relative to gold in English coinage.
notes: Smith vs. Locke on the silver premium. Locke's export-permission theory refuted by the gold-bullion counterexample. The deeper cause is the bimetallic ratio mismatch. Gold-regulation theory confirmed. Cross-reference with 1.5.33 on the ratio problem and 1.5.35 on reform implications.

refashioned: If silver coin were restored to its full standard weight while gold remained as it is, a guinea would probably exchange for more silver in coin than it could purchase in bullion. Since full-weight silver coin would contain its standard metal content, there would be a profit in melting it down, selling the bullion for gold coin, and then exchanging that gold for silver coin to melt again. Only an adjustment in the official gold-silver ratio could prevent this cycle.
elegant: If silver coin were restored to full weight under the current ratio, a guinea would buy more silver in coin than in bullion -- creating a profit loop of melting silver coin, selling bullion for gold, and converting gold back to silver coin. Only adjusting the official ratio could prevent this.
summary: Smith warns that restoring silver coin to full weight without adjusting the gold-silver ratio would create profitable arbitrage: melting full-weight silver coins into bullion, trading for gold, and converting back to silver coins for repeated melting.
distilled: Restoring silver coinage without adjusting the gold-silver ratio would create a destructive arbitrage loop of melting and recoining.
notes: Arbitrage and Gresham's Law in action. Overvalued gold drives undervalued silver out of circulation. The melting loop is a specific mechanism of Gresham's Law. Only ratio adjustment (not unilateral reform) solves the bimetallic problem. Cross-reference with 1.5.33-1.5.34.

refashioned: The problem might be less severe if silver were rated in coinage as much above its proper gold ratio as it is currently rated below it, provided silver was simultaneously limited as legal tender to making change for a guinea -- just as copper is limited to making change for a shilling. No creditor could then be cheated by overvalued silver, just as none is currently cheated by overvalued copper. Only bankers would suffer, since they sometimes delay payments during bank runs by paying in sixpences. This regulation would force them to keep larger cash reserves -- inconvenient for them, but providing greater security for their creditors.
elegant: One solution: overvalue silver and limit its legal tender to small change, as copper is limited now. Creditors would be protected; only bankers would suffer, losing their ability to delay payments during runs by paying in sixpences. They would need larger reserves -- inconvenient for them but more secure for depositors.
summary: Smith proposes overvaluing silver while restricting its legal tender to small transactions, mirroring copper's status. This would protect creditors while forcing bankers to maintain larger cash reserves, eliminating their practice of stalling during bank runs with sixpence payments.
distilled: Overvaluing silver but limiting its legal tender to small change would protect creditors and force bankers to hold larger reserves.
notes: Monetary reform proposal -- limit silver's legal tender scope. Anticipates the subsidiary coinage concept. The bank-run-in-sixpences tactic reveals contemporary banking practices. Larger reserves as a public good vs. private cost to bankers. Cross-reference with 1.5.35 on the problem and 1.5.37 on alternative solutions.

refashioned: The Mint price of gold -- three pounds seventeen shillings tenpence halfpenny -- certainly contains no more than an ounce of standard gold, and one might think it should not purchase more than an ounce of bullion. But coined gold is more convenient than bullion, and although English coinage is technically free, gold brought to the Mint cannot be returned as coin for several weeks -- in the current backlog, several months. This delay functions as a small implicit duty, making gold coin somewhat more valuable than the same weight of bullion. If silver were rated at its proper proportion to gold in English coinage, silver bullion would probably fall below the Mint price even without reforming the worn silver coins, since even degraded silver coin's value would be supported by its exchangeability for excellent gold coin.
elegant: Gold coin exceeds gold bullion's value despite containing the same metal because coin is more convenient and the Mint's delay in returning coined gold acts as an implicit duty. If silver's coin ratio were corrected, silver bullion would likely fall below the Mint price even without reforming worn silver coins -- because degraded silver's value is supported by its exchangeability for sound gold.
summary: Smith explains why gold coin trades above bullion value: convenience plus the Mint's processing delay create an implicit premium. He argues that simply correcting the silver-gold ratio would solve the silver premium problem, as silver coin's value would be anchored by sound gold coin.
distilled: Gold coin exceeds bullion value due to convenience and Mint delays; correcting the silver-gold ratio would fix the silver premium without reforming silver coins.
notes: Convenience yield and implicit seignorage through delay. The Mint's backlog as a de facto duty. The ratio-correction solution is simpler than silver recoinage. Cross-reference with 1.5.30 on the Mint price, 1.5.35-1.5.36 on reform alternatives.

refashioned: A small seignorage or duty on the coinage of both gold and silver would probably increase the premium of coined metal over bullion even further. The coinage would add value to the metal in proportion to the duty, just as craftsmanship adds value to silverware in proportion to the maker's fee. This premium of coin over bullion would discourage both melting coins down and exporting them. If coins were exported in an emergency, most would naturally return, since they could only be sold abroad at their bullion weight but would buy more than that weight at home -- creating a profit in bringing them back. In France, a seignorage of about eight percent is charged on coinage, and French coins, when exported, are said to return home of their own accord.
elegant: A small seignorage on coinage would increase coin's premium over bullion, discouraging both melting and export. Coin exported in emergencies would return naturally -- selling abroad only at bullion weight but buying more at home. France charges about 8% seignorage, and its exported coins reportedly return spontaneously.
summary: Smith argues that a small coinage duty (seignorage) would create a permanent premium of coin over bullion, preventing destructive melting and export. He cites France's 8% seignorage as evidence that coins return naturally when their domestic value exceeds their bullion export value.
distilled: A small seignorage on coinage would prevent coin melting and export by creating a permanent premium of coin over bullion, as demonstrated by French practice.
notes: Seignorage as monetary policy tool. The self-correcting export mechanism: coins return when domestic value exceeds foreign bullion value. France's 8% seignorage as empirical evidence. This anticipates modern discussions of currency premiums and capital controls. Cross-reference with 1.5.37 on the implicit Mint delay premium.

refashioned: The occasional fluctuations in the market price of gold and silver bullion arise from the same causes as fluctuations in other commodities. The constant loss of these metals -- through shipwrecks and land accidents, through gilding, plating, lace, embroidery, the wearing down of coins, and the wear of silverware -- requires countries without their own mines to continually import bullion to replace what is lost and consumed. Merchant importers, like all merchants, try to match their imports to what they expect the immediate demand to be. Despite their best efforts, they sometimes import too much and sometimes too little. When they import more than is needed, rather than bear the cost and risk of re-exporting it, they sometimes sell the surplus below the ordinary price. When they import less than is needed, they get more than the ordinary price. But when, despite all these short-term fluctuations, the market price of gold or silver bullion remains steadily above or below the mint price for several years running, we can be sure this persistent gap is caused by something in the condition of the coinage itself -- something that makes a given quantity of coin worth more or less than the precise quantity of bullion it is supposed to contain. A steady, constant effect implies a steady, constant cause.
elegant: Bullion prices fluctuate for the same reasons as any commodity: importers sometimes overshoot or undershoot demand, selling below the ordinary price when they import too much and above it when they import too little. But when bullion prices stay persistently above or below the official mint price for years running, the cause is not normal supply variation -- it is a systematic defect in the coinage itself, where coins contain more or less pure metal than their standard requires. A steady, constant deviation in price implies a steady, constant cause.
summary: Short-term bullion price fluctuations reflect normal supply and demand imbalances among importers. Persistent deviations from the mint price, however, signal a systematic problem with the coinage -- coins containing more or less precious metal than their official standard.
distilled: Temporary bullion price swings reflect import imbalances, but persistent deviations from the mint price reveal defects in the coinage itself.
notes: Bullion market dynamics -- mint price vs. market price -- coin degradation and debasement -- supply/demand framework applied to precious metals -- cross-ref 1.5.40 on coin accuracy as measure of value

refashioned: The money of any country is a more or less accurate measure of value depending on how closely the circulating coins match their official standard -- that is, whether they contain the precise quantity of pure gold or silver they are supposed to contain. If, for example, forty-four and a half guineas in England contained exactly one pound weight of standard gold (eleven ounces of fine gold and one ounce of alloy), the gold coinage would be as accurate a measure of value as the nature of money permits. But if, through rubbing and wearing, forty-four and a half guineas generally contain less than a pound of standard gold -- with some coins more worn than others -- then this measure of value becomes subject to the same kind of uncertainty as any imprecise weight or measure. Since weights and measures rarely match their standard exactly, merchants adjust their prices not according to what the measures should be, but according to what experience shows they actually are. In the same way, when the coinage is degraded, the price of goods adjusts not to the quantity of pure metal the coins ought to contain, but to what they actually do contain.
