elegant: Money measures value accurately only when coins match their official standard of precious metal content. When coins are worn down through years of circulation -- some more than others -- money becomes as unreliable a measure as any imprecise weight or scale. Just as merchants adjust for imprecise weights and measures by pricing according to what these instruments actually weigh rather than what they should, so they adjust for degraded coinage by pricing goods not according to what the coins ought to contain in pure metal, but according to what experience shows they actually do contain.
summary: A country's money is an accurate measure of value only insofar as its coins contain the correct amount of precious metal. When coins degrade through wear, merchants adjust prices based on actual metal content rather than the official standard.
distilled: Money measures value accurately only when coins match their official precious metal standard; worn coinage forces merchants to price goods by actual metal content.
notes: Coinage degradation -- money as unit of measurement -- gap between nominal and real value of currency -- merchant price adjustment behavior -- cross-ref 1.5.39 on mint price deviations

refashioned: When I refer to the money price of goods, I always mean the quantity of pure gold or silver for which they are sold, regardless of the coin's name or denomination. Six shillings and eightpence in the time of Edward I, for example, I consider the same money price as one pound sterling today, because both contained, as nearly as we can determine, the same quantity of pure silver.
elegant: By "money price," I always mean the quantity of pure gold or silver exchanged -- not the coin's name. Six shillings eightpence under Edward I equals one pound sterling today because both contain the same weight of pure silver.
summary: Smith defines "money price" as the actual quantity of pure precious metal exchanged, not the nominal denomination of the coins, allowing valid comparisons across different eras.
distilled: The true money price of goods is measured by the quantity of pure metal exchanged, not by the changing names of coins.
notes: Definitional clarity on money price -- nominal vs. real monetary comparison -- historical currency equivalence -- Edward I coinage reference -- foundation for cross-era price analysis

refashioned: In the early, primitive state of society -- before capital has been accumulated and land has been claimed as private property -- the only basis for exchanging one thing for another is the relative amount of labor required to obtain each. If, among a nation of hunters, killing a beaver typically takes twice the labor of killing a deer, then one beaver should naturally trade for two deer. Whatever normally requires two days' or two hours' labor should be worth double what normally requires one day's or one hour's labor.
elegant: Before capital accumulation and land ownership, the ratio of labor required to produce different goods is the sole basis for exchange. If a beaver takes twice the labor of a deer, one beaver trades for two deer.
summary: In primitive society without accumulated capital or private land, the exchange value of goods is determined solely by the relative labor required to produce them.
distilled: Before capital and land ownership, goods exchange in proportion to the labor required to produce them.
notes: Labor theory of value in its simplest form -- pre-capitalist exchange -- the beaver-deer example -- foundation for Ch. 1.6 on component parts of price -- cross-ref 1.6.3 on profit emerging with capital accumulation

refashioned: If one type of labor is more physically demanding than another, a natural allowance will be made for this greater hardship, so that one hour's work at the harder task may trade for two hours' work at the easier one. Similarly, if a type of labor requires exceptional skill or ingenuity, the respect people have for such talents naturally gives the product a higher value than the time spent would otherwise justify. Such talents are usually acquired only through long training, and their higher product value often represents nothing more than fair compensation for the time and effort invested in developing them. In advanced societies, these adjustments for superior hardship and skill are routinely built into wage differences, and something similar must have existed even in the earliest periods of human society.
elegant: Exchange ratios adjust for differences in hardship and skill. Harder labor commands a premium over easier work; skilled labor is valued above what time alone would warrant, compensating for the years of training required to acquire such expertise. These adjustments for hardship and skill, formalized as wage differentials in advanced societies, likely existed in some form even in the earliest human communities.
summary: Even in primitive exchange, allowances are made for differences in the difficulty and skill required by different types of labor. These adjustments for hardship and expertise are formalized as wage differentials in advanced societies.
distilled: Labor exchange ratios naturally adjust to compensate for greater hardship and the skill acquired through long training.
notes: Compensating differentials in wages -- skill premium and training investment -- labor quality vs. labor quantity -- proto-human capital theory -- cross-ref 1.6.1 on basic labor exchange

refashioned: In this primitive state, the entire product of labor belongs to the laborer, and the amount of labor typically needed to produce a good is the only factor determining how much labor it can buy or trade for. But as soon as capital accumulates in the hands of certain individuals, some of them will naturally use it to employ industrious workers -- supplying them with materials and subsistence in order to profit from selling what they produce. When the finished product is exchanged for money, labor, or other goods, something beyond the cost of materials and wages must be paid as profit to the entrepreneur who risked his capital in the venture. The value that workers add to the materials therefore splits into two parts: one pays their wages, the other pays the employer's profit on the total capital he advanced for both materials and wages. He would have no reason to employ workers unless he expected the sale of their output to return more than his costs, and no reason to invest a large amount rather than a small one unless profits were proportional to the capital invested.
elegant: In primitive society, the worker keeps everything he produces, and labor alone determines exchange value. But once capital accumulates, owners employ workers and advance materials and wages, expecting profit from the sale of the output. The value workers add to materials thus splits into two parts: wages for the workers and profit for the employer. Without the expectation of profit proportional to the capital invested, there would be no incentive to employ workers or to invest a larger sum rather than a smaller one.
summary: Before capital accumulation, workers keep their full output and labor alone governs exchange. Once capital enters the picture, the value added by workers divides into wages and profit -- the return to the capitalist who risked his investment in materials and subsistence.
distilled: Capital accumulation splits the value workers add into two components -- wages for the worker and profit for the capitalist who advanced the investment.
notes: Emergence of profit as a component of price -- capital accumulation as turning point -- the entrepreneur's risk and return -- profit proportional to capital invested -- cross-ref 1.6.1 on pre-capital exchange, 1.6.5 on worker no longer keeping full product

refashioned: One might suppose that profits on capital are simply wages by another name -- payment for the labor of managing and directing the business. But profits are fundamentally different from management wages. They are governed by entirely different principles and bear no proportion to the quantity, difficulty, or ingenuity of management work. Profits are determined entirely by the size of the capital employed, rising and falling in proportion to it. Consider two factories, each employing twenty workers at fifteen pounds per year, costing three hundred pounds in wages annually. In the first factory, the raw materials cost seven hundred pounds, so the total capital employed is one thousand pounds. In the second, finer materials cost seven thousand pounds, so the total capital is seven thousand three hundred pounds. At a standard annual profit rate of ten percent, the first factory owner expects about one hundred pounds in profit, while the second expects about seven hundred and thirty. Yet the actual labor of inspecting and directing both factories may be virtually the same -- or very nearly so. In many large enterprises, nearly all management work is delegated to a principal clerk, whose salary properly reflects the value of this supervisory labor. Though his wages account for his skill and the trust placed in him, they never bear any regular proportion to the capital he manages. And the owner of that capital, though thus relieved of nearly all management labor, still expects his profit to be regularly proportional to his capital. In the price of commodities, therefore, profits on capital constitute a component part entirely distinct from the wages of labor, governed by altogether different principles.
elegant: Profits are not disguised management wages. They are governed entirely by the size of capital invested, not by the effort of overseeing operations. Consider two factories with identical workforces of twenty men each: if one requires a thousand pounds in capital and the other seven thousand three hundred, their profits will differ sevenfold -- even though the management effort is identical or nearly so. In many large enterprises, the management work is delegated entirely to a principal clerk whose salary reflects supervisory labor. The owner, though discharged from nearly all labor of direction, still expects his profit to track his capital investment. Profit is therefore a fundamentally different component of price from the wages of labor, regulated by altogether different principles.
summary: Smith distinguishes profit from the wages of management. Profits are proportional to the capital employed, not to the quantity or difficulty of supervisory labor, as demonstrated by comparing factories with equal workforces but different capital requirements.
distilled: Profits are determined by the size of capital invested, not by the effort of management, making them fundamentally distinct from wages.
notes: Profit vs. wages of management -- profit proportional to capital, not labor -- the two-factory example -- principal clerk as proxy for management labor value -- key distinction in price theory -- cross-ref 1.6.3, 1.6.5

refashioned: Once capital is involved, the entire product of labor no longer belongs to the laborer. In most cases, he must share it with the owner of the capital that employs him. Nor is the quantity of labor used to produce a commodity the only thing that determines its exchange value. An additional amount must be included to cover the profits on the capital that advanced the wages and supplied the materials.
elegant: With capital in the picture, workers no longer keep their full product -- they must share it with the capital owner. Exchange value now reflects not just labor, but also the profit due on the capital that financed wages and materials.
summary: Once employers advance capital for wages and materials, workers must share their output. Exchange value now includes both labor costs and a return on the capital invested.
distilled: Capital ownership means workers share their product with employers, and exchange value must include profit on the capital advanced.
notes: Worker's loss of full product -- profit as necessary component of exchange value -- capital's claim on output -- cross-ref 1.6.3 on the split into wages and profit, 1.6.6 on rent as third component

refashioned: Once all the land in a country becomes private property, landlords -- like everyone else -- want to reap where they have not sown, demanding rent even for the land's natural produce. The wood of the forest, the grass of the field, and all the natural fruits of the earth -- which, when land was held in common, cost the laborer nothing but the effort of gathering -- now carry an additional price. The laborer must pay for permission to gather them and must surrender a portion of what his labor collects or produces to the landlord. This portion, or its equivalent price, constitutes the rent of land. In the price of most commodities, rent forms a third component part alongside wages and profit.
elegant: Once land becomes private property, landlords demand rent even for nature's bounty -- resources that once cost only the labor of gathering. The worker must now pay for permission to use the land and surrender part of his product. Rent thus becomes the third component of price, alongside wages and profit.
summary: Private land ownership introduces rent as the third component of price. Landlords demand payment even for natural resources that previously cost only the labor of gathering, extracting a share of every worker's output.
distilled: Private land ownership creates rent -- the third component of price -- as landlords claim a share of output for the mere use of their property.
notes: Rent as third price component -- 'reap where they never sowed' -- landlord's unearned claim -- transition from common to private land -- completes the wages-profit-rent triad -- cross-ref 1.6.3 (profit), 1.6.8 (all three combined)

refashioned: The real value of all the different components of price -- wages, profit, and rent -- is measured by the quantity of labor each can purchase or command. Labor measures the value not only of the portion of price that resolves into wages, but also of the portions that resolve into rent and profit.
elegant: The real value of all three components of price -- wages, profit, and rent -- is ultimately measured by the quantity of labor each can command.
summary: Labor serves as the universal measure of real value for all three components of price: wages, profit, and rent alike.
distilled: The real value of wages, profit, and rent is each measured by the quantity of labor it can command.
notes: Labor as universal value measure -- applies to all price components equally -- cross-ref 1.5 on labor as real measure of value -- unifying principle for the three revenue types

refashioned: In every society, the price of every commodity ultimately breaks down into one, two, or all three of these parts -- wages, profit, and rent. In every advanced society, all three typically enter as components into the price of most goods. Take the price of corn as an example. One part pays the landlord's rent, another pays the wages and upkeep of the laborers and working animals used to produce it, and a third pays the farmer's profit. These three parts seem to make up the entire price of corn, either directly or indirectly. One might think a fourth part is needed to replace the farmer's capital -- to compensate for the wear and tear of his working animals and farming equipment. But the price of any piece of farm equipment, such as a working horse, is itself composed of the same three parts: the rent of the land where it was raised, the labor of tending and raising it, and the profits of the farmer who advanced both that rent and those wages. So even though the price of corn must cover equipment costs as well as ongoing expenses, the whole price still ultimately resolves into the same three parts: rent, labor, and profit.
elegant: Every commodity's price ultimately resolves into wages, profit, rent, or some combination of the three. In corn's price, one part pays rent, another pays labor, and a third pays profit. Even the apparent fourth element -- replacement of capital equipment like working horses -- itself breaks down into the same three components when traced to its origin, since the horse was raised on rented land with hired labor and a farmer's capital. The decomposition is recursive and complete.
summary: The price of every commodity ultimately consists of wages, profit, and rent. Even capital replacement costs, which might seem like a fourth component, themselves decompose into the same three parts when traced to their origins.
distilled: Every price ultimately resolves into wages, profit, and rent -- even the cost of replacing capital equipment breaks down into these same three components.
notes: The three-component price theory -- recursive decomposition of capital costs -- the corn price example -- working horse as capital good that itself resolves into wages, profit, rent -- cross-ref 1.6.6 (rent), 1.6.9 (further price decomposition)

refashioned: In the price of flour, we must add to the price of the corn the miller's profits and his workers' wages. In the price of bread, we must add the baker's profits and his workers' wages. And in the price of both, we must include the labor of transporting the corn from the farmer to the miller and from the miller to the baker, together with the profits of those who advanced the wages for that transport labor.
elegant: Each stage of processing adds new layers of wages and profit. Flour's price includes the miller's profit and wages; bread adds the baker's. Transport costs at every stage contribute further wages and profits.
summary: At each stage of production -- milling, baking, transporting -- new wages and profits are added to the commodity's price, building up the final cost layer by layer.
distilled: Each stage of production adds its own layer of wages and profit to the commodity's final price.
notes: Value chain analysis -- cumulative price formation through production stages -- transport as value-adding activity -- vertical integration of wages and profit -- cross-ref 1.6.8 on price decomposition

refashioned: The price of flax resolves into the same three parts as corn. In the price of linen, we must add the wages of the flax-dresser, the spinner, the weaver, the bleacher, and others, together with the profits of their respective employers. As a commodity becomes more manufactured, the share of its price consisting of wages and profit grows larger relative to the share consisting of rent. In the progression of manufacturing, not only does the number of profit-takers increase, but each successive profit is larger than the one before, because the capital from which it derives must always be greater. The capital that employs the weavers, for example, must be larger than the capital that employs the spinners, because it must not only replace the spinners' capital with its profits but also pay the weavers' wages. And profits always bear some proportion to the capital invested.
elegant: As goods become more manufactured, wages and profit take up an ever-larger share of price relative to rent. Each stage of production requires more capital than the last -- the weaver's employer must cover the spinner's capital plus profits plus the weaver's wages -- so both the number and size of profit margins grow through the production chain.
summary: More manufacturing stages mean a larger share of the final price goes to wages and profit rather than rent. Each successive stage requires greater capital, making each profit layer larger than the one before.
distilled: As goods pass through more stages of manufacturing, the share of price going to wages and profit grows while rent's share shrinks, with each stage requiring larger capital and yielding larger profits.
notes: Manufacturing value chain -- escalating capital requirements -- compounding profits through production stages -- rent's declining share in manufactured goods -- flax-to-linen example -- cross-ref 1.6.8 on corn price decomposition

refashioned: Even in the most advanced societies, there are always some commodities whose price consists of only two parts -- wages and profit -- and a still smaller number whose price consists entirely of wages alone. In the price of sea fish, for example, one part pays the fisherman's labor and the other pays the profit on the capital employed in the fishery. Rent rarely enters into it, though it sometimes does, as I will discuss later. River fisheries are different, at least across most of Europe. A salmon fishery pays a rent, and that rent -- though it cannot properly be called the rent of land -- forms part of the salmon's price alongside wages and profit. In some parts of Scotland, a few poor people earn their living by gathering the small, colorful stones known as Scotch pebbles from the seashore. The price paid to them by the stone-cutter is entirely wages; neither rent nor profit forms any part of it.
elegant: Not all prices contain all three components. Sea fish typically involves only wages and profit, since rent rarely enters in. A still simpler case exists: Scotch pebbles gathered from the seashore are priced at pure wages alone, with no rent or profit component at all. River fisheries, by contrast, typically include all three, since salmon fisheries pay rent for their waters alongside the usual wages and profit.
summary: Not all prices contain all three components. Sea fish typically involves only wages and profit; Scotch pebbles gathered from the shore involve only wages. River fisheries, however, include rent alongside wages and profit.
distilled: Some prices contain only wages and profit, and a few consist of wages alone, depending on whether capital and land are involved in production.
notes: Exceptions to three-component pricing -- sea fisheries (wages + profit) -- Scotch pebbles (wages only) -- river fisheries include rent -- salmon fishery rent is not land rent -- cross-ref 1.6.8 on standard three-part decomposition

refashioned: But the entire price of any commodity must still ultimately resolve into one, two, or all three of these parts. Whatever remains after paying the rent of the land and the total cost of the labor employed in producing, manufacturing, and bringing it to market must necessarily represent profit to someone. Just as the price of every individual commodity resolves into some combination of wages, profit, and rent, so does the aggregate price of all commodities composing the entire annual output of every country's labor. The whole of what is annually collected or produced by a nation's workers -- or equivalently, the whole price of that output -- is originally distributed among the country's inhabitants either as the wages of their labor, the profits of their capital, or the rent of their land. Wages, profit, and rent are therefore the three original sources of all revenue and of all exchangeable value. Every other form of revenue is ultimately derived from one or another of these three.
elegant: Every commodity's price, and therefore the entire annual output of a nation, ultimately resolves into wages, profit, and rent. Whatever remains in any price after paying for land and labor is necessarily profit to someone. The whole annual product of every country's labor is distributed among its inhabitants through these same three channels. Wages, profit, and rent are the original sources of all revenue and all exchangeable value -- every other income is ultimately derived from them.
summary: All prices resolve into wages, profit, and rent. The entire annual output of a nation is distributed among its people through these same three channels, which are the original sources of all revenue and exchangeable value.
distilled: Wages, profit, and rent are the three original sources of all revenue and all exchangeable value, both for individual commodities and for a nation's entire output.
notes: Universal price decomposition -- national income accounting in embryo -- three sources of all revenue -- GDP as sum of wages + profits + rents -- cross-ref 1.6.8, 1.6.13 on derivative revenues

refashioned: Anyone who derives revenue from a fund that is their own must draw it from their labor, their capital, or their land. Revenue from labor is called wages. Revenue from capital, when managed by the owner, is called profit. Revenue from capital lent to another is called interest -- the compensation the borrower pays the lender for the opportunity to make profit with the money. Part of the profit naturally belongs to the borrower, who bears the risk and does the work of investing it, and part to the lender, who provides the opportunity. Interest is always a derivative form of revenue: if it is not paid from the profit generated by using the money, it must come from some other source -- unless the borrower is a spendthrift who takes on new debt to pay the interest on the old. Revenue derived entirely from land is called rent and belongs to the landlord. The farmer's revenue comes partly from his labor and partly from his capital; for him, land is merely the instrument that enables him to earn his wages and his profits. All taxes, and all the government revenues built upon them -- salaries, pensions, and annuities of every kind -- are ultimately derived from one of these three original sources and are paid, directly or indirectly, from the wages of labor, the profits of capital, or the rent of land.
elegant: All personal revenue comes from three sources: wages from one's own labor, profit from capital one manages, or rent from one's land. Interest is derivative -- the lender's share of profit generated by the borrower who bears the risk and does the work. A farmer earns both wages and profit, using land merely as his instrument. Revenue from land itself is rent, belonging to the landlord. All taxes and all government revenues built upon them -- salaries, pensions, annuities of every kind -- ultimately trace back to one of these three original sources of income, paid either directly or indirectly from wages, profit, or rent.
summary: Smith classifies all revenue into three original sources: wages from labor, profit from self-managed capital, and rent from land. Interest is derivative, being the lender's share of profit. All taxes and government expenditures ultimately draw from these same three streams.
distilled: All revenue derives from three original sources -- wages, profit, and rent -- with interest being a derivative form of profit and all taxation ultimately drawing from these same streams.
notes: Complete taxonomy of revenue types -- interest as derivative of profit -- farmer earns wages + profit (land as instrument) -- government revenue as derivative of wages, profit, rent -- all taxes trace to three sources -- cross-ref 1.6.12, 1.6.14 on confusion between categories

refashioned: When these three types of revenue belong to different people, they are easily distinguished. But when they belong to the same person, they are often confused with one another, at least in everyday language. A gentleman who farms part of his own estate should, after paying cultivation costs, earn both the landlord's rent and the farmer's profit. But he is likely to call his entire gain "profit," thus confusing rent with profit. Most North American and West Indian planters are in this situation. They farm their own estates, and so we rarely hear of a plantation's rent, but frequently of its profit.
elegant: When wages, profit, and rent go to different people, they are easily told apart. When the same person receives all three -- as when a gentleman farms his own estate -- they are commonly lumped together as 'profit,' confusing rent with the return on capital. This is typical of American and West Indian planters.
summary: The three types of revenue are easily distinguished when they go to different people, but are commonly confused when one person receives multiple types. A landowner who farms his own estate typically calls his entire gain 'profit,' blurring the line between rent and the return on capital.
distilled: When one person receives multiple types of revenue -- as when a landowner farms his own estate -- rent, profit, and wages are easily confused in common language.
notes: Confusion of revenue categories -- owner-operator conflation -- plantation economics -- rent disguised as profit -- importance of analytical clarity in economics -- cross-ref 1.6.15-1.6.17 for more examples

refashioned: Ordinary farmers rarely hire an overseer to manage the general operations of their farm. They typically do a great deal of the physical work themselves -- ploughing, harrowing, and so on. What remains of the harvest after paying the rent should not only replace their invested capital with its ordinary profit but also pay them the wages they are owed, both as laborers and as managers. Yet whatever is left after paying rent and maintaining the capital stock is simply called "profit." But wages clearly form part of this amount. By doing the work himself and saving the cost of hired labor, the farmer necessarily earns those wages. In this case, wages are confused with profit.
elegant: Farmers who work their own land earn wages for their labor, management fees for overseeing, and profit on their capital -- but they call it all 'profit.' By working the land themselves, they save on hired labor, effectively earning wages that get lumped in with their return on capital.
summary: Working farmers earn wages for their own labor, a management salary, and profit on capital, but they lump everything together as 'profit.' The wages they save by doing their own work are absorbed into what appears to be a higher profit margin.
distilled: When farmers work their own land, the wages they earn through their own labor become invisible, absorbed into what is loosely called profit.
notes: Wages disguised as profit -- self-employed farmer conflation -- implicit wages of owner-operators -- analytical decomposition of apparent profit -- cross-ref 1.6.14, 1.6.16

refashioned: An independent manufacturer who has enough capital to buy his own materials and support himself until he can sell his finished goods should earn both the wages a journeyman would receive working under a master and the profit that master would make from selling the journeyman's work. Yet his entire gain is commonly called profit, and wages are once again confused with profit.
elegant: An independent craftsman with his own capital earns both a worker's wages and a master's profit, but calls it all 'profit' -- another case of wages being absorbed into the return on capital.
summary: Independent manufacturers who finance their own work earn both wages and profit, but the two are conflated under the single label of 'profit.'
distilled: When an independent manufacturer is both worker and employer, his wages disappear into what is simply called profit.
notes: Self-employed craftsman conflation -- wages and profit merged -- independent manufacturer economics -- cross-ref 1.6.14-1.6.15 on similar confusions, 1.6.17 on all three merged

refashioned: A gardener who cultivates his own garden with his own hands combines in one person the three distinct roles of landlord, farmer, and laborer. His produce should therefore pay him the rent of the first, the profit of the second, and the wages of the third. Yet the whole is commonly considered simply as the earnings of his labor. In this case, both rent and profit are confused with wages.
elegant: A self-employed gardener is simultaneously landlord, farmer, and laborer -- earning rent, profit, and wages. Yet all three are lumped together as 'earnings from labor,' the most complete version of this analytical confusion.
summary: A gardener working his own land unites the roles of landlord, farmer, and laborer, but all three types of revenue are conflated as 'earnings of labor.'
distilled: When a gardener owns the land, supplies the capital, and does the work himself, rent, profit, and wages all collapse into a single undifferentiated income.
notes: Maximum conflation of all three revenue types -- the gardener example -- all three roles in one person -- analytical vs. colloquial understanding of income -- completes the series from 1.6.14-1.6.17

refashioned: In a civilized country, very few commodities derive their exchange value from labor alone; rent and profit contribute heavily to the value of most goods. As a result, the annual output of a nation's labor is always sufficient to purchase or command a much larger quantity of labor than was actually used to produce it. If a society were to employ all the labor its annual output could purchase, the quantity of labor would grow enormously each year, and each year's output would be vastly more valuable than the last. But no country actually employs its entire annual output in maintaining productive workers. The idle consume a large share everywhere. Depending on how the output is divided between the industrious and the idle, the nation's ordinary wealth must either increase, decrease, or stay the same from year to year.
elegant: Since rent and profit inflate most prices beyond the labor they embody, a nation's output can always command more labor than it took to produce. If all output were reinvested in employing workers, growth would compound rapidly. But the idle consume much of it, and the balance between productive and unproductive consumption determines whether national wealth grows, shrinks, or stagnates.
summary: Because rent and profit are built into most prices, a nation's annual output can command more labor than produced it, creating potential for compounding growth. Whether that potential is realized depends on how much output goes to productive employment versus idle consumption.
distilled: A nation's output can always command more labor than produced it, but growth depends on how much is reinvested productively versus consumed by the idle.
notes: Potential for compounding growth -- productive vs. unproductive consumption -- the idle as drag on growth -- national wealth accumulation dynamics -- annual output exceeds labor input in value -- cross-ref 1.6.12 on national income, Book II on productive vs. unproductive labor

refashioned: In every society or locality, there is an ordinary or average rate of both wages and profit for each type of employment of labor and capital. This rate is naturally determined partly by the general conditions of the society -- its wealth or poverty, whether it is growing, stagnant, or declining -- and partly by the particular nature of each occupation.
elegant: Every society has average rates of wages and profit for each occupation, shaped by the society's overall economic condition and by the specific nature of the work.
summary: Average wage and profit rates exist in every society, determined by the economy's general condition and the particular characteristics of each employment.
distilled: Every society has natural average rates of wages and profit shaped by its economic condition and the nature of each occupation.
notes: Introduction of natural rate concept -- wages and profit vary by occupation and economic condition -- foundation for natural price theory -- cross-ref 1.7.3 on natural price, 1.7.2 on natural rent rate

refashioned: There is likewise in every society or locality an ordinary or average rate of rent, determined partly by the general circumstances of the society or neighborhood where the land is located, and partly by the natural or improved fertility of the land. These ordinary or average rates may be called the natural rates of wages, profit, and rent, prevailing at a given time and place.
elegant: Every locality also has an average rent rate, shaped by local economic conditions and the land's fertility. These average rates of wages, profit, and rent are the natural rates for that time and place.
summary: An average rate of rent exists in every locality, determined by economic conditions and land fertility. Together with average wages and profit, these constitute the natural rates for a given time and place.
distilled: The natural rates of wages, profit, and rent are the ordinary averages prevailing in a particular time and place.
notes: Natural rent rate defined -- natural rates as averages -- determined by local conditions and land quality -- completes the trio of natural rates -- cross-ref 1.7.1 on wages/profit, 1.7.3 on natural price

refashioned: When the price of a commodity is exactly enough to pay the rent of the land, the wages of the labor, and the profits of the capital used to produce, prepare, and bring it to market -- each at their natural rates -- that commodity is sold at what may be called its natural price.
elegant: A commodity sells at its natural price when the price exactly covers rent, wages, and profit at their natural rates -- no more, no less.
summary: The natural price of a commodity is the price that exactly covers rent, wages, and profit at their ordinary average rates.
distilled: The natural price is the price that exactly covers rent, wages, and profit at their prevailing average rates.
notes: Natural price defined -- sum of natural rates of rent + wages + profit -- equilibrium price concept -- foundational to market price theory -- cross-ref 1.7.4 on cost of production, 1.7.6 on market price

refashioned: At the natural price, the commodity is sold for precisely what it is worth -- for what it truly costs the person who brings it to market. In everyday language, the "prime cost" of a commodity does not include the seller's profit. But if he sells at a price that does not yield the ordinary rate of profit in his area, he is clearly losing on the trade, since he could have earned that profit by investing his capital elsewhere. His profit is his livelihood -- the fund from which he supports himself. Just as he advances wages to his workers while preparing and transporting goods to market, he effectively advances his own subsistence as well, which is proportional to the profit he can reasonably expect. Unless the goods yield him this profit, they have not truly repaid what they cost him.
elegant: At the natural price, a commodity sells for what it truly costs to bring to market -- including the seller's expected profit. If he earns less than the ordinary rate of profit, he is losing money, since he could earn that return investing elsewhere. Profit is his livelihood, just as wages are his workers'; both must be covered for the venture to repay its true cost.
summary: The natural price represents the true cost of bringing a commodity to market, including the seller's expected profit. Without the ordinary rate of profit, the seller is effectively taking a loss, since he could earn that return on his capital elsewhere.
distilled: A commodity's true cost includes the seller's expected profit, because anything less means he would have been better off investing his capital elsewhere.
notes: Profit as true cost of production -- opportunity cost concept -- profit as the seller's subsistence fund -- prime cost vs. true cost -- seller advances his own subsistence like workers' wages -- cross-ref 1.7.3 on natural price, 1.7.5 on minimum viable price

refashioned: Although the price that yields this profit is not always the lowest at which a dealer might occasionally sell his goods, it is the lowest at which he is likely to sell them over any sustained period -- at least where there is full freedom and he can change his trade whenever he chooses. The actual price at which any commodity commonly sells is called its market price. It may be above, below, or exactly equal to the natural price.
elegant: The natural price is the lowest sustainable selling price where there is free competition. Below it, the seller would eventually exit the trade. The actual selling price -- the market price -- may sit above, below, or right at this natural price.
summary: The natural price is the lowest price at which a dealer will sell over the long term under free competition. The market price -- what the commodity actually sells for -- may diverge from this natural price in either direction.
distilled: The natural price is the floor for sustainable selling; the market price is what goods actually sell for, and it may diverge from the natural price.
notes: Natural price as long-run sustainable minimum -- market price introduced -- freedom to exit trade as discipline -- natural vs. market price distinction -- cross-ref 1.7.3, 1.7.6 on determinants of market price

refashioned: The market price of any commodity is determined by the ratio between the quantity actually brought to market and the demand from those willing to pay its natural price -- that is, the full value of rent, labor, and profit needed to bring it there. These buyers may be called effectual demanders, and their demand the effectual demand, since it is sufficient to actually bring the commodity to market. Effectual demand differs from absolute demand. A very poor man might, in some sense, demand a coach and six horses -- he might wish to have one -- but his demand is not effectual, because the commodity would never be produced to satisfy it.
elegant: Market price is set by the ratio of supply to effectual demand -- the demand from buyers willing and able to pay the natural price. This differs from mere desire: a poor man may want a coach and six, but his demand is not effectual because it cannot bring the product to market.
summary: Market price depends on the balance between supply and effectual demand -- demand backed by willingness and ability to pay the full natural price. Mere desire without purchasing power is not effectual demand.
distilled: Market price is determined by the balance between supply and effectual demand -- demand backed by the ability to pay the natural price, not mere desire.
notes: Effectual demand defined -- effectual vs. absolute demand -- demand must be backed by purchasing power -- supply-demand ratio determines market price -- the coach-and-six example -- cross-ref 1.7.7-1.7.9 on supply-demand scenarios

refashioned: When the quantity of any commodity brought to market falls short of the effectual demand, not all those willing to pay the full value of rent, wages, and profit can be supplied with the quantity they want. Rather than go entirely without, some will offer to pay more. A competition among these eager buyers immediately begins, and the market price rises above the natural price. How far it rises above depends on two things: the severity of the shortfall and the degree to which the wealth and extravagant habits of the competitors intensify the eagerness of their bidding. Among competitors of equal wealth and similar tastes for luxury, the same shortfall will generally produce more or less intense competition depending on how important the commodity is to them personally. This is why the prices of life's necessities become exorbitant during the blockade of a town or during a famine.
elegant: When supply falls short of effectual demand, buyers who cannot all be satisfied compete against each other, bidding the market price above the natural price. The extent of the rise depends on the severity of the shortage and on how much the wealth and extravagant habits of the competitors intensify the competition. This explains why necessities become exorbitantly expensive during sieges and famines.
summary: When supply falls short of effectual demand, competition among buyers drives the market price above the natural price. The price increase reflects both the severity of the shortage and the intensity of buyers' need.
distilled: Supply shortages trigger buyer competition that pushes the market price above the natural price, with the increase proportional to the shortage's severity and the good's importance.
notes: Supply shortage drives price above natural price -- buyer competition mechanism -- wealth and luxury intensify bidding -- necessity goods most affected -- siege/famine price spikes -- cross-ref 1.7.8 on surplus, 1.7.9 on equilibrium

refashioned: When the quantity brought to market exceeds the effectual demand, it cannot all be sold to those willing to pay the natural price. Some must be sold to buyers willing to pay less, and the low price they offer drags down the price of the whole supply. The market price sinks below the natural price, with the extent of the decline depending on how much the surplus intensifies competition among sellers and how urgently they need to dispose of the goods. The same surplus causes a much greater price drop for perishable goods than for durable ones -- for oranges, for example, compared to old iron.
elegant: When supply exceeds effectual demand, sellers must accept lower prices to move their surplus, pushing the market price below the natural price. The decline is sharper when sellers are desperate to sell quickly and the goods are perishable. The same surplus causes a much greater price drop for oranges, which must be sold quickly, than for durable goods like old iron.
summary: When supply exceeds effectual demand, competition among sellers drives the market price below the natural price. Perishable goods experience sharper price drops than durable ones because sellers are more desperate to sell them quickly.
distilled: Surplus supply forces sellers to compete, driving market prices below the natural price, with perishable goods suffering the steepest drops.
notes: Supply surplus drives price below natural price -- seller competition mechanism -- perishable vs. durable goods price sensitivity -- urgency of disposal affects price decline -- oranges vs. old iron example -- cross-ref 1.7.7 on shortage, 1.7.9 on equilibrium

refashioned: When the quantity brought to market is just enough to supply the effectual demand and no more, the market price naturally settles at or very near the natural price. The entire supply can be sold at this price, and no more can be obtained for it. Competition among dealers forces them all to accept this price, but does not force them to accept less.
elegant: When supply exactly matches effectual demand, the market price naturally equals the natural price. The full supply sells at this price, and competition prevents any seller from charging more or being forced to accept less.
summary: When supply precisely equals effectual demand, the market price converges to the natural price -- sellers can sell everything but cannot charge above the going rate.
distilled: When supply exactly meets effectual demand, the market price settles at the natural price.
notes: Market equilibrium -- supply equals effectual demand -- market price equals natural price -- competition prevents price divergence in either direction -- cross-ref 1.7.7 (shortage), 1.7.8 (surplus), 1.7.13 (gravitational metaphor)

refashioned: The quantity of any commodity brought to market naturally adjusts itself to the effectual demand. It is in the interest of everyone who employs their land, labor, or capital in producing a commodity that the supply never exceeds the effectual demand. And it is in the interest of everyone else that the supply never falls short of it.
elegant: Supply naturally adjusts to effectual demand. Producers want to avoid surplus, and consumers want to avoid shortage -- both forces push supply toward the quantity the market actually demands.
summary: Supply naturally adjusts to match effectual demand, driven by producers' interest in avoiding surplus and consumers' interest in avoiding shortage.
distilled: The self-interest of both producers and consumers naturally drives supply toward the level of effectual demand.
notes: Self-regulating supply mechanism -- mutual interest in equilibrium -- producers avoid surplus, consumers avoid shortage -- invisible hand dynamics -- cross-ref 1.7.11-1.7.12 on adjustment mechanism

refashioned: If at any time supply exceeds effectual demand, one or more of the price components must fall below its natural rate. If it is rent that falls, landlords will withdraw some of their land from that use. If it is wages or profit that falls, workers or employers will withdraw some of their labor or capital from that line of business. Supply will soon shrink to no more than the effectual demand requires. All the component parts of the price will rise back to their natural rates, and the whole price will return to its natural level.
elegant: When supply exceeds demand and any price component falls below its natural rate, the affected parties -- landlords, workers, or capitalists -- withdraw resources. Supply contracts until it matches demand, and all price components return to their natural rates.
summary: When oversupply pushes any price component below its natural rate, the affected resource owners withdraw their land, labor, or capital. Supply contracts until equilibrium is restored.
distilled: Oversupply triggers resource withdrawal by those earning below-natural returns, contracting supply until the price returns to its natural level.
notes: Self-correcting surplus mechanism -- resource reallocation in response to below-natural returns -- landlords, laborers, and capitalists all respond to price signals -- cross-ref 1.7.10, 1.7.12 on opposite scenario

refashioned: Conversely, if supply at any time falls short of effectual demand, one or more components of the price must rise above its natural rate. If it is rent, other landlords will prepare more land for producing that commodity. If it is wages or profit, other workers and investors will be drawn to employ more labor and capital in preparing and bringing it to market. Supply will soon expand to meet the effectual demand. All the price components will sink back to their natural rates, and the whole price to its natural level.
elegant: When supply falls short and any price component rises above its natural rate, new resources flow in -- more land, labor, and capital enter the market. Supply expands until demand is met and all price components return to their natural rates.
summary: Undersupply raises price components above their natural rates, attracting new land, labor, and capital into the market until supply expands to meet demand and prices normalize.
distilled: Undersupply attracts new resources into production, expanding supply until the price returns to its natural level.
notes: Self-correcting shortage mechanism -- above-natural returns attract new entrants -- resource inflow restores equilibrium -- symmetric with 1.7.11 on surplus -- cross-ref 1.7.13 on gravitational metaphor

refashioned: The natural price is, as it were, the central price toward which all commodity prices are continually gravitating. Various accidents may sometimes hold them well above it, and sometimes push them below it. But whatever obstacles prevent them from settling at this center of balance and stability, they are always tending toward it.
elegant: The natural price is the gravitational center toward which all market prices are constantly pulled. Disruptions may push prices above or below it, but the tendency toward equilibrium is relentless.
summary: The natural price acts as a gravitational center for market prices. Despite temporary disruptions in either direction, prices are always pulled back toward this equilibrium point.
distilled: The natural price is the gravitational center toward which all market prices constantly tend.
notes: Gravitational metaphor for price equilibrium -- natural price as center of repose -- one of Smith's most famous analogies -- anticipates general equilibrium theory -- cross-ref 1.7.11-1.7.12 on adjustment mechanisms

refashioned: The total amount of labor employed annually to bring any commodity to market naturally adjusts itself to the effectual demand, always aiming to supply exactly the needed quantity and no more. But in some types of work, the same amount of labor produces very different quantities in different years, while in others it produces the same amount, or very nearly so, every year. The same number of farm workers will produce very different quantities of corn, wine, oil, and hops from year to year. But the same number of spinners or weavers will produce roughly the same quantity of linen and woollen cloth every year. In agriculture, therefore, only the average output can be matched to the effectual demand. Since actual output often exceeds or falls short of the average by a wide margin, the quantity reaching market will frequently be well above or well below what effectual demand requires. Even if demand stays perfectly constant, the market price of agricultural goods will therefore be subject to large fluctuations, sometimes falling far below and sometimes rising far above the natural price. In manufacturing, by contrast, where equal labor consistently produces equal output, supply can be matched far more precisely to effectual demand. As long as demand remains the same, the market price will tend to stay at or very close to the natural price. Everyone knows from experience that the price of linen and woollen cloth is far more stable than the price of corn. The price of manufactured goods varies only with changes in demand, while the price of agricultural products varies both with demand and with the much larger and more frequent changes in supply itself.
elegant: Labor naturally adjusts to match effectual demand, but agricultural output varies dramatically year to year despite constant labor input, while manufacturing output is steady and predictable. This fundamental difference means that farm commodities regularly overshoot and undershoot effectual demand, causing sharp price swings even when demand stays perfectly constant. Manufactured goods, with their predictable and consistent output, can be matched closely to effectual demand, producing stable prices. Everyone knows from daily experience that corn prices are far more volatile than cloth prices. The price of manufactured goods varies only with changes in demand; the price of agricultural goods varies both with demand and with the much larger and more frequent fluctuations in the quantity actually brought to market.
summary: Manufacturing produces consistent output from consistent labor, allowing supply to match demand closely and prices to remain stable. Agriculture produces variable output despite consistent labor, causing frequent oversupply and undersupply that generates sharp price fluctuations.
distilled: Agricultural prices fluctuate sharply because output varies despite constant labor input, while manufacturing prices stay stable because output is predictable.
notes: Output variability by sector -- agriculture vs. manufacturing price stability -- average vs. actual production -- supply uncertainty in agriculture -- corn vs. cloth price volatility -- why agricultural prices are inherently more volatile -- cross-ref 1.7.13 on gravitational tendency, 1.7.15 on who bears price fluctuations

refashioned: The temporary fluctuations in a commodity's market price fall mainly on those parts of the price that resolve into wages and profit. The part that resolves into rent is less affected by them. A rent fixed as a certain amount of money is not affected at all, either in its rate or its value. A rent consisting of either a proportion or a fixed quantity of the raw produce is certainly affected in its yearly value by any temporary fluctuation in the market price of that produce, but it is seldom affected in its yearly rate. In negotiating the terms of a lease, the landlord and tenant endeavor, according to their best judgment, to set the rent rate based not on the temporary and occasional price of the produce, but on the average and ordinary price.
elegant: Market price fluctuations fall mainly on wages and profit, not on rent. Fixed money rents are entirely unaffected. Rents paid as a share of produce fluctuate in value but not in rate, since leases are based on average, ordinary prices rather than temporary market swings. The landlord is thus largely insulated from short-term volatility.
summary: Temporary market price fluctuations primarily affect wages and profit rather than rent. Rents are set based on ordinary average prices, insulating landlords from short-term market volatility.
distilled: Market price fluctuations are absorbed mainly by wages and profit; rent, set on long-term averages, remains largely insulated.
notes: Distribution of price volatility -- rent as fixed/stable claim -- wages and profit bear adjustment burden -- lease terms based on average prices -- landlord insulation from market risk -- cross-ref 1.7.14 on agricultural price volatility, 1.7.16 on specific examples

refashioned: Such fluctuations affect both the value and the rate of wages or profit, depending on whether the market is overstocked or understocked with goods or labor. A period of public mourning raises the price of black cloth -- always in short supply on such occasions -- and increases the profits of merchants who hold large stocks of it. But it does not affect weavers' wages, because the market is overstocked with finished goods, not with labor. It does, however, raise the wages of tailors, because the market is understocked with labor -- there is more work to be done than workers available. At the same time, mourning depresses the price of colored silks and cloths, reducing the profits of merchants holding those goods and the wages of workers who make them, since demand for their products has ceased for six months or perhaps a year. In this case, the market is overstocked with both goods and labor.
elegant: Whether market fluctuations hit wages or profit depends on what is over- or undersupplied. Public mourning raises black cloth profits because goods are scarce, and raises tailors' wages because labor is scarce. Simultaneously, it depresses colored silk prices and the wages of silk workers, because both finished goods and the labor that makes them are suddenly in surplus. The effect always falls on whichever component -- goods or labor -- is out of balance with demand.
summary: Market fluctuations affect wages or profit depending on whether the imbalance is in goods or labor. Smith uses public mourning to illustrate: black cloth profits rise, tailors' wages rise, but colored silk profits and wages both fall.
distilled: Market fluctuations hit wages when labor is the scarce or surplus factor, and profit when goods are -- as illustrated by the contrasting effects of public mourning on different trades.
notes: Differential impact of demand shocks -- public mourning example -- black cloth vs. colored silk -- goods surplus vs. labor surplus -- wages vs. profit adjustment -- cross-ref 1.7.15 on rent insulation, 1.7.17 on persistent deviations

refashioned: Although the market price of every commodity continually gravitates toward the natural price, particular accidents, natural causes, or government policies may sometimes keep the market price well above the natural price for extended periods. When increased effectual demand drives up the market price of a commodity significantly above the natural price, those who supply that market are generally careful to conceal this favorable change. If it were widely known, their large profits would tempt so many new competitors to invest their capital in the same line of business that effectual demand would soon be fully supplied. The market price would then be driven back down to the natural price, and perhaps for a time even below it. If the market is at a great distance from the suppliers' home base, they may sometimes be able to keep the secret for several years, enjoying their extraordinary profits all the while without attracting new rivals. Such secrets, however, can seldom be maintained for very long, and the extraordinary profits last barely longer than the secrecy that protects them.
elegant: Market prices gravitate toward the natural price, but accidents, nature, or government policy can hold them above it for extended periods. Suppliers earning windfall profits try to keep their good fortune secret, since publicity would attract competitors who would drive prices back down. Distance from the market can extend this secrecy for years, but such informational advantages rarely last long. The extraordinary profits dissolve almost as soon as the secret is discovered.
summary: While market prices tend toward the natural price, various factors can sustain above-natural prices. Suppliers conceal windfall profits to delay competition, but such secrecy is temporary, and extraordinary profits rarely outlast them.
distilled: Suppliers earning above-natural profits try to maintain secrecy, but competitors inevitably discover the opportunity and drive prices back toward the natural level.
notes: Information asymmetry and supernormal profits -- secrecy as barrier to entry -- distance from market extends advantage -- temporary nature of informational barriers -- gravitation despite obstacles -- cross-ref 1.7.13 on gravitational tendency, 1.7.18 on manufacturing secrets

refashioned: Manufacturing secrets can be kept longer than trade secrets. A dyer who discovers how to produce a particular color using materials costing half the usual price may, with careful management, enjoy the advantage of his discovery for his entire life and even pass it on to his heirs. His extraordinary earnings arise from the high price paid for his specialized knowledge and skill. They are essentially high wages for his labor. But because these earnings are repeated on every unit of output and bear a regular proportion to his total capital employed, they are commonly regarded as extraordinary profits on his capital.
elegant: Manufacturing secrets last longer than trade secrets. A dyer who halves his material costs can profit from the discovery for life and pass it to his heirs. These gains are really high wages for his specialized skill, but since they scale with output and capital, they are conventionally treated as extraordinary profit.
summary: Manufacturing secrets -- such as a dyer's cost-saving technique -- can sustain above-natural returns for a lifetime or more. These gains are essentially wages for specialized knowledge but are conventionally classified as extraordinary profit because they scale with capital.
distilled: Manufacturing secrets can sustain extraordinary returns for a lifetime because they represent specialized knowledge -- wages in substance, but classified as profit because they scale with capital.
notes: Manufacturing vs. trade secrets -- durability of knowledge-based advantages -- the dyer example -- wages disguised as profit again -- intellectual property as barrier to entry -- cross-ref 1.7.17 on secrecy, 1.6.14 on revenue category confusion

refashioned: The price enhancements described above are clearly the effects of particular accidents, though their impact may sometimes last for many years. Beyond such accidents, some natural products require such a singularity of soil and situation that all the suitable land in an entire country may not be sufficient to supply the effectual demand. The whole quantity brought to market can therefore be sold to buyers willing to pay more than what is needed to cover the rent of the land, the wages of the labor, and the profits of the capital employed in producing and bringing them to market, all at their natural rates. Such commodities may continue to sell at this elevated price for whole centuries, with the above-natural portion of the price generally taking the form of above-natural rent on the land. The rent of land that produces such singular and esteemed products -- like certain famous vineyards in France blessed with an exceptionally favorable soil and situation -- bears no regular proportion to the rent of other equally fertile and equally well-cultivated land in the surrounding area. The wages and profits involved in bringing these rare commodities to market, on the other hand, are seldom out of their natural proportion to those in other employments of labor and capital nearby.
elegant: Some price premiums arise from natural scarcity -- when all the suitable land in a country cannot satisfy demand for a commodity requiring unique soil and climate conditions. Such goods can sell above their natural price for centuries on end, with the premium accruing mainly as above-natural rent on the uniquely suited land. Famous French vineyards illustrate this perfectly: their rent bears no proportion to that of equally fertile neighbors, while the wages and profits in the wine trade remain at perfectly normal levels.
summary: Natural scarcity -- when unique soil and climate requirements limit supply below effectual demand -- can sustain above-natural prices for centuries. The premium accumulates as above-natural rent, while wages and profit remain at normal levels.
distilled: When nature limits the supply of goods requiring unique conditions, above-natural prices can persist for centuries, with the premium flowing to rent rather than wages or profit.
notes: Natural scarcity rent -- terroir and unique production conditions -- French vineyards as example -- Ricardian rent foreshadowed -- above-natural rent can persist indefinitely -- wages and profit stay normal -- cross-ref 1.7.17 on secrets, 1.7.20 on monopoly

refashioned: These price enhancements are clearly the effect of natural causes that may prevent effectual demand from ever being fully supplied, and that may therefore persist indefinitely. A monopoly granted to an individual or trading company has the same effect as a secret in trade or manufacturing. By keeping the market permanently understocked -- by never fully supplying the effectual demand -- monopolists sell their goods well above the natural price and raise their returns, whether in wages or profit, far above their natural rates.
elegant: Natural scarcity can sustain high prices forever by permanently preventing effectual demand from being fully supplied. Monopoly achieves the same result artificially: by deliberately keeping the market understocked and never fully supplying demand, monopolists sell far above the natural price.
summary: Natural scarcity can permanently prevent effectual demand from being satisfied. Monopolies produce the same effect artificially by deliberately keeping markets undersupplied, maintaining above-natural prices and returns.
distilled: Monopoly mimics natural scarcity by deliberately undersupplying the market to maintain prices permanently above the natural level.
notes: Monopoly as artificial scarcity -- equivalent to trade secrets and natural scarcity in effect -- permanent understocking of market -- monopoly grant to individuals or companies -- above-natural returns -- cross-ref 1.7.21 on monopoly pricing, 1.7.19 on natural scarcity

refashioned: The monopoly price is always the highest that can be extracted. The natural price, or the price of free competition, is, on the contrary, the lowest that sellers can sustainably accept over any considerable period. The monopoly price is the maximum that can be squeezed out of buyers -- or that they are expected to consent to pay. The competitive price is the minimum at which sellers can cover their costs and continue their business.
elegant: Monopoly price is the highest buyers can be made to pay. The competitive natural price is the lowest sellers can sustainably accept. One maximizes extraction; the other minimizes cost to consumers.
summary: Monopoly pricing extracts the maximum buyers will pay, while competitive pricing settles at the minimum sellers can sustainably accept. The two represent opposite extremes of the price spectrum.
distilled: Monopoly price is the maximum extractable from buyers; the competitive natural price is the minimum sustainable for sellers.
notes: Monopoly vs. competitive pricing -- maximum extraction vs. minimum sustainability -- monopoly as ceiling, competition as floor -- fundamental critique of monopoly -- cross-ref 1.7.20 on monopoly mechanics, 1.7.22 on quasi-monopolies

refashioned: The exclusive privileges of guilds, apprenticeship statutes, and all laws that restrict competition in particular occupations to fewer people than would otherwise enter them have the same tendency as monopolies, though to a lesser degree. They are a kind of enlarged monopoly and may, for entire generations and across whole classes of employment, keep market prices above natural prices and maintain both wages and profits above their natural rates.
elegant: Guild privileges, apprenticeship laws, and other restrictions on occupational entry function as diluted monopolies. By limiting competition, they can sustain above-natural prices, wages, and profits across entire industries for generations.
summary: Guild privileges and apprenticeship laws restrict competition in the same way monopolies do, just less extremely. They can keep prices, wages, and profits above their natural rates for generations across whole industries.
distilled: Guild privileges and restrictive labor laws function as diluted monopolies, sustaining above-natural prices and returns for generations.
notes: Guilds and apprenticeship as quasi-monopoly -- enlarged monopolies concept -- occupational entry barriers -- sustained above-natural returns across industries -- institutional barriers to competition -- cross-ref 1.7.21, 1.7.23 on duration, 1.7.24 on their downside

refashioned: Such policy-driven price enhancements can last as long as the regulations that cause them. However, while the market price of a commodity may remain above its natural price for a long time, it can rarely stay below it for long. Whenever any component of the price is paid below its natural rate, the affected parties immediately feel the loss and withdraw their land, labor, or capital from that use. Supply soon contracts to no more than the effectual demand requires, and the market price rises back to the natural price -- at least where there is full economic freedom.
elegant: Regulations can hold prices above the natural level indefinitely. But prices can rarely stay below the natural level for long: anyone earning below-natural returns quickly withdraws their resources, contracting supply until the price recovers. This correction requires economic freedom.
summary: Government regulations can sustain above-natural prices indefinitely, but below-natural prices are self-correcting: affected parties withdraw resources, contracting supply until prices recover to the natural level.
distilled: Above-natural prices can persist through regulation, but below-natural prices quickly self-correct as resource owners withdraw from unprofitable activities.
notes: Asymmetry in price deviations -- above-natural can persist (regulation), below-natural self-corrects -- resource withdrawal mechanism -- economic freedom required for self-correction -- cross-ref 1.7.11-1.7.12 on adjustment, 1.7.24 on regulation trapping workers

refashioned: The same apprenticeship statutes and corporation laws that allow workers to raise their wages well above the natural rate when their trade prospers sometimes force them to let wages fall well below it when the trade declines. Just as these laws exclude many people from entering the worker's occupation during good times, they exclude the worker from entering many other occupations during bad times. However, these regulations are far less durable in depressing wages than in raising them. Their wage-raising effect can last for centuries, but their wage-depressing effect can last only as long as the lifetimes of workers who were trained in the trade during its prosperity. Once those workers are gone, the number of new entrants will naturally adjust to the effectual demand. Only a policy as extreme as that of India or ancient Egypt -- where every person was bound by religious principle to follow their father's occupation and was considered to commit sacrilege by changing it -- could keep wages or profits below their natural rate for multiple generations.
elegant: Guild laws that inflate wages during prosperity also trap workers when their trade declines, preventing them from switching to other occupations. But this downside is temporary -- it lasts only as long as the lifetimes of workers trained during the good years. Once they retire or die, new entrants naturally adjust to demand. The upward effect on wages can persist for centuries, while the downward effect expires with one generation. Only extreme systems like those of India or ancient Egypt, which bound every person by religious mandate to follow their father's occupation, could suppress wages permanently.
summary: Apprenticeship and guild laws inflate wages for centuries during prosperity but can depress them only temporarily during decline, since the effect ends when existing workers retire. Only rigid hereditary occupation systems, like those of India and ancient Egypt, could permanently suppress wages below their natural rate.
distilled: Guild restrictions inflate wages for centuries but can depress them only for one generation, since new workers naturally adjust to demand -- unlike hereditary occupation systems that lock in suppression permanently.
notes: Asymmetric duration of regulation effects -- upward pressure lasts longer than downward -- occupational immobility during decline -- India and Egypt hereditary occupation systems -- religious sanction for occupational rigidity -- cross-ref 1.7.22-1.7.23, labor market flexibility

refashioned: This is all I think it necessary to say for now about how the market price of commodities deviates from the natural price, whether temporarily or permanently. The natural price itself changes whenever the natural rates of its components -- wages, profit, and rent -- change. And in every society, these rates vary according to the society's circumstances: its wealth or poverty, and whether it is advancing, stagnating, or declining. In the following four chapters, I will attempt to explain the causes of these variations as fully and clearly as I can.
elegant: This concludes the discussion of market price deviations. The natural price itself shifts when the natural rates of wages, profit, or rent change -- which they do as societies grow richer, stagnate, or decline. The next four chapters will explain why.
summary: Smith concludes his analysis of market price deviations and previews the next four chapters, which will examine how the natural rates of wages, profit, and rent change with a society's economic condition.
distilled: The natural price changes when the natural rates of wages, profit, and rent change, which varies with a society's stage of economic development.
notes: Transitional passage -- natural price as variable, not fixed -- natural rates shift with economic conditions -- preview of chapters 1.8-1.11 -- advancing vs. stationary vs. declining societies -- cross-ref 1.7.1-1.7.2 on natural rates

refashioned: First, I will try to explain what circumstances naturally determine the rate of wages, and how those circumstances are affected by whether the society is growing richer, stagnating, or declining. Second, I will try to show what circumstances naturally determine the rate of profit, and how those too are affected by the same variations in the state of society.
elegant: The next chapters address: first, what determines wage rates and how they respond to economic growth or decline; second, what determines profit rates and how they respond similarly.
summary: Smith outlines the plan for the next two chapters: explaining what determines wage rates and profit rates, and how each responds to the society's economic condition.
distilled: The following chapters will explain the determinants of wage and profit rates and how each responds to economic growth, stagnation, or decline.
notes: Chapter outline -- roadmap for 1.8 (wages) and 1.9 (profits) -- wages and profit as functions of economic condition -- structural preview -- cross-ref 1.7.25, 1.7.27

refashioned: Although wages and profits differ considerably across different employments of labor and capital, a certain consistent proportion seems to exist between wages in all the various types of work and between profits in all the various uses of capital. This proportion, as will be shown later, depends partly on the nature of the different employments and partly on the laws and policies of the society. But though it is shaped in many ways by law and policy, this proportion seems to be little affected by whether the society is rich or poor, growing or declining. It remains the same, or very nearly so, across all those different states. Third, I will try to explain what governs this proportion. Finally, in the fourth place, I will try to show what circumstances determine the rent of land, and what raises or lowers the real price of everything the land produces.
elegant: A stable proportional relationship exists between wages across different occupations and between profits across different uses of capital. This ratio depends on the nature of the work and on the society's laws -- but not on whether the economy is growing, stagnant, or declining. The third chapter will explain this ratio; the fourth will examine what determines land rent and the prices of land's products.
summary: Smith observes that the relative proportions of wages across occupations and profits across capital uses remain stable regardless of overall economic conditions, depending instead on the nature of the work and on institutional factors. He previews chapters on these proportions and on rent.
distilled: The relative proportions of wages and profits across different employments remain stable regardless of economic conditions, shaped by the nature of work and by law rather than by wealth or growth.
notes: Stable wage-profit proportions across employments -- institutional vs. economic determinants -- insensitivity to growth/decline -- preview of chapters on wage/profit ratios (1.10) and rent (1.11) -- cross-ref 1.7.25-1.7.26

refashioned: The product of labor is the natural reward -- the natural wages -- of labor. In the original state of things, before land was claimed as property and capital was accumulated, the entire product of labor belonged to the worker. He had neither landlord nor master to share with. Had this state continued, the wages of labor would have grown alongside every improvement in productivity that the division of labor makes possible. Everything would gradually have become cheaper, produced with less labor. And since goods produced by equal amounts of labor would naturally exchange for one another, they could also have been purchased with less labor.
elegant: Labor's product is its natural wage. Before land ownership and capital, the worker kept everything he produced. Had this continued, productivity gains from the division of labor would have made everything progressively cheaper -- less labor to produce, less labor to buy.
summary: In the original state before property and capital, workers kept their full output. Had this persisted, the division of labor would have continuously reduced prices by reducing the labor needed to produce and purchase goods.
distilled: Before land ownership and capital, workers kept all they produced; had this continued, the division of labor would have made everything progressively cheaper.
notes: Opening of wages chapter -- labor's natural reward is its full product -- the pre-property, pre-capital baseline -- division of labor as engine of falling prices -- counterfactual history -- cross-ref 1.6.1 on primitive exchange, 1.8.2 on real vs. nominal cheapness

refashioned: Although everything would have become genuinely cheaper in this hypothetical state, many things might have appeared more expensive -- exchanging for a greater quantity of other goods.
