Suppose, for example, that in most occupations productivity had improved tenfold, so that a day's labor produced ten times as much as before, but in one particular occupation productivity had only doubled. Trading a day's output from the typical occupation for a day's output from the less-improved one would mean exchanging ten times the original quantity for only twice the original quantity. A unit of the less-improved good -- say, a pound -- would appear five times more expensive than before. Yet in reality it would be twice as cheap: though it now required five times as many other goods to purchase it, it required only half as much labor to produce or buy it. The acquisition would actually be twice as easy as before.
elegant: Even with universal productivity gains, goods from slower-improving industries would appear more expensive relative to other goods, even though they are actually cheaper in terms of the labor needed to acquire them. If most industries improve tenfold but one only doubles, that good seems five times pricier when traded for other goods -- yet it costs only half the labor to produce or purchase. True cheapness is measured by the labor required, not by the exchange ratio with other commodities.
summary: Smith distinguishes real from apparent cheapness. When productivity improves unevenly, goods from slower-improving industries appear more expensive relative to other goods but are actually cheaper in terms of the labor needed to obtain them.
distilled: Uneven productivity gains make slower-improving goods appear expensive relative to other goods, even though they require less labor to obtain -- the true measure of cheapness.
notes: Real vs. nominal price -- apparent vs. true cheapness -- uneven productivity growth across sectors -- Baumol's cost disease foreshadowed -- labor as true measure of value -- cross-ref 1.5 on labor as real measure, 1.8.1 on baseline

refashioned: But this original state -- in which workers enjoyed the full product of their labor -- could not survive beyond the first introduction of private land ownership and capital accumulation. It ended long before any significant improvements in productivity occurred, and it would be pointless to speculate further about what its effects on wages might have been.
elegant: The original state where workers kept their full product ended with the arrival of property and capital -- long before significant productivity gains. Further speculation about it is fruitless.
summary: The hypothetical state where workers kept their full product ended with the emergence of private property and capital, well before major productivity improvements, making further analysis of it impractical.
distilled: Private property and capital accumulation ended the era when workers kept their full product, long before significant productivity gains occurred.
notes: Historical transition from pre-property to property society -- end of full-product wages -- practical pivot to analyzing wages under capital and property -- cross-ref 1.8.1 on the original state, 1.8.4 on landlord's claim

refashioned: As soon as land becomes private property, the landlord demands a share of nearly everything the worker can raise or collect from it. His rent is the first deduction from the product of labor applied to land. It rarely happens that the person who tills the soil can support himself until the harvest comes in. His maintenance is typically advanced from the capital of a master -- the farmer who employs him -- who would have no reason to employ him unless he could share in the product of his labor, or unless his capital was to be repaid with a profit. This profit is the second deduction from the product of labor applied to land.
elegant: Private property creates two successive deductions from the worker's product. First, the landlord takes rent for the use of the land. Second, the farmer who advances the worker's subsistence until harvest takes profit on his capital. The worker keeps only what remains after both claims are satisfied.
summary: Private land ownership creates two deductions from the agricultural worker's product: rent to the landlord, and profit to the farmer who advances the worker's subsistence. These are the first and second claims on labor's output.
distilled: Private property subjects the worker's product to two prior claims: rent for the landlord and profit for the capitalist farmer who finances the worker's subsistence.
notes: Two deductions from labor's product -- rent as first claim, profit as second -- landlord and farmer as claimants -- worker's dependence on advance of subsistence -- cross-ref 1.6.6 on rent, 1.6.3 on profit, 1.8.5 on manufacturing parallel

refashioned: The product of nearly all other labor is subject to the same deduction of profit. In every art and manufacture, most workers need a master to advance them the materials for their work and their wages and maintenance until it is completed. The master shares in the product of their labor -- or in the value it adds to the materials -- and this share is his profit.
elegant: The profit deduction applies beyond agriculture: in all arts and manufactures, most workers depend on a master who advances materials and wages, taking a share of the value added as his profit.
summary: In manufacturing as in agriculture, most workers depend on a master who advances materials and wages. The master's share of the value added by labor constitutes his profit.
distilled: Across all industries, workers depend on employers who advance materials and wages, and who claim a share of the value added as profit.
notes: Profit deduction universal across sectors -- manufacturing parallel to agriculture -- employer as financier of production -- value added as source of profit -- cross-ref 1.8.4 on agricultural deductions, 1.8.6 on independent workers

refashioned: It does sometimes happen that a single independent worker has enough capital to purchase his own materials and maintain himself until the work is completed. He is both master and worker, and enjoys the full product of his own labor -- the full value it adds to the materials. His income includes what are usually two separate revenues belonging to two separate people: the profits of capital and the wages of labor.
elegant: Occasionally, an independent worker with his own capital acts as both employer and employee, keeping the full value added -- both the profit and the wages that would normally go to two different people.
summary: Independent workers with sufficient capital keep both the wages and profits that would normally be split between worker and employer, earning the full value their labor adds to materials.
distilled: Independent workers with their own capital earn both wages and profit, keeping the full value they add to materials.
notes: Self-employed exception -- worker as both master and laborer -- full product retained -- wages and profit combined in one income -- cross-ref 1.6.16 on independent manufacturer, 1.8.7 on rarity of this case

refashioned: Such cases, however, are not common. Across Europe, for every independent worker, twenty serve under a master. The wages of labor are generally understood to be what they typically are when the worker is one person and the owner of the capital that employs him is another. What the common wages of labor are depends everywhere on the contract usually made between these two parties, whose interests are by no means the same. Workers want to get as much as possible; masters want to pay as little as possible. Workers are inclined to combine to raise wages; masters to combine to lower them.
elegant: Independent workers are rare -- twenty serve under a master for every one who is self-employed. Wages are set by the contract between worker and employer, whose interests are directly opposed: workers combine to raise wages, masters to lower them.
summary: Self-employed workers are rare; the typical wage reflects a negotiation between workers who want higher pay and masters who want lower costs, with their opposing interests creating an inherent tension.
distilled: Wages are determined by the inherently adversarial bargaining between workers who want more and employers who want to pay less.
notes: Wage determination as bargaining -- opposing interests of labor and capital -- 20:1 ratio of employed to independent -- combination (unionization) by both sides -- class conflict in wage setting -- cross-ref 1.8.8 on employer advantage, 1.8.9 on tacit employer combinations

refashioned: It is not difficult to foresee which of the two parties will generally have the advantage in this dispute. The masters, being fewer in number, can combine far more easily. Moreover, the law authorizes -- or at least does not prohibit -- their combinations, while it prohibits those of workers. There are no laws against employers combining to lower wages, but many against workers combining to raise them. In every such dispute, masters can hold out much longer. A landlord, farmer, manufacturer, or merchant could generally live for a year or two on the capital they have already accumulated, even without employing a single worker. Few workers could survive a week without employment; hardly any could last a month, and almost none a year. In the long run, the worker may be as necessary to the master as the master is to the worker, but the necessity is far less immediate.
elegant: Masters have every structural advantage in wage disputes. They are fewer in number and combine far more easily. The law authorizes their combinations while banning workers' combinations. Most critically, employers can survive for a year or two on accumulated capital while most workers cannot last even a week without wages. Though the worker may be equally necessary in the long run, his need for employment is far more immediate.
summary: Employers hold structural advantages in wage bargaining: they are fewer and combine more easily, the law favors their combinations, and they can survive far longer without workers than workers can survive without wages.
distilled: Employers dominate wage bargaining because they are fewer, combine more easily, enjoy legal protection, and can outlast workers in any dispute.
notes: Structural employer advantage in bargaining -- legal asymmetry favoring employers -- survival asymmetry (capital vs. wages) -- combination laws against workers -- class power dynamics -- cross-ref 1.8.9 on tacit employer combinations, 1.8.10 on worker resistance

refashioned: We rarely hear, it is said, of employers combining, though we frequently hear of workers doing so. But anyone who believes that employers rarely combine is as ignorant of the world as of the subject. Employers are always and everywhere in a kind of tacit, constant, and uniform combination not to raise wages above their current rate. Violating this unspoken agreement is deeply unpopular -- a kind of disgrace among fellow employers. We seldom hear of this combination precisely because it is the normal, natural state of affairs, which nobody thinks to mention. Employers also sometimes enter into explicit agreements to push wages even below the prevailing rate. These are always carried out in the utmost secrecy until the moment of execution. When workers yield -- as they sometimes do without resistance -- though they feel the effect severely, no one else ever hears of it.
elegant: Employer combinations are invisible not because they are rare, but because they are universal. Masters maintain a permanent, tacit agreement not to raise wages -- so natural it goes unnoticed. They sometimes conspire to push wages even lower, in total secrecy. Worker combinations are visible precisely because they are the exception, not the rule.
summary: Smith reveals that employer combinations are not rare but universal -- a permanent, tacit agreement not to raise wages, so normal it goes unnoticed. Explicit conspiracies to lower wages further happen in secrecy. Worker combinations are visible precisely because they are the ones that disrupt the status quo.
distilled: Employer wage suppression is invisible because it is universal and tacit; worker combinations are conspicuous because they challenge the accepted norm.
notes: Tacit employer collusion as the invisible norm -- asymmetry of visibility -- employer combinations as 'natural state' -- secret wage-cutting agreements -- workers' combinations are the visible disruption -- profound insight on class power -- cross-ref 1.8.8 on structural advantage, 1.8.10 on worker resistance

refashioned: Such employer combinations are frequently resisted by defensive combinations of workers, who sometimes also combine on their own initiative to raise the price of their labor. Their usual justifications are the high price of necessities or the large profits their employers make from their work. But whether their combinations are offensive or defensive, they are always highly visible. To force a quick resolution, workers always resort to the loudest protests and sometimes to shocking violence and destruction. They are desperate, and they act with the recklessness of desperate people who must either starve or frighten their employers into immediate compliance.
elegant: Workers resist employer collusion through their own combinations, justified by high living costs or employer profits. Unlike employers' quiet agreements, worker actions are always loud, public, and sometimes violent -- the desperate measures of people who face starvation if they fail.
summary: Workers form combinations to resist employer collusion, citing high living costs and employer profits. Their actions are always visible and sometimes violent -- the desperate response of people who face starvation as the alternative.
distilled: Worker combinations are visible and sometimes violent because they are the desperate resistance of people who face starvation if their demands are not met.
notes: Worker combinations as defensive response -- visibility asymmetry with employer collusion -- desperation drives extremism -- offensive vs. defensive combination -- high provisions and employer profits as justifications -- cross-ref 1.8.9 on invisible employer combinations, 1.8.11 on employer response

refashioned: On these occasions, the masters are equally vocal on the other side, never ceasing to demand the intervention of the courts and the strict enforcement of the severe laws enacted against worker combinations. Workers accordingly seldom gain any advantage from their turbulent actions, which typically end in nothing but the punishment or ruin of the ringleaders -- partly because of government intervention, partly because of the masters' greater staying power, and partly because most workers are forced to submit for the sake of immediate survival.
elegant: Employers respond by invoking the law, demanding enforcement of anti-combination statutes. Workers' strikes almost always fail -- crushed by government intervention, employer endurance, and the workers' own desperate need for immediate subsistence. The result is usually punishment for the ringleaders.
summary: Employers call for legal enforcement against worker combinations, which nearly always fail due to government intervention, employer staying power, and workers' inability to survive prolonged disputes.
distilled: Worker combinations almost always fail because employers invoke anti-combination laws, can outlast workers financially, and workers cannot survive without wages.
notes: Legal suppression of worker combinations -- three reasons for failure: law, employer endurance, worker desperation -- punishment of ringleaders -- structural inequality in industrial disputes -- cross-ref 1.8.8 on legal asymmetry, 1.8.12 on the wage floor

refashioned: But although employers generally have the upper hand in wage disputes, there is a certain minimum below which it seems impossible to reduce ordinary wages for any sustained period, even for the lowest types of labor. A person must live by his work, and his wages must at least be enough to keep him alive. On most occasions they must be somewhat more, because otherwise he could not raise a family, and the supply of such workers would not survive beyond the first generation. Cantillon estimated that the lowest class of common laborers must earn at least double their own maintenance, so that on average they can raise two children to adulthood. He assumed the wife's labor barely covers her own upkeep due to childcare duties. But since roughly half of all children born die before reaching adulthood, the poorest laborers must attempt to raise at least four children for two to survive to working age. The maintenance of four children roughly equals that of one adult man. The same author adds that the labor of a healthy slave is reckoned to be worth double his maintenance, and that of the poorest free laborer cannot be worth less. This much at least seems certain: to raise a family, even the lowest class of laborers must earn, between husband and wife, something more than what is strictly necessary for their own survival. In what exact proportion, I will not attempt to determine.
elegant: Despite employer dominance in wage disputes, there is a natural floor below which wages cannot sustainably fall. Workers must earn enough to survive and reproduce. Cantillon calculated that the lowest laborers need at least double their own maintenance, so that a couple can attempt to raise four children -- since half die before adulthood -- in hopes that two survive to working age. A wife's earnings during child-rearing years barely cover her own needs. Free labor cannot be worth less than slave labor, which is valued at double its maintenance cost. The exact minimum is uncertain, but it must exceed bare individual survival.
summary: There is a natural wage floor: workers must earn enough to maintain themselves and raise the next generation of workers. Cantillon estimated this at double individual maintenance, accounting for child mortality and the wife's limited earning capacity during child-rearing years.
distilled: Wages cannot sustainably fall below the level needed for workers to maintain themselves and raise enough children to replace the workforce, even accounting for high child mortality.
notes: Subsistence wage theory -- Cantillon's minimum wage calculation -- reproduction cost of labor -- child mortality factored in -- slave labor as benchmark -- natural wage floor -- iron law of wages foreshadowed -- cross-ref 1.8.11 on employer advantage, 1.8.13 on circumstances favoring workers

refashioned: There are certain circumstances, however, that sometimes give workers the advantage and enable them to raise their wages considerably above this minimum -- which is clearly the lowest rate consistent with basic human decency. When the demand for wage-laborers in a country is continually increasing -- when each year provides employment for more people than the year before -- workers have no need to combine to raise their wages. The scarcity of available workers creates competition among employers, who bid against each other for workers and thereby voluntarily break through their own tacit agreement not to raise wages. The demand for wage-laborers can only increase in proportion to the increase in the funds set aside to pay wages. These funds are of two kinds: first, the surplus revenue beyond what is needed for the owners' maintenance; and second, the surplus capital beyond what is needed to employ their current workforce.
elegant: When the demand for labor is continually growing, workers gain the advantage without needing to organize. Employer competition for scarce workers naturally breaks their tacit agreement not to raise wages. The scarcity of available hands forces masters to bid against one another voluntarily. This growth in labor demand occurs only when the funds available for paying wages increase -- either surplus revenue of the wealthy beyond their own maintenance needs, or surplus capital of employers beyond their current operational requirements.
summary: Growing labor demand gives workers bargaining power without the need for combinations. Employers competing for scarce workers voluntarily bid up wages. This growth depends on increasing wage funds -- surplus revenue and surplus capital.
distilled: When labor demand continually grows, employer competition for scarce workers naturally drives wages above the subsistence minimum without any need for worker organization.
notes: Labor scarcity as workers' advantage -- employer competition breaks tacit collusion -- two sources of wage funds: surplus revenue and surplus capital -- demand growth as key to rising wages -- cross-ref 1.8.9 on tacit employer combinations, 1.8.14 on wage fund mechanics

refashioned: When a landlord, annuitant, or wealthy investor has more revenue than he needs to maintain his own family, he uses the whole surplus, or part of it, to employ domestic servants. If this surplus increases, he naturally increases the number of servants he employs. When an independent craftsman -- say a weaver or shoemaker -- has more capital than he needs to buy his own materials and support himself until he can sell his work, he naturally employs one or more journeymen with the surplus, in order to profit from their labor. If this surplus grows, he naturally employs more journeymen.
elegant: Surplus revenue employs more servants; surplus capital employs more journeymen. As the wealthy gain more surplus income, they hire more domestic help. As craftsmen accumulate more capital, they hire more workers to profit from their labor.
summary: Surplus revenue leads to hiring more servants, and surplus capital leads to hiring more workers. Both mechanisms increase the demand for labor as wealth grows.
distilled: Surplus revenue hires servants and surplus capital hires workers -- both channels increase labor demand as wealth grows.
notes: Two channels of wage fund growth -- surplus revenue (consumption) vs. surplus capital (investment) -- both increase labor demand -- mechanics of employment creation -- cross-ref 1.8.13 on two kinds of wage funds, 1.8.15 on aggregate effect

refashioned: The demand for wage-laborers therefore necessarily increases with the growth of a country's revenue and capital, and cannot possibly increase without it. The growth of revenue and capital is the growth of national wealth. The demand for labor, therefore, naturally increases with the growth of national wealth, and cannot possibly increase without it.
elegant: Labor demand grows exactly in proportion to national wealth -- meaning the growth of revenue and capital. It cannot increase without this growth, and it necessarily increases with it.
summary: The demand for labor increases in direct proportion to the growth of national wealth, defined as the increase in revenue and capital. No growth in wealth means no growth in labor demand.
distilled: Labor demand grows in direct proportion to national wealth and cannot increase without it.
notes: Labor demand as function of national wealth -- necessary and sufficient condition -- growth of revenue and capital as definition of wealth growth -- simple but powerful theorem -- cross-ref 1.8.14 on mechanisms, 1.8.16 on growth rate vs. absolute wealth

refashioned: It is not the absolute size of national wealth but its continual increase that causes wages to rise. Accordingly, wages are highest not in the richest countries but in the fastest-growing ones -- those acquiring wealth most rapidly. England is certainly a much richer country than any part of North America. Yet wages are much higher in North America than anywhere in England. In New York province, common laborers earned in 1773, before the recent troubles, three shillings and sixpence currency (about two shillings sterling) per day. Ship carpenters earned ten shillings and sixpence currency plus a pint of rum, totaling about six shillings and sixpence sterling. House carpenters and bricklayers earned eight shillings currency, or about four shillings and sixpence sterling. Journeyman tailors earned five shillings currency, about two shillings and tenpence sterling. All of these exceed London wages, and wages in other colonies were said to be equally high. Moreover, the price of food was much lower throughout North America than in England. Famine was unknown there; even in the worst seasons, there was always enough for domestic needs, though less for export. Since the money price of labor is higher than in England while the cost of living is lower, the real purchasing power of American wages -- their command over necessities and comforts -- exceeds English wages by an even greater margin.
elegant: Wages rise from the rate of wealth growth, not from absolute wealth. England is richer than North America, yet American wages are far higher because America is growing much faster. In New York in 1773, common laborers, ship carpenters, bricklayers, and tailors all earned more than their London counterparts. Meanwhile, American food prices were much lower -- famine was unknown there. Since both money wages are higher and living costs are lower, the real purchasing power of American labor exceeds English labor by an even greater proportion than the nominal wage difference suggests.
summary: Smith's key insight: wages depend on the rate of economic growth, not absolute wealth. North America, though poorer than England, pays higher wages because it is growing faster. Both higher nominal wages and lower food prices give American workers far greater real purchasing power.
distilled: Wages are determined by the rate of economic growth, not absolute wealth -- which is why fast-growing North America pays higher wages than richer but slower-growing England.
notes: Growth rate vs. absolute wealth as wage determinant -- North America vs. England wage comparison -- 1773 New York wage data -- real vs. nominal wages -- food prices lower in America -- key theorem of the chapter -- cross-ref 1.8.15 on wealth and labor demand, 1.8.17 on population growth

refashioned: Although North America is not yet as rich as England, it is far more dynamic, advancing toward wealth with much greater speed. The most telling sign of any country's prosperity is the growth of its population. In Great Britain and most of Europe, the population is thought to take five hundred years to double. In the British colonies of North America, it has been found to double in twenty or twenty-five years. This increase is no longer primarily due to immigration but to the natural multiplication of the existing population. People who live to old age frequently see fifty to a hundred or more descendants of their own body. Labor is so well rewarded there that a large family of children, far from being a burden, is a source of wealth and prosperity for the parents. Each child's labor, before leaving the household, is estimated to be worth a clear one hundred pounds to the parents. A young widow with four or five small children -- who among the middling or lower ranks in Europe would have little chance of remarrying -- is in America frequently courted as a kind of fortune. The value of children is the greatest encouragement to marriage. It is no wonder, then, that Americans generally marry very young. Yet despite the rapid population increase from these early marriages, there is a constant complaint about the scarcity of workers in North America. The demand for labor -- the funds to maintain workers -- apparently grows even faster than workers can be found to fill the positions.
elegant: America's rapid growth is proven by its population doubling every twenty to twenty-five years, compared to roughly five hundred years in Europe. This increase comes not from immigration but from natural multiplication -- high wages make children an economic asset, not a burden. Each child's labor is worth an estimated hundred pounds clear gain to the parents before leaving home. A young widow with children is courted as a fortune rather than pitied. The value of children encourages early marriage. Yet despite this rapid population growth, demand for labor still outstrips supply, showing that the wage funds grow even faster than the people.
summary: North America's population doubles every 20-25 years through natural increase, compared to every 500 years in Europe. High wages make large families profitable, encouraging early marriage. Despite rapid population growth, labor demand still outpaces supply.
distilled: North America's population doubles every 20-25 years because high wages make children economically valuable, yet labor demand still grows faster than the population can keep up.
notes: Population growth as prosperity indicator -- 20-25 year doubling in America vs. 500 in Europe -- natural increase, not immigration -- children as economic assets -- early marriage encouraged -- labor scarcity despite population boom -- Malthusian themes -- cross-ref 1.8.16 on growth and wages, 1.8.18 on stagnant economies

refashioned: Though a country's wealth may be very great, if it has been stagnant for a long time, we should not expect to find high wages there. The wage funds -- the revenue and capital of its inhabitants -- may be enormous in total, but if they have remained at roughly the same level for centuries, the number of workers employed each year could easily supply, or even oversupply, the number needed the following year. There would rarely be a shortage of labor, and employers would not need to bid against each other to get workers.
elegant: In a wealthy but stagnant economy, wage funds are large but static. With no growth in demand, the existing labor supply easily meets or exceeds needs. There is no labor shortage, no employer competition, and therefore no upward pressure on wages.
summary: A wealthy but stagnant economy does not produce high wages. Without growth in the wage funds, labor supply keeps pace with demand, eliminating the competitive bidding among employers that drives wages up.
distilled: Wealth without growth produces no upward pressure on wages, because static labor demand means supply always keeps pace.
notes: Stagnant wealth vs. growing wealth -- static wage funds -- labor supply equilibrium in stagnant economies -- no employer competition without growth -- reinforces growth-rate thesis -- cross-ref 1.8.16 on growth as wage driver, 1.8.19 on China as example

refashioned: In a stagnant economy, the labor supply would naturally expand beyond the available employment. Workers would be forced to bid against each other for scarce jobs. If wages had ever been above subsistence level, the competition among workers and the self-interest of employers would soon push them down to the lowest rate consistent with basic humanity. China has long been one of the wealthiest -- that is, one of the most fertile, best cultivated, most industrious, and most populous -- countries in the world. Yet it appears to have been stagnant for a very long time. Marco Polo, who visited more than five hundred years ago, described its farming, industry, and population in nearly the same terms that travelers use today. China had perhaps already reached the maximum level of wealth that its laws and institutions permit, even long before Marco Polo's visit.
elegant: In stagnation, the labor supply naturally expands beyond available employment. Workers are forced to compete against each other for scarce jobs, and the combined pressure of worker competition and employer self-interest drives wages down to the bare subsistence minimum. China illustrates this precisely: wealthy, industrious, and enormously populous, yet economically stagnant for centuries. Marco Polo's thirteenth-century description of its farming, industry, and population matches modern accounts almost exactly.
summary: In a stagnant economy, labor oversupply drives wages to subsistence. China exemplifies this: enormously wealthy but economically stagnant for centuries, with Marco Polo's ancient descriptions still matching contemporary accounts.
distilled: Economic stagnation leads to labor oversupply and subsistence wages, as China -- wealthy but unchanging for centuries -- illustrates.
notes: China as case study of wealthy stagnation -- labor oversupply in static economies -- institutional limits on growth -- Marco Polo's description unchanged over 500 years -- laws and institutions as growth constraints -- cross-ref 1.8.18 on stagnation theory, 1.8.20 on Chinese poverty

refashioned: The accounts of all travelers, though contradicting each other on many points, agree on two things about China: the low wages of labor and the difficulty a laborer faces in supporting a family. If a laborer can earn enough by digging the ground all day to buy a small quantity of rice in the evening, he is content. The condition of skilled workers is, if anything, even worse. Instead of waiting in their workshops for customers to come to them as European craftsmen do, they are continually running through the streets with their tools, offering their services and practically begging for work.
elegant: All travelers agree: Chinese wages are desperately low and supporting a family is nearly impossible. A full day's digging buys only a little rice. Craftsmen, even worse off, roam the streets with their tools, begging for work rather than waiting for customers.
summary: Despite China's overall wealth, wages are desperately low. A day laborer earns barely enough rice to eat, and skilled craftsmen must roam the streets begging for work rather than waiting for customers.
distilled: In stagnant China, wages are so low that laborers barely survive on rice and craftsmen must beg for work in the streets.
notes: Empirical evidence of Chinese subsistence wages -- traveler accounts as evidence -- day labor barely buys rice -- craftsmen begging for work -- contrast with European workshop model -- visible poverty amid national wealth -- cross-ref 1.8.19 on stagnation, 1.8.21 on extreme poverty

refashioned: The poverty of China's lower classes far exceeds that of the most destitute nations in Europe. Near Canton, it is commonly said that many hundreds -- even thousands -- of families have no homes on land, living constantly in small fishing boats on the rivers and canals. Their subsistence is so meager that they eagerly fish up the most disgusting garbage thrown overboard from European ships. Any rotting carcass -- a dead dog or cat, for example, even half-decayed and stinking -- is as welcome to them as the freshest food would be to people of other countries. Marriage is encouraged in China not by the economic value of children but by the freedom to destroy them. In all the great towns, infants are exposed in the streets every night or drowned like puppies in the water.
elegant: Chinese poverty dwarfs European destitution. Near Canton, thousands live in boats on canals, eagerly scavenging rotten garbage from European ships. Marriage is encouraged not because children are valuable but because parents are free to dispose of them -- infants are routinely abandoned or drowned.
summary: The extreme poverty of China's lower classes -- families living on boats, scavenging rotten garbage, and routinely abandoning or drowning unwanted infants -- far surpasses anything found in Europe, illustrating the human cost of economic stagnation.
distilled: China's economic stagnation produces poverty so extreme that families scavenge garbage from ships and routinely abandon infants -- conditions far worse than anything in Europe.
notes: Extreme poverty in prosperous-but-stagnant China -- Canton boat-dwelling families -- scavenging behavior as poverty indicator -- infanticide and child abandonment -- marriage encouraged by freedom to destroy children -- shocking contrast with North American conditions in 1.8.17 -- cross-ref 1.8.20, 1.8.22

refashioned: The disposal of unwanted infants is even said to be an openly acknowledged profession by which some people earn their living. Yet China, though it may be standing still, does not appear to be moving backward. Its towns are not being abandoned. Once-cultivated land is not being neglected. The same annual labor continues to be performed, and the funds that support it are not visibly shrinking. The lowest class of laborers, despite their miserable subsistence, must somehow manage to keep their numbers roughly stable.
elegant: Infanticide is reportedly an openly acknowledged profession in China. Yet the country is stagnant, not declining: its towns remain populated, its cultivated lands are not neglected, and the same volume of annual labor continues to be performed. The lowest class of laborers, despite their wretched subsistence, somehow manages to maintain its numbers from one generation to the next.
summary: Despite horrific poverty including institutionalized infanticide, China is stagnant rather than declining -- its population, towns, and agricultural output remain stable, indicating the laboring class barely sustains itself at subsistence level.
distilled: China's economy is stagnant rather than declining: despite extreme poverty and institutionalized infanticide, population and output hold steady.
notes: Stagnation vs. decline distinction -- institutionalized infanticide -- population stability at subsistence -- the economy's ability to maintain but not grow -- cross-ref 1.8.21 on extreme poverty, 1.8.23 on declining economies (Bengal)

refashioned: But conditions would be far worse in a country where the funds for maintaining labor were actively declining. Each year, the demand for workers of every kind would be less than the year before. Many who had been employed in higher-status occupations, unable to find work in their own field, would be forced to seek employment in the lowest. The lowest class, already oversupplied with its own workers and now flooded with cast-offs from every other class, would see wages driven down to the most miserable and scanty level of subsistence. Many would be unable to find work even on those desperate terms and would be forced to beg, starve, or turn to crime. Famine, disease, and death would sweep through the laboring class and spread upward through all the classes above it, until the population shrank to what the remaining revenue and capital could support. This is perhaps close to the present condition of Bengal and some other British settlements in the East Indies. In a fertile country that had previously been much more populous, where subsistence should not be difficult, and where three or four hundred thousand people nevertheless die of hunger in a single year, we may be certain that the funds for maintaining the laboring poor are rapidly declining. The difference between the British constitution, which protects and governs North America, and the mercantile company that oppresses and dominates the East Indies, could hardly be better illustrated than by the contrasting conditions in those two regions.
elegant: In a declining economy, labor demand falls every year and workers cascade downward through the occupational hierarchy. Those displaced from higher trades compete for the lowest positions, overwhelming that class with both its own workers and refugees from every rank above. Wages collapse to starvation levels. Many cannot find work even on desperate terms and are driven to begging, crime, or death. Famine and mortality reduce the population until it matches the shrinking economy's capacity. Bengal under the East India Company illustrates this nightmare: a fertile land where hundreds of thousands starve annually. The contrast between constitutional governance in North America and mercantile company oppression in the East Indies could not be sharper.
summary: In a declining economy, falling labor demand cascades workers downward through occupational ranks until wages collapse, producing mass starvation and depopulation. Smith cites Bengal under the East India Company as a real example, contrasting it with North America's prosperity under the British constitution.
distilled: Economic decline creates a cascading collapse in which workers at every level are pushed downward, wages fall to starvation levels, and population shrinks -- as illustrated by Bengal under the East India Company.
notes: Declining economy dynamics -- downward occupational cascade -- mass starvation and depopulation -- Bengal under East India Company as case study -- contrast with North America -- British constitution vs. mercantile company rule -- strongest critique of colonial mercantilism -- cross-ref 1.8.17 on North America, 1.8.22 on stagnant China

refashioned: The liberal reward of labor, then, is both the necessary result and the natural sign of increasing national wealth. Scanty maintenance of the laboring poor is the natural sign that things are standing still, and their starvation is the sign that things are going rapidly backward. In Great Britain, present wages appear to be clearly above what is strictly necessary for a laborer to raise a family. To verify this, we need not attempt any tedious calculation of the minimum possible subsistence level. There are many clear indications that wages in Britain are nowhere regulated by that bare minimum consistent with basic humanity.
elegant: High wages are the natural symptom of increasing national wealth; subsistence wages signal economic stagnation; starvation wages signal rapid decline. In present-day Great Britain, wages clearly exceed the bare minimum needed to raise a family, as several plain indicators confirm without requiring any complicated calculation of minimum subsistence.
summary: Smith summarizes his framework: high wages indicate growth, subsistence wages indicate stagnation, and starvation indicates decline. He observes that British wages clearly exceed the subsistence minimum, as he will demonstrate with four pieces of evidence.
distilled: Liberal wages signal growth, subsistence signals stagnation, and starvation signals decline -- and British wages clearly exceed the subsistence floor.
notes: Wages as diagnostic of economic health -- three-stage framework (growth/stagnation/decline) -- British wages above subsistence -- transition to empirical evidence -- cross-ref 1.8.16-1.8.23 for the three cases, 1.8.25-1.8.28 for evidence

refashioned: First, in nearly every part of Great Britain there is a distinction, even in the lowest types of labor, between summer and winter wages. Summer wages are always higher. But because fuel is expensive, maintaining a family costs more in winter than in summer. If wages were set purely by the cost of family maintenance, they would be highest in winter, when expenses are greatest. Instead, wages are highest in summer, when the work is most valuable. This suggests that wages are regulated by the value of the work, not by the cost of living. One might argue that laborers ought to save part of their higher summer wages to cover winter expenses, making the yearly total just enough for family maintenance. But a slave, or anyone entirely dependent on another for immediate subsistence, would not be treated this way -- his daily rations would match his daily needs.
elegant: Evidence one: summer wages exceed winter wages, even though winter living costs are higher. If wages tracked subsistence needs, winter wages would be higher. Instead, wages track the value of work. A slave would be fed according to daily needs -- the fact that free workers are not suggests wages follow productivity, not subsistence.
summary: The first evidence that British wages exceed subsistence: summer wages are higher than winter wages despite higher winter living costs, indicating wages are set by the value of work rather than the bare cost of survival.
distilled: Summer wages exceed winter wages despite higher winter living costs, proving wages reflect the value of work, not bare subsistence needs.
notes: First of four evidences for above-subsistence wages -- seasonal wage variation -- wages track productivity, not cost of living -- slave comparison as analytical device -- cross-ref 1.8.24 on British wages above subsistence, 1.8.26 for second evidence

refashioned: Second, wages in Great Britain do not fluctuate with the price of food. Food prices vary everywhere from year to year, often from month to month. But in many places, the money price of labor remains the same for half a century at a time. If the laboring poor can support their families during expensive years, they must be comfortable in moderately priced years and well-off in years of exceptional cheapness. The sharp rise in food prices over the past ten years has not, in many parts of the country, been accompanied by any noticeable rise in money wages. Where wages have risen, it seems to owe more to increased demand for labor than to higher food prices.
elegant: Evidence two: wages stay constant for decades while food prices swing wildly year to year. If workers survive the dear years, they must prosper in the cheap ones. Recent food price increases have not been matched by wage increases, suggesting wage levels reflect labor demand, not food costs.
summary: The second evidence: money wages remain stable for decades despite large food price fluctuations. If workers can maintain families when food is expensive, they must be above subsistence when food is cheap.
distilled: The stability of wages despite volatile food prices proves that wages are not pegged to subsistence but reflect broader labor market conditions.
notes: Second evidence for above-subsistence wages -- wage stickiness -- food price volatility vs. wage stability -- wages respond to demand, not cost of living -- nominal wage rigidity -- cross-ref 1.8.25, 1.8.27 for third evidence

refashioned: Third, while the price of food varies more from year to year than wages do, wages vary far more from place to place than food prices. The prices of bread and butcher's meat are generally the same, or very nearly so, across most of the United Kingdom. These and most other retail goods -- the way the laboring poor buy everything -- are usually at least as cheap in large cities as in remote rural areas, for reasons I will explain later. But wages in a major city and its vicinity are frequently a quarter or a fifth higher -- twenty or twenty-five percent -- than just a few miles away. Eighteenpence a day may be considered the standard price of labor in London and its neighborhood. A few miles out, it drops to fourteen or fifteen pence. Tenpence may be reckoned the going rate in Edinburgh and its surroundings. A few miles from there, it falls to eightpence -- the typical wage across most of lowland Scotland, where it varies much less than in England. Such differences in wages, which seem insufficient to motivate a person to move from one parish to another, would -- if they existed in commodity prices -- cause an enormous transportation of the bulkiest goods from one end of the kingdom to the other, quickly equalizing prices. After everything that has been said about the fickleness and inconstancy of human nature, experience makes it abundantly clear that a human being is, of all kinds of freight, the most difficult to transport. If the laboring poor can support their families in those parts of the country where wages are lowest, they must be living in genuine comfort where wages are highest.
elegant: Evidence three: wages vary dramatically between nearby locations while food prices stay roughly uniform across the country. London wages of eighteenpence drop to fourteenpence just miles away; Edinburgh's tenpence falls to eightpence nearby. But bread and meat prices are nearly identical everywhere. If workers survive where wages are lowest, they must prosper where wages are highest. The persistence of these geographic wage gaps proves that labor is far less mobile than goods -- that a human being is, as experience demonstrates, of all kinds of freight the most difficult to transport. Commodity price differences of similar magnitude would trigger enormous flows of trade that would quickly equalize them.
summary: The third evidence: wages vary much more by location than food prices. Since food costs are similar everywhere but wages differ sharply over short distances, workers earning the lowest wages are surviving while those earning the highest must be comfortable. The persistence of these gaps proves labor is far less mobile than goods.
distilled: Wages vary sharply between nearby locations while food prices are roughly uniform, proving that workers at the lowest wage levels are above subsistence and that labor is far less geographically mobile than goods.
notes: Third evidence for above-subsistence wages -- geographic wage variation vs. price uniformity -- labor immobility ('most difficult freight to transport') -- London vs. rural wages -- Edinburgh vs. rural Scotland -- retail prices equalize but wages do not -- cross-ref 1.8.26, 1.8.28 for fourth evidence

refashioned: Fourth, the variations in the price of labor do not correspond, either in place or time, with the variations in the price of food. In fact, they are frequently opposite. Grain -- the staple food of the common people -- is more expensive in Scotland than in England, since Scotland regularly imports large quantities of English corn. But English corn must sell for more in Scotland (the importing country) than in England (the exporting country), and in terms of quality it cannot be priced higher than competing Scottish grain. English grain is so much superior in flour yield that, although it often appears dearer by volume, it is usually cheaper by quality or weight. The price of labor, however, is lower in Scotland than in England. If the laboring poor can support their families in England, they must be living even better relative to their costs in the cheaper-labor regions. Oatmeal does furnish the common people of Scotland with most of their food, which is generally inferior to the diet of their English counterparts. But this dietary difference is the effect of the wage difference, not its cause. By a common misunderstanding, I have frequently heard it presented the other way around. It is not because one man keeps a coach and his neighbor walks that the first is rich and the second poor; rather, one keeps a coach because he is rich, and the other walks because he is poor.
elegant: Evidence four: wages and food prices frequently move in opposite directions. Scotland has higher grain prices than England, since it imports English corn that costs more in the receiving country. Yet Scottish wages are significantly lower than English wages. If English workers can maintain their families, the discrepancy means Scottish workers are closer to subsistence. Scotland's common diet of oatmeal -- inferior to the English diet -- is the result of lower wages, not its cause. By a frequent misapprehension, the relationship is reversed: it is not because one man keeps a coach while his neighbor walks that the first is rich and the second poor; the coach follows from wealth and the walking from poverty.
summary: The fourth evidence: food prices and wages often move in opposite directions. Scotland has higher food costs but lower wages than England. The common Scottish diet of oatmeal reflects low wages rather than causing them -- confusing cause and effect, like assuming someone is rich because they keep a coach.
distilled: Food prices and wages often move in opposite directions -- Scotland has higher food costs but lower wages -- and the inferior diet of the poor is the effect of low wages, not its cause.
notes: Fourth evidence -- inverse relationship between food prices and wages -- Scotland vs. England comparison -- oatmeal diet as effect, not cause -- the coach analogy for cause-effect confusion -- English grain superior in flour yield -- import/export grain price dynamics -- cross-ref 1.8.25-1.8.27 for other evidences, 1.8.29 for historical data

refashioned: Over the course of the last century, taking one year with another, grain was more expensive in both parts of the United Kingdom than it is in the current century. This is a matter of fact that can no longer be reasonably doubted, and the evidence is, if anything, even stronger for Scotland than for England. In Scotland, it is supported by the official records of grain prices -- annual valuations made under oath according to the actual state of markets in every county.
elegant: Grain was more expensive in the previous century than the current one, across both England and Scotland. In Scotland, this is proven by official sworn grain price records from every county.
summary: Historical grain price data, including official Scottish records, shows that grain was more expensive in the previous century than the current one, across both parts of the United Kingdom.
distilled: Official records prove that grain prices have fallen from the previous century to the current one in both England and Scotland.
notes: Historical grain price evidence -- Scottish public fiars as data source -- sworn annual valuations -- falling grain prices over the century -- empirical foundation for wages argument -- cross-ref 1.8.28, 1.8.30 on corroborating evidence

refashioned: If this direct evidence required any supporting proof, I would note that the same trend has occurred in France and probably in most of Europe. For France, the evidence is very clear. But though grain was somewhat more expensive in the last century than in the present, labor was much cheaper. If the laboring poor could raise their families then, they must be far better off now. Over the last century, the most common daily wage for ordinary labor across much of Scotland was sixpence in summer and fivepence in winter. Three shillings per week, roughly the same amount, is still paid in some parts of the Highlands and Western Islands. Across most of the Lowlands, the standard wage is now eightpence a day, with tenpence or even a shilling near Edinburgh and in the counties bordering England -- probably because of that proximity -- and in a few other places where labor demand has recently grown, such as Glasgow, Carron, and Ayrshire. In England, improvements in agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce began much earlier than in Scotland.
elegant: France and most of Europe confirm the same pattern: grain has become cheaper over the past century. Meanwhile, labor has become considerably more expensive. If workers could support their families when grain cost more and wages were much lower, they must be significantly better off now. Scottish wages have roughly doubled over the period -- from sixpence to eightpence per day across the Lowlands, with higher rates near Edinburgh and the English border, and in areas of rising labor demand like Glasgow and Ayrshire.
summary: Historical data from Scotland, England, and France shows that grain prices have fallen while wages have risen substantially over the past century. If workers could survive under worse conditions, they must be better off now.
distilled: Grain has become cheaper and wages have risen substantially over the past century, proving that the real condition of the laboring poor has improved significantly.
notes: Corroborating international evidence (France, Europe) -- Scottish wage history: sixpence to eightpence per day -- regional wage variation within Scotland -- proximity to England raises wages -- Glasgow, Carron, Ayrshire labor demand growth -- England's earlier development -- cross-ref 1.8.29, 1.8.31

refashioned: The demand for labor, and consequently its price, must have increased with those improvements. In the last century, as in the present, wages were higher in England than in Scotland. They have risen considerably since then, though the wide variety of wages paid in different English locations makes it harder to determine by how much. In 1614, the pay of a foot soldier was eightpence a day, the same as today. When it was first established, military pay would naturally have been set at the prevailing wage for common labor, since ordinary laborers are the class from which soldiers are typically recruited. Lord Chief Justice Hales, writing during the reign of Charles II, calculated the necessary expense of a laborer's family of six -- father, mother, two children old enough to contribute some work, and two who were not -- at ten shillings a week, or twenty-six pounds a year.
elegant: Wages rose alongside England's economic improvements in agriculture, manufacturing, and commerce. A foot soldier's pay has been eightpence a day since 1614, originally set to match the prevailing wages of common laborers from whose ranks soldiers are recruited. Lord Chief Justice Hales, writing under Charles II, estimated that a laboring family of six required ten shillings per week, or twenty-six pounds per year.
summary: English wages have risen alongside economic development. Historical benchmarks include the foot soldier's pay of eightpence (unchanged since 1614) and Lord Chief Justice Hales's estimate of twenty-six pounds per year for a laboring family of six.
distilled: English wages rose with economic development; historical benchmarks include the soldier's eightpence since 1614 and Hales's estimate of twenty-six pounds annually for a laboring family.
notes: Historical wage evidence for England -- soldier's pay as wage proxy -- 1614 benchmark -- Lord Chief Justice Hales family budget under Charles II -- 10 shillings/week for family of 6 -- cross-ref 1.8.30, 1.8.32 on Gregory King's estimates

refashioned: If they could not earn this amount through their labor, Hales supposed they must make it up by begging or stealing. He appears to have investigated the matter very carefully. In 1688, Gregory King -- whose skill in political arithmetic was highly praised by Dr. Davenant -- estimated the ordinary income of laborers and household servants at fifteen pounds per year per family, which he reckoned at three and a half persons on average. Despite the apparent difference, King's calculation corresponds closely with Hales's at the bottom: both assume a weekly expenditure of about twentypence per person. Both the money income and expenses of such families have increased considerably since then across most of the country -- more in some places, less in others, though perhaps nowhere as much as some recent exaggerated reports of current wages have claimed.
elegant: Hales assumed families that could not earn ten shillings weekly would beg or steal. King in 1688 estimated laborer income at fifteen pounds per year for 3.5 persons -- roughly matching Hales's twentypence per head per week. Since then, both income and expenses have risen considerably, though not as dramatically as some recent accounts suggest.
summary: Two independent historical estimates -- Hales's and Gregory King's in 1688 -- converge on about twentypence per person per week for laboring families. Both income and expenses have risen since, though contemporary reports may overstate the increase.
distilled: Two 17th-century estimates converge on twentypence per person per week for laboring families; both wages and costs have risen since, though some contemporary accounts exaggerate.
notes: Gregory King's political arithmetic (1688) -- convergence of Hales and King estimates -- twentypence per head per week -- income growth since 17th century -- caution about exaggerated contemporary wage claims -- cross-ref 1.8.31, 1.8.33 on measurement difficulties

refashioned: The price of labor, it must be noted, cannot be determined very precisely anywhere. Different prices are often paid at the same place for the same type of work, varying not only with the skill of the worker but with the generosity or strictness of the employer. Where wages are not set by law, all we can determine is the most typical rate. And experience suggests that law can never regulate wages properly, though it has often claimed to do so.
elegant: Wages are inherently imprecise: different workers earn different amounts for the same job in the same place, depending on skill and employer temperament. We can determine only the most usual rate. And experience shows that legal regulation of wages never works well, despite frequent attempts.
summary: Precise wage measurement is impossible because pay varies by worker skill and employer generosity even for the same work in the same place. Only typical rates can be identified, and attempts to regulate wages by law have consistently failed.
distilled: Wages cannot be precisely measured because they vary by worker and employer, and legal attempts to regulate them have consistently failed.
notes: Wage measurement challenges -- intra-market wage variation -- worker ability and employer temperament as factors -- skepticism of wage regulation -- only 'most usual' rate can be identified -- cross-ref 1.8.32 on historical estimates, 1.8.34 on real wages

refashioned: The real compensation of labor -- the actual quantity of necessities and comforts it can buy for the worker -- has, during the present century, increased perhaps in an even greater proportion than its money price. Not only has grain become somewhat cheaper, but many other goods that provide the working poor with a wholesome and varied diet have become much cheaper. Potatoes now cost less than half what they did thirty or forty years ago. The same is true of turnips, carrots, and cabbages -- crops that once required hand cultivation with a spade but are now commonly grown with a plough. All types of garden produce have become cheaper. Most of the apples and even the onions consumed in Britain were imported from Flanders in the last century. Great improvements in the coarser linen and woollen manufactures have given workers cheaper and better clothing, and improvements in metalworking have provided cheaper and better tools as well as many useful and agreeable household items. Soap, salt, candles, leather, and fermented drinks have indeed become more expensive, mainly due to taxes. But the quantities of these that the laboring poor actually need to consume are so small that the price increases do not offset the dramatic cheapening of so many other goods. The common complaint that luxury now extends even to the lowest ranks -- that the laboring poor refuse to be satisfied with the food, clothing, and housing that once contented them -- should convince us that it is not merely money wages but real wages that have increased.
elegant: Real wages have risen even more than money wages during the present century. Grain has become somewhat cheaper, but many other goods have become dramatically cheaper through agricultural and manufacturing improvements: potatoes cost half what they did forty years ago, vegetables once grown by hand are now ploughed, garden produce is cheaper, and improvements in linen, woollen, and metal manufacturing provide cheaper clothing, better tools, and affordable household goods. Though soap, salt, candles, and leather have risen due to taxation, the poor consume such small quantities of these that the increases are more than offset. The widespread complaint that luxury now extends even to the lowest ranks -- that workers refuse the food, clothing, and housing that once satisfied them -- is itself the strongest proof that real living standards have genuinely improved.
summary: Real wages have risen even more than money wages during the present century, as many essential goods have become cheaper through agricultural and manufacturing improvements. The common complaint about expanding luxury among the poor is itself proof of genuine improvement in living standards.
distilled: Real wages have risen even more than money wages because agricultural and manufacturing improvements have made food, clothing, and tools much cheaper, visibly improving the living standards of the laboring poor.
notes: Real vs. nominal wage growth -- multiple goods becoming cheaper (potatoes, vegetables, clothing, tools) -- tax-driven exceptions (soap, salt, candles) -- agricultural improvements (spade to plough) -- manufacturing improvements -- 'luxury extending to lowest ranks' as proof of rising living standards -- cross-ref 1.8.33, 1.8.35 on whether this is good

refashioned: Should this improvement in the condition of the lower classes be regarded as an advantage or a disadvantage to society? The answer seems obvious. Servants, laborers, and workers of every kind make up the vast majority of every large society. Whatever improves conditions for the majority can never be considered harmful to the whole. No society can truly be called flourishing and happy when the great majority of its members are poor and miserable. It is only fair, moreover, that those who feed, clothe, and house the entire population should receive enough of the product of their own labor to be themselves tolerably well fed, clothed, and housed.
elegant: Is improving the condition of the laboring majority good for society? Obviously yes. Workers are the vast majority. What benefits the majority benefits the whole. No society is flourishing when most of its members are miserable. And those who feed, clothe, and house everyone deserve a decent share of their own product.
summary: Smith argues that improving the condition of the laboring poor benefits society as a whole, since workers constitute the majority. No society is truly prosperous when most of its members are miserable, and those who produce the necessities of life deserve a fair share of them.
distilled: Improving the condition of the laboring poor -- who are the vast majority -- is unambiguously good for society, and those who produce everything deserve a decent share of it.
notes: Moral argument for worker welfare -- majority principle -- no prosperity without popular well-being -- workers deserve fair share of output -- equity argument -- one of Smith's most progressive statements -- cross-ref 1.8.34 on rising real wages, 1.8.36 on poverty and reproduction

refashioned: Poverty, though it certainly discourages marriage, does not always prevent it. It even seems to favor reproduction. A half-starved Highland woman frequently bears more than twenty children, while a well-fed woman of fashion is often unable to bear any and is generally worn out by two or three. Infertility, so common among women of high social standing, is very rare among those of lower status. Luxury, while it may inflame the desire for pleasure, seems always to weaken and frequently to destroy the capacity for reproduction.
elegant: Poverty discourages marriage but not fertility. Poor women are far more fertile than wealthy ones. Highland women bear twenty children while fashionable women manage two or three. Luxury inflames desire but weakens reproductive capacity.
summary: Poverty does not reduce fertility -- in fact, poor women are far more fertile than wealthy ones. While luxury may increase desire, it consistently weakens reproductive capacity.
distilled: Poverty does not prevent reproduction; poor women are far more fertile than wealthy women, whose luxurious living weakens their reproductive capacity.
notes: Poverty and fertility -- inverse relationship between wealth and reproduction -- Highland women example -- luxury reduces fertility -- demographic observation -- cross-ref 1.8.37 on child mortality, 1.8.38 on population and subsistence

refashioned: But while poverty does not prevent reproduction, it is extremely hostile to the survival of children. The tender plant is produced, but in such a cold soil and harsh climate it soon withers and dies. It is not uncommon, I have been told, for a Highland mother who has borne twenty children not to have two still living. Several experienced military officers have assured me that, far from being able to recruit from their soldiers' children, they have never even been able to fill their drum and fife positions from all the children born in the regiment. Yet one seldom sees finer-looking children than those around a soldiers' barracks -- very few of whom, it seems, survive to age thirteen or fourteen. In some places, half of all children die before age four; in many places, before age seven; and nearly everywhere, before age nine or ten. This enormous mortality is found overwhelmingly among the children of the common people, who cannot afford the same care as wealthier families. Though their marriages produce more children, a smaller proportion reach adulthood. In foundling hospitals and among parish-charity children, mortality is even worse.
elegant: Poverty may not prevent birth, but it devastates child survival. Highland mothers who bear twenty children may have only two survive. Around army barracks, healthy-looking children rarely reach their teens. In some places, half die before age four; in most places, before nine or ten. This mortality falls overwhelmingly on the poor, who cannot afford proper care. Though their marriages are more fruitful, a far smaller proportion of their children reach adulthood. In foundling hospitals and among parish-charity children, the mortality rates are even worse.
summary: While poverty does not reduce fertility, it causes devastating child mortality. Among the poor, half or more of all children die before reaching adulthood. This mortality is highest in foundling hospitals and lowest among wealthier families who can afford better care.
distilled: Poverty produces high fertility but devastating child mortality -- most poor children die before reaching adulthood, with foundling hospitals showing the worst survival rates.
notes: Child mortality among the poor -- Highland mother example (20 born, 2 survive) -- military regiment children -- age-specific mortality rates -- wealth-mortality gradient -- foundling hospital mortality -- population replacement challenges -- cross-ref 1.8.36 on fertility, 1.8.38 on population limits

refashioned: Every species of animal naturally multiplies in proportion to its means of subsistence, and no species can ever multiply beyond that limit. But in civilized society, it is only among the lower ranks that scarcity of subsistence limits population growth, and it does so only by destroying a large proportion of the children that their frequent pregnancies produce.
elegant: All species multiply in proportion to their food supply and cannot exceed it. In civilized society, this limit operates only among the poor, and only through the death of their children.
summary: Population is naturally limited by subsistence. In civilized society, this limit operates exclusively among the poor, through the mechanism of high child mortality.
distilled: Population growth is limited by subsistence, and in civilized society this limit operates solely through the high child mortality of the poor.
notes: Population-subsistence relationship -- Malthusian principle avant la lettre -- child mortality as population check -- operates only among the poor -- natural population limits -- cross-ref 1.8.37 on child mortality, 1.8.39 on liberal wages as solution

refashioned: The liberal reward of labor, by enabling workers to provide better for their children and consequently to raise more of them to adulthood, naturally tends to widen these population limits. It deserves emphasis that this happens in almost exactly the proportion that labor demand requires. If demand is continually increasing, the reward of labor must encourage marriage and reproduction enough to supply the growing demand with a growing population. If the reward falls below what is needed for this purpose, the resulting labor shortage quickly drives it back up. If it exceeds what is needed, the resulting population surplus quickly drives it back down. The labor market would be so understocked in the first case and so overstocked in the second that the price of labor would quickly return to the rate the economy requires. In this way, the demand for workers -- like the demand for any other commodity -- regulates the production of workers: speeding it up when it is too slow, slowing it down when it is too fast. This demand determines the pace of population growth everywhere in the world: making it rapidly progressive in North America, slow and gradual in Europe, and completely stationary in China.
elegant: Higher wages let workers raise more children to adulthood, expanding the labor supply in proportion to demand. This is a self-regulating system: if wages fall below what is needed to sustain adequate population growth, labor shortages push wages back up; if wages exceed that level, the resulting population surplus pushes them back down. The demand for labor thus regulates the production of labor, just as demand for any commodity regulates its production -- accelerating it when it falls behind and slowing it when it runs ahead. This mechanism explains population dynamics worldwide: rapid growth in North America, gradual growth in Europe, and stagnation in China.
summary: Liberal wages expand population by reducing child mortality, and this expansion self-regulates to match labor demand. Like any commodity, the production of workers accelerates when supply is short and slows when supply is excessive -- explaining rapid growth in America, gradual growth in Europe, and stagnation in China.
distilled: The demand for labor regulates the production of labor through wages: higher wages reduce child mortality and expand population, while the system self-corrects to match the economy's actual needs.
notes: Self-regulating labor market -- wages as population regulator -- demand for labor regulates production of labor -- market mechanism applied to population -- North America (progressive), Europe (gradual), China (stationary) -- one of Smith's most important insights -- cross-ref 1.8.38 on population limits, 1.8.16-1.8.23 on the three cases

refashioned: The wear and tear of a slave, it has been said, is at the expense of his master, while that of a free worker is at his own expense. In reality, however, the maintenance of the free worker is just as much at the employer's expense as that of the slave. Wages paid to workers of every kind must be sufficient for them to sustain their families and continue their race in proportion to the economy's growing, shrinking, or stable demand. But though the maintenance of a free worker costs the employer just as much in principle, it generally costs much less in practice than maintaining a slave. The fund for replacing the wear and tear of the slave is typically managed by a negligent master or a careless overseer. The fund for the same purpose with a free worker is managed by the free worker himself. The wasteful habits that generally prevail in the households of the rich naturally infect the management of slave maintenance. The strict frugality and careful economy of the poor naturally govern the self-management of the free worker. Under such different management, the same objective necessarily requires very different levels of expenditure. The experience of all ages and nations confirms, I believe, that work done by free workers comes cheaper in the end than work performed by slaves. This has proven true even in Boston, New York, and Philadelphia, where the wages of common labor are very high.
elegant: Both slave and free worker maintenance are ultimately employer costs, since free workers' wages must cover the same reproduction needs as a slave's upkeep. But the crucial difference is management: the slave's maintenance fund is handled with the negligence typical of wealthy households, while the free worker manages his own fund with the strict frugality of the poor. Under such different management, the same objective requires vastly different expenditure. The result, confirmed by the experience of all ages and nations, is that free labor is cheaper than slave labor in the end -- even in high-wage American cities like Boston, New York, and Philadelphia.
summary: Smith argues that free labor is ultimately cheaper than slave labor. Both require the employer to fund worker maintenance and reproduction, but free workers manage their funds with frugal self-interest, while slave maintenance suffers from the negligence of wealthy owners. History and experience universally confirm this.
distilled: Free labor is cheaper than slave labor because free workers manage their own maintenance with frugality, while slave upkeep is wasted through negligent management by wealthy owners.
notes: Free vs. slave labor efficiency -- self-management advantage of free labor -- rich man's wastefulness vs. poor man's frugality -- universal historical evidence -- applies even in high-wage America -- economic argument against slavery -- cross-ref 1.8.12 on subsistence wages, 1.8.39 on labor reproduction costs

refashioned: The liberal reward of labor, then, is both the effect of increasing wealth and the cause of increasing population. To complain about it is to lament the necessary cause and consequence of the greatest public prosperity. It deserves to be noted that the happiest and most comfortable condition for the laboring poor -- the great body of the people -- is the progressive state, when society is still advancing toward greater wealth, rather than after it has reached its full potential. The condition of workers is difficult in a stationary economy and miserable in a declining one. The progressive state is, in reality, the cheerful and vigorous condition for all ranks of society. The stationary state is dull. The declining state is melancholy.
elegant: High wages are both the effect and the cause of prosperity -- effect of growing wealth, cause of growing population. Complaining about them is lamenting prosperity itself. The progressive state -- still growing, not yet arrived -- is the happiest for workers and all of society. The stationary state is dull; the declining state is wretched.
summary: Smith argues that high wages both result from and contribute to prosperity, making complaints about them absurd. The happiest condition for all of society is the progressive state of active growth -- superior to both the dull stationary state and the miserable declining one.
distilled: High wages are both the effect and cause of prosperity; the progressive state of economic growth is the happiest condition for all of society, while stagnation is dull and decline is miserable.
notes: High wages as dual cause-effect of prosperity -- progressive vs. stationary vs. declining states -- progressive state as happiest for all classes -- powerful normative statement -- culmination of the three-state analysis -- cross-ref 1.8.16-1.8.23 for the three states, 1.8.42 on productivity effects

refashioned: The liberal reward of labor not only encourages population growth but also increases the productivity of ordinary workers. Wages are the incentive for effort, and like every other human quality, industriousness improves in proportion to the encouragement it receives. Ample food increases the worker's physical strength, and the hopeful prospect of improving his condition and ending his days in comfort and plenty drives him to exert that strength to the fullest. Where wages are high, we always find workers more active, diligent, and energetic than where wages are low -- in England, for example, compared to Scotland; near large towns compared to remote rural areas. Some workers, it is true, will be idle for three days if they can earn a week's maintenance in four. But this is by no means typical. On the contrary, when liberally paid by the piece, workers very often overwork themselves, ruining their health within a few years. A London carpenter is not expected to maintain full vigor beyond eight years.
