Similar patterns appear in many other trades where piece-rate payment is standard, especially in manufacturing and in country labor where wages are above average. Nearly every class of craftsman is subject to some occupational disease caused by excessive dedication to their particular work. The Italian physician Ramazzini wrote an entire book on such afflictions.
elegant: High wages increase not just population but the productivity of ordinary workers. Better-fed workers are physically stronger, and the hope of improving their condition drives them to maximum effort. High-wage regions always have more active and diligent workers. The real risk is not idleness but overwork: piece-rate workers routinely ruin their health within a few years. A London carpenter is not expected to maintain full vigor beyond eight years. Similar burnout occurs across many trades wherever piece-rate payment prevails. The Italian physician Ramazzini catalogued the occupational diseases that result from such excessive application.
summary: Higher wages boost worker productivity through better nutrition and stronger motivation. The greater risk from high wages is not idleness but overwork -- piece-rate workers frequently destroy their health within a few years, as documented across many trades.
distilled: Higher wages increase worker productivity through better health and stronger motivation, and the real danger is not idleness but overwork that ruins health.
notes: Efficiency wage theory avant la lettre -- wages as incentive for effort -- nutrition and strength -- hope and motivation -- overwork as bigger risk than idleness -- piece-rate burnout -- London carpenter 8-year vigor -- Ramazzini's De Morbis Artificum -- occupational health -- cross-ref 1.8.41, 1.8.43 on overwork

refashioned: We do not consider soldiers the most industrious people among us. Yet when soldiers have been employed in particular types of work and paid liberally by the piece, their officers have frequently had to negotiate with the contractor that the soldiers should not be allowed to earn more than a certain amount per day. Before such limits were imposed, mutual competition and the desire for greater earnings frequently drove them to overwork and damage their health through excessive labor. Excessive effort for four days of the week is frequently the real cause of the idleness during the other three that is so loudly complained about. Intense labor, whether physical or mental, sustained over several days, is naturally followed in most people by an overwhelming desire for rest and relaxation -- a desire that, if not forcibly restrained or compelled by urgent necessity, is almost impossible to resist.
elegant: Even soldiers -- not known for industriousness -- overwork when paid by the piece, forcing officers to cap their daily earnings. Intense effort for four days causes the idleness of the remaining three. Prolonged hard work creates an almost irresistible need for rest that, without external constraint, will be indulged.
summary: Smith uses the example of piece-rate soldiers who overwork to the point of damaging their health, requiring officers to cap their earnings. The idleness commonly complained about is actually the natural recovery from excessive effort -- intense work for four days causes rest for three.
distilled: Excessive effort during working days -- not laziness -- is the real cause of workers' idle days, as even soldiers overwork when paid by the piece.
notes: Overwork causes compensatory rest -- soldiers as example of piece-rate overwork -- officers forced to cap earnings -- four-day intensity causes three-day rest -- reframing 'idleness' as recovery -- cross-ref 1.8.42 on overwork, 1.8.44 on moderation

refashioned: It is the call of nature, which demands relief through some indulgence -- sometimes simple rest, sometimes active recreation and amusement. If this need is not met, the consequences are often dangerous and sometimes fatal, and they almost always eventually produce the occupational diseases specific to the trade. If employers would consistently listen to the dictates of reason and humanity, they would more often need to moderate than to stimulate the efforts of many of their workers. I believe it will be found, in every type of trade, that the worker who works at a moderate, sustainable pace -- able to work consistently day after day -- not only preserves his health the longest but also produces the greatest total output over the course of a year.
elegant: The body demands rest after exertion -- deny it, and the result is illness or death, usually in the form of occupational disease. Enlightened employers should restrain overwork rather than demand more effort. In every trade, the worker who maintains a moderate, sustainable pace produces the most over a full year while best preserving his health.
summary: Smith argues that the body's need for rest after intense effort is a law of nature that cannot be safely ignored. Wise employers should moderate rather than maximize effort, since the worker who maintains a sustainable pace produces the most over time.
distilled: Sustainable moderate effort produces greater annual output than intense overwork, and wise employers should restrain rather than encourage excessive labor.
notes: Sustainable pace maximizes annual output -- moderation over intensity -- employer's duty of reason and humanity -- occupational disease prevention -- natural need for recovery -- proto-occupational health argument -- cross-ref 1.8.42-1.8.43 on overwork, 1.8.45 on cheap vs. dear years

refashioned: In cheap years, it is claimed, workers are generally more idle, and in expensive years more industrious than usual. A plentiful subsistence, the argument goes, makes workers lazy, while scarcity sharpens their effort. That slightly more abundance than usual may make some individual workers idle cannot be denied. But the claim that it has this effect on the majority -- that people generally work better when they are poorly fed than when well fed, when they are discouraged rather than in good spirits, when they are frequently sick rather than in good health -- seems highly improbable. Years of high food prices, it should be noted, are generally years of widespread sickness and death among the common people, which cannot fail to reduce the total output of their labor.
elegant: The conventional wisdom that cheap food makes workers lazy and dear food makes them industrious is largely wrong. A few may slack off with more abundance, but the majority cannot possibly work better when hungry, sick, and demoralized. Years of high food prices are years of sickness and death that reduce total output.
summary: Smith rejects the common claim that cheap food makes workers lazy. While a few individuals may work less with greater abundance, the majority cannot perform better when hungry, ill, and demoralized. High food prices bring sickness and mortality that reduce total output.
distilled: The claim that scarcity makes workers more industrious is largely false -- hungry, sick, and demoralized workers produce less, and dear years bring disease and death that reduce total output.
notes: Refutation of 'scarcity increases effort' thesis -- well-fed workers more productive -- dear years bring sickness and mortality -- reduced output in famine years -- humanitarian and economic argument aligned -- cross-ref 1.8.42 on wages and productivity, 1.8.44 on sustainable work

refashioned: In years of plenty, servants frequently leave their masters and trust their survival to what they can earn through their own efforts. But the same cheapness of food, by enlarging the fund available for maintaining servants, encourages masters -- especially farmers -- to hire more workers. Farmers in such times expect greater profit from their grain by feeding additional laborers than by selling it cheaply at market. The demand for servants therefore increases just as the number willing to serve decreases. For this reason, the price of labor often rises in cheap years.
elegant: In plentiful years, servants leave their masters to work independently, while cheap food encourages employers -- especially farmers -- to hire more hands. As demand for workers rises and supply falls, wages increase in times of plenty.
summary: Cheap food years cause servants to leave for independent work while simultaneously encouraging employers to hire more, creating a labor shortage that drives wages up.
distilled: Years of plenty raise wages because workers leave service for independence while employers expand their workforces.
notes: Counterintuitive labor market dynamics -- cheap provisions raise rather than lower wages. Cross-reference 1.8.47 for the opposite dynamic in scarce years. Demonstrates early supply-and-demand analysis of labor markets. The 'fund for maintaining servants' anticipates the wages-fund doctrine later developed by classical economists.

refashioned: In years of scarcity, the difficulty and uncertainty of making a living drive independent workers eagerly back into service. But the high price of food, by shrinking the funds available for paying servants, encourages masters to reduce rather than increase their workforce. In expensive years, poor independent workers frequently exhaust the small capital they had used to supply themselves with materials, and are forced to become hired laborers for bare survival. More people seek employment than can easily find it; many accept lower terms than usual. The wages of both servants and hired workers therefore frequently fall in expensive years.
elegant: In scarce years, independent workers return to service seeking security, while high food prices shrink employers' budgets for labor. With more people competing for fewer positions, wages for both servants and hired workers fall.
summary: Scarcity reverses the dynamic of plenty: independent workers return to service while employers cut staff, creating a labor surplus that depresses wages.
distilled: Years of scarcity lower wages because desperate workers flood the labor market while employers cut back on hiring.
notes: Mirror image of 1.8.46 -- scarcity depresses wages despite raising food costs. Independent workers losing their capital and becoming wage laborers illustrates downward economic mobility. The dynamic of workers 'bidding against one another' for employment is an early articulation of labor market competition.

refashioned: Masters of all kinds therefore strike better bargains with their workers in expensive years than in cheap ones, and find them more humble and dependent in the former than the latter. They naturally praise expensive years as better for industry. Landlords and farmers -- two of the largest classes of employers -- have an additional reason to welcome high prices: the rents of the former and the profits of the latter depend heavily on the price of food. Nothing, however, is more absurd than to suppose that people generally work less when they work for themselves than when they work for others. A poor independent worker will usually be more industrious than even a hired laborer paid by the piece. The independent worker keeps the entire product of his own labor; the hired man shares it with his master. The independent worker, in his separate state, is also less exposed to the temptations of bad company that so frequently corrupt workers in large factories. The superiority of the independent worker over those servants hired by the month or year -- whose wages remain the same whether they work hard or barely at all -- is likely to be even greater. Cheap years tend to increase the proportion of independent workers relative to hired laborers and servants, while expensive years tend to decrease it.
elegant: Masters find workers more compliant in expensive years and therefore praise scarcity as good for industry. Landlords and farmers prefer high prices because their rents and profits depend on them. But the claim that people work harder under masters than for themselves is absurd. Independent workers are generally more industrious -- they keep their full product, avoid the corrupting influence of large workplaces, and face stronger incentives than salaried servants whose pay is fixed regardless of effort. Cheap years increase the share of independent workers; dear years reduce it.
summary: Employers prefer scarce years because workers are more submissive and food prices boost rents and profits. But independent workers are generally more industrious than hired ones, since they keep their full product and face stronger incentives. Cheap years increase the proportion of independent workers.
distilled: Employers wrongly praise scarcity as good for industry, when in fact independent workers -- whose numbers grow in cheap years -- are inherently more productive than hired servants.
notes: Smith challenges employer class bias -- the preference for 'dear years' reflects self-interest, not economic truth. The argument for independent workers' superior productivity anticipates modern discussions of entrepreneurship and incentive alignment. The observation about 'bad company' in large manufactories reflects 18th-century moral concerns about factory life. Cross-reference 1.8.46-47 for the cheap/dear year wage dynamics.

refashioned: A French author of considerable knowledge and ingenuity, Monsieur Messance, a tax official in the district of Saint-Etienne, attempted to demonstrate that the poor do more work in cheap years than in expensive ones. He compared the quantity and value of goods produced under different conditions in three manufactures: a coarse woolen operation at Elbeuf, and linen and silk operations spread across the whole region of Rouen. According to his data, copied from public registers, the quantity and value of goods in all three factories was generally greater in cheap years than in expensive ones -- always highest in the cheapest years and lowest in the dearest. All three appear to have been stable industries whose output, though varying year to year, was neither consistently growing nor declining overall.
elegant: Monsieur Messance, a French tax official, tried to prove that the poor produce more in cheap years by comparing output in three stable manufactures -- coarse wool at Elbeuf, and linen and silk across the Rouen region. Public records showed that production was generally higher in cheap years and always highest in the cheapest, lowest in the dearest.
summary: French researcher Messance used public manufacturing records to argue that workers produce more when food is cheap, finding output consistently higher in plentiful years across three stable industries.
distilled: Messance's data from three French manufactures showed that production was consistently greater in cheap years than in expensive ones.
notes: Messance's 'Recherches sur la population' (1766) was an important early work of economic statistics. Smith uses this evidence to support his argument that cheap food benefits rather than harms productivity. The distinction between 'stationary' and growing manufactures matters -- see 1.8.50 for growing industries where the pattern is less clear. Early example of empirical economic research using government records.

refashioned: The Scottish linen manufacture and the coarse woolen manufacture of the West Riding of Yorkshire are growing industries whose output is generally -- though with some fluctuations -- increasing in both quantity and value. When I examined the published accounts of their annual production, I could not find any consistent connection between output variations and whether seasons were expensive or cheap. In 1740, a year of extreme scarcity, both industries did decline sharply. But in 1756, another year of great scarcity, the Scottish manufactures actually grew faster than usual. The Yorkshire industry did decline that year, and its output did not recover to 1755 levels until 1766, after the repeal of the American Stamp Act. That year and the next, output greatly exceeded all previous records, and it has continued to grow ever since.
elegant: In growing industries like Scottish linen and Yorkshire woolens, output fluctuations show no consistent link to food prices. While both declined in the scarce year of 1740, Scottish output actually grew in the equally scarce year of 1756. Yorkshire's recovery after 1756 owed more to the repeal of the American Stamp Act than to food prices.
summary: Growing manufactures like Scottish linen and Yorkshire woolens show no consistent link between output and food prices. External factors such as trade policy -- like the repeal of the Stamp Act -- matter more than seasonal abundance or scarcity.
distilled: In growing industries, output fluctuations correlate more with trade conditions and policy than with the cheapness or dearness of provisions.
notes: Important empirical qualification of Messance's findings in 1.8.49 -- the pattern holds only for stationary industries, not growing ones. The American Stamp Act (1765) and its repeal (1766) are cited as evidence that trade policy, not food prices, drives manufacturing growth. Cross-reference 1.8.51 for further explanation of why distant-sale manufactures respond to demand conditions rather than local food prices.

refashioned: The output of all major manufactures producing for distant markets must necessarily depend less on local food prices than on the conditions affecting demand in the countries where their goods are consumed -- on peace or war, on the prosperity or decline of rival manufacturers, and on the mood of their principal customers. A great deal of the extra work done in cheap years, moreover, never appears in public manufacturing records. Male servants who leave their masters become independent laborers. Women return to their families and commonly spin to make clothes for themselves and their households. Even independent workers do not always produce for public sale but are employed by neighbors making goods for family use. The output of all this labor therefore makes no appearance in those public records which are sometimes published with great fanfare, and from which merchants and manufacturers would often presume to announce the prosperity or decline of entire empires.
elegant: Output of manufactures for distant sale depends on demand conditions abroad -- peace or war, rival industries, customer sentiment -- not on local food prices. Much extra work in cheap years goes unrecorded: servants become independent laborers, women spin for their families, and workers produce for neighbors rather than for market. Public manufacturing records, despite being published with great fanfare, capture only a fraction of actual economic activity.
summary: Export manufactures depend on foreign demand conditions, not local food prices. Much productive work in cheap years -- independent labor, household spinning, neighbor-to-neighbor production -- never enters public records, making official statistics unreliable indicators of national prosperity.
distilled: Manufacturing output depends on foreign demand rather than local food prices, and much productive labor in cheap years goes entirely unrecorded in official statistics.
notes: Early critique of GDP-style measurement -- Smith recognizes that official records miss substantial economic activity, especially household production and informal labor. The insight that export industries respond to international demand conditions rather than domestic food prices is foundational to trade theory. Smith's skepticism about manufacturing statistics anticipates modern debates over economic indicators. Cross-reference 1.8.49-50 for the data he is qualifying.

refashioned: Although variations in the price of labor do not always correspond with changes in food prices -- and are frequently the opposite -- we should not conclude that food prices have no influence on wages. The money price of labor is necessarily determined by two factors: the demand for labor and the price of the necessities and conveniences of life. The demand for labor -- depending on whether it is increasing, stable, or declining, and thus requiring a growing, stable, or shrinking population -- determines what quantity of necessities and conveniences must be provided to the worker. The money price of labor is then determined by what it costs to purchase that quantity. So while money wages may sometimes be high when food is cheap, they would be even higher, given the same demand for labor, if food prices were high.
elegant: Though wages and food prices often move in opposite directions, food prices do influence wages. Money wages are determined by two factors: labor demand and the cost of necessities. Demand determines what real quantity of goods must go to workers; food prices determine what those goods cost in money terms. When food is cheap and wages are high, wages would be still higher if food were expensive, all else being equal.
summary: Money wages are determined by both labor demand and food prices. While wages often move opposite to food prices due to demand effects, wages would always be higher at any given level of demand if food prices were also higher.
distilled: Food prices and labor demand jointly determine money wages -- wages may rise when food is cheap due to increased demand, but would be even higher if food were expensive.
notes: Key theoretical synthesis resolving the apparent paradox of 1.8.46-48. Smith distinguishes between real wages (quantity of goods) and money wages (nominal price), a distinction central to classical economics. The two-factor model (demand + cost of living) anticipates later wage theories. Cross-reference 1.8.53-54 for further elaboration on how these two forces interact in years of sudden plenty and scarcity.

refashioned: It is because the demand for labor increases in years of sudden and extraordinary plenty, and decreases in years of sudden and extraordinary scarcity, that money wages sometimes rise in the one case and fall in the other. In a year of sudden and extraordinary plenty, many employers find themselves with funds sufficient to maintain and employ a greater number of workers than the previous year, and this extra number cannot always be found. Those masters who want more workers bid against one another to obtain them, which sometimes raises both the real and money price of their labor.
elegant: In years of sudden plenty, employers have surplus funds to hire more workers than the previous year, but the extra workers cannot always be found. Competing employers bid against each other for available labor, raising both real and money wages.
summary: Sudden plenty gives employers extra funds to expand their workforce, but the supply of workers cannot increase immediately. The resulting competition among employers drives wages up.
distilled: Sudden plenty raises wages because employers' expanded funds compete for a labor supply that cannot grow as quickly.
notes: Illustrates the short-run inelasticity of labor supply -- population and workforce cannot adjust immediately to demand shocks. The bidding mechanism among employers is a clear articulation of demand-side wage determination. Cross-reference 1.8.54 for the opposite case. The distinction between 'sudden' and gradual changes is important -- sudden shocks create temporary disequilibria.

refashioned: The opposite happens in a year of sudden and extraordinary scarcity. The funds available for employing workers are smaller than the previous year. A considerable number of people are thrown out of work and bid against one another to find employment, which sometimes lowers both the real and money price of labor. In 1740, a year of extraordinary scarcity, many people were willing to work for bare subsistence. In the plentiful years that followed, it was harder to find laborers and servants. The scarcity of an expensive year, by reducing the demand for labor, tends to push wages down, while the high price of food tends to push them up. The plenty of a cheap year, by increasing demand, tends to push wages up, while the cheapness of food tends to push them down. In the ordinary fluctuations of food prices, these two opposing forces seem to roughly cancel each other out, which is probably part of the reason why wages are everywhere much more stable and steady than food prices.
elegant: In years of sudden scarcity, shrinking employment funds throw workers into competition for fewer jobs, lowering wages -- as in 1740, when many worked for bare subsistence. Two opposing forces operate on wages: scarcity reduces labor demand (pushing wages down) while raising food costs (pushing wages up); plenty does the reverse. In normal fluctuations, these forces roughly cancel out, which is why wages are far more stable than food prices.
summary: Sudden scarcity lowers wages as unemployed workers compete for fewer jobs. In ordinary years, two opposing forces -- demand effects and cost-of-living effects -- roughly cancel each other out, explaining why wages are much more stable than food prices.
distilled: Wages remain more stable than food prices because the demand effects and cost-of-living effects of price changes tend to offset each other in normal years.
notes: The 1740 famine is a recurring reference point -- one of the worst subsistence crises in 18th-century Britain. The 'two opposing forces' framework is an elegant early model of wage determination under competing pressures. Smith's explanation for wage stability relative to price volatility anticipates modern macroeconomic analysis of wage stickiness. This paragraph synthesizes the entire argument of 1.8.46-53.

refashioned: Rising wages necessarily increase the price of many goods by enlarging the wage component of their cost, tending to reduce consumption both at home and abroad. However, the same force that raises wages -- the growth of capital -- also tends to increase labor's productive power, enabling a smaller amount of labor to produce a greater quantity of output. The owner of a large stock of capital who employs many workers will naturally, in his own interest, arrange the division and distribution of tasks so that workers produce the greatest possible output. For the same reason, he strives to equip them with the best machinery he or they can devise. What happens among workers in a particular workshop happens, for the same reason, among those of an entire society. The greater their number, the more naturally they divide into different classes and specialized occupations. More minds are engaged in inventing the best machinery for each type of work, and so better machines are more likely to be invented. Many goods therefore come to be produced with so much less labor than before that the increase in its price is more than offset by the reduction in the quantity needed.
elegant: Rising wages increase prices by raising costs, but the same capital accumulation that raises wages also increases productivity. Employers divide labor more efficiently and invest in better machinery as their workforce grows. Across society, more workers mean more specialization and more minds inventing better tools. The result is that many goods require so much less labor to produce that their falling labor-quantity more than compensates for its rising price.
summary: Although rising wages raise production costs, the capital growth behind wage increases also drives productivity gains through better division of labor and machinery. For many goods, the reduction in labor required more than offsets the increase in labor's price.
distilled: Rising wages are offset by the productivity gains -- through specialization and better machinery -- that accompany the same capital accumulation driving wages up.
notes: Connects the wages argument to the division of labor from Book I, Ch. 1-3. This is Smith's answer to mercantilist concerns about high wages destroying competitiveness. The 'quantity of labor vs. price of labor' distinction anticipates the productivity-adjusted unit labor cost concept in modern economics. Cross-reference 1.1 on division of labor and 1.10.25 on the compounding effects of profit increases vs. wage increases.

refashioned: The rise and fall of profits on capital depend on the same causes as the rise and fall of wages -- the increasing or declining wealth of the society -- but those causes affect the two very differently. The growth of capital, which raises wages, tends to lower profits. When the capital of many wealthy merchants is invested in the same trade, their mutual competition naturally drives down its profit; and when there is a similar increase of capital across all the different trades in a society, the same competition produces the same effect throughout.
elegant: Profits and wages respond to the same cause -- changes in national wealth -- but in opposite directions. Growing capital raises wages but lowers profits, because more capital in any trade means more competition, and more competition means lower returns.
summary: Profits and wages are driven by the same force -- the growth or decline of national wealth -- but in opposite directions. Capital accumulation raises wages by increasing demand for labor while lowering profits through intensified competition.
distilled: Capital growth raises wages but lowers profits, because more capital in any trade intensifies competition and drives down returns.
notes: Opens Chapter 9 -- 'Of the Profits of Stock.' Establishes the inverse relationship between wages and profits that is central to classical economics. The competition mechanism is key: profits fall not because individual businesses become less efficient, but because more businesses compete for the same customers. Cross-reference 1.8 for the parallel treatment of wages. This inverse wages-profit relationship was later formalized by Ricardo.

refashioned: It has already been observed that it is difficult to determine average wages even in a particular place and time. We can seldom establish more than the most common wages. But even this is rarely possible for profits on capital. Profit fluctuates so much that a person engaged in a particular trade often cannot tell you his own average annual profit. It is affected not only by every price change in the goods he deals in, but by the fortune of his rivals and his customers, and by a thousand other accidents to which goods are liable whether transported by sea or land, or even stored in a warehouse. Profit therefore varies not only from year to year, but from day to day, and almost from hour to hour. To determine the average profit across all trades in a great nation must be far more difficult; and to judge what it may have been in former times or distant periods, with any precision, is altogether impossible.
elegant: Determining average profits is far harder than determining average wages. Profits fluctuate so wildly -- affected by price changes, competitors' fortunes, customer behavior, and countless accidents -- that even individual traders often cannot state their own average annual return. Calculating average profit across an entire nation is vastly more difficult, and estimating historical profit rates is simply impossible.
summary: Average profits are nearly impossible to measure precisely because they fluctuate constantly due to price changes, competition, accidents, and other variables. Even individual merchants struggle to state their own average returns, let alone calculate national averages or historical rates.
distilled: Profits are far more volatile and harder to measure than wages, fluctuating daily with prices, competition, and countless accidents.
notes: Smith's candor about measurement difficulties is characteristic of his empiricism. The passage highlights the fundamental asymmetry between wages (relatively stable and observable) and profits (volatile and opaque). This measurement problem persists in modern economics -- corporate profitability data remains noisy and subject to accounting conventions. Cross-reference 1.9.3 for Smith's proposed proxy: interest rates.

refashioned: Although it may be impossible to determine average profits with any precision, either currently or historically, some idea of them can be formed from the interest rate on money. It can be stated as a general principle that wherever a great deal can be earned by using money, a great deal will commonly be paid for the use of it; and wherever little can be earned, little will be paid. As the prevailing market interest rate varies in any country, we can be confident that ordinary profits must vary with it -- falling as it falls, and rising as it rises. The history of interest rates, therefore, can give us some idea of the history of profits.
elegant: Though profits cannot be measured directly, interest rates serve as a useful proxy. Where money can earn high returns, borrowers will pay high interest; where returns are low, interest will be low too. The movement of interest rates therefore tracks the movement of profits.
summary: Interest rates serve as a proxy for unmeasurable profit rates. Since borrowers pay for money in proportion to what they can earn with it, changes in interest rates reflect changes in the underlying profitability of trade.
distilled: Interest rates serve as the best available proxy for profit rates, since the price of borrowed money reflects what can be earned by using it.
notes: Introduces Smith's key methodological innovation for tracking profit trends historically. The logic is straightforward: interest is the price of borrowed capital, and that price reflects capital's earning power. This proxy approach has limitations Smith acknowledges elsewhere -- legal interest rate caps, risk premiums, and institutional factors can distort the relationship. Cross-reference 1.9.4 for the historical interest rate data.

refashioned: Under Henry VIII, all interest above ten percent was declared unlawful. It seems that higher rates had sometimes been charged before that. Under Edward VI, religious zeal prohibited all interest entirely. This ban, however, like all others of its kind, reportedly had no effect and probably increased rather than decreased the problem of usury. Henry VIII's statute was revived under Elizabeth I, and ten percent remained the legal rate until James I, when it was lowered to eight percent. It was reduced to six percent soon after the Restoration, and to five percent under Queen Anne. All these statutory changes seem to have been made wisely. They appear to have followed, rather than preceded, the market rate of interest -- the rate at which creditworthy people actually borrowed. Since Queen Anne's time, five percent seems to have been somewhat above the market rate. Before the recent war, the government borrowed at three percent, and people of good credit in London and many other parts of the country borrowed at three and a half, four, or four and a half percent.
elegant: English interest rate caps fell steadily: ten percent under Henry VIII, eight under James I, six after the Restoration, five under Queen Anne. These laws wisely followed rather than led the market rate. Since Queen Anne, five percent has been above the market rate -- before the late war, the government borrowed at three percent and creditworthy private borrowers at three and a half to four and a half percent.
summary: England's legal interest rate ceiling fell progressively from ten percent to five percent over two centuries. These statutory caps wisely followed the market rate rather than trying to lead it. By the mid-18th century, actual borrowing rates were well below the five percent ceiling.
distilled: England's legal interest rate fell from ten percent under Henry VIII to five percent under Queen Anne, tracking the market rate's steady decline as the nation grew wealthier.
notes: Historical survey of English usury laws from Henry VIII (1545) through Queen Anne (1714). Smith approves of these regulations because they followed market trends rather than attempting to dictate them -- a key distinction in his regulatory philosophy. Edward VI's total prohibition (1552) illustrates Smith's view that outright bans backfire. The pre-war government borrowing rate of 3% indicates substantial capital accumulation. Cross-reference 1.9.5 for the economic interpretation.

refashioned: Since the time of Henry VIII, the wealth and income of the country have been continually advancing, and their pace seems to have been gradually accelerating rather than slowing. The economy appears not only to have been growing, but growing faster and faster. Wages have been continually rising during the same period, and in most branches of trade and manufacturing, the profits on capital have been declining.
elegant: Since Henry VIII, England's wealth has grown at an accelerating pace. Wages have risen continually while profits in most trades have declined -- the twin consequences of sustained capital accumulation.
summary: England's wealth has grown at an accelerating rate since Henry VIII. This growth has continually raised wages while steadily lowering profits across most trades and manufactures.
distilled: England's accelerating wealth since the 16th century has steadily raised wages and lowered profits -- the expected results of sustained capital growth.
notes: Concise summary of two centuries of English economic development. The simultaneous rise of wages and fall of profits confirms the theoretical framework of 1.9.1. The claim of 'accelerating' growth is notable -- Smith saw the 18th century as experiencing faster growth than previous centuries, presaging the Industrial Revolution then underway. Cross-reference 1.8 on rising wages and 1.9.3-4 on declining interest rates as profit proxies.

refashioned: It generally takes more capital to operate any type of business in a large city than in a country village. The large amounts of capital employed in every line of business, and the number of wealthy competitors, generally push profit rates lower in cities than in villages. But wages are generally higher in large cities than in villages. In a thriving city, those with substantial capital to employ frequently cannot find as many workers as they want, and so they bid against one another to hire as many as possible, raising wages and lowering profits. In remote parts of the country, there is often not enough capital to employ all the people, who therefore bid against one another for work, lowering wages and raising profits.
elegant: Large cities require more capital per business and have more wealthy competitors, pushing profits below village levels. But city wages are higher because employers with abundant capital compete for scarce workers. In remote areas, the reverse holds: insufficient capital means workers compete for jobs, raising profits and lowering wages.
summary: Cities have lower profits and higher wages than villages because abundant capital creates employer competition for workers. Rural areas have higher profits and lower wages because insufficient capital forces workers to compete for scarce employment.
distilled: Cities exhibit higher wages and lower profits than villages because capital abundance shifts bargaining power from employers to workers.
notes: Geographical application of the inverse wages-profit relationship from 1.9.1. The 'bidding' mechanism works symmetrically: employers bid for workers in capital-rich cities, workers bid for jobs in capital-poor countryside. This urban-rural wage differential persists in modern economies. Cross-reference 1.8.36-37 on high wages in prosperous cities.

refashioned: In Scotland, although the legal interest rate is the same as in England, the market rate is somewhat higher. People with the best credit there rarely borrow below five percent. Even private bankers in Edinburgh pay four percent on their promissory notes, which can be redeemed in whole or in part on demand. Private bankers in London pay no interest on deposits at all. There are few trades that cannot be carried on with less capital in Scotland than in England. The typical rate of profit must therefore be somewhat higher in Scotland.
elegant: Scotland's market interest rate exceeds England's despite identical legal caps -- Edinburgh bankers pay four percent on deposits while London bankers pay nothing. Since Scottish trades require less capital, profit rates must be higher there, confirming that less-developed economies yield higher returns on smaller capital stocks.
summary: Scotland's higher market interest rates and higher bank deposit rates compared to England indicate higher profit rates, consistent with Scotland being a less wealthy economy with less capital competing in each trade.
distilled: Scotland's higher interest rates reveal higher profit rates, reflecting less accumulated capital and less competition than in wealthier England.
notes: Comparative case study supporting the theory that capital abundance lowers profits. The Edinburgh vs. London banking comparison is particularly telling -- deposit rates directly reflect how much banks can earn by lending. Scotland's lower capital stock means less competition per trade, sustaining higher margins. Cross-reference 1.9.6 on urban vs. rural dynamics and 1.9.8 for the wage comparison.

refashioned: Wages, as already observed, are lower in Scotland than in England. Scotland is not only much poorer, but its progress toward prosperity, though clearly occurring, seems much slower and more hesitant. In France, the legal interest rate has not always followed the market rate during the present century. In 1720, interest was cut from five to two percent. In 1724, it was raised to three and a third percent. In 1725, it was raised again to five percent. In 1766, under the administration of Monsieur Laverdy, it was reduced to four percent.
elegant: Scottish wages are lower than English ones, consistent with Scotland's lesser wealth and slower progress. France's legal interest rate, unlike England's, has fluctuated erratically -- from five to two percent in 1720, back up to five in 1725, then down to four in 1766 -- often diverging from market rates rather than following them.
summary: Scotland's lower wages confirm its lesser wealth and slower growth compared to England. France's interest rate history shows erratic government manipulation rather than the gradual market-following approach that characterized English policy.
distilled: Scotland's lower wages reflect its lesser wealth, while France's erratic interest rate changes illustrate the hazards of government interference with market rates.
notes: Continues the international comparison: Scotland (poorer, higher profits, lower wages) vs. England (wealthier, lower profits, higher wages). France's volatile interest rate policy contrasts unfavorably with England's gradual, market-following approach described in 1.9.4. Laverdy was Controller-General of Finances 1763-1768. Cross-reference 1.9.9 for further analysis of French conditions.

refashioned: The Abbe Terray afterward raised the rate back to the old five percent. Many of these forced reductions in interest were supposedly intended to prepare the way for reducing the public debt -- a purpose sometimes actually carried out. France is perhaps not as wealthy a country as England in present times; and though France's legal interest rate has frequently been lower than England's, the market rate has generally been higher, since the French, like people in other countries, have found numerous easy ways to evade the law. Profits on trade, I have been told by British merchants who traded in both countries, are higher in France than in England. It is no doubt for this reason that many British investors choose to employ their capital in a country where trade is held in contempt rather than in one where it is highly respected.
elegant: France's frequent forced interest rate reductions aimed to shrink public debt. Despite often having a lower legal rate than England, France's market rate was generally higher -- the law was easily evaded. British merchants confirmed that trade profits were higher in France, which is why some British investors preferred deploying capital in France, where trade was socially despised, over England, where it was respected.
summary: France's legal interest rate was often below England's, but its market rate was higher because the law was routinely evaded. Higher French profits attracted British capital, illustrating how actual returns matter more than legal frameworks or social attitudes toward commerce.
distilled: France's higher market interest rates and trade profits -- despite lower legal caps -- attracted British capital and exposed the futility of trying to legislate rates below their natural level.
notes: Abbe Terray was Controller-General 1769-1774, known for aggressive fiscal measures. The irony of British capital flowing to France -- where trade was socially despised -- because profits were higher is a classic Smithian observation about how self-interest overrides cultural attitudes. Law evasion demonstrates Smith's principle that regulation cannot override market forces. Cross-reference 1.9.4 for the contrast with England's more successful regulatory approach.

refashioned: Wages are lower in France than in England. When you travel from Scotland to England, the difference in the dress and appearance of ordinary people in each country makes their different conditions obvious. The contrast is even starker when you return from France. France, though undoubtedly wealthier than Scotland, does not seem to be advancing as rapidly. A common and even popular opinion in France holds that the country is going backward -- an opinion I believe is unfounded even for France, but one that nobody could possibly hold about Scotland who has seen the country now and who saw it twenty or thirty years ago.
elegant: French wages are lower than English wages. The visible difference in prosperity between ordinary people in Scotland and England becomes even more striking when comparing France to England. France, though richer than Scotland, appears to be advancing more slowly. The popular French belief that their country is declining is likely wrong, but no one could hold such a view about Scotland given its obvious recent progress.
summary: France's lower wages and the visible poverty of its common people indicate slower economic progress than England's. While the French popular belief in national decline is probably mistaken, the contrast with Scotland's obvious recent advancement is telling.
distilled: Lower French wages and the visibly poorer condition of French common people reveal slower economic progress than in England, despite France's greater overall wealth.
notes: Smith uses personal travel observations as empirical evidence -- a characteristic method. The comparison across three countries (Scotland, England, France) creates a spectrum: Scotland poorer but advancing visibly, England wealthiest and advancing fastest, France wealthier than Scotland but advancing more slowly. The 'twenty or thirty years ago' reference to Scotland suggests Smith observed rapid Scottish development from roughly the 1740s-1770s. Cross-reference 1.8 on wages as indicators of national prosperity.

refashioned: Holland, on the other hand, relative to the size of its territory and population, is wealthier than England. The Dutch government borrows at two percent, and creditworthy private individuals at three. Wages are reportedly higher in Holland than in England, and the Dutch are well known to trade on lower profit margins than any other people in Europe. Some claim that Dutch trade is declining, and it may be true that certain branches are. But these symptoms clearly indicate no general decline. When profits shrink, merchants invariably complain that trade is decaying, even though falling profits are the natural result of prosperity -- of more capital being employed than before. During the recent war, the Dutch captured the entire carrying trade of France, a large share of which they still hold. The substantial property they own in both French and English government bonds -- reportedly around forty million in the latter, though I suspect considerable exaggeration -- and the large sums they lend to private borrowers in countries with higher interest rates all demonstrate a surplus of capital that has outgrown what they can profitably employ at home. But this does not prove that their domestic business has declined. Just as a private individual's capital, though originally earned in a particular trade, may grow beyond what that trade can employ while the trade itself continues to expand, so too may the capital of a great nation.
elegant: Holland, proportionally wealthier than England, borrows at two percent government and three percent private -- with higher wages and lower profits than any European nation. Merchants complain trade is 'decaying,' but shrinking profits are the natural sign of prosperity and capital abundance. Dutch investments abroad -- in French and English bonds, and private lending where rates are higher -- show surplus capital, not declining business. Just as a private fortune can outgrow a particular trade while that trade still thrives, so can a nation's capital.
summary: Holland exemplifies the most advanced stage of capital accumulation: the lowest profits and interest rates in Europe, the highest wages, and surplus capital invested abroad. Merchants mistake falling profits for declining trade, when in fact declining profits are the natural consequence of accumulated wealth and intensified competition.
distilled: Holland's rock-bottom interest rates, highest wages, and massive foreign investments exemplify how capital abundance naturally lowers profits while merchants wrongly mistake shrinking margins for declining trade.
notes: Holland serves as Smith's model of an advanced economy approaching capital saturation. The 2% government borrowing rate was remarkably low by 18th-century standards. Smith's insight that merchants confuse falling profits with declining trade is penetrating -- the same complaint recurs in every era of economic maturity. The distinction between capital outgrowing domestic employment and trade actually declining is crucial. Cross-reference 1.9.17 on the theoretical 'fully stocked' economy and 1.9.22 on Holland approaching that state.

refashioned: In the North American and West Indian colonies, not only wages but also the interest rate -- and consequently profits -- are higher than in England. In the various colonies, both legal and market interest rates range from six to eight percent. High wages and high profits, however, rarely coexist except in the special circumstances of new colonies. A new colony must always, for some time, have less capital relative to its territory, and fewer people relative to its capital, than most established countries. Its available capital is therefore applied only to cultivating the most fertile and best-situated land -- the land along seacoasts and navigable rivers.
elegant: The American and West Indian colonies have both higher wages and higher profits than England -- an unusual combination explained by colonial conditions. New colonies have too much land for their capital and too few people for their needs, so investment concentrates on the most fertile, best-situated land near coasts and rivers.
summary: The American and West Indian colonies uniquely combine high wages with high profits because new colonies are always understocked with capital relative to their territory and underpopulated relative to their capital. Investment therefore concentrates on the best available land.
distilled: New colonies uniquely combine high wages and high profits because their vast territory far exceeds their available capital and population.
notes: Important exception to the general rule that high wages and high profits cannot coexist (1.9.1). New colonies escape the inverse relationship because they have abundant natural resources relative to both capital and labor -- both factors are scarce, so both command high returns. The focus on coastal and riverside land reflects the critical importance of transportation costs in pre-railroad economies. Cross-reference 1.9.13 for how colonial profits evolve over time.

refashioned: Such land is also frequently purchased at a price well below the value of even its natural output. Capital invested in purchasing and improving such land must therefore yield very large profits and can consequently afford to pay very high interest. The rapid accumulation of wealth in such profitable employment enables the planter to increase his workforce faster than he can find workers in a new settlement. Those he can find are therefore very generously paid. As the colony grows, profits on capital gradually fall. Once all the most fertile and best-situated land has been occupied, less profit can be earned from cultivating inferior land in worse locations, and less interest can be paid on the capital employed in doing so.
elegant: Colonial land purchased below its natural productive value yields enormous profits and supports high interest rates. Rapid capital accumulation lets planters expand faster than they can find workers, keeping wages high. As colonies mature and the best land is taken, cultivation shifts to inferior land, and both profits and interest rates gradually decline.
summary: Colonial land bought cheaply yields enormous profits, enabling rapid capital growth. But as colonies mature and all the best land is claimed, the shift to inferior land gradually reduces both profits and the interest rates capital can support.
distilled: Colonial profits are initially enormous because cheap, fertile land yields high returns, but they gradually decline as settlement expands onto inferior land.
notes: Describes the natural lifecycle of colonial economic development -- high initial returns declining toward metropolitan norms. The mechanism of declining returns as cultivation moves to less productive land anticipates Ricardo's theory of differential rent. The labor scarcity that keeps colonial wages high is a persistent feature of New World economies. Cross-reference 1.9.14 for the empirical evidence and 1.9.12 for the initial conditions.

refashioned: Accordingly, both the legal and market interest rates have fallen considerably in most of our colonies during the present century. As wealth, improvement, and population have increased, interest has declined. But wages do not fall along with profits. The demand for labor increases with the growth of capital regardless of what profit rates are doing; and after profits have fallen, capital may not only continue to grow, but grow much faster than before. It is the same with industrious nations advancing in wealth as with industrious individuals. A large fortune, though earning a small percentage return, generally grows faster than a small fortune earning a high return. As the proverb says: money makes money.
elegant: Colonial interest rates have fallen as wealth and population grew -- but wages have not. Labor demand increases with capital regardless of profit rates, and capital may actually grow faster after profits decline. Large fortunes with low returns grow faster than small fortunes with high returns: money makes money.
summary: As colonies mature, interest rates and profits decline but wages do not, because labor demand grows with capital accumulation regardless of the profit rate. A large capital stock with low returns can grow faster than a small one with high returns.
distilled: Falling colonial profits do not reduce wages because labor demand depends on capital size, not profitability -- and large capital with low returns grows faster than small capital with high returns.
notes: Critical insight separating the trajectories of wages and profits during economic development. The 'money makes money' proverb encapsulates the compound growth advantage of large capital stocks. Even at lower percentage returns, absolute growth can accelerate as the base expands. This is an early articulation of what economists now call the 'convergence' or 'catch-up' dynamic in development economics. Cross-reference 1.9.1 on the inverse relationship and 1.9.15 on exceptions.

refashioned:
Once you have acquired a little capital, it is often easy to acquire more. The great difficulty is getting that initial amount. The connection between capital growth and industrial expansion -- that is, the growing demand for useful labor -- has been partly explained already and will be explored more fully later, in the discussion of capital accumulation.

The acquisition of new territory or new branches of trade may sometimes raise profits, and with them interest rates, even in a country that is rapidly growing wealthier. When a country's capital is insufficient for all the new business that such acquisitions open up to its various citizens, it is directed toward whichever branches offer the greatest profit. Some capital that had previously been employed in other trades is necessarily withdrawn and redirected into the new, more profitable ones. In all those older trades, competition therefore decreases. The market becomes less fully supplied with many goods, whose prices necessarily rise, yielding greater profits to those who deal in them -- who can therefore afford to borrow at higher interest. For some time after the conclusion of the recent war, not only private individuals of the best credit but some of the greatest companies in London commonly borrowed at five percent, having previously paid no more than four to four and a half percent. The great expansion of both territory and trade from our acquisitions in North America and the West Indies sufficiently explains this, without assuming any reduction in the nation's total capital. So vast an addition of new business to be managed with the existing capital must necessarily have reduced the amount employed in many particular trades, in which less competition meant higher profits. I shall later present my reasons for believing that Great Britain's total capital stock was not diminished even by the enormous expense of the recent war.
elegant: Getting the first bit of capital is the hardest part; after that, accumulation becomes easier. New territorial or trade acquisitions can temporarily raise profits even in a wealthy country by diverting capital from established trades into more profitable new ones, reducing competition in the old trades and raising their returns. After the recent war, London borrowing rates rose from four to five percent -- explained not by any shrinkage of national capital, but by the vast new business opened up by acquisitions in North America and the West Indies, which drew capital away from existing trades and reduced competition in them.
summary: New territorial acquisitions can temporarily raise profits even in a growing economy by redirecting capital from established trades to more profitable new ones, reducing competition in existing markets. Post-war London interest rate increases reflected not declining national wealth but the diversion of capital toward vast new colonial opportunities.
distilled: New territorial acquisitions temporarily raise profits by diverting capital into new opportunities, reducing competition in established trades even as national wealth continues to grow.
notes: Important qualification to the general trend of declining profits in wealthy nations. The Seven Years' War (1756-1763) and its aftermath provide the historical context -- Britain's territorial gains in North America and the Caribbean created enormous new investment opportunities. Smith's argument that capital was redirected rather than destroyed is a sophisticated macroeconomic insight. The opening aphorism -- 'the great difficulty is to get that little' -- captures a persistent truth about wealth accumulation and inequality. Cross-reference Book II on capital accumulation.

refashioned: A decline in a society's total capital -- the funds available for maintaining industry -- lowers wages while raising profits and consequently interest rates. With wages reduced, the remaining capital owners can bring goods to market more cheaply; with less total capital supplying the market, they can sell those goods at higher prices. Since their profits are enlarged on both ends -- lower costs and higher selling prices -- they can well afford to pay high interest. The great fortunes acquired so suddenly and easily in Bengal and other British settlements in the East Indies confirm that where wages are very low, profits are very high. Interest rates there are correspondingly extreme. In Bengal, money is frequently lent to farmers at forty, fifty, or sixty percent, with the next harvest mortgaged as security. Just as profits high enough to support such interest rates must consume nearly all of the landlord's rent, so such enormous usury must in turn consume most of those profits. A similar kind of usury seems to have been common in the provinces of the Roman Republic under the ruinous administration of their proconsuls. The virtuous Brutus lent money in Cyprus at forty-eight percent, as we learn from the letters of Cicero.
elegant: When a society's capital shrinks, wages fall and profits rise -- capital owners face lower costs and less competition, boosting margins on both sides. Bengal illustrates the extreme case: very low wages, very high profits, and interest rates of forty to sixty percent secured against future harvests. Such usury devours rents and then profits in turn. The pattern repeats historically -- Brutus charged forty-eight percent interest in Cyprus under Roman provincial administration.
summary: Declining capital lowers wages and raises profits simultaneously, as fewer competitors face lower costs and less-supplied markets. Bengal's extreme interest rates of forty to sixty percent illustrate how capital scarcity in a declining economy creates enormous profits that are then consumed by usury -- a pattern also seen in the Roman provinces.
distilled: Capital decline simultaneously lowers wages and raises profits, creating conditions for extreme usury -- as illustrated by Bengal's forty to sixty percent interest rates and ancient Roman provincial lending.
notes: The Bengal example is Smith's primary illustration of economic decline and exploitation. East India Company operations were deeply controversial in Smith's time. The parallel with Roman provincial exploitation under proconsuls is pointed political commentary -- Smith implicitly compares British colonial administrators to corrupt Roman officials. Brutus's forty-eight percent rate in Cyprus, reported by Cicero (Letters to Atticus, 5.21 and 6.1), was a famous classical scandal. Cross-reference 1.9.17 for the theoretical endpoint of fully stocked vs. declining economies.

refashioned: In a country that had acquired the maximum wealth its natural conditions and position allowed, and that therefore could advance no further without actually declining, both wages and profits would probably be very low. In a country fully populated relative to what its territory could support or its capital could employ, competition for jobs would be so intense that wages would be driven down to bare subsistence -- just enough to maintain the existing number of workers, which could never increase since the country was already at full population. In a country with as much capital invested in every trade as each trade could absorb, competition would be so universal and profits so low as possible.
elegant: In a country at its maximum possible wealth -- fully populated and fully capitalized -- both wages and profits would be extremely low. Workers would compete so fiercely that wages would cover only bare subsistence, while universal competition among capital owners would drive profits to the lowest possible level.
summary: A country at its theoretical maximum wealth would see both wages and profits at rock bottom -- wages driven to bare subsistence by labor competition and profits minimized by universal capital competition.
distilled: At the theoretical limit of national wealth, both wages and profits would be minimized by maximum competition among workers and capital owners alike.
notes: Smith describes the 'stationary state' -- a theoretical endpoint that deeply concerned classical economists. Ricardo and Mill later developed this concept further. The stationary state represents the logical conclusion of capital accumulation: with no room for growth, both labor and capital returns are compressed to minimums. No country has actually reached this state, as Smith notes in 1.9.18. Cross-reference 1.9.22 on Holland as the closest approximation.

refashioned: But perhaps no country has ever actually reached this degree of wealth. China seems to have been stationary for a long time and had probably long ago reached the maximum wealth consistent with its laws and institutions. But this level may be far below what different laws and institutions would allow, given its soil, climate, and geographic position. A country that neglects or despises foreign trade, and that permits foreign vessels into only one or two of its ports, cannot conduct the same volume of business that different policies would enable. Similarly, in a country where the wealthy enjoy considerable security but the poor -- owners of small capital -- enjoy almost none, being liable at any time to be plundered by corrupt officials under the pretense of justice, the total capital employed in business can never reach what the actual scope of business would permit. In every line of commerce, the oppression of the poor establishes a monopoly for the rich, who, by keeping all trade to themselves, are able to extract very large profits. Twelve percent is reportedly the typical interest rate in China, and ordinary profits must be high enough to sustain it.
elegant: No country has reached its theoretical maximum wealth. China has long been stationary, but its stagnation reflects bad laws and institutions, not natural limits. By restricting foreign trade and allowing corrupt officials to plunder small capital holders, China suppresses investment far below what its soil, climate, and position would support. The oppression of the poor creates monopolies for the rich, yielding profits high enough to sustain a twelve percent interest rate.
summary: No country has reached its theoretical wealth limit. China's stagnation results not from natural limits but from institutions that restrict trade and allow official corruption, suppressing capital investment and creating monopolies for the wealthy. Its twelve percent interest rate reflects artificially high profits sustained by these distortions.
distilled: China's economic stagnation results not from reaching natural limits but from institutional failures -- trade restrictions and official corruption -- that suppress capital and create monopolies sustaining artificially high profits.
notes: Landmark passage in institutional economics. Smith argues that China's stagnation is caused by institutions, not geography or natural resources -- anticipating the modern institutional economics of North, Acemoglu, and others. The critique of extractive institutions (corruption allowing 'inferior mandarins' to plunder the poor) and restrictive trade policy is remarkably modern. The twelve percent Chinese interest rate, compared to two percent in Holland, quantifies the difference between institutional environments. Cross-reference 1.9.17 for the theoretical framework and 1.9.19 for how legal defects affect interest rates.

refashioned: A defect in the legal system may sometimes raise interest rates considerably above what the country's level of wealth or poverty would warrant. When the law does not enforce contracts, all borrowers are placed in roughly the same position as bankrupts or people of doubtful credit in better-governed countries. The uncertainty of recovering his money leads the lender to demand the same exorbitant interest typically charged to bankrupts. Among the barbarian nations that conquered the western provinces of the Roman Empire, contract enforcement was left for many centuries to the good faith of the parties involved. The courts of their kings seldom intervened. The high interest rates that prevailed in those ancient times can perhaps be partly explained by this failure.
elegant: Legal defects can inflate interest rates above what economic conditions would dictate. Where laws fail to enforce contracts, all borrowers are treated like bankrupts, and lenders demand usurious rates to compensate for the risk of non-recovery. The high interest rates in post-Roman barbarian kingdoms partly reflected this failure of contract enforcement.
summary: Defective legal systems inflate interest rates by making all lending risky. When courts fail to enforce contracts, lenders treat every borrower as a potential default, demanding usurious compensation for the uncertainty -- as occurred in the barbarian kingdoms that succeeded Rome.
distilled: Weak contract enforcement inflates interest rates above their natural level by forcing lenders to price in the risk of non-recovery from all borrowers.
notes: Extends the institutional analysis from 1.9.18 (China) to European history. Contract enforcement is identified as a foundational institution for functioning capital markets -- without it, risk premiums overwhelm the underlying economic rate of return. This insight is central to modern law-and-economics literature on the relationship between legal institutions and financial development. The post-Roman period reference covers roughly the 5th-10th centuries.

refashioned: When the law prohibits interest entirely, it does not prevent it. Many people must borrow, and nobody will lend without receiving compensation not only for what could be earned using the money, but also for the difficulty and danger of evading the law. Montesquieu explains the high interest rates in Muslim nations not by their poverty, but partly by the prohibition of interest itself and partly by the difficulty of recovering the money.
elegant: Banning interest does not eliminate it -- borrowing continues, but lenders add a premium for the risk of breaking the law. Montesquieu attributed high interest rates in Muslim nations not to poverty but to the legal prohibition itself and weak debt recovery.
summary: Laws prohibiting interest are self-defeating: they cannot stop lending but do raise its cost by adding a legal risk premium. High interest rates in Muslim nations reflected the prohibition itself, not underlying poverty.
distilled: Prohibiting interest raises rather than eliminates it, because lenders demand compensation for the legal risk of evasion on top of the money's productive value.
notes: Classic Smithian argument about unintended consequences of prohibition -- banning a practice does not eliminate it but drives it underground at higher cost. Montesquieu's analysis from 'The Spirit of the Laws' (1748) is cited approvingly. The Islamic prohibition on riba (interest/usury) created elaborate workarounds in practice, much as Christian usury bans did in medieval Europe. Cross-reference 1.9.4 on Edward VI's total prohibition having the same effect in England.

refashioned: The lowest ordinary rate of profit must always be somewhat more than what is needed to cover the occasional losses that every investment is exposed to. Only this surplus constitutes net or clear profit. What is called gross profit frequently includes not only this surplus but also a reserve for compensating extraordinary losses. The interest a borrower can afford to pay corresponds only to the clear profit. Likewise, the lowest ordinary interest rate must be somewhat more than enough to cover the occasional losses that even prudent lending entails. If it were not, only charity or friendship would motivate anyone to lend.
elegant: The minimum profit rate must exceed the expected rate of occasional losses -- only the surplus above loss compensation is true 'clear profit.' Gross profit includes reserves for extraordinary losses. Interest rates must similarly exceed lending losses, since only clear profit can fund interest payments; otherwise, only charity would motivate lending.
summary: Clear profit is what remains after covering expected losses; gross profit includes loss reserves. Both the minimum profit rate and the minimum interest rate must exceed expected losses, or there would be no incentive to invest or lend.
distilled: The minimum viable profit and interest rates must exceed expected losses, since only the surplus above loss compensation constitutes genuine return.
notes: Important distinction between gross and net (clear) profit. The concept of a risk-adjusted minimum return anticipates modern finance theory's risk-free rate plus risk premium framework. The observation that interest must come from clear profit (not gross) establishes a floor for both. The mention of 'charity or friendship' as the only alternative to profitable lending appears in discussions of Islamic finance and gift economies. Cross-reference 1.9.22 for the upper and lower bounds of profit.

refashioned: In a country that had reached its full complement of wealth -- where every trade employed the maximum capital it could absorb -- the ordinary rate of clear profit would be so small, and the market interest rate that could be sustained from it so low, that only the very wealthiest people could afford to live on the interest of their money. Everyone of small or moderate fortune would be compelled to personally manage the investment of their own capital. Nearly every person would need to be in business or engaged in some trade. Holland seems to be approaching this condition. There, it is unfashionable not to be a man of business. Necessity makes it common for nearly everyone to be one, and custom everywhere dictates fashion. Just as it is considered ridiculous not to dress properly, it is similarly considered improper not to be engaged in business like everyone else. Just as a man of a civilian profession appears awkward in a military camp and even risks being despised there, so does an idle man among people of business.
elegant: In a fully capitalized economy, profits and interest would be so low that only the very wealthy could live on investment returns alone. Everyone else would need to manage their own capital actively. Holland approaches this state: there, being in business is not merely common but socially mandatory. Idleness among businesspeople carries the same stigma as a civilian in a military camp.
summary: When an economy reaches near-saturation of capital, interest rates become too low for anyone but the very wealthy to live on. Holland exemplifies this: nearly everyone must be actively engaged in business, and idleness carries strong social stigma.
distilled: In a near-saturated economy like Holland's, interest rates are so low that virtually everyone must actively engage in business to maintain their standard of living.
notes: Holland continues as Smith's primary example of an economy approaching capital saturation (see 1.9.11). The social observation -- that necessity creates customs that then enforce themselves through stigma -- is characteristically Smithian sociology. The military camp analogy is vivid. This passage influenced Max Weber's later analysis of the Protestant work ethic in the Netherlands. Cross-reference 1.9.17 for the theoretical framework of the fully stocked state.

refashioned: The highest ordinary rate of profit may be one that, in the price of most goods, consumes everything that should go to the landlord as rent, leaving only enough to pay the labor of preparing and bringing goods to market at the lowest rate labor can possibly be paid -- bare subsistence. The worker must always have been fed somehow while working, but the landlord need not always have been paid. The profits of the trade that East India Company officials carry on in Bengal may not be far from this extreme rate.
elegant: At its theoretical maximum, profit absorbs everything except bare subsistence wages -- consuming the landlord's entire rent. The worker must always be fed; the landlord need not always be paid. East India Company trade in Bengal approaches this extreme.
summary: The theoretical maximum profit rate is one that absorbs all rent and leaves workers only bare subsistence. East India Company operations in Bengal approximated this extreme, where profits consumed nearly everything above minimal labor costs.
distilled: Maximum profit consumes the landlord's entire rent and reduces wages to bare subsistence -- a condition approximated by East India Company trade in Bengal.
notes: Establishes the theoretical upper bound of profit, complementing the lower bound in 1.9.21. The tripartite distribution (wages, profits, rent) is zero-sum at the extremes: maximum profit squeezes both wages (to subsistence) and rent (to zero). Bengal under the East India Company serves as the empirical case -- a deeply exploitative system Smith clearly condemns. Cross-reference 1.9.16 for Bengal's usurious interest rates and 1.9.17 for the theoretical lower bound.

refashioned: The proportion that the market interest rate should bear to the ordinary rate of clear profit necessarily varies as profit rises or falls. In Great Britain, double the interest rate is considered what merchants call a good, moderate, reasonable profit -- terms that simply mean a common and typical return. In a country where the ordinary clear profit rate is eight or ten percent, it may be reasonable for half to go to interest when business is conducted with borrowed money. The borrower bears the risk of the capital, effectively insuring the lender against loss; four or five percent may in most trades provide both adequate compensation for that insurance risk and sufficient reward for the trouble of managing the capital. But the ratio between interest and clear profit would differ in countries where the typical profit rate was either much lower or much higher. Where profits were much lower, perhaps half could not be spared for interest; where profits were much higher, more than half might be afforded.
elegant: The proper ratio of interest to profit varies with overall profit levels. In Britain, merchants consider double the interest rate a 'good, moderate' profit -- with half going to interest and half compensating the borrower's risk and management effort. This roughly even split works at eight to ten percent profit but would need adjustment where profits were much higher or lower.
summary: In Britain, a reasonable profit is roughly double the interest rate, with half compensating the lender and half rewarding the borrower's risk and management. This ratio works at moderate profit levels but must adjust where profits are significantly higher or lower.
distilled: The interest-to-profit ratio in Britain is roughly one to two -- half compensating lenders, half rewarding borrowers -- but this proportion varies with the overall level of profits.
notes: Establishes a practical rule of thumb for the interest-profit relationship. The 'double interest' formula was a common merchant's benchmark in 18th-century Britain. The borrower effectively 'insures' the lender's capital -- an early articulation of the risk premium concept. The acknowledgment that the ratio varies with profit levels shows Smith's awareness that financial relationships are not fixed but contextual. Cross-reference 1.9.3 on interest as a proxy for profits.

refashioned:
