In countries advancing rapidly in wealth, low profit rates may, through their effect on prices, compensate for high wages, enabling those countries to sell goods as cheaply as their less prosperous neighbors where wages are lower.

In fact, high profits tend to raise prices far more than high wages do. If, in the linen industry for example, the wages of every worker -- the flax-dressers, spinners, weavers, and so on -- were all raised by twopence a day, the price of a piece of linen would need to increase only by a number of twopences equal to the number of workers multiplied by the number of days they worked. The wage component of the price would rise in simple arithmetical proportion. But if the profits of every employer in the production chain were raised by five percent, the effect would compound. The flax-dresser's employer would need an additional five percent on the total value of materials and wages he advanced. The spinner's employer would need five percent not only on the wages but also on the already-increased price of the flax. The weaver's employer would need five percent on both the already-increased price of the yarn and the wages of the weavers. In raising prices, wage increases operate like simple interest in the accumulation of debt, while profit increases operate like compound interest. Our merchants and manufacturers complain loudly about the damaging effect of high wages on prices and sales, both domestic and foreign. They say nothing about the damaging effect of high profits. They are silent about the harmful consequences of their own gains and complain only about those of other people.
elegant: In wealthy countries, low profits can offset high wages in pricing, keeping goods competitive with poorer neighbors. In fact, high profits raise prices far more than high wages. Wage increases compound only arithmetically through the production chain -- adding a fixed amount per worker per day. Profit increases compound geometrically -- each employer requires a percentage on top of the already-inflated price from the previous stage. Wages operate like simple interest; profits like compound interest. Yet merchants complain endlessly about wages while staying silent about their own profits.
summary: High profits raise commodity prices far more than high wages because wages compound arithmetically through the production chain while profits compound geometrically, like compound interest. Despite this, merchants blame high wages for uncompetitive pricing while ignoring the greater impact of their own high profits.
distilled: Profit increases raise prices geometrically through the production chain -- like compound interest -- while wage increases add only arithmetically, yet merchants blame wages for high prices while ignoring profits.
notes: One of Smith's most incisive analytical passages and a direct challenge to mercantilist employer interests. The simple-vs-compound interest analogy brilliantly illustrates why profit margins matter more for price levels than wage rates. This is an early articulation of how markup pricing cascades through supply chains. Smith's closing observation about merchant hypocrisy -- complaining about wages while silent on profits -- is a recurring theme. Cross-reference 1.8.55 on wage increases being offset by productivity, and 1.11 for further analysis of how the three components (wages, profit, rent) constitute price.

refashioned: The total advantages and disadvantages of all different employments of labor and capital must, within the same area, be either perfectly equal or continually tending toward equality. If any employment in the same neighborhood were clearly more or less advantageous than the rest, so many people would crowd into it in the first case, and abandon it in the second, that its advantages would quickly return to the level of other employments. This, at least, would be the case in a society where things followed their natural course -- where there was perfect liberty and every person was completely free both to choose whatever occupation he preferred and to change it whenever he wished. Everyone's self-interest would naturally lead him to seek out advantageous employments and avoid disadvantageous ones.
elegant: In a free market, the total advantages and disadvantages of different employments must tend toward equality. If any occupation offered clearly better or worse returns, workers would flock to or flee from it until its advantages leveled with others. This requires perfect liberty -- freedom to choose and change occupations at will, guided by self-interest.
summary: Under conditions of perfect liberty, the total advantages of all employments tend toward equality because workers freely move toward better opportunities and away from worse ones until returns equalize.
distilled: Perfect freedom of occupational choice naturally equalizes the total advantages of different employments through the movement of workers toward better opportunities.
notes: Opens Chapter 10 -- 'Of Wages and Profit in the Different Employments of Labour and Stock.' This is Smith's equilibrium principle for labor markets, analogous to the law of one price for goods. The emphasis on 'total' advantages (not just wages) is crucial -- the chapter explains why nominal wages differ even in equilibrium. The phrase 'natural course' and 'perfect liberty' establish the ideal benchmark against which actual market distortions are measured. Cross-reference 1.10.2 for the two sources of deviation.

refashioned: Monetary wages and profits are indeed extremely different across Europe depending on the particular employment of labor and capital. But this variation arises partly from certain characteristics of the employments themselves that -- either in reality or at least in people's imagination -- compensate for low pay in some jobs and offset high pay in others, and partly from European government policies that nowhere leave things at perfect liberty.
elegant: Wage and profit differences across occupations arise from two sources: inherent characteristics of the work itself that compensate for or offset monetary differences, and government policies that restrict the free movement of labor and capital.
summary: Occupational wage differences have two causes: characteristics of the work that create compensating differentials, and government policies that restrict free labor mobility.
distilled: Wage differences across occupations reflect both the inherent characteristics of the work and government interference with free labor markets.
notes: Sets up the chapter's two-part structure: Part I covers natural equalizing differences (1.10.3-39), Part II covers policy-created inequalities (1.10.40 onward). The concept of 'compensating differentials' -- where unpleasant features of a job are offset by higher pay -- remains central to modern labor economics. The distinction between real and imagined characteristics is also important. Cross-reference 1.10.3 for the five specific circumstances.

refashioned:
The detailed examination of these circumstances and policies will divide this chapter into two parts.

The five principal circumstances that, as far as I have been able to observe, compensate for low pay in some employments and offset high pay in others are as follows. First, the agreeableness or disagreeableness of the work itself. Second, the ease and cheapness, or the difficulty and expense, of learning the trade. Third, the steadiness or irregularity of employment. Fourth, the degree of trust that must be placed in the worker. And fifth, the probability or improbability of success.
elegant: Five circumstances create compensating wage differentials across occupations: the pleasantness or unpleasantness of the work; the cost of training; the steadiness of employment; the trust required; and the probability of success.
summary: Smith identifies five factors that explain why wages differ across occupations even in free markets: agreeableness of the work, cost of learning the trade, constancy of employment, required trust, and likelihood of success.
distilled: Five factors create natural wage differences: pleasantness, training cost, employment stability, required trust, and probability of success.
notes: This five-part framework for compensating wage differentials is one of Smith's most enduring analytical contributions to labor economics. Every modern labor economics textbook covers these factors, often explicitly crediting Smith. The framework explains why wage equalization means equalization of total advantage, not nominal pay. Each factor is developed in 1.10.4-38. The observation that these are 'as far as I have been able to observe' reflects Smith's empiricist methodology.

refashioned: First, wages vary with the ease or hardship, the cleanliness or dirtiness, the honorableness or dishonorableness of the work. In most places, taking the year as a whole, a journeyman tailor earns less than a journeyman weaver because his work is much easier. A journeyman weaver earns less than a journeyman smith -- not because his work is always easier, but because it is much cleaner. A journeyman blacksmith, though a skilled tradesman, seldom earns as much in twelve hours as a coal miner, who is merely a laborer, earns in eight. The blacksmith's work is not quite as dirty, is less dangerous, and is carried on in daylight above ground. Honor forms a large part of the reward in all honorable professions. In terms of monetary compensation, all things considered, they are generally underpaid, as I shall attempt to demonstrate later. Dishonor has the opposite effect. The trade of a butcher is a brutal and unpleasant business, but in most places it is more profitable than most common trades. The most despised of all occupations -- that of public executioner -- is, in proportion to the amount of work done, better paid than any ordinary trade.
elegant: Wages compensate for the disagreeableness of work. Tailors earn less than weavers (easier work), weavers less than smiths (cleaner work), and smiths less than coal miners (safer, daylight work). Honorable professions are underpaid in money because honor itself is part of the compensation. Conversely, despised trades like butchering pay well, and the most detested -- public execution -- pays best of all per unit of work.
summary: Wages systematically compensate for unpleasant working conditions: harder, dirtier, more dangerous, or more dishonorable work commands higher pay. Honorable professions accept lower monetary compensation because prestige forms part of the reward, while despised occupations like butchering and execution command premiums.
distilled: Wages compensate for the disagreeableness of work -- dirty, dangerous, and dishonorable jobs pay more, while prestige substitutes for money in honorable professions.
notes: First compensating differential: agreeableness. The tailor-weaver-smith-collier wage ladder is a brilliantly constructed empirical illustration. The observation that honor is part of compensation (making 'honorable' professions monetarily underpaid) is counterintuitive and profound -- it explains why teachers, clergy, and military officers accept below-market wages. The executioner example dramatically illustrates the stigma premium. Cross-reference 1.10.22 for performers and 1.10.15 for combined disagreeableness and irregularity.

refashioned: Hunting and fishing, the most important occupations of humanity in its primitive state, become, in advanced societies, their most popular amusements. People pursue for pleasure what they once followed from necessity. In an advanced society, therefore, those who follow these activities as a trade are typically very poor. Fishermen have been poor since the time of Theocritus. A poacher is everywhere in Great Britain a very poor man. In countries where the law strictly forbids poaching, the licensed hunter is scarcely better off. The natural appeal of these activities draws more people to them than can comfortably earn a living from them, and the produce of their labor, relative to its quantity, always comes too cheaply to market to provide more than the most meager subsistence.
elegant: Hunting and fishing -- once humanity's primary occupations -- became leisure activities in advanced societies. Because they are naturally appealing, too many people pursue them professionally, flooding the market and driving returns down to bare subsistence. Fishermen have been poor since ancient times; poachers and hunters remain so.
summary: Activities that are naturally appealing -- like hunting and fishing -- attract too many practitioners as professions, depressing earnings to bare subsistence. What was once economic necessity becomes recreation, and those who persist in it professionally are invariably poor.
distilled: Naturally enjoyable occupations like hunting and fishing attract excess practitioners, driving professional earnings down to subsistence as pleasure substitutes for monetary reward.
notes: Extension of the first compensating differential to its positive side: agreeable work pays less because more people want to do it. The Theocritus reference (Idyll 21, 'The Fishermen') is a characteristically erudite touch -- the Greek pastoral poet depicted fishermen's poverty circa 270 BC. The poacher example is distinctly British. This principle applies in modern economies to artistic, athletic, and outdoor professions. Cross-reference 1.10.4 for the inverse (disagreeable work pays more).

refashioned: Disagreeableness and disgrace affect the profits of capital in the same way they affect wages. The keeper of an inn or tavern, who is never master of his own house and is constantly exposed to the rudeness of every drunkard, runs neither a very pleasant nor a very respectable business. But there is hardly any common trade in which a small investment yields such large profits.
elegant: Disagreeableness affects profits just as it affects wages. Innkeeping is unpleasant and undignified -- the owner is at the mercy of every drunkard -- yet few trades yield such high returns on a small investment.
summary: The compensating differential for disagreeableness applies to capital as well as labor. Innkeeping, though unpleasant and disrespected, yields unusually high profits on small investments.
distilled: Innkeeping yields high profits on small capital precisely because the work is disagreeable and undignified, deterring competition.
notes: Brief but important extension: compensating differentials apply to capital returns as well as wages. The innkeeper example captures the daily indignities of service-industry work. Smith's observation that high returns come from the combination of disagreeableness AND small capital requirements explains why certain small businesses remain highly profitable niches. Cross-reference 1.10.4 for the wage parallel.

refashioned:
Second, wages vary with the ease and cheapness, or the difficulty and expense, of learning the trade.

When an expensive machine is built, the extraordinary output it produces before wearing out must be expected to repay the capital invested in it, along with at least the ordinary rate of profit. A person educated at great expense of time and effort for a job requiring extraordinary skill and dexterity can be compared to one of these expensive machines. The work he learns to perform must be expected, over and above the usual wages of common labor, to repay the entire cost of his education with at least the ordinary profit on an equally valuable capital investment. And it must do so within a reasonable time, given the uncertain duration of human life, in the same way that a machine must repay its cost within its more predictable lifespan.
elegant: Wages compensate for training costs. An educated worker is like an expensive machine: the higher wages his skills command must repay the full cost of his education, plus ordinary profit on that investment, within the uncertain span of his working life -- just as a machine must repay its cost before wearing out.
summary: Higher wages for skilled workers compensate for the cost of training, much as a machine's output must repay its construction cost. The educated worker's premium must cover the full investment in his education plus a reasonable return, within an uncertain working life.
distilled: Skilled workers earn higher wages to recoup their education costs with interest, just as an expensive machine must earn back its construction cost before wearing out.
notes: Second compensating differential: training cost. Smith's comparison of an educated worker to an expensive machine is the conceptual origin of 'human capital' theory, later developed by Gary Becker and Theodore Schultz. The calculation -- education cost plus opportunity cost plus normal profit, discounted by life expectancy -- is essentially the modern human capital investment model. The uncertainty of human lifespan vs. machine lifespan introduces a risk premium for human capital investment. Cross-reference 1.10.8-10 for the institutional framework of apprenticeship.

refashioned:
The difference between skilled and common labor wages is founded on this principle.

European policy treats the labor of all mechanics, tradespeople, and manufacturers as skilled labor, and that of all agricultural workers as common labor. It assumes the former to be more refined and delicate than the latter. In some cases this is true, but in most it is quite the opposite, as I shall attempt to demonstrate later. European laws and customs therefore impose an apprenticeship requirement to qualify anyone for skilled trades, though with varying degrees of strictness in different places. Agricultural labor, by contrast, is left free and open to everyone. During the apprenticeship, all of the apprentice's labor belongs to his master.
elegant: The skilled-common wage gap reflects training cost differences. European policy classifies all manufacturing as skilled and all agriculture as common labor -- often wrongly, since much farm work is more demanding. Laws require apprenticeships for skilled trades while leaving agriculture open to all. During apprenticeship, the master claims the apprentice's entire output.
summary: European policy distinguishes skilled from common labor through apprenticeship requirements, classifying all manufacturing as skilled and all agriculture as common. This distinction is often inaccurate, since agricultural work frequently demands more skill than factory work, but it persists through law and custom.
distilled: European apprenticeship laws create an artificial skilled-common labor distinction that often misclassifies agricultural work as unskilled while protecting manufacturing trades.
notes: Transitions from natural compensating differentials to institutional distortions. Smith challenges the assumption that manufacturing work is inherently more skilled than agriculture -- a point he develops later. The apprenticeship system is portrayed as partly a mechanism for masters to capture apprentice labor, not purely an educational institution. This critique of occupational licensing anticipates modern debates about professional credentialing. Cross-reference 1.10.53-58 for the detailed critique of apprenticeship laws.

refashioned: In the meantime, the apprentice must in many cases be maintained by his parents or relatives, and in almost all cases must be clothed by them. Some money is also commonly paid to the master for the instruction. Those who cannot pay in money pay in time, binding themselves for more years than usual -- a consideration that, though not always beneficial to the master due to the typical laziness of apprentices, is always costly to the apprentice. In agricultural labor, by contrast, the laborer learns the more difficult parts of his work while performing the easier tasks, and his own labor supports him through every stage of his training.
elegant: Apprentices bear heavy costs: maintained and clothed by their families, paying masters in money or extra years of service. Those who pay in time always lose, even if idle apprentices give masters little benefit. Farm workers, by contrast, learn on the job while supporting themselves -- their training is self-financing.
summary: Apprenticeship imposes significant costs on trainees: family support, clothing, and payments to masters either in money or extra years of service. Agricultural training, by contrast, is self-financing because laborers learn while earning.
distilled: Apprenticeship imposes heavy costs on trainees and their families, while agricultural workers learn on the job at no additional expense.
notes: Details the actual costs of the apprenticeship system. The observation that apprentices who pay in time rather than money always lose is Smith's critique of the regressive nature of the system -- poorer apprentices face worse terms. The contrast with agricultural training, which is organically self-financing, strengthens the argument that apprenticeship requirements are artificial barriers rather than genuine educational necessities. Cross-reference 1.10.7 on human capital investment.

refashioned: It is therefore reasonable that in Europe, the wages of skilled tradespeople and manufacturers should be somewhat higher than those of common laborers. And they are. Their higher earnings generally cause them to be regarded as a superior class of people. This superiority, however, is usually quite small. The daily or weekly earnings of journeymen in the more common manufactures -- such as plain linen and woolen cloth -- are, on average, in most places only slightly above the daily wages of common laborers. Their employment is admittedly more steady and consistent, so their total annual earnings may be somewhat greater. But this advantage appears to be no more than what is needed to offset the greater cost of their training. Education in the creative arts and the liberal professions is still more time-consuming and expensive.
elegant: Skilled tradesmen reasonably earn somewhat more than common laborers, but the premium is surprisingly small. Journeymen in common manufactures earn only slightly more per day, though steadier employment raises their annual total. This modest advantage merely compensates for training costs. Education in the liberal professions costs still more.
summary: The wage premium for skilled trades is small -- just enough to compensate for the cost of apprenticeship. Skilled workers earn slightly more per day and enjoy steadier employment, but these advantages barely offset their greater training investment. Liberal professions require even more expensive education.
distilled: The skilled-trade wage premium is surprisingly modest -- roughly sufficient to compensate for the cost of apprenticeship training and no more.
notes: Empirical confirmation that the training-cost compensating differential roughly equalizes total lifetime advantage. The observation that the premium is 'no greater than what is sufficient to compensate' supports the equilibrium theory of 1.10.1. The distinction between daily wages and annual earnings (accounting for employment stability) is methodologically important. Sets up the discussion of liberal professions in 1.10.11. Cross-reference 1.10.7 for the theoretical framework.

refashioned:
The monetary compensation of painters and sculptors, of lawyers and physicians, ought therefore to be much more generous; and it is.

The profits of capital, however, seem to be little affected by the ease or difficulty of learning the trade in which it is employed. All the different ways capital is typically invested in large cities seem, in practice, to be almost equally easy and equally difficult to learn. No branch of foreign or domestic trade is substantially more complex as a business than any other.
elegant: Painters, sculptors, lawyers, and physicians earn more to compensate for their longer, costlier education. But profits on capital are unaffected by learning difficulty -- all major trades in cities are roughly equally complex as businesses.
summary: Liberal professions command higher pay to compensate for expensive, lengthy education. Training costs affect wages but not profits, because all trades require roughly comparable business knowledge to manage capital.
distilled: Training costs create wage differentials across professions but do not affect profit rates, since all trades require comparable business skill.
notes: The second compensating differential applies to wages but not profits -- an important asymmetry. The claim that all trades are equally easy or difficult as business ventures (from the capital-management perspective) is debatable but reflects Smith's view that commercial skill is generic rather than trade-specific. Cross-reference 1.10.7-10 for training costs in skilled trades and 1.10.19 for the probability of success as a separate factor.

refashioned:
Third, wages in different occupations vary with the constancy or irregularity of employment.

Some trades offer much steadier work than others. In most manufacturing, a journeyman can count on employment nearly every day of the year that he is able to work. A mason or bricklayer, on the other hand, cannot work in hard frost or foul weather, and even in better conditions depends on occasional customer demand. He is consequently liable to frequent periods without any work. What he earns when employed must therefore not only support him when idle but also compensate for the anxiety and discouragement that such a precarious situation inevitably causes. Where the typical earnings of most manufacturers are roughly level with common labor wages, those of masons and bricklayers are generally fifty to one hundred percent higher. Where common laborers earn four or five shillings a week, masons and bricklayers frequently earn seven or eight; where the former earn six, the latter often earn nine or ten; and where the former earn nine or ten, as in London, the latter commonly earn fifteen to eighteen. No skilled trade seems easier to learn than masonry or bricklaying. London chairmen are even said to work as bricklayers during summer. The high wages of these workers therefore reflect not the reward for their skill but compensation for the irregularity of their employment.
elegant: Wages compensate for irregular employment. Masons and bricklayers -- who cannot work in frost, rain, or between customer calls -- earn fifty to one hundred percent above common labor, though their trade is no harder to learn. London chairmen sometimes moonlight as bricklayers in summer. These high wages compensate not for skill but for idle time and the anxiety of uncertain employment.
summary: Workers in irregular occupations earn substantially more to compensate for idle periods and the psychological burden of employment uncertainty. Masons and bricklayers earn fifty to one hundred percent above common labor not because their skill is greater -- chairmen can do the work -- but because they face frequent involuntary idleness.
distilled: Masons and bricklayers earn far above common labor wages not for superior skill but to compensate for weather-dependent irregular employment and its attendant anxiety.
notes: Third compensating differential: employment constancy. The quantitative evidence (50-100% premium) is carefully compiled across multiple wage levels. The chairmen-as-bricklayers example cleverly disentangles skill from irregularity. The inclusion of psychological costs ('anxious and desponding moments') is sophisticated -- modern economics calls this a risk premium on income volatility. Cross-reference 1.10.13-15 for related cases and 1.10.16 for why this factor affects wages but not profits.

refashioned: A house carpenter seems to practice a somewhat more refined and skilled trade than a mason. In most places, however -- though not universally -- his daily wages are slightly lower. His employment, though considerably dependent on customer demand, does not depend on it as entirely as a mason's, and is not as vulnerable to weather interruptions.
elegant: House carpenters, though more skilled than masons, earn slightly less per day because their employment is somewhat steadier -- less dependent on weather and more continuous between customer jobs.
summary: Carpenters earn less than masons despite greater skill because their employment is more regular, requiring less compensation for idle time.
distilled: Carpenters earn less than masons because steadier employment reduces the premium needed to compensate for irregularity, despite carpentry requiring more skill.
notes: Clean confirmation that employment constancy, not skill level, drives the mason-carpenter wage differential. This case isolates the third compensating differential from the second (training costs) by comparing two trades where the more skilled one earns less. Cross-reference 1.10.12 for the mason's premium and 1.10.4 for agreeableness differentials.

refashioned: When trades that normally provide steady employment happen not to do so in a particular place, the wages of their workers always rise well above their usual proportion to common labor wages. In London, almost all journeyman tradesmen are liable to be hired and dismissed by their masters from day to day and week to week, just as day laborers are elsewhere. The lowest-ranking tradesmen, journeyman tailors, accordingly earn half a crown a day, though eighteen pence may be taken as the wage of common labor. In small towns and country villages, the wages of journeyman tailors rarely exceed those of common laborers. But in London they are often unemployed for many weeks at a time, particularly during the summer.
elegant: When normally steady trades become irregular in a particular location, wages rise sharply. In London, where even journeyman tailors are hired and fired day to day, they earn half a crown against common labor's eighteen pence -- though in small towns where their employment is steadier, tailors earn no more than common workers. London tailors face weeks of summer unemployment.
summary: When normally steady occupations become irregular in a specific location, wages rise to compensate. London journeyman tailors earn far above common labor rates because they face the same day-to-day hiring uncertainty and seasonal unemployment that day laborers face elsewhere.
distilled: When steady trades become irregular in a given location, as with London tailors facing day-to-day hiring and seasonal unemployment, wages rise to compensate for the instability.
notes: Location-specific application of the third compensating differential. The London labor market's casualization of normally steady trades creates higher wages to compensate. The seasonal unemployment of London tailors (summer being the off-season for fashionable tailoring) illustrates how local market conditions modify general patterns. The half-crown vs. eighteen-pence comparison shows a roughly 67% premium for irregularity. Cross-reference 1.10.12 for the general principle.

refashioned: When employment irregularity combines with hardship, disagreeableness, and dirtiness, it sometimes raises the wages of the most common labor above those of the most skilled tradesmen. A coal miner working by the piece supposedly earns about double the wages of common labor at Newcastle, and roughly triple them in many parts of Scotland. His high wages arise entirely from the hardship, disagreeableness, and dirtiness of his work. His employment is generally as steady as he wishes. The coal heavers of London perform work that in hardship, dirtiness, and disagreeableness nearly equals that of miners, but because coal ships arrive irregularly, most of them face highly inconsistent employment. If miners commonly earn double or triple common labor wages, it should not seem unreasonable that coal heavers sometimes earn four or five times as much. In a recent inquiry into their condition, it was found that at their prevailing rates they could earn six to ten shillings a day. Six shillings is about four times common labor wages in London, and in every trade the lowest common earnings represent those of the vast majority. However extravagant these earnings may appear, if they were more than sufficient to compensate for all the disagreeable aspects of the work, competition would soon bring them down -- since the trade has no exclusive privilege restricting entry.
elegant: When irregularity compounds hardship and dirtiness, even common laborers can outearn skilled tradesmen. Miners earn double or triple common wages for dirty, dangerous work alone; London coal heavers, facing the same conditions plus irregular employment, earn four to five times common wages. A recent inquiry found coal heavers earning six to ten shillings daily -- yet if this were truly excessive, unrestricted competition would quickly drive it down.
summary: Combining employment irregularity with hard, dirty, dangerous conditions can push common labor wages far above skilled trades. London coal heavers earn four to five times common wages -- compensating for extreme disagreeableness plus irregular work -- yet free competition prevents these rates from exceeding fair compensation.
distilled: When hard, dirty, dangerous work combines with irregular employment, common laborers like coal heavers can earn four to five times standard wages -- a premium sustained only because conditions genuinely warrant it.
notes: Powerful illustration of how multiple compensating differentials compound. Coal heavers faced both the first differential (disagreeableness) and the third (irregularity), producing dramatic wage premiums. The self-correcting mechanism -- if premiums were excessive, competition would erode them -- demonstrates Smith's faith in free-entry market equilibrium. The 'recent inquiry' refers to parliamentary investigations of London labor conditions. Cross-reference 1.10.4 for disagreeableness alone and 1.10.12 for irregularity alone.

refashioned:
Whether capital is constantly employed or not depends on the individual trader, not on the trade itself, so employment irregularity does not affect the ordinary rate of profit in any particular business.

Fourth, wages vary according to the degree of trust that must be placed in the worker.
elegant: Employment constancy affects wages but not profits, since whether capital stays employed depends on the trader, not the trade. Fourth, wages vary with the trust required of the worker.
summary: The constancy of capital employment depends on the individual trader rather than the trade, so irregularity affects wages but not profit rates. The fourth wage differential involves the degree of trust required.
distilled: Employment irregularity affects wages but not profits because capital deployment depends on the trader, and wages also vary with the trust required of workers.
notes: Transitional passage doing double duty: clarifying that the third differential (constancy) applies only to wages, and introducing the fourth differential (trust). The wages-vs-profits asymmetry is a recurring theme -- of the five compensating differentials, only two (disagreeableness and risk) affect profits. Cross-reference 1.10.17-18 for the trust factor and 1.10.33 for the summary of which factors affect profits.

refashioned: The wages of goldsmiths and jewelers are everywhere higher than those of many other workers of equal or even greater skill, because of the precious materials entrusted to them. We trust our health to the physician, our fortune -- and sometimes our life and reputation -- to the lawyer. Such confidence could not safely be given to people of very low social standing. Their compensation must therefore be sufficient to give them the social rank that such an important trust requires. The long training period and great expense of their education, combined with this need for social standing, necessarily raise the price of their labor still further.
elegant: Goldsmiths earn more than equally skilled workers because they handle precious materials. Physicians and lawyers earn still more because we trust them with our health, fortune, and reputation -- responsibilities that demand social standing their pay must support. Long, expensive education compounds this trust premium.
summary: Workers entrusted with valuable materials or critical responsibilities earn higher wages to ensure they occupy the social position such trust requires. Physicians and lawyers must be paid enough to maintain the standing appropriate to the life-and-death responsibilities entrusted to them.
distilled: Workers handling precious materials or critical responsibilities like health and legal matters command higher wages to maintain the social standing that such trust demands.
notes: Fourth compensating differential: trust. Smith identifies two forms: physical trust (goldsmiths with precious materials) and professional trust (physicians with health, lawyers with fortune and reputation). The social-status argument is distinctly 18th-century -- wages must sustain a certain rank appropriate to the responsibility. This intersects with the second differential (training costs), since professional education both builds competence and signals trustworthiness. Cross-reference 1.10.18 for why trust does not affect profit rates.

refashioned: When a person invests only his own capital in trade, trust is not an issue. Whatever credit he receives from others depends not on the nature of his business but on their assessment of his fortune, integrity, and judgment. The different rates of profit in different trades therefore cannot arise from varying degrees of trust placed in the traders.
elegant: Trust does not affect profit rates because a trader's credit depends on his personal reputation and wealth, not on the nature of his trade. When using only his own capital, trust is irrelevant entirely.
summary: Unlike wages, profit rates are unaffected by trust requirements because a trader's creditworthiness depends on his personal character and fortune, not on his specific trade.
distilled: Trust affects wages but not profits, because a trader's creditworthiness depends on personal reputation rather than on the nature of his business.
notes: Completes the trust differential analysis by explaining the wages-vs-profits asymmetry. Personal creditworthiness is trade-independent, so it cannot create inter-trade profit differentials. This is the fourth factor shown to affect wages but not profits. Cross-reference 1.10.33 for the summary: only disagreeableness and risk affect both wages and profits.

refashioned:
Fifth, wages in different employments vary with the probability or improbability of succeeding in them.

The likelihood that any particular person will become qualified for the work he is trained for varies greatly across occupations. In most mechanical trades, success is nearly certain; in the liberal professions, it is highly uncertain. Send your son to apprentice with a shoemaker and there is little doubt he will learn to make shoes. Send him to study law and the odds are at least twenty to one against his ever earning a living from it. In a perfectly fair lottery, the prize winners ought to gain everything lost by the losers. In a profession where twenty fail for every one who succeeds, that one person ought to earn everything the twenty unsuccessful ones should have earned. However extravagant lawyers' fees may sometimes appear, their actual compensation never equals this. Compare the likely total annual earnings and total annual expenses of all workers in a common trade like shoemaking or weaving, and the earnings will generally exceed the expenses. Make the same calculation for all the lawyers and law students in all the Inns of Court, and their annual earnings will bear only a tiny proportion to their annual spending, even estimating earnings generously and expenses modestly. The lottery of the law is therefore far from being a perfectly fair lottery, and the legal profession -- like many other liberal and honorable occupations -- is clearly underpaid in monetary terms.
elegant: Wages vary with the probability of success. Mechanical trades are nearly certain; liberal professions are highly risky. A shoemaker's apprentice will surely learn his trade, but a law student faces twenty-to-one odds against earning a living. In a fair lottery, one successful lawyer would earn what twenty failures should have -- but actual legal earnings fall far short of this. Comparing total earnings to total expenses across all law students shows the profession is systematically underpaid in money. The legal profession, like many honorable callings, is a deeply unfair lottery.
summary: The fifth wage differential reflects the probability of success. Mechanical trades offer near-certain returns, while liberal professions like law are essentially unfair lotteries where the few successes never fully compensate for the many failures. Total earnings across all law students fall far short of total expenses, making law systematically underpaid.
distilled: Liberal professions like law are unfair lotteries -- the few who succeed never earn enough to compensate for the many who fail, making these careers systematically underpaid despite appearing lucrative.
notes: Fifth compensating differential: probability of success. Smith's 'lottery' framework for professional careers is brilliant and influential. The twenty-to-one odds against legal success, the comparison of aggregate earnings to aggregate costs, and the conclusion that the profession is 'underpaid' in expected-value terms anticipate modern tournament theory and winner-take-all economics. The Inns of Court were London's legal training institutions. Cross-reference 1.10.20-26 for why people enter these unfavorable lotteries anyway.

refashioned: These professions nonetheless maintain their numbers relative to other occupations. Despite these discouraging odds, all the most generous and ambitious spirits are eager to crowd into them. Two causes contribute to their appeal. First, the desire for the reputation that comes with excelling in any of them. Second, the natural confidence that every person has, to a greater or lesser degree, not only in their own abilities but in their own good fortune.
elegant: Despite being systematically underpaid, liberal professions attract the most talented and ambitious people for two reasons: the desire for the reputation that excellence brings, and the universal human overconfidence in both one's own abilities and one's own luck.
summary: Liberal professions remain filled despite poor expected returns because they attract ambitious people who seek the reputation of excellence and who overestimate both their own abilities and their good fortune.
distilled: Ambition for reputation and overconfidence in personal ability and luck explain why talented people crowd into liberal professions despite systematically poor expected returns.
notes: Introduces two psychological explanations for 'irrational' career choices: status-seeking and overconfidence. The overconfidence bias -- people systematically overestimate their own abilities and underestimate risks -- is now one of the best-documented findings in behavioral economics. Smith identifies it here in 1776, roughly two centuries before Kahneman and Tversky's formal research. Cross-reference 1.10.21 for reputation effects and 1.10.23-25 for overconfidence analysis.

refashioned: To excel in any profession where few even achieve mediocrity is the most decisive mark of what people call genius or superior talent. The public admiration that accompanies such distinguished abilities always forms part of their reward -- a greater or smaller part depending on the degree of eminence achieved. It forms a considerable part of the reward in medicine, a still greater part in law, and in poetry and philosophy it constitutes almost the entire reward.
elegant: Excellence in a field where most people never even achieve mediocrity is the clearest mark of genius. Public admiration for such talent is always part of the compensation -- considerable in medicine, greater in law, and nearly the whole reward in poetry and philosophy.
summary: Public admiration for exceptional talent forms an increasing share of total compensation as professions become more intellectually prestigious: considerable in medicine, greater in law, and nearly the entirety in poetry and philosophy.
distilled: Public admiration substitutes for monetary compensation in proportion to a profession's intellectual prestige -- from medicine through law to poetry and philosophy, where fame is nearly the whole reward.
notes: Develops the first cause from 1.10.20: reputation as non-monetary compensation. The ascending scale -- medicine, law, poetry, philosophy -- shows an inverse relationship between intellectual prestige and monetary reward. This analysis explains the persistent puzzle of why brilliant people accept low-paying academic or artistic careers. The concept of fame as compensation connects to modern discussions of 'psychic income' and status goods. Cross-reference 1.10.4 on honor as part of reward in all 'honourable professions.'

refashioned: There are certain very attractive and beautiful talents whose possession commands admiration, but whose exercise for monetary gain is considered -- whether from reason or prejudice -- a kind of public degradation. The monetary compensation of those who practice them this way must therefore be sufficient not only to pay for the time, labor, and expense of acquiring the talents, but also for the social disgrace attached to using them as a livelihood. The extravagant pay of actors, opera singers, and opera dancers is founded on these two principles: the rarity and beauty of their talents, and the disgrace of exercising them for money. It seems absurd at first that we should despise their persons yet reward their talents with the most lavish generosity. But while we do the one, we must necessarily do the other. Should public opinion ever change regarding these occupations, their pay would quickly fall. More people would enter them, and competition would rapidly drive down compensation. Such talents, though far from common, are by no means as rare as people imagine. Many possess them in great perfection but disdain to use them commercially, and many more could acquire them if doing so were considered honorable.
elegant: Some admired talents carry social stigma when practiced for money, so performers must be compensated for both rarity of skill and disgrace of commercial use. The extravagant pay of actors and opera performers rests on these twin pillars. If the stigma disappeared, far more people would perform professionally -- because such talents are much less rare than assumed -- and competition would drive pay down sharply.
summary: Performers command extravagant pay because their compensation must offset both the rarity of their talents and the social disgrace of using them commercially. If public attitudes changed, many more people would enter these professions, revealing that such talents are far less rare than supposed.
distilled: Performers earn extravagant pay because compensation must cover both rare talent and social stigma, but if the stigma disappeared, an influx of competitors would quickly drive earnings down.
notes: Fascinating application of compensating differentials to the entertainment industry. Smith identifies the paradox of simultaneous social contempt and lavish pay -- we despise performers' social position while richly rewarding their work. The claim that performing talent is more common than assumed has been vindicated by modern entertainment industries, where reduced stigma has indeed expanded the talent pool enormously. This passage prefigures Sherwin Rosen's 'Economics of Superstars' (1981). Cross-reference 1.10.4 on dishonor premiums and 1.10.21 on admiration as compensation.

refashioned: The excessive confidence that most people have in their own abilities is an ancient failing noted by philosophers and moralists in every age. Their equally absurd overconfidence in their own good fortune has received less attention. It is, if anything, even more universal. No one alive, when in reasonable health and spirits, is entirely free of it. Every person overvalues the chance of gain to some degree, and most people undervalue the chance of loss. Hardly anyone in tolerable health and spirits values the chance of loss at more than its actual worth.
elegant: People universally overestimate both their abilities and their luck -- an ancient failing noted by philosophers. Overconfidence in abilities is well recognized, but overconfidence in good fortune is even more pervasive: virtually everyone overvalues their chance of gain and undervalues their chance of loss.
summary: Human beings universally overestimate both their abilities and their good fortune. While overconfidence in talent has long been recognized, overconfidence in luck is even more widespread -- nearly everyone overweights the chance of gain and underweights the chance of loss.
distilled: Virtually all people overestimate both their own abilities and their luck, systematically overvaluing gains and undervaluing losses.
notes: One of Smith's most prescient psychological observations. This is a precise description of what behavioral economists now call 'optimism bias' and 'overconfidence bias.' Written 200 years before Kahneman and Tversky's prospect theory (1979), Smith identifies the asymmetric treatment of gains and losses that is central to modern behavioral economics. The note that this tendency operates when people are 'in tolerable health and spirits' anticipates research on mood-dependent risk assessment. Cross-reference 1.10.24-25 for empirical evidence.

refashioned: That people naturally overvalue the chance of gain is evident from the universal success of lotteries. The world has never seen, and never will see, a perfectly fair lottery -- one where total prizes equal total ticket costs -- because the organizer would make nothing from it. In state lotteries, tickets are not actually worth the price paid by original buyers, yet they commonly sell on the secondary market at twenty, thirty, or even forty percent above face value. The vain hope of winning a large prize is the sole cause of this demand. The most level-headed people scarcely consider it foolish to pay a small sum for a chance at ten or twenty thousand pounds, even knowing that the small sum is perhaps twenty or thirty percent more than the chance is mathematically worth. In a lottery where no prize exceeded twenty pounds -- even one that was otherwise much fairer than typical state lotteries -- there would be far less demand for tickets. To improve their shot at a large prize, some people buy multiple tickets while others buy small shares in many tickets. But it is a mathematical certainty that the more tickets you buy, the more likely you are to lose. Buy every ticket in the lottery and you lose for certain; the more tickets you hold, the closer you approach that certainty.
elegant: Lotteries prove that people overvalue gains. No perfectly fair lottery can exist -- the organizer must profit. State lottery tickets sell above face value despite being objectively overpriced, because the hope of a large prize drives demand. People willingly overpay by twenty to thirty percent for a small chance at a fortune, and show little interest when prizes are small. Mathematically, buying more tickets only increases the certainty of losing.
summary: The universal popularity of lotteries proves people overvalue the chance of gain. State lottery tickets consistently sell above their mathematical value because buyers are drawn by the hope of large prizes. Ironically, buying more tickets -- which many do to improve their chances -- only increases the mathematical certainty of overall loss.
distilled: Lottery popularity proves people systematically overvalue the chance of gain -- paying far above mathematical value for the hope of large prizes, even as buying more tickets guarantees larger net losses.
notes: Brilliant empirical demonstration of optimism bias using lotteries. Smith's observation that no fair lottery can exist (because the operator needs profit) anticipates the modern concept of 'house edge.' The insight that demand depends on prize size, not fairness, explains modern lottery design (massive jackpots attract players despite worse odds). The mathematical certainty that more tickets mean more losses is counterintuitive to most people, illustrating the cognitive bias. Cross-reference 1.10.25 for the undervaluation of loss and 1.10.23 for the theoretical framework.

refashioned: That people frequently undervalue the chance of loss, and rarely value it at more than its true worth, is evident from the very moderate profits of insurance companies. To make fire or maritime insurance a viable business at all, the standard premium must be sufficient to cover typical losses, pay management costs, and yield the same profit that an equal capital could earn in any other trade. Those who pay no more than this evidently pay no more than the real value of the risk -- the lowest price at which insurance can reasonably be offered. Yet though many people have made modest money from insurance, very few have made great fortunes from it, which strongly suggests that the typical balance of profit and loss in insurance is no better than in other trades. Moderate though insurance premiums are, many people consider the risk too small to bother paying them. Averaging across the entire kingdom, nineteen houses out of twenty -- or perhaps ninety-nine out of a hundred -- are not insured against fire. Maritime risk alarms more people, and a higher proportion of ships is insured. Yet many ships sail at all seasons, even in wartime, without any insurance. This may sometimes be reasonable: when a large company or merchant has twenty or thirty ships at sea, they can effectively insure each other, and the premiums saved across the fleet may more than cover any likely losses. But the failure to insure ships, like the failure to insure houses, is in most cases not the result of careful calculation but of thoughtless recklessness and overconfident contempt for the risk.
elegant: Insurance profits prove people undervalue loss. Premiums are set just high enough to cover losses, expenses, and normal profit -- yet few insurers grow rich, confirming the business is no more profitable than average. Despite these moderate premiums, the vast majority of houses go uninsured against fire, and many ships sail uninsured even in wartime. Large fleets may rationally self-insure, but most non-insurance reflects thoughtless contempt for risk rather than calculation.
summary: The moderate profitability of insurance proves people undervalue the chance of loss. Despite premiums representing the true cost of risk, most property owners refuse to insure -- nineteen in twenty houses lack fire insurance. While some large ship-owners may rationally self-insure, most non-insurance reflects reckless overconfidence rather than careful risk assessment.
distilled: The unpopularity of insurance despite actuarially fair premiums proves people systematically undervalue the chance of loss -- mostly from overconfidence, not rational self-insurance.
notes: Companion piece to 1.10.24 on overvaluing gains. Together they demonstrate the asymmetric treatment of gains and losses central to behavioral economics. The insurance industry data is compelling: if people correctly valued risk, insurance would be universal at fair premiums. The distinction between rational self-insurance (large diversified fleets) and irrational non-insurance (most individual cases) shows Smith's analytical precision. The statistic of 19/20 or 99/100 uninsured houses is striking. Cross-reference 1.10.32 for risk and profit rates.

refashioned: Contempt for risk and overconfident hope of success are at their strongest when young people are choosing their professions. How little the fear of failure can counterbalance the hope of success at that age is even more evident in the willingness of common people to enlist as soldiers or go to sea than in the eagerness of those from better backgrounds to enter the liberal professions.
elegant: Overconfidence and contempt for risk peak during the age when people choose careers. This is even more visible in young men eagerly enlisting as soldiers or going to sea than in those entering the liberal professions.
summary: The overconfidence and risk-contempt that distort career choices are strongest in youth, most visibly in the eagerness of young men to enlist as soldiers or sailors despite poor prospects.
distilled: Youthful overconfidence in choosing careers is most strikingly visible in the eagerness of young men to become soldiers or sailors despite objectively poor odds.
notes: Bridges the theoretical analysis of overconfidence (1.10.23-25) to its real-world career consequences. The military and naval examples in 1.10.27-31 are about to illustrate the point dramatically. Smith recognizes that cognitive biases have their strongest effects at critical decision points -- career choice during youth. This anticipates modern research on age-dependent risk preferences. Cross-reference 1.10.27-29 for the military-naval analysis.

refashioned: What a common soldier stands to lose is obvious enough. Yet, despite the danger, young volunteers never enlist as eagerly as at the start of a new war. Though they have virtually no chance of advancement, they imagine, in their youthful daydreams, a thousand opportunities for winning honor and distinction that never actually arise. These romantic fantasies constitute the entire price of their blood. Their pay is less than that of common laborers, and in actual service their hardships are far greater.
elegant: Young soldiers enlist most eagerly at the start of wars, imagining glory and distinction that almost never materialize. These romantic fantasies are the full price paid for their blood -- their actual pay falls below common labor wages while their hardships far exceed them.
summary: Young men enlist most enthusiastically at the start of wars, driven by fantasies of glory that rarely materialize. Their pay is below common labor wages and their hardships far greater -- romantic imagination is the only compensation for the risk of their lives.
distilled: Young soldiers volunteer for less than common labor wages because romantic fantasies of glory and distinction -- which almost never materialize -- constitute the full premium they accept for risking their lives.
notes: Devastating application of overconfidence theory to military recruitment. The phrase 'these romantic hopes make the whole price of their blood' is among Smith's most powerful lines. The combination of below-market wages, extreme hardship, and near-zero advancement prospects makes military service an extreme 'unfair lottery.' Smith's analysis explains why militaries have always relied on youth -- older adults with more experience would better assess the actual risks. Cross-reference 1.10.28-29 for the naval comparison.

refashioned: The lottery of the sea is not quite as unfavorable as that of the army. The son of a respectable laborer or tradesman may frequently go to sea with his father's approval, but if he enlists as a soldier, it is always without it. Other people can see some possibility of his making something of himself at sea; no one but the young man himself sees any prospect in the army. The greatest admirals attract less public admiration than the greatest generals, and the highest success in the naval service promises less brilliant fortune and reputation than equal success on land.
elegant: The navy offers a less unfavorable lottery than the army. Families consent to sons going to sea but not enlisting as soldiers, because others can see prospects in naval life that nobody perceives in common soldiering. Yet even the greatest admirals win less public glory than the greatest generals.
summary: Naval service offers somewhat better prospects than the army -- families consent to it because they can see some chance of success. But even the highest naval achievements bring less fame and fortune than equivalent military accomplishments on land.
distilled: The naval lottery is slightly better than the army's -- families can see some prospects in it -- but even top admirals receive less glory and fortune than top generals.
notes: Comparative risk analysis of military branches. The family consent test is a clever proxy for rational risk assessment -- parents are less biased than the young volunteers themselves. The observation that naval glory trails military glory reflects 18th-century social values but also the structural difference that land battles are more visible and dramatic. Cross-reference 1.10.29 for how this affects the distribution of rewards at lower ranks.

refashioned: The same difference runs through all the lower ranks of both services. By the rules of precedence, a navy captain ranks equally with an army colonel, but in public estimation he does not. Since the top prizes in the naval lottery are smaller, the lesser prizes must be more numerous. Common sailors therefore gain some fortune and advancement more frequently than common soldiers, and the hope of these smaller prizes is what principally makes the trade attractive. Though their skill and dexterity far surpass those of almost any tradesmen, and their entire life is one continuous ordeal of hardship and danger, they receive scarcely any reward for all this skill, hardship, and danger beyond the pleasure of exercising the one and overcoming the other. Their wages are no higher than those of common laborers at the port that sets the rate for seamen's pay. Since sailors continually travel from port to port, their monthly pay across all British ports is more nearly equalized than that of any other type of worker. The rate at the port from which the most sailors depart -- London -- sets the rate for all the rest. In London, wages for most classes of workers are roughly double those of the same classes in Edinburgh.
elegant: Since naval top prizes are smaller than military ones, smaller prizes must be more frequent -- common sailors advance more often than common soldiers, and this hope sustains recruitment. Despite skills surpassing most tradesmen's and a life of constant hardship and danger, sailors earn no more than common port laborers. Their pay is uniquely uniform across Britain because sailors move between ports, with London's rate setting the standard. London workers generally earn double Edinburgh wages.
summary: Common sailors advance more often than soldiers because naval top prizes are smaller, requiring more frequent lesser rewards. Despite exceptional skills and constant danger, sailors' wages merely equal those of common port laborers, with London's rate setting the national standard due to sailors' mobility between ports.
distilled: Sailors earn no more than common laborers despite far greater skill and danger, sustained by the hope of modest advancement that their mobile profession makes slightly more frequent than in the army.
notes: Extends the military-naval comparison to the rank and file. The observation that sailors' inter-port mobility equalizes their wages nationwide is an early application of the law of one price to labor markets -- geographic arbitrage through worker mobility. The London wage-setting mechanism (dominant port sets the rate) anticipates modern analysis of how large markets anchor regional pricing. The captain-colonel precedence comparison illustrates social vs. formal status divergence. Cross-reference 1.10.30 for specific wage data.

refashioned: But sailors departing from London seldom earn more than three or four shillings a month above those sailing from Leith, and the difference is frequently even smaller. In peacetime merchant service, the London rate runs from one guinea to about twenty-seven shillings per calendar month. A common laborer in London, at nine or ten shillings a week, can earn forty to forty-five shillings in a calendar month. The sailor, it is true, receives provisions on top of his pay. But their value may not always exceed the gap between his pay and a common laborer's, and even when it does, the surplus is not a clear gain to the sailor, since he cannot share it with the wife and family he must support from his wages at home.
elegant: London sailors earn only three to four shillings more per month than Leith sailors. In peacetime, a London sailor earns a guinea to twenty-seven shillings monthly, while a common laborer earns forty to forty-five shillings. Sailors receive provisions, but these rarely exceed the wage gap -- and even when they do, the surplus cannot be shared with the family the sailor supports remotely from his cash wages.
summary: Sailors' monetary wages are substantially below those of common laborers -- a London sailor earns roughly half what a London laborer does. Free provisions partly close the gap but cannot be shared with the sailor's family, limiting their real value.
distilled: Sailors earn roughly half what common laborers earn in cash wages, with free provisions only partly closing the gap since they cannot be shared with their families at home.
notes: Detailed wage comparison proving that sailors are objectively underpaid relative to common laborers. The Leith (Edinburgh's port) comparison confirms the narrow geographic wage spread described in 1.10.29. The insight that in-kind benefits (provisions) have limited value because they cannot be transferred to dependents is analytically sophisticated -- modern compensation theory similarly distinguishes between fungible and non-fungible benefits. Cross-reference 1.10.29 for the broader argument and 1.10.31 for why young men choose this poorly-paid career.

refashioned: The dangers and narrow escapes of an adventurous life, instead of discouraging young people, frequently attract them to a trade. An anxious mother among the lower classes is often afraid to send her son to school in a port town, worried that the sight of ships and the stories of sailors will entice him to go to sea. The distant prospect of dangers from which one hopes to escape through courage and skill is not unpleasant and does not raise the wages of any occupation. It is different with dangers where courage and skill are useless. In trades known to be extremely unhealthy, wages are always remarkably high. Unhealthiness is a form of disagreeableness, and its effects on wages fall under that general category.
elegant: Adventure attracts rather than deters the young -- mothers fear port-town schools will lure their sons to sea. Dangers that can be overcome by courage and skill are exciting, not repellent, and do not raise wages. But unavoidable dangers -- particularly unhealthy working conditions where skill offers no protection -- do command wage premiums as a form of disagreeableness.
summary: Escapable dangers actually attract young workers rather than deterring them, so they do not raise wages. Only unavoidable dangers -- particularly unhealthy work conditions where courage cannot help -- command compensating wage premiums, classified under disagreeableness.
distilled: Dangers that can be overcome by courage attract workers and do not raise wages, while unavoidable dangers like unhealthy conditions repel workers and command premiums.
notes: Crucial distinction between two types of risk: those that engage human agency (exciting, wage-neutral) and those that are passive and unavoidable (repellent, wage-raising). This explains why military, naval, and adventure professions can pay poorly despite extreme danger -- the danger is part of the appeal. The anxious mother anecdote is vivid ethnographic observation. The health-risk premium is classified under the first compensating differential (disagreeableness) rather than the fifth (probability of success). Cross-reference 1.10.15 for disagreeableness premiums in mining.

refashioned: In all the different investments of capital, the ordinary rate of profit varies with the certainty or uncertainty of returns. Returns are generally less uncertain in domestic trade than in foreign trade, and less uncertain in some branches of foreign trade than others -- in the North American trade, for example, compared to the Jamaican trade. The ordinary rate of profit always rises somewhat with risk. But it does not seem to rise in proportion to the risk or enough to fully compensate for it. Bankruptcies are most common in the riskiest trades. The riskiest trade of all -- smuggling -- though the most profitable when successful, is the surest road to bankruptcy. The overconfident hope of success seems to operate here as in every other situation, luring so many adventurers into risky trades that their competition drives profits below what is needed to compensate for the risk. To fully compensate, ordinary returns would need to cover not only all occasional losses but also provide the adventurers with a surplus profit equivalent to what an insurer would charge. But if ordinary returns were sufficient for all of this, bankruptcies would be no more frequent in hazardous trades than in others.
elegant: Profit rates rise with uncertainty of returns -- domestic trade being safer than foreign, North American trade safer than Jamaican. But profit does not rise enough to fully compensate for risk, because overconfident adventurers flood risky trades and compete away the adequate premium. Smuggling, the riskiest and most profitable trade when successful, is also the surest path to bankruptcy. If risk were fully compensated, bankruptcies would be equally frequent across all trades.
summary: Profits rise with risk but never enough to fully compensate for it, because overconfident entrepreneurs crowd into hazardous trades and compete away the risk premium. Smuggling epitomizes this pattern -- the most profitable trade when successful, yet the most certain road to ruin. Excess bankruptcies in risky trades prove that overconfidence suppresses returns below adequate risk compensation.
distilled: Profits rise with risk but never fully compensate for it because overconfident entrepreneurs crowd into hazardous trades, competing away the premium that rational risk assessment would demand.
notes: Applies the overconfidence analysis from 1.10.23-25 to entrepreneurial risk-taking. The conclusion that market risk premiums are systematically too low -- because overconfidence drives excess entry -- challenges the efficient-market assumption that risk is always adequately priced. The smuggling example (highest risk, highest individual returns, highest failure rate) perfectly illustrates 'survivorship bias' -- we see the successful smugglers, not the majority who went bankrupt. Cross-reference 1.10.25 on insurance and 1.10.33 for which factors affect profits.

refashioned: Of the five circumstances that create wage differences, therefore, only two also affect the rate of profit: the agreeableness or disagreeableness of the business, and the risk or security involved. In terms of agreeableness, there is little or no difference across most investments of capital, though there are great differences across types of labor. The ordinary rate of profit, though it rises with risk, does not always seem to rise in proportion to it. It follows from all this that, within the same society or area, the average and ordinary profit rates across different investments should be more nearly equal than the wages of different types of labor.
elegant: Only two of the five wage-differentiating factors also affect profits: disagreeableness and risk. Since most investments differ little in agreeableness, and profits do not rise proportionally to risk, profit rates across different trades converge more closely than wages across different types of labor.
summary: Only disagreeableness and risk -- two of the five factors that differentiate wages -- also affect profit rates. Since most capital investments are similarly agreeable and risk premiums are insufficient, profit rates across trades converge more closely than wages across occupations.
distilled: Profit rates across trades are more uniform than wages across occupations because only two of the five compensating factors -- disagreeableness and risk -- apply to capital returns.
notes: Summary assessment closing the five-factor analysis. The asymmetry between wages (affected by all five factors) and profits (affected by only two) explains why profit rates are more uniform than wage rates -- an empirically testable prediction. The observation that the two profit-affecting factors have weaker effects than their wage counterparts reinforces the convergence conclusion. Cross-reference 1.10.3 for the five-factor framework and 1.10.34 for empirical confirmation.

refashioned: And so they are. The difference between the earnings of a common laborer and those of a well-employed lawyer or physician is clearly much greater than the difference between ordinary profits in any two branches of trade. The apparent difference in profits between different trades, moreover, is generally an illusion arising from our failure to distinguish what should properly be counted as wages from what should be counted as profit.
elegant: Profit rates are indeed more uniform than wages: the gap between a laborer's and a lawyer's earnings far exceeds the gap between profits in any two trades. Moreover, apparent profit differences often result from misclassifying wages as profit.
summary: Profit rates are more uniform than wages, confirming theory. The earnings gap between a laborer and a doctor dwarfs any profit gap between trades. Many apparent profit differences are actually disguised wage differences.
distilled: Profit rates are far more uniform than wage rates across occupations, and much of the apparent variation in profits actually reflects disguised wages.
notes: Empirical confirmation of the prediction from 1.10.33. The wages-disguised-as-profits insight is developed in the following passages (1.10.35-37) on apothecaries and small retailers. This misclassification problem persists in modern economics -- small business 'profits' often include the owner's implicit wages. Cross-reference 1.10.35-36 for specific examples.

refashioned: An apothecary's profit has become proverbial for meaning something outrageously excessive. This apparently enormous profit, however, is often nothing more than the reasonable wages of his labor. An apothecary's skill is a much more refined and precise matter than that of any ordinary tradesman, and the trust placed in him is far more important. He is the physician of the poor in all cases, and of the wealthy when the illness or danger is not very serious. His compensation should therefore match his skill and the trust placed in him, and it comes primarily from the price at which he sells his drugs. But the total drugs that even the busiest apothecary in a large market town sells in a year may cost him no more than thirty or forty pounds. Even if he sells them for three or four hundred pounds -- a markup of one thousand percent -- this may be no more than the reasonable wages of his labor, charged in the only way available to him: through the price of his products. The greater part of the apparent profit is actually wages disguised as profit.
elegant: An apothecary's seemingly outrageous thousand-percent markup is actually reasonable wages for skilled, trusted medical work -- charged through drug prices because no other billing method exists. His total annual drug costs may be only thirty to forty pounds, so even selling at three to four hundred pounds merely compensates for the skill and trust his role demands. Most of the apparent profit is disguised wages.
summary: The apothecary's proverbially excessive profit margin is actually reasonable compensation for skilled medical judgment and the trust of patients, charged through drug prices because that is the only available billing mechanism. What appears as enormous profit is mostly disguised wages.
distilled: The apothecary's apparently outrageous thousand-percent markup is actually fair wages for medical skill and patient trust, disguised as profit because drugs are his only billing vehicle.
notes: Classic example of the wages-disguised-as-profit problem identified in 1.10.34. The apothecary performed many functions of a modern general practitioner -- 'physician of the poor' -- but could only bill through product sales. This analysis applies today to many professional services (consulting, financial advice) where compensation is embedded in product pricing rather than billed separately. The trust factor (1.10.17) and training costs (1.10.7) compound the required compensation. Cross-reference 1.10.36 for the small grocer parallel.

refashioned: In a small seaport town, a small grocer will earn forty or fifty percent profit on a hundred-pound stock, while a substantial wholesale merchant in the same place will barely make eight or ten percent on ten thousand pounds. The grocer's trade may be necessary for the convenience of the local inhabitants, and the narrowness of the market may not allow a larger investment in the business. But the grocer must not only live by his trade but live in a manner appropriate to what it requires of him. Besides having a small amount of capital, he must be able to read, write, and do accounts, and must be a reasonable judge of perhaps fifty or sixty different types of goods -- their prices, qualities, and the cheapest markets for obtaining them. He must have all the knowledge required of a great merchant; nothing prevents him from becoming one except lack of capital. Thirty or forty pounds a year cannot be considered too much for the labor of such an accomplished person. Subtract this from the seemingly large profits on his capital, and little remains beyond the ordinary rate of profit. The greater part of the apparent profit is, in this case too, actually wages.
elegant: A small-town grocer earning forty to fifty percent on a hundred-pound stock appears far more profitable than a wholesale merchant earning eight to ten percent on ten thousand. But the grocer must possess the same knowledge as a great merchant -- reading, writing, accounting, and expertise in fifty or sixty types of goods. Deducting thirty to forty pounds for this skilled labor leaves only ordinary profit on his capital. Most of his apparent profit is disguised wages.
summary: The small grocer's apparently high profit rate includes disguised wages for substantial commercial expertise. After subtracting fair compensation for the skilled labor of managing fifty to sixty product lines, his actual return on capital is only ordinary.
distilled: The small grocer's seemingly high profit rate is mostly disguised wages for commercial expertise -- deduct fair compensation for his skilled labor and only ordinary capital returns remain.
notes: Second example of wages disguised as profits. The grocer possesses the same knowledge as a wholesale merchant but on a tiny capital base, so his implicit wages dominate his apparent returns. This perfectly describes many modern small businesses where the owner's labor is the primary input but returns are classified as 'profit.' The observation that only 'want of a sufficient capital' separates the grocer from the great merchant is characteristically egalitarian. Cross-reference 1.10.35 for the apothecary parallel and 1.10.37 for how this effect diminishes with scale.
