refashioned: The difference between apparent retail and wholesale profit rates is much smaller in capital cities than in small towns and villages. Where ten thousand pounds can be invested in the grocery business, the grocer's labor wages become a trivial addition to the actual profit on such a large capital. The apparent profit of the wealthy retailer is therefore much closer to that of the wholesale merchant. This is why retail goods are generally as cheap -- and frequently much cheaper -- in capital cities than in small towns. Grocery goods, for example, are generally much cheaper in cities. Bread and meat are frequently just as cheap. Grocery goods cost no more to transport to a city than to a village, so they are cheapest where the smallest profit is added. Bread and meat cost more to supply in cities because most must come from greater distances. The same cause that reduces apparent profit -- large market scale requiring more capital -- increases the prime cost of these goods. The reduced profit and increased prime cost roughly offset each other in most cases, which probably explains why, though grain and cattle prices differ widely across regions, bread and meat prices are nearly the same throughout most of the country.
elegant: In capital cities, where grocers invest large capital, their labor becomes a negligible share of returns, so retail profits converge with wholesale rates. City grocery goods are therefore cheaper than village goods -- same transport cost, lower markup. Bread and meat are roughly the same price because cities' lower markups are offset by higher supply costs from greater distances. This balancing of lower margins against higher logistics explains why bread and meat prices are remarkably uniform across regions.
summary: The gap between retail and wholesale profit rates narrows in cities because large-scale retail dilutes the labor component of apparent profit. This makes city grocery goods cheaper than village goods. For bread and meat, lower urban margins offset higher transport costs, producing remarkably uniform prices across regions.
distilled: Large-scale urban retail reduces the labor component of apparent profit, making grocery goods cheaper in cities, while for perishables like bread and meat, lower margins and higher transport costs roughly cancel out.
notes: Sophisticated supply-chain analysis linking market size, profit margins, and transport costs. The observation that grocery goods are cheaper in cities (same transport, lower markup) while bread and meat are equal (higher transport, lower markup) is empirically testable and generally confirmed by modern evidence. The explanation for regional price uniformity of perishable goods is an early application of spatial economics. Cross-reference 1.10.36 for the small-scale retail case and 1.10.38 for how great fortunes are built despite low margins.

refashioned: Although profit rates in both wholesale and retail are generally lower in capital cities than in small towns, great fortunes are frequently built from small beginnings in cities but rarely in villages. In small towns, the narrow market prevents expanding a business as capital grows. Though a particular person's profit rate may be high, the total amount of profit can never be very large, nor can annual accumulation be substantial. In great cities, by contrast, trade can expand as capital increases, and a frugal, thriving person's credit grows much faster than his capital. His trade expands in proportion to both capital and credit, his total profit in proportion to trade volume, and his annual accumulation in proportion to total profit. It rarely happens, however, that even in great cities, large fortunes are made through any single established and well-known trade -- except through a long life of industry, frugality, and careful attention. Sudden fortunes are sometimes made through what is called the trade of speculation. The speculative merchant practices no single regular business. He is a grain merchant this year, a wine merchant the next, and a sugar, tobacco, or tea merchant the year after. He enters every trade when he expects it to be unusually profitable and leaves when he expects profits to return to normal levels. His profits and losses therefore follow no regular pattern relative to any established business. A bold speculator may sometimes build a considerable fortune through two or three successful ventures but is just as likely to lose one through two or three unsuccessful ones. This kind of trading can only exist in great cities, where the intelligence needed for it can be obtained through extensive commercial networks.
elegant: Great fortunes grow in cities, not villages, because cities allow businesses to scale with growing capital and credit. But even in cities, fortunes from regular trade require a long life of industry and frugality. Sudden fortunes come through speculation -- the merchant who moves between grain, wine, sugar, and tobacco trades as opportunities arise. A bold speculator may get rich from a few good bets or go bankrupt from a few bad ones. This trade exists only in great cities with the information networks it requires.
summary: Cities enable wealth accumulation that villages cannot because expanding markets allow businesses to grow with their capital. Regular trade builds fortunes slowly through lifelong diligence, while speculation offers the chance of rapid wealth through opportunistic trade-switching -- but with equally rapid ruin. Speculation requires the extensive information networks available only in major commercial centers.
distilled: Cities enable great fortunes because expanding markets allow capital to scale, though regular trade builds wealth slowly while speculation offers rapid but equally precarious gains requiring large-city information networks.
notes: Rich analysis of wealth accumulation dynamics. The regular-trade vs. speculation distinction anticipates the modern difference between value investing and trading. The emphasis on credit growing faster than capital describes financial leverage. The speculator's profile -- moving between commodities based on anticipated price movements -- is essentially a commodity trader. The information advantage of cities explains why financial centers persist. Cross-reference 1.10.37 for why profit rates are lower but total profits higher in cities.

refashioned: The five circumstances discussed above, though they create considerable differences in wages and profit rates, create no differences in the total advantages and disadvantages -- real or imagined -- of different employments of labor and capital. The nature of these circumstances is such that they compensate for low monetary returns in some occupations and offset high returns in others.
elegant: The five compensating circumstances create large differences in wages and profit rates but none in total advantage. Each serves to offset low pay in some occupations and counterbalance high pay in others, maintaining overall equilibrium.
summary: The five compensating differentials -- agreeableness, training cost, constancy, trust, and success probability -- create nominal wage and profit differences but maintain equality of total advantage across employments.
distilled: The five compensating differentials create nominal differences in pay and profit while maintaining equality of total advantage across all employments.
notes: Summary conclusion of Part I of Chapter 10. Restates the fundamental equilibrium principle from 1.10.1: nominal differences in compensation serve to equalize total advantage. This framework remains the foundation of modern labor economics. Cross-reference 1.10.40 onward for Part II: policy-created inequalities that genuinely disrupt this equilibrium.

refashioned: For this equality of total advantages and disadvantages to hold, however, three conditions must be met, even under the most perfect freedom. First, the employments must be well known and long established in the area. Second, they must be in their ordinary or natural state. And third, they must be the sole or principal employments of those who work in them.
elegant: Three conditions are required for the natural equalization of advantages across employments: the trades must be well-established, operating under normal conditions, and serving as workers' primary occupations.
summary: The natural equalization of employment advantages requires three conditions: well-established trades, normal operating conditions, and workers for whom the trade is their primary occupation. Deviations from these conditions create genuine inequalities.
distilled: Natural wage equalization requires well-established trades in normal conditions that serve as workers' primary occupations -- deviations from any condition create real inequalities.
notes: Identifies three prerequisites for the compensating-differential equilibrium to operate. These are conditions for the natural market mechanism, not policy distortions. Sections 1.10.41-49 develop each condition. The 'natural state' qualification is important -- temporary shocks and transitions create genuine disequilibria even in free markets. Cross-reference 1.10.50-58 for the much larger policy-created inequalities.

refashioned:
First, this equalization can occur only in employments that are well known and long established in the area.

All other things being equal, wages are generally higher in new trades than in old ones. When an entrepreneur tries to establish a new manufacture, he must initially attract workers from other trades by offering wages higher than they could earn in their existing jobs or than the new work would otherwise require. Considerable time must pass before he can safely reduce wages to the normal level. Manufactures driven by fashion and novelty are continually changing and rarely last long enough to be considered established industries. Those serving basic needs, by contrast, are more durable -- the same design or product may remain in demand for centuries. Wages are therefore likely to be higher in the former than in the latter. Birmingham deals mainly in fashion-driven manufactures, Sheffield in utility-driven ones, and wages in these two cities are reportedly consistent with this difference.
elegant: New trades pay above-market wages to attract workers from established occupations, and the premium persists until the trade is well established. Fashion-driven manufactures (like Birmingham's) constantly create new trades with above-normal wages, while utility-driven industries (like Sheffield's) are more stable. Wages in these cities reflect the difference.
summary: New trades must offer premium wages to attract workers, creating genuine inequalities until the trade becomes established. Fashion industries constantly regenerate this premium by creating new trades, while utility industries maintain more stable, lower wages.
distilled: New trades pay premium wages to attract workers from established occupations, and fashion-driven industries perpetuate this premium by constantly creating new trades.
notes: First condition for natural equalization: well-established trades. The Birmingham vs. Sheffield comparison is a natural experiment -- both cities in the same region but with different industrial profiles producing different wage dynamics. The insight that fashion industries create perpetual 'newness premiums' explains modern wage patterns in tech, fashion, and entertainment versus manufacturing and utilities. Cross-reference 1.10.42 for the parallel effect on profits.

refashioned: The establishment of any new manufacture, new branch of commerce, or new agricultural practice is always a speculation from which the entrepreneur expects extraordinary profits. These profits are sometimes very large, and sometimes -- perhaps more frequently -- quite the opposite. But in general they bear no regular proportion to the profits of established trades in the area. If the venture succeeds, profits are usually very high at first. When the trade or practice becomes thoroughly established and well known, competition brings returns down to the level of other trades.
elegant: New ventures are speculations with highly variable returns bearing no regular proportion to established trades. Success initially yields extraordinary profits, but as the trade becomes established, competition drives returns to normal levels.
summary: New ventures offer speculative returns that may be very high or very low, with no regular relationship to established trade profits. Successful innovations eventually see their extraordinary returns competed away to normal levels.
distilled: New ventures yield speculative profits unrelated to established norms -- extraordinary when successful, but inevitably driven to normal levels by competition as the trade matures.
notes: Profit-side parallel to the wage analysis in 1.10.41. The lifecycle of innovation profits -- high initial returns competed away over time -- is precisely the dynamic described by Schumpeter's 'creative destruction' 150 years later. The acknowledgment that failure may be more common than success echoes 1.10.19 on the lottery of the professions. Cross-reference 1.10.38 on speculative merchants.

refashioned:
Second, the equalization of total advantages and disadvantages across employments can occur only when those employments are in their ordinary or natural state.

The demand for nearly every type of labor is sometimes greater and sometimes less than usual. When it is greater, the advantages of that employment rise above the common level; when less, they fall below it. The demand for farm labor is higher at harvest and haymaking time than during most of the year, and wages rise accordingly. In wartime, when forty or fifty thousand sailors are forced from the merchant service into the navy, demand for merchant sailors rises sharply with their scarcity, and their wages -- normally one to two guineas per month -- commonly rise to forty shillings or three pounds. In a declining industry, on the other hand, many workers, rather than abandon their trade, accept wages lower than their work's nature would normally warrant.
elegant: The second condition for natural equalization is that employments be in their normal state. Demand fluctuations create temporary wage deviations: harvest time raises farm wages, wartime naval conscription doubles merchant sailors' pay from one guinea to three pounds per month. Conversely, workers in declining industries accept below-normal wages rather than abandon their trade.
summary: Natural wage equalization requires normal demand conditions. Seasonal peaks like harvest, wartime labor shortages from naval conscription, and industrial decline all create temporary wage deviations -- above normal in the first two cases, below normal in the third.
distilled: Temporary demand fluctuations -- seasonal peaks, wartime conscription, industrial decline -- disrupt natural wage equalization by pushing pay above or below its normal level.
notes: Second condition for natural equalization: normal operating conditions. The wartime naval impressment example is particularly striking -- government forcibly removing 40,000-50,000 sailors from the merchant fleet creates an enormous supply shock. The observation that workers in declining industries accept lower wages rather than switch trades illustrates labor market friction and occupational attachment. Cross-reference 1.10.44 for the parallel effect on profits.

refashioned: The profits of capital vary with the prices of the commodities in which it is invested. As any commodity's price rises above the ordinary or average level, the profits of at least some of the capital used in bringing it to market rise above their normal level, and as it falls, they sink below it. All commodities are subject to price variations, but some much more so than others. In all goods produced by human industry, the annual output is naturally regulated by annual demand so that average production roughly matches average consumption. In some industries, the same amount of labor always produces roughly the same quantity of goods -- in the linen or woolen manufactures, for example, the same number of workers will process nearly the same quantity of cloth year after year. Price variations in such goods arise only from fluctuations in demand -- a period of public mourning, for instance, raises the price of black cloth. But since demand for most plain linen and wool is fairly stable, so are their prices. Other industries, however, produce wildly different quantities from the same labor input year to year. The same effort will produce very different amounts of grain, wine, hops, sugar, and tobacco depending on conditions. Prices for these goods fluctuate with both demand variations and the much larger variations in supply, making them extremely volatile. The profits of dealers in such commodities must therefore fluctuate with their prices. Speculative merchants focus precisely on these volatile commodities, buying when they expect prices to rise and selling when they expect them to fall.
elegant: Profits fluctuate with commodity prices. Manufactured goods like linen and wool have stable output and demand, producing stable prices and profits. Agricultural products like grain, wine, and tobacco have wildly variable output from the same labor, causing extreme price and profit volatility through supply fluctuations. Speculators exploit this volatility, buying commodities expected to rise and selling those expected to fall.
summary: Profit volatility depends on commodity type. Manufactured goods with stable output and demand have steady prices and profits. Agricultural products with variable yields experience extreme price swings driven by supply fluctuations, creating opportunities for speculation and corresponding profit volatility.
distilled: Agricultural commodities produce far more profit volatility than manufactured goods because their output varies wildly from year to year despite constant labor input, creating price swings that attract speculators.
notes: Distinguishes between demand-driven and supply-driven price volatility. Manufactured goods face only demand variation; agricultural goods face both demand and (much larger) supply variation. This explains why commodity speculation centers on agricultural and natural products rather than manufactures. The speculative merchant from 1.10.38 reappears here in context. The black-cloth-for-mourning example illustrates a pure demand shock. Cross-reference 1.10.43 for labor-market parallels.

refashioned:
Third, the equalization of total advantages and disadvantages across employments can occur only when those employments are the sole or principal occupations of the people engaged in them.

When a person earns his living from one employment that does not take up most of his time, he is often willing to work at a second job during his free hours for wages lower than the nature of that work would normally require.
elegant: The third condition for natural equalization is that each employment must be the worker's primary occupation. When workers derive their main income elsewhere, they will accept below-market wages for secondary work during idle hours.
summary: Natural wage equalization requires each job to be the worker's primary occupation. Side employment during idle hours depresses wages because the secondary income need not support the worker's full subsistence.
distilled: Workers with other primary income sources will accept below-market wages for secondary work, disrupting the natural equalization of employment advantages.
notes: Third condition for natural equalization. This describes what modern economists call the 'secondary labor market' or 'gig economy' -- workers whose primary income comes from elsewhere accept lower rates for supplementary work, depressing wages in those secondary occupations. Cross-reference 1.10.46-49 for detailed examples (cottagers, stocking-knitters, linen-spinners, London lodging-houses).

refashioned: In many parts of Scotland there still exists a class of people called cottars or cottagers, though they were more common some years ago than now. They are a kind of semi-dependent rural workers attached to landlords and farmers. Their usual compensation includes a house, a small garden for vegetables, enough pasture to feed a cow, and perhaps an acre or two of poor farmland. When their master needs their labor, he additionally provides two pecks of oatmeal per week, worth about sixteen pence. For much of the year, he has little or no need of their services, and cultivating their own small plot does not fill the rest of their time. When these workers were more numerous, they reportedly offered their spare time for very little compensation and worked for lower wages than other laborers. In ancient times, they appear to have been common throughout Europe. In poorly cultivated and sparsely populated countries, most landlords and farmers could not otherwise have obtained the large temporary workforce that agriculture requires at certain seasons. The daily or weekly pay these laborers received from their masters was clearly not the full price of their labor -- their small holdings constituted a substantial part of it. This daily or weekly pay, however, seems to have been treated as their entire compensation by many writers who have collected historical data on wages and prices, and who have taken pleasure in showing both to be remarkably low.
elegant: Scottish cottagers -- semi-dependent rural workers with houses, garden plots, pasture, and small patches of land from their landlords -- traditionally offered their idle-season labor cheaply, having already secured basic subsistence from their holdings. Their daily pay understated their true compensation, since land tenure formed a substantial part of it. Historical writers who recorded only the cash wages of such workers presented a misleadingly low picture of ancient wages and living standards.
summary: Scottish cottagers received most of their compensation through land tenure -- a house, garden, pasture, and small farm. Their low cash wages for spare-time labor understated their true total compensation, misleading historical writers into thinking ancient wages were remarkably low.
distilled: Cottagers' low cash wages were misleading because their total compensation included substantial in-kind benefits from land tenure, causing historical writers to understate actual living standards.
notes: Important methodological point about historical wage data. The cottar system was a feudal remnant -- semi-serf labor arrangements persisting into 18th-century Scotland. Smith's warning that cash wages alone misrepresent total compensation is directly relevant to modern debates about comparing historical living standards. The observation that seasonal labor demands created these arrangements explains their prevalence in agrarian economies. Cross-reference 1.10.47-48 for how secondary labor depresses market wages.

refashioned: The produce of such secondary labor often comes to market cheaper than it otherwise would. Stockings in many parts of Scotland are knitted much more cheaply than they can be made on a loom anywhere. They are produced by servants and laborers whose primary livelihood comes from other work. More than a thousand pairs of Shetland stockings are imported annually into Leith, priced at fivepence to sevenpence a pair. In Lerwick, the small capital of the Shetland Islands, tenpence a day is reportedly a standard wage for common labor. In those same islands, people knit worsted stockings worth a guinea a pair and more.
elegant: Secondary labor produces goods that undercut market prices. Scottish hand-knitted stockings sell for less than loom-made ones because they are produced by workers whose primary income comes from other employment. Shetland imports over a thousand pairs annually at five to seven pence despite common labor wages of tenpence a day -- yet the same knitters produce luxury worsted stockings worth a guinea per pair.
summary: Goods produced as secondary labor -- like hand-knitted Scottish stockings -- come to market below their normal cost because the workers do not depend on them for primary income. Shetland knitters produce both cheap stockings and luxury worsted goods alongside their main occupations.
distilled: Secondary labor brings goods to market below their natural price because the workers' primary income comes from other sources, as illustrated by cheaply priced Scottish hand-knitted stockings.
notes: Concrete example of how secondary labor depresses product prices. The Shetland stocking trade illustrates dual production -- basic goods produced cheaply as side work alongside luxury goods commanding premium prices. The fivepence-sevenpence stocking price compared to tenpence daily wages shows that knitting alone could barely sustain anyone. Leith was Edinburgh's port and commercial hub. Cross-reference 1.10.45-46 for the theoretical framework.

refashioned: The spinning of linen yarn in Scotland is carried on in much the same way as stocking-knitting -- by servants principally employed for other purposes. Those who try to earn their entire living from either of these trades can barely scrape together a subsistence. In most parts of Scotland, a woman considered a good spinner can earn about twentypence a week.
elegant: Scottish linen spinning, like stocking-knitting, is done by servants whose primary employment lies elsewhere. Those attempting to live from spinning alone earn barely subsistence wages -- a good spinner makes only twentypence a week in most of Scotland.
summary: Linen spinning in Scotland, like stocking-knitting, is performed as secondary work by servants employed for other purposes. Full-time spinners earn barely enough to survive -- about twentypence weekly for skilled work.
distilled: Scottish linen spinning pays only subsistence wages because it is dominated by workers for whom it is secondary employment, not a primary livelihood.
notes: Second example of secondary labor depressing wages. The gendered nature of the work is notable -- spinning was primarily women's work. The twentypence weekly wage for a 'good spinner' is strikingly low even by 18th-century standards. Cross-reference 1.10.47 for the stocking-knitting parallel and 1.10.45 for the theoretical framework.

refashioned:
In wealthy countries, the market is generally large enough that any single trade can fully employ all the labor and capital of those who practice it. Cases of people living primarily from one employment while earning supplementary income from another occur mainly in poorer countries. The following example, however, involves something similar in the capital of a very rich one. There is no city in Europe where house rents are higher than in London, and yet I know of no capital where a furnished apartment can be rented so cheaply. Lodging is not only much cheaper in London than in Paris; it is much cheaper than in Edinburgh for comparable quality. And, remarkably, the very dearness of house rents is the cause of cheap lodging.

London's expensive rents arise partly from the usual causes that make housing dear in all great capitals -- costly labor, expensive building materials that must come from distant places, and above all the dearness of land, with every landlord acting as a monopolist and often charging more for one acre of poor urban land than could be gotten for a hundred acres of the best farmland. But rents also arise partly from the peculiar English custom that requires every head of household to rent an entire house from top to bottom. An English dwelling-house means everything under one roof. In France, Scotland, and much of Europe, it often means just a single floor. A London tradesman must rent a whole house in the neighborhood where his customers live. His shop occupies the ground floor, and he and his family sleep in the attic. He then tries to offset part of his rent by letting the middle floors to lodgers. He expects to support his family through his trade, not through his lodgers. In Paris and Edinburgh, by contrast, people who let lodgings typically have no other source of income, so the lodging price must cover not only the rent of the house but the entire expense of the family.
elegant: In wealthy countries, each trade occupies its practitioners fully, but the following London paradox illustrates the secondary-employment principle in a rich capital. London has Europe's highest house rents yet cheapest furnished lodgings. The cause: English custom requires tradesmen to rent entire houses, so they let middle floors as secondary income to offset rent, setting prices low since lodging is not their livelihood. In Paris and Edinburgh, lodging-house keepers depend entirely on rental income, so they must charge enough to support their families.
summary: London's paradox of highest house rents but cheapest lodgings illustrates secondary employment in a wealthy capital. English tradesmen who rent whole houses let middle floors as supplementary income, pricing lodgings cheaply since their livelihood comes from trade. Continental landlords who depend entirely on rental income must charge higher lodging prices.
distilled: London lodgings are Europe's cheapest despite highest house rents because English tradesmen let rooms as secondary income, while continental landlords depend entirely on lodging revenue.
notes: Brilliant paradox illustrating the third equalization condition. The institutional cause -- English whole-house tenure customs versus continental floor-by-floor arrangements -- creates fundamentally different landlord incentive structures. This anticipates modern analysis of how institutional frameworks shape market outcomes. The ground-rent monopoly observation (one acre of urban land worth more than a hundred rural acres) is an early statement of urban land economics. Cross-reference 1.10.45 for the theoretical framework and 1.10.50 for the transition to policy-created inequalities.

refashioned: Such are the inequalities in the total advantages and disadvantages of different employments that arise from failing to meet the three conditions just described, even under perfect freedom. But the policies of Europe, by not leaving things at perfect liberty, create other inequalities of far greater importance.
elegant: The natural inequalities just described arise even under perfect freedom when the three conditions are not met. But European policies, by restricting freedom, create far larger and more consequential inequalities.
summary: Natural inequalities from unmet market conditions are modest compared to the far greater inequalities created by European government policies that restrict economic freedom.
distilled: Policy-created inequalities in labor and capital markets are far more significant than the natural inequalities arising from unmet market conditions.
notes: Pivotal transitional passage from Part I (natural compensating differentials, 1.10.1-49) to Part II (policy-created distortions, 1.10.50-end). Smith signals that government intervention is the primary source of genuine inequality, not market forces. This framing is central to his broader argument for economic liberalism. Cross-reference 1.10.51 for the three categories of policy distortion.

refashioned: European policy creates these inequalities principally in three ways. First, by restricting competition in some employments to fewer people than would otherwise enter them. Second, by increasing competition in other employments beyond its natural level. And third, by obstructing the free movement of labor and capital, both between different employments and between different places.
elegant: European policies distort markets in three ways: restricting entry into some trades, artificially expanding entry into others, and obstructing the free movement of labor and capital between occupations and locations.
summary: European government policies create market inequalities through three mechanisms: restricting competition in some trades, inflating it in others, and blocking the free circulation of labor and capital between employments and locations.
distilled: Government policies distort markets by restricting competition in some trades, inflating it in others, and obstructing the free movement of labor and capital.
notes: Three-part framework for analyzing policy distortions, paralleling the five-factor framework for natural differentials (1.10.3). The first (restricting competition) is developed most extensively through the analysis of corporations and apprenticeship laws (1.10.52-58). The second (inflating competition) and third (obstructing mobility) are developed in later sections. Cross-reference 1.10.52 for the first policy distortion.

refashioned:
First, European policy creates a very significant inequality in the total advantages and disadvantages of different employments by restricting competition in some occupations to fewer people than would otherwise enter them.

The exclusive privileges of incorporated trades -- guilds and corporations -- are the principal means used for this purpose.
elegant: The first and most important policy distortion is restricting competition through the exclusive privileges of incorporated trades -- guilds and corporations.
summary: The most significant policy-created inequality comes from guild and corporation privileges that restrict the number of practitioners in protected trades, reducing competition below its natural level.
distilled: Guild and corporation privileges are the primary policy tool used to restrict competition in European trades below its natural level.
notes: Begins the detailed critique of guild restrictions that occupies much of the remainder of Chapter 10. The guild system -- corporate monopolies over specific trades in specific towns -- was one of the most pervasive regulatory structures in pre-industrial Europe. Smith's critique influenced the gradual dismantling of guild privileges in the 19th century. Cross-reference 1.10.53-58 for specific mechanisms (apprenticeship restrictions, entry barriers).

refashioned: The exclusive privilege of an incorporated trade necessarily limits competition in the town where it is established to those who are members of the trade. Having completed an apprenticeship in the town under a properly qualified master is typically the requirement for obtaining membership. The bylaws of the corporation sometimes regulate the number of apprentices any master may take, and nearly always dictate the number of years each apprentice must serve. Both regulations are designed to restrict competition to far fewer people than would otherwise enter the trade. Limiting the number of apprentices restricts competition directly. A long term of apprenticeship restricts it more indirectly but just as effectively, by increasing the cost of entering the profession.
elegant: Incorporated trades limit competition to certified members by requiring completed apprenticeships under qualified masters. Guild bylaws restrict apprentice numbers (directly limiting entry) and mandate long apprenticeship terms (indirectly limiting entry by raising costs). Both mechanisms keep practitioners far below the number that free competition would produce.
summary: Guilds restrict trade competition through two apprenticeship mechanisms: limiting the number of apprentices each master may train, and requiring long apprenticeship terms. Both serve to keep the number of practitioners far below what free entry would produce.
distilled: Guilds restrict competition through two apprenticeship controls -- limiting trainee numbers and mandating long terms -- both designed to keep practitioners artificially scarce.
notes: Details the mechanics of guild entry barriers. The distinction between direct restriction (limiting apprentice numbers) and indirect restriction (long terms that raise entry costs) anticipates modern analysis of occupational licensing barriers. The 'freedom of the trade' -- guild membership -- was literally a form of property right that could be bought, sold, and inherited. Cross-reference 1.10.54 for specific examples and 1.10.55-56 for the seven-year apprenticeship norm.

refashioned: In Sheffield, no master cutler may have more than one apprentice at a time, by a bylaw of the corporation. In Norfolk and Norwich, no master weaver may have more than two apprentices, under penalty of five pounds a month to the crown. No master hatter anywhere in England or the English colonies may have more than two apprentices, under penalty of five pounds a month -- half to the crown and half to whoever brings suit. Both these regulations, though confirmed by national law, were clearly dictated by the same guild mentality that produced Sheffield's bylaw. The London silk weavers had scarcely been incorporated for a year before they enacted a bylaw limiting any master to two apprentices at a time. It took a special act of Parliament to overturn this restriction.
elegant: Specific guild restrictions on apprentice numbers: Sheffield cutlers allow one per master, Norfolk weavers and English hatters allow two, with five-pound monthly fines for violations. These restrictions, though backed by national law, reflect pure guild self-interest. London silk weavers enacted the same limit within a year of incorporation -- requiring an act of Parliament to rescind.
summary: Guild apprentice limits were severe and widespread: one apprentice per master in Sheffield cutlery, two in Norfolk weaving and English hatmaking, all backed by substantial fines. London silk weavers imposed the same restriction within a year of forming their guild, requiring parliamentary intervention to overturn.
distilled: Guild apprentice restrictions -- typically one or two per master -- were enforced by substantial fines and backed by national law, with even newly formed guilds immediately restricting entry.
notes: Specific evidence of guild entry barriers. The rapid adoption of apprentice limits by newly incorporated trades (silk weavers acting within one year) reveals that restriction was the primary motive for incorporation, not quality control or training standards. The need for parliamentary override demonstrates how entrenched these restrictions became. The fine structure (half to the crown, half to the informer) created private enforcement incentives. Cross-reference 1.10.55-56 for the seven-year apprenticeship requirement.

refashioned: Seven years seems anciently to have been the standard apprenticeship term throughout Europe for most incorporated trades. All such incorporations were originally called universities -- which is indeed the proper Latin word for any corporation whatever. The 'university of smiths' and the 'university of tailors' are expressions commonly found in the old charters of ancient towns. When the particular institutions now called universities were first established, the number of years required to earn a master of arts degree was evidently copied from the apprenticeship term in the common trades, whose incorporations were much older. Just as working seven years under a properly qualified master was necessary to become a master and take on apprentices in a common trade, so studying seven years under a properly qualified teacher was necessary to become a master, teacher, or doctor -- words that were originally synonymous -- in the liberal arts, and to take on students or apprentices, words that were likewise originally synonymous.
elegant: Seven years was the standard European apprenticeship across all incorporated trades, which were originally called 'universities' -- the Latin word for any corporation. Academic universities copied the seven-year term: the master's degree replicated the master craftsman's qualification, 'doctor' originally meant 'teacher,' and 'student' originally meant 'apprentice.'
summary: The seven-year apprenticeship was the European standard, and academic universities -- originally just another type of corporation -- copied this term for their degree requirements. The titles 'master,' 'doctor,' and 'student' all derive from the trade apprenticeship system.
distilled: Academic universities copied the seven-year apprenticeship term from trade guilds, and titles like 'master' and 'doctor' originated as guild terminology for qualified craftsmen and their teachers.
notes: Fascinating etymological and institutional history connecting trade guilds to academic institutions. The Latin 'universitas' simply meant 'corporation' -- applying to smiths, tailors, and scholars equally. The parallel between master craftsman/master of arts, and apprentice/student, reveals that academic credentialing adopted the guild model wholesale. This institutional transfer helps explain why academic degree requirements persist at arbitrary lengths. Cross-reference 1.10.56 for the Statute of Apprenticeship that formalized the seven-year term.

refashioned:
Under the Statute of Apprenticeship -- the fifth year of Elizabeth's reign -- it was enacted that no person could in future practice any trade, craft, or skill then exercised in England without first serving an apprenticeship of at least seven years. What had previously been the bylaw of many individual corporations became the general and public law governing all trades in market towns. Though the statute's language is very broad and seems to cover the whole kingdom, its application has been limited by legal interpretation to market towns, since it was held that in country villages a person may practice several trades without a seven-year apprenticeship in each, these being necessary for the convenience of inhabitants too few to supply each trade with dedicated workers.

By strict interpretation, the statute also applies only to trades existing in England before Elizabeth's fifth year, and has never been extended to trades introduced since then. This limitation has produced several distinctions that, considered as regulatory policy, appear as absurd as possible. It has been ruled, for example, that a coachmaker cannot make or employ journeymen to make his own coach wheels, but must buy them from a master wheelwright -- since wheelwrighting predated the statute. But a wheelwright, never having served as a coachmaker's apprentice, may freely make or hire journeymen to make coaches -- since coachmaking postdated the statute. The manufactures of Manchester, Birmingham, and Wolverhampton are largely exempt from the statute for this reason, not having existed in England before Elizabeth's fifth year.
elegant: Elizabeth's Statute of Apprenticeship (1563) made the seven-year term mandatory for all market-town trades -- generalizing what had been individual guild rules. But judicial interpretation limited it to market towns and to trades existing before the statute, producing absurdities: a coachmaker cannot make his own wheels (wheelwrighting predates the statute) but a wheelwright can freely make coaches (coachmaking postdates it). Manchester, Birmingham, and Wolverhampton's newer industries largely escape the law entirely.
summary: The 1563 Statute of Apprenticeship imposed a universal seven-year requirement on all market-town trades, but judicial interpretation limited it to pre-existing trades, creating absurd distinctions. A coachmaker could not make wheels, but a wheelwright could make coaches. Newer manufacturing cities like Manchester and Birmingham were largely exempt.
distilled: The Statute of Apprenticeship imposed a universal seven-year requirement but only for pre-1563 trades, creating absurd regulatory distinctions and exempting the newer manufacturing cities that would drive the Industrial Revolution.
notes: The Statute of Artificers (5 Elizabeth, c. 4, 1563) was one of the most consequential labor regulations in English history. Smith's critique -- that it produced absurd distinctions and accidentally exempted the most dynamic industrial centers -- is devastatingly effective. The irony that Manchester, Birmingham, and Wolverhampton (future powerhouses of the Industrial Revolution) thrived partly because they escaped guild regulation is historically significant. This passage influenced the statute's eventual repeal in 1814. Cross-reference 1.10.53-55 for the guild system it formalized.

refashioned: In France, the length of apprenticeships varies by city and trade. In Paris, five years is the requirement for many trades, but before anyone can practice as a master, he must often serve five additional years as a journeyman. During this second term he is called his master's companion, and the period itself is called his companionship.
elegant: French apprenticeship terms vary by city and trade. In Paris, many trades require five years of apprenticeship followed by five years as a journeyman 'companion' before one can become a master -- ten years total before independent practice.
summary: French apprenticeship requirements varied by location but could be even more restrictive than English ones. In Paris, many trades required five years of apprenticeship plus five years as a journeyman companion -- a decade of controlled training before independent practice.
distilled: Parisian trades often required ten years of supervised work before independent practice -- five years as an apprentice plus five as a journeyman companion.
notes: The French 'compagnonnage' system -- the journeyman companion stage between apprenticeship and mastership -- added an extra layer of entry restriction beyond the English model. Ten years of supervised work before independent practice is extremely long by modern standards. The companion system also had a cultural dimension: journeymen traveled between masters to broaden their skills, creating networks (compagnonnages) that functioned as early labor organizations. Cross-reference 1.10.55-56 for the English seven-year system.

refashioned: In Scotland, there is no general law governing the length of apprenticeships. The term varies among different corporations. Where it is long, part of it can generally be bought off by paying a small fee. In most towns, a very small fee is also sufficient to purchase membership in any corporation. Linen and hemp cloth weavers -- the country's principal manufacturers -- along with all tradespeople who serve them, such as wheel-makers and reel-makers, may practice their trades in any incorporated town without paying any fee at all. In all corporate towns, anyone is free to sell butcher's meat on any lawful day of the week. Three years is a common apprenticeship term in Scotland, even in some quite skilled trades. In general, I know of no country in Europe where corporate laws are so little oppressive.
elegant: Scotland has no national apprenticeship law. Terms vary by corporation but are typically short -- three years even for skilled trades. Apprenticeships can often be shortened by paying a fee, corporation membership is cheaply purchased, and key industries like linen weaving operate freely across all towns. Scottish corporate laws are the least oppressive in Europe.
summary: Scotland's apprenticeship system is far more liberal than England's or France's: no national law, three-year terms common even for skilled trades, fees to shorten terms or buy guild membership, and key industries exempt from restrictions entirely. Smith considers Scottish corporate laws the least oppressive in Europe.
distilled: Scotland has Europe's least restrictive guild system -- short apprenticeships, cheap guild membership, and key industries exempt from corporate restrictions entirely.
notes: Scotland serves as Smith's positive example of relatively free labor markets, contrasting with England's rigid Statute of Apprenticeship (1.10.56) and France's decade-long training requirements (1.10.57). The three-year term, buyable exemptions, and exempted key industries represent a significantly more market-oriented approach. Smith's judgment that Scottish corporate laws are 'so little oppressive' is notable given his Scottish identity -- this is not mere national pride but a factual comparative assessment. The exemption of linen weavers -- Scotland's primary manufacture -- removed the biggest potential bottleneck. Cross-reference 1.10.53-57 for the contrast with England and France.

refashioned: Every person's right to their own labor is the original foundation of all other property, and therefore the most sacred and inviolable. A poor person's entire wealth lies in the strength and skill of their hands. To prevent them from using that strength and skill in whatever way they see fit -- so long as they harm no one else -- is a clear violation of this most fundamental property right. It is an obvious infringement on the rightful liberty of both the worker and anyone who might wish to employ them. It stops one person from working at what they choose, and stops others from hiring whom they choose. Surely the judgment of whether someone is fit for a job can be trusted to the employers, whose own interests depend on it. The lawmaker's supposed concern that employers might hire an unqualified person is as presumptuous as it is oppressive.
elegant: Every person's labor is their most sacred property. To forbid a poor person from using their strength and skill as they choose -- without harming others -- violates this fundamental right. It restricts both workers and employers. Whether someone is fit for employment should be left to the employer whose own interest depends on it. The lawmaker's anxiety about improper hiring is as presumptuous as it is oppressive.
summary: Smith argues that a person's own labor is the most fundamental form of property. Restricting how people use their labor violates both the worker's and the employer's liberty, and the government's paternalistic concern about hiring decisions is both unnecessary and oppressive.
distilled: A person's right to their own labor is the most sacred property, and government restrictions on how it may be used violate both workers' and employers' natural liberty.
notes: Natural rights theory applied to labor -- labor as foundational property right -- critique of paternalistic regulation -- liberty of contract between employer and worker -- connects to Locke's labor theory of property

refashioned: Long apprenticeships provide no guarantee that shoddy work will not be sold to the public. When defective goods reach the market, it is generally due to fraud, not incompetence -- and no length of apprenticeship can guard against fraud. Entirely different regulations are needed to address that problem. Quality marks stamped on silver plate, and inspection stamps on linen and woolen cloth, give buyers far greater assurance than any apprenticeship statute. Consumers typically check for these marks but never bother to ask whether the craftsman served a seven-year apprenticeship.
elegant: Long apprenticeships cannot prevent shoddy goods from reaching market. When they do, it is usually fraud, not lack of skill -- and apprenticeships cannot prevent fraud. Quality stamps on silver, linen, and wool give consumers far better assurance. Buyers check these marks but never ask about a craftsman's apprenticeship.
summary: Smith argues that apprenticeship requirements fail to prevent poor-quality goods from being sold. Quality control marks and stamps are far more effective consumer protections than requiring years of training.
distilled: Apprenticeships cannot prevent fraud or ensure quality -- inspection stamps and quality marks serve consumers far better.
notes: Quality assurance mechanisms -- product certification vs. producer certification -- consumer behavior and information -- critique of apprenticeship as consumer protection

refashioned: Long apprenticeships do nothing to cultivate industriousness in young people. A journeyman paid by the piece is likely to be hardworking because he profits directly from every effort. An apprentice is likely to be idle -- and almost always is -- because he has no immediate incentive to work hard. In lower-status jobs, the entire appeal of labor lies in the pay it brings. Those who can soonest enjoy that reward are soonest likely to develop a taste for it and form early habits of industry. A young person naturally develops an aversion to work when they labor for a long time without any benefit. The boys sent out as apprentices from public charities are typically bound for even longer than the usual term, and they generally turn out to be very lazy and unproductive.
elegant: Long apprenticeships do not foster industriousness. A journeyman paid by the piece works hard because effort directly benefits him. An apprentice, gaining nothing from exertion, is almost always idle. In ordinary trades, the appeal of labor is its reward -- those who taste that reward earliest develop industry earliest. A young person forced to work long without benefit naturally grows to resent labor. Charity apprentices, bound for the longest terms, typically become the laziest workers.
summary: Smith contends that long apprenticeships actually discourage hard work by removing the immediate connection between effort and reward. Piece-rate workers are industrious because they benefit directly, while apprentices, seeing no reward, develop habits of idleness.
distilled: Apprenticeships breed idleness by severing the link between effort and reward, while piece-rate payment naturally encourages industriousness.
notes: Incentive theory -- piece-rate vs. fixed compensation -- habit formation -- intrinsic vs. extrinsic motivation -- charity apprentices as case study -- moral hazard in apprenticeship

refashioned: Apprenticeships were completely unknown in the ancient world. The mutual obligations of master and apprentice fill a substantial section in every modern legal code, yet Roman law says nothing about them. I know of no Greek or Latin word -- and I believe none exists -- that expresses the concept we now attach to the word 'apprentice': a servant bound to work at a particular trade for the benefit of a master for a set number of years, on the condition that the master will teach them that trade.
elegant: Apprenticeships were unknown to the ancients. Though master-apprentice duties fill pages in modern law, Roman law is silent on them. No Greek or Latin word exists for our concept of an apprentice -- a servant bound to work at a trade for years in exchange for instruction.
summary: Smith notes that the apprenticeship system is a modern invention with no precedent in the ancient world, as evidenced by the absence of any equivalent concept in Greek or Roman law.
distilled: Apprenticeships are a purely modern institution unknown to ancient Greece and Rome.
notes: Historical context of apprenticeship -- Roman law comparison -- institutional history -- the apprenticeship system as medieval/modern invention

refashioned: Long apprenticeships are entirely unnecessary. Even the arts far superior to common trades -- such as clock and watchmaking -- contain no mystery requiring years of instruction. The original invention of such beautiful machines, and of the instruments used to make them, was undoubtedly the product of deep thought and long effort, and may rightly be counted among humanity's finest achievements. But once both machine and instruments have been invented and are well understood, explaining to a young person in complete detail how to apply the instruments and construct the machines should take no more than a few weeks of lessons -- perhaps even a few days. For common mechanical trades, a few days would certainly suffice. Practical dexterity, even in common trades, does require practice and experience. But a young person would practice far more diligently and attentively if, from the start, they worked as a journeyman -- paid in proportion to the small amount of work they could produce, and paying in turn for materials they might spoil through clumsiness and inexperience. Their education would generally be more effective this way, and always less tedious and expensive. The master, admittedly, would lose out -- he would forfeit the seven years of virtually free labor an apprentice currently provides. In the end, the apprentice himself might also lose out, for in a trade so easily learned he would face more competitors, and his wages as a fully trained worker would be lower. The same increase in competition would also reduce the masters' profits. The trades, the crafts, the guilds -- all would lose. But the public would gain, as the work of all craftsmen would come to market much more cheaply.
elegant: Long apprenticeships are unnecessary. Even complex arts like watchmaking require only weeks of instruction once the craft is well understood; common trades need only days. True skill comes from practice, but a young person would practice harder as a paid journeyman than as an unpaid apprentice. This approach would be more effective and less costly. Masters would lose their free labor, and workers would face more competition and lower wages. But the public would gain enormously, as goods would come to market much more cheaply.
summary: Smith argues that even sophisticated trades require only brief formal instruction, with the rest learned through practice. Apprenticeships primarily serve to restrict competition. If abolished, masters and established workers would earn less, but the public would benefit from cheaper goods.
distilled: Long apprenticeships are unnecessary for learning trades and exist mainly to restrict competition, keeping prices artificially high at the public's expense.
notes: Human capital theory -- distinction between formal instruction and practical learning -- competition and prices -- whose interests apprenticeships serve -- public interest vs. producer interest -- rent-seeking through training requirements

refashioned: It is precisely to prevent this reduction in prices -- and consequently in wages and profits -- by restraining the free competition that would certainly cause it, that all corporations and most corporation laws have been established. In many parts of Europe, the only authority needed to form a corporation in ancient times was that of the town government where it was established. In England, a royal charter was also required. But this royal prerogative seems to have been reserved more for extracting money from subjects than for defending the common liberty against oppressive monopolies. Upon paying a fine to the king, charters were generally granted readily. And when a particular class of craftsmen or traders chose to act as a corporation without a charter, these so-called 'adulterine guilds' were not always disbanded -- they were simply required to pay annual fines to the king for permission to exercise their assumed privileges. The direct oversight of all corporations and the bylaws they might enact for their own governance belonged to the town government where they were established. Whatever discipline was imposed on them generally came not from the king, but from the larger municipal corporation of which these smaller ones were merely parts.
elegant: Corporations and their laws exist to prevent the reduction of prices, wages, and profits that free competition would bring. Forming them required town or royal approval, but royal charters served more to extract fees than to protect the public. Even unauthorized 'adulterine guilds' were tolerated if they paid annual fines. Oversight came from town governments, not the crown -- these guilds were simply parts of the larger municipal corporation.
summary: Smith explains that corporations were created specifically to suppress competition and maintain artificially high prices. Royal charters were more about revenue extraction than public protection, and oversight of these organizations rested with town governments rather than the crown.
distilled: Corporations were established to restrain competition and keep prices high, with royal charters serving mainly as a revenue tool rather than a public safeguard.
notes: History of corporations and guilds -- rent-seeking behavior -- royal prerogative as revenue extraction -- adulterine guilds -- municipal governance -- monopoly formation

refashioned: Town governments were entirely controlled by traders and craftsmen, and it was clearly in every group's interest to prevent the market from being 'overstocked' -- as they put it -- with their own type of goods. In reality, this meant keeping the market permanently understocked. Each group eagerly established regulations to achieve this, and each was willing to let every other group do the same, provided it could do so itself. As a result, each group had to buy goods from other trades within the town at somewhat higher prices than they otherwise would have paid. But in return, they could sell their own goods at equally inflated prices -- so within the town, it was a wash, as the saying goes: none of them lost out in their dealings with each other. However, in their dealings with the countryside, they were all enormous winners. And it is these dealings with the countryside that constitute the entire trade which sustains and enriches every town.
elegant: Town governments, run by traders and craftsmen, had every incentive to keep markets understocked with their own goods. Each group set restrictions and accepted that others would too. Within the town, the higher prices balanced out. But in dealings with the countryside -- the trade that truly sustains every town -- they were all enormous winners.
summary: Smith describes how town guilds cooperated in mutual market restriction. While the inflated prices cancelled out in their dealings with each other, the real beneficiaries were all the town's trades collectively, who gained at the expense of the rural population.
distilled: Town guilds mutually agreed to restrict competition, and while this balanced out among themselves, they collectively profited enormously at the countryside's expense.
notes: Collective action among guilds -- urban vs. rural economic power -- mutual monopoly agreements -- implicit cartel behavior -- the town-country economic relationship

refashioned: Every town draws its entire sustenance and all the raw materials of its industry from the countryside. It pays for these in two main ways. First, by sending manufactured goods back to the country -- in which case the price includes the workers' wages and the employers' profits. Second, by sending the country either raw or manufactured goods imported from other regions or countries -- in which case the original price is increased by the wages of carriers or sailors and the profits of the merchants who employ them. The town's manufacturing advantage comes from what it gains on the first branch; its trading advantage from the second. The wages of workers and the profits of their employers together make up all that is gained from both. Any regulations that tend to raise those wages and profits beyond their natural level enable the town to purchase, with a smaller quantity of its own labor, the product of a greater quantity of the country's labor. Such regulations give the town's traders and craftsmen an advantage over the country's landlords, farmers, and laborers, and destroy the natural equality that would otherwise prevail in their commerce. The entire annual product of society's labor is divided between these two groups. Through such regulations, the town's inhabitants receive a larger share than they would naturally get, and the country's inhabitants receive less.
elegant: Towns get all their food and raw materials from the countryside, paying with manufactured goods and imported products. Regulations that push town wages and profits above natural levels let the town buy more country labor with less of its own. This gives urban traders an advantage over rural landlords, farmers, and laborers, distorting the natural balance. The result: towns claim a larger share of society's total output at the country's expense.
summary: Smith explains the two channels through which towns trade with the countryside and argues that regulations inflating urban wages and profits allow towns to exchange less of their own labor for more of the country's, distorting the natural economic balance between urban and rural populations.
distilled: Regulations that inflate urban wages and profits let towns purchase more rural labor with less of their own, unfairly shifting wealth from the countryside to the town.
notes: Urban-rural terms of trade -- manufacturing vs. agricultural surplus -- distributional effects of regulation -- zero-sum transfer through monopoly pricing -- natural vs. regulated equilibrium

refashioned:
The real price a town pays for the provisions and materials it imports each year is the quantity of manufactured and other goods it exports. The more expensively the exports are sold, the more cheaply the imports are effectively bought. Urban industry becomes more profitable, and rural industry less so.

That urban industry is everywhere in Europe more profitable than rural industry can be confirmed by a simple observation, without any elaborate calculations. In every European country, we find at least a hundred people who have built great fortunes from modest beginnings through trade and manufacturing -- urban industries -- for every one who has done so through agriculture and land cultivation. Industry, therefore, must be better rewarded in towns: wages and profits must clearly be higher in urban than in rural occupations. But capital and labor naturally seek the most profitable employment, so they naturally flow toward towns and away from the countryside.
elegant: The more expensively a town sells its exports, the more cheaply it effectively buys its food and raw materials -- making urban industry more profitable at rural industry's expense. The proof is simple: in every European country, for every person who has built a fortune through farming, a hundred have done so through urban trade and manufacturing. Capital and labor naturally seek the best returns, so they flow toward towns and desert the countryside.
summary: Smith argues that the terms of trade between town and country systematically favor urban industry. The proof is that vastly more fortunes have been built through urban trade than through farming, causing capital and labor to concentrate in towns.
distilled: Urban industry is demonstrably more profitable than agriculture across Europe, as evidenced by the overwhelming concentration of self-made fortunes in trade and manufacturing rather than farming.
notes: Terms of trade -- urban-rural wealth gap -- capital mobility toward higher returns -- empirical observation of fortune-building -- self-reinforcing urban advantage

refashioned: Town inhabitants, being concentrated in one place, can easily organize collectively. Even the most trivial trades in towns have, in one place or another, been formally incorporated. And even where they have not been incorporated, the corporate mentality -- suspicion of outsiders, reluctance to take apprentices, secrecy about trade methods -- generally prevails, often leading to voluntary associations and agreements to prevent the free competition they cannot prohibit by law. Trades employing only a small number of workers fall into such combinations most easily. Half a dozen wool-combers, for example, might be needed to keep a thousand spinners and weavers busy. By agreeing not to take apprentices, they can monopolize the trade, reduce the entire manufacturing chain to a kind of servitude, and push their wages far above what the nature of their work warrants.
elegant: Town workers, concentrated together, combine easily. Even the smallest trades have formed corporations, and where they have not, the corporate mentality -- secrecy, hostility to outsiders, reluctance to train newcomers -- still prevails through voluntary agreements. Trades with few workers combine most easily. Six wool-combers can hold a thousand spinners and weavers hostage by refusing to take apprentices, monopolizing the trade and inflating their wages far beyond what the work deserves.
summary: Smith observes that urban workers can easily combine due to their physical proximity. Even without formal incorporation, the corporate spirit of secrecy and exclusion prevails. Trades with few workers are especially prone to forming monopolistic combinations that exploit the larger workforce dependent on them.
distilled: Urban workers easily form combinations to restrict competition, and trades with few practitioners can effectively hold entire industries hostage by refusing to train newcomers.
notes: Collective action problem -- geographic concentration enables collusion -- bottleneck occupations -- monopsony/monopoly in labor markets -- wool-combers as case study of strategic labor scarcity

refashioned: Country inhabitants, scattered across distant locations, cannot easily combine. They have never been incorporated, and the corporate spirit has never taken hold among them. No apprenticeship has ever been thought necessary for farming, the great trade of the countryside. Yet after the fine arts and the liberal professions, there is perhaps no occupation requiring such a wide range of knowledge and experience. The countless volumes written on agriculture in every language should convince us that, even among the wisest nations, it has never been considered an easy subject to master. And from all those volumes we would search in vain for the practical knowledge of farming's complex operations that even an ordinary farmer possesses -- however contemptuously the quite contemptible authors of some of those books may speak of him. By contrast, there is scarcely a common mechanical trade whose entire set of operations cannot be fully explained in a pamphlet of a few pages, illustrated with diagrams. In the French Academy of Sciences' ongoing history of the arts, several trades are actually described this way. Moreover, farming operations must be adjusted constantly with every change in weather and many other variable conditions, requiring far more judgment and discretion than trades where the work is always the same or nearly so.
elegant: Country people, scattered widely, cannot combine like town workers. No apprenticeship was ever required for farming -- yet farming demands more varied knowledge than almost any other occupation besides the fine arts. Countless volumes on agriculture prove it has never been considered simple. The practical knowledge of an ordinary farmer exceeds what any book captures, while most mechanical trades can be fully explained in a brief pamphlet. Farming also demands constant adaptation to weather and conditions, requiring far greater judgment than repetitive trades.
summary: Smith argues that while rural workers lack the ability to organize collectively, farming actually requires far more knowledge, experience, and adaptive judgment than most mechanical trades. The inability of farmers to combine, not any deficiency in skill, explains their disadvantaged position.
distilled: Farming requires more knowledge and adaptive judgment than most mechanical trades, yet farmers cannot combine like urban workers to protect their interests.
notes: Tacit vs. codifiable knowledge -- complexity of agriculture -- rural collective action problem -- intellectual demands of farming vs. manufacturing -- French Academy's arts publications -- defense of the common farmer's intelligence

refashioned: Not only does farming itself require great skill, but many subordinate branches of country labor also demand more skill and experience than most mechanical trades. A person who works with brass and iron uses instruments and materials whose properties remain constant. But a plowman working with a team of horses or oxen works with instruments whose health, strength, and temperament vary constantly. The materials he works upon -- the soil and its conditions -- are equally variable, and both demand considerable judgment and discretion. The common plowman, though generally regarded as the model of stupidity and ignorance, is seldom deficient in this judgment. He is, admittedly, less accustomed to social interaction than the town mechanic. His speech and manner are rougher and harder for townspeople to understand. Yet his mind, being accustomed to dealing with a far greater variety of situations, is generally much superior to that of the mechanic, whose attention from morning to night is typically consumed by one or two very simple operations. How much the rural lower classes actually surpass their urban counterparts is well known to anyone who has dealt extensively with both. In China and India, accordingly, both the status and wages of rural laborers are said to exceed those of most craftsmen and manufacturers. This would probably be the case everywhere, if corporation laws and the corporate spirit did not prevent it.
elegant: Many branches of country labor require more skill than mechanical trades. A metalworker uses materials with constant properties, but a plowman works with living animals and variable soil, demanding constant judgment. The common plowman, though dismissed as ignorant, deals with far greater variety than the town mechanic who repeats the same simple operations all day. His understanding is generally superior. In China and India, rural laborers outrank most urban craftsmen in both status and pay -- and this would be universal if not for corporation laws.
summary: Smith defends the intelligence of rural workers, arguing that farming requires greater adaptability and judgment than repetitive urban trades. He notes that in countries without strong guild systems, like China and India, rural workers are accordingly ranked higher and paid better than most urban craftsmen.
distilled: Rural laborers exercise greater judgment and adaptability than most urban mechanics, and would be better compensated everywhere if not for the artificial advantages created by corporation laws.
notes: Cognitive complexity of agricultural vs. mechanical work -- defense of the plowman's intelligence -- variable vs. constant working conditions -- China and India as comparison cases -- corporation laws as distortion of natural wage hierarchy

refashioned: The superiority of urban over rural industry throughout Europe is not solely due to corporations and their laws. It is supported by many other regulations as well. High duties on foreign manufactures and on all goods imported by foreign merchants serve the same purpose. Corporation laws protect town producers from being undercut by domestic competitors; these additional regulations protect them equally against foreign competitors. The resulting price increases are ultimately paid by the country's landlords, farmers, and laborers, who have rarely opposed the establishment of such monopolies. They generally have neither the inclination nor the capacity to form combinations of their own. And the clamor and sophistical arguments of merchants and manufacturers easily persuade them that the private interest of one group -- and a subordinate group at that -- is the general interest of the whole society.
elegant: Urban industry's advantage over rural industry stems not only from corporation laws but also from import duties that shield town producers from foreign competition. The resulting higher prices are ultimately paid by landlords, farmers, and laborers, who rarely resist these monopolies. Lacking the ability to organize, rural people are easily persuaded by merchants' sophistry that the private interest of one class is the general interest of all.
summary: Smith argues that the urban advantage is reinforced by import duties alongside corporation laws. Rural populations, unable to organize effectively, bear the costs and are easily deceived by merchants' arguments that producer interests represent the public interest.
distilled: Import duties and corporation laws together protect urban industry at rural society's expense, and the scattered rural population is easily deceived into accepting this arrangement.
notes: Protectionism -- import duties as complement to guild monopolies -- political economy of special interests -- rural populations as diffuse losers -- concentrated benefits vs. dispersed costs -- sophistical arguments for producer protection

refashioned: In Great Britain, the advantage of urban over rural industry appears to have been greater in the past than it is today. Country wages have moved closer to manufacturing wages, and agricultural profits closer to trading and manufacturing profits, compared to the previous century or the beginning of the current one. This change may be seen as the necessary, though very delayed, consequence of the extraordinary encouragement given to urban industry. The capital accumulated in towns eventually grows so large that it can no longer earn its former rate of profit in urban industries alone. Like every other industry, urban industry has its limits, and the accumulation of capital, by increasing competition, inevitably reduces profit. Falling urban profits force capital out to the countryside, where it creates new demand for rural labor and necessarily raises rural wages. Capital then spreads, so to speak, across the face of the land, and by being employed in agriculture, is partly restored to the country at whose expense it had originally been accumulated in the towns. I shall endeavor to show later that the greatest improvements throughout European agriculture have resulted from such overflows of capital originally accumulated in towns, and at the same time to demonstrate that though some countries have achieved considerable wealth by this process, it is inherently slow, uncertain, vulnerable to countless disruptions, and in every respect contrary to the natural and rational order. The interests, prejudices, laws, and customs that gave rise to this unnatural course, I shall explain as fully as I can in the third and fourth books of this work.
elegant: In Britain, the urban-rural economic gap has narrowed over time -- a delayed consequence of excessive encouragement to urban industry. As urban capital accumulated beyond what could earn its former profits, competition drove returns down, forcing capital into the countryside. This raised rural wages and spread investment across the land, partly restoring to the country what had been extracted. Smith promises to show later that Europe's agricultural improvements mostly resulted from such capital overflow -- but that this roundabout process is inherently slow, uncertain, and contrary to natural economic order.
summary: Smith traces how excess urban capital accumulation eventually forces investment back into the countryside, narrowing the urban-rural gap. He views this as a corrective but deeply inefficient process -- contrary to the natural order where agriculture would develop first -- which he promises to analyze fully in later books.
distilled: Excess urban capital accumulation eventually forces investment back into agriculture, narrowing the urban-rural gap, but this roundabout development path is inherently slow and contrary to natural economic order.
notes: Capital overflow theory -- diminishing returns to urban capital -- natural vs. artificial development order -- preview of Books III and IV -- convergence of urban and rural returns -- self-correcting market mechanisms

refashioned: People in the same trade seldom gather together, even for socializing, without the conversation ending in a conspiracy against the public or some scheme to raise prices.
