It is impossible to prevent such meetings through any law that could be enforced or that would be consistent with liberty and justice. But while the law cannot stop people in the same trade from occasionally meeting, it should do nothing to facilitate such gatherings -- much less to make them necessary.
elegant: People in the same trade rarely meet, even socially, without conspiring against the public or scheming to raise prices. No enforceable law consistent with liberty can prevent such meetings. But the law should never facilitate them, much less make them necessary.
summary: Smith observes that members of the same trade inevitably conspire to raise prices when they gather. While preventing such meetings would violate liberty, the law should avoid creating conditions that encourage or require them.
distilled: People in the same trade inevitably conspire against the public when they meet, so while the law cannot prevent such gatherings, it should never facilitate them.
notes: One of Smith's most famous passages -- collusion as natural tendency -- limits of regulation -- balance between liberty and competition policy -- warning against trade associations

refashioned:
Any regulation that requires everyone in the same trade within a town to register their names and addresses in a public directory facilitates such collusion. It connects people who might never otherwise have known each other and gives every member of the trade a way to find every other member.

A regulation that allows members of the same trade to tax themselves to fund support for their poor, sick, widows, and orphans -- by giving them a shared interest to manage -- makes such assemblies not just possible but necessary.
elegant: Requiring tradespeople to register in public directories facilitates collusion by connecting people who would otherwise never meet. Allowing them to tax themselves for mutual aid -- supporting their poor, sick, widows, and orphans -- gives them a common interest that makes assemblies necessary.
summary: Smith identifies two specific regulations that promote trade collusion: public trade registries that connect potential conspirators, and mutual aid funds that give tradespeople a shared purpose requiring regular meetings.
distilled: Trade registries and mutual aid provisions facilitate collusion by connecting traders and creating reasons for them to assemble regularly.
notes: Institutional design and unintended consequences -- information networks enabling collusion -- mutual aid as pretext for combination -- specific policy critique

refashioned: A formal incorporation not only makes such assemblies necessary but makes the decisions of the majority binding on everyone. In a free trade, an effective combination can only be formed with the unanimous consent of every single trader, and it lasts only as long as every trader remains in agreement. But the majority of a corporation can enact a bylaw, with enforceable penalties, that will restrict competition more effectively and more permanently than any voluntary agreement ever could.
elegant: Incorporation makes the majority's decisions binding on all members. In free trade, combinations require unanimous consent and dissolve when anyone dissents. But a corporation's majority can enact bylaws with penalties that restrict competition far more effectively and durably than any voluntary agreement.
summary: Smith explains that formal incorporation transforms voluntary agreements into binding rules, since a corporate majority can impose restrictions on all members through enforceable bylaws -- far more powerful than any voluntary combination.
distilled: Incorporation gives the majority power to impose binding competition-restricting bylaws on all members, making combinations far more durable than voluntary agreements.
notes: Majority rule in corporations -- binding vs. voluntary agreements -- collective action and free-riding -- institutional power to enforce cartels -- corporate governance and competition

refashioned: The claim that corporations are necessary for proper governance of a trade has no foundation. The real and effective discipline over a worker comes not from his corporation but from his customers. It is the fear of losing business that restrains fraud and corrects negligence. An exclusive corporation necessarily weakens this discipline, because a particular group of workers must be employed regardless of whether they perform well or badly. This is why, in many large incorporated towns, competent workers cannot be found even in some of the most essential trades. If you want work done properly, it must be done in the suburbs, where workers have no exclusive privileges and depend entirely on their reputation -- and then you must smuggle the goods into town as best you can.
elegant: The claim that corporations govern trade quality is baseless. The real discipline comes from customers -- the fear of losing business restrains fraud and corrects negligence. Exclusive corporations weaken this by guaranteeing employment regardless of quality. In many large incorporated towns, competent workers cannot be found even in essential trades. To get good work, one must go to the suburbs, where workers depend on reputation alone.
summary: Smith argues that customer choice, not corporate governance, ensures quality work. Exclusive corporations actually degrade quality by removing competitive pressure, which is why competent craftsmen are often found only in unregulated suburbs rather than in incorporated towns.
distilled: Customer competition, not corporate regulation, ensures work quality -- exclusive corporations degrade standards by guaranteeing employment regardless of performance.
notes: Market discipline vs. regulatory discipline -- customer sovereignty -- monopoly and quality degradation -- suburbs as competitive fringe -- reputation as quality assurance mechanism

refashioned:
This, then, is how European policy, by restricting competition in some occupations to fewer people than would otherwise enter them, creates a significant inequality in the overall advantages and disadvantages of different employments of labor and capital.

Second, European policy also increases competition in certain other occupations beyond its natural level, creating an opposite kind of inequality in those employments.
elegant: European policy creates inequality in two directions: by restricting competition in some occupations to fewer participants than would naturally enter, and by artificially increasing competition in others beyond its natural level.
summary: Smith transitions from discussing how policy restricts competition in some trades (raising returns) to how it artificially increases competition in others (depressing returns), creating inequality in both directions.
distilled: European policy distorts employment returns in two opposing ways: by restricting competition in some trades and artificially increasing it in others.
notes: Transition paragraph -- two forms of policy distortion -- symmetry of analysis -- introduction to education subsidies discussion -- framework for analyzing labor market interventions

refashioned: The education of young people for certain professions has been considered so important that sometimes public funds and sometimes private charity have established numerous scholarships, bursaries, and other financial support for this purpose. This draws far more people into those professions than could otherwise pursue them. In all Christian countries, the education of most clergy is funded in this way. Very few are educated entirely at their own expense. The long, tedious, and costly education of those who do pay their own way will therefore not always earn them a suitable reward, because the profession is flooded with people willing to accept far less compensation than such an education would normally merit. In this way, the competition of the subsidized poor takes away the reward of the self-funded. It would be unseemly, no doubt, to compare a curate or chaplain with an ordinary journeyman worker.
elegant: Public funds and private charity have established scholarships to train people for certain professions, drawing in far more than could otherwise enter. Most clergy are educated this way. The resulting oversupply means the long, expensive education of self-funded candidates goes unrewarded, as the profession fills with subsidized candidates willing to work for far less. The competition of the subsidized poor takes away the reward of the self-funded.
summary: Smith argues that public subsidies for education in certain professions -- particularly the clergy -- create oversupply, driving down compensation below what the expensive training would otherwise command. The subsidized poor crowd out the self-funded.
distilled: Educational subsidies for certain professions flood them with candidates, driving compensation below what the required training would naturally command.
notes: Education subsidies and labor market distortion -- overcrowding in subsidized professions -- clergy as case study -- unintended consequences of charitable funding -- cross-reference to 1.10.77 on artificial competition increase

refashioned: The pay of a curate or chaplain may quite properly be compared to the wages of a journeyman. All three are paid for their work according to whatever contract they make with their respective superiors. Until after the middle of the fourteenth century, five merks -- containing about as much silver as ten pounds in present money -- was the standard pay for a curate or stipendiary parish priest in England, as regulated by various national councils. At the same time, fourpence a day, equivalent to a present-day shilling, was the declared pay for a master mason, and threepence a day, equivalent to ninepence in current money, for a journeyman mason. The wages of both these laborers, assuming steady employment, were therefore considerably higher than those of the curate.
elegant: A curate's pay is comparable to a journeyman's wages -- both are paid by contract. In fourteenth-century England, a curate earned five merks (about ten pounds today) annually. Meanwhile, a master mason earned a shilling a day and a journeyman mason ninepence -- both considerably more than the curate, assuming steady employment.
summary: Smith draws a direct comparison between clerical and manual labor compensation, showing that in fourteenth-century England, both master and journeyman masons earned more than curates, illustrating the depressing effect of educational subsidies on clergy wages.
distilled: In medieval England, masons earned considerably more than curates, demonstrating how the oversupply of subsidized clergy depressed clerical wages below manual labor rates.
notes: Historical wage comparison -- curate vs. mason wages -- 14th century English labor markets -- Statute of Labourers reference -- silver-equivalent purchasing power comparisons

refashioned: The wages of a master mason, even allowing for being unemployed one-third of the year, would have fully equaled those of a curate. By the statute of the 12th year of Queen Anne, chapter 12, it was declared: 'Whereas, for want of sufficient maintenance and encouragement to curates, the parishes have in several places been poorly served, the bishop is therefore empowered to appoint, under his hand and seal, a sufficient stipend not exceeding fifty and not less than twenty pounds a year.' Forty pounds a year is currently considered very good pay for a curate, and despite this statute, many curacies pay less than twenty pounds a year.
elegant: Even a master mason unemployed for a third of the year earned as much as a curate. Queen Anne's statute empowered bishops to set curate stipends between twenty and fifty pounds yearly, yet forty pounds is now considered excellent pay, and many curacies still fall below twenty pounds despite the law.
summary: Smith notes that even with seasonal unemployment, a master mason earned as much as a curate. Despite parliamentary attempts to raise curate stipends to at least twenty pounds, many still earn less, showing the law's inability to override market forces driven by oversupply.
distilled: Parliamentary attempts to raise curate pay proved ineffective because the oversupply of clergy, driven by subsidized education, kept wages stubbornly low.
notes: Wage floors and market forces -- Queen Anne statute c.12 -- law's inability to enforce above-market wages -- clerical labor surplus -- continuing historical wage comparison

refashioned: There are journeymen shoemakers in London who earn forty pounds a year, and scarcely an industrious workman of any kind in that city who does not earn more than twenty. This latter sum, indeed, does not exceed what common laborers frequently earn in many country parishes. Whenever the law has attempted to regulate workers' wages, it has always been to lower them, not raise them. But the law has repeatedly tried to raise curates' wages, for the dignity of the church, by obliging parish rectors to pay them more than the miserable maintenance they themselves might accept. In both cases, the law has been equally ineffective: it has never managed to raise curates' wages or lower laborers' wages to the intended degree. It cannot prevent curates from accepting less than the legal minimum, driven by their poverty and the multitude of competitors, nor can it prevent laborers from receiving more, due to the competing demand of those who expect to profit or gain pleasure from employing them.
elegant: London journeymen shoemakers earn forty pounds a year; scarcely any industrious worker earns less than twenty. The law has always tried to lower workers' wages but raise curates' wages -- and has been equally ineffective in both directions. Curates accept less than the legal minimum because of their poverty and oversupply, while laborers receive more because employers compete for their services.
summary: Smith observes that common laborers earn as much as or more than curates, despite legal attempts to achieve the opposite in both cases. The law fails because it cannot override the fundamental market forces of supply and demand.
distilled: Legal attempts to raise curate wages and lower laborer wages both fail because market forces of supply and demand are more powerful than statutory regulation.
notes: Wage regulation ineffectiveness -- supply and demand vs. legal mandates -- curate vs. laborer comparison -- asymmetric labor market interventions -- price floors and ceilings in labor markets

refashioned: The great benefices and other high ecclesiastical positions maintain the honor of the church, despite the poor circumstances of some of its lower members. The respect accorded to the profession also partly compensates even the poorest clergy for their meager pay. In England and in all Roman Catholic countries, the church's lottery is in practice far more generous than necessary. The example of the churches of Scotland, Geneva, and several other Protestant bodies shows that in so respectable a profession, where education is so easily obtained, the prospect of much more moderate rewards will still attract a sufficient number of learned, decent, and respectable people to the clergy.
elegant: Great benefices uphold the church's honor despite the poverty of its lower clergy. Professional respect partly compensates for low pay. In England and Catholic countries, the church's lottery of rewards is more generous than necessary -- the Protestant churches of Scotland and Geneva prove that moderate prospects suffice to attract capable, respectable clergy.
summary: Smith argues that the church maintains its prestige through a few lucrative positions and the social respect it commands, which together compensate for the low wages of most clergy. Protestant examples show that even more modest rewards would attract sufficient qualified candidates.
distilled: The church attracts clergy through a lottery of a few great rewards and social prestige, but Protestant examples prove that much more modest incentives would suffice.
notes: Tournament theory -- lottery-like reward structures -- intrinsic vs. extrinsic rewards -- social status as compensation -- Protestant vs. Catholic church economics -- Scotland and Geneva as comparison cases

refashioned: In professions without benefices, such as law and medicine, if an equal proportion of people were educated at public expense, competition would soon become so intense as to severely depress financial rewards. It would then no longer be worth anyone's while to educate a son in either profession at their own expense. These professions would be entirely abandoned to those educated by public charities, whose numbers and financial desperation would generally force them to accept miserable compensation -- to the complete degradation of the now-respectable professions of law and medicine.
elegant: If law and medicine were subsidized like the clergy, competition would crash their rewards. No one would pay to educate a child in these fields. The professions would be left to charity-educated graduates whose desperation would force them to accept miserable pay, degrading these now-respectable careers.
summary: Smith warns that if public subsidies funded education in law and medicine as they do for the clergy, the resulting oversupply would destroy financial rewards and degrade these professions, which would be left entirely to desperate charity graduates.
distilled: If law and medicine were publicly subsidized like clerical education, oversupply would destroy their financial rewards and degrade them as professions.
notes: Counterfactual analysis -- education subsidies and professional degradation -- law and medicine as comparison cases -- supply-side effects on professional prestige -- cautionary argument against universal professional subsidies

refashioned: That unfortunate class of people commonly called men of letters find themselves in roughly the situation that lawyers and physicians would be in under the scenario just described. Throughout Europe, most of them were originally educated for the church but were prevented by various circumstances from entering holy orders. They have generally been educated at public expense, and their numbers are everywhere so large that the price of their labor is typically reduced to a very meager level.
elegant: Men of letters occupy the position that lawyers and physicians would if those professions were similarly subsidized. Mostly educated for the church at public expense but diverted from holy orders, their great numbers everywhere depress the price of their labor to a pittance.
summary: Smith explains that literary intellectuals, mostly trained for the clergy at public expense but diverted into secular work, exemplify the wage-depressing effects of subsidized education -- their oversupply keeps their compensation low.
distilled: Men of letters, mostly educated for the church at public expense but diverted to secular work, suffer the low wages that oversupply of subsidized professionals inevitably produces.
notes: Men of letters as case study -- clergy-trained intellectuals -- excess supply from educational subsidies -- intellectual labor market -- connection to broader argument about subsidized professions

refashioned: Before the invention of printing, the only way a man of letters could earn a living from his knowledge was as a public or private teacher -- communicating the useful and interesting knowledge he had acquired. This remains surely a more honorable, more useful, and generally even more profitable occupation than writing for a bookseller, which the printing press made possible. The time, study, genius, knowledge, and dedication required to become an eminent teacher of the sciences are at least equal to what is needed for the greatest practitioners of law and medicine. But the typical reward for an eminent teacher bears no proportion to that of a lawyer or physician, because teaching is crowded with impoverished people educated at public expense, whereas the other two professions have very few such subsidized competitors. Even the modest compensation teachers do receive would be still lower if the competition of yet more destitute men of letters -- those who write for bread -- were not diverted into a separate market. Before the invention of printing, 'scholar' and 'beggar' were very nearly synonymous terms. University authorities in those times appear to have frequently granted their scholars licenses to beg.
elegant: Before printing, scholars could only earn through teaching -- still a more honorable and profitable pursuit than writing for booksellers. Becoming an eminent teacher demands abilities equal to the greatest lawyers or physicians, yet teachers' rewards are vastly lower because the profession is flooded with publicly educated indigents. Even their meager pay would be lower still without the printing press diverting some competitors into writing. Before printing, 'scholar' and 'beggar' were nearly synonymous -- universities even granted licenses to beg.
summary: Smith traces how scholars have always been poorly paid because their education was publicly subsidized, creating oversupply. Before printing, teaching was the only scholarly income source, and scholars were so poor that universities granted them begging licenses. Printing helped slightly by diverting some competitors into writing.
distilled: Publicly subsidized education has always depressed scholars' wages to near-destitution levels, with printing only partially relieving the oversupply by creating an alternative outlet in writing for booksellers.
notes: History of intellectual labor markets -- printing press as labor market disruptor -- teaching vs. writing as income sources -- begging licenses for scholars -- subsidized education creating poverty -- parallel to modern academic labor markets

refashioned: In ancient times, before charitable endowments had been established to educate indigent people for the learned professions, the rewards of eminent teachers were much more substantial. Isocrates, in his discourse against the sophists, reproaches the teachers of his day with inconsistency. 'They make magnificent promises to their students,' he says, 'and undertake to teach them to be wise, happy, and just; and in return for so important a service, they charge the paltry fee of four or five minae.' 'Those who teach wisdom,' he continues, 'ought certainly to be wise themselves; but if anyone sold such a bargain at such a price, he would be convicted of the most obvious folly.' He certainly was not exaggerating the fee, and we can be sure it was not less than he states. Four minae were equal to about thirteen pounds, six shillings, and eightpence; five minae to about sixteen pounds, thirteen shillings, and fourpence. Something at least equal to the larger of those two sums, therefore, must have been the usual fee paid to the most eminent teachers at Athens. Isocrates himself charged ten minae -- about thirty-three pounds, six shillings, and eightpence -- from each student.
elegant: Before charitable educational endowments existed, eminent teachers earned far more. Isocrates mocked fellow teachers for charging only four or five minae while promising to teach wisdom, happiness, and justice -- arguing that selling such a bargain so cheaply proved foolishness. These fees equaled roughly thirteen to seventeen pounds sterling. Isocrates himself charged double: ten minae, or about thirty-three pounds per student.
summary: Smith cites Isocrates to show that before subsidized education flooded the market, ancient teachers commanded substantial fees. Isocrates himself charged ten minae per student and considered even four or five minae a respectable sum for teaching wisdom.
distilled: Before subsidized education created oversupply, eminent ancient teachers like Isocrates commanded substantial fees that reflected the true value of their instruction.
notes: Ancient Greek education economics -- Isocrates as source -- historical fee levels -- minae to sterling conversion -- pre-subsidy teacher compensation -- discourse against the sophists

refashioned: When Isocrates taught at Athens, he is said to have had a hundred students. I understand this to mean the number who attended at one time -- what we would call one course of lectures. This number is not extraordinary for so great a city and so famous a teacher, especially since he taught rhetoric, which was then the most fashionable of all subjects. He must therefore have earned a thousand minae, or about three thousand three hundred and thirty-three pounds, from each course of lectures. A thousand minae, accordingly, is said by Plutarch to have been his didactron, or standard teaching fee. Many other eminent teachers of that era appear to have amassed great fortunes. Gorgias made a gift to the temple at Delphi of his own statue cast in solid gold.
elegant: Isocrates reportedly taught a hundred students at a time in the most fashionable subject, rhetoric. At ten minae per student, each course earned him a thousand minae -- about three thousand three hundred pounds. Plutarch confirms this as his standard fee. Other eminent teachers also grew wealthy: Gorgias donated his own statue in solid gold to the temple at Delphi.
summary: Smith calculates that Isocrates earned about three thousand three hundred pounds per lecture course from a hundred students, and notes that other ancient teachers also accumulated great wealth, as evidenced by Gorgias's gold statue donation to Delphi.
distilled: Ancient teachers like Isocrates earned enormous sums -- roughly three thousand pounds per lecture course -- demonstrating the high rewards available before subsidized education created oversupply.
notes: Isocrates' earnings -- Plutarch as source -- didactron (teaching fee) -- Gorgias and wealth from teaching -- rhetoric as fashionable subject -- ancient education as lucrative profession

refashioned: We should not suppose that Gorgias's golden statue was life-sized. But his lifestyle, like that of Hippias and Protagoras -- two other eminent teachers of the era -- is described by Plato as splendid, even ostentatious. Plato himself reportedly lived with considerable magnificence. Aristotle, after serving as tutor to Alexander and being most generously rewarded by both Alexander and his father Philip -- as is universally agreed -- still thought it worthwhile to return to Athens and resume teaching at his school. Teachers of the sciences were probably less common in those times than they became a generation or two later, when increased competition had likely reduced both the price of their labor and the public admiration for their persons.
elegant: Gorgias's golden statue was presumably not life-sized, but ancient teachers lived lavishly. Plato, Hippias, and Protagoras all lived in splendor. Even Aristotle, after being magnificently rewarded as Alexander's tutor, returned to Athens to teach -- suggesting the profession was still highly lucrative. Teachers were rarer then; later competition reduced both their earnings and public esteem.
summary: Smith notes that ancient philosophers lived lavishly, and even Aristotle chose to return to teaching after tutoring Alexander. The high rewards of teaching in this era reflected the relative scarcity of qualified teachers, which later competition would diminish.
distilled: Ancient teachers lived magnificently because their scarcity kept rewards high -- even Aristotle returned to teaching despite having already been richly rewarded as Alexander's tutor.
notes: Gorgias, Hippias, Protagoras, Plato, Aristotle -- ancient teacher wealth -- scarcity premium for intellectuals -- competition reducing rewards over time -- Alexander and Philip's patronage

refashioned: The most eminent ancient teachers always appear to have enjoyed a degree of public esteem far surpassing anything accorded to their modern counterparts. The Athenians sent Carneades the Academic and Diogenes the Stoic on a solemn embassy to Rome. Though Athens had by then declined from its former greatness, it was still an independent and considerable republic.
elegant: The most eminent ancient teachers commanded public esteem far exceeding that of modern scholars. Athens even sent philosophers -- Carneades the Academic and Diogenes the Stoic -- as ambassadors to Rome, while it was still an independent and considerable republic.
summary: Smith notes that ancient philosophers enjoyed far greater public respect than modern scholars, as demonstrated by Athens sending Carneades and Diogenes as official ambassadors to Rome.
distilled: Ancient philosophers commanded such public esteem that Athens appointed them as ambassadors, a level of respect unmatched by modern scholars.
notes: Social status of ancient philosophers -- Carneades and Diogenes as ambassadors -- Athens-Rome relations -- decline of intellectual prestige over time -- public esteem as non-monetary reward

refashioned:
Carneades was a Babylonian by birth, and since no people were more jealous of admitting foreigners to public office than the Athenians, their regard for him must have been extraordinary.

This inequality in rewards is, on the whole, perhaps more beneficial than harmful to the public. It may somewhat diminish the prestige of teaching as a profession, but the cheapness of literary education is an advantage that greatly outweighs this minor inconvenience. The public might derive still greater benefit if the institutions where education is conducted were organized more sensibly than is currently the case throughout most of Europe.
elegant: That even a foreign-born Babylonian like Carneades held public office in notoriously exclusive Athens shows extraordinary regard for eminent teachers. Overall, the low pay of educators is more beneficial than harmful: cheap literary education greatly outweighs the mild degradation of the teaching profession. The public would benefit still more if European educational institutions were better organized.
summary: Smith concludes that while subsidized education depresses teachers' pay, the resulting cheapness of education benefits the public more than it harms the profession. He adds that European educational institutions could be far better organized to increase this benefit.
distilled: The cheapness of education resulting from oversupply of teachers is, on balance, a public benefit that outweighs the degradation of the teaching profession.
notes: Carneades as foreigner in Athens -- cost-benefit analysis of education subsidies -- net public benefit despite teacher underpayment -- critique of European educational institutions -- foreshadowing Book V discussion of education

refashioned:
Third, European policy obstructs the free movement of labor and capital -- both between different occupations and between different places -- causing in some cases a deeply inconvenient inequality in the overall conditions of different employments.

Apprentice statutes obstruct the free movement of labor from one occupation to another, even within the same town. The exclusive privileges of corporations obstruct it from one place to another, even within the same occupation.
elegant: European policy's third distortion: obstructing the free movement of labor and capital between occupations and locations. Apprenticeship statutes block movement between trades in the same place; corporate privileges block movement between places in the same trade.
summary: Smith introduces the third way European policy distorts labor markets: by obstructing labor mobility both between occupations (through apprenticeship laws) and between locations (through corporate privileges), creating harmful inequalities.
distilled: Apprenticeship laws block occupational mobility while corporate privileges block geographic mobility, together preventing labor and capital from flowing to their most productive uses.
notes: Third policy distortion -- occupational vs. geographic mobility -- apprenticeship statutes -- corporate exclusive privileges -- labor market segmentation -- transition to settlement law discussion

refashioned: It frequently happens that workers in one trade receive high wages while those in another can barely subsist. The first trade is expanding and constantly needs new workers; the second is declining and has a growing surplus of hands. These two trades may sometimes exist in the same town or neighborhood without being able to help each other at all. Apprenticeship statutes may block movement in one case; both apprenticeship laws and corporate privileges in the other. Yet in many trades, the work is so similar that workers could easily switch between them if these absurd laws did not prevent it. The arts of weaving plain linen and plain silk, for example, are almost identical. Plain woolen weaving is somewhat different, but so slightly that a linen or silk weaver could become competent in just a few days. If any of these three major trades were declining, workers could find employment in one of the others that was thriving, which would prevent wages from rising too high in the prosperous trade or falling too low in the declining one. The linen trade in England is, by special statute, open to everyone, but since it is not widely practiced, it provides no general refuge for workers displaced from other declining trades. Under apprenticeship laws, such workers have no choice but to seek parish relief or work as common laborers -- for which their training makes them far less qualified than for any trade resembling their own. They generally choose parish relief.
elegant: High wages in one trade and bare subsistence in another often coexist in the same town, yet workers cannot move between them due to apprenticeship and corporation laws. Many trades involve nearly identical skills -- linen, silk, and wool weaving, for example -- yet legal barriers prevent easy transition. Without these obstacles, labor would flow naturally from declining to thriving trades, stabilizing wages in both. Instead, displaced workers face only parish relief or unskilled labor, and typically choose the parish.
summary: Smith demonstrates how apprenticeship and corporation laws trap workers in declining trades while neighboring trades go understaffed, even when the skills are nearly identical. The result is that displaced workers end up on parish relief rather than in productive employment.
distilled: Legal barriers prevent workers from moving between similar trades, trapping them in declining industries when they could easily transition to thriving ones nearby.
notes: Labor market rigidity -- skill transferability between trades -- weaving as example (linen, silk, wool) -- welfare dependency as consequence of immobility -- parish relief system -- simultaneous surplus and shortage in adjacent trades

refashioned: Whatever obstructs the free movement of labor between occupations also obstructs the movement of capital, since the amount of capital that can be employed in any business depends heavily on the available labor supply. Corporation laws, however, obstruct the movement of capital between places less than they obstruct the movement of labor. It is far easier everywhere for a wealthy merchant to obtain the privilege of trading in an incorporated town than for a poor craftsman to obtain the privilege of working there.
elegant: Barriers to labor mobility also restrict capital mobility, since capital investment depends on available labor. However, corporation laws obstruct capital less than labor -- a wealthy merchant can far more easily gain trading privileges in an incorporated town than a poor craftsman can gain working privileges.
summary: Smith notes that restrictions on labor mobility indirectly restrict capital mobility too, but corporation laws are more permeable for wealthy merchants than for poor craftsmen, creating an asymmetry in their effects.
distilled: Barriers to labor movement also obstruct capital movement, though corporation laws are far easier for wealthy merchants to circumvent than for poor workers.
notes: Capital-labor complementarity -- asymmetric barriers by wealth -- corporation laws' differential impact -- wealthy merchants vs. poor craftsmen -- capital mobility less restricted than labor mobility

refashioned: The obstruction that corporation laws place on the free movement of labor is, I believe, common to every part of Europe. But the obstruction created by the poor laws is, as far as I know, peculiar to England. It consists in the difficulty a poor person faces in obtaining a 'settlement' -- or even being allowed to work -- in any parish other than the one to which they legally belong. Corporation laws obstruct only the movement of craftsmen and manufacturers; settlement laws obstruct even the movement of common laborers. It is worth giving some account of the origin, development, and current state of this system, which is perhaps the greatest disorder in all of English domestic policy.
elegant: Corporation laws obstruct labor mobility throughout Europe, but England's poor laws add a uniquely burdensome restriction: the settlement system, which prevents poor people from working in any parish other than their own. While corporation laws affect only skilled trades, settlement laws restrict even common laborers -- perhaps the greatest disorder in English domestic policy.
summary: Smith identifies England's settlement laws as a uniquely severe restriction on labor mobility, going beyond corporation laws by preventing even common laborers from moving between parishes. He calls it perhaps the greatest failing of English domestic policy.
distilled: England's settlement laws, which prevent poor workers from moving between parishes, represent perhaps the greatest failing of English domestic policy and a restriction on labor mobility unique in Europe.
notes: Settlement laws -- parish system -- unique English labor restriction -- poor laws -- distinction from corporation laws -- 'greatest disorder in English police' -- introduction to detailed historical analysis

refashioned: When the dissolution of the monasteries deprived the poor of the charity those religious houses had provided, and after several other failed attempts at relief, the statute of the 43rd year of Elizabeth, chapter 2, enacted that every parish must provide for its own poor. Overseers of the poor were to be appointed annually, who together with the churchwardens would raise adequate funds through a parish tax for this purpose.
elegant: After the dissolution of monasteries eliminated monastic charity for the poor, the Elizabethan Poor Law (43 Elizabeth, c. 2) required every parish to provide for its own poor through annually appointed overseers funded by parish taxation.
summary: Smith traces the origin of the parish poor relief system to the Elizabethan Poor Law, which was enacted after the dissolution of monasteries removed the primary source of charitable support for the poor.
distilled: The Elizabethan Poor Law made every parish responsible for its own poor, establishing the parish taxation system that would later become the basis for restrictive settlement laws.
notes: 43 Elizabeth c.2 -- dissolution of monasteries -- origin of parish poor relief -- overseers of the poor -- church-wardens -- parish rates -- historical foundation of settlement system

refashioned: This statute made it obligatory for every parish to support its own poor. The question of who counted as a parish's poor therefore became critically important. After some variation, this was settled by the statute of the 13th and 14th year of Charles II, which enacted that forty days of undisturbed residence would gain any person a settlement in any parish. However, within that period, two justices of the peace -- upon complaint from the churchwardens or overseers -- could remove any new inhabitant to the parish where they were last legally settled, unless the newcomer either rented a property worth ten pounds a year or could provide security, satisfactory to the justices, that they would not become a burden on the parish.
elegant: Once parishes were obligated to support their own poor, determining who belonged to each parish became critical. Under Charles II (13th & 14th year), forty days' undisturbed residence created settlement rights. But justices could remove newcomers within that period upon complaint, unless they rented property worth ten pounds annually or provided financial security against becoming a parish burden.
summary: Smith explains how the obligation to support the poor led to the settlement system under Charles II, where forty days' residence created legal settlement, but newcomers could be removed unless they met property or security requirements.
distilled: The settlement system under Charles II allowed parishes to remove newcomers within forty days unless they could demonstrate financial independence, creating a fundamental barrier to labor mobility.
notes: 13th & 14th Charles II -- forty-day settlement rule -- removal powers of justices -- ten-pound rental threshold -- financial security requirements -- evolution of settlement law

refashioned: Frauds were reportedly committed under this statute: parish officers sometimes bribed their own poor to move secretly to another parish and, by remaining concealed for forty days, to gain a settlement there -- thus relieving their original parish of the burden. It was therefore enacted by the statute of the 1st year of James II that the forty days of undisturbed residence required for settlement would count only from the time the person delivered written notice of their address and family size to a churchwarden or overseer of the parish where they had come to live.
elegant: Parishes gamed the system by bribing their poor to move secretly to other parishes and stay hidden for forty days, gaining settlement elsewhere. James II's statute closed this loophole by requiring the forty-day period to start only after the newcomer delivered written notice of their address and family to the parish.
summary: Smith describes how parish officers exploited the settlement system by secretly relocating their poor to other parishes. The loophole was addressed by requiring written notice before the forty-day settlement clock began.
distilled: After parishes gamed the settlement system by secretly relocating their poor, legislation under James II required written notice before the forty-day settlement period could begin.
notes: Gaming the settlement system -- parish officer fraud -- 1st James II -- written notice requirement -- amendment closing loopholes -- institutional gaming and response

refashioned: But parish officers, it seems, were not always more honest regarding their own parishioners than they had been regarding those of other parishes. They sometimes accepted written notices and then took no action, thereby conniving at unauthorized settlement. Since every person in a parish was assumed to have an interest in preventing such unauthorized newcomers from becoming a burden, it was further enacted under the 3rd year of William III that the forty-day residence would count only from the public reading of the written notice in the church, immediately after Sunday services.
elegant: Parish officers sometimes connived at unauthorized settlements by accepting notices but taking no action. Under William III (3rd year), the law was tightened further: the forty-day period now counted only from the public reading of the notice in church after Sunday services, ensuring the whole parish was informed.
summary: Smith describes how parish officers circumvented settlement laws by ignoring notices. The law was tightened under William III to require public announcement of notices in church, giving all parishioners the opportunity to object.
distilled: After parish officers conspired to ignore settlement notices, the law required public reading of notices in church so the whole parish could monitor newcomers.
notes: 3rd William III -- church publication of notices -- parish self-policing -- escalating regulatory complexity -- principal-agent problem in parish administration

refashioned: 'After all,' says Doctor Burn, 'this kind of settlement by continuing forty days after publication of written notice is very seldom obtained. The design of the acts is not so much to enable people to gain settlements as to help them avoid gaining settlements by coming into a parish secretly. Giving notice is really just forcing the parish to act: to either remove you or let you stay. If a person's situation is unclear -- if it is doubtful whether they are legally removable or not -- giving notice compels the parish either to allow settlement uncontested by letting the person remain forty days, or to remove them and thereby test the legal right in court.'
elegant: As Doctor Burn notes, settlement by forty-day notice is very rarely achieved in practice. The real purpose of the notice requirement is not to grant settlements but to prevent clandestine entry -- it forces the parish to either accept the newcomer or challenge their right to stay through formal removal proceedings.
summary: Smith quotes Doctor Burn to show that the forty-day notice system rarely resulted in actual settlement. Its real function was to force parishes to formally confront newcomers -- either accepting them or removing them through legal proceedings.
distilled: The notice requirement for settlement rarely achieved its stated purpose, instead functioning mainly as a mechanism to force parishes into formally removing unwanted newcomers.
notes: Doctor Burn -- practical vs. theoretical operation of settlement law -- notice as forced confrontation -- legal procedure in settlement disputes -- gap between legislative intent and practical effect

refashioned: This statute therefore made it nearly impossible for a poor person to gain a new settlement in the old way, through forty days of residence. But to avoid appearing to completely prevent ordinary people from one parish from ever establishing themselves securely in another, it created four alternative ways to gain settlement without requiring any notice. First, by being taxed for parish rates and paying them. Second, by being elected to an annual parish office and serving for a year. Third, by completing an apprenticeship in the parish. Fourth, by being hired for a year and completing the full year of service. However, no one can gain settlement through either of the first two methods without the parish's active consent. Parishes are far too aware of the financial consequences to adopt any newcomer who has nothing but labor to support them -- they would never voluntarily tax such a person or elect them to parish office.
elegant: The statute made forty-day settlement nearly impossible while providing four alternatives: paying parish rates, serving in an annual parish office, completing an apprenticeship, or completing a year of hired service. But the first two require the parish's active consent, which no parish would grant to a newcomer with nothing but labor to support them.
summary: Smith explains how the settlement law created four nominal alternatives to forty-day residence, but two of them required the parish's cooperation -- which was never forthcoming for poor newcomers -- making settlement practically unattainable for those who needed it most.
distilled: The four alternative paths to settlement were designed to appear fair but were practically inaccessible to poor workers, since parishes would never voluntarily accept financial responsibility for newcomers.
notes: Four paths to settlement -- parish consent requirements -- practical inaccessibility -- parish self-interest blocking mobility -- institutional design vs. practical outcomes

refashioned: No married person could easily gain settlement through either of the last two methods. An apprentice is almost never married, and the law explicitly states that no married servant can gain settlement by being hired for a year. The main effect of introducing settlement by service was to largely destroy the old custom of hiring for a year -- which had been so common in England that, even now, if no specific term is agreed upon, the law assumes every servant is hired for a year. But masters are not always willing to give their servants a settlement by hiring them this way, and servants are not always willing to be hired on those terms either, because each new settlement cancels all previous ones. They might thereby lose their original settlement in the place of their birth, where their parents and relatives live.
elegant: Married people are effectively excluded from the last two settlement paths: apprentices are rarely married, and married servants are legally barred from gaining settlement through annual hire. This largely destroyed the old custom of yearly hiring. Masters avoid granting settlement through hiring, and workers fear losing their original settlement -- since each new one cancels all previous ones -- in the parish of their birth and family.
summary: Smith shows how settlement laws undermined the traditional practice of annual hiring, since both masters and servants had reason to avoid it. Masters did not want to grant settlement, and servants feared losing their original parish rights.
distilled: Settlement laws effectively ended the custom of annual hiring by making both masters and servants reluctant to create new settlement obligations.
notes: Marriage and settlement exclusions -- destruction of annual hiring custom -- new settlement cancels old -- perverse incentives for both parties -- unintended consequences of settlement law on employment practices

refashioned: No independent worker, whether laborer or craftsman, was likely to gain a new settlement by either apprenticeship or service. When such a person brought their skills to a new parish, they could be removed at the whim of any churchwarden or overseer, no matter how healthy and industrious they were -- unless they rented a property worth ten pounds a year (impossible for someone with nothing but their labor to live on) or could provide financial security satisfactory to two justices of the peace.
elegant: No independent worker could gain settlement through apprenticeship or service. When they moved to a new parish, however healthy and industrious, they could be removed at any churchwarden's whim -- unless they rented a ten-pound property (impossible for a laborer) or provided substantial financial security.
summary: Smith highlights the vulnerability of independent workers under settlement laws: they could be expelled from any new parish at the discretion of local officials, with the only exemptions requiring financial resources far beyond a laborer's means.
distilled: Independent workers moving to new parishes could be removed at any official's whim, since the financial requirements for exemption were impossible for anyone living by labor alone.
notes: Vulnerability of mobile workers -- churchwarden discretion -- ten-pound rental impossibility for laborers -- arbitrary removal power -- settlement as barrier to independent labor mobility

refashioned: The amount of security required is left entirely to the justices' discretion, but they could hardly require less than thirty pounds, since the law provides that purchasing a freehold estate worth less than thirty pounds does not grant settlement, as being insufficient to discharge the parish's obligations. But this is a level of security that virtually no laborer can provide -- and much greater security is frequently demanded.
elegant: Justices could hardly require less than thirty pounds' security, since freeholds below that value do not qualify for settlement. Yet virtually no laborer can provide even that amount, and much more is frequently demanded.
summary: Smith notes that the minimum financial security for settlement was effectively thirty pounds -- a sum no laborer could provide -- and that justices often demanded even more, making settlement practically impossible for working people.
distilled: The thirty-pound minimum security requirement for settlement was utterly beyond the means of any laborer, effectively barring working people from establishing themselves in new parishes.
notes: Thirty-pound threshold -- freehold estate comparison -- judicial discretion -- financial impossibility for laborers -- de facto exclusion of working poor from mobility

refashioned: To partially restore the free movement of labor that these statutes had nearly destroyed, the certificate system was invented. Under the statute of the 8th and 9th year of William III, if a person brought a certificate from the parish of their last legal settlement -- signed by the churchwardens and overseers and approved by two justices -- every other parish was obligated to receive them. They could not be removed merely for being likely to become a burden, but only upon actually becoming one. When that happened, the parish that issued the certificate was responsible for paying both their maintenance and removal costs. To give the receiving parish maximum security, the same statute provided that a certificate holder could gain no settlement there by any means -- not by notice, service, apprenticeship, or paying parish rates -- except by renting a ten-pound property or serving in an annual parish office. Under Queen Anne's statute, even the servants and apprentices of certificated persons could not gain settlement in the parish where their master resided under such certificate.
elegant: The certificate system was invented to partially restore labor mobility. Under William III, a certificate from one's home parish guaranteed acceptance elsewhere. The holder could be removed only if actually -- not merely likely to -- become a burden, with the certifying parish covering costs. However, certificate holders could gain no new settlement except by renting a ten-pound property or serving in a parish office. Under Queen Anne, even their servants and apprentices were excluded from gaining settlement.
summary: Smith explains the certificate system as a partial remedy for settlement restrictions: certified workers could move parishes but could almost never gain new settlement, and their home parish remained financially responsible for them. Even their servants and apprentices were excluded from gaining new settlement rights.
distilled: The certificate system partially restored labor mobility by allowing workers to reside in new parishes while preventing them from ever gaining new settlement there, keeping their home parish permanently responsible.
notes: 8th & 9th William III -- certificate system -- portable settlement -- receiving parish protections -- Queen Anne amendments -- servants and apprentices of certificated persons -- partial vs. complete labor mobility restoration

refashioned: How far this invention actually restored the free movement of labor can be understood from Doctor Burn's shrewd observation: 'There are various good reasons for requiring certificates from persons coming to settle: certificated persons cannot gain settlement by apprenticeship, service, notice, or parish rates; they cannot settle apprentices or servants; if they become a burden, the removing parish is clearly known and must pay for both removal and maintenance; and if they fall ill and cannot be moved, the certifying parish must support them. None of this can happen without a certificate. These same reasons strongly discourage parishes from granting certificates in ordinary cases, since they will more likely than not get the certificated persons back in worse condition.' The lesson, Burn concludes, is that certificates should always be demanded by receiving parishes but seldom granted by sending parishes. 'There is something harsh in this certificate system,' says the same author in his History of the Poor Laws, 'in that it gives a parish officer the power to imprison a person for life, as it were, however inconvenient it may be for them to remain in the place where they had the misfortune to acquire what is called a settlement, or whatever advantage they might gain from living elsewhere.'
elegant: Doctor Burn observed that the very reasons receiving parishes should demand certificates -- protection from financial liability -- are the same reasons sending parishes should refuse to grant them. Parishes face worse-than-even odds of getting their people back in worse condition. The result, Burn notes, is that certificates are always demanded but seldom granted. He concludes: 'There is something harsh in this system, giving a parish officer power to imprison a person for life, however inconvenient it may be for them to stay where they acquired their settlement, or whatever advantage they might find elsewhere.'
summary: Smith quotes Doctor Burn's incisive analysis that the certificate system was self-defeating: the same logic that made receiving parishes demand certificates made sending parishes refuse to grant them, effectively imprisoning workers in their home parishes for life.
distilled: The certificate system was self-defeating because sending parishes had every financial incentive to refuse certificates, effectively imprisoning workers in their home parishes regardless of their wishes or prospects.
notes: Doctor Burn's analysis -- self-defeating institutional design -- parish incentives against granting certificates -- 'imprisoned for life' metaphor -- History of the Poor Laws -- structural critique of settlement system

refashioned: Although a certificate carries no endorsement of good character and certifies nothing more than that the person belongs to the parish they actually belong to, it is entirely at the parish officers' discretion whether to grant or refuse one. Doctor Burn reports that someone once sought a mandamus -- a court order -- to compel churchwardens and overseers to sign a certificate, but the Court of King's Bench rejected the motion as 'a very strange attempt.'
elegant: A certificate merely confirms which parish a person belongs to -- it says nothing about character -- yet granting one is entirely discretionary. When someone sought a court order to compel parish officers to issue a certificate, the King's Bench rejected it as 'a very strange attempt.'
summary: Smith emphasizes the arbitrary power of parish officers: they could refuse to issue even a basic certificate of parish membership, with no legal recourse available -- the courts refused to compel them.
distilled: Parish officers had absolute discretion to refuse certificates, with courts explicitly rejecting any attempt to compel their issuance.
notes: Arbitrary parish officer power -- mandamus rejected -- Court of King's Bench -- no legal recourse -- discretionary bureaucratic authority over labor mobility

refashioned: The highly unequal wages we frequently observe in England, in places not far from one another, probably result from the settlement laws' obstruction of a poor person's ability to move their labor from one parish to another without a certificate. A single healthy, industrious person may sometimes be tolerated without one, but a person with a wife and family who attempted this would almost certainly be removed in most parishes. And if the single person later married, they would generally be removed as well. The labor shortage in one parish therefore cannot always be relieved by the surplus in another, as it constantly is in Scotland and, I believe, in all other countries without settlement restrictions. In such countries, wages may rise somewhat near a large town or wherever there is extraordinary demand for labor, and decline gradually with distance, falling back to the common rate. But we never encounter the sudden, inexplicable differences in wages between neighboring places that we sometimes find in England, where it is often harder for a poor person to cross the artificial boundary of a parish than to cross an arm of the sea or a ridge of high mountains -- natural boundaries that sometimes separate quite different wage rates in other countries.
elegant: England's strikingly unequal wages between nearby places stem from settlement laws preventing labor mobility. A single person may be tolerated without a certificate, but families are almost always removed. Labor shortages in one parish cannot be relieved by surpluses next door, as they constantly are in Scotland and other countries without settlement restrictions. In those countries, wages adjust gradually with distance from towns. In England, crossing a parish boundary is harder for a poor worker than crossing a mountain range is elsewhere.
summary: Smith argues that England's settlement laws cause dramatic wage differences between neighboring parishes by preventing the free flow of labor. He contrasts this with Scotland and other countries, where wages adjust smoothly with distance, and notes that parish boundaries create greater barriers than natural geographic obstacles.
distilled: Settlement laws create sharper wage differences between neighboring English parishes than mountains or seas create between regions in countries without such restrictions.
notes: Wage inequality from settlement laws -- England vs. Scotland comparison -- artificial vs. natural barriers -- labor market segmentation -- geographic wage gradients -- family penalties under settlement system

refashioned: To remove a person who has committed no offense from the parish where they choose to live is a clear violation of natural liberty and justice. The common people of England, though famously jealous of their liberty, have -- like most ordinary people in other countries -- never truly understood what liberty means. For more than a century, they have allowed themselves to suffer this oppression without remedy. Though thoughtful observers have sometimes criticized settlement laws as a public grievance, these laws have never provoked the kind of widespread popular outrage that was directed at general warrants -- which were certainly an abuse, but one unlikely to cause widespread oppression. There is scarcely a poor person in England over forty years of age, I venture to say, who has not at some point in their life been most cruelly oppressed by this badly designed settlement law.
elegant: Removing someone who has committed no offense from their chosen parish of residence violates natural liberty and justice. Yet the English common people, famously jealous of their freedom but never truly understanding it, have endured this oppression for over a century without protest. General warrants provoked popular outrage, though they affected few; settlement laws, which cruelly oppressed virtually every poor person over forty, never did.
summary: Smith condemns settlement laws as a violation of natural liberty and justice, and marvels that the English people -- supposedly devoted to freedom -- never protested this widespread oppression, while raising outcry over general warrants that affected far fewer people.
distilled: Settlement laws violate natural liberty by punishing mobility, yet the English public, famous for loving freedom, never recognized or protested this pervasive oppression of the poor.
notes: Natural liberty and justice -- public ignorance of true liberty -- general warrants comparison -- widespread vs. concentrated oppression -- popular awareness and political action -- critique of English liberty as incomplete

refashioned: I shall conclude this long chapter by observing that, although it was once customary to regulate wages -- first by general laws covering the whole kingdom, and later by specific orders of justices of the peace in each county -- both practices have now fallen entirely out of use. 'By the experience of over four hundred years,' says Doctor Burn, 'it seems time to abandon all attempts to impose strict regulation on what, by its own nature, seems incapable of precise limitation. For if all persons doing the same kind of work were to receive equal wages, there would be no incentive, and no room left for industry or ingenuity.'
elegant: Smith concludes the chapter noting that wage regulation -- once common through national laws and local justices' orders -- has been entirely abandoned. As Doctor Burn observes: after four hundred years of experience, it is time to stop regulating what cannot be precisely limited, since equal wages for equal work would destroy all incentive for industry and ingenuity.
summary: Smith notes that centuries of failed wage regulation have led to its abandonment in practice, quoting Doctor Burn's argument that uniform wages would eliminate all incentive for individual effort and skill.
distilled: Four centuries of experience have shown that wage regulation is impractical and counterproductive, as equal pay for the same work destroys incentives for industry and ingenuity.
notes: Doctor Burn quote -- historical failure of wage regulation -- incentive effects of uniform wages -- justices of the peace -- four hundred years of evidence -- natural conclusion of anti-regulation argument

refashioned: Nevertheless, particular acts of parliament still sometimes attempt to regulate wages in specific trades and places. For example, the statute of the 8th year of George III prohibits, under heavy penalties, all master tailors in London and within five miles of it from paying -- and their workers from accepting -- more than two shillings and sevenpence halfpenny a day, except during a general mourning. Whenever the legislature tries to regulate disputes between masters and workers, its advisors are always the masters. When the resulting regulation favors workers, it is always just and fair; when it favors masters, it is sometimes not. The law requiring masters in several trades to pay their workers in money rather than goods is entirely just -- it merely obliges them to pay in money the value they had pretended, but not always actually delivered, in goods. But the 8th of George III favors the masters. When masters combine to reduce wages, they typically make a private agreement not to pay above a certain amount, with a penalty for violation. If workers made a similar agreement not to accept below a certain wage, the law would punish them severely. If the law dealt impartially, it would treat masters the same way. But the 8th of George III enforces by statute the very regulation masters sometimes attempt through private combinations. The workers' complaint that it puts the most able and industrious on the same footing as an ordinary worker seems perfectly well founded.
elegant: Parliament still regulates specific wages -- such as capping London tailors' pay at two shillings sevenpence halfpenny under the 8th of George III. Legislative advisors on labor disputes are always the masters. Laws favoring workers (like requiring payment in money, not goods) are just; those favoring masters often are not. When masters privately combine to cap wages, the law ignores it. When workers combine to set minimum wages, the law punishes them severely. The 8th of George III gives legal force to exactly what master combinations attempt privately. The workers' objection that it equates the most skilled with the ordinary worker is entirely justified.
summary: Smith exposes the double standard in labor regulation: masters who combine to reduce wages go unpunished while workers who combine to maintain wages face severe penalties. Specific statutes like the 8th of George III legally enforce what would be illegal if workers attempted it.
distilled: Labor law operates with a systematic double standard -- enforcing wage caps that masters seek while criminalizing workers' attempts to do the same in reverse.
notes: 8th George III -- wage caps for London tailors -- double standard in labor law -- master vs. worker combinations -- payment in kind vs. money -- legislative bias toward employers -- asymmetric enforcement of combination laws

refashioned: In ancient times, it was also customary to regulate the profits of merchants and other dealers by fixing the prices of provisions and goods. The bread assize is, as far as I know, the only surviving remnant of this practice. Where an exclusive corporation exists, it may perhaps be appropriate to regulate the price of bread, the most essential necessity. But where there is no such monopoly, free competition will regulate the price far better than any assize. The method of setting the bread assize established by the 31st year of George II could not be applied in Scotland due to a legal deficiency: its enforcement depended on the office of clerk of the market, which did not exist there. This defect was not corrected until the 3rd year of George III. The absence of an assize caused no noticeable problems, and its establishment in the few places where it has been introduced has produced no noticeable benefit. In most Scottish towns, however, there is a bakers' incorporation that claims exclusive privileges, though these are not strictly enforced. The proportion between the rates of wages and profit in different employments of labor and capital does not appear to be much affected, as has already been noted, by whether society is growing richer or poorer, advancing or declining. Such changes in public welfare, though they affect the general levels of both wages and profit, must ultimately affect them equally across all different employments. The proportion between them must therefore remain the same and cannot be significantly altered by such changes for any considerable period.
elegant: The bread assize is the last remnant of ancient price regulation. Where monopolies exist, regulating bread prices may be justified. Without them, competition works better than any assize. Scotland's experience proves this: the absence of a bread assize caused no problems, and its introduction produced no benefit. The chapter concludes by reiterating that while general prosperity affects overall wage and profit levels, the proportions between different employments remain relatively stable regardless of society's economic trajectory.
summary: Smith concludes his analysis of wage and price regulation by examining the bread assize as the last vestige of ancient price controls. Scotland's experience showed that competition regulates prices better than legislation. He reiterates that while absolute levels of wages and profits change with general prosperity, the ratios between different employments remain relatively stable.
distilled: Competition regulates prices better than government assizes, as Scotland's experience with bread pricing demonstrates, and the proportions between wages and profits across different employments remain stable regardless of changes in general prosperity.
notes: Bread assize -- last remnant of price regulation -- Scotland as natural experiment -- 31st George II and 3rd George III -- competition vs. regulation -- Scottish bakers' incorporation -- concluding restatement of chapter themes -- proportional stability across employments

refashioned: Rent, considered as the price paid for the use of land, is naturally the highest amount the tenant can afford in the land's actual circumstances. In setting the terms of a lease, the landlord tries to leave the tenant only enough of the produce to cover the costs of seed, labor, cattle, and other farming equipment, along with the ordinary farming profits of the area. This is clearly the smallest share the tenant can accept without losing money, and the landlord rarely intends to leave more. Whatever portion of the produce -- or its price -- exceeds this minimum, the landlord naturally tries to claim as rent. This is evidently the maximum the tenant can afford to pay. Sometimes the landlord's generosity, or more often his ignorance, leads him to accept somewhat less. Occasionally, though more rarely, the tenant's ignorance leads him to agree to pay more, or to accept less than the ordinary farming profits. But this portion may still be considered the natural rent of land -- the rent at which land is generally intended to be let.
elegant: Rent is naturally the highest amount a tenant can pay after covering seed, labor, equipment, and ordinary farming profits. The landlord claims everything above these necessary costs. Sometimes landlord ignorance leads to lower rent; sometimes tenant ignorance leads to higher. But this maximum-extraction amount represents the natural rent -- the rent at which land is generally meant to be let.
summary: Smith defines rent as the residual that the landlord claims after the tenant covers all costs of production plus ordinary profits. It is naturally set at the maximum the tenant can afford, representing a monopoly extraction by the landlord.
distilled: Rent is the maximum surplus a landlord can extract after the tenant covers all costs of production and earns ordinary profits -- it is set by what the tenant can afford, not by what the landlord has invested.
notes: Definition of rent -- residual theory of rent -- landlord-tenant bargaining -- natural rent concept -- landlord as surplus extractor -- information asymmetry (landlord vs. tenant ignorance) -- opening of Chapter 11

refashioned: It might be thought that the rent of land is frequently just a reasonable return on the landlord's investment in improvements. This may partly be true on some occasions, but it is never the whole story. Landlords demand rent even for completely unimproved land, and any supposed return on improvement costs is generally an addition to this base rent. Moreover, improvements are not always made at the landlord's expense -- sometimes the tenant makes them. Yet when the lease comes up for renewal, the landlord typically demands the same increase in rent as if all improvements had been made with his own money.
elegant: Rent is not simply a return on the landlord's improvements. Landlords charge rent even for unimproved land, with improvement costs added on top. Often the tenant, not the landlord, makes improvements -- yet at renewal, the landlord still demands higher rent as if he had paid for them himself.
summary: Smith refutes the idea that rent merely compensates landlords for improvement costs. Rent is charged even on unimproved land, and landlords typically claim the value of improvements regardless of who actually paid for them.
distilled: Rent is not a return on improvement investment -- landlords charge rent on unimproved land and capture the value of improvements made at tenants' expense.
notes: Rent vs. return on investment -- unimproved land rent -- tenant-made improvements captured by landlord -- landlord extraction at lease renewal -- critique of improvement-based rent justification

refashioned: Landlords sometimes demand rent for land completely incapable of human improvement. Kelp is a species of seaweed that, when burned, produces an alkaline salt useful for making glass, soap, and other products. It grows in various parts of Great Britain, particularly in Scotland, only on rocks that lie below the high-water mark -- rocks that are submerged twice daily by the tide, and whose production has therefore never been enhanced by human effort. Yet the landlord whose estate borders such a kelp shore demands rent for it just as he would for his cornfields.
elegant: Landlords even demand rent for land beyond human improvement. Kelp -- seaweed yielding alkaline salt for glass and soap -- grows on tidal rocks in Scotland that human industry never enhanced. Yet landlords charge rent for these shores just as they do for cultivated cornfields.
summary: Smith provides kelp shores as a striking example of rent charged on completely unimprovable land, proving that rent has nothing to do with the landlord's investment or improvement efforts.
distilled: Landlords charge rent even for tidal kelp shores that human industry never improved, proving rent reflects extractive power rather than productive investment.
notes: Kelp as case study -- rent on unimprovable land -- Scottish kelp industry -- alkaline salt production -- rent as pure extraction -- natural resources and rent

refashioned: The sea near the Shetland Islands is exceptionally rich in fish, which forms a large part of the inhabitants' sustenance. But to profit from the sea's bounty, they must have a place to live on the neighboring land. The landlord's rent there is set not by what the farmer can earn from the land alone, but by what he can earn from both the land and the sea combined. The rent is partly paid in sea fish -- one of the very few cases where rent forms part of the price of that commodity.
elegant: Near the Shetland Islands, the exceptionally fish-rich sea provides much of the inhabitants' livelihood. But accessing this bounty requires residing on nearby land. So the landlord's rent reflects earnings from both land and sea, and is partly paid in fish -- one of the rare cases where rent enters into the price of fish.
summary: Smith uses the Shetland Islands to illustrate how landlords capture value from natural resources they did not create: rent there reflects not just the land's productivity but also the sea's fishing bounty, with rent even paid in fish.
distilled: Shetland landlords capture rent from the sea's bounty by controlling access to the neighboring land, showing how rent extracts value from resources the landlord did nothing to create.
notes: Shetland Islands -- fishing and rent -- rent paid in fish -- landlord capturing resource value -- access to natural resources as rent basis -- rent in commodity prices

refashioned:
The rent of land, considered as the price paid for its use, is therefore naturally a monopoly price. It bears no proportion to what the landlord may have spent on improvements or to what he could afford to accept. It is determined entirely by what the farmer can afford to pay.

Only those products of the land whose ordinary market price is enough to cover the cost of production -- the capital employed and its ordinary profits -- can normally be brought to market. If the price exceeds this, the surplus naturally goes to the landlord as rent. If it does not exceed it, the product can still reach market, but it will yield no rent for the landlord. Whether the price exceeds the cost of production depends on the demand.
elegant: Land rent is a monopoly price, determined not by the landlord's costs or needs, but solely by what the tenant can afford. Only products whose market price covers production costs and ordinary profits can be brought to market. Any surplus above these costs goes to the landlord as rent. Whether such a surplus exists depends on demand.
summary: Smith declares land rent a monopoly price set by what tenants can pay, not by landlords' costs. Rent exists only when the market price of produce exceeds production costs and ordinary profits, with the surplus depending entirely on demand.
distilled: Land rent is a monopoly price determined by what tenants can afford to pay, existing only when produce prices exceed production costs -- and the surplus depends entirely on demand.
notes: Rent as monopoly price -- demand-determined rent -- key theoretical statement -- rent as residual after costs and profits -- landlord monopoly power -- foundational concept for Ricardian rent theory

refashioned: Some products of the land always command a price high enough to yield rent -- the demand for them is always sufficient to push prices above the cost of bringing them to market. Other products may or may not command such a price, depending on circumstances. The first category always provides rent to the landlord. The second may or may not, depending on conditions.
