elegant: Some land products always command prices yielding rent; others may or may not, depending on circumstances. The former always provide landlord revenue; the latter do so only under favorable conditions.
summary: Smith distinguishes between land products that always generate enough demand to yield rent and those where rent depends on variable market circumstances.
distilled: Some land products always yield rent because demand invariably exceeds production costs, while others yield rent only under favorable market conditions.
notes: Two categories of land produce -- always-rent vs. sometimes-rent products -- demand conditions and rent -- framework for Chapter 11 analysis -- food as always-rent category

refashioned: It should be noted that rent enters into the price of commodities in a fundamentally different way from wages and profit. High or low wages and profit are the causes of high or low prices. High or low rent is the effect. Wages and profit must be paid at certain levels to bring a commodity to market, and those levels determine the price. But it is because the price happens to be high or low -- exceeding the necessary wages and profit by a lot, a little, or not at all -- that the rent is high, low, or nonexistent.
elegant: Rent enters prices differently from wages and profit. Wages and profit are causes of price -- they must be paid to bring goods to market. Rent is the effect -- it exists only because the price exceeds what wages and profit require. High wages cause high prices; high prices cause high rent.
summary: Smith makes a crucial theoretical distinction: wages and profit determine prices (they are causes), while rent is determined by prices (it is an effect). Rent is the residual that exists only when prices exceed the necessary costs of wages and profit.
distilled: Wages and profit cause prices; rent is caused by prices -- it is the residual that exists only when market prices exceed the cost of wages and profit required for production.
notes: Critical theoretical distinction -- rent as effect not cause of price -- wages and profit as price determinants -- rent as residual -- foundational for classical rent theory -- key passage for understanding Smith's price theory

refashioned: This chapter will be divided into three parts. First, the consideration of those products of the land that always provide some rent. Second, those that sometimes may and sometimes may not provide rent. Third, the variations that naturally occur, at different stages of economic development, in the relative value of these two types of raw produce -- compared both with each other and with manufactured goods.
elegant: The chapter divides into three parts: first, products that always yield rent; second, products that sometimes do and sometimes do not; third, how the relative values of these two categories change at different stages of economic development, compared both with each other and with manufactured goods.
summary: Smith outlines the three-part structure of Chapter 11: products always yielding rent, products conditionally yielding rent, and how the relative values of these categories shift with economic development.
distilled: Chapter 11 examines three topics: products always yielding rent, products conditionally yielding rent, and how their relative values change with economic progress.
notes: Chapter outline -- structural overview -- three-part division of Chapter 11 -- always-rent vs. sometimes-rent products -- relative value changes with development stage

refashioned: Since humans, like all animals, naturally multiply in proportion to their means of subsistence, food is always in demand to some degree. It can always command some quantity of labor -- someone can always be found willing to work for food. The quantity of labor food can purchase is not always equal to what it could theoretically support if managed with maximum economy, because wages are sometimes high. But food can always purchase enough labor to sustain itself at the rate at which that kind of labor is typically maintained in the area.
elegant: Since population grows with food supply, food is always in demand. It can always command some labor -- someone will always work for food. Though high wages may mean food purchases less labor than it could theoretically support, it always buys enough labor to sustain workers at prevailing local rates.
summary: Smith argues that food always commands demand because population naturally expands to match the food supply. Food can therefore always purchase labor, though the amount varies with prevailing wage rates.
distilled: Food always commands demand because population grows with subsistence, ensuring that food can always purchase some quantity of labor at prevailing rates.
notes: Population-food relationship -- Malthusian principle -- food as universal demand -- labor command of food -- subsistence and population growth -- foundational for 'always yields rent' argument

refashioned: But land, in almost any situation, produces more food than is needed to sustain all the labor required to bring that food to market, even when that labor is generously maintained. The surplus is always more than enough to replace the invested capital along with its profits. Something, therefore, always remains as rent for the landlord.
elegant: Land almost always produces more food than needed to sustain the labor of cultivating it and to replace the capital invested with its profits. The surplus that remains constitutes the landlord's rent.
summary: Smith argues that land almost universally produces enough food to cover labor costs, capital replacement, profits, and still leave a surplus -- which becomes the landlord's rent.
distilled: Land almost always produces a food surplus beyond what is needed for labor, capital, and profit -- and this surplus is what constitutes rent.
notes: Agricultural surplus as basis of rent -- land productivity exceeds labor cost -- surplus theory of rent -- food-producing land as always yielding rent -- foundation for rent as natural surplus

refashioned: Even the most barren moors in Norway and Scotland produce some pasture for cattle, whose milk and natural increase are always more than sufficient to maintain the labor of tending them and to pay the ordinary profit to the farmer or herd owner -- while still affording some small rent to the landlord. Rent increases with the quality of the pasture. Better land not only supports more cattle but, since the animals are kept in a smaller area, requires less labor to tend them and collect their produce. The landlord benefits both ways: from greater output and from lower labor costs.
elegant: Even the most barren moors produce pasture whose cattle yield enough to cover labor costs, pay ordinary profits, and still afford some rent. Better pasture increases rent doubly: it supports more cattle while requiring less labor to tend them in their smaller range.
summary: Smith demonstrates that even the poorest land yields some rent through cattle grazing, and that rent increases with pasture quality both because output rises and because labor costs fall as animals graze in a smaller area.
distilled: Even the poorest moors yield some rent through grazing, and better pasture doubles the landlord's advantage by increasing output while reducing the labor needed.
notes: Marginal land and rent -- Norway and Scotland moors -- cattle grazing economics -- dual benefit of better pasture -- extensive vs. intensive grazing -- rent gradient by land quality

refashioned: The rent of land varies not only with its fertility, regardless of what it produces, but also with its location, regardless of its fertility. Land near a town commands higher rent than equally fertile land in a remote area. Although cultivating both costs the same, transporting the distant land's produce to market costs more. A greater share of the output must therefore go to cover transportation costs, reducing the surplus from which both the farmer's profit and the landlord's rent are drawn. Moreover, as has already been shown, the rate of profit tends to be higher in remote areas than near large towns. A smaller proportion of this already-diminished surplus therefore goes to the landlord.
elegant: Rent varies with location as well as fertility. Land near towns yields higher rent because less is spent on transportation. Remote land produces a smaller surplus after transport costs, and since profit rates are higher in remote areas, the landlord's share of that diminished surplus is smaller still.
summary: Smith explains that rent depends on both fertility and location. Remote land yields less rent because higher transportation costs reduce the surplus, and higher rural profit rates further diminish the landlord's share.
distilled: Location affects rent as much as fertility: remote land yields less rent because transportation costs and higher rural profit rates both reduce the landlord's share of the surplus.
notes: Location theory of rent -- transportation costs and rent -- distance from market -- rural vs. urban profit rates -- double squeeze on remote land rent -- precursor to von Thunen's model

refashioned: Good roads, canals, and navigable rivers reduce transportation costs, bringing remote regions closer to the economic level of areas near towns. They are therefore the greatest of all improvements. They encourage cultivation in the most distant areas, which always comprise the largest part of the country. They benefit towns by breaking down the local monopoly enjoyed by nearby countryside producers. They even benefit those nearby producers: though new competitors enter their traditional markets, many new markets open for their goods. Monopoly, moreover, is the great enemy of good management, which can only become universal when free competition forces everyone to adopt it in self-defense. It was not much more than fifty years ago that some counties near London petitioned parliament against extending turnpike roads to remoter counties, arguing that cheaper rural labor would undercut them in the London market, reducing rents and ruining cultivation. In fact, their rents have risen and their agriculture has improved since then.
elegant: Good roads, canals, and navigable rivers are the greatest improvements of all. By reducing transport costs, they bring remote areas nearer to urban markets, encourage distant cultivation, break down local monopolies, and open new markets even for nearby producers. Monopoly is the enemy of good management -- only universal competition forces universal efficiency. Counties near London once petitioned against extending roads to remote areas, fearing competition would lower their rents. Instead, their rents rose and agriculture improved.
summary: Smith champions transportation infrastructure as the greatest of all improvements, benefiting everyone by breaking down local monopolies and forcing efficient management through competition. He cites the London counties' misguided petition against turnpike roads as proof that opening markets benefits even those who fear competition.
distilled: Transportation improvements are the greatest of all economic advances because they break down local monopolies, extend cultivation, and force universal efficiency through competition.
notes: Infrastructure as greatest improvement -- transportation and market integration -- breaking monopoly power -- competition forces good management -- London counties' turnpike petition -- fear of competition vs. actual outcomes -- roads, canals, navigable rivers

refashioned: A moderately fertile cornfield produces far more food for humans than the best pasture of equal size. Though cultivation requires much more labor, the surplus remaining after replacing the seed and maintaining all that labor is also much greater. If a pound of butcher's meat were never valued at more than a pound of bread, this larger surplus would everywhere be more valuable, constituting a greater fund for both the farmer's profit and the landlord's rent. This appears to have been the case universally in the early stages of agriculture.
elegant: A cornfield of moderate fertility produces far more human food than the best equal-sized pasture. Despite higher labor costs, the surplus after replacing seed and labor is much greater. If meat and bread were valued equally by weight, the cornfield would always yield more profit and rent. This was the case in early agriculture.
summary: Smith argues that cornfields produce more total food value than equal-sized pastures, yielding a greater surplus for profit and rent -- at least in the early stages of agriculture when bread and meat were valued comparably by weight.
distilled: Cornfields produce a greater food surplus than equal-sized pastures, yielding more rent and profit -- a relationship that prevailed universally in early agriculture.
notes: Corn vs. pasture productivity -- surplus comparison -- early agriculture pricing -- bread vs. meat value -- land use and food production efficiency

refashioned: But the relative values of bread and butcher's meat are very different at different stages of agricultural development. In the earliest stages, the vast unimproved wilderness that makes up most of the country is given over entirely to cattle. There is more meat than bread, so bread -- being the scarcer food -- commands the higher price and faces the greater competition. At Buenos Aires, we are told by Ulloa, four reals (about twenty-one and a half pence sterling) was, forty or fifty years ago, the ordinary price of an ox chosen from a herd of two or three hundred. He says nothing about the price of bread, presumably because it was unremarkable. An ox there cost little more than the labor of catching it. But grain can nowhere be raised without considerable labor, and in a country on the River Plate -- then the main route from Europe to the silver mines of Potosi -- the money-price of labor could not have been cheap. The situation reverses when cultivation spreads across most of the land. There is then more bread than meat. Competition shifts, and the price of meat rises above the price of bread.
elegant: The relative values of bread and meat reverse as agriculture develops. In early stages, vast uncultivated lands support abundant cattle, making meat cheap and bread scarce and expensive. At Buenos Aires, an ox cost merely twenty-one pence -- barely more than the labor of catching it -- while grain required significant labor. But as cultivation expands, bread becomes abundant and meat becomes scarce. Competition reverses, and meat becomes more expensive than bread.
summary: Smith traces how the bread-meat price relationship reverses with agricultural development: in early stages, abundant wild cattle make meat cheap while scarce grain makes bread expensive; as cultivation expands, the relationship inverts.
distilled: The relative prices of bread and meat reverse with agricultural development -- meat is cheap when land is uncultivated and cattle roam freely, but becomes expensive as cultivation expands and pasture shrinks.
notes: Price reversal in agricultural development -- Buenos Aires cattle prices -- Ulloa as source -- Potosi silver mines -- extensive vs. intensive agriculture -- supply-driven price changes -- development stages and food prices

refashioned: As cultivation expands, moreover, the remaining wild lands become insufficient to supply the demand for meat. Much of the cultivated land must then be devoted to raising and fattening cattle, whose price must therefore be high enough to cover not only the labor of tending them, but also the rent and profit that the landlord and farmer could have earned from that land if used for tillage. Cattle raised on the most uncultivated moors, when brought to the same market, sell at the same price proportional to their weight and quality as those raised on the most improved land. The owners of those moors benefit accordingly and raise their rents in proportion. Not much more than a century ago, in many parts of the Scottish Highlands, butcher's meat was as cheap as or cheaper than oatmeal bread. The Union opened the English market to Highland cattle. Their ordinary price is now about three times what it was at the beginning of the century, and the rents of many Highland estates have tripled or quadrupled over the same period. In almost every part of Great Britain today, a pound of the best butcher's meat is generally worth more than two pounds of the best white bread, and in plentiful years sometimes three or four pounds.
elegant: As cultivation expands, wild lands cannot meet meat demand, so cultivated land must be used for cattle -- raising meat prices to cover the rent and profit that tillage would have earned. Even cattle from the poorest moors sell at the same price per pound as those from improved land, raising moorland rents accordingly. Highland cattle prices tripled after the Union opened English markets, and Highland rents tripled or quadrupled. Today in Britain, a pound of the best meat generally exceeds two pounds of the best bread in value.
summary: Smith explains how expanding cultivation forces meat prices up by requiring cultivated land for cattle. The Union's opening of English markets tripled Highland cattle prices and multiplied estate rents, illustrating how market access transforms the value of previously marginal land.
distilled: As cultivation expands and wild pasture shrinks, meat prices must rise to cover the opportunity cost of using cultivated land for cattle, a process that tripled Highland cattle prices after the Union opened English markets.
notes: Opportunity cost of land use -- Scottish Highlands cattle prices -- Act of Union and market integration -- moorland rent increases -- meat-bread price ratios -- marginal land benefiting from market prices set by improved land

refashioned: This is how, as economic development progresses, the rent and profit of unimproved pasture come to be governed in some measure by those of improved land, which are in turn governed by the rent and profit of corn. Corn is an annual crop; cattle require four or five years to grow. Since an acre of land produces a much smaller quantity of meat than grain, the lesser quantity must be compensated by a higher price. If the price more than compensated, more cornland would be converted to pasture. If it did not compensate sufficiently, some pasture would be brought back into grain production.
elegant: As development progresses, pasture rents are governed by improved land rents, which are governed by corn rents. Since corn is annual but cattle take four or five years, and an acre produces less meat than grain, the price of meat must compensate for the lower quantity. Market forces maintain this balance: overcompensation shifts land to pasture; undercompensation shifts it back to corn.
summary: Smith explains how rent equilibrates between corn and pasture through price adjustments. Since cattle take years to raise and land produces less meat than grain per acre, meat prices must be proportionally higher, with market forces ensuring balance through land-use shifts.
distilled: Market forces equilibrate corn and pasture rents through price adjustments that compensate for meat's longer production cycle and lower per-acre yield, with land shifting between uses as relative prices change.
notes: Rent equalization between uses -- corn vs. pasture -- annual vs. multi-year crops -- price as compensating mechanism -- land-use arbitrage -- equilibrium through market adjustment

refashioned: This equality between the rent and profit of grassland and those of cornland -- between land producing animal food and land producing human food -- should be understood as applying only to the bulk of improved land in a large country. In certain specific locations, circumstances differ entirely, and the rent and profit of grass far exceed what corn can yield.
elegant: The equality between grass and corn rents applies only to the general mass of improved land. In particular local situations, grass rents and profits may far exceed what corn can yield.
summary: Smith qualifies his equilibrium argument: the equalization of grass and corn rents holds generally across improved land but breaks down in specific locations where local conditions strongly favor one use over the other.
distilled: The equalization of grass and corn rents applies as a general rule across most improved land, but specific local conditions can create significant exceptions.
notes: Qualification of general rule -- local exceptions to rent equalization -- general vs. particular analysis -- transition to discussion of local advantages

refashioned: Near a large town, for example, demand for milk and horse fodder -- together with the high price of butcher's meat -- often push the value of grass well above its natural proportion to corn. This local advantage obviously cannot be shared by lands at a distance.
elegant: Near large towns, demand for milk, horse fodder, and expensive butcher's meat raises grass value well above its natural proportion to corn -- a local advantage that distant lands cannot share.
summary: Smith identifies urban demand for dairy and horse fodder as factors that elevate grass rents above corn rents near large towns, creating a localized premium that distant lands cannot capture.
distilled: Urban demand for milk, fodder, and meat creates a local premium for grassland near towns that distant lands cannot share.
notes: Urban proximity premium -- milk and fodder demand -- localized rent advantage -- perishability and transport costs -- local vs. general market conditions

refashioned: Particular circumstances have sometimes made certain countries so densely populated that their entire territory, like land near a great town, cannot produce both the grass and the grain their inhabitants need. Their land is therefore devoted mainly to grass -- the bulkier commodity, harder to transport from afar -- while grain, the food of the masses, is largely imported. Holland is currently in this position, and much of ancient Italy appears to have been during Rome's prosperity. 'To feed well,' said old Cato, as Cicero reports, 'was the first and most profitable thing in managing an estate; to feed tolerably well, the second; and to feed badly, the third. To plow ranked only fourth in profit and advantage.' Indeed, tillage near Rome must have been greatly discouraged by the distributions of grain to the people, either free or at very low prices. This grain came from conquered provinces, several of which were required to furnish a tenth of their produce as tax at a set price of about sixpence a peck. The low price at which this grain was distributed to the Roman people must have depressed the price of locally grown grain and discouraged cultivation in the Roman territory.
elegant: Some countries become so densely populated that they devote land mainly to grass -- the bulkier, harder-to-transport commodity -- and import grain. Holland exemplifies this today, as did ancient Italy under Rome's prosperity. Cato ranked feeding cattle as farming's most profitable activity, with plowing only fourth. Roman agriculture was further distorted by cheap or free grain distributions from conquered provinces, which depressed local grain prices and discouraged Italian cultivation.
summary: Smith describes how densely populated regions prioritize grass production and import grain, citing Holland and ancient Rome. Roman agriculture was particularly distorted by grain distributions from conquered provinces, which undercut local farmers and discouraged cultivation near Rome.
distilled: Densely populated countries devote land to grass and import grain, as seen in Holland and ancient Rome, where cheap provincial grain distributions discouraged local cultivation.
notes: Population density and land use -- Holland as modern example -- ancient Roman agriculture -- Cato via Cicero on farm management -- provincial grain as tax -- food distributions depressing local agriculture -- import substitution in land use

refashioned: In an open country where grain is the main crop, a well-enclosed piece of grassland will often rent higher than any neighboring cornfield. It is useful for maintaining the cattle employed in grain cultivation, and its high rent is really paid not from its own produce's value but from that of the cornlands it serves. This premium would likely disappear if all the neighboring land were fully enclosed. The currently high rent of enclosed land in Scotland seems to result from the scarcity of enclosure and will probably not last beyond that scarcity. The advantage of enclosure is greater for pasture than for grain: it saves the labor of guarding the cattle, which also feed better when not disturbed by their keeper or his dog.
elegant: In grain country, enclosed grassland often rents higher than cornfields because it supports the cattle that work the corn. This premium really comes from the cornlands' value, not the grass itself, and would disappear if all land were enclosed. Scotland's high enclosed-land rents reflect the scarcity of enclosure. Enclosure benefits pasture more than corn -- it saves guarding labor and lets cattle feed undisturbed.
summary: Smith explains that enclosed grassland commands premium rent in grain country because it supports draft animals, but this premium reflects scarcity of enclosure rather than inherent superiority. The benefit of enclosure is greater for pasture than corn.
distilled: Enclosed grassland rents high in grain country because it supports the cattle that work the cornfields, but this premium reflects the scarcity of enclosure and would vanish if all land were enclosed.
notes: Enclosure and rent premiums -- complementary land uses -- scarcity premium for enclosed land -- Scotland enclosure scarcity -- cattle management and enclosure -- derived demand for pasture from grain production

refashioned:
But where no such local advantage exists, the rent and profit of grain -- or whatever the common staple food is -- naturally regulate the rent and profit of pasture on land suitable for either use.

The introduction of cultivated grasses, turnips, carrots, cabbages, and other innovations that allow the same amount of land to support more cattle than natural grass would, should be expected to somewhat reduce the price advantage that meat naturally has over bread in developed countries. This appears to have happened: there is reason to believe that, at least in the London market, the price of meat relative to bread is considerably lower now than it was at the beginning of the last century.
elegant: Without local advantages, grain rents regulate pasture rents on land suited to both. The introduction of cultivated grasses, turnips, and other fodder crops has increased the amount of cattle that land can support, reducing the natural price advantage of meat over bread. In the London market, meat's price relative to bread appears considerably lower than a century ago.
summary: Smith explains that grain rents generally regulate pasture rents, and notes that agricultural innovations in fodder crops have reduced meat's price premium over bread by allowing more cattle to be raised on the same land.
distilled: Grain rents regulate pasture rents in the absence of local advantages, and fodder crop innovations have narrowed the price gap between meat and bread by increasing cattle capacity per acre.
notes: Grain as rent regulator -- agricultural innovation in fodder crops -- turnips, cultivated grasses, cabbages -- meat-bread price ratio declining -- London market evidence -- technology and relative prices

refashioned: In the appendix to the life of Prince Henry, Doctor Birch provides an account of the prices of butcher's meat as typically paid by that prince. It states that the four quarters of an ox weighing six hundred pounds usually cost him nine pounds ten shillings, or about thirty-one shillings and eightpence per hundred pounds of weight. Prince Henry died on November 6, 1612, in the nineteenth year of his age.
elegant: According to Doctor Birch's account, Prince Henry typically paid nine pounds ten shillings for a six-hundred-pound ox -- about thirty-one shillings eightpence per hundredweight. Prince Henry died on November 6, 1612, aged nineteen.
summary: Smith cites Doctor Birch's records of Prince Henry's meat purchases in the early seventeenth century as historical price evidence, establishing a benchmark for comparison with later periods.
distilled: Prince Henry paid about thirty-one shillings eightpence per hundredweight of beef around 1612, providing a historical price benchmark.
notes: Prince Henry (d. 1612) -- Doctor Birch as source -- historical beef prices -- price benchmarking -- early 17th century food costs

refashioned: In March 1764, parliament investigated the causes of high food prices. Among the evidence presented, a Virginia merchant testified that in March 1763 he had provisioned his ships with beef at twenty-four or twenty-five shillings per hundredweight, which he considered the normal price. In the expensive year of 1764, he had paid twenty-seven shillings for the same weight and quality. This high 1764 price, however, was still four shillings and eightpence cheaper per hundredweight than the price Prince Henry ordinarily paid. And it should be noted that only the best beef is suitable for salting for long sea voyages.
elegant: In 1764, a parliamentary inquiry into high food prices heard a Virginia merchant testify that he normally paid twenty-four to twenty-five shillings per hundredweight for beef, rising to twenty-seven shillings in that expensive year. Yet even this inflated 1764 price was four shillings eightpence cheaper than Prince Henry's ordinary price 150 years earlier -- and only the best beef is used for ships' provisions.
summary: Smith uses parliamentary testimony from 1764 to show that even inflated beef prices were significantly lower than those paid by Prince Henry 150 years earlier, demonstrating a long-term decline in real meat prices relative to bread.
distilled: Even the high beef prices of 1764 were significantly cheaper than Prince Henry's ordinary prices 150 years earlier, demonstrating the long-term decline in real meat costs.
notes: 1764 parliamentary inquiry -- Virginia merchant testimony -- historical price comparison -- beef prices declining over 150 years -- ship provisioning -- best beef for salting

refashioned:
The price Prince Henry paid amounts to about three and four-fifths pence per pound for the whole carcass, averaging coarse and choice cuts together. At that rate, the choice cuts could not have been sold retail for less than four and a half or five pence per pound.

In the 1764 parliamentary inquiry, witnesses stated that the best retail beef cost consumers four to four and a half pence per pound for choice cuts, and roughly seven farthings to two and a half or two and three-quarter pence for coarse pieces. They noted that these prices were about a halfpenny higher per pound than the usual March prices. But even this elevated price was still considerably cheaper than what we can reasonably estimate was the ordinary retail price in Prince Henry's time.
elegant: Prince Henry paid about three and four-fifths pence per pound wholesale, implying choice retail cuts of at least four and a half to five pence. In 1764, choice retail beef was four to four and a half pence per pound, with coarse cuts at roughly seven farthings to two and three-quarter pence -- about a halfpenny above normal March prices. Even these high 1764 prices were considerably below estimated retail prices in Prince Henry's era.
summary: Smith compares wholesale and retail beef prices across periods, showing that even the elevated prices of 1764 were lower than the implied retail prices of Prince Henry's era, further confirming the long-term decline in real meat costs.
distilled: Detailed price comparison confirms that even the high beef prices of 1764 were lower than retail prices in Prince Henry's time, demonstrating meat's long-term cheapening relative to bread.
notes: Retail vs. wholesale price analysis -- pence per pound comparisons -- choice vs. coarse cuts -- 1764 parliamentary evidence -- long-term price trend confirmation

refashioned:
During the first twelve years of the last century, the average price of the best wheat at the Windsor market was one pound, eighteen shillings, and three and a half pence per quarter of nine Winchester bushels.

But in the twelve years preceding and including 1764, the average price of the same measure of the best wheat at the same market was two pounds, one shilling, and nine and a half pence.
elegant: At the Windsor market, the average price of the best wheat was about one pound eighteen shillings per quarter in the first twelve years of the century, rising to about two pounds two shillings in the twelve years up to 1764.
summary: Smith provides wheat price data from the Windsor market showing a modest increase from about one pound eighteen shillings to about two pounds two shillings per quarter between the early century and the period around 1764.
distilled: Windsor market wheat prices rose modestly from about thirty-eight shillings to about forty-two shillings per quarter between the early century and the period around 1764.
notes: Windsor market wheat prices -- historical price data -- quarterly wheat prices -- Winchester bushels -- early vs. mid-century comparison

refashioned:
In the first twelve years of the last century, therefore, wheat appears to have been considerably cheaper and butcher's meat considerably dearer than in the twelve years ending in 1764.

In every large country, the bulk of cultivated land is used to produce either food for humans or food for cattle. The rent and profit of these two uses regulate the rent and profit of all other cultivated land. If any particular crop yielded less, the land would soon be converted to grain or pasture. If any yielded more, some grain or pasture land would soon be switched to that crop.
elegant: In the early century, wheat was cheaper and meat dearer than around 1764 -- confirming the long-term shift in relative prices. In every large country, most cultivated land produces food for people or cattle, and the rents from these two uses regulate all other land rents. Land shifts between uses as relative returns change.
summary: Smith confirms that wheat became relatively more expensive while meat became cheaper over the century, and restates the principle that grain and pasture rents serve as the benchmark regulating all other land rents through competitive land-use shifting.
distilled: The century-long shift toward cheaper meat and dearer wheat confirms that grain and pasture rents, as the dominant land uses, regulate all other agricultural rents through competitive land-use arbitrage.
notes: Relative price shift confirmation -- wheat vs. meat over the century -- land-use arbitrage -- grain and pasture as rent benchmarks -- regulatory role of dominant crops

refashioned: Crops that require either a greater initial investment in land improvement or greater ongoing cultivation costs do generally appear to yield higher rents and profits than grain or pasture. However, this premium rarely amounts to more than a reasonable return on the additional expense.
elegant: Crops requiring greater improvement or cultivation costs generally yield higher rents and profits than grain or pasture, but this premium typically amounts to no more than a reasonable return on the extra expense.
summary: Smith notes that higher-cost crops yield higher rents and profits, but the premium generally just compensates for the additional investment required.
distilled: Higher-cost crops command higher rents, but the premium generally only compensates for the additional improvement and cultivation expenses.
notes: Cost-based rent differentials -- reasonable return on extra investment -- compensation principle in rent -- transition to discussion of gardens and vineyards

refashioned: In a hop garden, fruit garden, or kitchen garden, both the landlord's rent and the farmer's profit are generally greater than in a cornfield or pasture. But preparing the ground for these uses requires more initial expense, which justifies a higher rent. The cultivation also demands more attentive and skilled management, which justifies a higher profit. The crops, especially in hop and fruit gardens, are also more precarious. Their price must therefore compensate for occasional losses -- essentially including an insurance premium. The generally modest circumstances of gardeners, who are never more than comfortably off, confirm that their considerable skill is not typically overcompensated. Their delightful art is practiced by so many wealthy amateurs for pleasure that little profit is left for those who practice it commercially, since the people who would naturally be their best customers supply themselves with the most valuable produce.
elegant: Gardens yield higher rent and profit than cornfields, justified by greater initial expense, more demanding management, and riskier harvests that require an implicit insurance premium. Yet gardeners remain modestly situated -- their skill is never overpaid because wealthy amateurs practice the art for pleasure, growing their own finest produce and depriving commercial gardeners of their best potential customers.
summary: Smith explains that gardens yield higher rent and profit to compensate for greater expense, skill, and risk. But commercial gardeners earn only modest returns because wealthy hobbyists grow their own finest produce, undermining the market for professional growers.
distilled: Gardens yield higher rent and profit than cornfields to compensate for greater cost, skill, and risk, but commercial gardeners remain modestly compensated because wealthy amateurs grow their own best produce.
notes: Hop, fruit, and kitchen gardens -- risk premium in pricing -- gardener compensation -- wealthy amateur competition -- insurance component in crop prices -- compensating differentials in agriculture

refashioned: The advantage landlords derive from such improvements seems never to have exceeded what was sufficient to justify the initial expense. In ancient agriculture, after the vineyard, a well-watered kitchen garden was considered the most valuable part of a farm. But Democritus, who wrote on farming about two thousand years ago and was regarded as one of the founders of the art, thought it unwise to enclose a kitchen garden -- the profit, he said, would not justify the cost of a stone wall, and sun-dried bricks crumbled in rain and winter storms, requiring constant repair. Columella, reporting this view, did not dispute it but suggested a frugal alternative: a hedge of brambles and briars, which he had found by experience to be both lasting and impenetrable -- though apparently unknown in Democritus's time. Palladius adopted Columella's view, which Varro had previously recommended. By the judgment of these ancient authorities, garden produce barely sufficed to cover the extra costs of cultivation and irrigation -- for in such sun-drenched countries, it was thought essential then as now to have a water supply for every garden bed. Throughout most of Europe today, a kitchen garden still does not warrant better enclosure than what Columella recommended. In Great Britain and other northern countries, however, the finest fruits cannot ripen without a wall. Their price must therefore cover the cost of building and maintaining that wall. The fruit wall often surrounds the kitchen garden as well, which thereby enjoys enclosure its own produce could rarely justify.
elegant: Landlords' returns from garden improvements have never exceeded what justified the initial expense. Democritus thought kitchen garden enclosure unprofitable; Columella suggested bramble hedges as a cheaper alternative. Ancient authorities agreed that garden produce barely covered extra cultivation and irrigation costs. Today, most European kitchen gardens still need no better fence. In northern countries like Britain, walls are needed for fine fruit, and their cost must be recovered in the price -- kitchen gardens benefit from the enclosure only because they share the fruit wall.
summary: Smith traces two millennia of evidence that kitchen garden improvements barely justify their costs. From Democritus through Columella to modern practice, the returns from garden cultivation have never much exceeded the expense, with northern climates requiring costly walls whose expense is shared between fruit and kitchen gardens.
distilled: Two thousand years of evidence from Democritus to modern practice show that kitchen garden improvements have never yielded returns significantly above their costs, with enclosure justified only where fruit walls serve double duty.
notes: Democritus on garden economics -- Columella's bramble hedges -- Palladius and Varro -- ancient vs. modern gardening -- northern climate fruit walls -- shared infrastructure costs -- historical consistency of garden economics

refashioned: That the vineyard, when properly established and brought to maturity, was the most valuable part of a farm seems to have been an accepted truth in ancient agriculture, as it is in modern wine countries. But whether it was profitable to plant a new vineyard was disputed among ancient Italian farmers, as we learn from Columella. He argued in favor of vineyards, as a true devotee of intensive cultivation, and tried to demonstrate through cost-benefit analysis that they were the most profitable improvement. Such comparisons between the costs and returns of new ventures are commonly quite unreliable, however, and nowhere more so than in agriculture. If the gains from such plantings had truly been as great as he imagined, there would have been no debate about it.
elegant: That mature vineyards were a farm's most valuable asset was accepted in both ancient and modern agriculture. But planting new vineyards was controversial: Columella argued for them through cost-benefit analysis, but such calculations in agriculture are notoriously unreliable. If vineyards were truly as profitable as he claimed, there would have been no debate.
summary: Smith notes that while established vineyards were universally valued as the most profitable part of a farm, the profitability of planting new ones was disputed even in ancient times. Columella's optimistic cost-benefit analysis was unreliable, as the ongoing debate itself proved.
distilled: Mature vineyards were universally considered a farm's most valuable asset, but the disputed profitability of planting new ones reveals the unreliability of agricultural cost-benefit projections.
notes: Vineyard economics -- Columella's advocacy -- cost-benefit analysis in agriculture -- unreliability of new venture projections -- ancient agricultural debate -- revealed preference argument (if profitable, no debate)

refashioned: The same question remains controversial today in wine countries. Their agricultural writers, like Columella, generally favor vineyards as advocates of intensive cultivation. In France, the anxiety of existing vineyard owners to prevent the planting of new ones seems to support their view that vine cultivation is currently more profitable than any alternative. At the same time, however, this anxiety suggests another opinion: that this superior profit depends entirely on the laws that currently restrict the free planting of vines. In 1731, vineyard owners obtained a royal order prohibiting both the planting of new vineyards and the renewal of old ones that had been out of cultivation for two years, without special royal permission. Such permission required certification from the provincial intendant that the land had been inspected and found incapable of any other use.
elegant: The vineyard debate continues in modern wine countries, where agricultural writers favor intensive vine cultivation. In France, established vineyard owners' efforts to block new plantings suggest vine cultivation is indeed more profitable -- but also that this profit depends on legal restrictions on free planting. In 1731, they secured a royal order prohibiting new vineyards or renewal of abandoned ones without royal permission based on proof that the land was unfit for anything else.
summary: Smith observes that French vineyard owners' efforts to restrict new planting reveal both that viticulture is unusually profitable and that this profitability depends on artificial legal protection rather than natural market conditions.
distilled: French vineyard owners' lobbying against new plantings reveals that wine's superior profitability depends on legal restrictions, not natural market conditions -- free competition would erode the premium.
notes: French vineyard regulations -- 1731 royal order -- incumbent protection -- revealed preference for restriction -- profitability dependent on monopoly -- provincial intendant certification -- rent-seeking by established producers

refashioned: The stated justification for this order was a scarcity of grain and pasture, and a supposed overabundance of wine. But if the overabundance had been real, it would have prevented new vineyard planting on its own -- by reducing wine profits below their natural proportion to grain and pasture profits, without any government intervention. As for the supposed grain scarcity caused by vineyard expansion: nowhere in France is grain more carefully cultivated than in the wine provinces -- Burgundy, Guienne, and the Upper Languedoc -- where the land is suitable for it.
elegant: The order claimed to address grain scarcity and wine overproduction. But true overabundance would have naturally discouraged new vineyards by depressing wine profits -- no regulation needed. And the supposed grain scarcity is disproven by fact: nowhere in France is grain more carefully cultivated than in the wine provinces of Burgundy, Guienne, and Upper Languedoc.
summary: Smith demolishes the justification for restricting vineyard planting: true wine overabundance would have self-corrected through falling profits, and the wine provinces actually cultivate grain more carefully than anywhere else in France.
distilled: The justification for restricting vineyard planting was false: true overabundance would self-correct through lower profits, and wine provinces actually cultivate grain more carefully than other regions.
notes: Self-correcting markets -- false pretexts for regulation -- Burgundy, Guienne, Upper Languedoc -- wine provinces and grain cultivation -- market adjustment vs. government intervention

refashioned:
The numerous workers employed in one form of cultivation necessarily encourage the other by providing a ready market for its products. Reducing the number of people who can afford to buy grain is surely a most unpromising way to encourage grain cultivation. It is like trying to promote agriculture by discouraging manufacturing.

The rents and profits of crops requiring greater initial improvement costs or ongoing cultivation expenses, though often much higher than those of grain and pasture, are -- when they merely compensate for these extra costs -- actually regulated by the rents and profits of those standard crops.
elegant: Workers in one form of cultivation encourage others by creating a market for their products. Restricting wine growers to promote grain farming is as counterproductive as discouraging manufacturing to promote agriculture. Though specialty crops yield higher rents and profits, these premiums merely compensate for extra costs and are ultimately regulated by grain and pasture returns.
summary: Smith argues that restricting one form of cultivation to encourage another is self-defeating, since cultivators of one crop create demand for others. He reiterates that the higher returns on specialty crops merely compensate for higher costs and are regulated by baseline grain and pasture returns.
distilled: Restricting one crop to promote another is self-defeating because different cultivations create mutual demand, and specialty crop premiums merely compensate for higher costs rather than representing true excess returns.
notes: Complementarity of different cultivations -- mutual demand creation -- analogy between agriculture restriction and manufacturing restriction -- compensating differentials -- grain and pasture as baseline returns

refashioned: It sometimes happens, however, that the quantity of land suitable for a particular crop is too small to meet effective demand. The entire output can then be sold to buyers willing to pay more than what is needed to cover the full rent, wages, and profit required for production and marketing at their normal rates. The surplus price that remains after covering all improvement and cultivation costs may, in this case -- and in this case alone -- bear no regular proportion to the corresponding surplus for grain or pasture. It may exceed it by almost any degree, and the greater part of this excess naturally accrues as rent to the landlord.
elegant: When land suitable for a particular crop is scarce relative to demand, the entire output sells to buyers willing to pay above normal costs. The price surplus may then bear no regular proportion to grain or pasture surpluses, exceeding them by almost any degree -- with the excess going mainly to the landlord as rent.
summary: Smith identifies the one case where crop returns can vastly exceed the grain and pasture baseline: when the land suitable for a particular product is too scarce to meet demand, allowing prices to rise far above normal cost-plus-profit levels, with the excess captured as landlord rent.
distilled: When land suitable for a particular crop is scarce relative to demand, prices can rise far above normal returns, with the excess captured almost entirely as landlord rent.
notes: Scarcity rent -- inelastic supply of specialized land -- demand exceeding supply -- excess returns to landlord -- exception to compensating differential rule -- monopoly rent from natural scarcity

refashioned: The usual proportional relationship between the rent and profit of wine and those of grain and pasture applies only to vineyards that produce nothing but ordinary wine -- the kind that can be grown almost anywhere on any light, gravelly, or sandy soil, and whose only merits are its strength and wholesomeness. Only these ordinary vineyards compete with common agricultural land. Vineyards producing wines of distinctive quality obviously face no such competition.
elegant: The normal proportionality between wine and grain returns applies only to vineyards producing ordinary wine -- the kind grown on any light, gravelly soil with no distinction beyond strength and wholesomeness. Only these compete with common agricultural land. Vineyards producing wines of distinctive quality are in a different category entirely.
summary: Smith distinguishes between ordinary vineyards that compete directly with grain and pasture land, and premium vineyards whose distinctive wines face no such competition, allowing them to earn rent far above normal agricultural levels.
distilled: Ordinary vineyards compete with grain and pasture, but vineyards producing wines of distinctive quality face no such competition and can earn rent far above normal agricultural returns.
notes: Ordinary vs. premium vineyards -- quality differentiation and rent -- terroir concept (avant la lettre) -- competitive land use applies only to common wine -- monopoly rent from unique products

refashioned: The vine is more affected by soil differences than any other fruit tree. Certain soils impart a flavor that no amount of cultivation or management on other soils can replicate, or so it is believed. This distinctive flavor sometimes belongs to the produce of just a few vineyards, sometimes extends across much of a small district, and sometimes through a considerable portion of a large province. The total quantity of such wines that reaches market falls short of effective demand -- the demand from those willing to pay the full normal cost of production and transport. The entire supply can therefore be sold to buyers willing to pay more, which necessarily raises prices above those of ordinary wine. The premium varies with how fashionable and scarce the wine is, and how eagerly buyers compete for it. Whatever the premium, most of it goes to the landlord as rent. Though such vineyards are generally cultivated with greater care than most others, the high price seems to be not so much the result of careful cultivation as its cause. When the product is so valuable, the losses from negligence would be so great that even the most careless owners are forced to pay attention. Only a small part of the high price therefore covers the extra labor and capital invested in their cultivation.
elegant: Vines are uniquely sensitive to soil, sometimes producing flavors that no cultivation elsewhere can replicate. Such wines -- whether from a few vineyards, a district, or a province -- always fall short of demand from willing buyers, raising prices above ordinary levels. The premium, driven by fashion and scarcity, goes mainly to the landlord. Though these vineyards are carefully cultivated, the high price causes the careful cultivation, not the reverse -- the value of the product forces attention even from careless owners. Only a small fraction of the price covers extra labor and capital.
summary: Smith explains that certain terroirs produce irreplicable wine flavors, creating scarcity that drives prices far above ordinary wine. The resulting premium goes mainly to landlords as rent. Crucially, the high price causes careful cultivation rather than the reverse -- valuable products force even negligent owners to pay attention.
distilled: Unique terroirs create irreplicable wines whose scarcity drives prices far above ordinary levels, with the premium going mainly to landlords -- and the high price causes careful cultivation, not the other way around.
notes: Terroir and rent -- scarcity premium for distinctive wines -- fashion and scarcity driving competition -- causation: high price causes care, not vice versa -- negligence costs force attention -- most of premium goes to landlord rent -- Burgundy, Bordeaux implicitly

refashioned: The sugar colonies of the European nations in the West Indies may be compared to these precious vineyards. Their entire output falls short of European demand and can be sold to buyers willing to pay more than the full normal cost of production and transport. In Cochin China, the finest white sugar typically sells for about three piastres per quintal -- roughly thirteen shillings and sixpence of English money -- according to Mr. Poivre, a careful observer of that country's agriculture. What is there called a quintal weighs between one hundred fifty and two hundred Paris pounds, averaging about one hundred seventy-five. This reduces the English hundredweight price to about eight shillings -- less than a quarter of the common price of brown or muscovado sugar from British colonies, and less than a sixth of the price of the finest white sugar.
elegant: West Indian sugar colonies resemble precious vineyards: their output falls short of European demand, commanding premium prices. The comparison with Cochin China is striking: there, fine white sugar sells for about eight shillings per English hundredweight -- less than a quarter of what British colonial brown sugar costs, and less than a sixth of the finest white sugar's price in Europe.
summary: Smith compares West Indian sugar plantations to premium vineyards, noting that limited supply relative to European demand drives prices far above normal production costs. The comparison with Cochin China's sugar prices -- a fraction of European colonial prices -- reveals the enormous scarcity premium European consumers pay.
distilled: West Indian sugar colonies, like premium vineyards, earn enormous rents because their output falls far short of European demand, as shown by Cochin China's sugar costing a fraction of European colonial prices.
notes: Sugar colonies as premium vineyards -- West Indies sugar economics -- Cochin China sugar prices -- Mr. Poivre as source -- scarcity rent in colonial commodities -- price comparison across production regions -- European demand exceeding colonial supply

refashioned: The greater part of cultivated land in Cochin China is used to grow corn and rice, the staple food of the population. The respective prices of corn, rice, and sugar there are probably in their natural proportion -- the ratio that normally prevails across the bulk of cultivated land and that compensates landlord and farmer roughly according to the usual costs of improvement and cultivation. But in European sugar colonies, the price of sugar bears no such natural proportion to the price of rice or corn, whether in Europe or America.
elegant: In Cochin China, most land grows corn and rice, and the prices of corn, rice, and sugar maintain their natural proportions -- reflecting normal improvement and cultivation costs. In European sugar colonies, by contrast, sugar prices bear no natural proportion to grain prices whatsoever.
summary: Smith contrasts the natural price proportions between crops in Cochin China with the distorted proportions in European sugar colonies, where sugar prices far exceed what normal cost-based proportionality would suggest.
distilled: Sugar prices in European colonies bear no natural proportion to grain prices, unlike in Cochin China where all crop prices maintain normal cost-based relationships.
notes: Natural vs. distorted price proportions -- Cochin China as natural baseline -- European colonial sugar price distortion -- comparison of production systems -- cost-based proportionality in crop pricing

refashioned: It is commonly said that a sugar planter expects the rum and molasses to cover the entire cost of cultivation, with the sugar itself being pure profit. If this is true -- and I make no claim to confirm it -- it is as if a grain farmer expected the chaff and straw to pay all his cultivation costs, leaving the grain as pure profit. We regularly see merchant partnerships in London and other trading cities purchasing waste land in the sugar colonies, expecting to improve and cultivate it profitably through agents and managers, despite the great distance and uncertain returns caused by the defective administration of justice in those countries. Nobody attempts the same thing with the most fertile lands of Scotland, Ireland, or the grain-producing provinces of North America, even though the more reliable legal systems in those countries would promise more regular returns.
elegant: Sugar planters reportedly expect rum and molasses to cover all costs, with sugar as pure profit -- as if a grain farmer expected chaff and straw to pay for everything. London merchants buy waste land in sugar colonies to cultivate through distant agents despite poor legal systems and uncertain returns. Yet nobody attempts this with the most fertile lands in Scotland, Ireland, or North American grain provinces, where reliable legal systems would offer more certain returns.
summary: Smith illustrates the extraordinary profitability of sugar cultivation: planters allegedly treat sugar as pure profit after byproducts cover costs, and London merchants invest in distant sugar colonies despite poor governance -- investments they would never make in closer, better-governed grain-producing regions.
distilled: The extraordinary profitability of sugar cultivation is revealed by planters treating sugar as pure profit and by merchants investing in distant, poorly governed sugar colonies while ignoring more fertile, better-governed grain lands closer to home.
notes: Sugar profitability -- rum and molasses covering costs -- chaff and straw analogy -- absentee investment in sugar colonies -- administration of justice and investment -- Scotland, Ireland, North America comparison -- London merchant partnerships -- risk-return calculation favoring distant sugar over nearby grain

refashioned: In Virginia and Maryland, farmers prefer growing tobacco over corn because it is more profitable. Tobacco could be grown successfully across most of Europe, but nearly every European country has made it a major target of taxation. Since collecting taxes from every individual farm that might grow tobacco would be impractical, governments have found it easier to tax it upon importation at the customs house. For this reason, tobacco cultivation has been absurdly banned throughout most of Europe, which effectively grants a monopoly to the countries where it is still permitted. Virginia and Maryland, as the largest producers, reap a substantial share of this monopoly's benefits, though they do face some competition.
elegant: Virginia and Maryland prefer tobacco to corn for its higher profits. Most of Europe has banned tobacco cultivation because taxing it farm-by-farm is impractical -- it is easier to tax at importation. This prohibition grants a de facto monopoly to the colonies where cultivation is allowed, benefiting Virginia and Maryland most of all.
summary: European governments banned domestic tobacco cultivation because it was easier to tax at the point of importation than at individual farms. This created a monopoly advantage for Virginia and Maryland as the leading producers.
distilled: European tobacco cultivation bans created a monopoly for American colonies like Virginia and Maryland by making importation the sole taxable channel.
notes: Tax policy as trade barrier -- government prohibition of domestic cultivation functions as a protective monopoly for colonial producers. Cross-reference 1.7 on monopoly rents and 1.11.44 on food-land rent as the baseline. -- Illustrates how fiscal convenience (ease of tax collection) can override rational agricultural policy.

refashioned: Growing tobacco, however, appears less profitable than growing sugar. I have never heard of a tobacco plantation developed and financed by British merchants living in Great Britain, and our tobacco colonies do not send home the kind of wealthy planters we regularly see arriving from our sugar islands. Although the preference for tobacco over corn in those colonies suggests that European demand for tobacco is not fully met, it is probably closer to being satisfied than European demand for sugar. While the current price of tobacco likely exceeds what is needed to cover the full costs of rent, wages, and profit at rates typical of corn land, it does not exceed those costs by nearly as much as the price of sugar does. Tobacco planters have shown the same anxiety about oversupply that old vineyard owners in France have shown about an excess of wine. By legislative act, they have limited cultivation to six thousand plants per working slave between sixteen and sixty years of age -- a quantity expected to yield about a thousand pounds of tobacco.
elegant: Tobacco cultivation is less profitable than sugar. No British merchant has invested in tobacco plantations as they have in sugar, and tobacco colonies produce no planters as wealthy as those from sugar islands. Though tobacco demand is not fully met, it is closer to saturation than sugar demand, and tobacco's price premium over production costs is smaller. Like French vineyard owners fearing wine oversupply, tobacco planters have legislated output restrictions -- limiting cultivation to six thousand plants per slave.
summary: Tobacco is less profitable than sugar, as evidenced by the absence of wealthy tobacco planters comparable to sugar planters. Tobacco planters, fearing oversupply like French vintners, have legally restricted output per worker.
distilled: Tobacco cultivation, while profitable, falls well short of sugar's returns, and planters have restricted output by law to prevent oversupply.
notes: Comparative colonial profitability -- sugar vs. tobacco as competing cash crops. -- Output restrictions by colonial assemblies parallel French vineyard regulations (see 1.11.38-40) -- both represent producer-driven supply management. -- 'Effectual demand' concept from 1.7 applied: tobacco demand is closer to being fully supplied than sugar demand. -- Labor measured per enslaved worker reflects the brutal realities of colonial plantation economics.

refashioned: Such a slave, in addition to this quantity of tobacco, is reckoned capable of managing four acres of Indian corn. To prevent oversupply, planters in plentiful years have sometimes -- according to Dr. Douglas, though I suspect his information may be faulty -- burned a set quantity of tobacco for every slave, in the same way the Dutch are said to destroy surplus spices. If such extreme measures are needed to maintain tobacco's current price, then any remaining advantage of tobacco cultivation over corn is unlikely to last much longer.
elegant: A slave can also manage four acres of corn alongside the tobacco quota. To prevent gluts, planters reportedly burned surplus tobacco -- much as the Dutch destroyed excess spices. If such drastic measures are needed to maintain prices, tobacco's advantage over corn cultivation will not endure.
summary: Colonial tobacco planters reportedly destroyed surplus crops to maintain prices, similar to Dutch spice destruction. Smith doubts tobacco's long-term profitability advantage over corn if such extreme measures are required.
distilled: If tobacco planters must destroy surplus crops to maintain prices, the crop's advantage over corn is unsustainable.
notes: Supply destruction to maintain prices -- an early example of what would later be called 'price support' or cartel behavior. -- Parallel with Dutch East India Company spice destruction. -- Smith's skepticism ('I suspect he has been ill informed') shows his critical approach to sources. -- Cross-reference 1.11.38-40 on French wine restrictions as analogous supply management.

refashioned: This is how the rent of cultivated land that produces human food sets the standard for the rent of most other cultivated land. No crop can sustain a rent below the food-land baseline for long, because the land would simply be redirected to food production. And if any particular crop consistently commands a higher rent, it is because the amount of land suitable for growing it is too limited to satisfy the full demand.
elegant: The rent of food-producing land sets the floor for all other cultivated land. No crop can yield less rent for long, since the land would be converted to food production. Crops that yield more rent do so only because the land suited to them is too scarce to meet demand.
summary: Food-producing land establishes the baseline rent for all cultivated land. Land shifts to food production if alternative crops yield less, while crops commanding higher rents reflect scarcity of suitable land.
distilled: The rent of food-producing land sets the baseline for all agricultural rents, with deviations explained by land scarcity or convertibility.
notes: Key theoretical conclusion of Part I of Chapter 11 -- food rent as the regulator of all agricultural rents. -- Opportunity cost principle: land gravitates toward its most remunerative use. -- 'Effectual demand' concept from 1.7 explains why some crops command premiums -- insufficient land to supply demand fully. -- Cross-reference 1.11.1-4 on the three components of price (rent, wages, profit).

refashioned: In Europe, corn is the principal crop that directly feeds people. Therefore, except in unusual circumstances, the rent of corn land sets the standard for all other cultivated land across Europe. Britain need not envy France its vineyards or Italy its olive groves. Except in special situations, the value of those crops is governed by the value of corn, and Britain's fertility in corn production is not far behind that of either France or Italy.
elegant: Corn is Europe's primary food crop, so corn-land rent generally regulates all other agricultural rents. Britain need not envy French vineyards or Italian olive groves, since their value is ultimately governed by corn's value -- and Britain's corn fertility rivals both countries.
summary: Since corn is Europe's staple food, corn-land rent sets the benchmark for all other agricultural rents. Britain's corn fertility makes it competitive with France's vineyards and Italy's olive plantations.
distilled: Corn-land rent is the benchmark for European agricultural rents because corn is the continent's primary food crop.
notes: Application of the food-rent baseline (1.11.44) to European agriculture specifically. -- 'Corn' in Smith's usage means grain generally, especially wheat. -- Comparative advantage argument: Britain should not envy specialty crops whose rents are ultimately governed by grain rents. -- Cross-reference 1.11.38-40 on vineyard rents being regulated by corn-land rents.

refashioned: If the common and preferred food of a country's people came from a plant that produced, on ordinary land and with similar cultivation, a far greater quantity of food than the most fertile corn land, then the landlord's rent -- the surplus remaining after paying labor and replacing the farmer's capital with its ordinary profits -- would necessarily be much larger. Whatever the prevailing rate of wages in that country, this greater surplus could always support more labor, enabling the landlord to purchase or command a greater quantity of it. The real value of his rent -- his actual power and authority, his ability to command the necessities and comforts of life that other people's labor could provide -- would necessarily be much greater.
elegant: If a country's staple food came from a crop far more productive than corn on similar land, the landlord's surplus after wages and capital costs would be correspondingly larger. This greater surplus would support more labor, giving landlords greater real wealth -- more command over necessities and comforts.
summary: If a staple food crop were more productive per acre than corn, landlords would enjoy larger surpluses and greater real wealth, commanding more labor and goods.
distilled: A more productive staple food crop than corn would generate larger landlord surpluses and proportionally greater real wealth and economic power.
notes: Introduces the hypothetical that leads to the potato and rice discussions. -- Real vs. nominal value distinction: landlord's power measured in command over labor, not money. -- Surplus theory of rent -- rent as what remains after wages and profits. -- Cross-reference 1.5 on labor as the real measure of value, and 1.11.47-50 on rice and potatoes as higher-yield alternatives.

refashioned: A rice field produces far more food than even the most fertile corn field. Two harvests per year, each yielding thirty to sixty bushels, are considered the standard output of an acre. Although rice cultivation requires more labor, a much larger surplus remains after all that labor is sustained. In countries where rice is the staple food and where the workers who cultivate it are mainly fed on rice, a greater share of this larger surplus should therefore go to the landlord than in corn-growing countries. In Carolina, where planters are typically both farmers and landlords (so that rent and profit are combined), rice cultivation is found to be more profitable than corn cultivation, even though their fields produce only one crop per year and, following European custom, rice is not the people's preferred staple food.
elegant: Rice fields vastly outproduce corn fields -- yielding two crops annually of thirty to sixty bushels each. Despite requiring more labor, a much larger surplus remains. Where rice is the staple, landlords should receive a greater share of this surplus than in corn countries. Even in Carolina, where rice is not the staple and yields only one annual crop, rice cultivation proves more profitable than corn.
summary: Rice produces far more food per acre than corn, with two annual harvests yielding thirty to sixty bushels each. Even in Carolina, where rice is not the staple and produces only one crop yearly, it outperforms corn in profitability.
distilled: Rice's vastly greater productivity per acre generates larger surpluses and higher rents than corn, even in places like Carolina where it is not the staple food.
notes: Empirical case study supporting the hypothesis from 1.11.46. -- Rice as a higher-yield alternative to corn -- relevant to modern discussions of caloric output per acre. -- Carolina example shows that even under suboptimal conditions (one crop, not the local staple), rice outperforms corn. -- Rent and profit 'confounded' when planter is also landlord -- see 1.6 on the distinction between these income categories.

refashioned: A productive rice field is essentially a swamp year-round, and for part of the year a flooded swamp at that. It is unsuitable for corn, pasture, vineyards, or virtually any other crop useful to people, and the land suitable for those purposes cannot grow rice. Even in rice-producing countries, therefore, the rent of rice land cannot set the standard for other cultivated land, since that land can never be converted to rice production.
elegant: Rice fields are permanent bogs -- unsuitable for any other crop, and ordinary farmland cannot grow rice. Therefore rice-land rent cannot regulate other agricultural rents, since the two types of land are not interchangeable.
summary: Rice land and other cultivated land are not interchangeable because rice requires permanent wetland conditions. Consequently, rice-land rent cannot serve as the benchmark for other agricultural rents.
distilled: Rice-land rent cannot regulate other land rents because rice requires wetland conditions incompatible with all other crops.
notes: Important qualification to the food-rent baseline theory (1.11.44) -- the regulating crop must be grown on convertible land. -- Land non-substitutability: when land types cannot be converted between uses, their rents are determined independently. -- Contrast with the potato discussion (1.11.49-50), where potato land IS convertible to other uses.

refashioned: The food produced by a field of potatoes is no less in quantity than that from a rice field, and far exceeds what a wheat field yields. Twelve thousand pounds of potatoes per acre is no greater a harvest than two thousand pounds of wheat. The solid nourishment from each plant is not perfectly proportional to its weight, since potatoes contain so much water. But even allowing half the weight of potatoes to be water -- a very generous estimate -- an acre of potatoes still produces six thousand pounds of solid nourishment: three times what an acre of wheat yields. Potatoes also cost less to cultivate than wheat, since the fallow period that typically precedes wheat sowing more than offsets the hoeing and extra care that potatoes require. If potatoes ever became, in any part of Europe, what rice is in rice-growing countries -- the common staple food of the people, occupying the same proportion of farmland that wheat and other food grains currently do -- then the same amount of cultivated land would feed far more people. Workers fed on potatoes would leave a greater surplus after all costs of production were covered. A larger share of this surplus would go to the landlord. Population would grow, and rents would rise far beyond their current levels.
elegant: Potatoes match rice and vastly outproduce wheat per acre. Even discounting half their weight as water, an acre yields six thousand pounds of solid nourishment -- triple wheat's output -- at lower cultivation cost. If potatoes became Europe's staple food, occupying the same farmland share as grain, the same land would feed far more people, leave a larger surplus, and drive rents and population far higher.
summary: Potatoes produce three times the solid nourishment per acre as wheat, at lower cost. If they became Europe's staple crop, population and rents would increase dramatically because the same land would support far more people.
distilled: Potatoes yield triple the nourishment of wheat per acre at lower cost, and if adopted as Europe's staple, would dramatically increase population and rents.
notes: Remarkable prediction about potatoes' potential -- partially realized in Ireland before the Famine. -- Caloric yield comparison: potatoes vs. wheat vs. rice as competing staple crops. -- Connects productivity to population growth and rent -- anticipates Malthusian logic. -- Cross-reference 1.11.46 on hypothetical higher-yield staples and 1.11.50-51 on potato land's versatility and storage limitations.

refashioned:
Land suitable for potatoes is suitable for almost every other useful crop. If potatoes occupied the same share of cultivated land that corn currently does, they would regulate the rent of most other cultivated land in the same way corn does now.

In some parts of Lancashire, I am told, it is claimed that oatmeal bread is heartier food for laborers than wheat bread, and I have often heard the same argument in Scotland. I am somewhat skeptical, however. The common people of Scotland, who eat oatmeal, are generally neither as strong nor as good-looking as their English counterparts who eat wheat bread. They neither work as well nor look as well. Since the upper classes in both countries show no such difference, experience suggests that the diet of Scotland's common people is less suited to human health than that of their English peers. But with potatoes the case seems different. The porters, coal-heavers, and chairmen of London, along with the unfortunate women who live by prostitution -- perhaps the strongest men and most beautiful women in the British Isles -- are said to come largely from the lowest ranks of Irish society, who are generally fed on potatoes. No food could provide more convincing proof of its nutritional quality or its suitability to the human body.
elegant: Potato land, unlike rice land, suits almost any crop -- so if potatoes became the staple, their rent would regulate all other agricultural rents. While oatmeal-fed Scots appear weaker and less healthy than wheat-fed English (with no such difference among the upper classes), potatoes tell a different story: London's strongest laborers and most striking women are said to come from Ireland's poorest potato-fed classes -- powerful evidence of the potato's nutritional superiority.
summary: Unlike rice, potato land is versatile enough to regulate other agricultural rents. Smith contrasts oatmeal-fed Scots unfavorably with wheat-fed English, but praises potatoes as superior nourishment, citing the physical vigor of potato-fed Irish laborers in London.
distilled: Potato land is versatile enough to set agricultural rent benchmarks, and the physical health of potato-fed Irish laborers in London testifies to the crop's nutritional excellence.
notes: Potato land versatility contrasted with rice land (1.11.48) -- potatoes could regulate rents because the land is convertible. -- Smith's comparative nutrition analysis of oats vs. wheat vs. potatoes is empirical but reflects 18th-century prejudices about Scottish and Irish peoples. -- The observation about Irish laborers in London reflects migration patterns driven by poverty. -- The passage about prostitution is characteristically blunt for Smith's era.

refashioned: Potatoes are difficult to preserve throughout the year and impossible to store for two or three years the way corn can be.
