The fear of being unable to sell them before they rot discourages their cultivation and is perhaps the main obstacle preventing potatoes from ever becoming, in any large country, the principal food of all classes of people, the way bread is now.
elegant: Potatoes cannot be stored like grain -- they rot within a year. This perishability discourages large-scale cultivation and is the chief barrier to potatoes ever replacing bread as the universal staple food.
summary: The potato's inability to be stored long-term like grain is its critical disadvantage and the main reason it is unlikely to become the universal staple food.
distilled: Potatoes' perishability prevents them from replacing grain as the universal staple despite their superior per-acre yield.
notes: Storage as economic constraint -- perishability limits market reach and risk management. -- Contrast with corn/grain which can be stored for years, enabling inter-year price stabilization. -- This limitation proved catastrophic in the Irish Famine (1845-52) when blight destroyed the crop with no stored reserves. -- Completes the potato analysis begun in 1.11.49-50.

refashioned:
Food for human consumption seems to be the only product of land that always and necessarily yields some rent to the landlord. Other types of produce sometimes do and sometimes do not, depending on the circumstances.

After food, clothing and shelter are the two greatest needs of humankind.
elegant: Human food is the only land product that always yields rent. Other products may or may not, depending on circumstances. After food, clothing and shelter are humanity's two greatest needs.
summary: Food is the only land product that invariably generates rent for the landlord. Clothing and shelter, while essential, do not always command rent and constitute humanity's next most important needs after food.
distilled: Human food is the sole product of land that always and necessarily affords rent; clothing and shelter are the next greatest human needs.
notes: Pivotal transitional paragraph -- concludes Part I (rent from food) and introduces Part II (rent from non-food produce: clothing and lodging materials). -- Establishes the hierarchy of human needs: food, then clothing and shelter. -- 'Always and necessarily' distinguishes food-land rent from all other land rents, which are conditional. -- Cross-reference 1.11.44 on food-land rent as the regulator.

refashioned: In its original uncultivated state, land can supply materials for clothing and shelter to far more people than it can feed. In its improved state, it can sometimes feed more people than it can supply with those materials -- at least in the forms people want and are willing to pay for. In the first state, therefore, there is always a surplus of these materials, which are often worth little or nothing. In the second state, there is frequently a shortage, which drives up their value. In the primitive state, much of the material is discarded as useless, and the price of what is used covers only the labor and expense of preparing it -- yielding no rent to the landlord. In the improved state, everything is put to use, and demand often exceeds supply. Someone is always willing to pay more for these materials than what it costs to bring them to market. Their price can therefore always provide some rent to the landlord.
elegant: Uncultivated land provides more clothing and shelter materials than food, making these materials nearly worthless. Improved land reverses this: it feeds more people than it can supply with materials, creating scarcity that raises their value. In primitive conditions, surplus materials yield no rent; in developed conditions, demand exceeds supply and materials always afford some rent.
summary: In primitive societies, clothing and shelter materials are superabundant and nearly worthless. As land is improved, food production outpaces material supply, creating scarcity that raises material prices and generates rent for landlords.
distilled: Economic development reverses the relative scarcity of food and materials -- primitive abundance of materials gives way to scarcity that generates rent as societies advance.
notes: Fundamental observation about how development changes relative scarcity. -- In primitive economies: materials abundant, food scarce. In developed economies: food relatively abundant, materials scarce. -- This reversal drives the emergence of rent on non-food land. -- Cross-reference 1.11.54-56 for specific examples with animal skins, timber, and stone.

refashioned: The skins of large animals were the original materials for clothing. Among hunting and herding peoples, whose diet consists mainly of these animals' flesh, every person who feeds himself also obtains more clothing material than he can wear. Without foreign trade, most of these skins would be discarded as worthless. This was likely the situation among the native peoples of North America before European contact, with whom they now exchange surplus pelts for blankets, firearms, and brandy -- giving the skins some value. In today's commercial world, even the most remote nations with established property rights have some foreign trade of this kind. They find among their wealthier neighbors enough demand for their surplus clothing materials to raise prices above the cost of shipping. This demand yields some rent to the landlord. When most Highland cattle were consumed locally, hide exports were the most significant item of Highland commerce, adding something to the rent of Highland estates. English wool, which in earlier times could not be used or processed domestically, found a market in the then-wealthier and more industrious Flanders, contributing something to the rent of the land that produced it. In countries as undeveloped as England was then, or as the Scottish Highlands are now, and lacking foreign trade, clothing materials would obviously be so overabundant that much would be wasted and none would yield any rent.
elegant: Animal skins were humanity's first clothing. Among hunting peoples, each person who feeds himself produces more skins than he can use -- without trade, most would be wasted. Before European contact, North American natives had no market for surplus pelts. Today, even remote nations find foreign demand for their materials, raising prices above transport costs and generating some rent. Highland hides and English wool found markets in wealthier neighboring countries, yielding rent that would not otherwise exist. Without foreign trade, clothing materials in undeveloped countries are too abundant to command any rent.
summary: Foreign trade transforms surplus clothing materials from waste into rent-generating commodities. Historical examples include North American pelts traded with Europeans, Highland cattle hides, and English wool exported to Flanders.
distilled: Foreign commerce gives value to surplus clothing materials that would otherwise be worthless, enabling even undeveloped regions to earn rent from their exports.
notes: Trade as the creator of value for surplus materials -- without markets, abundance equals worthlessness. -- Historical examples span from pre-contact North America to medieval England. -- Highland cattle hides and English wool illustrate how export demand generates landlord rent. -- Cross-reference 1.11.53 on the reversal of material abundance as economies develop. -- The exchange of pelts for 'blankets, fire-arms, and brandy' reflects colonial trade dynamics.

refashioned: Building materials cannot always be transported as far as clothing materials and do not as easily become objects of foreign trade. When they are overabundant in the country that produces them, they frequently remain worthless to the landlord, even in today's commercial world. A good stone quarry near London would command a considerable rent. In many parts of Scotland and Wales, quarries yield none. Timber for construction is highly valuable in a populous, well-cultivated country, and the land producing it earns a significant rent. But in many parts of North America, a landlord would be grateful to anyone who would clear away most of his large trees. In some parts of the Scottish Highlands, bark is the only part of the wood that can be sent to market due to the lack of roads and waterways; the timber itself is left to rot on the ground. When building materials are this overabundant, whatever is used is worth only the labor and expense of preparing it, yielding no rent to the landlord, who generally gives access to anyone who asks. However, demand from wealthier nations can sometimes enable him to earn a rent. The paving of London's streets has allowed owners of barren rocks on Scotland's coast to earn rent from what previously generated none. The forests of Norway and the Baltic coasts find markets in many parts of Britain that they could not find domestically, thereby yielding some rent to their owners.
elegant: Building materials are harder to transport than clothing materials and less suited to foreign trade. When overabundant locally, they often yield no rent -- a quarry near London commands high rent while Scottish quarries yield none; American landlords would pay to have trees removed. In the Highlands, only bark can reach market while timber rots. But demand from wealthier regions can create value: London's paving created rent for barren Scottish coastal rocks, and Norwegian timber finds profitable markets in Britain.
summary: Building materials, being costly to transport, only generate rent when local or accessible demand exists. A quarry near London is valuable while remote ones are worthless. Foreign demand from wealthier nations can transform previously valueless materials into rent-producing assets.
distilled: Building materials yield rent only when accessible demand exists -- proximity to markets and transport infrastructure determine whether abundant resources are valuable or worthless.
notes: Transport costs as the key variable for building materials vs. clothing materials. -- Location theory: the same resource (stone, timber) has vastly different values depending on proximity to demand. -- London paving creating Scottish coastal rents is a vivid example of derived demand across regions. -- Norwegian/Baltic timber trade to Britain illustrates how foreign commerce extends the margin of rent-bearing land. -- Cross-reference 1.11.54 on clothing materials and foreign trade.

refashioned: Countries are populous not in proportion to the number of people their land can clothe and shelter, but in proportion to the number it can feed. When food is available, finding adequate clothing and shelter is easy. But even when clothing and shelter are at hand, finding food can be difficult. In some parts of the British territories, what passes for a house can be built with a single day's labor by one person. The simplest clothing -- animal skins -- requires somewhat more labor to prepare, though not a great deal. Among primitive peoples, perhaps a hundredth part of the year's total labor suffices to provide the clothing and shelter that satisfy most of the population. All the remaining ninety-nine hundredths are often barely enough to provide food.
elegant: Population depends on food supply, not on the availability of clothing or shelter. Food is the binding constraint: when food is secured, clothing and shelter follow easily. Among primitive peoples, perhaps one percent of total labor provides adequate clothing and shelter, while the remaining ninety-nine percent barely suffices to provide food.
summary: Population is limited by food supply, not by clothing or shelter availability. In primitive societies, only about one percent of labor goes to clothing and shelter while nearly all the rest is devoted to food production.
distilled: Food supply, not clothing or shelter, is the binding constraint on population -- primitive societies devote nearly all labor to producing food.
notes: Food as the ultimate population constraint -- anticipates Malthusian population theory. -- The 99:1 labor ratio between food and shelter/clothing in primitive societies quantifies the primacy of food. -- 'A house may be built by one day's labour' -- illustrates extreme simplicity of shelter in undeveloped regions. -- Cross-reference 1.11.52 on food as the only product that always yields rent, and 1.11.57-58 on how agricultural improvement frees labor for other purposes.

refashioned: But when land improvement and cultivation enable one family's labor to produce enough food for two families, half of society's labor becomes sufficient to feed everyone. The other half -- or at least most of it -- can then be directed toward providing other things, satisfying the additional wants and desires of humankind. Clothing, shelter, household furniture, and what is called equipage are the main objects of these wants and desires. The rich person consumes no more food than his poor neighbor. The food may differ greatly in quality, requiring more labor and skill to select and prepare, but in quantity it is nearly the same.
elegant: When agricultural improvement lets one family feed two, half of society can turn to other work -- producing clothing, shelter, furniture, and luxuries. The rich consume no more food in quantity than the poor; quality may differ, but the stomach's capacity is the same.
summary: Agricultural productivity gains free labor for non-food production. Once one family can feed two, half of society can produce clothing, shelter, furniture, and luxuries. The rich eat no more food in quantity than the poor.
distilled: Agricultural improvement that doubles food output per worker frees half of society to produce clothing, shelter, furniture, and luxuries.
notes: Division of labor enabled by agricultural surplus -- the foundation of economic development. -- The observation that the rich consume no more food in quantity is crucial: the stomach sets a natural limit on food demand, but no such limit exists for other goods (see 1.11.58). -- Cross-reference 1.8 on wages and 1.11.56 on food as the binding constraint. -- Anticipates modern development economics on structural transformation from agriculture to industry.

refashioned: But compare the spacious palace and vast wardrobe of the wealthy person with the hovel and few rags of the poor, and you will see that the difference in their clothing, shelter, and household goods is almost as great in quantity as it is in quality. The desire for food is limited in every person by the small capacity of the human stomach, but the desire for comforts and ornaments in buildings, clothing, carriages, and household furnishings seems to have no limit whatsoever. Those who command more food than they can consume are therefore always willing to exchange the surplus -- or its price -- for gratifications of this other kind. Whatever exceeds the limited appetite for food is given over to desires that seem entirely boundless.
elegant: The gap between rich and poor in clothing, housing, and furnishings is as vast in quantity as in quality. The stomach limits food consumption, but desire for material comforts and ornaments has no boundary. Those with surplus food willingly exchange it for these unlimited wants -- what satisfies the finite appetite for food is traded to feed desires that are effectively endless.
summary: While food consumption is naturally limited by the stomach, desire for clothing, housing, and furnishings is boundless. The wealthy exchange their food surplus for these unlimited material wants, driving demand for non-food goods.
distilled: The stomach limits food consumption, but desire for material comforts is boundless -- surplus food is always exchanged for goods that satisfy these unlimited wants.
notes: Critical insight: food demand is naturally bounded; demand for everything else is not. -- This asymmetry drives economic development -- surplus food becomes the engine for all other production. -- 'The parade of riches' theme recurs in 1.11.78 regarding precious metals. -- Cross-reference 1.11.57 on agricultural surplus freeing labor, and 1.11.59 on how the poor serve the rich's unlimited desires. -- Anticipates modern consumer theory and the concept of diminishing marginal utility for necessities vs. luxuries.

refashioned: The poor, to obtain food, exert themselves to gratify the tastes of the rich. To secure their livelihood more reliably, they compete with one another in the cheapness and quality of their work. The number of workers grows with the increasing quantity of food -- that is, with the progressive improvement of the land. And because the nature of their occupations allows for extreme subdivision of labor, the quantity of materials they can process increases in a far greater proportion than their numbers. This generates demand for every kind of material that human ingenuity can put to use, whether practically or decoratively, in construction, clothing, carriages, or household furnishings -- including the minerals and fossils found deep in the earth, the precious metals, and the precious stones.
elegant: The poor labor to gratify the rich in exchange for food, competing to offer cheaper and better work. As food supply and population grow, the division of labor multiplies output far beyond the increase in workers. This creates demand for every material human invention can employ -- minerals, precious metals, precious stones -- for building, clothing, and furnishing.
summary: Workers compete to serve the rich's desires in exchange for food. As agricultural improvement increases population, division of labor multiplies output far beyond worker numbers, generating demand for all materials including precious metals and stones.
distilled: Competition among workers to serve the rich, amplified by division of labor, generates ever-expanding demand for every material resource including precious metals and stones.
notes: Links division of labor (Chapter 1.1) to demand for raw materials -- the causal chain runs: agricultural surplus -> population growth -> division of labor -> multiplied output -> demand for all materials. -- 'Fossils and minerals contained in the bowels of the earth' transitions to Part II's discussion of mining rents. -- Cross-reference 1.1 on division of labor, 1.11.57-58 on surplus food driving non-food demand.

refashioned:
Food is thus not only the original source of rent, but every other product of land that eventually yields rent derives that portion of its value from improvements in agricultural productivity -- the increased power of labor to produce food through better cultivation of the land.

However, these other products of land do not always yield rent. Even in developed and cultivated countries, the demand for them is not always sufficient to command a price above what is needed to cover labor costs and replace the invested capital with its ordinary profits. Whether demand reaches that level depends on varying circumstances.
elegant: Food is the original source of all rent. Every other land product that yields rent derives its value from agricultural improvement -- the increased power of labor to produce food. Yet these non-food products do not always yield rent; even in developed countries, demand may not exceed the cost of labor and capital with ordinary profits. Whether it does depends on circumstances.
summary: Food is the fundamental source of all rent. Non-food land products derive their rent-generating capacity from agricultural productivity gains, but unlike food, they do not always command prices high enough to yield rent.
distilled: All rent ultimately traces back to food production, though non-food land products yield rent only when demand exceeds the costs of labor and capital.
notes: Summary statement linking Parts I and II of Chapter 11. -- Food as the ultimate source of all rent -- even mining and quarrying rents depend on agricultural surplus creating demand. -- Conditional vs. unconditional rent: food always yields rent; everything else is contingent on demand. -- Transitions to specific analysis of coal mines (1.11.61-67) and metal mines (1.11.68-81).

refashioned:
Whether a coal mine can yield any rent depends partly on its fertility and partly on its location.

A mine of any kind may be called fertile or barren depending on whether the quantity of mineral that a given amount of labor can extract from it is greater or less than what the same amount of labor could extract from most other mines of the same type.
elegant: A coal mine's ability to yield rent depends on its fertility and its location. A mine is 'fertile' if a given amount of labor extracts more mineral from it than from most other mines of the same kind; otherwise it is 'barren.'
summary: Coal mine rent depends on two factors: fertility (output per unit of labor relative to other mines) and location (access to markets).
distilled: A coal mine yields rent based on its relative fertility -- output per unit of labor compared to other mines -- and its proximity to markets.
notes: Begins the analysis of mining rents. -- Fertility defined in relative terms: output per unit of labor compared to other mines, not absolute output. -- Two determinants: fertility and situation (location) -- the relative importance of each differs for coal vs. metals (see 1.11.68). -- Cross-reference 1.11.62-63 for examples of mines that fail on each criterion.

refashioned:
Some coal mines, despite being well-located, cannot be operated because they are too barren. Their output does not cover expenses, so they yield neither profit nor rent.

Other mines produce just enough to cover labor costs and replace the invested capital with its ordinary profits. These yield some profit to the mine operator but no rent to the landowner. Only the landowner himself can operate such mines profitably, since he earns the ordinary return on his own capital without having to pay rent to anyone. Many coal mines in Scotland are worked this way and can be worked in no other. The landowner will not let anyone else operate them without paying rent, and no one can afford to pay any.
elegant: Some well-located coal mines are too barren to cover expenses -- they yield neither profit nor rent. Others barely cover costs and capital replacement, yielding profit to the operator but no rent. Only the landowner can work these, since he pays no rent to himself. Many Scottish mines operate this way: the landowner demands rent from any other operator, but no one can afford to pay it.
summary: Barren coal mines cannot cover costs regardless of location. Marginal mines yield only enough for the operator's profit but no rent, so only the landowner himself can profitably work them -- as is common in Scotland.
distilled: Marginal coal mines yield profit but no rent, and can only be worked by the landowner himself since no tenant can afford to pay rent.
notes: Marginal mine concept -- the mine that earns only ordinary profit and no rent. -- Landlord as residual operator: when no tenant can afford rent, the landlord must operate the mine himself or leave it idle. -- Scottish coal mines as empirical example. -- Cross-reference 1.11.61 on fertility vs. situation, and 1.11.63 on fertile mines that fail due to location.

refashioned: Other coal mines in the same country are sufficiently fertile but cannot be operated because of their location. They could produce enough mineral to cover working expenses using ordinary or even less-than-ordinary labor, but in an inland area that is thinly populated and lacks good roads or water transport, this quantity simply could not be sold.
elegant: Some fertile coal mines cannot operate because they are too remote. Though they could produce mineral cheaply enough, in thinly populated inland areas without roads or water transport, there is simply no market for the output.
summary: Fertile coal mines in remote inland locations without adequate transportation cannot operate profitably because their output cannot reach a market.
distilled: Even fertile mines are worthless without transportation infrastructure to connect them to markets.
notes: Location/transportation as binding constraint -- fertility alone is insufficient without market access. -- Complements 1.11.62 where barrenness was the constraint despite good location. -- Infrastructure (roads, waterways) as determinant of economic viability. -- Cross-reference 1.11.55 on building materials and transport costs, and 1.11.68 on how metals differ because they can bear long-distance transport.

refashioned:
Coal is a less pleasant fuel than wood and is said to be less healthful as well. The cost of coal where it is consumed must therefore generally be somewhat lower than the cost of wood.

The price of wood varies with the state of agriculture in much the same way and for the same reasons as the price of cattle. In a country's early stages, most of the land is covered with forest, which is a mere nuisance to the landlord, who would happily give it away to anyone who would cut it. As agriculture advances, the woods are partly cleared by the spread of tillage and partly decay because of increasing cattle herds. Cattle, though they do not multiply as rapidly as corn -- which is entirely the product of human effort -- do increase under human care. People store up feed in times of plenty for seasons of scarcity, provide more food year-round than nature offers, and destroy the cattle's natural predators. Large herds wandering through the woods do not destroy old trees but prevent young ones from growing, so that over a century or two the entire forest is ruined. Wood then becomes scarce and its price rises. It yields a good rent, and the landlord sometimes finds that his best land cannot be employed more profitably than in growing timber, where the size of the profit often compensates for the long wait for returns. This appears to be the current situation in several parts of Britain, where the profit from planting matches that of corn or pasture. The landlord's advantage from planting can never long exceed the rent that corn or pasture would yield, and in an inland, well-cultivated country it will often come close to that rent. On the well-developed coast, however, where coal is conveniently available as fuel, it may sometimes be cheaper to import construction timber from less-developed foreign countries than to grow it domestically. In Edinburgh's New Town, built in recent years, there is perhaps not a single piece of Scottish timber.
elegant: Coal is less pleasant and less healthful than wood, so it must be somewhat cheaper. Wood prices follow the same pattern as cattle prices through agricultural development. In primitive times, forests are worthless nuisances. As agriculture and cattle herds expand, trees are cleared and new growth is prevented -- eventually making wood scarce and valuable. The resulting high timber rents sometimes match corn or pasture returns, though they cannot long exceed them. On developed coasts with cheap coal, imported foreign timber may be cheaper than domestic -- Edinburgh's New Town contains virtually no Scottish timber.
summary: Coal must be cheaper than wood since it is less agreeable. Wood progresses from worthless abundance in primitive times to profitable scarcity as agriculture and livestock destroy forests. Timber rents eventually match corn-land returns, though coastal areas may import cheaper foreign timber.
distilled: Agricultural development transforms wood from a worthless surplus into a scarce, rent-bearing commodity, though coastal regions with coal access may find imported timber cheaper than domestic.
notes: Long developmental narrative: forest -> clearance by agriculture and cattle -> timber scarcity -> rising rent. -- Cattle herds as unintentional deforesters -- preventing regeneration over one to two centuries. -- Timber rent converges to corn/pasture rent in equilibrium (opportunity cost). -- Edinburgh's New Town as example of import substitution on developed coasts. -- Cross-reference 1.11.65 on coal-wood price relationships and 1.11.55 on building material transport costs.

refashioned: Whatever the price of wood, if the cost of coal makes a coal fire about equal in expense to a wood fire, we can be sure that coal has reached its highest possible price in that place. This appears to be the case in some inland parts of England, particularly in Oxfordshire, where it is common even in ordinary households to burn a mix of coal and wood, suggesting the cost difference between the two fuels cannot be very large. In coal-producing regions, coal is everywhere well below this maximum price. If it were not, coal could not bear the expense of long-distance transport by land or water. Only a small quantity could be sold, and the mine owners and operators find it more profitable to sell large quantities at a price somewhat above the minimum than small quantities at the maximum price. Moreover, the most fertile coal mine in a district sets the price for all neighboring mines. Both the mine owner and operator discover that they can earn greater rent and profit by slightly undercutting all their competitors. Their neighbors are soon forced to match this lower price, even though they cannot as easily afford it, and it always reduces -- sometimes eliminates entirely -- both their rent and their profit. Some operations are abandoned altogether, and others can no longer yield any rent and can only be worked by their owners.
elegant: When coal costs as much as wood for the same heat, coal has reached its ceiling price. In coal regions, prices stay well below this -- otherwise coal could not bear transport costs. Mine owners prefer selling large volumes at moderate prices over small volumes at maximum prices. The most fertile mine sets prices for all neighbors by undercutting competitors. Neighbors must match or lose business, often sacrificing rent and profit entirely -- some mines are abandoned, others can only be worked by their owners.
summary: Coal's maximum price equals the cost of equivalent wood fuel. In practice, coal regions price well below this to enable long-distance sales. The most fertile mine acts as price-setter, forcing competitors to match lower prices that often eliminate their rent and profit.
distilled: Coal's price ceiling is the cost of equivalent wood fuel, while its market price is set by the most fertile mine's ability to undercut all competitors.
notes: Price ceiling concept: coal price bounded by the cost of the substitute (wood). -- Price-setting by the lowest-cost producer -- the most fertile mine determines market price, forcing higher-cost competitors out. -- Volume vs. margin tradeoff: selling large quantities at moderate prices beats small quantities at high prices. -- Oxfordshire coal-wood mixing as empirical evidence of price convergence. -- Cross-reference 1.11.62-63 on marginal mines and 1.11.64 on coal vs. wood.

refashioned: The lowest price at which coal can be sold for any extended period, like that of all other goods, is the price just sufficient to replace the invested capital along with its ordinary profits. At a coal mine where the landlord cannot earn any rent and must either work it himself or abandon it entirely, the price of coal must generally hover near this minimum.
elegant: Coal's long-run minimum price, like that of any commodity, must cover capital costs plus ordinary profit. At mines yielding no rent -- which the landlord must work himself or abandon -- coal prices settle near this floor.
summary: The minimum sustainable coal price covers capital replacement and ordinary profit. Mines yielding no rent set this floor price, as the landlord must operate them himself or leave them idle.
distilled: Coal's long-run price floor is the cost of capital replacement plus ordinary profit, observed at mines that yield no rent.
notes: Natural price floor -- the minimum price for sustained production, equal to costs plus ordinary profit. -- Parallels the 'natural price' concept from 1.7. -- Rent-free mines define the price floor just as marginal land defines the floor in agricultural rent theory. -- Cross-reference 1.11.62 on marginal Scottish mines and 1.11.65 on the price ceiling.

refashioned: Rent, even where coal does yield some, generally makes up a smaller share of the price than it does for most other raw products of land. The rent of an above-ground estate typically amounts to about a third of the gross produce and is usually a fixed amount independent of annual crop variations. In coal mines, a fifth of the gross produce is a very high rent, a tenth is the common rate, and it is seldom a fixed amount but rather depends on fluctuations in output. These fluctuations are so significant that in a country where thirty years' purchase is considered a reasonable price for a landed estate, ten years' purchase is regarded as a good price for a coal mine.
elegant: Rent takes a smaller share of coal's price than of most other raw produce. Surface land typically yields rent of one-third of gross produce at a fixed rate. Coal mine rent is commonly one-tenth, rarely exceeds one-fifth, and fluctuates with unpredictable output. This volatility explains why coal mines sell for just ten years' purchase versus thirty for landed estates.
summary: Coal mine rent is proportionally smaller and more volatile than agricultural rent -- typically one-tenth versus one-third of gross produce. This instability means coal mines are valued at only ten years' purchase compared to thirty for surface land.
distilled: Coal mine rent is smaller (one-tenth vs. one-third) and more volatile than agricultural rent, making mines worth far less per unit of annual income than surface land.
notes: Rent share comparison: coal (1/10 to 1/5) vs. agriculture (1/3). -- Volatility discount: uncertain mine output vs. relatively predictable crop yields. -- Capitalization rate difference: 10 years' purchase for mines vs. 30 for land reflects the risk premium. -- Cross-reference 1.11.71-72 on tin and silver mine rents for further comparison.

refashioned: The value of a coal mine to its owner depends as much on its location as on its fertility. For a metallic mine, fertility matters more and location matters less. The coarser metals, and especially the precious metals, are so valuable once separated from the ore that they can generally absorb the cost of very long overland journeys and the most distant sea voyages. Their market is not limited to neighboring countries but extends to the entire world. Japanese copper is traded in Europe. Spanish iron reaches Chile and Peru. Peruvian silver finds its way not only to Europe but onward from Europe to China.
elegant: Coal mine value depends equally on location and fertility, but for metal mines, fertility dominates. Refined metals are valuable enough to bear long-distance transport by land and sea, giving them a worldwide market. Japanese copper trades in Europe, Spanish iron reaches South America, and Peruvian silver flows to Europe and onward to China.
summary: Coal mines depend heavily on location because coal is costly to transport, but metal mines depend more on fertility because refined metals are valuable enough to bear worldwide shipping costs.
distilled: Coal mine value depends on location; metal mine value depends on fertility -- because metals are valuable enough to bear global transport costs while coal is not.
notes: Key distinction between coal and metal economics: transport cost relative to value. -- Coal markets are local; metal markets are global. -- Global commodity flows: Japan -> Europe (copper), Spain -> South America (iron), Peru -> Europe -> China (silver). -- This distinction determines whether rent depends on relative or absolute fertility. -- Cross-reference 1.11.61 on coal mine determinants and 1.11.69-70 on how global metal markets affect pricing.

refashioned: The price of coal in Westmoreland or Shropshire has little effect on coal prices in Newcastle, and the price of coal in the Lyonnais has no effect whatsoever. The output of such distant coal mines can never be brought into competition with one another. But the output of the most distant metallic mines frequently can be, and commonly is, brought into direct competition.
elegant: Distant coal mines never compete -- Westmoreland coal has no effect on Newcastle prices, nor Lyonnais coal on either. But distant metal mines routinely compete with each other in global markets.
summary: Coal markets are strictly local -- distant mines never compete with each other. Metal markets are global, with mines across the world in direct competition.
distilled: Coal markets are local and non-competing; metal markets are global and directly competitive across vast distances.
notes: Local vs. global market structure determined by transport cost relative to value. -- Specific examples: Westmoreland, Shropshire, Newcastle (English coal regions); Lyonnais (French coal region). -- This local isolation of coal markets contrasts sharply with the global integration of metal markets described in 1.11.68 and 1.11.70.

refashioned: The price of the coarser metals, and even more so the precious metals, at the world's most fertile mines must therefore affect prices at every other mine. The price of Japanese copper has some influence on copper prices at European mines. The price of Peruvian silver -- the quantity of labor or other goods it can buy there -- has some influence on silver prices not only at European silver mines but also at those in China. After the discovery of the Peruvian mines, most European silver mines were abandoned. Silver's value had fallen so much that their output could no longer cover the cost of working them or replace, at a profit, the food, clothing, shelter, and other necessities consumed in operations. The same happened to the mines of Cuba and Hispaniola, and even to Peru's older mines after the discovery of those at Potosi. Since the price of every metal at every mine is thus regulated to some degree by its price at the world's most fertile active mine, the price at most mines can do little more than cover working costs and can rarely yield much rent to the landlord. At most mines, rent accounts for only a small share of the price of the coarser metals and an even smaller share for the precious metals. Labor and profit make up the bulk of both.
elegant: The world's most fertile mine sets metal prices globally. Japanese copper prices affect European mines; Peruvian silver prices reach Europe and China. After Peru's mines opened, most European silver mines were abandoned -- silver's fallen value could not cover their costs. Cuba, Hispaniola, and even Peru's older mines suffered the same fate when Potosi was discovered. Since the most fertile mine regulates all others, most mines barely cover costs. Rent is a small share of coarse metal prices and even smaller for precious metals -- labor and profit dominate.
summary: The world's most fertile mine sets global metal prices, often driving higher-cost mines out of business. After the Peruvian discoveries, most European silver mines were abandoned. At most mines, rent is negligible -- labor and profit constitute the bulk of metal prices.
distilled: Global metal prices are set by the most fertile mine in the world, leaving most other mines barely able to cover costs and yielding little or no rent.
notes: Global price-setting by the most fertile producer -- the marginal mine theory applied worldwide. -- Historical sequence: European mines -> Peruvian mines -> Potosi discovery, each wave rendering previous mines unprofitable. -- Rent as a residual: when the global price leader sets low prices, rent is squeezed out at all other mines. -- Cross-reference 1.11.65 on coal price-setting by the most fertile mine (local), now extended globally for metals. -- Cross-reference 1.11.80-81 on how this affects mine valuation.

refashioned: According to the Reverend Mr. Borlase, vice-warden of the stannaries, a sixth of the gross produce may be taken as the average rent of the tin mines of Cornwall -- the most fertile in the known world. Some yield more and some less. A sixth of the gross produce is also the rent at several very fertile lead mines in Scotland.
elegant: Cornwall's tin mines -- the world's most fertile -- yield an average rent of one-sixth of gross produce, according to Reverend Borlase. Several fertile Scottish lead mines yield the same proportion.
summary: The world's most fertile tin mines in Cornwall yield an average rent of one-sixth of gross produce, matching the rate at some fertile Scottish lead mines.
distilled: Cornwall's world-leading tin mines and some Scottish lead mines yield rent of about one-sixth of gross produce.
notes: Empirical data point: tin mine rent at 1/6 of gross produce -- compare to coal at 1/10 (1.11.67) and agricultural land at 1/3. -- Reverend Borlase as source -- Smith's careful citation of authorities. -- Stannaries: the tin mining districts of Cornwall and Devon, with their own courts and regulations. -- Cross-reference 1.11.72 for comparison with Peruvian silver mine rents.

refashioned: In the silver mines of Peru, according to Frezier and Ulloa, the mine owner frequently demands nothing from the operator except that the ore be ground at his mill, paying the standard milling fee. Until 1736, the Spanish king's tax amounted to one-fifth of the refined silver, which until then could be considered the effective rent of most Peruvian silver mines -- the richest known in the world. Without this tax, that fifth would naturally have gone to the landowner, and many mines that could not bear the tax would have been workable. The Duke of Cornwall's tax on tin supposedly exceeds five percent, or one-twentieth of the value, and that proportion would also naturally belong to the mine owner if tin were duty-free. Adding one-twentieth to one-sixth, we find that the total average rent of Cornwall's tin mines was to that of Peru's silver mines as thirteen to twelve. But Peru's silver mines can no longer even pay that low rent, and in 1736 the silver tax was cut from one-fifth to one-tenth. Even this reduced silver tax tempts more smuggling than the one-twentieth tax on tin, and smuggling is naturally much easier with a precious metal than with a bulky commodity. The Spanish king's tax is said to be very poorly collected, while the Duke of Cornwall's is very well collected. Rent therefore probably represents a larger share of tin's price at the most fertile tin mines than silver's price at the most fertile silver mines in the world. After replacing the capital invested in working these different mines along with its ordinary profits, the residual going to the mine owner is greater for the coarser metal than for the precious one.
elegant: Peruvian silver mine owners often demand only that ore be milled at their facilities. Until 1736, the Spanish crown took one-fifth of refined silver -- effectively the entire rent of the world's richest silver mines. Cornwall's tin mines, adding the Duke's one-twentieth tax to the one-sixth rent, yield a combined return of thirteen-twelfths -- exceeding Peru's silver ratio of twelve-twelfths. Peru could no longer sustain even this, so the silver tax was halved in 1736. Smuggling further erodes silver revenues. Rent thus makes up a larger share of tin's price than of silver's, and after costs, mine owners retain more from coarse metals than from precious ones.
summary: Comparing the world's most fertile tin mines (Cornwall) with the richest silver mines (Peru), tin generates proportionally more rent. Peru's silver mines struggled under even reduced taxation, while Cornwall's tin mines paid taxes reliably. Coarser metals yield better returns to mine owners than precious metals.
distilled: Cornwall's tin mines yield proportionally more rent than Peru's silver mines, demonstrating that coarser metals often generate better returns to mine owners than precious ones.
notes: Detailed comparative analysis: Cornwall tin vs. Peruvian silver. -- Tax as de facto rent: the king's fifth functioned as the landlord's rent on royal mines. -- Smuggling as tax evasion -- precious metals' high value-to-bulk ratio facilitates smuggling. -- 13:12 ratio calculation comparing total rent burdens. -- 1736 tax reduction from 1/5 to 1/10 reflects Peru's declining mine profitability. -- Cross-reference 1.11.71 on tin mine rents and 1.11.73 on silver mining as a losing venture.

refashioned: Nor are the profits of silver mine operators in Peru typically very high. The same highly respected and well-informed authors tell us that anyone who undertakes to work a new mine in Peru is universally regarded as a man destined for bankruptcy and ruin, and is accordingly shunned and avoided by everyone. Mining there, it seems, is viewed the same way as here -- as a lottery where the prizes do not compensate for the losses, though the size of some prizes tempts many adventurers to throw away their fortunes in these unprofitable ventures.
elegant: Silver mine profits in Peru are rarely impressive. Anyone opening a new mine is universally regarded as destined for ruin and shunned by all. Mining is viewed as a lottery where prizes do not compensate for losses, though the allure of occasional great prizes tempts many to ruin.
summary: Silver mining in Peru is widely regarded as a path to ruin. New mine operators are shunned as destined for bankruptcy, since mining functions as a lottery where the losses generally outweigh the gains.
distilled: Silver mining in Peru is considered a losing lottery -- new operators are universally expected to go bankrupt despite the occasional spectacular success.
notes: Mining as gambling -- prizes do not compensate for blanks (losses). -- Risk perception and social stigma attached to mine speculation. -- Cross-reference 1.10 on risk premiums in different occupations and the 'lottery' nature of speculative ventures. -- Frezier and Ulloa as Smith's South American sources. -- Despite poor expected returns, behavioral bias toward overweighting large prizes drives continued investment.

refashioned: Since the sovereign derives a substantial part of his revenue from silver mine output, Peruvian law gives every possible encouragement to discovering and opening new mines. Anyone who discovers a new mine may claim a section measuring 246 feet along the supposed direction of the vein and half that distance in width. The discoverer becomes the owner of this portion and can work it without paying anything to the landlord. The Duke of Cornwall's interests have produced a similar rule in that ancient duchy. On waste and unenclosed land, anyone discovering a tin mine may mark out its boundaries to a certain extent -- a process called 'bounding a mine.' The bounder becomes the actual owner and may work the mine himself or lease it to another without the landowner's consent, though a very small fee must be paid to the landowner when it is worked. In both systems, the rights of private property are sacrificed to the supposed interests of public revenue.
elegant: Since the sovereign profits from silver mining, Peruvian law maximizes discovery incentives: finders may claim 246 feet along the vein and half that in width, working it without paying the landlord. Cornwall has similar rules -- anyone discovering tin on waste land may 'bound' the mine and become its owner, bypassing the landowner. In both cases, private property rights are sacrificed to the supposed interests of public revenue.
summary: Both Peru and Cornwall grant mine discoverers ownership rights that override the landowner's claims, incentivizing mineral discovery at the expense of private property rights in the interest of public revenue.
distilled: Peru and Cornwall both sacrifice private property rights to encourage mining discovery, granting finders ownership claims that override the landowner.
notes: State incentive structure for mineral discovery -- overriding property rights to encourage exploration. -- 'Bounding a mine' -- Cornish stannary law allowing claim-staking on waste land. -- Parallel institutions across very different legal systems (Spanish colonial and English ducal). -- Smith's critique: 'sacred rights of private property sacrificed to supposed interests of public revenue.' -- Cross-reference 1.11.72 on the Duke of Cornwall's tin tax.

refashioned: The same incentives apply in Peru to discovering and working new gold mines, where the king's tax on gold amounts to only one-twentieth of the standard metal. It was formerly one-fifth, then one-tenth as with silver, but these rates proved too heavy for gold mining to bear. According to Frezier and Ulloa, while it is rare to find someone who has made a fortune from a silver mine, it is far rarer to find one who has done so from a gold mine. This one-twentieth seems to represent the entire rent paid by most gold mines in Chile and Peru. Gold is even more vulnerable to smuggling than silver, not only because of its higher value relative to its bulk but because of how nature produces it. Silver is almost never found in pure form; it is typically combined with other substances and requires a laborious, lengthy refining process that must be conducted in dedicated facilities, exposed to the inspection of royal officials. Gold, by contrast, is almost always found in its pure state -- sometimes in sizable pieces, and even when mixed in tiny particles with sand and earth, it can be separated by a quick, simple process using a small amount of mercury, performable in any private dwelling by anyone. If the king's tax on silver is poorly collected, the tax on gold is likely collected far worse, and rent must therefore constitute an even smaller portion of gold's price than of silver's.
elegant: Peru's gold mining tax is just one-twentieth -- reduced from one-fifth because gold mining could not bear more. Fortune from gold mining is even rarer than from silver. Gold is far easier to smuggle: its high value-to-bulk ratio and the fact that it is found in pure form (separable with simple mercury processing in any home) make tax evasion almost inevitable. Silver requires industrial refining under official inspection. If silver taxes are poorly collected, gold taxes must be worse, making rent an even smaller share of gold's price.
summary: Gold mining is even less profitable than silver mining, with lower tax rates reflecting the industry's inability to bear costs. Gold's ease of smuggling -- due to its pure natural form and simple processing -- means tax collection is even worse than for silver, making rent a negligible part of gold's price.
distilled: Gold mining yields even less rent than silver because gold's pure natural form and high value-to-bulk ratio make smuggling nearly inevitable, undermining tax collection.
notes: Tax incidence and evasion: gold tax reduced from 1/5 to 1/20 because mining could not bear it. -- Smuggling ease determined by physical properties: value-to-bulk ratio and processing requirements. -- Silver requires industrial refining (observable, taxable); gold requires only mercury separation (private, untaxable). -- Descending profitability hierarchy: tin > silver > gold in terms of rent share. -- Cross-reference 1.11.72 on silver mine taxation and 1.11.76-77 on precious metal price determination.

refashioned: The lowest price at which precious metals can be sold, or the smallest quantity of other goods for which they can be exchanged over any extended period, is determined by the same principles that govern the minimum price of all other commodities. The capital that must typically be invested -- the food, clothing, and shelter that must be consumed in bringing them from the mine to market -- determines this floor. The price must at minimum be enough to replace that capital along with ordinary profits.
elegant: The minimum long-run price of precious metals follows the same rule as any commodity: it must cover the costs of production -- food, clothing, shelter, and other necessities consumed in mining and transport -- plus ordinary profit on the invested capital.
summary: The floor price for precious metals, like any commodity, must cover production and transport costs plus ordinary profit on capital invested.
distilled: Precious metal prices have the same minimum as any commodity -- enough to replace production costs and earn ordinary profit.
notes: Universal price floor principle applied to precious metals -- cost of production plus ordinary profit. -- 'Natural price' concept from 1.7 applied to mining. -- The necessities consumed in production (food, clothing, shelter for miners) are the real cost basis. -- Cross-reference 1.11.66 on the identical principle for coal, and 1.11.77 on the contrasting lack of a ceiling price for precious metals.

refashioned: The highest price of precious metals, however, seems not to be determined by anything except the actual scarcity or abundance of these metals themselves. It is not capped by the price of any other commodity the way coal prices are capped by wood prices, beyond which no degree of scarcity can push them. Increase the scarcity of gold sufficiently, and the smallest fragment of it may become more valuable than a diamond and exchange for a greater quantity of other goods.
elegant: Unlike coal, whose price is capped by the cost of wood, precious metals have no ceiling price -- only their actual scarcity or abundance determines their upper limit. Make gold scarce enough and the tiniest bit may become worth more than a diamond.
summary: Precious metals have no price ceiling analogous to coal's cap at wood-equivalent cost. Their maximum price is limited only by their actual scarcity, with no substitute to bound it.
distilled: Unlike coal (capped by wood prices), precious metals have no price ceiling -- only their physical scarcity limits how valuable they can become.
notes: Asymmetric price bounds: floor set by production costs (1.11.76), but no ceiling for precious metals. -- Contrast with coal, which has both a floor (production cost) and ceiling (wood price). -- No close substitute constrains precious metal prices. -- The gold-diamond comparison anticipates the famous diamond-water paradox more fully explored elsewhere. -- Cross-reference 1.11.65 on coal's price ceiling and 1.11.78 on the sources of precious metal demand.

refashioned: Demand for precious metals arises partly from their usefulness and partly from their beauty. Except for iron, they are perhaps more useful than any other metal. Being less prone to rust and contamination, they are more easily kept clean, and utensils for the table or kitchen are often preferred in these metals for that reason -- a silver pot is cleaner than one of lead, copper, or tin, and a gold one would be cleaner still. Their main appeal, however, lies in their beauty, which makes them especially suited for ornamental use in clothing and furnishings. No paint or dye can match the splendor of gilding. Their beauty is greatly enhanced by their scarcity. For most wealthy people, the chief pleasure of being rich lies in displaying their wealth, and this display is never so complete as when they possess things that no one else can afford. In their eyes, the worth of any useful or beautiful object is greatly increased by its scarcity or by the great effort needed to acquire it in quantity -- effort that only they can afford. They will pay more for such objects than for things far more beautiful and useful but more common. These qualities of usefulness, beauty, and scarcity are the original basis for the high price of precious metals -- the large quantity of other goods for which they can be exchanged everywhere. This value existed before they were used as money and was in fact the quality that made them suitable for that purpose. Their use as money, by creating additional demand and reducing the quantity available for other uses, may have subsequently helped maintain or increase their value.
elegant: Precious metals are valued for utility (resistance to rust, cleanliness), beauty (unmatched by any dye), and scarcity. For the rich, the chief pleasure of wealth is its display, which is most complete when possessing things others cannot afford. Scarcity enhances beauty in their eyes, making them willing to pay more for rare objects than for more useful common ones. These three qualities -- utility, beauty, scarcity -- established precious metals' high value before they became money. Their monetary use then added new demand and further supported their price.
summary: Precious metals command high prices due to three qualities: practical utility (corrosion resistance), beauty (unmatched by dyes), and scarcity (which enhances perceived value among the wealthy who prize conspicuous display). This value predated and enabled their use as money.
distilled: Precious metals derive their high value from utility, beauty, and scarcity -- qualities that predated their monetary use and in fact qualified them for it.
notes: Three-part value theory for precious metals: utility, beauty, scarcity. -- Conspicuous consumption: 'the chief enjoyment of riches consists in the parade of riches' -- anticipates Veblen's Theory of the Leisure Class (1899). -- Scarcity premium: willingness to pay more for rare items than for more useful common ones. -- Metals' value predated and enabled their monetary function -- money did not create their value but amplified it. -- Cross-reference 1.5 on the origins of money, 1.11.58 on unlimited desire for non-food goods, and 1.11.79 on precious stones.

refashioned: Demand for precious stones arises entirely from their beauty. They have no practical use except as ornaments, and their beauty is greatly enhanced by their scarcity and by the difficulty and expense of extracting them from mines. Wages and profit therefore make up almost the entire price on most occasions. Rent accounts for a very small share, and frequently none at all; only the most fertile mines yield any significant rent. When the jeweler Tavernier visited the diamond mines of Golconda and Vijapur, he was told that the sovereign who owned them had ordered all mines closed except those producing the largest and finest stones. The others were apparently not worth working.
elegant: Precious stones are valued purely for beauty, enhanced by scarcity and the difficulty of extraction. Since they have no practical use, wages and profit make up almost their entire price, with rent minimal or absent. Only the richest mines yield significant rent -- Tavernier learned that India's diamond sovereign closed all mines except those yielding the largest stones, as the rest were not worth working.
summary: Precious stones derive value solely from beauty enhanced by scarcity. With no practical utility, their price consists almost entirely of wages and profit, with negligible rent. Even in India's famed diamond mines, only those producing the finest stones were kept open.
distilled: Precious stones have no utility beyond beauty, so their price is almost entirely wages and profit, with rent negligible except at the very richest mines.
notes: Pure scarcity-beauty value -- no utility component unlike precious metals (1.11.78). -- Rent nearly eliminated: wages and profit dominate precious stone prices. -- Tavernier's diamond mines of Golconda -- historical source for Indian diamond trade. -- Sovereign-ordered mine closures to maintain quality/scarcity. -- Cross-reference 1.11.78 on precious metals (which have utility + beauty + scarcity) vs. stones (beauty + scarcity only).

refashioned: Since the prices of both precious metals and precious stones are regulated worldwide by their price at the most fertile mine, the rent any mine can afford its owner is proportional not to its absolute fertility but to its relative fertility -- its superiority over other mines of the same kind. If new mines were discovered as much superior to those of Potosi as Potosi was superior to Europe's mines, silver's value might fall so far that even Potosi would no longer be worth working. Before the discovery of the Spanish West Indies, Europe's most fertile mines may have yielded as much rent as Peru's richest mines do today. Although the quantity of silver was much smaller, it could have exchanged for an equal quantity of other goods, and the owner's share could have enabled him to purchase or command an equal quantity of labor or commodities.
elegant: Since the world's most fertile mine sets global prices, a mine's rent depends on its relative fertility -- its superiority over competitors -- not its absolute output. If mines far richer than Potosi were found, even Potosi would become worthless. Before America's discovery, Europe's best mines may have yielded as much real rent as Peru's do now: less silver, but exchangeable for the same quantity of goods and labor.
summary: Mine rent depends on relative fertility, not absolute output, since the world's richest mine sets global prices. New discoveries can render previously profitable mines worthless, as Potosi did to European mines. Real rent depends on purchasing power, not quantity of metal.
distilled: A mine's rent depends on its relative superiority over other mines worldwide, not its absolute output -- new discoveries can render even the richest existing mines worthless.
notes: Relative vs. absolute fertility -- the key distinction for mining economics. -- Hypothetical: mines superior to Potosi would destroy Potosi's value, just as Potosi destroyed European mines' value. -- Real vs. nominal rent: pre-discovery European mines may have yielded equal real rent despite producing less silver. -- This principle does not apply to surface land (see 1.11.82 for the contrast). -- Cross-reference 1.11.70 on global price-setting and 1.11.81 on the implications for wealth.

refashioned:
The value of both the produce and the rent -- the real income they provided to both the public and the mine owner -- might have been exactly the same.

The most abundant mines of precious metals or precious stones could add little to the world's wealth. A product whose value derives mainly from its scarcity is inevitably devalued by abundance. A set of silver plate and other frivolous ornaments for clothing and furniture could be bought for a smaller quantity of goods, and this would be the sole advantage the world could derive from such abundance.
elegant: Even with less silver, pre-discovery European mines may have provided equal real income. The most abundant mines of precious metals or gems add little to world wealth -- products valued for scarcity are devalued by abundance. The only gain from more abundant precious metals would be cheaper silverware and ornaments.
summary: Abundant precious metal discoveries add little to real wealth because these products derive their value from scarcity. Greater abundance merely cheapens luxury ornaments without increasing genuine welfare.
distilled: Abundant precious metal mines add little to world wealth because scarcity-based value is destroyed by the very abundance that new mines create.
notes: Paradox of precious metal abundance: more metal = less value per unit, with little net welfare gain. -- Contrasts sharply with agricultural land (1.11.82) where greater fertility genuinely increases wealth. -- 'Frivolous ornaments' -- Smith's dismissive attitude toward luxury spending. -- Anticipates the distinction between real wealth (goods and services) and nominal wealth (money/precious metals). -- Cross-reference 1.11.78 on scarcity as a source of value.

refashioned: The situation is entirely different for land above ground. The value of both the produce and the rent of surface land is proportional to its absolute fertility, not its relative fertility. Land that produces a certain quantity of food, clothing, and shelter materials can always feed, clothe, and house a certain number of people. Whatever share goes to the landlord, it will always give him a proportional command over those people's labor and over the goods that labor can produce. The value of the most barren land is not reduced by the proximity of the most fertile land. On the contrary, it is generally increased by it. The large population sustained by the fertile land creates a market for many products of the barren land that it could never have found among those its own produce could support.
elegant: Surface land is the opposite of mines: its value depends on absolute fertility, not relative. Land producing a given quantity of food always supports a given number of people, giving the landlord proportional command over their labor. Barren land is not devalued by fertile neighbors -- it benefits, because the larger population on fertile land creates markets for the barren land's products.
summary: Unlike mines, surface land derives value from absolute fertility. Fertile land supports more people, who create demand for nearby barren land's products. Proximity to fertile land increases, rather than decreases, the value of less productive land.
distilled: Surface land value depends on absolute fertility -- unlike mines -- and barren land benefits from fertile neighbors whose populations create new markets for its products.
notes: Critical contrast: mines (relative fertility) vs. surface land (absolute fertility). -- Fertile land creates positive externalities for barren neighbors through market demand -- a form of agglomeration benefit. -- This is why new mine discoveries hurt existing mines but new agricultural improvements help surrounding land. -- Cross-reference 1.11.80 on relative fertility in mining and 1.11.83 on how food abundance drives all other demand.

refashioned: Whatever increases the fertility of food-producing land raises not only the value of that land itself but also contributes to raising the value of many other lands by creating new demand for their products. The abundance of food that many people command beyond their own needs, as a result of agricultural improvement, is the great driver of demand for precious metals and precious stones, as well as for every other luxury in clothing, shelter, household goods, and carriages. Food is not only the principal component of the world's wealth; it is the abundance of food that gives most other forms of wealth their value. The poor inhabitants of Cuba and Hispaniola, when first discovered by the Spaniards, wore little bits of gold as ornaments in their hair and clothing. They seemed to value them as we might value attractive pebbles -- worth picking up but not worth refusing to anyone who asked for them. They gave gold freely to their new visitors without thinking they were making any remarkable gift. They were astonished at the Spaniards' desperate eagerness for these trinkets and could not imagine that any country existed where many people had such a surplus of food that, in exchange for a tiny quantity of these glittering objects, they would willingly give enough to feed a whole family for years. Had the natives understood this, the Spaniards' passion would not have surprised them.
elegant: Agricultural improvement increases not only the value of improved land but of all surrounding land by creating new demand. Food abundance drives demand for precious metals, gems, and every luxury. Food is the principal wealth, and food abundance gives all other wealth its value. Cuba's natives wore gold as worthless trinkets -- they could not comprehend that in food-abundant countries, people would trade years of sustenance for a few glittering baubles. Had they understood European food surpluses, Spanish gold-lust would have seemed perfectly rational.
summary: Agricultural improvement increases demand for all goods including precious metals and luxuries. Food abundance is the true source of all other wealth's value. The Cuban natives' bewilderment at Spanish gold-lust illustrates how food scarcity makes precious metals worthless -- only surplus food creates demand for luxury.
distilled: Food abundance is the ultimate source of all other wealth's value -- without food surpluses, even gold is merely a trinket, as the Cuban natives' indifference to it demonstrated.
notes: Food as the foundation of all value -- Smith's most powerful statement of this thesis. -- Cuban/Hispaniolan gold anecdote vividly illustrates how food scarcity eliminates demand for luxury. -- The natives' perspective inverts European values: gold is worthless where food is scarce. -- 'Had they understood this' -- Smith uses the natives' rationality to explain the apparently irrational Spanish behavior. -- Cross-reference 1.11.58 on unlimited desires beyond food, 1.11.78 on precious metal value, and 1.11.82 on absolute fertility.

refashioned: The increasing abundance of food resulting from progressive agricultural improvement must necessarily increase demand for every product of land that is not food and that can be put to practical or decorative use. Throughout the entire course of economic progress, one might therefore expect only a single pattern of change in the relative values of these two categories of products: the value of those that sometimes do and sometimes do not yield rent should steadily rise relative to those that always yield rent. As arts and industry advance, the materials of clothing and shelter, useful minerals from the earth, precious metals and precious stones should all gradually become more sought after, exchanging for ever-greater quantities of food -- in other words, they should gradually become more expensive. This has indeed been the pattern for most of these goods on most occasions, and it would have been universal if particular events had not, on some occasions, increased the supply of certain goods in an even greater proportion than demand increased.
elegant: Agricultural improvement increases demand for all non-food products. Throughout economic progress, the value of non-food goods (clothing materials, minerals, precious metals, stones) should steadily rise relative to food, exchanging for ever-greater quantities of it. This has generally been the case, except where particular events increased supply even faster than demand grew.
summary: Economic progress should cause non-food products to steadily appreciate relative to food, since agricultural improvement increases demand for all materials. This has generally been the historical pattern, with exceptions where supply increases outpaced demand.
distilled: Economic progress causes non-food goods to appreciate relative to food, unless supply increases outpace growing demand -- a pattern generally confirmed by history.
notes: General law of economic development: non-food goods should appreciate relative to food over time. -- The exception clause ('particular accidents') sets up the discussion of New World silver discoveries that disrupted this pattern. -- Unifies the chapter's themes: food as baseline, non-food value as derivative, supply shocks as disruptions. -- Cross-reference 1.11.60 on food as the source of all rent, and 1.11.85-88 on how this plays out specifically for silver.

refashioned: The value of a freestone quarry, for example, will necessarily increase with the growing development and population of the surrounding area, especially if it is the only quarry nearby. But the value of a silver mine, even with no competitor within a thousand miles, will not necessarily increase with the improvement of the country where it is located. The market for a quarry's output rarely extends more than a few miles, and demand generally matches the development and population of that small area. But the market for a silver mine may span the entire known world. Unless the world as a whole is advancing in development and population, the demand for silver might not increase at all even from the improvement of a large neighboring country. And even if the world were generally improving, the discovery of new mines far more fertile than any previously known could increase supply so much more than demand that the real price of silver might gradually fall -- that is, a given weight of silver might buy less and less labor, or exchange for smaller and smaller quantities of corn, the principal component of workers' subsistence.
elegant: A quarry's value rises with local development since its market is purely local. A silver mine's value need not, since its market is global. Unless the entire world advances, local improvement may not increase silver demand. Even with global improvement, discovery of richer mines could increase supply faster than demand, causing silver's real price to fall -- each pound buying less labor and less corn.
summary: Quarry values track local development because their markets are local. Silver mine values may not, because silver's global market means local improvement has little effect. New, richer mine discoveries can cause silver's real price to fall even as the world advances.
distilled: Local quarries benefit from local development, but silver mines face global competition where new discoveries can depress prices regardless of local or even worldwide improvement.
notes: Local vs. global market dynamics applied to the quarry-mine comparison. -- Silver price can fall despite growing demand if supply grows faster -- sets up the historical analysis of post-1570 silver depreciation. -- 'Real price' measured in labor and corn, not nominal money. -- Cross-reference 1.11.63 on local coal markets, 1.11.68-70 on global metal markets, and 1.11.86-88 on the three possible scenarios for silver values.

refashioned:
The great market for silver is the commercially developed and civilized part of the world.

If, through general progress and improvement, demand in this market should increase while supply does not keep pace, the value of silver will gradually rise relative to corn. Any given quantity of silver will exchange for more and more corn -- in other words, the average money price of corn will gradually fall.
elegant: Silver's great market is the civilized commercial world. If demand from economic progress outpaces supply, silver rises in value relative to corn -- meaning corn's money price gradually falls.
summary: If demand for silver from economic progress grows faster than supply, silver appreciates relative to corn and the money price of corn declines.
distilled: When silver demand from economic progress outpaces supply, silver appreciates and corn's money price falls -- the first of three possible scenarios.
notes: First of three scenarios for silver's value trajectory (see 1.11.87 for the second and third). -- Silver value measured against corn as the real benchmark. -- Rising silver value = falling money price of corn. -- Cross-reference 1.11.89-108 where Smith traces this scenario in the historical record (first period: 1350-1570).

refashioned:
If, on the contrary, some event causes supply to increase for many years running in a greater proportion than demand, the metal will gradually become cheaper -- in other words, the average money price of corn will, despite all improvements, gradually rise.

But if supply happens to increase in roughly the same proportion as demand, silver will continue to purchase approximately the same quantity of corn, and the average money price of corn will, despite all improvements, remain roughly the same.
elegant: If silver supply outpaces demand, silver cheapens and corn's money price rises despite all improvement. If supply and demand grow in balance, silver's purchasing power and corn's money price remain stable.
summary: If silver supply outpaces demand, corn's money price rises. If supply and demand grow proportionally, corn's money price stays stable. These complete the three possible relationships between silver supply, demand, and corn prices.
distilled: Silver supply exceeding demand raises corn's money price; balanced growth in both keeps it stable -- completing the three possible scenarios for silver's value.
notes: Second and third scenarios (of three) for silver's value. -- Together with 1.11.86, these exhaust the logical possibilities: demand > supply (silver rises), supply > demand (silver falls), supply = demand (stable). -- Cross-reference 1.11.88 confirming all three occurred historically, and 1.11.123-127 on the second period when American mines caused supply to exceed demand.

refashioned: These three scenarios seem to exhaust all the possible combinations of events that can occur as an economy progresses. And during the four centuries preceding the present, judging by what has happened in both France and Great Britain, each of these three combinations appears to have taken place in the European market, and roughly in the same order in which I have described them.
elegant: These three scenarios exhaust all possibilities. Over the preceding four centuries in France and Britain, each occurred in the European market in the order presented.
summary: The three scenarios for silver's value relative to corn exhaust all possibilities, and all three occurred sequentially in European history over the four preceding centuries.
distilled: All three possible silver-corn value relationships occurred in sequence across four centuries of European economic history.
notes: Transition to the historical 'Digression on Silver' -- the longest digression in the Wealth of Nations. -- Three periods: (1) rising silver value c.1350-1570, (2) falling silver value c.1570-1640, (3) stable silver value c.1640-present. -- Cross-reference 1.11.89 for the beginning of the first period's analysis.

refashioned:
Digression Concerning the Variations in the Value of Silver During the Last Four Centuries.

First Period. -- In 1350 and for some time before, the average price of a quarter of wheat in England appears to have been no lower than four ounces of silver (Tower weight), equivalent to about twenty shillings in present money. From that price, it seems to have fallen gradually to two ounces of silver, equivalent to about ten shillings in present money -- the price at which we find it estimated at the beginning of the sixteenth century and at which it appears to have remained until about 1570.
elegant: First Period of the silver digression: Around 1350, a quarter of wheat cost about four ounces of silver (twenty shillings present money). By the early sixteenth century, it had fallen gradually to two ounces (ten shillings), where it remained until about 1570 -- indicating that silver's value had doubled relative to corn.
summary: In the first period (1350-1570), the price of wheat fell from four ounces of silver per quarter to two ounces, indicating that silver's purchasing power approximately doubled over this period.
distilled: Between 1350 and 1570, wheat's silver price halved from four ounces to two ounces per quarter, meaning silver's real value doubled.
notes: Begins Smith's famous 'Digression on Silver' -- the longest historical excursus in the Wealth of Nations. -- First period: c.1350-1570, silver appreciating (corn becoming cheaper in silver terms). -- Tower weight: the English standard for measuring silver, predating Troy weight. -- Twenty shillings = one pound in Smith's contemporary money. -- Cross-reference 1.11.86 (scenario 1: demand outpaces supply, silver rises).

refashioned: In 1350, the twenty-fifth year of Edward III's reign, Parliament enacted what is called the Statute of Labourers. Its preamble complains bitterly about the insolence of servants who were trying to raise their wages. It therefore decrees that all servants and laborers must accept the same wages and liveries (which in those times meant provisions as well as clothing) that they had received in the king's twentieth year and the four preceding years.
