For this purpose, the wheat component of their livery was to be valued at no more than tenpence per bushel, with the master having the option to pay either in wheat or in money. Tenpence per bushel, therefore, had been considered a very moderate wheat price in the twenty-fifth year of Edward III, since a specific statute was needed to force servants to accept it in place of their usual food provisions. It had also been considered reasonable ten years earlier, in the sixteenth year of the king's reign, which is the benchmark the statute references. In the sixteenth year of Edward III, tenpence contained about half an ounce of silver (Tower weight), roughly equivalent to half a crown in present money. Four ounces of silver (Tower weight), equal to six shillings and eightpence in the money of that era and about twenty shillings in present money, must therefore have been considered a moderate price for a quarter of eight bushels.
elegant: The 1350 Statute of Labourers, enacted to suppress wage demands, capped livery-wheat at tenpence per bushel -- considered moderate since a statute was needed to enforce acceptance. Tenpence then contained half an ounce of silver, making a quarter of wheat worth four ounces of silver or about six shillings eightpence -- confirming twenty shillings present money as the moderate mid-fourteenth-century wheat price.
summary: The 1350 Statute of Labourers set livery-wheat at tenpence per bushel, confirming four ounces of silver as the moderate price for a quarter of wheat. The statute's very existence proves this was an established reasonable price, since legislation was needed to compel workers to accept it.
distilled: The 1350 Statute of Labourers confirms four ounces of silver per quarter as the moderate wheat price of mid-fourteenth-century England.
notes: The Statute of Labourers (1351) -- enacted after the Black Death labor shortage to suppress wage increases. -- Smith uses the statute as evidence of prevailing prices, since legislated prices must reflect what was considered 'moderate.' -- Livery = provisions + clothing, not just clothing. -- Silver content analysis: tenpence = half ounce silver in Edward III's coinage. -- Cross-reference 1.11.91 on this statute as price evidence vs. individual year records.

refashioned: This statute is surely better evidence of what was considered a moderate grain price in those times than the prices from particular years that historians and other writers have typically recorded precisely because they were extraordinarily high or low -- and from which it is therefore difficult to judge ordinary prices. There are, moreover, other reasons to believe that in the early fourteenth century and for some time before, the common price of wheat was no less than four ounces of silver per quarter, with other grains priced proportionally.
elegant: The statute provides better evidence of ordinary prices than the individual years historians tend to record, which are noted precisely for their extraordinary dearness or cheapness. Additional evidence confirms that wheat commonly cost no less than four ounces of silver per quarter in the early fourteenth century.
summary: Statutory price references are more reliable evidence of ordinary prices than individual year records, which historians selected for their exceptional dearness or cheapness. Multiple sources confirm four ounces of silver per quarter as the standard wheat price in the early 1300s.
distilled: Statutory references provide better evidence of ordinary grain prices than historians' records of exceptional years, confirming four ounces of silver per quarter as normal in the early fourteenth century.
notes: Methodological point about historical price evidence: statutory references reflect 'moderate' prices; chroniclers recorded extremes. -- Selection bias in historical records: extraordinary prices are more likely to be written down. -- Smith's critical approach to sources anticipates modern historical methodology. -- Cross-reference 1.11.90 on the Statute of Labourers and 1.11.92-93 for additional corroborating evidence.

refashioned: In 1309, Ralph de Born, prior of St. Augustine's, Canterbury, hosted an installation feast whose bill of fare and prices William Thorn has preserved. The feast consumed: first, fifty-three quarters of wheat at seven shillings and twopence per quarter (about twenty-one shillings and sixpence in present money); second, fifty-eight quarters of malt at six shillings per quarter (about eighteen shillings in present money); third, twenty quarters of oats at four shillings per quarter (about twelve shillings in present money). The prices of malt and oats here appear higher relative to wheat than their usual proportions.
elegant: A 1309 Canterbury feast consumed fifty-three quarters of wheat at seven shillings twopence (twenty-one shillings sixpence present), fifty-eight quarters of malt at six shillings (eighteen shillings present), and twenty quarters of oats at four shillings (twelve shillings present). Malt and oats appear relatively expensive compared to wheat.
summary: A well-documented 1309 feast at Canterbury purchased wheat at about twenty-one shillings sixpence per quarter in present money, confirming high grain prices in the early fourteenth century. Malt and oats were proportionally even more expensive.
distilled: A detailed 1309 Canterbury feast record shows wheat at about twenty-one shillings sixpence per quarter in modern money, corroborating high early fourteenth-century grain prices.
notes: Primary source evidence: Prior Ralph de Born's feast accounts preserved by William Thorn. -- Prices converted to contemporary money for comparability. -- Malt and oats disproportionately expensive relative to wheat -- possibly reflecting specific local conditions. -- Cross-reference 1.11.91 on the superiority of incidental price records over chronicles of extreme years.

refashioned:
These prices were not recorded because they were remarkably high or low but are mentioned incidentally as the actual prices paid for large quantities of grain at a feast famous for its magnificence.

In 1262, the fifty-first year of Henry III's reign, an ancient statute called the Assize of Bread and Ale was revived. The king states in the preamble that it had been made in the times of his predecessors, former kings of England, so it is probably at least as old as his grandfather Henry II's time and may date back to the Conquest. It regulates the price of bread according to wheat prices ranging from one shilling to twenty shillings per quarter in the money of that era. Statutes of this kind are generally assumed to provide equally for prices above and below the midpoint. Ten shillings, therefore -- containing six ounces of silver (Tower weight) and equal to about thirty shillings in present money -- must have been considered the middle price of wheat when the statute was first enacted and must have remained so in the fifty-first year of Henry III. We therefore cannot be far wrong in supposing that the middle price was at least one-third of the highest price regulated by the statute, or six shillings and eightpence in the money of those times, containing four ounces of silver (Tower weight).
elegant: The feast prices were incidental, not recorded for being extreme -- making them reliable evidence. An even older source, the Assize of Bread and Ale (revived 1262 but dating possibly to the Conquest), regulated bread prices for wheat from one to twenty shillings per quarter. Assuming the statute covers prices equally above and below the midpoint, ten shillings (six ounces of silver, thirty shillings present) was the presumed middle price. The minimum reasonable estimate is six shillings eightpence (four ounces of silver).
summary: The feast prices were incidental records, making them reliable. The ancient Assize of Bread and Ale, regulating prices from one to twenty shillings per quarter, implies a middle wheat price of about ten shillings (six ounces of silver), with a floor estimate of six shillings eightpence (four ounces).
distilled: Incidental feast records and the ancient Assize of Bread and Ale both confirm that wheat's ordinary price was at least four ounces of silver per quarter in medieval England.
notes: Two types of evidence: incidental price records (feast) and regulatory statutes (Assize). -- Assize of Bread and Ale -- one of England's oldest price regulations, possibly Norman-era. -- Statistical reasoning: the statute's midpoint implies the ordinary price. -- Four ounces of silver as the minimum estimate consistently emerges from all sources. -- Cross-reference 1.11.91-92 for the convergence of evidence.

refashioned:
From these various facts, we have good reason to conclude that around the middle of the fourteenth century, and for a considerable time before, the average or ordinary price of a quarter of wheat was not less than four ounces of silver (Tower weight).

From about the middle of the fourteenth century to the beginning of the sixteenth, the recognized reasonable and moderate price of wheat -- that is, the ordinary or average price -- seems to have fallen gradually to about half this amount, eventually reaching about two ounces of silver (Tower weight), equivalent to about ten shillings in present money. It appears to have remained at this level until about 1570.
elegant: Multiple sources confirm that around the mid-fourteenth century, wheat's ordinary price was at least four ounces of silver per quarter. From then until the early sixteenth century, this price gradually halved to about two ounces (ten shillings present money), where it remained until about 1570.
summary: Evidence converges on four ounces of silver per quarter as wheat's ordinary price around 1350. Over the next century and a half, this gradually halved to two ounces, remaining there until 1570 -- meaning silver's purchasing power doubled during the first period.
distilled: Wheat's ordinary price fell from four ounces of silver per quarter around 1350 to two ounces by the early 1500s, confirming that silver's value doubled during the first period.
notes: Summary conclusion for the first period's price evidence. -- Silver's purchasing power doubled between c.1350 and c.1500: four ounces -> two ounces per quarter of wheat. -- The convergence of statutory, incidental, and chronicle evidence strengthens the conclusion. -- Cross-reference 1.11.89 for the period overview and 1.11.95-99 for further corroborating evidence from specific statutes and records.

refashioned: In the household book of Henry, the fifth Earl of Northumberland, drawn up in 1512, wheat is estimated at two different prices. In one entry it appears at six shillings and eightpence per quarter, in the other at only five shillings and eightpence. In 1512, six shillings and eightpence contained only two ounces of silver (Tower weight) and was equivalent to about ten shillings in present money.
elegant: The 1512 household book of the Earl of Northumberland records wheat at six shillings eightpence and five shillings eightpence per quarter. Six shillings eightpence then contained only two ounces of silver -- about ten shillings present money -- confirming the halved price level.
summary: The Earl of Northumberland's 1512 household accounts show wheat at six shillings eightpence per quarter, containing just two ounces of silver -- confirming the halved price level from four ounces in the mid-fourteenth century.
distilled: The 1512 Northumberland household book confirms wheat at two ounces of silver per quarter, consistent with the halved price level of the first period's end.
notes: Primary source: household book of Henry Percy, 5th Earl of Northumberland -- a major source for early Tudor domestic economy. -- Two different wheat estimates in the same account suggest price variability. -- Six shillings eightpence = two ounces silver (1512 coinage), confirming the price decline from four ounces. -- Cross-reference 1.11.94 on the gradual decline and 1.11.96-98 on statutory confirmations.

refashioned: From the twenty-fifth year of Edward III to the beginning of Elizabeth's reign -- a span of more than two hundred years -- six shillings and eightpence had continued, as multiple statutes confirm, to be regarded as the moderate and reasonable price of wheat, that is, the ordinary or average price. The actual quantity of silver in that nominal sum, however, had been continually shrinking due to alterations in the coinage. But the increase in silver's value had apparently compensated for the reduction in its quantity within the same nominal amount, so that legislators did not think the change worth noticing.
elegant: For over two centuries from Edward III to Elizabeth, six shillings eightpence remained the statutory 'moderate' wheat price, confirmed by multiple statutes. Though the silver content of this nominal sum kept shrinking from coinage debasement, silver's rising value compensated -- legislators saw no need to adjust the figure.
summary: Six shillings eightpence remained the statutory moderate wheat price for over two centuries despite continuous coinage debasement, because silver's rising value offset the declining silver content of the nominal sum.
distilled: The statutory wheat price remained nominally unchanged for two centuries because silver's rising value exactly compensated for the coinage's declining silver content.
notes: Nominal stability masking real changes -- the nominal price stayed the same while both the silver content and silver's value shifted in offsetting directions. -- Coinage debasement: systematic reduction of silver in coins, a common fiscal expedient. -- Legislators' inattention to the composition of nominal prices anticipates modern debates about inflation measurement. -- Cross-reference 1.11.94 on the halving of real wheat prices and 1.11.97-98 for specific statutory examples.

refashioned: Thus in 1436 it was enacted that wheat could be exported without a license when the price was as low as six shillings and eightpence. And in 1463, it was enacted that no wheat should be imported unless the price exceeded six shillings and eightpence per quarter. The legislature had reasoned that when the price was this low, exports posed no danger, but that when it rose higher, imports should be permitted. Six shillings and eightpence at that point contained about the same quantity of silver as thirteen shillings and fourpence in present money -- one-third less than the same nominal sum had contained under Edward III. Yet it was still regarded as the moderate and reasonable price of wheat.
elegant: A 1436 statute permitted wheat exports below six shillings eightpence; a 1463 statute permitted imports above it. Legislators treated this price as the dividing line between surplus and scarcity. By then, six shillings eightpence contained only about thirteen shillings fourpence present money's worth of silver -- a third less than under Edward III -- yet it was still considered wheat's moderate price.
summary: Mid-fifteenth-century trade statutes used six shillings eightpence as the threshold between surplus and scarcity for wheat, even though the nominal sum now contained a third less silver than under Edward III, confirming silver's continued appreciation.
distilled: Fifteenth-century trade legislation maintained six shillings eightpence as the moderate wheat price despite a one-third reduction in its silver content, proving silver's rising value compensated.
notes: Export/import thresholds as price policy instruments -- exports allowed when cheap (surplus), imports when dear (scarcity). -- Silver content decline: 1/3 less silver in the same nominal sum from Edward III to mid-15th century. -- The policy logic reveals legislators' concept of 'moderate price' as a supply-demand equilibrium indicator. -- Cross-reference 1.11.96 on nominal stability with real adjustment.

refashioned: In 1554 under Philip and Mary, and again in 1558 under Elizabeth, wheat exports were prohibited whenever the price exceeded six shillings and eightpence per quarter -- which by then contained only about twopence more silver than the same nominal sum does today. But it was soon recognized that restricting exports until the price fell this low amounted to banning exports altogether. In 1562, therefore, under Elizabeth, wheat exports were permitted from certain ports whenever the price did not exceed ten shillings -- a sum containing nearly the same quantity of silver as ten shillings does now. This price had by then come to be considered the moderate and reasonable price of wheat. It matches closely the estimate in the Northumberland household book of 1512.
elegant: By the 1550s, six shillings eightpence contained almost the same silver as today. Export bans at this threshold effectively prohibited all exports, so in 1562 Elizabeth raised the limit to ten shillings -- nearly identical in silver content to modern ten shillings. This became the new 'moderate' wheat price, matching the 1512 Northumberland estimate.
summary: By Elizabeth's reign, the traditional six shillings eightpence export threshold had become unrealistically low, effectively banning all exports. The 1562 adjustment to ten shillings reflected the new moderate price, consistent with 1512 household estimates.
distilled: Elizabeth's 1562 adjustment of the wheat export threshold from six shillings eightpence to ten shillings acknowledged the new moderate price level after centuries of coinage debasement.
notes: Policy adjustment catching up with monetary reality. -- The export threshold's evolution: six shillings eightpence (Edward III) -> ten shillings (Elizabeth) reflects accumulated coinage changes. -- Near-modern silver content by 1558: the great Tudor recoinage stabilized the currency. -- Convergence with the 1512 Northumberland estimate validates both sources. -- Cross-reference 1.11.95 on the Northumberland book and 1.11.99 on French parallels.

refashioned: That in France the average grain price was similarly much lower in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries than in the two preceding centuries has been observed by both Dupre de Saint-Maur and by the elegant author of the Essay on the Policy of Grain. The price had probably fallen in the same manner across the greater part of Europe during this period.
elegant: French grain prices followed the same pattern -- much lower in the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries than in the two centuries before, as noted by Dupre de Saint-Maur and the author of the Essay on the Policy of Grain. The decline was probably Europe-wide.
summary: French grain prices followed the same declining pattern as English ones between the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, suggesting a Europe-wide increase in silver's purchasing power.
distilled: French sources confirm that grain prices fell across Europe between the fourteenth and sixteenth centuries, corroborating the continent-wide rise in silver's value.
notes: Cross-national confirmation: France shows the same pattern as England. -- Dupre de Saint-Maur: French economic historian whose price data parallels Fleetwood's for England. -- The 'elegant author' is likely Galiani or another French physiocrat-era writer. -- Europe-wide pattern suggests a systemic cause (rising silver value) rather than local factors. -- Cross-reference 1.11.94 on the English pattern and 1.11.100 on possible causes.

refashioned: This rise in silver's value relative to corn may have been caused entirely by growing demand for silver as a result of increasing economic improvement, with supply remaining constant. Or it may have been caused entirely by the gradual exhaustion of existing mines, which made them more expensive to work, while demand remained constant. Or it may have resulted from some combination of both factors. By the late fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries, most of Europe was moving toward more settled government than it had experienced for several centuries. Greater security would naturally encourage industry and improvement, and the demand for precious metals -- like demand for every other luxury -- would naturally increase with growing wealth. A larger annual output would need more coin to circulate it, and a growing number of wealthy people would want more silver plate and other ornaments. It is also reasonable to suppose that most of the mines then supplying the European market were substantially depleted and had become more costly to operate. Many had been worked since Roman times.
elegant: Silver's appreciation could stem from increased demand (economic improvement requiring more coin and plate), decreased supply (mine exhaustion raising costs), or both. By the late fifteenth century, Europe's growing political stability encouraged industry, increasing demand for all luxuries including silver. Simultaneously, European mines -- many worked since Roman times -- were likely becoming exhausted and more expensive to operate.
summary: Silver's rising value between 1350 and 1570 resulted from some combination of increasing demand (driven by economic progress and political stability) and decreasing supply (as mines worked since Roman times became depleted and costlier to operate).
distilled: Silver appreciated between 1350 and 1570 due to growing demand from European economic progress combined with declining supply from the exhaustion of mines worked since Roman times.
notes: Dual causation: demand-pull (economic growth) and supply-push (mine depletion) both contributed. -- Political stability as a precondition for economic growth -- late medieval state formation. -- Mine exhaustion as a long-run supply constraint -- some European mines had been worked for over a thousand years. -- Cross-reference 1.11.86 (scenario 1: demand outpaces supply) and 1.11.101 on the prevailing but mistaken opinion about silver's value trend.

refashioned: Most writers on the prices of commodities in ancient times, however, have held the opposite view: that from the Conquest, or perhaps from Julius Caesar's invasion, until the discovery of the American mines, silver's value was continually declining. They seem to have been led to this opinion partly by their observations on the prices of corn and other raw land products, and partly by the popular belief that since the quantity of silver naturally increases with a country's wealth, its value must fall as its quantity grows.
elegant: Most writers have held the opposite view -- that silver declined in value from the Roman invasion through to the American discoveries. This error arose from misreading grain prices and from the popular but groundless assumption that increasing national wealth necessarily increases silver quantity, which necessarily reduces its value.
summary: Most earlier writers wrongly believed silver's value continually declined from Roman times to the American discoveries, misled by faulty price observations and the incorrect assumption that growing wealth always depresses silver's value.
distilled: Earlier writers wrongly assumed silver steadily lost value from Roman times to the American discoveries, misled by flawed price evidence and a false theory linking wealth growth to silver depreciation.
notes: Smith challenges the conventional wisdom of his predecessors. -- Two sources of error: (1) misinterpretation of historical price data, (2) the fallacy that more wealth = more silver = lower silver value. -- The second error confuses two distinct causes of silver increase (see 1.11.114-115). -- Cross-reference 1.11.102-108 for Smith's detailed critique of the price evidence, and 1.11.113-116 for his refutation of the theoretical assumption.

refashioned:
Three different factors seem to have frequently misled these writers in their observations on corn prices.

First, in ancient times nearly all rents were paid in kind -- a set quantity of corn, cattle, poultry, and so forth. Sometimes, however, the landlord stipulated the right to demand either the annual payment in kind or a fixed sum of money in its place. The price at which the in-kind payment was converted to money is called in Scotland the 'conversion price.' Since the landlord always had the option of taking either the goods or the cash, the conversion price needed to be set below the average market price for the tenant's protection. In many places, accordingly, it was set at barely half the market price. This custom persists in much of Scotland for poultry and in some places for cattle. It might have continued for corn as well, had the institution of the public fiars not replaced it. These fiars are annual valuations, determined by a jury, of the average price of every type and quality of grain, based on actual market prices in each county. This institution made it safe enough for tenants, and far more convenient for landlords, to convert corn rents at the current year's fiar price rather than at a fixed amount. But writers who collected ancient corn prices seem frequently to have mistaken the conversion price for the actual market price. Fleetwood himself acknowledges on one occasion that he made this mistake. Since he wrote his book for a particular purpose, however, he waits until after citing this conversion price fifteen times before making the admission. The price in question was eight shillings per quarter of wheat. In 1423, when his citations begin, this sum contained the same quantity of silver as sixteen shillings in present money. But by 1562, where his citations end, it contained no more silver than eight shillings does today.
elegant: Three errors misled earlier writers on corn prices. First, they confused 'conversion prices' with market prices. Ancient rents were paid in kind, but landlords sometimes had the option of taking cash instead. This conversion price was deliberately set below market -- often at half -- to protect tenants. Scotland's public fiars (annual jury-assessed average prices) eventually replaced this system for corn. But historians, including Fleetwood, mistook these below-market conversion prices for true market prices. Fleetwood admits the error only after citing the same conversion price fifteen times.
summary: The first error in historical price analysis was confusing below-market 'conversion prices' (at which in-kind rents could optionally be paid in cash) with actual market prices. Even Fleetwood acknowledged making this mistake, though only belatedly.
distilled: Earlier writers mistook below-market rent conversion prices for actual market prices, systematically underestimating historical corn prices -- an error even Fleetwood eventually admitted.
notes: First of three methodological errors identified by Smith. -- Conversion price: the below-market cash equivalent of in-kind rent, deliberately set low to protect tenants. -- Scottish fiars: annual official price assessments -- an early form of price index. -- Fleetwood's delayed admission of error reveals how purpose-driven scholarship can distort evidence. -- Cross-reference 1.11.103-104 for the second error (transcription problems) and 1.11.107 for the third (extreme price years).

refashioned:
Second, these writers were misled by the careless manner in which some ancient regulatory statutes had sometimes been copied by lazy transcribers and sometimes even drafted by the legislature itself.

The ancient assize statutes appear to have always begun by setting the price of bread and ale corresponding to the lowest grain prices, then proceeded to specify what prices should be as grain costs gradually increased. But the copyists frequently transcribed only the first three or four lowest price entries, apparently thinking this was sufficient to show the proportional relationship that should hold at all higher prices as well.
elegant: Second, lazy transcribers copied only the lowest price entries from ancient assize statutes, which were structured to begin at the lowest grain prices and proceed upward. Copyists apparently thought the first few entries sufficed to show the pattern for all higher prices.
summary: The second error arose from transcribers who copied only the lowest price entries from regulatory statutes, creating a false impression that these low prices represented the full range of historical grain costs.
distilled: Lazy transcribers who copied only the lowest entries from ancient price statutes created a systematic downward bias in historical grain price records.
notes: Second methodological error: transcription bias. -- Assize statutes structured from lowest to highest prices -- scribes truncated at the low end. -- Both copyist laziness and original legislative sloppiness contributed. -- This created a systematic underestimation of the price range regulated. -- Cross-reference 1.11.104-106 for specific examples and 1.11.102 for the first error.

refashioned: Thus, in the Assize of Bread and Ale from the fifty-first year of Henry III, bread prices were regulated for wheat prices ranging from one shilling to twenty shillings per quarter in the money of those times. But in the manuscripts from which all editions of the statutes before Mr. Ruffhead's were printed, the copyists had transcribed the regulation only up to the price of twelve shillings. Several writers, misled by this incomplete transcription, quite naturally concluded that the middle price -- six shillings per quarter, equivalent to about eighteen shillings in present money -- had been the ordinary or average price of wheat at that time.
elegant: In the Henry III Assize, bread was regulated for wheat prices from one to twenty shillings per quarter. But copyists transcribed only up to twelve shillings, leading writers to calculate six shillings as the midpoint -- about eighteen shillings present money -- and mistake it for the average wheat price, when the true midpoint was ten shillings.
summary: Copyists truncated the Henry III bread assize at twelve shillings instead of twenty, causing writers to calculate the wrong midpoint (six shillings instead of ten) and systematically underestimate medieval wheat prices.
distilled: Truncated transcriptions of Henry III's bread assize led writers to calculate a false midpoint price, significantly underestimating actual medieval wheat costs.
notes: Specific example of the transcription error described in 1.11.103. -- True range: 1-20 shillings (midpoint 10s); truncated range: 1-12 shillings (midpoint 6s). -- Mr. Ruffhead's edition corrected the truncation. -- The error produced an underestimate of about 40% in the supposed average price. -- Cross-reference 1.11.93 where Smith used the correct 1-20 shilling range for his own calculation.

refashioned: In the Statute of Tumbrel and Pillory, enacted around the same time, ale prices are regulated according to every sixpence rise in barley's price, from two shillings to four shillings per quarter. However, four shillings was not meant to be the highest price barley might reach in those times. These prices were merely examples of the proportional relationship to be observed at all prices, higher or lower, as the statute's closing words make clear: 'Et sic deinceps crescetur vel diminuetur per sex denarios' -- meaning that the price of ale is to be increased or diminished by every sixpence rise or fall in barley's price. The language is quite sloppy, but the meaning is clear enough. In drafting this statute, the legislature itself seems to have been as careless as the copyists were in transcribing the other.
elegant: The Statute of Tumbrel and Pillory regulated ale prices for barley at two to four shillings per quarter -- but four shillings was not the intended maximum. The closing Latin phrase ('and so on, increasing or decreasing by sixpence') shows these were examples of proportional relationships, not endpoints. The legislature's drafting was as careless as the copyists' transcription of the bread assize.
summary: The Statute of Tumbrel and Pillory listed ale prices for barley at two to four shillings only as examples of a proportional relationship, not as the full price range. The statute's own closing phrase proves this, though the drafting was characteristically sloppy.
distilled: The Tumbrel and Pillory statute's barley prices were illustrative examples of a proportional rule, not maximum prices -- though sloppy drafting invited misinterpretation.
notes: Legislative sloppiness complementing transcriber laziness -- both sources of error in historical price records. -- Latin closing phrase proves the price range was illustrative, not exhaustive. -- Statute of Tumbrel and Pillory: regulated ale quality and pricing, with punishments (tumbrel = ducking stool, pillory = public shaming device). -- Cross-reference 1.11.103-104 on the same type of error in the bread assize.

refashioned: In an ancient manuscript of the Regiam Majestatem, an old Scottish law book, there is a bread assize regulating prices according to wheat costs ranging from tenpence to three shillings per Scottish boll, which equals about half an English quarter. Three Scottish shillings, at the time this assize was supposedly enacted, equaled about nine shillings sterling in present money. Mr. Ruddiman concluded from this that three shillings was the highest price wheat ever reached in those times, and that tenpence, a shilling, or at most two shillings were the ordinary prices. But upon examining the manuscript, it becomes clear that all these prices are merely examples of the proportional relationship between wheat and bread prices. The statute's closing words state: 'reliqua judicabis secundum praescripta, habendo respectum ad pretium bladi' -- 'You shall judge the remaining cases according to what is written above, having regard to the price of corn.'
elegant: A Scottish law book's bread assize lists wheat prices from tenpence to three shillings per boll. Ruddiman concluded three shillings was the historical maximum. But the manuscript's closing Latin -- 'judge remaining cases accordingly, having regard to the price of corn' -- proves these were proportional examples, not the full price range.
summary: A Scottish bread assize was misread by Ruddiman as showing the maximum wheat price, when its Latin closing phrase reveals the listed prices were merely proportional examples for calculating bread prices at any wheat cost.
distilled: Ruddiman misinterpreted a Scottish bread assize's example prices as maximum prices, an error revealed by the statute's own closing instruction to apply the proportions to all price levels.
notes: Scottish parallel to the English transcription errors. -- Regiam Majestatem: major medieval Scottish legal text. -- Ruddiman: Thomas Ruddiman, Scottish classical scholar and librarian. -- The Latin closing phrase is the key evidence, as with the Tumbrel and Pillory statute (1.11.105). -- Cross-reference 1.11.103-105 for the same pattern of misinterpreting example prices as actual maximum prices.

refashioned: Third, these writers seem to have been misled by the very low prices at which wheat sometimes sold in ancient times, leading them to assume that since the lowest prices were much lower than in later periods, the ordinary prices must also have been much lower. But they might have noticed that in those ancient times, the highest prices were just as far above anything seen in later periods as the lowest prices were below. In 1270, for example, Fleetwood records two wheat prices: one at four pounds sixteen shillings (equal to fourteen pounds eight shillings in present money) and another at six pounds eight shillings (equal to nineteen pounds four shillings in present money). No price from the late fifteenth or early sixteenth century comes close to such extremes. Corn prices, though always subject to variation, fluctuate most wildly in turbulent, disordered societies where interrupted trade and communication prevent the plenty of one region from relieving the scarcity of another. In the disorderly England of the Plantagenets, from about the mid-twelfth to the late fifteenth century, one district might enjoy abundance while another nearby suffered famine. If a hostile lord's lands lay between them, one could provide no help to the other. Under the vigorous rule of the Tudors, who governed England through the later fifteenth and entire sixteenth century, no baron was powerful enough to disturb the public peace.
elegant: Third, writers assumed that very low ancient wheat prices meant low average prices. But ancient highs were equally extreme: Fleetwood records 1270 wheat at fourteen to nineteen pounds present money -- far beyond anything in later centuries. Price volatility was greatest in disordered societies where trade disruptions prevented regional surpluses from relieving local famines. Under the anarchic Plantagenets, adjacent districts could experience abundance and famine simultaneously if hostile lords blocked commerce between them. Tudor stability dramatically reduced such volatility.
summary: The third error was inferring low average prices from low extremes, ignoring that ancient price highs were equally extraordinary. Medieval political disorder caused extreme price volatility by preventing interregional trade, while Tudor stability smoothed price fluctuations.
distilled: Ancient grain prices were not lower on average -- they were more volatile, with extreme highs matching extreme lows, driven by political disorder that blocked interregional trade.
notes: Third methodological error: confusing volatility with level. -- Price volatility as a function of political order and market integration. -- Plantagenet disorder vs. Tudor stability as natural experiment in institutional economics. -- 1270 wheat at 14-19 pounds present money = extreme outlier from famine conditions. -- Market integration (ability of surplus regions to supply deficit regions) as the key to price stability. -- Cross-reference 1.11.102-106 for the first two errors.

refashioned: The reader will find at this chapter's end all the wheat prices collected by Fleetwood from 1202 to 1597, converted to present money and arranged into seven twelve-year periods. Each period's average price is also given. Over this long span, Fleetwood found prices for only eighty years, leaving four years short of the final twelve-year period. I have therefore added the prices for 1598, 1599, 1600, and 1601 from Eton College records -- my only addition. The reader will see that from the early thirteenth century through the mid-sixteenth century, the average price for each twelve-year period falls gradually, and that toward the end of the sixteenth century it begins to rise again. The prices Fleetwood collected were mainly those notable for extraordinary dearness or cheapness, and I do not claim that very firm conclusions can be drawn from them. But insofar as they prove anything, they confirm the account I have been giving. Fleetwood himself, however, along with most other writers, believed that throughout this entire period silver's value was continually falling due to its increasing abundance. The corn prices he himself collected certainly do not support this view. They align perfectly with the account of Dupre de Saint-Maur and with my own analysis. Bishop Fleetwood and Dupre de Saint-Maur are the two authors who seem to have collected ancient prices with the greatest diligence and accuracy. It is somewhat curious that although their interpretations differ greatly, their facts -- at least regarding corn prices -- agree remarkably well.
elegant: Fleetwood's wheat prices from 1202-1597, organized into twelve-year averages, show gradual decline through the mid-sixteenth century, then a rise. His data (supplemented by Eton College records for 1598-1601) confirm silver's rising value during the first period, despite Fleetwood's own contrary interpretation. His prices align with Dupre de Saint-Maur's French data and with Smith's analysis. Curiously, though these two most diligent price historians reached opposite theoretical conclusions, their factual data agree remarkably.
summary: Fleetwood's wheat price data, organized into twelve-year averages, confirms a gradual decline through the mid-sixteenth century followed by a rise -- supporting Smith's account of rising then falling silver value, even though Fleetwood himself drew the opposite conclusion.
distilled: Fleetwood's own carefully collected price data contradicts his conclusion that silver was declining -- the prices confirm Smith's account of rising silver value through the mid-sixteenth century.
notes: Smith turns an opponent's evidence against his conclusion -- a characteristic rhetorical move. -- Fleetwood's data: 80 price observations over 395 years, heavily biased toward extreme years. -- Smith's only addition: four years from Eton College records. -- The Fleetwood-Dupre convergence despite differing theories is presented as particularly compelling. -- Cross-reference 1.11.89-94 for Smith's interpretation and 1.11.101 for the contrary view he is rebutting.

refashioned: It is not so much from the low price of corn, however, as from the low price of other raw produce of land that the most careful writers have inferred the great value of silver in very ancient times. Corn, it has been argued, was a kind of manufactured product and was therefore relatively more expensive in those primitive ages than most other goods -- meaning, I suppose, more expensive than unprocessed commodities like cattle, poultry, game, and the like. That these goods were proportionally much cheaper than corn in times of poverty and barbarism is undoubtedly true. But this cheapness did not result from silver being more valuable; it resulted from those commodities being less valuable. The reason was not that silver could then purchase or represent more labor, but that such goods could purchase or represent much less labor than in times of greater prosperity and development. Silver is certainly cheaper in Spanish America than in Europe -- cheaper in the producing country than in one to which it must be carried at great expense by land and sea, with freight and insurance costs. Yet, as Ulloa reports, an ox chosen from a herd of three or four hundred could recently be had at Buenos Aires for twenty-one and a half pence sterling. And according to Mr. Byron, a good horse in Santiago, Chile, cost sixteen shillings sterling. In a naturally fertile but largely uncultivated country, cattle, poultry, and game can be acquired with very little labor and therefore command very little in exchange. Their low money price is not evidence that silver is very valuable there, but that those commodities are very cheap.
elegant: The strongest argument for high ancient silver values comes not from low corn prices but from the cheapness of cattle, poultry, and game. These goods were indeed proportionally cheaper than corn in primitive times -- but this reflected their low value, not silver's high value. In undeveloped countries, such goods require little labor to produce and therefore command little in exchange. Buenos Aires oxen at twenty-one pence and Santiago horses at sixteen shillings prove the point: silver is clearly cheaper in America than Europe, yet livestock prices are extremely low because the animals cost almost nothing to produce -- not because silver buys more labor there.
summary: The cheapness of cattle and game in primitive or undeveloped societies reflects the low labor cost of producing them, not the high value of silver. South American examples (Buenos Aires oxen at twenty-one pence, Chilean horses at sixteen shillings) confirm this: silver is cheaper there than in Europe, yet livestock is even cheaper.
distilled: Low livestock prices in primitive societies reflect low production costs, not high silver value -- a crucial distinction earlier writers failed to make.
notes: Key analytical distinction: cheap commodities vs. dear silver -- earlier writers confused the two. -- Labor theory of value applied: goods requiring little labor command little value regardless of silver prices. -- South American livestock prices as evidence: silver is demonstrably cheap there (near the mines), yet livestock is cheaper still. -- Ulloa (Buenos Aires) and Byron (Santiago) as sources for colonial price data. -- Cross-reference 1.11.110-111 on labor as the real measure of value and corn as its proxy.

refashioned:
It must always be remembered that labor, not any particular commodity or set of commodities, is the real measure of the value of both silver and all other goods.

But in countries that are nearly uninhabited or only thinly populated, cattle, poultry, game, and the like, being spontaneous products of nature, are often produced in much greater quantities than the inhabitants can consume. In such conditions, supply routinely exceeds demand. In different states of society and different stages of development, therefore, such commodities will represent or be equivalent to very different quantities of labor.
elegant: Labor -- not any commodity -- is the true measure of all value, including silver's. In thinly populated countries, nature spontaneously produces cattle, poultry, and game far beyond what inhabitants can consume. With supply exceeding demand, these goods represent very different quantities of labor at different stages of development.
summary: Labor is the ultimate measure of value for all goods including silver. In sparsely populated regions, nature produces livestock and game far beyond local needs, making them represent very little labor -- explaining their cheapness without reference to silver's value.
distilled: Labor is the true measure of all value; cheap livestock in undeveloped countries reflects natural overabundance relative to population, not the high value of silver.
notes: Restatement of the labor theory of value from 1.5 applied to the silver digression. -- Natural abundance in undeveloped regions: supply exceeds demand for spontaneous products. -- The same good (an ox) represents vastly different quantities of labor in different societies. -- Cross-reference 1.5 on labor as the real measure of value and 1.11.111 on corn as a more stable value measure than livestock.

refashioned: In every state of society, at every stage of development, corn is the product of human effort. But the average output of every kind of industry is always roughly matched to average consumption -- average supply to average demand. At every different stage of development, moreover, raising equal quantities of corn on the same soil in the same climate requires, on average, roughly equal quantities of labor -- or what amounts to the same thing, roughly equal cost. The continual increase in labor productivity that comes with agricultural improvement is more or less offset by the continual increase in the price of cattle, the main tools of farming. For all these reasons, we can be confident that equal quantities of corn will, in every society and at every stage of development, more closely represent or correspond to equal quantities of labor than equal quantities of any other raw product of land. Corn, as has already been observed, is therefore a more accurate measure of value across all stages of wealth and development than any other single commodity or group of commodities. In all these different stages, therefore, we can better judge the real value of silver by comparing it with corn than with anything else.
elegant: Corn is always produced by human labor, and its average output matches average consumption at every development stage. Equal quantities of corn require roughly equal labor in any era -- productivity gains being offset by rising cattle costs. Corn therefore represents labor more consistently than any other commodity across all stages of development, making it the best measure of silver's real value.
summary: Corn is a more stable measure of value than other commodities because it always requires human labor to produce, its output matches consumption, and equal quantities require roughly equal labor across development stages due to offsetting forces.
distilled: Corn is the most reliable measure of real value across all stages of development because equal quantities consistently represent equal quantities of labor.
notes: Corn as the universal value benchmark -- the theoretical justification for using wheat prices to track silver's real value throughout the Digression. -- Key insight: productivity gains in agriculture are offset by rising input costs (cattle), keeping corn's labor cost roughly stable. -- Supply-demand equilibrium: corn output matches consumption at every stage. -- Cross-reference 1.5 on labor as the real measure of value and 1.11.112 on corn as the basis of laborer subsistence.

refashioned: Corn, or whatever else is the common staple food of the people, constitutes in every civilized country the principal part of the laborer's subsistence. As agriculture expands, every country produces a much greater quantity of vegetable food than animal food, and laborers everywhere live mainly on the cheapest and most abundant wholesome food available. Butcher's meat, except in the most prosperous countries or where labor is most highly paid, makes up only a small part of the laborer's diet; poultry an even smaller part, and game none at all. In France, and even in Scotland where labor is somewhat better paid than in France, the laboring poor seldom eat butcher's meat except on holidays and other special occasions. The money price of labor therefore depends far more on the average money price of corn -- the laborer's main sustenance -- than on that of butcher's meat or any other raw land product. The real value of gold and silver -- the real quantity of labor they can purchase or command -- therefore depends far more on the quantity of corn they can buy than on the quantity of butcher's meat or any other raw product.
elegant: Corn is the laborer's main food in every civilized country. As agriculture develops, vegetable food predominates over animal food, and workers eat the cheapest wholesome option. Meat is a luxury for laborers -- in France and Scotland, the poor eat it only on holidays. Since corn dominates the laborer's diet, wages depend mainly on corn prices, and the real value of gold and silver depends more on their corn-purchasing power than on their power to buy any other commodity.
summary: Since corn constitutes the bulk of laborers' diets in civilized countries, the money price of labor depends primarily on corn prices. Consequently, the real value of precious metals is best measured by their purchasing power over corn rather than over meat or other products.
distilled: The real value of precious metals depends primarily on their corn-purchasing power because corn is the principal food and therefore the main determinant of labor's money price.
notes: Corn -> wages -> silver value: the causal chain linking food prices to monetary values. -- Dietary hierarchy: corn (daily) > butcher's meat (holidays only) > poultry (rare) > game (never) for laboring poor. -- France and Scotland as examples of working-class diet. -- This justifies Smith's methodological choice to measure silver's value against corn throughout the Digression. -- Cross-reference 1.11.111 on corn as the most stable value measure and 1.8 on the relationship between food prices and wages.

refashioned: Such brief observations on the prices of corn and other commodities would probably not have misled so many intelligent writers had they not also been influenced by the popular belief that as the quantity of silver naturally increases with a country's growing wealth, its value must decline as its quantity grows. This notion, however, appears to be entirely without foundation.
elegant: The price evidence alone would not have misled so many intelligent writers without the reinforcing influence of the popular but groundless belief that silver's value necessarily declines as national wealth (and thus silver quantity) increases.
summary: Earlier writers' errors about historical silver values were reinforced by the unfounded popular belief that increasing national wealth necessarily increases silver quantity, which necessarily reduces its value.
distilled: The false assumption that growing national wealth necessarily depreciates silver's value compounded earlier writers' misreading of the price evidence.
notes: Two reinforcing errors: (1) flawed price evidence (1.11.102-107) and (2) flawed theory (wealth -> more silver -> lower value). -- The theoretical error is addressed in 1.11.114-116. -- Smith calls the notion 'altogether groundless' -- strong language indicating this is a fundamental misconception he considers important to refute. -- Cross-reference 1.11.101 where this popular opinion was first introduced.

refashioned: The quantity of precious metals in any country may increase from two distinct causes: first, from the discovery of more abundant mines; second, from the increased wealth of the people, representing the increased output of their annual labor. The first cause is indeed necessarily connected with a decline in the value of precious metals, but the second is not.
elegant: Precious metals increase in a country from two causes: more abundant mines, or greater national wealth (increased annual production). The first necessarily reduces metal values; the second does not.
summary: Precious metal quantities grow either from richer mines or from greater national wealth. Only the first cause necessarily reduces their value; the second does not.
distilled: More abundant mines necessarily reduce precious metal values, but greater national wealth does not -- a crucial distinction that earlier writers failed to make.
notes: The key distinction that demolishes the popular fallacy identified in 1.11.113. -- Two causes of increased metal quantity yield opposite value effects. -- This anticipates the quantity theory of money debates: not all increases in money supply are inflationary. -- Cross-reference 1.11.115 on why mine abundance depreciates metals and 1.11.116 on why wealth-driven increases do not.

refashioned: When more abundant mines are discovered, a greater quantity of precious metals is brought to market. Since the quantity of necessities and conveniences available for exchange remains the same, equal quantities of metal must now be exchanged for smaller quantities of goods. To the extent, therefore, that the increase in precious metals in any country results from more abundant mines, it is necessarily connected with some reduction in their value.
elegant: When richer mines increase the metal supply while goods remain constant, each unit of metal exchanges for fewer goods -- its value falls. Increased metal from more abundant mines therefore necessarily depreciates metal values.
summary: More abundant mines increase metal supply against a constant quantity of goods, so each unit of metal buys less. Mine-driven increases in precious metal quantity necessarily reduce their value.
distilled: When richer mines increase metal supply without a corresponding increase in goods, metal values necessarily fall -- more metal chasing the same goods.
notes: Simple supply-demand logic: more metal + same goods = lower metal value per unit. -- This is the mechanism behind the second period's silver depreciation (1.11.123-127) after American mine discoveries. -- Equivalent to the quantity theory of money in its simplest form. -- Cross-reference 1.11.116 for the contrasting case of wealth-driven metal increase.

refashioned: When, on the contrary, a country's wealth increases -- when the annual output of its labor becomes steadily greater -- a larger quantity of coin becomes necessary to circulate a larger quantity of goods. The people, able to afford it and having more commodities to offer in exchange, will naturally acquire a growing quantity of plate as well. The amount of coin increases from necessity; the amount of plate increases from vanity and ostentation, or for the same reason that fine statues, paintings, and other luxuries tend to multiply among prosperous people. But just as sculptors and painters are not likely to be paid worse in times of wealth and prosperity than in times of poverty and decline, neither is gold and silver likely to be paid for at a worse rate.
elegant: When national wealth grows, more coin is needed to circulate more goods, and the wealthy buy more silver plate from vanity. But this wealth-driven increase does not depreciate metals: just as sculptors and painters are not paid worse in prosperous times, gold and silver command no less value when their increase stems from growing wealth rather than from richer mines.
summary: When national wealth drives increased precious metal holdings -- more coin for commerce, more plate for display -- metals do not lose value, because the increase in goods keeps pace with the increase in metal. Prosperity does not reduce gold and silver's purchasing power.
distilled: Wealth-driven increases in precious metals do not depreciate their value because the supply of goods grows in proportion, unlike mine-driven increases where goods remain constant.
notes: The crucial distinction from 1.11.114 elaborated: wealth-driven metal increase is matched by goods increase, so value is preserved. -- Coin increase from necessity (circulation needs); plate increase from vanity (conspicuous consumption). -- The sculptor/painter analogy: demand for luxury goods and services rises with wealth, supporting rather than depressing their price. -- Cross-reference 1.11.115 for the contrasting mine-driven depreciation and 1.11.78 on conspicuous consumption.

refashioned: The price of gold and silver, when not depressed by the accidental discovery of more abundant mines, naturally rises with a country's wealth. Whatever the state of the mines, precious metal prices are always naturally higher in a rich country than in a poor one. Gold and silver, like all commodities, naturally flow to the market where they command the best price, and the best price is generally found in the country that can best afford to pay it. Labor, it must be remembered, is the ultimate price paid for everything, and in countries where labor is equally well rewarded, the money price of labor will be proportional to that of the laborer's subsistence.
elegant: Without new mine discoveries, precious metal prices naturally rise with national wealth -- they are always higher in rich countries than poor ones. Gold and silver flow toward the best-paying market, which is the wealthiest country. Since labor is the ultimate price of everything, and labor's money price reflects subsistence costs, precious metals gravitate toward countries where subsistence costs (and thus money wages) are highest.
summary: Precious metal values naturally rise with wealth, absent new mine discoveries. Gold and silver flow to the richest markets where labor -- the ultimate price of everything -- commands the highest money wages proportional to subsistence costs.
distilled: Precious metals naturally appreciate with national wealth and flow toward the richest markets, where the highest subsistence costs support the highest money wages.
notes: Gold and silver as commodities seeking the highest return -- gravitating toward wealthy countries. -- Labor as the ultimate price of everything (from 1.5). -- Money wages proportional to subsistence costs -- linking food prices, wages, and metal values. -- Cross-reference 1.11.116 on wealth-driven metal appreciation and 1.11.118 on international price differentials between rich and poor countries.

refashioned: Gold and silver naturally exchange for a greater quantity of food in a rich country than in a poor one -- in a country abundant in food rather than one poorly supplied. If the two countries are far apart, the difference may be very large, because although metals naturally flow from the worse to the better market, transporting them in sufficient quantities to equalize prices across both may be difficult. If the countries are near, the difference will be smaller and perhaps barely noticeable, since transportation will be easy. China is a much richer country than any part of Europe, and the difference between subsistence prices in China and Europe is very great. Rice in China is much cheaper than wheat anywhere in Europe. England is much richer than Scotland, but the difference in corn prices between the two is much smaller and barely perceptible. In proportion to quantity or measure, Scottish corn generally appears considerably cheaper than English corn, but in proportion to quality it is certainly somewhat more expensive. Scotland receives very large grain imports from England nearly every year, and any commodity must generally cost more in the importing country than in the exporting one. English corn, therefore, must be more expensive in Scotland than in England. Yet in terms of quality -- the quantity and goodness of flour or meal it produces -- it cannot usually sell for more than the competing Scottish corn at market.
elegant: Precious metals buy more food in rich countries than poor ones. The price gap depends on distance: China and Europe differ greatly in subsistence costs (rice is far cheaper in China), while England and Scotland differ only slightly (Scottish corn is cheaper in quantity but dearer in quality). Distance determines how effectively metals flow to equalize prices. Scotland imports heavily from England, yet Scottish corn holds its own at market through quality competition.
summary: Precious metals buy more food in richer countries, with the price gap determined by distance and transport ease. China and Europe show large differences; England and Scotland show small ones. Scottish corn appears cheaper by quantity but dearer by quality relative to English imports.
distilled: Precious metals command more food in richer countries, with the price gap between countries determined by distance and transport costs that impede metal flows toward equilibrium.
notes: International price differentials and arbitrage: metals flow from low-price to high-price markets, but distance creates persistent gaps. -- China as the ultimate 'rich country' comparison to Europe -- a common 18th-century reference point. -- England-Scotland comparison shows how proximity reduces differentials. -- Quantity vs. quality distinction in corn pricing: Scottish corn cheaper by volume, dearer by nutritional value. -- Cross-reference 1.11.117 on metals flowing to the best market and 1.11.119 on labor price differentials.

refashioned: The difference in the money price of labor between China and Europe is still greater than the difference in the money price of food, because labor's real compensation is higher in Europe than in China -- the greater part of Europe being in a state of economic advancement while China appears to be standing still. The money price of labor is lower in Scotland than in England because labor's real compensation is much lower there: Scotland, though advancing toward greater wealth, advances much more slowly than England. The frequency of emigration from Scotland and its rarity from England sufficiently prove that the demand for labor is very different in the two countries. The ratio of real compensation for labor between different countries, it must be remembered, is naturally determined not by their actual wealth or poverty but by whether their condition is advancing, stationary, or declining.
elegant: Money wages differ even more than food prices between countries, because real labor compensation depends on whether economies are advancing, stationary, or declining -- not on current wealth. Europe pays more than China because Europe advances while China stagnates. Scotland pays less than England because it advances more slowly. Emigration patterns confirm the difference: Scots emigrate frequently, the English rarely.
summary: International wage differences exceed food price differences because real wages depend on whether an economy is advancing, stationary, or declining -- not on its current wealth. Europe's advancement versus China's stagnation, and England's faster growth versus Scotland's slower growth, explain their respective wage gaps.
distilled: Real wages are determined by an economy's rate of advancement, not its current wealth level -- explaining why advancing Europe pays more than stagnant China, and faster-growing England more than Scotland.
notes: Dynamic vs. static determinants of wages: rate of change matters more than level of wealth. -- China as 'stationary' economy -- a recurring Smith characterization. -- Emigration as revealed preference indicator for labor demand differentials. -- Cross-reference 1.8 on wages and the advancing/stationary/declining framework, and 1.11.118 on food price differentials.

refashioned:
Gold and silver are naturally most valuable among the richest nations and least valuable among the poorest. Among truly primitive peoples, the poorest of all nations, they have scarcely any value at all.

In large towns, corn is always more expensive than in remote parts of the countryside. This is not because silver is cheaper in towns, but because corn is more expensive. It costs no less labor to transport silver to the city than to the countryside, but it costs considerably more to transport corn.
elegant: Precious metals are most valued by the richest nations and nearly worthless among the poorest. In cities, corn is dearer than in the countryside -- not because silver is cheaper there, but because transporting corn is costlier than transporting silver. The difference is in corn's real cost, not silver's value.
summary: Precious metals are most valuable among wealthy nations and nearly worthless among the poorest. Higher urban corn prices reflect corn's transport costs, not lower silver value -- a distinction Smith insists on maintaining.
distilled: Higher urban corn prices reflect the cost of transporting a bulky commodity, not a lower value of silver -- precious metals are most valued among the wealthiest nations and least among the poorest.
notes: Wealth and metal value correlation: richest nations value metals most, poorest value them least. -- Urban-rural price differential explained by transport costs, not monetary factors. -- Corrects the common confusion between commodity dearness and money cheapness. -- Cross-reference 1.11.117-118 on international metal value differentials and 1.11.121 on the Holland/Genoa examples.

refashioned: In some very rich and commercial countries like Holland and the territory of Genoa, corn is expensive for the same reason it is expensive in large cities. These places do not produce enough to feed their inhabitants. They are rich in the skills of their artisans and manufacturers, in every kind of labor-saving machinery, in shipping, and in all other instruments of transport and commerce -- but they are poor in corn, which must be brought from distant countries and must pay its transport costs through a higher price. It costs no less labor to bring silver to Amsterdam than to Danzig, but it costs far more to bring corn. The real cost of silver must be nearly the same in both places, but the real cost of corn must be very different. If Holland's or Genoa's real prosperity were to decline while their populations remained the same, diminishing their ability to supply themselves from abroad, the price of corn -- instead of falling along with the decrease in their silver (which would necessarily accompany this decline, whether as cause or effect) -- would rise to famine levels. When we desperately need necessities, we part with all luxuries, whose value rises in times of prosperity and falls in times of distress. Necessities behave oppositely: their real price -- the quantity of labor they command -- rises in times of poverty and distress and falls in times of prosperity, which are always times of abundance, for they could not otherwise be times of prosperity. Corn is a necessity; silver is merely a luxury.
elegant: Holland and Genoa, like great cities, have expensive corn because they cannot feed themselves and must import at high transport cost. Silver costs the same to ship to Amsterdam as to Danzig, but corn costs far more. If these wealthy trading nations declined, corn prices would rise to famine levels even as silver disappeared -- because in distress, necessities appreciate while luxuries depreciate. Corn is a necessity whose real price rises with scarcity; silver is a luxury whose real price falls. Prosperity means abundance of necessities, which is why their real price is low in good times and high in bad.
summary: Wealthy trading nations like Holland and Genoa have expensive corn because they must import it, not because silver is cheap. If their prosperity declined, corn would rise to famine prices while silver depreciated -- because necessities and luxuries move in opposite directions during economic distress.
distilled: Corn is expensive in wealthy trading nations because of import costs, and in economic decline corn prices would soar while silver depreciated -- necessities and luxuries respond oppositely to distress.
notes: Necessity vs. luxury price behavior: necessities appreciate in distress, luxuries depreciate. -- Holland and Genoa as 'rich but food-poor' trading economies -- dependent on imports for subsistence. -- Amsterdam vs. Danzig: equal silver transport cost, vastly different corn transport cost. -- The corn-silver divergence in decline is a powerful theoretical insight. -- Cross-reference 1.11.120 on urban-rural price differentials and 1.11.82 on the contrast between surface land and mines.

refashioned: Whatever increase in the quantity of precious metals may have occurred between the mid-fourteenth and mid-sixteenth centuries as a result of growing wealth and improvement, it could have had no tendency to diminish their value, either in Great Britain or anywhere else in Europe. If those who collected the prices of things in ancient times had no valid reason during this period to infer a decline in silver's value from their observations on the prices of corn or other commodities, they had even less reason to infer it from any supposed increase in wealth and improvement.
elegant: Any increase in precious metals during 1350-1570 that stemmed from growing wealth could not have reduced their value. If price evidence gave no valid basis for inferring silver's depreciation during this period, the argument from increasing wealth provided even less justification.
summary: The wealth-driven increase in precious metals between 1350 and 1570 could not have depressed their value. Neither the price evidence nor the theoretical argument from growing wealth supports the claim that silver depreciated during this period.
distilled: Neither price evidence nor the theory linking wealth to metal depreciation supports the claim that silver lost value between 1350 and 1570 -- both arguments fail.
notes: Concluding summary for the first period's analysis. -- Double refutation: (1) price evidence misread (1.11.102-108), (2) theoretical argument fallacious (1.11.113-116). -- Smith has demonstrated both that prices moved in the opposite direction from what critics claimed and that their theoretical framework was wrong. -- Cross-reference 1.11.94 (price conclusion) and 1.11.114-116 (theoretical refutation).

refashioned:
Second Period. -- However varied the opinions of scholars about silver's value trajectory during the first period, they are unanimous about the second.

From about 1570 to about 1640, over roughly seventy years, the relationship between silver's value and corn's price reversed course. Silver fell in its real value -- it could buy less labor than before -- and corn rose in its money price. Instead of commonly selling for about two ounces of silver per quarter (about ten shillings in present money), corn came to sell for six to eight ounces of silver per quarter (about thirty to forty shillings in present money).
elegant: Second Period (c.1570-1640): All scholars agree that silver's value reversed course. Silver's real value fell -- buying less labor -- while corn's money price tripled or quadrupled, rising from about two ounces of silver per quarter (ten shillings) to six or eight ounces (thirty to forty shillings).
summary: During the second period (1570-1640), silver's real value fell dramatically while corn's money price tripled or quadrupled, from about ten shillings to thirty or forty shillings per quarter. All scholars agree on this reversal.
distilled: Between 1570 and 1640, silver depreciated sharply as corn's money price rose from ten shillings to thirty or forty shillings per quarter -- a universally acknowledged reversal.
notes: Second period: silver depreciation, c.1570-1640. -- Corresponds to scenario 2 from 1.11.87: supply exceeds demand, silver cheapens. -- Corn price increase: 3-4x in nominal silver terms (2 oz -> 6-8 oz per quarter). -- Universal scholarly agreement on this period contrasts with the controversy over the first period. -- Cross-reference 1.11.124 for the cause (American mine discoveries).

refashioned: The discovery of America's abundant mines appears to have been the sole cause of this decline in silver's value relative to corn. This explanation is universally accepted, and there has never been any dispute about either the fact or its cause. The greater part of Europe was advancing in industry and improvement during this period, and demand for silver must therefore have been increasing. But the increase in supply so far exceeded the increase in demand that the metal's value fell considerably. Notably, the American mine discoveries do not seem to have significantly affected English prices until after 1570, even though the mines of Potosi had been discovered more than twenty years earlier.
elegant: The discovery of abundant American mines was the universally accepted sole cause of silver's depreciation. European demand was growing from economic progress, but American supply so far exceeded it that silver's value fell substantially. The effect was delayed -- English prices were unaffected until after 1570, though Potosi was discovered over twenty years earlier.
summary: American mine discoveries caused silver's depreciation during the second period, overwhelming growing European demand with even faster supply growth. The price impact was delayed, not reaching England until after 1570 despite Potosi's discovery decades earlier.
distilled: Abundant American silver mines overwhelmed growing European demand, causing silver to depreciate -- though the effect took over twenty years to reach English prices after Potosi's discovery.
notes: American silver as the exogenous supply shock. -- Supply overwhelmed demand despite economic growth -- a real-world demonstration of the quantity theory. -- Time lag: 20+ years between mine discovery and price effects -- reflecting transport time, minting delays, and gradual market absorption. -- Potosi (discovered 1545) as the landmark mine. -- Cross-reference 1.11.115 on how mine abundance depreciates metals and 1.11.125-126 for price data.

refashioned: From 1595 to 1620 inclusive, the average price of nine bushels of the best wheat at Windsor market, according to Eton College records, was two pounds, one shilling, and six and nine-thirteenths pence. Ignoring the fraction and deducting one-ninth (four shillings and seven and one-third pence), the price per quarter of eight bushels comes to one pound, sixteen shillings, and ten and two-thirds pence. Ignoring that fraction as well and deducting another ninth (four shillings and one and one-ninth pence) for the difference between best and middle wheat, the price of middle wheat comes to about one pound, twelve shillings, and eight and eight-ninths pence -- or about six and one-third ounces of silver.
elegant: From 1595-1620, Eton College records show the average price of best wheat at Windsor at about two pounds one shilling sixpence per nine bushels. Adjusting to eight bushels and from best to middle quality, the price of ordinary wheat was approximately one pound twelve shillings ninepence -- about six and one-third ounces of silver per quarter.
summary: Eton College records for 1595-1620 show middle-quality wheat averaging about six and one-third ounces of silver per quarter at Windsor market, confirming the sharp increase from the two-ounce level of the first period.
distilled: Windsor market wheat prices from 1595-1620 averaged about six and one-third ounces of silver per quarter, tripling from the first period's two-ounce level.
notes: Empirical price data for the second period's first sub-interval. -- Eton College records: one of the most reliable continuous price series for English wheat. -- Methodological adjustments: nine to eight bushels, best to middle wheat quality. -- Six and one-third ounces confirms roughly tripling from two ounces in the first period. -- Cross-reference 1.11.126 for the next sub-interval (1621-1636).

refashioned: From 1621 to 1636 inclusive, the average price of the same quantity of the best wheat at the same market, from the same records, was two pounds ten shillings. Making the same deductions as before, the average price per quarter of eight bushels of middle wheat comes to one pound, nineteen shillings, and sixpence -- or about seven and two-thirds ounces of silver.
elegant: From 1621-1636, best wheat at Windsor averaged two pounds ten shillings per nine bushels. After the same quality and quantity adjustments, middle wheat was about one pound nineteen shillings sixpence per quarter -- roughly seven and two-thirds ounces of silver.
summary: Windsor wheat prices for 1621-1636 show middle wheat at about seven and two-thirds ounces of silver per quarter, continuing the upward trend from six and one-third ounces in the previous sub-period.
distilled: Wheat prices continued rising in 1621-1636, reaching about seven and two-thirds ounces of silver per quarter at Windsor market.
notes: Second sub-interval of the second period shows continued silver depreciation. -- Price increase from ~6.3 to ~7.7 ounces of silver per quarter between the two sub-periods. -- Same methodology and source (Eton College records) ensures comparability. -- Cross-reference 1.11.125 for the first sub-interval and 1.11.127 for the transition to the third period.

refashioned: Third Period. -- Between 1630 and 1640, around 1636, the American mines' effect in reducing silver's value appears to have been fully absorbed, and silver seems never to have sunk lower relative to corn than it was around that time. It appears to have risen somewhat during the present century, and this recovery had probably begun even before the end of the last century.
elegant: Third Period: Around 1636, the American mines' depressive effect on silver's value was fully absorbed. Silver never fell lower relative to corn than at that time, and has risen somewhat since -- a recovery that probably began before the end of the seventeenth century.
summary: The third period begins around 1636 when silver's depreciation from American mine discoveries bottomed out. Silver's value has since partially recovered, with the recovery likely beginning in the late seventeenth century.
distilled: Silver's value bottomed out around 1636 as American mine effects were fully absorbed, and has partially recovered since -- matching scenario three where supply and demand roughly balance.
