notes: Third period: stabilization and partial recovery of silver's value, c.1636-present. -- Corresponds to scenario 3 from 1.11.87: supply and demand grow roughly in proportion. -- The 'completion' of mine effects suggests a new equilibrium between American supply and European demand. -- Cross-reference 1.11.128-133 for the detailed evidence of this stabilization and 1.11.87 for the theoretical framework.

refashioned: From 1637 to 1700 inclusive -- the sixty-four final years of the last century -- the average price of nine bushels of the best wheat at Windsor market, from the same records, was two pounds, eleven shillings, and one-third of a penny. This is only one shilling and one-third of a penny more than the average for the sixteen years before 1637. But during these sixty-four years, two events occurred that must have produced a much greater scarcity of corn than weather patterns alone would have caused, and which therefore -- without assuming any further decline in silver's value -- more than sufficiently account for this very small price increase.
elegant: From 1637-1700, best wheat at Windsor averaged two pounds eleven shillings -- barely more than the 1621-1636 average. This near-stability is remarkable because two disruptive events during this period should have raised prices significantly. Without any further silver depreciation, these events alone more than explain the tiny increase.
summary: Wheat prices from 1637 to 1700 barely exceeded the previous period's average despite two major disruptions, suggesting silver's value had stabilized rather than continuing to decline.
distilled: The near-stability of wheat prices from 1637-1700, despite two major supply disruptions, confirms that silver had stopped depreciating by this period.
notes: Price stability as evidence of silver value stabilization. -- The 'two events' (civil war and export bounty) are detailed in 1.11.129-130. -- The tiny price increase is attributed entirely to supply disruptions, not to continuing silver depreciation. -- Cross-reference 1.11.127 for the period overview and 1.11.129-131 for the specific events.

refashioned: The first event was the Civil War, which, by discouraging farming and disrupting commerce, must have raised corn prices well above what weather conditions alone would have caused. This effect was felt at all markets throughout the kingdom, but especially at those near London, which needed the longest supply lines. In 1648, the price of the best wheat at Windsor was four pounds five shillings, and in 1649 it was four pounds per quarter of nine bushels. The excess of these two years over the pre-1637 average of two pounds ten shillings amounts to three pounds five shillings. Spread over the sixty-four years from 1637 to 1700, this alone nearly accounts for the small overall price increase during the period. These were the highest prices, but by no means the only elevated prices that the Civil War seems to have caused.
elegant: The English Civil War disrupted farming and commerce, raising corn prices above weather-driven levels -- especially near London, which depended on the longest supply chains. Wheat peaked at four pounds five shillings (1648) and four pounds (1649), exceeding the prior average by three pounds five shillings. This excess alone, spread over sixty-four years, nearly explains the entire period's small price increase -- and these were not the only war-inflated years.
summary: The English Civil War disrupted agriculture and trade, spiking wheat prices to four pounds five shillings in 1648. This single disruption, averaged over sixty-four years, accounts for nearly the entire modest price increase of the third period.
distilled: The English Civil War's disruption of agriculture and trade produced price spikes that alone account for nearly all of the third period's modest wheat price increase.
notes: Civil War (1642-1651) as an exogenous supply shock to grain markets. -- London's vulnerability: longest supply lines = most affected by trade disruption. -- 1648-1649 price spike: ~70% above the prior average. -- Averaging the spike over 64 years shows how a short disruption can explain long-run averages. -- Cross-reference 1.11.128 on the overall period stability and 1.11.130 on the second event (export bounty).

refashioned: The second event was the bounty on corn exports, established in 1688. Many people have argued that this bounty, by encouraging farming, may have eventually produced greater abundance and lower corn prices in the domestic market than would otherwise have prevailed. I will examine later how far the bounty could actually produce this effect. For now, I will only observe that between 1688 and 1700, it had not had enough time to produce any such result. During this short period, its only effect must have been to encourage the export of each year's surplus, thereby preventing the abundance of one year from offsetting the scarcity of another, and thus raising domestic prices. The scarcity that prevailed in England from 1693 to 1699 inclusive, though mainly caused by bad weather and extending across much of Europe, must have been somewhat worsened by the bounty. In 1699, accordingly, corn exports were prohibited for nine months.
elegant: The 1688 corn export bounty was the second disruption. Though some argued it would eventually increase domestic supply through encouraging farming, between 1688 and 1700 it could only have raised domestic prices by shipping away surpluses that would otherwise have offset scarce years. The 1693-1699 scarcity, primarily weather-driven but aggravated by the bounty, became severe enough that exports were banned for nine months in 1699.
summary: The 1688 corn export bounty raised domestic prices in the short term by encouraging surplus exports and preventing good years from compensating for bad ones. Combined with poor harvests from 1693 to 1699, it contributed to scarcity severe enough to prompt a temporary export ban.
distilled: The 1688 corn export bounty worsened domestic scarcity by shipping away surpluses, contributing to the 1693-1699 grain shortage that required a temporary export ban.
notes: Export bounty as price-destabilizing policy -- by removing surpluses, it prevents inter-year price smoothing. -- Short-run vs. long-run effects: Smith reserves judgment on the bounty's eventual agricultural benefits (addressed later in Book IV). -- 1693-1699 scarcity: weather-driven but policy-aggravated. -- Nine-month export ban in 1699 as emergency intervention. -- Cross-reference 1.11.129 on the Civil War disruption and 1.11.131 on the third (monetary) disruption.

refashioned: A third event also occurred during this period which, though it could not cause any actual scarcity of corn or increase the real quantity of silver paid for it, must have raised the nominal money price. This event was the severe debasement of the silver coinage through clipping and wear. The problem had begun under Charles II and worsened continuously until 1695, when, according to Mr. Lowndes, the circulating silver coin was on average about twenty-five percent below its standard value. But the nominal price of every commodity at market is necessarily determined not by the quantity of silver the coin should contain according to the standard, but by the quantity it actually does contain based on experience. This nominal sum is therefore necessarily higher when the coinage is heavily debased through clipping and wear than when it is close to its standard value.
elegant: A third event -- the debasement of silver coinage through clipping and wear -- raised nominal (but not real) corn prices. Beginning under Charles II and worsening until 1695, the circulating silver coin fell about twenty-five percent below standard value (per Lowndes). Since market prices reflect the actual silver content of coins, not the official standard, debased coins necessarily produce higher nominal prices.
summary: Coin debasement through clipping and wear, reaching twenty-five percent below standard by 1695, inflated nominal corn prices without affecting real silver payments. Market prices necessarily rose because they tracked actual rather than official coin silver content.
distilled: Silver coin debasement of twenty-five percent by 1695 inflated nominal corn prices without changing the real quantity of silver exchanged.
notes: Nominal vs. real price distinction applied to coinage debasement. -- Clipping and wear: physical reduction of coins' silver content, distinct from official debasement (reducing the legal standard). -- Lowndes: William Lowndes, Secretary to the Treasury, author of Essay on Silver Coin (1695). -- Gresham's Law context: debased coins drove good coins out of circulation. -- Cross-reference 1.11.132-133 on subsequent recoinage and its effects.

refashioned: During the present century, the silver coin has never been further below its standard weight than it is now. But though much worn, its value has been maintained by that of the gold coin for which it is exchanged. Before the recent recoinage, the gold coin was also somewhat worn, but less so than the silver. In 1695, by contrast, the silver coin's value was not supported by the gold coin -- a guinea then commonly exchanged for thirty shillings in the worn and clipped silver. Before the recent gold recoinage, the price of silver bullion was seldom higher than five shillings and sevenpence an ounce, only fivepence above the mint price.
elegant: Today's silver coin, though worn, maintains its value because gold coin supports it through exchange. Before the recent recoinage, gold was less worn than silver, keeping silver's value stable -- bullion prices stayed near the mint price. But in 1695, gold did not support silver: a guinea exchanged for thirty shillings in debased silver, reflecting the extreme debasement.
summary: Current silver coinage maintains its value despite wear because the less-degraded gold coinage supports it. In 1695, no such support existed -- a guinea bought thirty shillings of debased silver, and bullion prices diverged sharply from the mint price.
distilled: Gold coinage currently supports worn silver's value through exchange, unlike 1695 when extreme silver debasement severed this relationship and bullion prices soared above the mint price.
notes: Bimetallic standard dynamics: gold supports silver value when both circulate. -- 1695 breakdown: silver so debased that the gold-silver exchange rate diverged from the official rate (guinea at 30s instead of standard 21s). -- Bullion price as a debasement indicator: 5s 7d vs. mint price (close) in the present vs. 6s 5d (far above mint) in 1695. -- Cross-reference 1.11.131 on the debasement and 1.11.133 on the post-recoinage recovery.

refashioned: But in 1695, the common price of silver bullion was six shillings and fivepence an ounce -- fifteen pence above the mint price. Even before the recent gold recoinage, therefore, the combined gold and silver coinage, compared to silver bullion, was estimated to be no more than eight percent below its standard value. In 1695, by contrast, it had been estimated at nearly twenty-five percent below standard. But at the beginning of the present century -- that is, immediately after the great recoinage under King William -- the greater part of the circulating silver coin must have been still closer to its standard weight than it is at present.
elegant: In 1695, silver bullion cost six shillings fivepence per ounce -- fifteen pence above the mint price, reflecting twenty-five percent debasement. Even before the recent gold recoinage, the combined coinage was only eight percent below standard. Immediately after King William's great recoinage at the century's start, silver coins must have been even closer to standard than they are today.
summary: Silver bullion prices in 1695 reflected twenty-five percent debasement, compared to only eight percent before the recent recoinage. King William's great recoinage at the century's start restored coin quality to near-standard levels, closer than present circulation.
distilled: King William's recoinage restored silver coin quality from twenty-five percent below standard in 1695 to near-standard levels, demonstrating how monetary reform can eliminate the inflationary effects of debasement.
notes: Quantitative comparison: 25% debasement (1695) vs. 8% (pre-recent recoinage) vs. near-standard (post-William recoinage). -- Bullion price as debasement metric: 15d above mint (1695) vs. 5d above (present). -- The Great Recoinage of 1696 under William III restored silver coin integrity -- one of the major monetary events of English history, managed by John Locke and Isaac Newton. -- This entry concludes the immediate discussion of monetary disruptions affecting the third period's price data. -- Cross-reference 1.11.131-132 on the debasement problem and its effects on nominal prices.

refashioned: During the present century, there has been no great public calamity, such as a civil war, that could discourage farming or disrupt the country's internal trade. And though the corn bounty, which has been in place for most of this century, must always raise the price of corn somewhat above what it would otherwise be given the actual state of agriculture, the bounty has also had ample time to produce all the beneficial effects commonly attributed to it -- namely, encouraging farming and thereby increasing the supply of corn in the domestic market. Thus, according to the principles of a system I shall explain and examine later, the bounty may be supposed to have done something to lower the price of corn in one way, even as it raised it in another.
elegant: This century has seen no civil war or calamity to discourage farming or disrupt trade. Though the corn bounty raises prices above their natural level, it has also had time to encourage agriculture and increase domestic supply. The bounty may therefore have lowered corn prices in one way even as it raised them in another.
summary: The present century has been free of major disruptions to agriculture. The corn bounty, while raising prices artificially, has also had time to encourage farming and increase supply, potentially offsetting its own price-inflating effect.
distilled: The corn bounty may have simultaneously raised and lowered corn prices -- raising them directly while lowering them by encouraging greater agricultural production.
notes: The 'bounty' refers to the corn export subsidy established in 1688 -- a policy Smith critiques at length in Book IV. -- Smith hints at a paradox central to his critique of mercantilism: interventions intended to help producers often have self-canceling effects. -- The phrase 'a system which I shall explain and examine hereafter' foreshadows his systematic critique of mercantile policy. -- Cross-reference: Book IV, Chapter 5 on bounties.

refashioned: Many people believe the bounty has done more than merely offset its own effects. During the first sixty-four years of the present century, the average price of the best wheat (a quarter of nine bushels) at Windsor market was, according to Eton College records, roughly two pounds and sixpence -- about ten shillings and sixpence, or more than twenty-five percent, cheaper than during the last sixty-four years of the previous century. It was also about nine shillings and sixpence cheaper than during the sixteen years before 1636, when the discovery of America's abundant mines may be supposed to have produced its full effect on prices. And it was about one shilling cheaper than during the twenty-six years before 1620, before that discovery could have fully affected prices. According to this account, the average price of middle wheat during the first sixty-four years of the present century works out to about thirty-two shillings per quarter of eight bushels.
elegant: Many believe the bounty has done even more. In the first sixty-four years of this century, the average price of the best wheat at Windsor market was over twenty-five percent cheaper than in the last sixty-four years of the previous century, and cheaper still than in the periods before and after America's silver mines fully affected European prices. The average price of middle wheat comes out to about thirty-two shillings per quarter.
summary: Wheat prices in the first sixty-four years of the eighteenth century were significantly lower than in comparable periods of the seventeenth century -- over twenty-five percent cheaper than the previous century's final sixty-four years, according to Eton College records.
distilled: Eighteenth-century wheat prices at Windsor market were substantially lower than seventeenth-century prices, suggesting a rise in the value of silver relative to corn.
notes: The Eton College price records were a widely used historical data source in Smith's era. -- The 'quarter of nine bushels' for best wheat vs. 'quarter of eight bushels' for middle wheat reflects differing measurement conventions. -- The reference to 1636 and 1620 connects to Smith's periodization of how American silver affected European prices. -- Smith is building an empirical case for a gradual rise in silver's purchasing power during the eighteenth century.

refashioned: The value of silver therefore appears to have risen somewhat relative to corn during the present century, and this rise probably began even before the end of the previous one. In 1687, the price of the best wheat (a quarter of nine bushels) at Windsor market was one pound, five shillings, and twopence -- the lowest price recorded since 1595.
elegant: Silver's value relative to corn appears to have risen during this century, likely beginning before the last century ended. In 1687, the best wheat at Windsor reached its lowest recorded price since 1595.
summary: The value of silver relative to corn has been rising since before the end of the seventeenth century, as evidenced by wheat reaching its lowest price since 1595 in the year 1687.
distilled: Silver's purchasing power relative to corn has been rising since the late seventeenth century.
notes: Smith treats corn as a more stable measure of real value than silver over long periods -- a key methodological commitment throughout this chapter. -- The 1687 price point serves as empirical evidence that silver's real value had already begun rising before the eighteenth century. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.143, where Smith argues that changes in corn's money price should be attributed to changes in silver's value rather than corn's.

refashioned: In 1688, Gregory King -- a man celebrated for his expertise in such matters -- estimated the average price of wheat in years of moderate plenty at three shillings and sixpence per bushel to the grower, or twenty-eight shillings per quarter. By the 'grower's price,' I understand what is sometimes called the contract price: the price at which a farmer agrees to deliver a set quantity of corn to a dealer over a period of years. Since such a contract saves the farmer the expense and trouble of marketing, the contract price is generally lower than the average market price. King judged twenty-eight shillings per quarter to be the ordinary contract price in years of moderate plenty at that time. Before the scarcity caused by the recent extraordinary run of bad seasons, I have been assured that this was still the ordinary contract price in normal years.
elegant: In 1688, Gregory King estimated wheat's average price to the grower in moderate years at twenty-eight shillings per quarter -- the 'contract price' at which farmers agree to deliver fixed quantities to dealers. This price is typically below the market price because it saves the farmer marketing costs. Before the recent run of bad seasons, twenty-eight shillings reportedly remained the standard contract price in normal years.
summary: Gregory King's 1688 estimate put the grower's contract price for wheat at twenty-eight shillings per quarter in years of moderate plenty. This contract price, which saves marketing costs, remained roughly standard until the recent period of bad harvests.
distilled: The contract price of wheat -- twenty-eight shillings per quarter in moderate years -- had remained relatively stable from 1688 until the recent bad seasons.
notes: Gregory King (1648--1712) was a pioneering English statistician and political economist, famous for his social table estimating England's population and wealth by class. -- The distinction between contract price and market price anticipates modern economics' distinction between spot and forward prices. -- Smith frequently uses the testimony of recognized authorities to establish empirical claims before subjecting them to analytical scrutiny. -- The 'late extraordinary course of bad seasons' refers to the 1760s harvest failures.

refashioned: In 1688, Parliament granted a bounty on the exportation of corn. The country gentlemen, who then composed an even greater share of the legislature than they do now, had perceived that the money price of corn was falling. The bounty was a device to raise it artificially to the high price at which corn had frequently sold during the reigns of Charles I and Charles II. It was to apply until wheat reached forty-eight shillings per quarter -- twenty shillings, or five-sevenths, more than what King had estimated that very year as the grower's price in times of moderate plenty. If his calculations deserve any part of their widely acknowledged reputation, forty-eight shillings per quarter was a price that, without some expedient like the bounty, could not have been expected except in years of extraordinary scarcity. But King William's government was not yet securely established. It was in no position to refuse anything to the country gentlemen, from whom it was, at that very moment, soliciting approval for the first annual land tax.
elegant: In 1688, Parliament granted a corn export bounty. The country gentlemen who dominated the legislature saw corn prices falling and devised the bounty to raise them artificially to levels seen under Charles I and II. The bounty applied until wheat reached forty-eight shillings per quarter -- five-sevenths above what Gregory King estimated as the normal grower's price. Without such intervention, that price could only have been expected in extraordinary scarcity. But King William's insecure government could refuse nothing to the landed gentry from whom it was soliciting the first annual land tax.
summary: The 1688 corn bounty was designed by landed interests in Parliament to artificially raise corn prices back to levels seen under earlier monarchs. King William's insecure government granted it as a political concession while seeking support for the first land tax.
distilled: The 1688 corn bounty was a political bargain -- landed gentry got artificial price supports in exchange for approving King William's first land tax.
notes: This passage reveals Smith's political economy at work: he shows how policy emerges from the intersection of economic interests and political power. -- The corn bounty (1689--1814) paid exporters a subsidy when domestic prices fell below a threshold, effectively creating a price floor. -- King William III's precarious political position after the Glorious Revolution of 1688 made him dependent on Parliamentary goodwill. -- The land tax, first imposed in 1692, became a permanent feature of English public finance. -- Cross-reference: Book IV, Chapter 5 for Smith's full critique of corn bounties.

refashioned: The value of silver relative to corn had therefore probably risen somewhat before the end of the last century, and it appears to have continued rising during most of the present century. However, the necessary effect of the bounty must have prevented this rise from being as noticeable as it otherwise would have been, given the actual state of agriculture.
elegant: Silver's value relative to corn had probably begun rising before the last century ended and continued rising through most of the present one, though the bounty masked the full extent of this increase.
summary: Silver's purchasing power relative to corn has been rising since the late seventeenth century, though the corn bounty has partially concealed the true magnitude of this trend.
distilled: The corn bounty obscured what would otherwise have been a more visible rise in silver's value relative to corn.
notes: Smith separates the underlying trend (rising silver value) from the policy distortion (the bounty), a method characteristic of his analytical approach. -- This passage synthesizes the historical evidence from the preceding paragraphs into a clear thesis. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.134 on the bounty's dual effects.

refashioned: In plentiful years, the bounty causes an extraordinary volume of exports, which necessarily raises the price of corn above what it would otherwise be. Keeping up the price of corn even in the most plentiful years, to encourage farming, was the declared purpose of the policy. In years of great scarcity, the bounty has generally been suspended. Nevertheless, it must have had some effect on prices even in many of those years. By causing extraordinary exports in years of plenty, the bounty frequently prevents the abundance of one year from compensating for the scarcity of another.
elegant: In plentiful years, the bounty drives extraordinary exports that raise corn prices above their natural level -- its declared purpose being to encourage farming by maintaining prices. Though suspended during great scarcities, the bounty still affects prices by preventing surplus years from offsetting deficit ones.
summary: The corn bounty raises prices in plentiful years through extraordinary exports and, by preventing surpluses from carrying over, also affects prices in scarce years. Its stated aim was to encourage farming by keeping prices high.
distilled: The corn bounty prevents the natural averaging of good and bad harvests by draining surpluses through subsidized exports.
notes: Smith identifies a key unintended consequence: by exporting surpluses in good years, the bounty removes the buffer that would otherwise moderate prices in bad years. -- This is an early articulation of what modern economists call intertemporal price stabilization -- the role of inventories in smoothing prices across periods. -- The distinction between the 'avowed end' and actual effects of policy is characteristic of Smith's critique of mercantilism.

refashioned: In both plentiful and scarce years, therefore, the bounty raises the price of corn above what it would naturally be given the actual state of agriculture. If the average price during the first sixty-four years of the present century has been lower than during the last sixty-four years of the previous century, it would have been much lower still, in the same state of farming, had it not been for the bounty's effect.
elegant: The bounty raises corn prices in all years -- plentiful and scarce alike. If eighteenth-century average prices are lower than seventeenth-century ones, they would have been lower still without the bounty.
summary: Since the bounty raises corn prices in all conditions, the observed decline in average prices from the seventeenth to the eighteenth century understates the true fall that would have occurred without the subsidy.
distilled: The decline in average corn prices between centuries would have been even greater without the artificial support of the export bounty.
notes: Smith is constructing a counterfactual argument -- reasoning about what prices would have been without the policy intervention. -- This analytical technique anticipates the modern economic concept of 'but for' analysis. -- The argument strengthens his case that silver's real value has been rising independently of the bounty's distortions.

refashioned: But without the bounty, some will argue, the state of agriculture would not have been the same. I shall attempt to explain the bounty's actual effects on agriculture later, when I treat the subject of bounties specifically. For now, I will only observe that this rise in silver's value relative to corn has not been peculiar to England. It has been observed in France during the same period and in nearly the same proportion, by three very reliable and diligent collectors of corn price data: Dupre de St. Maur, Messance, and the author of the Essay on the Police of Grain. But in France, until 1764, the exportation of grain was prohibited by law. It is rather difficult to suppose that nearly the same decline in corn's money price that occurred in one country despite a prohibition on exports should, in another country, be attributed to the extraordinary encouragement given to exports.
elegant: Some may argue that without the bounty, agriculture would have been different. But this rise in silver's value relative to corn is not unique to England -- it occurred in France in the same proportion, as documented by three reliable French scholars. Yet France prohibited grain exports until 1764. It is hard to argue that the same price decline occurred in one country because of export subsidies and in another despite an export ban.
summary: The rise in silver's value relative to corn occurred in both England and France to a similar degree, even though England subsidized grain exports while France prohibited them. This parallel undermines the argument that England's bounty caused the price change.
distilled: The fact that corn prices fell similarly in both England and France -- one subsidizing exports, the other prohibiting them -- proves the bounty was not the cause.
notes: This is a powerful natural experiment argument: two countries with opposite trade policies experienced the same price trend, suggesting an underlying cause independent of policy. -- Dupre de St. Maur, Messance, and the anonymous author Smith cites were important contributors to the emerging discipline of political arithmetic. -- The 'Essay on the Police of Grain' likely refers to Herbert's work. -- Smith's use of cross-national comparison as an analytical tool anticipates modern comparative economics.

refashioned: It would be more appropriate to regard this variation in the average money price of corn as the effect of some gradual rise in the real value of silver in the European market, rather than of any fall in the real average value of corn. As I have already observed, corn is a more accurate measure of value over long periods than either silver or perhaps any other commodity. When, after the discovery of America's abundant mines, corn rose to three or four times its former money price, this change was universally attributed not to any rise in the real value of corn, but to a fall in the real value of silver. If, therefore, during the first sixty-four years of the present century the average money price of corn has fallen somewhat below what it was during most of the previous century, we should likewise attribute this change not to any fall in the real value of corn, but to some rise in the real value of silver in the European market.
elegant: This decline in corn's money price is better explained by a gradual rise in silver's real value than by any fall in corn's real value. Corn is a more reliable long-term measure of value than silver. When American silver caused corn's money price to triple or quadruple, everyone attributed the change to silver's depreciation, not corn's appreciation. By the same logic, the recent fall in corn's money price should be attributed to silver's rising value, not corn's declining value.
summary: Changes in the money price of corn should be attributed to changes in the real value of silver rather than corn. Just as the post-discovery price explosion was understood as silver depreciating, the recent decline in corn prices reflects silver appreciating.
distilled: Corn is the more stable measure of real value; changes in its money price reflect shifts in silver's value, not its own.
notes: This passage states one of Smith's most important methodological principles: that corn (grain) is a better long-run measure of real value than silver. -- The reasoning parallels modern debates about choosing the right price deflator or numeraire. -- Smith's argument that we should attribute price changes to the more volatile commodity anticipates the modern distinction between real and nominal variables. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.3-1.11.7 for Smith's earlier discussion of corn as a value measure.

refashioned: The high price of corn over the past ten or twelve years has indeed raised suspicion that the real value of silver continues to fall in the European market. However, this high price appears clearly to have been caused by extraordinarily unfavorable seasons and should therefore be regarded as a temporary and occasional event, not a permanent one. For ten or twelve years, the seasons have been unfavorable across most of Europe, and the disorders in Poland have greatly increased the scarcity in countries that normally relied on Polish grain in dear years. Such a long run of bad seasons, though not very common, is by no means unheard of; anyone who has studied the history of corn prices will easily recall several similar episodes. Ten years of extraordinary scarcity are no more remarkable than ten years of extraordinary plenty. The low price of corn from 1741 to 1750, inclusive, may well be set against the high prices of the past eight or ten years. During 1741 to 1750, the average price of the best wheat at Windsor market was only about one pound, thirteen shillings, and ninepence -- nearly six shillings and threepence below the average for the century's first sixty-four years. The average price of middle wheat during those ten years comes out to only about one pound, six shillings, and eightpence.
elegant: Recent high corn prices have raised suspicion that silver's value continues falling. But these prices clearly resulted from a decade of bad seasons across Europe, worsened by Poland's political disorders disrupting grain supply -- a temporary event, not a permanent trend. Such runs of bad seasons have historical precedents, and ten years of scarcity are no more remarkable than ten years of plenty. The low corn prices from 1741 to 1750, well below the century's average, provide a natural counterpoint to the recent highs.
summary: The high corn prices of the 1760s were caused by bad weather and Polish political disruptions, not by a continuing decline in silver's value. This temporary scarcity has historical parallels, including the equally unusual period of low prices from 1741 to 1750.
distilled: Recent high corn prices reflect a temporary run of bad seasons, not a permanent decline in silver's value -- just as the unusually low prices of the 1740s reflected temporary abundance.
notes: The 'disorders of Poland' refer to the political instability preceding the First Partition of Poland (1772). Poland was a major grain exporter to Western Europe. -- Smith's argument distinguishes between short-term price volatility (driven by weather and politics) and long-term value trends (driven by monetary factors) -- a distinction fundamental to modern macroeconomics. -- The symmetry argument (bad decades are matched by good ones) reflects Smith's empirical temperament and resistance to drawing conclusions from limited samples.

refashioned: Between 1741 and 1750, however, the bounty must have prevented the price of corn from falling as low in the domestic market as it naturally would have. During those ten years, the quantity of all sorts of grain exported, according to custom-house records, amounted to no less than 8,029,156 quarters and one bushel. The bounty paid for this came to 1,514,962 pounds, seventeen shillings, and fourpence halfpenny. In 1749, Prime Minister Pelham observed to the House of Commons that a very extraordinary sum had been paid as bounty for corn exports over the preceding three years. He had good reason for this observation, and the following year would have given him even better reason: in that single year, the bounty paid amounted to no less than 324,176 pounds, ten shillings, and sixpence. It is unnecessary to point out how much this forced exportation must have raised the price of corn above what it would otherwise have been in the domestic market.
elegant: Between 1741 and 1750, the bounty prevented corn prices from falling as low as they naturally would have. Over eight million quarters of grain were exported during these years, with bounty payments exceeding 1.5 million pounds. In 1749, Prime Minister Pelham noted the extraordinary sums being paid; the following year's bounty alone exceeded 324,000 pounds. This forced exportation obviously raised domestic corn prices above their natural level.
summary: During the low-price decade of 1741-1750, the corn bounty subsidized massive grain exports -- over eight million quarters -- artificially preventing domestic prices from falling to their natural level. Prime Minister Pelham himself remarked on the extraordinary sums being spent.
distilled: Even during the cheap decade of the 1740s, the corn bounty drove massive subsidized exports that kept domestic prices artificially elevated.
notes: Henry Pelham (1694--1754) served as Prime Minister from 1743 to 1754. -- The scale of bounty payments (over 1.5 million pounds in a decade) illustrates the fiscal cost of agricultural price supports. -- Smith uses official customs records as empirical evidence -- characteristic of his evidence-based approach. -- The phrase 'forced exportation' reveals Smith's view that the bounty distorted natural trade patterns. -- Cross-reference: Book IV, Chapter 5.

refashioned: At the end of the accounts appended to this chapter, the reader will find the detailed figures for those ten years separated from the rest, along with the figures for the preceding ten years, whose average is also below -- though not as far below -- the general average for the century's first sixty-four years. The year 1740, however, was one of extraordinary scarcity. These twenty years before 1750 may well be compared with the twenty years before 1770. Just as the former period was considerably below the general century average, despite including one or two dear years, so the latter has been considerably above it, despite including one or two cheap years such as 1759. If the former period was not as far below the average as the latter has been above it, we should probably attribute the difference to the bounty. The change has clearly been too sudden to be explained by any shift in the value of silver, which always moves slowly and gradually. Only a cause that can operate suddenly -- the accidental variations of the seasons -- can account for the suddenness of the effect.
elegant: The twenty years before 1750 were below the century's average despite some dear years, while the twenty years before 1770 were above it despite some cheap ones. If the former period's deviation was smaller, the bounty likely accounts for the difference. The change was too sudden to reflect shifts in silver's value, which move slowly. Only seasonal variation can explain such rapid swings.
summary: Comparing the twenty years before 1750 with the twenty before 1770 reveals opposite deviations from the century's average. The asymmetry is attributable to the bounty, while the rapidity of the change points to seasonal variation rather than gradual monetary shifts.
distilled: Sudden price swings between decades must reflect seasonal variation, not slow-moving changes in silver's value -- and asymmetries between cheap and dear periods reflect the bounty's distortion.
notes: Smith employs comparative period analysis to separate the effects of policy (the bounty) from underlying value trends (silver) and short-term shocks (weather). -- The methodological principle that sudden effects require sudden causes, while gradual effects suggest gradual causes, is a form of causal reasoning Smith uses throughout. -- This passage demonstrates Smith's careful empiricism: he does not simply assert conclusions but builds them from data comparisons.

refashioned: The money price of labor in Great Britain has indeed risen during the present century. This, however, appears to be the effect not so much of any fall in silver's value in the European market, as of an increase in the demand for labor in Great Britain, arising from the great and nearly universal prosperity of the country. In France, a country not quite so prosperous, the money price of labor has been observed to decline gradually alongside the average money price of corn since the middle of the last century. In both the last century and the present, daily wages for common labor in France have reportedly remained at about one-twentieth of the average price of a septier of wheat -- a measure slightly larger than four Winchester bushels. In Great Britain, by contrast, the real compensation of labor -- the actual quantities of necessities and comforts given to the worker -- has increased considerably during the present century. The rise in money wages appears to be the effect not of any decline in silver's value across Europe generally, but of a rise in the real price of labor in the particular British market, owing to the country's uniquely favorable circumstances.
elegant: Money wages have risen in Britain this century, but this reflects increased demand for labor from national prosperity, not any decline in silver's value. In France, money wages have fallen with corn prices, remaining at about one-twentieth of wheat's price. In Britain, real wages -- the actual goods workers receive -- have increased considerably. The rise in British money wages reflects a genuine rise in labor's real price due to the country's uniquely favorable circumstances, not a European-wide decline in silver's value.
summary: Rising British money wages reflect genuine prosperity and increased labor demand, not declining silver value. French wages, by contrast, have tracked falling corn prices. Britain's uniquely favorable circumstances have produced a real increase in workers' purchasing power.
distilled: British money wages rose because the country's prosperity increased real demand for labor, not because silver lost value across Europe.
notes: This passage distinguishes between nominal wage increases (money wages) and real wage increases (purchasing power) -- a distinction central to modern labor economics. -- The comparison between Britain and France serves as a natural experiment: if silver's value were the cause, both countries would show similar wage trends. -- The 'septier' was a French unit of dry measure. -- Smith's observation that British workers received more 'necessaries and conveniencies' connects to his earlier discussion in chapters 1.8 on wages. -- The phrase 'peculiarly happy circumstances' reflects Smith's view that Britain's institutional framework -- property rights, rule of law, open internal markets -- was superior to France's.

refashioned: For some time after America was first discovered, silver would have continued to sell at or near its former price. Mining profits would have been very high for a while, well above their natural rate. But those who imported silver into Europe would soon have found that the entire annual supply could not be sold at that high price. Silver would gradually exchange for less and less in goods. Its price would sink lower and lower until it reached its natural price -- just enough to pay, at their natural rates, the wages of labor, the profits of stock, and the rent of land required to bring silver from the mine to the market. In most of Peru's silver mines, the king of Spain's tax, amounting to a tenth of gross output, consumes the entire rent of the land. This tax was originally one-half; it was then reduced to one-third, then to one-fifth, and finally to one-tenth, where it remains. In most Peruvian silver mines, this tenth is apparently all that remains after the mine operator replaces his capital along with its ordinary profits. It is universally acknowledged that these profits, once very high, are now as low as they can be while still keeping the mines in operation.
elegant: After America's discovery, silver initially sold at its old price, generating extraordinary mining profits. But as imports grew, silver gradually exchanged for fewer goods until its price fell to its natural level -- just enough to cover wages, profits, and rent at their natural rates. In most Peruvian silver mines, the king's tax (reduced over time from one-half to one-tenth of output) now absorbs the entire land rent, and mining profits are acknowledged to be at their minimum viable level.
summary: After the discovery of America, silver prices gradually fell from their initially high levels to a natural price that just covered production costs. In Peru's silver mines, the king's tax -- progressively reduced from one-half to one-tenth -- now absorbs all the land rent, and profits are at their minimum.
distilled: Silver's price fell gradually after America's discovery until it reached the natural price that just covers the costs of extraction -- wages, profits, and rent.
notes: This passage applies Smith's theory of natural price (from chapter 1.7) to the specific case of silver mining. -- The progressive reduction of the Spanish mining tax (from 1/2 to 1/10) illustrates the concept of diminishing rents as commodity prices fall. -- The three components of natural price -- wages, profits, and rent -- are the same framework Smith developed earlier for all commodities. -- The observation that mining profits have fallen to their minimum viable level suggests the silver market had reached long-run equilibrium. -- Cross-reference: 1.7 on natural vs. market price.

refashioned: The king of Spain's tax was reduced to one-fifth of registered silver in 1504, forty-one years before the discovery of the mines of Potosi in 1545. In the ninety years that followed -- that is, by 1636 -- these mines, the most productive in all the Americas, had had sufficient time to produce their full effect: to reduce the value of silver in the European market as low as it could fall while still bearing this tax. Ninety years is time enough to bring any commodity without a monopoly to its natural price -- the lowest price at which it can continue to be sold for any considerable time while still paying a particular tax.
elegant: The Spanish silver tax was reduced to one-fifth in 1504, forty-one years before Potosi's discovery. By 1636 -- ninety years later -- these enormously productive mines had fully depressed European silver values to the lowest level sustainable under that tax. Ninety years suffices to bring any non-monopolized commodity to its natural price.
summary: By 1636, ninety years after the discovery of Potosi, silver had reached its natural price in Europe -- the lowest level at which it could be sustainably produced while paying the Spanish crown's one-fifth tax.
distilled: Ninety years after Potosi's discovery, silver had fallen to its natural price -- the minimum sustainable level under the Spanish tax.
notes: Potosi (in modern Bolivia) was discovered in 1545 and became the single largest source of silver in the world. -- Smith's concept of natural price as the long-run equilibrium price is applied here to precious metals mining. -- The ninety-year timeframe represents Smith's estimate of how long it takes for a major supply shock to fully work through the market. -- Cross-reference: 1.7 on natural price theory.

refashioned: The price of silver in the European market might have fallen still lower, and it might have become necessary either to reduce the tax further -- not merely to one-tenth as in 1736, but to one-twentieth like the gold tax -- or to abandon the greater part of the American mines currently in operation. The gradual increase in the demand for silver, arising from the gradual expansion of the market for the produce of the American silver mines, is probably what has prevented this from happening. This growing demand has not only maintained silver's value in the European market but has perhaps even raised it somewhat above where it stood around the middle of the last century.
elegant: Silver's price might have fallen further, forcing either deeper tax cuts or mine closures. What prevented this was the gradual expansion of demand for silver as its market grew. This growing demand has not only maintained silver's value but may have raised it somewhat above mid-seventeenth-century levels.
summary: The gradual expansion of the global market for silver has prevented its price from falling low enough to force further tax reductions or mine closures, and may have actually raised silver's value above mid-seventeenth-century levels.
distilled: Growing global demand for silver has sustained its value and prevented the mine closures or tax reductions that would otherwise have been necessary.
notes: Smith identifies demand growth as the countervailing force against the natural tendency of abundant supply to depress prices. -- This anticipates the market expansion argument he develops in the next several paragraphs about Europe, America, and Asia as three expanding markets for silver. -- The interaction of supply (mine output) and demand (market expansion) determining price is classical supply-demand analysis.

refashioned: Since the discovery of America, the market for the produce of its silver mines has been growing gradually more extensive. First, the European market itself has expanded. Since the discovery of America, most of Europe has improved considerably. England, Holland, France, and Germany -- even Sweden, Denmark, and Russia -- have all advanced significantly in both agriculture and manufactures. Italy does not appear to have gone backward; its decline preceded the conquest of Peru, and since then it seems to have somewhat recovered. Spain and Portugal are indeed supposed to have declined, but Portugal is only a very small part of Europe, and Spain's decline is perhaps not as great as commonly imagined. At the start of the sixteenth century, Spain was a very poor country, even compared to France, which has itself improved so much since then. As Emperor Charles V, who traveled frequently through both countries, famously observed: everything abounded in France, but everything was wanting in Spain. The increasing output of European agriculture and manufactures necessarily required a gradual increase in the quantity of silver coin to circulate it, and the growing number of wealthy individuals required a similar increase in their silver plate and other silver ornaments.
elegant: Since America's discovery, the market for its silver has been steadily expanding. First, the European market has grown: England, Holland, France, Germany, and even Scandinavia and Russia have advanced in agriculture and manufactures. Even Spain's decline may be exaggerated -- Charles V himself noted that Spain was poor compared to France. Growing European production required more silver coin for circulation, and rising wealth demanded more silver plate and ornaments.
summary: The European market for silver has expanded steadily since America's discovery, driven by agricultural and manufacturing growth across the continent. More economic activity required more silver coin for circulation, and greater wealth created demand for silver luxury goods.
distilled: Europe's expanding economy since America's discovery has continuously increased demand for silver -- both as money for circulation and as material for luxury goods.
notes: This begins Smith's three-part analysis of expanding silver markets: Europe, the Americas, and Asia. -- Emperor Charles V (1500--1558) ruled both Spain and the Holy Roman Empire, giving him direct experience of both countries. -- Smith's observation that Spain was poor even before its supposed decline challenges the mercantilist narrative that Spain's problems came from losing its gold and silver. -- The distinction between silver as coin (medium of exchange) and silver as plate (store of value/luxury) reflects the dual nature of precious metals in this era.

refashioned: Second, America is itself a new market for the produce of its own silver mines. Since its advances in agriculture, industry, and population are much more rapid than those of the most thriving European countries, its demand must be growing much faster. The English colonies represent an entirely new market that, partly for coin and partly for plate, requires a continually increasing supply of silver across a vast continent where no such demand previously existed. Most of the Spanish and Portuguese colonies are likewise entirely new markets. New Granada, the Yucatan, Paraguay, and Brazil were, before European discovery, inhabited by peoples who had neither arts nor agriculture. Both have now been introduced to some considerable degree throughout these regions. Even Mexico and Peru, though not entirely new markets, are certainly far more extensive ones than they ever were before. Despite all the wonderful tales told about the splendor of these civilizations in ancient times, anyone who reads the history of their discovery and conquest with sober judgment will see that their inhabitants were far more backward in arts, agriculture, and commerce than the Tartars of the Ukraine are today. Even the Peruvians, the more civilized of the two nations, though they used gold and silver as ornaments, had no coined money whatsoever. Their entire commerce was conducted by barter, and there was accordingly scarcely any division of labor among them. Those who cultivated the ground were obliged to build their own houses, make their own clothing, shoes, and farming tools.
elegant: Second, America itself is a new market for its own silver, with demand growing faster than any European country's. The English colonies need ever more silver coin and plate across a continent that previously had no such demand. Most Spanish and Portuguese colonies are equally new markets. Despite romanticized accounts, pre-Columbian Mexico and Peru were far less advanced than commonly imagined -- even the Peruvians had no coined money and conducted all trade by barter, with virtually no division of labor.
summary: The Americas constitute a rapidly growing new market for silver, driven by colonization and economic development across a continent that previously had virtually no monetary economy. Even the supposedly advanced pre-Columbian civilizations had no coined money and almost no division of labor.
distilled: The Americas -- a continent that previously had no monetary economy -- represent an enormous and rapidly growing new source of demand for silver.
notes: Smith debunks romanticized accounts of pre-Columbian civilization, using the absence of coined money and division of labor as evidence of economic underdevelopment. -- The connection between money, division of labor, and economic advancement is a core Smithian theme established in Book I, chapters 1-4. -- New Granada corresponds roughly to modern Colombia, Venezuela, and Ecuador. -- Smith's assessment of pre-Columbian economies, while reflecting eighteenth-century European perspectives, correctly identifies the absence of coined money as a significant economic feature.

refashioned: The few artisans among them are said to have been maintained entirely by the sovereign, the nobles, and the priests, and were probably their servants or slaves. All the ancient arts of Mexico and Peru never furnished a single manufacture to Europe. The Spanish armies, though they rarely exceeded five hundred men and frequently numbered less than half that, found great difficulty obtaining provisions almost everywhere they went. The famines they reportedly caused in countries simultaneously described as highly populous and well cultivated are sufficient proof that the stories of such dense population and high cultivation are largely fictitious.
elegant: Pre-Columbian artisans were maintained by rulers and priests as servants or slaves. All the arts of Mexico and Peru never produced a single manufacture for Europe. Spanish armies of no more than a few hundred men struggled everywhere to find provisions -- and the famines they caused in supposedly populous, well-cultivated lands expose those accounts of prosperity as largely fictitious.
summary: The claims of pre-Columbian prosperity are undermined by the facts: their arts produced nothing for European trade, and tiny Spanish armies caused widespread famines in lands supposedly teeming with people and agriculture.
distilled: The inability of supposedly advanced pre-Columbian civilizations to feed small Spanish armies exposes romanticized accounts of their prosperity as fiction.
notes: Smith uses a logical argument from evidence: if these civilizations were truly populous and well-cultivated, tiny Spanish armies could not have caused famines. -- The observation that pre-Columbian artisans were maintained as servants of the elite, not independent producers, illustrates the absence of a market economy. -- Smith is implicitly arguing that the Spanish narratives of conquest exaggerated pre-Columbian wealth to enhance their own achievement. -- This skeptical empiricism is characteristic of the Scottish Enlightenment.

refashioned: The Spanish colonies operate under a government that is, in many respects, less favorable to agriculture, improvement, and population growth than that of the English colonies. Nevertheless, they appear to be advancing in all these areas more rapidly than any country in Europe. In a fertile soil and favorable climate, the great abundance and cheapness of land -- a circumstance common to all new colonies -- seems to be so great an advantage that it compensates for many defects in civil government. Frezier, who visited Peru in 1713, described Lima as containing between twenty-five and twenty-eight thousand inhabitants. Ulloa, who lived in the same country between 1740 and 1746, reported it as containing more than fifty thousand.
elegant: Though the Spanish colonies suffer worse governance than the English ones, they advance faster than any European country. In fertile soil with cheap, abundant land, the advantages common to all new colonies compensate for poor government. Lima's population reportedly doubled from around twenty-five thousand in 1713 to over fifty thousand by the 1740s.
summary: Despite inferior governance, Spanish colonies grew faster than European countries thanks to abundant cheap land. Lima's population apparently doubled in just thirty years, illustrating the power of favorable conditions to overcome institutional defects.
distilled: Abundant cheap land in the colonies compensated for poor governance, enabling growth rates that surpassed any European country.
notes: This passage illustrates a key Smithian principle: natural advantages (land, climate) can outweigh institutional disadvantages (bad governance), at least in the short to medium term. -- Amedee-Francois Frezier (1682--1773) was a French military engineer and traveler. -- Antonio de Ulloa (1716--1795) was a Spanish naval officer and scientist. -- Smith's comparison of English and Spanish colonial governance foreshadows his extensive analysis of colonial systems in Book IV. -- The rapid population growth supports Smith's argument about expanding silver demand in the Americas.

refashioned: The differences in their accounts of the populations of several other principal towns in Chile and Peru are nearly the same. Since there is no reason to doubt the reliability of either observer, this indicates growth scarcely inferior to that of the English colonies. America is therefore a new market for the produce of its own silver mines, and its demand must be increasing much more rapidly than that of the most thriving country in Europe.
elegant: Multiple observers confirm similar population growth across major towns in Chile and Peru -- growth rates nearly matching those of the English colonies. America's demand for its own silver is therefore growing faster than demand in any European country.
summary: Population growth data from multiple reliable observers confirms that Spanish American colonies were growing at rates approaching those of the English colonies, driving rapidly expanding demand for silver.
distilled: The rapid growth of American colonial populations created a fast-expanding new market for the continent's own silver output.
notes: Smith's use of independent corroborating sources (Frezier and Ulloa) demonstrates his commitment to empirical verification. -- The comparison between English and Spanish colonial growth rates reinforces the argument that natural advantages can partially offset institutional differences. -- This completes Smith's second market (the Americas) in his three-part analysis of expanding silver demand.

refashioned: Third, the East Indies is another market for the produce of the American silver mines, and one that has been absorbing an ever-increasing quantity of silver since those mines were first discovered. The direct trade between America and the East Indies, conducted through the Acapulco ships, has been continually growing, and the indirect trade via Europe has been expanding in an even greater proportion. During the sixteenth century, the Portuguese were the only European nation conducting regular trade with the East Indies.
elegant: Third, the East Indies has been absorbing ever more American silver since the mines' discovery. Direct trade via the Acapulco ships and indirect trade through Europe have both expanded continuously. In the sixteenth century, only Portugal traded regularly with the East Indies.
summary: The East Indies represents a third expanding market for American silver, with both the direct Acapulco trade route and the indirect European route carrying increasing quantities of the metal since the sixteenth century.
distilled: The East Indies has been absorbing growing quantities of American silver through both direct and indirect trade routes since the sixteenth century.
notes: The Acapulco ships (Manila Galleons) were Spanish trading vessels that sailed between Acapulco, Mexico and Manila, Philippines from 1565 to 1815 -- one of the first regular transpacific trade routes. -- This begins Smith's analysis of the third and largest expanding market for silver. -- The East India trade is central to understanding global silver flows in this period, as Asia was a persistent net importer of silver. -- Cross-reference: Smith's later discussion of East India trade in Book IV.

refashioned: In the closing years of that century, the Dutch began to encroach upon this monopoly and within a few years expelled the Portuguese from their principal settlements in India. During most of the seventeenth century, these two nations divided the bulk of the East India trade between them, with the Dutch share continually growing in greater proportion than the Portuguese share declined. The English and French conducted some trade with India in the seventeenth century, but it expanded greatly during the present one. The Swedish and Danish East India trades began during the present century. Even the Russians now trade regularly with China, by means of caravans traveling overland through Siberia and Tartary to Peking.
elegant: The Dutch displaced the Portuguese from key Indian settlements and, with them, dominated seventeenth-century East India trade. English and French trade, modest in the seventeenth century, expanded greatly in the eighteenth. Sweden, Denmark, and even Russia (via overland caravans to Peking) have since entered the trade. The number of European nations trading with Asia has steadily multiplied.
summary: European trade with the East Indies expanded from a Portuguese monopoly in the sixteenth century to include the Dutch, English, French, Swedes, Danes, and even Russians by the eighteenth century, with each nation's trade volume continually growing.
distilled: The number of European nations trading with Asia multiplied steadily from the sixteenth to the eighteenth century, expanding the channel through which silver flowed eastward.
notes: The Dutch displacement of the Portuguese in Asia (early 1600s) represents one of the major geopolitical shifts of the early modern period. -- The VOC (Dutch East India Company, founded 1602) and EIC (English East India Company, founded 1600) were among the world's first major joint-stock corporations. -- Russian trade with China via Siberia was formalized by the Treaty of Kyakhta (1727). -- Smith's enumeration of trading nations illustrates the progressive integration of global markets.

refashioned: The East India trade of all these nations, with the exception of the French -- whose trade was nearly destroyed by the last war -- has been almost continuously expanding. The growing consumption of East India goods in Europe is apparently so great as to provide increasing employment for all of them. Tea, for example, was a commodity scarcely used in Europe before the middle of the last century. At present, the value of tea annually imported by the English East India Company for domestic consumption alone amounts to more than a million and a half pounds a year. Even this is not enough: a great deal more is constantly smuggled into the country from the ports of Holland, from Gothenburg in Sweden, and from the coast of France -- at least while the French East India Company was still prosperous.
elegant: The East India trade has been expanding for every European nation except France, whose trade the last war nearly destroyed. European demand for Asian goods grows fast enough to sustain them all. Tea, scarcely used in Europe before the mid-seventeenth century, now generates over 1.5 million pounds in annual imports for England alone -- with much more smuggled in from Holland, Sweden, and France.
summary: European demand for East India goods has expanded so rapidly that it sustains the growing trade of almost every European nation. Tea alone went from near-zero European consumption to over 1.5 million pounds in annual English imports, supplemented by extensive smuggling.
distilled: European appetite for Asian goods like tea expanded so enormously that it sustained the growing East India trade of nearly every European nation simultaneously.
notes: The 'last war' refers to the Seven Years' War (1756--1763), which devastated the French East India Company. -- Tea's transformation from exotic rarity to mass commodity is one of the great consumption revolutions of the eighteenth century. -- Smuggling from Holland, Sweden, and France illustrates how high tariffs create incentives for illegal trade -- a recurring theme in Smith's critique of trade restrictions. -- Gothenburg (Goteborg) was a major Swedish port and base for the Swedish East India Company (founded 1731).

refashioned: The consumption of Chinese porcelain, of spices from the Moluccas, of Bengali textiles, and of innumerable other articles has increased in nearly the same proportion. The total tonnage of all European shipping employed in the East India trade at any one time during the last century was probably not much greater than that of the English East India Company alone before its recent reduction of shipping.
elegant: Consumption of Chinese porcelain, Moluccan spices, Bengali textiles, and countless other Asian goods has grown similarly. All European shipping employed in the East India trade during the entire seventeenth century was probably no larger than the English East India Company's fleet alone before its recent downsizing.
summary: European consumption of Asian goods -- porcelain, spices, textiles -- has grown enormously, to the point where the English East India Company's modern fleet alone rivals the total European East India shipping of the previous century.
distilled: European demand for Asian goods grew so rapidly that one nation's fleet in the eighteenth century matched all of Europe's East India shipping in the seventeenth.
notes: The Moluccas (Maluku Islands, in modern Indonesia) were the original 'Spice Islands' -- the sole source of cloves, nutmeg, and mace. -- Bengal was the center of the global textile trade, producing fine cotton and silk fabrics. -- The comparison of one company's modern fleet to the previous century's total European fleet powerfully illustrates the scale of trade expansion. -- The 'recent reduction of shipping' refers to changes in the EIC's operations in the 1760s-70s.

refashioned: But in the East Indies, particularly in China and India, the value of precious metals was much higher when Europeans first began trading there than it was in Europe -- and it remains so. In rice-growing countries, which typically yield two and sometimes three crops per year, each more plentiful than any ordinary grain harvest, the abundance of food must be much greater than in any grain-growing country of equal size. Such countries are accordingly much more populous. The wealthy in these countries, having a much larger surplus of food beyond what they can personally consume, have the means to purchase a far greater quantity of other people's labor.
elegant: In the East Indies, especially China and India, precious metals were -- and remain -- more valuable than in Europe. Rice countries yield two or three annual crops, each more abundant than any grain harvest, making them far more populous. Their wealthy, with vast food surpluses, can command far more labor than their European counterparts.
summary: Precious metals command higher value in Asia than in Europe because rice-growing countries produce far more food per acre, supporting larger populations and enabling the wealthy to accumulate enormous surpluses of labor-purchasing power.
distilled: The higher productivity of rice cultivation makes Asian countries more populous and precious metals more valuable there than in grain-growing Europe.
notes: Smith's analysis of rice vs. grain productivity connects agricultural systems to population density, wealth distribution, and the relative value of precious metals -- a remarkably integrated chain of reasoning. -- The observation that rice yields multiple annual crops while grain yields one was well established in eighteenth-century accounts of Asian agriculture. -- The argument that food surplus determines the ability to command labor is central to Smith's theory of wealth and distribution. -- Cross-reference: 1.8 and 1.11 on food as the ultimate determinant of real value.

refashioned: The retinue of a grandee in China or India is, by all accounts, far more numerous and splendid than that of the wealthiest subjects in Europe. The same superabundance of food enables them to give a greater quantity of it for all those singular and rare products that nature furnishes only in very small quantities -- such as precious metals and precious stones, the great objects of competition among the rich. Therefore, even if the mines supplying the Indian market had been as abundant as those supplying Europe, such commodities would naturally exchange for a greater quantity of food in India than in Europe.
elegant: Asian grandees maintain far larger retinues than the richest Europeans, thanks to their greater food surpluses. This same surplus enables them to bid more for naturally scarce items like precious metals and gemstones. Even with equally abundant mines, such commodities would exchange for more food in India than in Europe.
summary: The enormous food surpluses of Asian elites allow them to outbid Europeans for scarce luxury goods like precious metals and gemstones, which is why these commodities command higher value in Asia regardless of mine output.
distilled: Asian elites' greater food surpluses give them more purchasing power for scarce luxuries, making precious metals inherently more valuable in Asia than Europe.
notes: Smith explains the higher Asian value of precious metals through supply and demand: greater surplus wealth competing for inherently scarce goods drives prices up. -- The 'retinue' comparison illustrates wealth differences in terms of commanded labor, consistent with Smith's labor theory of value. -- 'The great objects of the competition of the rich' -- Smith recognizes that luxury goods prices are driven by competitive bidding among the wealthy, an early insight into what Veblen would later call conspicuous consumption.

refashioned: But the mines supplying the Indian market with precious metals appear to have been considerably less abundant, while those supplying it with precious stones appear to have been considerably more abundant, than the mines supplying the European market. Precious metals would therefore naturally exchange in India for a somewhat greater quantity of precious stones and for a much greater quantity of food than in Europe. The money price of diamonds -- the greatest of all superfluities -- would be somewhat lower, and that of food -- the first of all necessities -- a great deal lower in India than in Europe.
elegant: India's mines produced fewer precious metals but more precious stones than Europe's. Consequently, precious metals exchanged in India for more gems and far more food than in Europe, while diamond prices were lower and food prices much lower in India than in Europe.
summary: India had fewer precious metal mines but richer gemstone mines than Europe, so precious metals bought more food and more gems in India, while diamonds and food were both cheaper there in money terms.
distilled: Scarcer metal mines and richer gemstone mines in India made precious metals relatively more valuable and diamonds relatively cheaper there than in Europe.
notes: This passage illustrates how relative scarcity determines relative prices across markets -- a fundamental principle of trade theory. -- India's famous diamond mines (particularly Golconda) were the world's primary source of diamonds until Brazilian deposits were discovered in the 1720s. -- The contrast between 'the greatest of all superfluities' (diamonds) and 'the first of all necessaries' (food) echoes Smith's famous water-diamond paradox from 1.4. -- Cross-reference: 1.4 on use value vs. exchange value.

refashioned: But the real price of labor -- the actual quantity of necessities given to the worker -- is lower in both China and India, the two great markets of the East, than in most of Europe. Wages there will purchase a smaller quantity of food. And since the money price of food is much lower in India than in Europe, the money price of labor is lower on a double account: both because it purchases less food and because that food itself is cheaper in money terms.
elegant: Real wages -- the actual necessities given to workers -- are lower in China and India than in Europe. Money wages are even lower on two counts: workers receive less food, and that food costs less in money terms.
summary: Workers in China and India receive less food than European workers, and that food costs less in money terms, making Asian money wages lower than European ones on both counts.
distilled: Asian money wages are doubly low: workers receive less food, and food itself is cheaper in money terms.
notes: Smith distinguishes real wages (goods received) from money wages (nominal payment) -- a distinction fundamental to labor economics. -- The 'double account' of low Asian wages anticipates modern discussions of purchasing power parity. -- Despite Asia's greater food production, workers receive less because the surplus is captured by elites -- an implicit observation about distribution. -- Cross-reference: 1.8 on wages and the real price of labor.

refashioned: But in countries of comparable skill and industry, the money price of most manufactures will be proportional to the money price of labor. In manufacturing skill and industry, China and India, though somewhat inferior, do not seem greatly inferior to any part of Europe. The money price of most manufactures is therefore naturally much lower in these great empires than anywhere in Europe. Across most of Europe, moreover, the cost of land transport substantially increases both the real and nominal price of most manufactures: it costs more labor, and therefore more money, to bring first the raw materials and then the finished goods to market. In China and India, the extent and variety of inland waterways save the greater part of this labor and money, reducing both the real and nominal price of most manufactures still further. For all these reasons, precious metals have always been, and continue to be, an extremely profitable commodity to carry from Europe to India.
elegant: Since manufacturing skill is roughly comparable, lower wages make Asian manufactures much cheaper than European ones. European land transport also inflates prices, while China and India benefit from extensive inland waterways that reduce costs further. For all these reasons, precious metals remain extremely profitable to ship from Europe to India.
summary: Lower labor costs and superior inland waterways make Asian manufactures much cheaper than European ones, which is why precious metals -- commanding higher relative value in Asia -- have always been among the most profitable goods to export from Europe to India.
distilled: Low wages, cheap manufactures, and extensive waterways in Asia make precious metals the most profitable European export to India.
notes: Smith identifies three factors making silver profitable to export eastward: lower Asian wages, cheaper Asian manufactures, and lower Asian transport costs from waterways. -- The emphasis on inland navigation as a cost advantage connects to his earlier discussion in 1.3 about the role of water transport in extending markets. -- This helps explain the persistent flow of silver from Europe to Asia that characterized global trade for centuries. -- Cross-reference: 1.3 on the importance of water transport for commerce.

refashioned: There is scarcely any commodity that fetches a better price there, or that, in proportion to the labor and goods it costs in Europe, will purchase a greater quantity of labor and goods in India. It is also more advantageous to carry silver than gold to India, because in China and most other Indian markets the ratio between fine silver and fine gold is only ten or at most twelve to one, whereas in Europe it is fourteen or fifteen to one. In China and most of India, ten or at most twelve ounces of silver will buy an ounce of gold; in Europe, it takes fourteen to fifteen ounces.
elegant: No commodity fetches a better return in India relative to its European cost than precious metals. Silver is even more profitable to export than gold, because the silver-to-gold ratio in Asia is ten or twelve to one, compared to fourteen or fifteen to one in Europe -- meaning silver buys proportionally more gold in Asia.
summary: Precious metals offer the highest return of any commodity exported to India relative to European costs, and silver is more profitable to export than gold because the silver-to-gold ratio is lower in Asia than in Europe.
distilled: Silver is the most profitable commodity to export from Europe to Asia because it commands relatively more purchasing power -- and proportionally more gold -- there.
notes: The different gold-silver ratios between Europe and Asia created a persistent arbitrage opportunity that drove global silver flows eastward for centuries. -- In Europe: 1 oz gold = 14-15 oz silver. In Asia: 1 oz gold = 10-12 oz silver.
