This means silver was relatively more valuable in Asia. -- This arbitrage is a key mechanism in early modern global monetary history. -- The silver-gold ratio differences reflect different relative supplies in each region (abundant American silver in Europe vs. relatively less silver reaching Asia).

refashioned: In the cargoes of most European ships sailing to India, silver has therefore generally been one of the most valuable items. It is the most valuable article in the Acapulco ships sailing to Manila. The silver of the New World seems, in this way, to be one of the principal commodities by which trade between the two extremities of the Old World is conducted. It is largely by means of this silver that these distant parts of the world are connected to one another.
elegant: Silver has been the most valuable article in most European cargoes to India and in the Acapulco ships to Manila. American silver thus serves as the principal medium connecting the two ends of the Old World in trade, linking distant regions of the globe.
summary: American silver is the principal commodity linking global trade, connecting Europe with Asia both through direct European shipping and through the Acapulco-Manila route. It serves as the medium of exchange that binds the world's distant regions together.
distilled: American silver is the connective tissue of global trade, linking the two extremities of the Old World through both European and transpacific commerce.
notes: This is one of Smith's most globally-minded passages, recognizing silver as the first truly global commodity connecting the Americas, Europe, and Asia. -- The Acapulco-Manila Galleon trade (1565--1815) was one of the longest-running trade routes in history. -- Smith anticipates modern world-systems theory in identifying silver as the medium linking disparate economic regions. -- The phrase 'the two extremities of the old one' (Europe and East Asia) connected by 'the new continent' (America) captures the triangular structure of early modern global commerce.

refashioned: To supply so vastly extended a market, the quantity of silver annually extracted from the mines must be sufficient not only to support the continued increase in both coin and plate required in all thriving countries, but also to replace the continual waste and consumption of silver that occurs in every country where the metal is used.
elegant: Supplying this vast global market requires annual mine output sufficient not only to meet growing demand for coin and plate in thriving countries, but also to replace the constant wear and consumption of silver everywhere it is used.
summary: The global silver supply must meet two demands simultaneously: the growing need for new coin and plate as economies expand, and the replacement of silver constantly lost through wear and industrial consumption.
distilled: Global silver production must cover both growing demand in expanding economies and the constant replacement of metal lost through wear and use.
notes: Smith identifies two components of silver demand: the extensive margin (growing economies needing more) and the replacement margin (wear, loss, and industrial consumption). -- This framework anticipates the modern economic distinction between net investment and depreciation. -- The observation that even durable metals suffer continual consumption sets up his next detailed discussion of the many ways silver is lost.

refashioned: The continual wearing away of precious metals in coins, and in plate through both wearing and cleaning, is very noticeable. For commodities so widely used, this alone would require a very substantial annual supply. The consumption of these metals in certain specific manufactures, though perhaps no greater in total than this gradual wearing away, is much more conspicuous because it is much more rapid. In the manufactures of Birmingham alone, the quantity of gold and silver annually used in gilding and plating -- and thereby permanently removed from circulation as recognizable metals -- is said to exceed fifty thousand pounds sterling. From this we may form some idea of how great the annual consumption must be across all parts of the world, whether in Birmingham-type manufactures or in laces, embroideries, gold and silver fabrics, the gilding of books and furniture, and so on. A considerable quantity must also be annually lost in transporting these metals by sea and land. In most Asian governments, moreover, the nearly universal custom of burying treasures underground -- the knowledge of whose location frequently dies with the person who concealed them -- must occasion the loss of still greater quantities.
elegant: Precious metals are continually consumed through coin wearing, plate cleaning, and industrial use. Birmingham alone uses over fifty thousand pounds of gold and silver annually in gilding and plating. Worldwide consumption in similar manufactures, laces, embroideries, and gilding must be enormous. Additional losses occur through transport accidents and, in Asia, through the widespread custom of burying treasure whose location dies with the owner.
summary: Silver and gold are continuously consumed through coin wear, plate cleaning, industrial gilding, textile manufacturing, transport losses, and the Asian practice of burying treasure. Birmingham's manufactures alone consume over fifty thousand pounds sterling annually, suggesting enormous global attrition.
distilled: Precious metals are consumed relentlessly through wear, industrial use, transport losses, and buried treasure -- requiring vast annual production merely to maintain existing stocks.
notes: Birmingham was already England's industrial metalworking center in Smith's time -- the forerunner of its later reputation as the 'workshop of the world.' -- The observation about buried Asian treasure reflects both a real practice and European fascination with it. -- Smith's catalogue of silver consumption channels is remarkably comprehensive: monetary wear, plate maintenance, industrial transformation, transport loss, and hoarding. -- This analysis supports his argument that silver supply may barely keep pace with total demand, explaining why its value has not continued to fall.

refashioned: The quantity of gold and silver imported through both Cadiz and Lisbon -- including not only what is registered but what is believed to be smuggled -- amounts, according to the best accounts, to about six million pounds sterling per year. According to Mr. Meggens, the annual importation of precious metals into Spain (averaged over six years from 1748 to 1753) and into Portugal (averaged over seven years from 1747 to 1753) amounted to 1,101,107 pounds weight in silver and 49,940 pounds weight in gold. The silver, at sixty-two shillings per pound troy, comes to 3,413,431 pounds and ten shillings sterling. The gold, at forty-four and a half guineas per pound troy, comes to 2,333,446 pounds and fourteen shillings sterling. Together they total 5,746,878 pounds and four shillings sterling. The registered figures, he assures us, are exact, and he provides detailed breakdowns of the specific locations from which the gold and silver originated and the particular quantities each produced according to the register. He also makes an allowance for what he estimates was smuggled. The great experience of this judicious merchant gives his opinion considerable weight.
elegant: Annual gold and silver imports through Cadiz and Lisbon, including estimated smuggling, total about six million pounds sterling. Meggens' detailed accounts for 1747-1753 show roughly 3.4 million in silver and 2.3 million in gold, totaling nearly 5.75 million pounds sterling from registered sources plus smuggling allowances. His exactness regarding registered quantities and his detailed source breakdowns give his estimates considerable authority.
summary: Annual precious metal imports into Spain and Portugal totaled roughly six million pounds sterling, according to detailed accounts by the merchant Meggens covering 1747-1753, including allowances for smuggling beyond the registered amounts.
distilled: Europe received approximately six million pounds sterling in gold and silver annually through Cadiz and Lisbon, based on detailed trade records and smuggling estimates.
notes: Cadiz and Lisbon were the two great entry points for American precious metals into Europe, reflecting Spain's and Portugal's colonial mining operations. -- Mr. Meggens' data represents the kind of empirical trade statistics Smith valued highly. -- The smuggling allowance acknowledges that official figures systematically understated actual flows. -- The split between silver (roughly 60%) and gold (roughly 40%) is notable. -- The postscript correction Smith mentions illustrates the challenges of accurate economic data in this period.

refashioned: According to the eloquent, and sometimes well-informed, author of the Philosophical and Political History of the Europeans in the Two Indies, the annual importation of registered gold and silver into Spain, averaged over eleven years from 1754 to 1764, amounted to 13,984,185 and three-fifths piastres of ten reals. Including smuggling, the whole annual importation may have reached seventeen million piastres, which at four shillings and sixpence per piastre equals 3,825,000 pounds sterling. He too provides details of the sources and quantities. He further informs us that if we judge Brazil's annual gold exports to Lisbon by the king of Portugal's tax -- one-fifth of the standard metal -- we might value them at eighteen million cruzadoes, or forty-five million French livres, equal to about two million pounds sterling. Adding an eighth for smuggling brings the total to about 2,250,000 pounds sterling. According to this account, the whole annual importation of precious metals into both Spain and Portugal amounts to roughly 6,075,000 pounds sterling.
elegant: The author of the History of the Europeans in the Two Indies estimates Spain's annual registered precious metal imports at nearly fourteen million piastres, or with smuggling about 3.825 million pounds sterling. Brazil's gold exports to Lisbon, estimated from the Portuguese king's one-fifth tax plus smuggling, total about 2.25 million pounds sterling. Combined, annual imports into Spain and Portugal reach roughly 6.075 million pounds sterling.
summary: A second independent estimate, from Raynal's History, puts total annual precious metal imports into Spain and Portugal at roughly 6.075 million pounds sterling, closely matching Meggens' figure of about six million.
distilled: Two independent estimates converge on approximately six million pounds sterling as the annual flow of precious metals from the Americas into Spain and Portugal.
notes: The 'eloquent, and sometimes well-informed' author is Guillaume Thomas Raynal (1713--1796), whose Histoire philosophique et politique was enormously influential but sometimes criticized for inaccuracy -- hence Smith's backhanded compliment. -- The convergence of Meggens' and Raynal's estimates around six million pounds strengthens the figure's reliability. -- The Portuguese tax of one-fifth on Brazilian gold allows indirect estimation of total output -- a clever use of fiscal data. -- Piastres, cruzadoes, and livres illustrate the multiplicity of currencies in European commerce.

refashioned: Several other well-authenticated, though unpublished, accounts I have been told also put this total annual importation at roughly six million pounds sterling on average -- sometimes a little more, sometimes a little less. The annual importation into Cadiz and Lisbon, however, does not represent the entire annual output of the American mines. Some portion is sent annually by the Acapulco ships to Manila; some is used in the contraband trade that the Spanish colonies carry on with those of other European nations; and some, no doubt, remains in the Americas. Besides, the American mines are by no means the world's only gold and silver mines -- though they are by far the most abundant. The output of all other known mines is acknowledged to be insignificant by comparison, and the far greater part of American output is likewise acknowledged to flow annually into Cadiz and Lisbon. But Birmingham's consumption alone, at fifty thousand pounds per year, equals one hundred and twentieth of this annual importation at six million. The total annual global consumption of gold and silver may therefore be nearly equal to the total annual production. The surplus may barely suffice to meet the increasing demand of all thriving countries -- and may even have fallen short of that demand, thereby somewhat raising the price of these metals in the European market.
elegant: Multiple manuscript accounts confirm annual imports of roughly six million pounds sterling. This does not represent total American output, since some silver goes to Manila, some to contraband colonial trade, and some stays in America. Other mines exist but are insignificant by comparison. Yet if Birmingham alone consumes one-hundred-and-twentieth of the total annual import, global consumption of precious metals may nearly equal global production. The surplus may barely supply growing demand in thriving countries -- or may even fall short, raising metal prices in Europe.
summary: Total annual precious metal production may be nearly matched by global consumption through wear, industrial use, and loss. What remains may barely meet the growing demand of expanding economies, which could explain why silver's value has been rising in the European market.
distilled: Global gold and silver consumption may nearly equal annual production, leaving barely enough surplus to meet the expanding demand of growing economies.
notes: Smith's calculation is striking: if Birmingham alone consumes 1/120th of annual imports, and there are many more such consumers worldwide, total consumption could absorb most or all of annual production. -- This is an early example of what economists now call stock-flow analysis: the relationship between the accumulated stock of a commodity and its annual production and consumption flows. -- The contraband trade between Spanish colonies and other European settlements illustrates how trade restrictions generate black markets. -- The conclusion that supply may barely meet demand supports Smith's thesis that silver's value has been gently rising.

refashioned: The quantity of brass and iron annually brought from mines to market is vastly greater than that of gold and silver. Yet we do not on that account suppose that these base metals will multiply beyond demand or grow gradually cheaper. Why should we suppose the precious metals will? The base metals, though harder, are put to much harder uses, and being less valuable, less care is taken in preserving them. The precious metals, however, are not immortal either: they too can be lost, wasted, and consumed in a great variety of ways.
elegant: We do not expect brass and iron to become endlessly cheaper despite their far greater annual production, because they are consumed through hard use. Why assume precious metals will? Though more carefully preserved, gold and silver are also subject to loss, waste, and consumption in many forms.
summary: Just as no one expects iron and brass to become perpetually cheaper despite enormous production, there is no reason to assume gold and silver will either. All metals are consumed through use, regardless of how carefully they are preserved.
distilled: The assumption that precious metals must continually depreciate is no more logical than assuming iron or brass will -- all metals are consumed through use.
notes: Smith uses analogy to challenge the common assumption that precious metal abundance necessarily means depreciation. -- The comparison between base and precious metals highlights that durability is a matter of degree, not kind. -- This challenges the quantity theory of money in its simplest form: more metal does not necessarily mean lower value if consumption keeps pace. -- The argument reflects Smith's consistent empiricism: he tests popular assumptions against observable patterns.

refashioned: The price of all metals, though subject to slow and gradual changes, varies less from year to year than that of almost any other raw product of the land. The price of precious metals is even less prone to sudden variation than that of base metals. The durability of metals is the foundation of this extraordinary price stability. The corn brought to market last year will be entirely or almost entirely consumed long before this year ends. But some of the iron brought from the mine two or three hundred years ago may still be in use, and perhaps some of the gold mined two or three thousand years ago as well. The different quantities of corn that must supply the world's consumption in different years will always be roughly proportional to each year's harvest. But the proportion between the different quantities of iron in use in two different years will be very little affected by any accidental difference in those two years' mine output; and the proportion between quantities of gold will be even less affected. Though the output of most metallic mines varies from year to year perhaps even more than that of most cornfields, these variations do not have the same effect on the price of metals as they do on the price of corn.
elegant: Metal prices vary less annually than almost any other raw commodity, and precious metals vary least of all. This stability stems from durability: last year's corn is consumed within months, but iron may last centuries and gold millennia. Annual mine output variations barely affect the vast accumulated stock of metals in existence, whereas each year's corn supply depends almost entirely on that year's harvest.
summary: The durability of metals gives them extraordinary price stability compared to perishable goods like corn. While each year's corn supply depends on that year's harvest, the stock of metals in use reflects centuries or millennia of accumulated production, making annual output variations relatively insignificant.
distilled: Metals enjoy extraordinary price stability because their accumulated stock from centuries of production dwarfs any single year's output variation.
notes: This is a brilliant insight about stock-flow dynamics: for durable goods, the existing stock dominates the flow of new production in determining price. -- The corn-iron-gold comparison illustrates increasing durability and correspondingly increasing price stability. -- This analysis anticipates modern commodity pricing theory, which distinguishes between 'flow' commodities (agricultural) and 'stock' commodities (metals). -- The principle explains why gold remains remarkably stable as a store of value over long periods. -- Cross-reference: modern economics of buffer stocks and inventory-driven commodity pricing.

refashioned: Variations in the Proportion between the Respective Values of Gold and Silver. Before the discovery of the American mines, the value of fine gold to fine silver was regulated in different European mints at between one to ten and one to twelve -- that is, an ounce of fine gold was considered worth ten to twelve ounces of fine silver. By about the middle of the last century, it had come to be regulated at between one to fourteen and one to fifteen -- an ounce of fine gold was considered worth fourteen to fifteen ounces of fine silver. Gold rose in its nominal value, or in the quantity of silver given for it. Both metals fell in their real value, or in the quantity of labor they could purchase, but silver fell more than gold. Although both the gold and silver mines of America exceeded in fertility all previously known mines, the silver mines had apparently been proportionally even more fertile than the gold mines.
elegant: Before America's discovery, the gold-to-silver ratio was between 1:10 and 1:12 across European mints. By the mid-seventeenth century, it had shifted to 1:14 or 1:15. Gold rose in nominal terms (buying more silver), while both metals fell in real terms (buying less labor) -- but silver fell further. America's silver mines, though both were extraordinarily fertile, had apparently been proportionally more productive than its gold mines.
summary: The discovery of American mines shifted the gold-silver ratio from about 1:10-12 to 1:14-15, as silver's real value fell more sharply than gold's. This reflected the disproportionately greater fertility of American silver mines compared to gold mines.
distilled: American silver mines were proportionally more fertile than gold mines, causing silver to lose more real value and shifting the gold-silver ratio from roughly 1:11 to 1:14.5.
notes: The gold-silver ratio is one of the most important monetary parameters in pre-modern economics. -- The shift from 1:10-12 to 1:14-15 reflects the massive influx of American silver, particularly from Potosi. -- Smith carefully distinguishes between nominal changes (gold buys more silver) and real changes (both buy less labor), showing that the relative shift was within a context of absolute decline for both metals. -- This analysis is relevant to bimetallic monetary systems, where the mint ratio could diverge from the market ratio, causing one metal to drive the other from circulation (Gresham's Law).

refashioned: The large quantities of silver carried annually from Europe to India have, in some English settlements, gradually reduced silver's value relative to gold. In the mint of Calcutta, an ounce of fine gold is valued at fifteen ounces of fine silver, the same as in Europe. This may actually be too high for the prevailing market value in Bengal. In China, the gold-to-silver ratio remains at one to ten or one to twelve. In Japan, it is reportedly one to eight.
elegant: European silver exports to India have gradually altered local ratios. At the Calcutta mint, gold is valued at fifteen times silver, matching Europe -- possibly overvaluing gold for the Bengal market. In China the ratio remains 1:10-12, and in Japan reportedly 1:8.
summary: Silver's value relative to gold varies significantly across Asia: the Calcutta mint matches Europe's 1:15 ratio (possibly overvaluing gold locally), while China maintains 1:10-12 and Japan reportedly 1:8.
distilled: European silver exports to Asia have begun converging Asian gold-silver ratios toward European levels, though significant regional differences persist.
notes: The convergence of the Calcutta mint ratio toward the European ratio illustrates how trade flows equalize prices across markets -- a precursor to the law of one price. -- Japan's extremely low ratio (1:8) reflects its relative isolation and different mineral endowments. -- The persistence of different ratios across Asian markets despite ongoing trade shows that price convergence is gradual and incomplete, especially across large distances with limited arbitrage. -- The Calcutta mint ratio being 'too high' for Bengal suggests a divergence between official mint prices and market prices.

refashioned: According to Mr. Meggens' account, the proportion between the quantities of gold and silver annually imported into Europe is about one to twenty-two -- that is, for every ounce of gold, a little more than twenty-two ounces of silver are imported. The large quantity of silver sent annually to the East Indies, he supposes, reduces the quantities of these metals remaining in Europe to a ratio of one to fourteen or fifteen -- the ratio of their values. He appears to think that the ratio of values must necessarily match the ratio of quantities, and would therefore be one to twenty-two were it not for this greater exportation of silver.
elegant: Meggens notes that Europe imports gold and silver in a ratio of roughly 1:22 by weight. He supposes that silver exports to Asia reduce European stocks to a 1:14-15 ratio matching market values. He seems to believe that value ratios must equal quantity ratios, and only the silver drain to Asia prevents a 1:22 value ratio.
summary: Meggens observed that Europe imports silver and gold in a 1:22 quantity ratio, and believed the silver drain to Asia was all that prevented the value ratio from matching. Smith implies this reasoning is flawed.
distilled: Meggens mistakenly assumed that the value ratio between gold and silver must match their import quantity ratio, failing to understand that value is determined by more than relative quantities.
notes: Smith is setting up a critique of what economists would later call the quantity theory in its crudest form -- the idea that relative values are simply determined by relative quantities. -- Meggens' error illustrates a common mercantilist confusion between quantity and value. -- Smith will correct this reasoning in the following paragraphs. -- The 1:22 import ratio vs. 1:14-15 value ratio shows a significant divergence that cannot be explained by simple quantity reasoning.

refashioned: But the ordinary proportion between the values of two commodities is not necessarily the same as the proportion between the quantities of them commonly in the market. The price of an ox, reckoned at ten guineas, is about sixty times the price of a lamb at three shillings and sixpence. It would be absurd, however, to infer that there are normally sixty lambs in the market for every one ox. And it would be just as absurd to infer that because an ounce of gold commonly purchases fourteen or fifteen ounces of silver, there are normally only fourteen or fifteen ounces of silver in the market for every ounce of gold.
elegant: The value ratio between two goods need not match their quantity ratio in the market. An ox costs sixty times as much as a lamb, but no one infers there are sixty lambs for every ox in the market. Equally, the fact that gold is worth fourteen times silver does not mean there are only fourteen ounces of silver per ounce of gold.
summary: Value ratios between commodities do not reflect their quantity ratios in the market. Just as an ox costing sixty times a lamb does not mean sixty lambs exist per ox, gold being worth fifteen times silver does not mean only fifteen ounces of silver exist per ounce of gold.
distilled: Price ratios between commodities do not reflect their relative quantities -- a point as obvious with oxen and lambs as it should be with gold and silver.
notes: Smith uses a brilliantly simple analogy (oxen and lambs) to demolish a common error in monetary reasoning. -- This corrects the crude quantity theory that equates relative values with relative supplies. -- Value depends on both supply and demand, not supply alone -- a principle Smith understands clearly even without formal supply-demand diagrams. -- This passage anticipates the marginalist revolution's insight that price reflects marginal utility and scarcity together, not just quantity.

refashioned: The quantity of silver commonly in the market is probably much greater in proportion to that of gold than the value of gold is to that of silver. The total quantity of a cheap commodity brought to market is usually not only greater but of greater total value than the total quantity of a dear one. The total quantity of bread annually brought to market is not only greater in volume but greater in total value than the total quantity of butcher's meat; the total quantity of butcher's meat exceeds that of poultry in both volume and value; and poultry exceeds wild fowl.
elegant: The quantity of silver in the market is probably far greater relative to gold than the gold-silver price ratio suggests. Cheap commodities typically come to market in greater total quantity and greater total value than dear ones: more bread than meat, more meat than poultry, more poultry than wild fowl -- in both volume and value.
summary: Cheap commodities come to market in greater total quantity and greater total value than expensive ones. Bread exceeds meat, meat exceeds poultry, and poultry exceeds wild fowl in both volume and total value -- a pattern that applies equally to silver relative to gold.
distilled: Cheaper commodities come to market in greater total quantity and total value than dearer ones, so the market contains far more silver than a simple price ratio with gold would suggest.
notes: Smith establishes an empirical regularity: cheaper goods have both greater quantity and greater total market value than dearer goods. -- This insight anticipates the concept of price elasticity of demand -- cheaper goods tend to have more purchasers and broader markets. -- The bread-meat-poultry-wild fowl hierarchy is a memorable illustration. -- Applied to precious metals: silver's lower unit price means the total stock of silver in circulation far exceeds that of gold in both weight and value.

refashioned: There are so many more buyers for the cheap commodity than for the dear one that not only a greater quantity but a greater total value can be sold. The total quantity of the cheap commodity must therefore be greater in proportion to the total quantity of the dear one than the value of a given amount of the dear one is to the value of an equal amount of the cheap one. When we compare the precious metals, silver is the cheap commodity and gold the dear one. We should naturally expect, therefore, that there should always be in the market not only a greater quantity but a greater total value of silver than of gold. Let anyone who has some of each compare their own silver plate with their gold plate, and they will probably find that not only the quantity but the value of the former greatly exceeds the latter. Many people, moreover, have considerable silver plate but no gold plate at all, and even those who have it generally confine it to watch-cases, snuff-boxes, and similar trinkets of no great total value.
elegant: Cheap goods attract more buyers, enabling greater sales in both quantity and value. Silver being the cheap and gold the dear precious metal, there should naturally be more silver than gold in the market -- not just in quantity but in total value. Anyone comparing their own silver and gold plate will find the silver far exceeds the gold in both measures, and many people own silver plate but no gold at all.
summary: Because cheap goods attract more buyers, the total market value of silver exceeds that of gold, just as the total value of bread exceeds that of meat. Most people own far more silver plate than gold, and many own no gold at all.
distilled: Silver's total market value exceeds gold's because cheaper goods attract more buyers and generate larger total sales.
notes: Smith's argument that total market value is inversely related to unit price (for commonly used goods) is an important economic insight. -- The appeal to personal experience ('let any man compare his own silver with his gold plate') is a rhetorical device Smith uses effectively to ground abstract arguments in everyday observation. -- This passage effectively refutes the crude quantity-value equivalence that Meggens assumed. -- The observation about gold plate being confined to trinkets reflects the social reality of eighteenth-century material culture.

refashioned: In the British coin, indeed, the value of gold greatly preponderates, but this is not the case everywhere. In some countries, the value of the two metals in coin is nearly equal. In the Scottish coin before the union with England, gold preponderated very little, though it did somewhat. In many countries, silver preponderates in the coinage. In France, the largest sums are commonly paid in silver, and it is difficult there to obtain more gold than what is needed to carry about in one's pocket.
elegant: Gold dominates British coinage by value, but not all countries' coinage. In pre-Union Scotland, gold barely preponderated. In many countries silver dominates, and in France, large payments are typically made in silver, with gold used only for pocket money.
summary: While gold dominates British coinage by value, this pattern is not universal. In pre-Union Scotland gold barely exceeded silver, and in France and many other countries, silver is the dominant medium for large transactions.
distilled: Gold's dominance in British coinage is exceptional; in most countries, silver serves as the primary medium of exchange even for large transactions.
notes: The variation in gold-silver coinage ratios across countries reflects different monetary policies and trade patterns. -- Pre-Union Scottish coinage (before 1707) was a distinct monetary system. -- France's reliance on silver for large transactions illustrates the bimetallic standard's practical operation. -- Smith's reference to Ruddiman's Preface to Anderson's Diplomata shows his characteristic attention to documentary sources. -- The variation undermines any simple generalization about which metal is 'more important' in monetary systems.

refashioned: The superior value of silver plate over gold plate, which holds in all countries, more than compensates for the preponderance of gold coin over silver coin that holds only in some countries. Though in one sense silver always has been and probably always will be much cheaper than gold, in another sense gold may perhaps, in the present state of the Spanish market, be said to be somewhat cheaper than silver. A commodity may be called dear or cheap not only according to the absolute level of its usual price, but according to whether that price is more or less above the lowest price at which it can be brought to market for any considerable time. This lowest price is the one that barely replaces the capital employed in bringing the commodity to market, together with a moderate profit.
elegant: Silver plate's greater total value in all countries more than offsets gold coin's greater value in some. But 'cheapness' has two meanings: absolute price level, and proximity to the minimum sustainable price. In the latter sense, gold in the Spanish market may actually be cheaper than silver -- its price is closer to the bare minimum needed to cover production costs with moderate profit.
summary: Cheapness can be measured either by absolute price or by how close a price is to the minimum sustainable level. By the second measure, gold in the Spanish market may actually be cheaper than silver because gold's price sits closer to its cost-covering minimum.
distilled: Gold may be 'cheaper' than silver in the economic sense that its market price is closer to the minimum needed to sustain production.
notes: Smith introduces a sophisticated definition of cheapness: not absolute price but price relative to the natural minimum (cost of production plus normal profit). -- This anticipates the modern economic concept of economic rent -- the surplus above the minimum price needed to keep a resource in production. -- By this measure, a high-priced good can be 'cheap' if it yields little surplus over cost, while a low-priced good can be 'dear' if it yields large surplus. -- Cross-reference: 1.7 on natural price as the cost-covering minimum.

refashioned: This is the price that affords nothing to the landlord -- in which rent forms no component part -- and which resolves itself entirely into wages and profit. In the present state of the Spanish market, gold is certainly somewhat nearer to this lowest price than silver. The king of Spain's tax on gold is only one-twentieth of the standard metal, or five percent, whereas his tax on silver amounts to one-tenth, or ten percent. These taxes, as I have already observed, constitute the entire rent of the greater part of the gold and silver mines of Spanish America, and the tax on gold is even less well paid than that on silver.
elegant: The minimum sustainable price includes only wages and profit, with no rent component. In the Spanish market, gold is closer to this minimum than silver: the king's tax (which constitutes virtually all mine rent) is only 5% on gold versus 10% on silver, and even the gold tax is poorly paid.
summary: Gold is closer than silver to its minimum sustainable price in the Spanish market, as evidenced by the lower tax rate (5% vs. 10%) and the fact that even this lower tax is poorly collected -- indicating that gold mining generates less economic surplus above costs.
distilled: Gold mining in Spanish America operates closer to the break-even point than silver mining, as shown by its lower tax rate and poorer tax compliance.
notes: Smith decomposes price into its three components (wages, profit, rent) and shows that gold's price contains less rent than silver's. -- The mining tax serving as a proxy for rent is an elegant analytical device. -- Poor tax compliance on gold suggests mines are barely profitable -- they cannot afford to pay even the reduced tax. -- This analysis uses the concept of economic rent to measure the 'cheapness' of production. -- Cross-reference: 1.6 on the components of price; 1.11.148 on the progressive reduction of the Spanish mining tax.

refashioned: The profits of gold mine operators, since they less frequently make fortunes, must generally be even more modest than those of silver mine operators. The price of Spanish gold, therefore, as it yields both less rent and less profit, must in the Spanish market be somewhat nearer to the lowest price for which it can be brought to market than the price of Spanish silver. When all costs are reckoned, it would seem that the entire quantity of gold cannot be sold in the Spanish market as advantageously as the entire quantity of silver.
elegant: Gold miners make fortunes less often than silver miners, implying lower average profits. Spanish gold yields less rent and less profit than silver, making its price closer to the production minimum. Overall, gold is a less profitable commodity to bring to market than silver.
summary: Gold mining is less profitable than silver mining in Spanish America, yielding lower rents, lower profits, and fewer fortunes. Gold's market price therefore sits closer to its cost-covering minimum than silver's does.
distilled: Gold mining is less profitable than silver mining, placing gold's market price closer to the bare minimum needed to sustain production.
notes: The observation that gold miners 'more rarely make a fortune' is an empirical claim about the distribution of mining returns. -- Lower average profits in gold mining could reflect either less productive mines or less favorable geology. -- Smith's conclusion that gold is 'cheaper' than silver in the economic sense (closer to its natural minimum price) inverts the common intuition based on absolute price. -- This analysis demonstrates the practical application of natural price theory to real commodity markets.

refashioned: The king of Portugal's tax on Brazilian gold is, however, the same as the old Spanish tax on silver from Mexico and Peru: one-fifth of the standard metal. It may therefore be uncertain whether, in the general European market, the total mass of American gold comes at a price closer to its minimum sustainable level than the total mass of American silver.
elegant: However, Portugal taxes Brazilian gold at one-fifth -- the same as Spain's old silver tax -- so it remains uncertain whether, across the European market as a whole, gold is really produced closer to its minimum sustainable price than silver.
summary: The Portuguese tax on Brazilian gold (one-fifth) is higher than Spain's current silver tax (one-tenth), making it uncertain whether gold is truly closer to its minimum sustainable price than silver when the entire European market is considered.
distilled: Portugal's higher tax on Brazilian gold introduces uncertainty about whether gold is truly cheaper to produce than silver across the European market as a whole.
notes: Smith introduces an important qualification: the conclusion about gold being 'cheaper' depends on which specific mines and tax regimes you examine. -- The higher Portuguese tax on gold vs. the lower Spanish tax on silver shows that institutional factors (tax policy) interact with natural factors (mine productivity) in complex ways. -- This passage illustrates Smith's intellectual honesty in acknowledging the limits of his own argument. -- The distinction between the Spanish market and the general European market matters because metals from different colonial sources enter through different channels.

refashioned: The price of diamonds and other precious stones may perhaps be even closer to the lowest price at which they can be brought to market than the price of gold. Though it is unlikely that any part of a tax on silver -- imposed upon one of the most appropriate subjects of taxation, a mere luxury, and yielding such important revenue -- will ever be given up so long as it can be paid, the same inability to pay that made it necessary to reduce the tax from one-fifth to one-tenth in 1736 may in time require still further reductions, just as it forced the reduction of the gold tax to one-twentieth. It is universally acknowledged that the silver mines of Spanish America, like all other mines, are becoming gradually more expensive to work, because of the greater depths at which operations must be carried on and the greater expense of pumping water and supplying fresh air at those depths.
elegant: Diamond prices may sit even closer to their production minimum than gold's. Meanwhile, though the silver tax revenue is too important to abandon voluntarily, rising mining costs may eventually force further reductions. Spain's silver mines are universally acknowledged to be growing more expensive as they go deeper, requiring more costly drainage and ventilation.
summary: Diamond prices may be even closer to their minimum sustainable level than gold's. Silver mining costs are rising as mines go deeper, requiring more expensive drainage and ventilation, which may eventually force further tax reductions.
distilled: Rising costs in deeper silver mines may eventually force further tax reductions, while diamond prices may already sit at the very floor of sustainable production.
notes: The observation that mines become more expensive at greater depths is a fundamental principle of extractive economics -- mining exhibits increasing marginal costs. -- Rising extraction costs for silver represent a form of diminishing returns in mining. -- The comparison with diamonds suggests a hierarchy of 'cheapness' (proximity to cost floor): diamonds closest, then gold, then silver. -- The political economy observation that governments will not voluntarily abandon revenue-producing taxes connects economic analysis to institutional realities. -- Cross-reference: Ricardo later developed the theory of diminishing returns in mining more formally.

refashioned: These causes, which are equivalent to a growing scarcity of silver -- for a commodity may be said to grow scarcer when it becomes more difficult and expensive to collect a given quantity of it -- must in time produce one of three outcomes. The increased expense must either be compensated entirely by a proportional increase in the metal's price; or it must be compensated entirely by a proportional reduction in the tax on silver; or it must be compensated partly by one and partly by the other. This third outcome is very possible. Just as gold rose in price relative to silver despite a great reduction in the gold tax, so silver might rise in price relative to labor and commodities despite an equal reduction in the silver tax.
elegant: Rising extraction costs amount to growing scarcity, since a commodity is effectively scarcer when it costs more to produce. This must lead to one of three outcomes: higher silver prices, lower silver taxes, or some combination of both. Just as gold's price rose despite a large tax reduction, silver's price could rise even while its tax falls.
summary: Rising silver mining costs create effective scarcity that must be resolved through higher prices, lower taxes, or a combination. The precedent of gold -- whose price rose even as its tax was cut -- shows that both adjustments can occur simultaneously.
distilled: Rising mining costs create effective silver scarcity that must be compensated by higher prices, lower taxes, or both -- as the precedent of gold demonstrates.
notes: Smith defines scarcity in terms of production cost rather than absolute quantity -- a sophisticated economic insight. -- The three possible adjustments (price up, tax down, or both) represent a clear analytical framework for thinking about supply-side constraints. -- The gold precedent serves as an empirical test case for the theory. -- This passage anticipates the concept of cost-push inflation in modern economics. -- The interaction between tax policy and commodity prices illustrates how institutional and market forces jointly determine outcomes.

refashioned: Such successive tax reductions, however, though they may not entirely prevent the rise in silver's value, must certainly slow it down. As a result of such reductions, many mines that could not previously have been profitably worked -- because they could not afford the old tax -- can now be operated. The quantity of silver annually brought to market must always be somewhat greater, and therefore the value of any given quantity somewhat less, than it otherwise would have been. As a result of the 1736 reduction, the value of silver in the European market, though perhaps not lower today than before the reduction, is probably at least ten percent lower than it would have been had Spain continued to exact the old tax. That silver's value has nevertheless begun to rise somewhat during the present century is what the facts and arguments presented above lead me to believe -- or more properly, to suspect and conjecture. For the best opinion I can form on this subject scarcely deserves the name of belief. The rise, supposing there has been one, has been so very small that, after all that has been said, it may still appear to many people uncertain not only whether silver's value has actually risen, but whether it may not in fact still be falling.
elegant: Tax reductions slow silver's rising value by enabling previously unprofitable mines to operate, increasing supply. The 1736 tax cut probably left silver's value at least ten percent lower than it would otherwise be. Despite this, the evidence suggests silver's value has begun rising slightly this century -- though Smith admits this is more suspicion than conviction, and the rise, if any, has been so small that reasonable people may disagree about whether it has occurred at all.
summary: Tax reductions on silver mining have slowed but not prevented a slight rise in silver's value by enabling more mines to operate. Smith candidly admits that his conclusion about silver's rising value is more conjecture than certainty, given the smallness of the change.
distilled: Tax reductions have slowed silver's appreciation by expanding supply, but Smith suspects a slight rise in silver's value has nonetheless occurred -- though he admits this is more conjecture than certainty.
notes: Smith's intellectual honesty in qualifying his own conclusion ('scarce deserves the name of belief') is remarkable and characteristic. -- The mechanism by which tax cuts increase supply (enabling marginal mines to operate) is a straightforward application of supply theory. -- The ten percent estimate for the tax cut's effect shows Smith attempting quantitative reasoning about policy impacts. -- Smith's frank acknowledgment of uncertainty stands in sharp contrast to the dogmatic claims of many of his contemporaries. -- This passage models the epistemic humility that Smith considered essential to good economic reasoning.

refashioned: It must be observed, however, that whatever the supposed annual importation of gold and silver may be, there must come a point at which annual consumption equals annual importation. Consumption must increase as the total stock increases -- indeed, in a much greater proportion. As the stock grows, the metals lose value; they are used more freely, cared for less, and consequently consumed at a faster rate relative to their mass. After a certain point, therefore, annual consumption must come to equal annual importation, provided that importation is not continually increasing -- which in the present times it is not supposed to be.
elegant: At some point, annual precious metal consumption must equal annual importation. As the total stock grows, falling value leads to more careless use, so consumption rises faster than the stock itself. This equilibrium between consumption and importation will eventually be reached, provided imports are not continually increasing.
summary: Annual precious metal consumption must eventually equal annual importation because as stocks grow and values fall, the metals are used more freely and wasted more readily, accelerating consumption until it matches supply.
distilled: Precious metal consumption naturally rises to match importation because declining value leads to more careless use, creating an equilibrium between supply and waste.
notes: Smith describes a self-correcting mechanism: abundance reduces value, which increases waste, which limits abundance. -- This is an early description of what systems theorists would call negative feedback or homeostasis. -- The insight that lower value leads to less careful treatment is psychologically astute and economically significant. -- The assumption that imports are not continually increasing is important -- if they were, the equilibrium would never be reached. -- This analysis supports Smith's broader argument that silver's value need not fall indefinitely.

refashioned: If, once annual consumption has come to equal annual importation, the importation should then gradually diminish, consumption may for some time continue to exceed importation. The total stock of these metals may gradually and imperceptibly shrink, and their value may gradually and imperceptibly rise, until the annual importation, becoming stable again, allows consumption to gradually and imperceptibly adjust to what that importation can sustain.
elegant: If importation declines after reaching equilibrium with consumption, the stock will gradually shrink and values will imperceptibly rise until consumption adjusts downward to match the new, lower level of importation.
summary: If precious metal imports decline after reaching equilibrium with consumption, the existing stock gradually shrinks and values slowly rise until consumption adjusts downward to match the reduced supply.
distilled: When precious metal imports decline, rising value gradually reduces consumption until a new equilibrium is reached at a lower level of both supply and waste.
notes: Smith describes the adjustment dynamics of a commodity market moving from one equilibrium to another -- an early example of comparative statics. -- The emphasis on 'gradually and insensibly' reflects Smith's understanding that monetary adjustments happen slowly, making them difficult to observe in real time. -- This explains why debates about silver's value are so contentious: the changes are too slow for easy empirical detection. -- The passage completes Smith's theoretical framework for understanding long-run precious metal values.

refashioned: Grounds for the Suspicion that the Value of Silver Still Continues to Decrease. The increase of wealth in Europe, together with the popular notion that as the quantity of precious metals naturally increases with wealth, so their value diminishes as their quantity increases, may dispose many people to believe that the value of precious metals continues to fall in the European market. The still gradually increasing price of many raw products of the land may confirm them further in this opinion.
elegant: Many believe silver's value continues falling, based on two ideas: that growing European wealth increases the quantity of precious metals, and that more metal means less value. The rising prices of many raw products seem to confirm this view.
summary: The popular belief that silver's value continues declining rests on two assumptions: that wealth increases the quantity of precious metals, and that greater quantity means lower value. Rising prices for raw products seem to support this view.
distilled: The popular belief in silver's continuing depreciation rests on the assumption that wealth increases metal quantity, which reduces value -- reinforced by rising raw product prices.
notes: This section heading ('Grounds of the Suspicion') signals Smith's shift to examining and rebutting the opposing view. -- The 'popular notion' Smith describes is essentially the quantity theory of money in its simplest form. -- Smith will argue that rising raw product prices reflect real changes in those products' value, not declining silver value. -- The rhetorical structure -- presenting the opposing view fairly before dismantling it -- is characteristic of Smith's argumentative method.

refashioned: I have already tried to show that the increase in the quantity of precious metals arising from a country's growing wealth has no tendency to diminish their value. Gold and silver naturally flow to a rich country for the same reason that all kinds of luxuries and curiosities do: not because they are cheaper there than in poorer countries, but because they are dearer -- because a better price is offered for them. It is the superiority of price that attracts them, and as soon as that superiority ceases, they necessarily cease to flow there.
elegant: As I have argued, increasing national wealth does not diminish the value of precious metals. Gold and silver flow to rich countries not because they are cheap there, but because they are dear -- the higher price attracts them. When the price advantage disappears, so does the flow.
summary: Precious metals flow to wealthy countries because they command higher prices there, not lower ones. The very fact that metals are attracted to rich countries proves that wealth does not diminish their value -- it increases it locally.
distilled: Gold and silver flow to rich countries because they are worth more there, not less -- disproving the notion that wealth diminishes the value of precious metals.
notes: Smith inverts the popular reasoning: metals flowing to wealthy countries proves their value is higher there, not lower. -- This is an application of the principle that goods move from where they are cheap to where they are dear. -- The argument parallels modern trade theory's explanation of capital flows. -- Smith had made this argument earlier in the chapter and is now deploying it as a rebuttal to the 'declining silver value' thesis. -- Cross-reference: Smith's earlier discussion of how precious metals distribute themselves across the globe.

refashioned: If we except corn and similar crops raised entirely by human industry, I have already tried to show that all other sorts of raw produce -- cattle, poultry, game of all kinds, useful fossils and minerals, and so forth -- naturally become dearer as society advances in wealth and improvement. Though such commodities come to exchange for a greater quantity of silver than before, it does not follow that silver has become really cheaper, or that it will purchase less labor. Rather, these commodities have become really dearer: they will purchase more labor than before. It is not merely their nominal price but their real price that rises with improvement. The rise in their nominal price is the effect not of any degradation in silver's value, but of the rise in their real price.
elegant: Except for grain, most raw products -- cattle, game, minerals -- naturally grow dearer as society advances. That they exchange for more silver does not mean silver is cheaper; it means these goods are genuinely more valuable, commanding more labor. Their rising nominal price reflects rising real price, not declining silver value.
summary: Most raw products naturally become more expensive as economies develop, not because silver loses value but because these goods genuinely become scarcer and more valuable relative to the labor needed to produce them.
distilled: Rising raw product prices reflect genuine increases in their real value, not declining silver value -- it is the commodities that have grown dearer, not the money that has grown cheaper.
notes: Smith carefully distinguishes between nominal price changes (more silver per unit) and real price changes (more labor per unit). -- The exception for corn is important: Smith argues that corn's real value remains relatively stable over time because agricultural technology can scale with demand. -- The argument that raw products grow genuinely scarcer with development anticipates the modern concept of Ricardian scarcity rent. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.193 for Smith's classification of raw products by their response to development.

refashioned: Different Effects of the Progress of Improvement upon Three Different Sorts of Raw Produce. These different sorts of raw produce may be divided into three classes. The first includes those which human industry can scarcely multiply at all. The second includes those which it can multiply in proportion to demand. The third includes those in which the power of industry is either limited or uncertain. In the progress of wealth and improvement, the real price of the first class may rise to any degree of extravagance and seems not to be limited by any fixed boundary. The real price of the second class, though it may rise greatly, has a definite ceiling beyond which it cannot long remain. The real price of the third class, though its natural tendency is to rise with improvement, may at any given stage of improvement sometimes actually fall, sometimes stay the same, and sometimes rise more or less, depending on how successfully human industry manages to increase the supply.
elegant: Raw produce falls into three classes based on how human industry affects supply. The first (impossible to multiply) can rise in price without limit. The second (multiplicable in proportion to demand) can rise significantly but has a natural ceiling. The third (limited or uncertain multiplicability) tends to rise with improvement but may fluctuate depending on the success of efforts to increase supply.
summary: Smith classifies raw products into three categories: those that cannot be multiplied by human effort (unlimited price potential), those that can be multiplied proportionally to demand (limited price rise), and those where human effort has uncertain effects on supply (variable price behavior).
distilled: Raw products divide into three classes by how well human industry can increase supply, which determines whether their prices can rise without limit, up to a ceiling, or unpredictably.
notes: This tripartite classification is one of Smith's most original analytical frameworks. -- First class (wild game, rare fish): fixed supply with elastic demand leads to potentially unlimited price increases. -- Second class (cattle, grain): reproducible supply with a price ceiling set by the cost of cultivation. -- Third class (wool, hides): supply constrained by byproduct relationships and uncertain productivity. -- This taxonomy anticipates the modern economic distinction between renewable, reproducible, and exhaustible resources. -- The framework structures the remaining analysis of specific commodities.

refashioned: First Sort -- The first class of raw produce whose price rises with improvement consists of those things that human industry can scarcely multiply at all. These are things that nature produces only in limited quantities and that, being highly perishable, cannot be accumulated from one season to the next. Such are the greater part of rare and singular birds and fishes, many different sorts of game, almost all wild fowl, and all migratory birds in particular, as well as many other things. When wealth, and the luxury that accompanies it, increase, the demand for these is likely to increase as well, and no amount of human effort may be able to increase the supply much beyond what it was before the demand rose.
elegant: The first class consists of goods nature produces in fixed quantities that cannot be accumulated across seasons: rare birds and fish, game, wild fowl, migratory birds. As wealth and luxury grow, demand for these rises while supply remains essentially fixed, with no amount of human industry able to increase it significantly.
summary: The first category of raw produce includes rare, perishable wild products whose supply nature fixes and human industry cannot expand. As wealth grows and luxury demand increases for these items, their prices can rise without limit.
distilled: Rare wild products that nature supplies in fixed, perishable quantities face unlimited price increases as wealth-driven demand rises against an inelastic supply.
notes: This first category represents what economists now call perfectly inelastic supply -- no amount of price increase can elicit more production. -- The perishability constraint prevents stockpiling from smoothing supply across seasons. -- Examples like migratory birds and rare fish have modern parallels in discussions of endangered species and unsustainable harvesting. -- The connection between rising wealth, increased luxury demand, and price escalation for fixed-supply goods anticipates Veblen's analysis of luxury consumption. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.195 for historical examples of extreme prices for such goods.

refashioned: The quantity of such commodities remaining the same or nearly the same, while competition to purchase them continually increases, their price may rise to any degree of extravagance without any fixed limit. If woodcocks were to become so fashionable as to sell for twenty guineas apiece, no amount of human effort could increase the number brought to market much beyond present levels. The high prices that the Romans paid at the height of their grandeur for rare birds and fish can easily be explained in this way. These prices were not the effect of low silver value in those times but of the high value placed on such rarities that human industry could not multiply at will.
elegant: With supply fixed and demand rising, prices for these goods can escalate without limit. Even at twenty guineas per woodcock, human effort could not meaningfully increase supply. The Romans' extravagant prices for rare birds and fish reflected the high value of irreproducible luxuries, not cheap silver.
summary: When supply is fixed by nature and demand rises with wealth, prices have no natural ceiling. The Romans' legendary spending on rare delicacies reflected genuine scarcity of irreproducible luxuries, not a decline in silver's value.
distilled: Fixed-supply luxuries can command any price when competing wealth drives demand -- as the Romans' extravagant spending on rare birds and fish demonstrated.
notes: The woodcock example makes the abstract principle concrete: even enormous prices cannot call forth more wild birds. -- Smith uses Roman luxury spending to illustrate a timeless economic principle, not just a historical curiosity. -- The key insight is that high prices for rare goods reflect real scarcity, not monetary depreciation -- countering the common assumption that high ancient prices meant cheap money. -- This connects to Smith's broader argument that rising prices for certain goods do not prove silver's value is falling.

refashioned: The real value of silver was higher at Rome for some time before and after the fall of the republic than it is in most of Europe today. Three sestertii, equal to about sixpence sterling, was the price the republic paid for a modius, or peck, of the tithe wheat of Sicily. This was probably below the average market price, since the obligation to deliver wheat at this rate was considered a tax on the Sicilian farmers. When the Romans needed additional corn beyond the tithe, they were required by agreement to pay four sestertii, or eightpence sterling per peck -- which was probably considered the moderate and reasonable contract price of those times. This is equal to about twenty-one shillings per quarter. Twenty-eight shillings per quarter was, until the recent scarcity, the ordinary English contract price for wheat -- and English wheat, being of inferior quality, generally sells for less than Sicilian wheat in the European market.
elegant: Silver was worth more in ancient Rome than in modern Europe. The tithe price of Sicilian wheat (about sixpence per peck, likely below market) and the contract price for additional corn (about eightpence per peck, or twenty-one shillings per quarter) were both below England's recent contract price of twenty-eight shillings -- even though English wheat is of inferior quality. Silver thus purchased more grain in Rome than it does today.
summary: Comparison of wheat prices shows that silver was more valuable in ancient Rome than in modern Europe: Roman contract prices for superior Sicilian wheat were about twenty-one shillings per quarter, while inferior English wheat cost twenty-eight shillings.
distilled: Silver had greater purchasing power in ancient Rome than in modern Europe, as evidenced by the lower grain prices prevailing even for superior Sicilian wheat.
notes: The modius was a Roman unit of dry measure roughly equivalent to a peck (about 8.7 liters). -- Smith's comparison of Roman and English wheat prices is an early example of cross-temporal purchasing power analysis. -- The distinction between the tithe price (a tax) and the contract price (a market-adjacent price) shows Smith's sensitivity to institutional context in interpreting price data. -- Sicily was Rome's most important grain supplier -- the 'breadbasket of Rome.' -- Cross-reference: 1.5 and 1.11 on wheat as a standard of value comparison.

refashioned: The value of silver in those ancient times must therefore have been to its present value roughly as four to three -- inversely: three ounces of silver would then have purchased the same quantity of labor and commodities that four ounces purchase today. So when we read in Pliny that Seius bought a white nightingale as a gift for the empress Agrippina for six thousand sestertii, equal to about fifty pounds in modern money, and that Asinius Celer bought a surmullet for eight thousand sestertii, equal to about sixty-six pounds, thirteen shillings, and fourpence -- the extravagance of these prices, however surprising it appears, actually seems about one-third less than it really was. Their real price, measured in the labor and subsistence given up for them, was about one-third more than the nominal price suggests to us today. Seius gave for the nightingale the command of labor and subsistence equal to what sixty-six pounds would purchase today, and Asinius Celer gave for a surmullet what nearly eighty-nine pounds would purchase. What drove these extravagant prices was not the abundance of silver but the abundance of labor and subsistence that these Romans could command beyond their own needs.
elegant: Silver was worth about one-third more in ancient Rome than today, so the real extravagance of Roman luxury purchases was one-third greater than their nominal prices suggest. Seius's nightingale (nominally fifty pounds) really cost the equivalent of sixty-six pounds in modern labor, and Asinius Celer's surmullet (nominally sixty-six pounds) cost nearly eighty-nine. The cause was not cheap silver but the enormous surplus of labor these Romans commanded.
summary: Roman luxury prices, already shocking in nominal terms, were actually about one-third higher in real purchasing power than they appear. A nightingale costing fifty nominal pounds represented sixty-six pounds of real labor. The extravagance was driven by vast labor surpluses, not cheap money.
distilled: Roman luxury extravagances were even greater than they appear because silver was worth more then -- the cause was vast surplus wealth commanding labor, not depreciated money.
notes: Pliny the Elder (23--79 CE) recorded these purchases in his Natural History. -- Seius's nightingale for Empress Agrippina (mother of Nero) and Asinius Celer's surmullet (a prized Mediterranean fish) were famous examples of Roman excess. -- Smith's real vs. nominal price adjustment demonstrates how to properly compare purchasing power across centuries. -- The conclusion that 'abundance of labour and subsistence' rather than 'abundance of silver' explains luxury prices is a key anti-mercantilist argument. -- Cross-reference: 1.5 on labor as the real measure of value.

refashioned: The quantity of silver at their disposal was considerably less than what the same command of labor and subsistence would procure today. Second Sort -- The second class of raw produce whose price rises with improvement consists of those useful plants and animals which, in uncultivated countries, nature produces in such profuse abundance that they have little or no value, but which, as cultivation advances, must yield ground to more profitable crops. Throughout a long period of improvement, the supply of these diminishes continually while demand continually increases. Their real value -- the real quantity of labor they will purchase -- gradually rises until it becomes as profitable to raise them as to raise anything else on the best cultivated land. Once it has reached that point, the price cannot go much higher, because if it did, more land and labor would soon be devoted to increasing their supply.
elegant: Second Sort -- The second class includes useful plants and animals that nature provides abundantly in undeveloped countries but that give way to more profitable crops as cultivation advances. Their supply diminishes while demand grows, driving real prices upward until raising them becomes as profitable as any other use of prime farmland. At that ceiling, higher prices would simply attract more land to their production, preventing further increases.
summary: The second category of raw products -- things like cattle that nature provides abundantly in undeveloped lands -- experience rising prices as cultivation displaces them. Prices rise until it becomes as profitable to raise these products deliberately as to grow any other crop on good land, at which point the price stabilizes.
distilled: Products that nature provides freely in wild lands but cultivation displaces will rise in price until deliberately raising them becomes as profitable as any other use of good farmland.
notes: This second category exhibits what economists now call an upward-sloping but bounded supply curve. -- The 'ceiling' price is where the marginal cost of deliberate cultivation equals the price -- a natural equilibrium. -- Smith's key insight is that development itself creates scarcity of goods that were previously abundant in the wild state. -- This framework explains the historical transition from hunting/gathering to deliberate animal husbandry. -- The concept of 'opportunity cost' is implicit: the ceiling price is set by what the land could earn in its best alternative use.

refashioned: When the price of cattle, for example, rises so high that it is as profitable to cultivate land in order to raise food for them as to raise food for humans, the price cannot well go higher. If it did, more cornland would soon be converted to pasture. The extension of tillage, by diminishing wild pasture, reduces the quantity of butcher's meat that the country produces naturally without labor or cultivation, while simultaneously increasing the number of people who have corn -- or its equivalent in money -- to exchange for meat, thus increasing demand. The price of butcher's meat and therefore of cattle must gradually rise until it becomes as profitable to devote the most fertile, best cultivated land to feeding cattle as to growing corn. But it must always be late in the progress of improvement before tillage extends far enough to raise cattle prices to this height; and until it does, if the country is advancing at all, their price must be continually rising. There are perhaps some parts of Europe where cattle prices have not yet reached this height. In Scotland before the Union, the price had not reached it. Had Scottish cattle always been confined to the Scottish market -- where the quantity of land suited only for feeding cattle is so great relative to land usable for other purposes -- it is hard to imagine their price could ever have risen high enough to make it profitable to cultivate land specifically for feeding them. In England, the price of cattle appears, at least near London, to have reached this height around the beginning of the last century, but it was probably much later before it did so in the remoter counties, where in some cases it may not have reached it even yet. Of all the products in this second class, however, cattle are perhaps the first whose price reaches this ceiling.
elegant: When cattle prices reach the point where raising cattle feed is as profitable as growing grain, the price cannot rise further -- more land would simply be converted to pasture. Expanding tillage naturally raises cattle prices by reducing wild pasture while increasing the population demanding meat. But this ceiling is reached late in development. In pre-Union Scotland, with its vast grazing lands, cattle prices probably could never have reached it without access to English markets. Near London, the ceiling was reached around the early seventeenth century; in remoter English counties, perhaps much later. Of all second-category products, cattle are likely the first to hit this price ceiling.
summary: Cattle prices rise as tillage expands (reducing wild pasture while increasing demand), until raising cattle feed becomes as profitable as growing grain -- a ceiling beyond which prices cannot sustainably rise. This ceiling was reached near London by the early 1600s but much later elsewhere, and perhaps not at all in pre-Union Scotland.
distilled: Cattle prices naturally rise as cultivation expands until feeding cattle becomes as profitable as growing grain -- a ceiling reached first near major cities and last in remote pastoral regions.
notes: Smith traces a complete causal chain: tillage expansion reduces wild pasture, reducing natural meat supply, while increasing the population that demands meat, driving prices up to the cultivation ceiling. -- The Scottish case illustrates how market access (the Union of 1707) can be transformative: by connecting Scotland to England's larger market, cattle prices could rise to levels that justified land improvement. -- The geographic gradient (London first, remote areas last) reflects the importance of market proximity. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.204 on the Union's impact on Scottish cattle prices.

refashioned: Until cattle prices reach this height, it seems scarcely possible for most of the land capable of the highest cultivation to be fully improved. On all farms too distant from any town to receive its manure -- that is, the great majority of farms in any extensive country -- the quantity of well-cultivated land must be proportional to the quantity of manure the farm itself produces. This in turn must be proportional to the stock of cattle maintained on it. Land is manured either by pasturing cattle on it or by feeding them in the stable and carrying out their dung.
elegant: Until cattle prices reach the cultivation ceiling, most good land cannot be fully improved. Farms distant from towns depend on their own manure supply, which depends on their cattle stock. Land is manured either by grazing cattle directly or by stable-feeding them and spreading their dung.
summary: Full land cultivation requires adequate manure, which depends on adequate cattle, which depends on cattle prices being high enough to justify keeping them. Most farms, being too distant from towns to import manure, can only improve as much land as their own cattle can fertilize.
distilled: Full agricultural improvement is impossible until cattle prices justify maintaining herds large enough to produce sufficient manure for the land.
notes: Smith identifies a critical agricultural bottleneck: the interdependence of cattle raising and crop cultivation through the manure cycle. -- This is an early systems analysis showing how one sector (livestock) constrains another (crops). -- The observation about distance from towns reflects the high cost of transporting bulky manure before modern transport. -- This interdependence explains why cattle prices are so important to overall agricultural improvement. -- The passage anticipates the concept of 'mixed farming' -- the integration of livestock and crop production -- as essential to sustainable agriculture.

refashioned: But unless the price of cattle is sufficient to pay both the rent and profit of cultivated land, the farmer cannot afford to pasture them on it, and he can still less afford to feed them in the stable. Cattle can only be stable-fed with the produce of improved and cultivated land, because gathering the scanty and scattered produce of waste and unimproved lands would require too much labor and expense. If the price of cattle is not enough to pay for the produce of improved land when they merely graze it, that price will be even less sufficient when that produce must be gathered with considerable additional labor and brought into the stable. In these circumstances, therefore, no more cattle can profitably be stable-fed than what are strictly necessary for tillage.
elegant: If cattle prices do not cover the rent and profit on cultivated land, farmers cannot afford to graze cattle on such land, let alone stable-feed them with its expensive produce. Gathering forage from unimproved land costs too much labor. So only the minimum cattle needed for plowing can be profitably maintained.
summary: When cattle prices are too low to cover the rent and profit on cultivated land, farmers can only maintain the bare minimum of cattle needed for plowing. This limits both pasture use and stable-feeding, creating a bottleneck for the entire farming system.
distilled: Low cattle prices create a vicious cycle: farmers can only maintain enough cattle for plowing, producing insufficient manure for land improvement, which prevents the very development that would raise cattle prices.
notes: Smith describes what modern economists would call a poverty trap or low-level equilibrium: low prices prevent investment, which prevents the improvements that would justify higher prices. -- The distinction between grazing (lower cost) and stable-feeding (higher cost, needing cultivated forage) shows escalating capital requirements for intensification. -- 'No more cattle can with profit be fed than what are necessary for tillage' represents the minimum viable herd size. -- This analysis explains why agricultural development can be so slow in the absence of external demand shocks (like market access).

refashioned: But these cattle can never produce enough manure to keep all the land they could cultivate in good condition. What manure they produce, being insufficient for the whole farm, will naturally be reserved for the land where it can be most advantageously or conveniently applied -- the most fertile fields, or perhaps those nearest the farmyard. These will be kept constantly in good condition and fit for tillage. The rest will mostly be left as waste, producing scarcely anything but miserable pasture, just sufficient to keep alive a few straggling, half-starved cattle. The farm, though greatly overstocked relative to what would be needed for its complete cultivation, will frequently be overstocked even relative to its actual output.
