A portion of this waste land, after being pastured in this wretched manner for six or seven years, may be plowed up and will yield perhaps a poor crop or two of bad oats or some other coarse grain. Then, being entirely exhausted, it must be rested and pastured again, and another portion plowed up to be exhausted and rested in its turn. Such was the general farming system throughout the Scottish lowlands before the Union.
elegant: With insufficient cattle, manure goes only to the best fields near the farmyard. The rest lies waste, supporting only a few starving cattle. Paradoxically, the farm is overstocked for its meager output yet understocked for its potential. Waste portions are occasionally plowed for a poor crop or two of oats, then left to recover for years before being exhausted again. This was the standard farming system in lowland Scotland before the Union.
summary: Before the Union, Scottish lowland farming was trapped in a cycle of underinvestment: insufficient cattle produced insufficient manure, so only the best fields were cultivated while the rest alternated between degraded pasture and exhaustive cropping. Farms were simultaneously overstocked for their output and understocked for their potential.
distilled: Pre-Union Scottish farming was trapped in a low-productivity cycle where insufficient cattle meant insufficient manure, confining real cultivation to a fraction of potential farmland.
notes: Smith provides a vivid case study of agricultural underdevelopment caused by the livestock-manure bottleneck. -- The paradox of being simultaneously overstocked and understocked captures the inefficiency of the low-level equilibrium. -- The six-to-seven year exhaustion cycle describes what is now called shifting cultivation or slash-and-burn farming -- typically associated with tropical agriculture, but here found in eighteenth-century Scotland. -- The Union of 1707 opened English markets to Scottish cattle, breaking the low-price trap. -- This passage powerfully illustrates how market access (trade) can transform productive capacity.

refashioned: The lands kept constantly well manured and in good condition seldom exceeded a third or fourth of the whole farm, and sometimes amounted to only a fifth or sixth. The rest was never manured, though portions of it were regularly cultivated and exhausted in rotation. Under this system, even the land in Scotland capable of good cultivation could produce only a fraction of what it might be capable of producing. But however disadvantageous this system may appear, before the Union the low price of cattle seems to have made it almost unavoidable. If, despite a great rise in prices, it still continues in considerable parts of the country, this is due in many places to ignorance and attachment to old customs, but in most places to unavoidable obstacles that the natural course of things opposes to the quick establishment of a better system. First, the poverty of the tenants -- their not having had time to acquire enough cattle to cultivate their lands more fully, since the very rise in prices that makes a larger herd advantageous makes acquiring one more expensive. Second, their not having had time to bring their lands into condition to properly support this larger herd, even if they could acquire it.
elegant: Only a third to a sixth of each farm was well manured; the rest was periodically exhausted and abandoned. Scotland's productive potential was vastly underutilized, but before the Union, low cattle prices made this system almost unavoidable. Even after prices rose, the old system persists due to ignorance, custom, and two structural obstacles: tenants lack capital to buy more cattle (the same price rise that makes larger herds profitable makes them harder to afford), and their land needs time to be brought into condition for more intensive farming.
summary: Pre-Union Scotland cultivated only a fraction of its potential because low cattle prices made intensification unprofitable. Even after prices rose following the Union, the transition is slow: tenants lack capital to buy more cattle, and land needs time to improve -- a classic catch-22 of agricultural development.
distilled: Agricultural improvement is a slow, capital-intensive process: the same price increases that make intensification profitable also make the necessary investments harder to afford.
notes: Smith identifies a classic development trap: the price signal that should trigger investment also raises the cost of that investment. -- The distinction between 'ignorance and attachment to old customs' and genuine structural obstacles shows Smith's balanced assessment of barriers to change. -- The observation that land improvement and stock increase 'must go hand in hand' (developed in 1.11.204) is a key insight about complementary investments. -- This passage has clear parallels to modern development economics' discussion of poverty traps, capital constraints, and the difficulty of transitioning from subsistence to commercial agriculture.

refashioned: The increase of livestock and the improvement of land are two developments that must proceed together; neither can far outpace the other. Without some increase in livestock, there can be scarcely any improvement of land, but there can be no considerable increase in livestock without considerable land improvement, because otherwise the land could not support them. These natural obstacles to establishing a better system can only be removed through a long course of frugality and industry. Half a century or a century more may need to pass before the old system, which is gradually wearing out, can be completely abolished throughout all parts of the country. Of all the commercial advantages Scotland has derived from the Union with England, however, this rise in the price of cattle is perhaps the greatest. It has not only raised the value of all Highland estates but has perhaps been the principal cause of improvement in the Lowlands.
elegant: Livestock increase and land improvement must advance together -- neither can far outpace the other. Breaking out of the old system requires a long course of saving and industry, perhaps another half-century or century. But the rise in cattle prices is arguably Scotland's greatest benefit from the Union: it raised Highland estate values and drove Lowland agricultural improvement.
summary: Agricultural improvement requires the simultaneous advancement of livestock and land quality, which can only proceed gradually through decades of patient investment. The Union's greatest economic benefit to Scotland was raising cattle prices, which catalyzed improvement throughout the country.
distilled: Livestock and land improvement must advance together through patient decades of investment, and the Union's cattle price increase was arguably Scotland's greatest commercial benefit.
notes: The complementarity of livestock and land improvement is a key insight about co-investment in agricultural development. -- Smith's estimate of 50-100 years for systemic transformation is remarkably patient for an economic analysis -- he recognizes that institutional change operates on generational timescales. -- The characterization of the cattle price rise as Scotland's 'greatest' benefit from the Union is striking: not trade access, not political stability, but a simple commodity price change with cascading effects. -- This illustrates Smith's understanding of how price signals propagate through an entire economic system. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.199 on the cattle price ceiling mechanism.

refashioned: In all new colonies, the great quantity of waste land that can for many years serve no other purpose than feeding cattle soon makes cattle extremely abundant, and wherever there is great abundance, there is necessarily great cheapness. Though all the cattle of the European colonies in America were originally brought from Europe, they multiplied so rapidly and became so worthless that even horses were allowed to run wild in the woods without anyone thinking it worth claiming them. It must be a long time after a colony's first establishment before it becomes profitable to feed cattle on the produce of cultivated land.
elegant: In new colonies, vast waste land feeds cattle so abundantly that they become nearly worthless -- even horses were left to run wild in American colonies. It takes a long time after settlement before cattle prices rise enough to justify feeding them on cultivated land.
summary: The abundance of waste land in new colonies makes cattle so plentiful and cheap that even horses run wild unclaimed. Only after long development do cattle prices rise enough to justify deliberate cultivation of feed.
distilled: In new colonies, abundant free pasture makes cattle so cheap that horses run wild -- and it takes generations before prices justify cultivating feed crops.
notes: The image of horses running wild in American forests powerfully illustrates the concept of superabundance -- goods so plentiful they have near-zero value. -- Smith connects colonial agricultural development to the same framework he used for Scotland: cheap cattle prevent intensive farming. -- The parallel between new colonies and undeveloped Scotland reinforces the universality of his theory. -- This passage anticipates Frederick Jackson Turner's frontier thesis about the transformative effect of abundant land on American society and economy.

refashioned: The same causes -- insufficient manure and a disproportion between the stock used in cultivation and the land it must cultivate -- are likely to produce in the colonies a farming system not unlike that still practiced in much of Scotland. The Swedish traveler Kalm, describing the agriculture of some English colonies in North America as he found it in 1749, observes that he can scarcely recognize in it the character of the English nation, so skilled in all branches of farming. The colonists make almost no manure for their cornfields, he says; when one piece of ground is exhausted by continuous cropping, they clear and cultivate another, and when that is exhausted, they move to a third. Their cattle are allowed to wander through the woods and uncultivated ground, half-starved, having long ago destroyed almost all the natural annual grasses by cropping them too early in spring, before they could flower or shed seed. These annual grasses had apparently been the best natural grasses in that part of North America and had formerly grown thick and three or four feet high. A piece of ground that when Kalm wrote could not sustain one cow would, in former times, he was assured, have maintained four, each giving four times as much milk.
elegant: American colonial farming repeated Scotland's pattern: exhaustive cropping without manure, shifting to fresh land when soil was depleted, while cattle wandered half-starved through degraded woods. Swedish traveler Kalm, visiting in 1749, found the agriculture unrecognizable as English. Colonists had destroyed native grasses by overgrazing, reducing land that once sustained four productive cows to supporting barely one.
summary: American colonial farming in 1749 replicated the same dysfunctional pattern as pre-Union Scotland: exhaustive cropping, no manure, shifting cultivation, and degraded pasture. Native grasses destroyed by overgrazing had reduced carrying capacity to a fraction of its original level.
distilled: American colonial agriculture repeated Scotland's low-productivity pattern: exhaustive cropping without manure, shifting cultivation, and pasture degraded by overgrazing to a fraction of its original capacity.
notes: Pehr Kalm (1716--1779) was a Finnish-Swedish botanist who traveled through North America in 1748-1751. His observations provide invaluable records of colonial agriculture and ecology. -- The destruction of native grasses through premature grazing is an early account of what ecologists now call overgrazing-driven ecosystem degradation. -- The four-to-one decline in carrying capacity illustrates how rapidly unsustainable practices can degrade productive land. -- Smith uses Kalm's account to demonstrate that the Scottish agricultural problems were not uniquely Scottish but characteristic of any land-abundant, capital-poor economy. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.202 on the Scottish version of the same pattern.

refashioned: The poorness of the pasture had, in Kalm's opinion, caused the degradation of the colonial cattle, which degenerated noticeably from one generation to the next. They were probably not unlike the stunted breed that had been common throughout Scotland thirty or forty years earlier, and which has now been so much improved through most of the lowlands -- not so much by changing the breed, though that has been done in some places, as by a more plentiful method of feeding them.
elegant: Poor pasture degraded the colonial cattle, which degenerated visibly across generations -- similar to the stunted Scottish breeds of thirty or forty years ago, since improved mainly through better feeding rather than breed changes.
summary: Colonial cattle degenerated due to poor pasture, much like the stunted breeds that were common in Scotland a generation earlier. Scottish cattle improved primarily through better feeding rather than breed replacement.
distilled: Poor pasture causes cattle to degenerate across generations, as seen in both colonial America and pre-improvement Scotland -- and better feeding, not breed change, drives recovery.
notes: Smith distinguishes between genetic factors (breed) and environmental factors (nutrition) in cattle quality -- coming down firmly on the side of nutrition as the primary driver. -- This anticipates the nature-vs-nurture debate in animal husbandry. -- The Scottish cattle improvement provides a hopeful counterexample: the same breeds improved dramatically with better feeding. -- The parallel between American and Scottish cattle reinforces the universality of the agricultural development pattern. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.204 on the improvement of Scottish agriculture after the Union.

refashioned: Though it is late in the progress of improvement before cattle can fetch a price that makes it profitable to cultivate land specifically for feeding them, of all the different products comprising this second class of raw produce, cattle are perhaps the first to reach this price. This is because until they do, it seems impossible for agricultural improvement to approach even the level of development it has achieved in many parts of Europe.
elegant: Cattle are the first second-category product to reach the price ceiling that justifies deliberate cultivation for feeding, and they must reach it before agriculture can approach European levels of development.
summary: Of all products in the second category, cattle are the first to reach prices justifying deliberate feed cultivation -- a milestone that must be achieved before broader agricultural improvement can proceed.
distilled: Cattle prices reaching the feed-cultivation threshold is the essential first step in agricultural development, without which broader improvement is impossible.
notes: Smith establishes cattle as the 'gateway' commodity for agricultural development -- their price must rise first because the entire farming system depends on the manure-cultivation cycle they enable. -- This creates a natural sequence of development: cattle prices rise first, enabling land improvement, which then allows other products to follow. -- The argument connects the commodity-specific analysis back to the broader theory of economic development. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.200-1.11.204 on the cattle-manure-cultivation interdependence.

refashioned: As cattle are among the first, venison is perhaps among the last products of this sort to reach this price. The price of venison in Great Britain, however extravagant it may appear, is not nearly sufficient to compensate for the expense of maintaining a deer park, as everyone experienced in deer husbandry well knows. If it were otherwise, feeding deer would soon become an ordinary branch of farming, just as the feeding of small birds called turdi was among the ancient Romans. Varro and Columella assure us that it was a most profitable pursuit. The fattening of ortolans -- migratory birds that arrive lean in the country -- is said to be similarly profitable in some parts of France. If venison continues in fashion and if British wealth and luxury continue growing as they have been, its price may very probably rise still higher than it is at present.
elegant: If cattle reach the cultivation ceiling first, venison reaches it last. Despite seemingly extravagant prices, venison does not cover the cost of maintaining a deer park. Were it profitable, deer farming would become common -- as bird-fattening was for the Romans (turdi) and remains for French ortolans. If wealth continues growing, venison prices may rise further still.
summary: Venison, despite its high price, is still not expensive enough to cover the cost of deer parks -- placing it among the last products to reach the cultivation ceiling. Ancient Romans profitably farmed birds, and if British wealth continues growing, venison prices may eventually rise enough to make deer farming viable.
distilled: Venison's price, though seemingly extravagant, remains below the level needed to make deer farming profitable -- making it among the last raw products to reach its cultivation ceiling.
notes: The deer park example illustrates a product still below its cultivation threshold despite high absolute prices -- reinforcing the distinction between 'expensive' and 'profitable to produce.' -- Varro (116--27 BCE) and Columella (4--70 CE) were major Roman agricultural writers whose works survived into Smith's era. -- Turdi (thrushes) were fattened in dark rooms (aviaria) as a Roman delicacy. -- Ortolans were (and controversially remain) a French gastronomic luxury. -- The projection that venison prices may continue rising connects to Smith's broader theory of luxury goods and economic development.

refashioned: Between the period in the progress of improvement that brings to its peak the price of so necessary an article as cattle, and the period that does the same for such a luxury as venison, there is a very long interval. During this interval, many other sorts of raw produce gradually reach their highest prices, some sooner and some later, depending on different circumstances.
elegant: A long interval separates the point when cattle reach their price ceiling from when venison does. During this period, many other raw products gradually reach their own peak prices at different rates depending on circumstances.
summary: The development timeline stretches from cattle (a necessity reaching its price ceiling early) to venison (a luxury reaching its ceiling late), with many other raw products finding their peak prices at various points along this continuum.
distilled: Economic development creates a long timeline of rising raw product prices, from necessities like cattle reaching their ceiling early to luxuries like venison reaching theirs late.
notes: Smith describes a sequential process of price maturation: different products reach their cultivation ceiling at different stages of development. -- The necessity-luxury axis determines the sequence: essential goods hit their ceiling first because demand is stronger and more universal. -- This framework provides a way to measure a country's development stage by observing which products have reached their price ceiling. -- The 'long interval' between cattle and venison spans potentially centuries of development. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.193 for the three-category framework within which this progression operates.

refashioned: On every farm, the waste from the barn and stable will support a certain number of poultry. Since these birds are fed on what would otherwise be lost, they are essentially a way of salvaging scraps. They cost the farmer almost nothing, so he can afford to sell them for very little. Almost everything he gets for them is pure gain, and their price can scarcely be so low as to discourage him from keeping this number. But in poorly cultivated and therefore sparsely populated countries, the poultry raised in this cost-free manner are often sufficient to supply the entire demand. In such circumstances, they are often as cheap as butcher's meat or any other sort of animal food.
elegant: Poultry raised on barn and stable scraps cost the farmer virtually nothing -- they are a 'save-all' converting waste into value. In sparsely populated, poorly cultivated countries, these cost-free poultry often supply the entire demand, making them as cheap as butcher's meat.
summary: Poultry are initially a cost-free byproduct of farming, raised on barn scraps. In undeveloped, thinly populated countries, this zero-cost production satisfies all demand, keeping poultry prices as low as any other meat.
distilled: When poultry can be raised entirely on farm waste, they cost nothing to produce and sell as cheaply as any other meat.
notes: The 'save-all' concept -- converting waste into value -- is an early articulation of what modern economics calls byproduct utilization or waste valorization. -- Smith's key point is that the cost structure of a product determines its pricing behavior: zero marginal cost means the farmer accepts any price above zero. -- This sets up the argument that development changes the cost structure by making waste-fed poultry insufficient to meet rising demand. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.215 for the analogous argument about hogs as 'save-alls.'

refashioned: But the total quantity of poultry that the farm can produce at no expense must always be much smaller than the total quantity of butcher's meat it raises. And in times of wealth and luxury, when something rare has only roughly equal quality to something common, the rare item is always preferred. As wealth and luxury increase through improvement and cultivation, the price of poultry therefore gradually rises above that of butcher's meat, until at last it becomes profitable to cultivate land specifically for feeding them. Once it has reached that point, the price cannot well go higher.
elegant: Farm waste produces far less poultry than butcher's meat. As wealth grows, rarity makes poultry preferred over common beef, driving poultry prices above meat prices until it becomes profitable to cultivate land for poultry feed. At that point, the price reaches its ceiling.
summary: Poultry, being produced in smaller quantities than beef from farm waste, becomes relatively scarce and therefore more expensive as wealth grows. Prices rise until deliberate cultivation for poultry feed becomes profitable, establishing a natural price ceiling.
distilled: As wealth grows, poultry's natural scarcity relative to beef drives its price upward until deliberate feed cultivation becomes profitable -- the price ceiling.
notes: Smith identifies a consumer preference effect: 'what is rare, with only nearly equal merit, is always preferred to what is common.' This is an early observation of scarcity-driven consumer preference. -- The transition from waste-fed to deliberately-fed poultry marks a shift from zero to positive marginal cost, which fundamentally changes the pricing dynamics. -- The price ceiling mechanism is the same as for cattle: the opportunity cost of using good land for feed. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.198-1.11.199 for the general theory of second-category price ceilings.

refashioned: If it did go higher, more land would soon be devoted to this purpose. In several provinces of France, the feeding of poultry is considered an important branch of rural economy, profitable enough to encourage farmers to raise considerable quantities of Indian corn and buckwheat specifically for this purpose. A middling farmer there will sometimes keep four hundred fowls in his yard. The feeding of poultry does not yet seem to be generally considered as important in England. Poultry are certainly, however, dearer in England than in France, since England receives considerable supplies from France.
elegant: In several French provinces, poultry raising is already profitable enough to justify growing corn and buckwheat as feed -- middling farmers may keep four hundred fowls. England does not yet treat poultry farming as seriously, and English poultry are dearer than French, with England importing considerable supplies from France.
summary: French farmers have already reached the stage where deliberate poultry cultivation is profitable, with middling farmers keeping hundreds of fowls. England lags behind, importing poultry from France at higher prices.
distilled: French agriculture has reached the poultry cultivation stage -- with farmers deliberately growing feed for hundreds of fowls -- while England still imports from France at higher prices.
notes: The France-England comparison illustrates how different countries can be at different stages of the same developmental sequence. -- Indian corn (maize) and buckwheat as poultry feed represent deliberate cultivation of feed crops -- the threshold that defines the price ceiling. -- England importing poultry from France despite being wealthier illustrates comparative advantage in agricultural specialization. -- Four hundred fowls for a 'middling farmer' suggests significant commercial-scale production. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.214 on how feed crop innovation affects meat prices.

refashioned: In the progress of improvement, the period at which any particular kind of animal food is dearest must naturally be the period immediately preceding the general adoption of cultivating land to raise it. For some time before this practice becomes widespread, scarcity must drive the price up. After it becomes general, new feeding methods are commonly discovered that enable the farmer to raise a much greater quantity on the same land. The resulting abundance not only forces him to sell cheaper but also, thanks to these improvements, allows him to afford selling cheaper -- for if he could not, the abundance would not last. It was probably in this manner that the introduction of clover, turnips, carrots, and cabbages helped to lower the common price of butcher's meat in the London market somewhat below where it stood at the beginning of the last century.
elegant: Each type of animal food reaches its peak price just before cultivation for feeding becomes common practice. Before that point, scarcity drives prices up. Afterward, new feeding methods (clover, turnips, carrots, cabbages) increase output per acre, forcing and enabling lower prices. This is probably how London butcher's meat prices fell below their early seventeenth-century levels.
summary: Meat prices peak just before deliberate feed cultivation becomes widespread. Once established, agricultural innovations like clover and turnip farming dramatically increase output, reducing prices. London meat prices likely fell below early-1600s levels through precisely this process.
distilled: Meat prices peak just before feed cultivation becomes general, then fall as innovations like clover and turnip farming dramatically increase output per acre.
notes: Smith describes the innovation cycle that follows price signals: high prices attract cultivation, cultivation drives innovation, innovation increases supply, and supply lowers prices. -- The 'agricultural revolution' crops he names -- clover, turnips, carrots, cabbages -- were central to the Norfolk four-course rotation that transformed English farming in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. -- The observation that the farmer 'can afford to sell cheaper' because of productivity improvements is an early description of cost-reducing technological change. -- Cross-reference: modern agricultural economics on the technology treadmill -- innovations that benefit consumers through lower prices while squeezing farmer margins.

refashioned: The hog, which finds its food among refuse and greedily devours many things rejected by every other useful animal, is, like poultry, originally kept as a save-all. As long as the number of hogs that can be raised at little or no expense is sufficient to supply demand, this sort of butcher's meat comes to market at a much lower price than any other. But when demand rises beyond what this cost-free supply can meet, and it becomes necessary to raise food specifically for feeding and fattening hogs, just as for other cattle, the price necessarily rises. It then becomes proportionally higher or lower than the price of other butcher's meat, depending on whether the nature of the country and the state of its agriculture make feeding hogs more or less expensive than feeding other cattle. In France, according to Buffon, the price of pork is nearly equal to that of beef. In most parts of Great Britain, it is at present somewhat higher.
elegant: Hogs, like poultry, are originally 'save-alls' feeding on refuse. While this free supply meets demand, pork is the cheapest meat. When demand outstrips free supply and deliberate feeding becomes necessary, pork prices rise to levels determined by the relative cost of feeding hogs vs. other cattle. In France, pork equals beef in price; in Britain, it is somewhat higher.
summary: Hogs follow the same economic pattern as poultry: initially cheap because they are raised cost-free on refuse, but becoming more expensive once rising demand requires deliberate feeding. The resulting price depends on the relative cost of pig versus cattle feed.
distilled: Hogs follow the same 'save-all' to deliberate-cultivation price trajectory as poultry, with final prices depending on relative feeding costs compared to other livestock.
notes: Smith's parallel between poultry and hogs as 'save-alls' demonstrates the generality of his framework. -- Buffon (Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon, 1707--1788) was the era's most famous naturalist, author of the monumental Histoire Naturelle. -- The France-Britain price comparison illustrates how local conditions (agriculture, climate, preferences) affect the relative cost structure of different meats. -- The 'save-all' concept connects to modern discussions of waste reduction and circular economy principles.

refashioned: The great rise in the price of both hogs and poultry in Great Britain has frequently been attributed to the declining number of cottagers and other small landholders -- a development that has been the immediate forerunner of improvement and better cultivation everywhere in Europe, but which may have contributed to raising these prices both somewhat sooner and somewhat faster than they would otherwise have risen. Just as the poorest family can usually maintain a cat or dog at no expense, the poorest smallholder can typically keep a few poultry or a sow with some pigs at very little cost. Their own table scraps, whey, skimmed milk, and buttermilk provide part of the animals' food, and the rest is found in neighboring fields without doing noticeable damage. By reducing the number of such smallholders, therefore, the supply of these provisions produced at little or no cost must certainly have diminished, raising their prices both sooner and faster than would otherwise have been the case. Sooner or later, however, in the progress of improvement, these prices would in any case have risen to their ultimate height -- the price that covers the cost of cultivating the land that feeds them, just as well as this cost is covered for most other cultivated land.
elegant: Rising pork and poultry prices in Britain are partly attributed to declining numbers of cottagers and smallholders -- whose scraps, whey, and buttermilk fed animals at virtually no cost. As these small producers disappeared (a universal precursor to agricultural improvement), cheap supply fell and prices rose sooner and faster than development alone would have caused. But ultimately, prices would have reached the same ceiling -- the cost of cultivating feed on good land.
summary: The disappearance of cottagers and smallholders, while a sign of agricultural progress, accelerated the rise in pork and poultry prices by removing the cheap, waste-fed supply. However, development would eventually have driven prices to the same cultivation-cost ceiling regardless.
distilled: The enclosure-driven loss of cottagers accelerated rising meat prices by eliminating cheap waste-fed production, though development would have reached the same price ceiling eventually.
notes: Smith identifies the enclosure movement (consolidation of small holdings into larger farms) as a cause of rising food prices -- a nuanced view acknowledging both its role in agricultural improvement and its negative consequences for the poor. -- The observation that 'the poorest family can often maintain a cat or dog without any expense' is a characteristically Smithian detail. -- Whey, skimmed milk, and buttermilk as animal feed illustrate the dairy-livestock integration of smallholder farming. -- The distinction between timing (sooner/faster) and ultimate outcome (same ceiling) shows Smith's careful analytical framework. -- This passage has clear relevance to modern debates about the social costs of agricultural consolidation.

refashioned: The dairy business, like the feeding of hogs and poultry, is originally carried on as a save-all. The cattle necessarily kept on the farm produce more milk than is needed either to raise their young or to supply the farmer's family, and they produce the most at one particular season. But of all land products, milk is perhaps the most perishable. In the warm season, when it is most abundant, it will scarcely keep twenty-four hours. By making it into fresh butter, the farmer stores a small portion for a week; by making it into salt butter, for a year; and by making it into cheese, he stores a much greater portion for several years. Part of all these is reserved for his own family's use; the rest goes to market in search of the best price available, which can scarcely be so low as to discourage him from sending whatever exceeds his family's needs.
elegant: Dairying, like hog and poultry raising, begins as a save-all. Farm cattle produce surplus milk, especially seasonally, but milk is extremely perishable -- lasting barely a day in warm weather. Preservation through butter (weeks to a year) and cheese (years) extends its useful life. After reserving what the family needs, the rest goes to market at whatever price is available.
summary: Dairying initially operates as a save-all business, converting perishable surplus milk into more durable products -- fresh butter, salt butter, and cheese -- for market. Since the milk would otherwise be wasted, any price above zero justifies selling.
distilled: The dairy business begins as a save-all, converting perishable surplus milk into butter and cheese for whatever price the market offers -- since the alternative is pure waste.
notes: Smith identifies milk as perhaps 'the most perishable' of all land products -- a key economic characteristic that drives the entire dairy value chain. -- The preservation hierarchy (milk: hours; fresh butter: a week; salt butter: a year; cheese: several years) represents progressively more capital-intensive and skilled processing. -- The 'save-all' framework applies here exactly as it did to poultry and hogs: zero opportunity cost means any revenue is 'pure gain.' -- This analysis explains why dairy products were historically cheap in pastoral regions. -- The seasonal production pattern (most milk when least needed) creates the fundamental problem that preservation technology solves.

refashioned: If the price is very low indeed, the farmer will likely manage his dairy in a slovenly and dirty manner, and may not even think it worthwhile to have a dedicated room or building for the purpose. Instead, the work will be carried on amid the smoke, filth, and squalor of his own kitchen -- as was the case in almost all Scottish farm dairies thirty or forty years ago, and as is still the case in many of them. The same causes that gradually raise the price of butcher's meat -- increasing demand and, as the country improves, a diminishing supply of animals that can be fed at little or no cost -- raise the price of dairy produce in the same manner, since the price of dairy products naturally tracks the price of butcher's meat, or more precisely, the cost of feeding cattle.
elegant: At very low prices, farmers run their dairies carelessly, without dedicated facilities -- as in most Scottish farms thirty or forty years ago. The same forces that raise butcher's meat prices (rising demand, shrinking free-range supply) raise dairy prices in parallel, since dairy production costs track cattle-feeding costs.
summary: Low dairy prices produce low quality, as farmers see no reason to invest in proper facilities. As development raises both demand and the cost of feeding cattle, dairy prices rise in tandem with butcher's meat prices.
distilled: Low dairy prices produce slovenly quality; rising cattle-feeding costs and growing demand gradually push dairy prices upward in lockstep with meat prices.
notes: Smith describes the quality-price feedback loop: low prices lead to poor quality, which reinforces low prices -- until external demand growth breaks the cycle. -- The vivid description of dairy work amid 'smoke, filth, and nastiness' is characteristic of Smith's willingness to use concrete detail. -- The linkage between dairy and meat prices through shared cattle-feeding costs is an early recognition of joint-product pricing. -- The thirty-to-forty year timeframe for Scottish dairy improvement aligns with the post-Union development period Smith describes elsewhere. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.219-1.11.221 for the continuation of the dairy price analysis.

refashioned: The increase in price pays for more labor, care, and cleanliness. The dairy becomes more worthy of the farmer's attention, and the quality of its produce gradually improves. Eventually the price gets high enough that it becomes worthwhile to use some of the most fertile and best cultivated land for feeding cattle solely for the purpose of the dairy. When it has reached this height, it cannot well go higher -- if it did, more land would soon be turned to this purpose. It seems to have reached this height throughout the greater part of England, where much good land is commonly employed in this way.
elegant: Higher prices fund better care, cleanliness, and quality. Eventually dairy prices rise enough to justify using prime farmland solely for dairy cattle. This ceiling appears to have been reached throughout most of England, where good land is commonly devoted to dairying.
summary: Rising dairy prices improve quality by funding better practices, and eventually reach a ceiling where prime farmland is devoted to dairy cattle. This ceiling has been reached in most of England.
distilled: Dairy prices rise until prime farmland is profitably devoted to dairy cattle -- a ceiling reached in most of England but not yet in Scotland.
notes: The positive feedback from price to quality to further price increases illustrates how market incentives drive quality improvements. -- The price ceiling for dairy is the same as for other second-category products: the opportunity cost of using prime farmland. -- England reaching this ceiling while Scotland has not (see 1.11.220) illustrates different stages of development within the same country. -- This passage completes the 'save-all to cultivation' trajectory for dairy, paralleling the earlier analyses of poultry and hogs.

refashioned: Except in the neighborhood of a few considerable towns, this price does not seem to have been reached anywhere in Scotland, where ordinary farmers seldom use much good land for raising cattle food solely for dairy purposes. The price of Scottish dairy produce, though it has risen considerably in recent years, is probably still too low to justify this. The inferiority of quality, compared to English dairy products, is fully equal to the inferiority of price. But this inferior quality is perhaps rather the effect of the low price than the cause of it.
elegant: Outside a few major towns, Scottish dairy prices remain too low to justify using good land for dairy farming. Scottish dairy quality is as inferior to English as its price -- but the low quality is probably the effect of low prices rather than the cause.
summary: Scottish dairy prices remain below the cultivation ceiling except near major towns. The poor quality of Scottish dairy products relative to English ones is a consequence of low prices (discouraging investment in quality), not the cause.
distilled: Scottish dairy's inferior quality is the effect of its low prices, not the cause -- low prices discourage the investment needed for quality improvement.
notes: Smith identifies the causation correctly: low prices cause low quality (by discouraging investment), not vice versa. This counters the intuitive but wrong assumption that Scottish dairy is cheap because it is bad. -- The urban exception (prices reaching the ceiling near towns) reflects the higher demand density and transport advantages of urban proximity. -- This is another application of the positive feedback between price, investment, and quality that Smith has been developing. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.218 on the squalid conditions of low-price dairy farming.

refashioned: Even if the quality were much better, most of what is brought to market could not, I believe, be sold at a much better price given the country's present circumstances. And the current price would probably not cover the expense of the land and labor needed to produce much better quality. Throughout most of England, despite the higher prices, dairying is not considered a more profitable use of land than growing corn or fattening cattle -- the two great objects of agriculture. Throughout most of Scotland, therefore, it cannot yet be even that profitable.
elegant: Even with better quality, Scottish dairy could not fetch much more in the current market, and current prices would not cover the cost of producing better quality. Even in England, with its higher prices, dairying is no more profitable than growing corn or fattening cattle. In Scotland, it must therefore be even less so.
summary: Scottish dairy faces a double bind: the market cannot absorb better-quality products at higher prices, and current prices cannot fund quality improvements. Even in England, dairying is no more profitable than alternative land uses.
distilled: Scottish dairy is trapped: the market will not pay more even for better quality, and current prices cannot fund the improvements needed to produce it.
notes: Smith describes what development economists call a 'low equilibrium trap' -- where market conditions and productive capacity reinforce each other's limitations. -- The comparison with English dairying as 'not more profitable than corn or cattle fattening' confirms that dairy in England sits exactly at the price ceiling -- the opportunity cost of alternative land uses. -- This implies that English dairy prices have reached their natural maximum under current conditions. -- The analysis shows Smith's sophisticated understanding of how local market conditions constrain production possibilities.

refashioned: It is evident that no country's land can ever be completely cultivated and improved until the price of every product that human industry must raise upon it has risen high enough to cover the expense of complete improvement and cultivation. To achieve this, the price of each particular product must be sufficient, first, to pay the rent of good cornland (since that is what regulates the rent of most other cultivated land), and second, to cover the farmer's labor and expenses as well as they are normally covered on good cornland -- in other words, to replace with ordinary profits the capital he employs. This rise in the price of each particular product must obviously come before the improvement and cultivation of the land destined for it. Gain is the end of all improvement, and nothing that necessarily results in loss deserves the name of improvement. But loss must necessarily result from improving land for a product whose price could never recoup the expense. If the complete improvement and cultivation of the country is, as it most certainly is, the greatest of all public advantages, then this rise in the price of all these different sorts of raw produce, instead of being regarded as a public calamity, should be viewed as the necessary forerunner and companion of the greatest of all public benefits.
elegant: Complete land improvement requires that every product's price covers full cultivation costs -- both cornland-level rent and the farmer's expenses with ordinary profits. Price rises must precede improvement, since no rational person invests where loss is guaranteed. If full national cultivation is the greatest public good, then rising raw product prices are not a calamity but the necessary precursor and companion of that supreme benefit.
summary: Full agricultural development requires that every product's price rises enough to cover the complete costs of cultivation. Since price must rise before investment can be justified, rising raw product prices should be seen not as a public calamity but as the essential precondition for the greatest of all public benefits -- the complete improvement of the nation's land.
distilled: Rising raw product prices are not a public calamity but the essential precondition for full national agricultural development -- the greatest of all public benefits.
notes: This is one of Smith's most important policy conclusions in this chapter: rising food prices, though painful for consumers, are the necessary signal that drives agricultural improvement. -- The argument inverts populist concern about high food prices by showing them as a sign of and prerequisite for development. -- The two-part price test (covering rent and covering costs with normal profits) restates the natural price theory from 1.7. -- 'Gain is the end of all improvement' is a characteristically direct Smithian maxim. -- This passage has clear parallels to modern debates about food price policy in developing countries, where price controls can suppress the investment signals needed for agricultural development.

refashioned: This rise in the nominal or money price of all these different sorts of raw produce has been the effect not of any degradation in the value of silver, but of a rise in their real price. They have come to be worth not only a greater quantity of silver but a greater quantity of labor and subsistence than before. As it costs a greater quantity of labor and subsistence to bring them to market, so when they arrive there they represent, or are equivalent to, a greater quantity.
elegant: Rising money prices for raw products reflect rising real prices, not declining silver value. These goods now cost more labor to produce and therefore command more labor in exchange. They are genuinely worth more, not just priced in cheaper money.
summary: The rising money prices of raw products reflect genuine increases in their real value -- they cost more labor to produce and command more labor in exchange. Silver's value has not degraded; the goods themselves have become genuinely more valuable.
distilled: Rising raw product prices reflect genuine increases in real value -- more labor to produce, more labor commanded -- not any decline in silver's purchasing power.
notes: Smith reiterates his central thesis: the observed price increases are real, not nominal. -- The symmetry between cost of production (labor input) and exchange value (labor commanded) reflects Smith's labor theory of value. -- This passage serves as a summary conclusion to the entire analysis of second-category raw products. -- The distinction between real and nominal price changes remains one of the most important concepts in economics. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.192 where this argument was first stated for raw products generally.

refashioned: Third Sort -- The third and last class of raw produce whose price naturally rises with improvement consists of those goods where the power of human industry to increase supply is either limited or uncertain. Though the real price of this class naturally tends to rise with improvement, different circumstances may render human efforts to increase supply more or less successful, so the price may sometimes actually fall, sometimes stay the same, and sometimes rise more or less, even at similar stages of improvement.
elegant: The third class includes raw products where human industry's ability to increase supply is limited or uncertain. Though prices naturally tend to rise with development, unpredictable success in augmenting supply means prices may sometimes fall, stay constant, or rise at varying rates even at comparable stages of improvement.
summary: The third category of raw produce consists of goods whose supply human effort can only increase to a limited or uncertain degree. Their prices tend to rise with development but behave unpredictably depending on how successfully industry manages to augment supply.
distilled: The third category of raw products has prices that tend to rise with development but fluctuate unpredictably based on the uncertain success of efforts to increase supply.
notes: This third category is the most analytically complex: supply responds to human effort, but unreliably. -- Examples (developed in subsequent paragraphs) include wool, raw hides, and other byproducts whose supply is tied to the production of something else. -- The distinction between limited and uncertain efficacy is important: some goods have a known supply ceiling; others have an unknown one. -- This category is the most relevant to modern discussions of natural resource economics, where extraction costs, technological change, and discovery rates all introduce uncertainty. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.193 for the three-category framework.

refashioned: Some sorts of raw produce are, by nature, appendages to other sorts, so that the quantity of one that any country can supply is necessarily limited by the quantity of the other. The quantity of wool or raw hides, for example, that any country can produce is necessarily limited by the number of cattle -- both large and small -- kept within it. The state of the country's improvement and the nature of its agriculture in turn determine that number.
elegant: Some raw products are natural byproducts of others, their supply constrained by the primary product's output. Wool and hides, for instance, are limited by the number of cattle, which is itself determined by the country's agricultural development.
summary: Certain raw products like wool and hides are natural byproducts whose supply is constrained by the number of livestock, which depends on the country's overall agricultural development.
distilled: The supply of byproduct materials like wool and hides is inherently constrained by the livestock numbers that the country's agriculture supports.
notes: Smith identifies joint production as a key constraint on supply -- an insight central to modern production economics. -- Wool and hides cannot be increased without increasing the number of sheep and cattle, which depends on broader agricultural conditions. -- This creates a situation where demand for the byproduct may grow faster than the primary product, leading to price pressures. -- The concept of supply constraints imposed by joint production relationships is important in industries from petroleum (where gasoline, diesel, and petrochemicals are joint products) to agriculture. -- Cross-reference: 1.11.226 for how this joint-production constraint affects price dynamics.

refashioned: The same causes that, in the progress of improvement, gradually raise the price of butcher's meat should, one might think, have the same effect on the prices of wool and raw hides, raising them in nearly the same proportion. This would probably be the case if, in the early stages of improvement, the market for wool and hides were confined within the same narrow boundaries as the market for meat. But the extent of their respective markets is usually extremely different.
elegant: One might expect wool and hide prices to rise alongside butcher's meat as development proceeds. They would, if their markets were equally limited. But the markets for these byproducts are usually far more extensive than the local meat market.
summary: While meat, wool, and hide prices might be expected to rise together with development, they diverge because wool and hides have much broader markets than locally-consumed meat, altering the supply-demand dynamics for each.
distilled: Wool and hide prices diverge from meat prices because their markets extend far beyond the local boundaries that constrain fresh meat trade.
notes: Smith identifies market extent as the key variable explaining why joint products can have divergent price trajectories. -- Fresh meat is perishable and confined to local markets; wool and hides are durable and tradeable over long distances. -- This means wool and hide prices respond to international supply and demand, while meat prices respond to local conditions. -- The insight that the same production process can yield products facing different market structures is fundamental to understanding commodity pricing. -- This passage sets up a longer analysis (continuing beyond this chunk) of how international trade in wool and hides affects their prices differently from meat.

refashioned:
The market for butcher's meat is almost always limited to the country that produces it. Ireland and parts of British America do carry on a significant trade in salted provisions, but they are, I believe, the only countries in the commercial world that export any considerable portion of their fresh meat.

The market for wool and raw hides, by contrast, is rarely confined to the producing country, even in the earliest stages of economic development. These materials can easily be transported over long distances -- wool without any preparation, and raw hides with very little. Since they serve as raw materials for many manufactures, the industries of other countries may generate demand for them, even when no such demand exists at home.
elegant: Butcher's meat markets are almost always local, since meat is hard to transport. Wool and raw hides, however, can easily reach distant markets. As raw materials for manufacturing, they attract international demand even when the producing country has none of its own.
summary: Fresh meat markets are confined to the producing country, but wool and hides can be easily transported and sold internationally as manufacturing inputs.
distilled: Meat markets are local, but wool and hide markets are international because these materials transport easily and serve distant manufacturers.
notes: Transportability as a determinant of market scope -- perishable goods (meat) have local markets while durable raw materials (wool, hides) access global demand. Foreshadows modern trade theory on transport costs and market integration. Cross-ref 1.11.93 on market extent determining price.

refashioned: In poorly cultivated and thinly populated countries, the price of wool and hides always makes up a much larger share of the total value of the animal than in countries where agriculture and population are more advanced, creating greater demand for meat. Hume observes that in Saxon times, the fleece was estimated at two-fifths of the whole sheep's value -- well above its current proportion. In some provinces of Spain, I have been told, sheep are frequently killed solely for their fleece and tallow, with the carcass left to rot on the ground or be consumed by scavengers. If this sometimes happens in Spain, it happens almost constantly in Chile, Buenos Aires, and many other parts of Spanish America, where cattle are routinely slaughtered just for the hide and tallow. The same used to happen in Hispaniola when it was infested by buccaneers, before the settlement and growing population of the French plantations -- which now extend around nearly the entire western coast of the island -- gave some value to Spanish cattle. The Spaniards still possess the eastern coast and the entire mountainous interior.
elegant: In undeveloped countries, wool and hides represent a far larger share of an animal's total value than in advanced ones, where meat demand is high. In Saxon England, the fleece was two-fifths of a sheep's value. In parts of Spain and widely across Spanish America, animals are still killed solely for their wool, hides, and tallow, with the meat left to rot -- a clear sign of how little demand exists for the carcass where population is sparse.
summary: In undeveloped countries with sparse populations, wool and hides dominate an animal's value because meat demand is low. In parts of Spain and across Spanish America, animals are killed for their hides and tallow alone, with the carcass discarded.
distilled: Where population is sparse and meat demand low, wool and hides dominate an animal's total value, and the carcass itself may be worthless.
notes: Illustrates how population density and economic development shift the value composition of livestock products. Historical examples: Saxon England, Spain, Chile, Buenos Aires, Hispaniola. Hume reference -- David Hume's historical economic observations. Buccaneers of Hispaniola as a case study of pre-development economics. Cross-ref 1.11.227 on transportability.

refashioned:
As improvement and population advance, the price of the whole animal necessarily rises, but the price of the carcass is likely to be affected much more than that of the wool and hide. The meat market, being confined in primitive societies to the producing country, necessarily expands in proportion to that country's improvement and population growth. But the market for wool and hides, even from a primitive country, often extends to the entire commercial world, and can seldom be expanded in the same proportion. The state of the whole commercial world is rarely much affected by improvements in any single country, so the market for such commodities may remain nearly the same after those improvements as before.

However, in the natural course of things, this market should be somewhat expanded as a result of improvement. If the manufactures that use these materials come to flourish in the producing country, the market -- though perhaps not much enlarged -- would at least be brought much closer to the source of supply. The price of those materials might then rise by whatever amount had previously been spent transporting them to distant countries. So while the price of wool and hides might not rise as much as that of butcher's meat, it ought naturally to rise somewhat, and certainly should not fall.
elegant: As population grows, the price of meat rises more than that of wool and hides. The meat market, initially local, expands with domestic development. But the wool and hide market already spans the commercial world and cannot grow proportionally. Still, if manufacturing develops locally, these materials no longer need distant transport, so their price should rise at least by the saved freight costs. Wool and hide prices should rise somewhat with development -- they certainly should not fall.
summary: Economic development raises meat prices more than wool and hide prices because meat markets expand with local population while wool and hide markets are already global. However, domestic manufacturing development should still push raw material prices somewhat higher by eliminating transport costs.
distilled: Development raises meat prices more than wool and hide prices because local meat markets expand with population, while the already-global wool and hide markets grow proportionally less.
notes: Key distinction between locally traded goods and globally traded raw materials -- development disproportionately raises prices of the former. The transport-cost savings argument anticipates import-substitution logic. Cross-ref 1.11.227-228 on market scope.

refashioned:
In England, however, despite the flourishing state of its woolen manufacture, the price of English wool has fallen considerably since the time of Edward III. Many authentic records demonstrate that during his reign -- around the mid-fourteenth century, roughly 1339 -- the moderate and reasonable price of a tod (twenty-eight pounds) of English wool was not less than ten shillings of that era's money, containing about six ounces of silver at twenty pence per ounce (Tower weight), equal to roughly thirty shillings in present money. Today, twenty-one shillings per tod may be considered a good price for very good English wool.

The money price of wool in Edward III's time was therefore to its present money price as ten to seven. But the decline in real price was even greater. At six shillings and eightpence per quarter, ten shillings would have bought twelve bushels of wheat. At twenty-eight shillings per quarter, twenty-one shillings now buys only six bushels. The ratio of real prices, ancient to modern, is therefore twelve to six -- or two to one. A tod of wool in those ancient times would have purchased twice the quantity of subsistence it buys today, and consequently twice the quantity of labor, assuming real wages were the same in both periods.
elegant: Despite England's thriving woolen industry, English wool prices have fallen sharply since Edward III's reign. In the 1340s, a tod of wool cost ten shillings (about thirty shillings in current money); today, twenty-one shillings is a good price. The nominal decline is ten to seven. But measured in wheat -- the true indicator of real value -- wool's purchasing power has halved: it once bought twelve bushels, now only six.
summary: English wool prices have fallen dramatically since the fourteenth century, both nominally and in real terms. Measured by wheat purchasing power, a tod of wool buys half what it once did, despite England's flourishing woolen manufacture.
distilled: English wool's real price has halved since Edward III's reign, with its wheat-purchasing power dropping from twelve bushels to six per tod.
notes: Historical price analysis using silver content and wheat equivalence to establish real vs. nominal price changes. Edward III (c. 1339) as benchmark. Tod = 28 pounds of wool. Tower weight silver standard. Demonstrates that a flourishing domestic manufacture does not guarantee rising raw material prices -- contradicts the natural expectation from 1.11.229.

refashioned:
This decline in both the real and nominal value of wool could never have occurred through natural market forces. It was, in fact, the result of deliberate interference and manipulation: first, the absolute prohibition on exporting wool from England; second, the permission to import Spanish wool duty-free; and third, the prohibition on exporting wool from Ireland to any country except England.

Because of these regulations, the market for English wool -- instead of expanding somewhat as England improved -- has been confined to the domestic market, where wool from several other countries is permitted to compete with it, and where Irish wool is forced into competition with it. Since Ireland's own woolen manufactures are discouraged as much as can be reconciled with justice and fair dealing, the Irish can work up only a small portion of their wool at home and are therefore compelled to send a disproportionate share to Great Britain -- the only market they are allowed.
elegant: The fall in wool prices was not natural but the result of deliberate policy: export bans on English wool, duty-free imports of Spanish wool, and the restriction of Irish wool exports to England alone. These regulations shrank the English wool market instead of letting it expand with development, while forcing Irish wool into direct competition on the only market Ireland was permitted to access.
summary: England's declining wool prices resulted from government intervention -- export prohibitions, duty-free imports, and restrictions on Irish trade -- that confined the wool market rather than allowing it to expand naturally with economic development.
distilled: Government restrictions on wool exports and trade artificially depressed English wool prices by confining the market and forcing foreign competition.
notes: Central example of how trade policy distorts natural price movements. Three specific regulations cited: English wool export ban, Spanish wool duty-free import, Irish wool export restriction. Critique of mercantilist trade policy -- foreshadows Book IV. Cross-ref 1.11.229-230 on natural vs. actual price trajectories. Ireland's subjugated trade position as a recurring Smith theme.

refashioned:
I have not been able to find authentic records concerning the price of raw hides in ancient times. Wool was commonly paid as a subsidy to the king, and its valuation in that subsidy establishes at least roughly what its ordinary price was. This does not appear to have been the case with raw hides. Fleetwood, however, from a 1425 account between the Prior of Burcester, Oxford, and one of his canons, gives us prices as stated on that particular occasion: five ox hides at twelve shillings, five cow hides at seven shillings and threepence, thirty-six sheep skins of two years old at nine shillings, and sixteen calf skins at two shillings.

In 1425, twelve shillings contained roughly the same quantity of silver as twenty-four shillings of our present money. An ox hide was therefore valued at the equivalent of about four shillings and four-fifths in current money. Its nominal price was considerably lower than at present.
elegant: Authentic records of ancient hide prices are scarce, since hides were not commonly used in royal subsidies the way wool was. Fleetwood's 1425 account from Burcester Priory provides one data point: ox hides at about twelve shillings for five, which in silver content equals roughly twenty-four present shillings -- making each ox hide worth about four shillings and four-fifths in current money. Nominally, this was well below present prices.
summary: Unlike wool, there are few reliable historical records of hide prices. A 1425 priory account valued ox hides at about four shillings and four-fifths in modern money -- nominally much lower than current prices.
distilled: Historical hide price data is scarce, but a 1425 record shows ox hides at a nominal price well below modern levels.
notes: Methodological challenge of historical price research -- data availability depends on fiscal record-keeping practices. Fleetwood's Chronicon Preciosum as a source. Burcester Priory (Bicester), Oxford. Silver-content conversion method for cross-temporal price comparison. Cross-ref 1.11.230 on wool price methodology.

refashioned:
At six shillings and eightpence per quarter, those twelve shillings would have purchased fourteen and four-fifths bushels of wheat, which at today's price of three shillings and sixpence per bushel would cost fifty-one shillings and fourpence. An ox hide would therefore have purchased as much grain as ten shillings and threepence buys today. Its real value was equivalent to ten shillings and threepence in our present money.

In those ancient times, when cattle were half-starved through most of the winter, we cannot suppose they were very large. An ox hide weighing four stone (of sixteen pounds avoirdupois) is not considered a bad hide today; in those times, it would probably have been reckoned a very good one.
elegant: Measured in wheat purchasing power, a fifteenth-century ox hide had a real value of about ten shillings and threepence in present money -- considerably more than its nominal value suggested. Yet the hides themselves were likely smaller, since medieval cattle, half-starved through winter, were not large animals.
summary: An ox hide in 1425 had a real value -- measured by wheat purchasing power -- of about ten shillings and threepence in modern money. Medieval cattle were likely smaller due to poor winter feeding, making their hides smaller too.
distilled: Medieval ox hides had higher real value than their nominal price suggests, though the hides themselves were probably smaller due to poorly fed cattle.
notes: Real vs. nominal price distinction using wheat as numeraire. The observation about cattle size introduces a quality-adjustment problem in historical price comparison -- a precursor to modern hedonic pricing. Cross-ref 1.11.232. Four stone = 64 pounds avoirdupois.

refashioned:
At half a crown per stone, which I understand to be the common price at this moment (February 1773), such a hide would cost only ten shillings today. So although its nominal price is now higher than in those ancient times, its real price -- the actual quantity of subsistence it can purchase -- is somewhat lower.

The cow hide prices in the account above are roughly in their usual proportion to ox hides. Sheep skin prices are well above that proportion -- they had probably been sold with the wool still on. Calf skin prices, on the contrary, are far below the normal ratio. In countries where cattle prices are very low, calves not intended for breeding are generally killed very young, as was the case in Scotland twenty or thirty years ago. This saves the milk, which their sale price would not cover. Their skins, therefore, are typically worth very little.
elegant: At current prices (February 1773), such a hide costs about ten shillings -- nominally higher than in 1425 but in real terms slightly lower. Cow hides follow the usual proportion to ox hides. Sheep skins were priced high, likely because they included the wool. Calf skins were very cheap because in poor countries, calves are killed young to save the milk -- making their skins nearly worthless.
summary: Despite higher nominal prices, the real price of ox hides has slightly declined since the fifteenth century. Calf skins were especially cheap in earlier times because calves were killed young to conserve milk in countries with low cattle prices.
distilled: Ox hides have a slightly lower real price today than in 1425, while calf skins were historically cheap because calves were killed young to save milk.
notes: Dated reference: February 1773 anchors composition timeline. Real vs. nominal price inversion -- nominal rise masking real decline. Calf-killing economics -- an example of how low output prices change production decisions at the margin. Scotland 'twenty or thirty years ago' = c. 1743-1753. Cross-ref 1.11.232-233.

refashioned:
The price of raw hides is currently well below what it was a few years ago, probably due to the removal of the duty on seal skins and the temporary duty-free importation of raw hides from Ireland and the plantations, permitted in 1769. Taking the present century as a whole, however, their real price has probably been somewhat higher than in ancient times.

The nature of hides makes them less suitable for transport to distant markets than wool. They deteriorate more with keeping -- a salted hide is considered inferior to a fresh one and sells for less. This naturally tends to depress the price of hides from countries that do not manufacture them and must export them, while raising the price in manufacturing countries. It therefore tends to lower hide prices in primitive economies and raise them in advanced ones -- sinking them in ancient times and raising them in modern ones.

Our tanners, moreover, have not been as successful as our clothiers in persuading the government that national security depends on their industry's prosperity. They have accordingly been much less favored. The export of raw hides has been prohibited and declared a nuisance, but imports from foreign countries have been subject to a duty. Although this duty was removed for Irish and plantation hides for a limited five-year period, Ireland has not been confined to the British market for selling its surplus hides. Only recently have common cattle hides been added to the enumerated commodities that plantations can send only to the mother country. Irish hide commerce has not yet been oppressed to support British manufactures.
elegant: Hide prices recently fell due to the removal of seal skin duties and temporary duty-free imports from Ireland and the plantations (1769). Over the century, though, real hide prices have been somewhat higher than in ancient times. Hides transport less well than wool -- salted hides sell below fresh ones -- which naturally depresses prices in non-manufacturing countries and raises them in manufacturing ones. Tanners have also been less politically successful than clothiers in securing favorable regulations, so hide trade has been less restricted: exports are banned, but imports face fewer barriers, and Ireland has not been confined to the British market for hides as it has been for wool.
summary: Hide prices recently declined due to policy changes, but have been somewhat higher over the century than in ancient times. Hides transport less well than wool, creating natural price differentials between manufacturing and non-manufacturing countries. Tanners have secured less regulatory protection than clothiers.
distilled: Raw hide prices are influenced by their perishability in transport, recent trade liberalization, and the tanners' lesser political success compared to wool manufacturers in securing protective regulations.
notes: Comparative political economy of wool vs. hide industries -- demonstrates how political influence shapes trade policy. 1769 liberalization. Enumerated commodities -- colonial trade restrictions under the Navigation Acts. Perishability as a trade barrier distinct from transport cost. 'Wisdom of the nation' -- Smith's ironic phrase for Parliament's susceptibility to industry lobbying. Cross-ref 1.11.231 on wool trade restrictions.

refashioned: Any regulation that pushes the price of wool or raw hides below its natural level must, in an improved and cultivated country, tend to raise the price of butcher's meat. The price of cattle raised on improved land must be sufficient to cover the rent the landlord expects and the profit the farmer expects from that land. If it is not, they will simply stop raising cattle. Whatever portion of this required price is not covered by the wool and hide must therefore be covered by the carcass.
elegant: Regulations that artificially depress wool or hide prices must raise meat prices in developed countries. Cattle raised on improved land must cover the landlord's rent and farmer's profit. Whatever shortfall the wool and hide leave, the carcass must make up.
summary: Artificially depressing wool and hide prices forces meat prices higher, because livestock raised on improved land must still generate enough total revenue to cover rent and profit.
distilled: Regulations that lower wool and hide prices inevitably raise meat prices, since the total revenue from each animal must still cover land rent and farming profit.
notes: Zero-sum pricing of joint products -- the animal's total value must meet a floor set by land costs. Opportunity cost reasoning: if livestock cannot cover the returns from crop farming, farmers switch. Cross-ref 1.11.229 on the natural price relationship between carcass and by-products. Anticipates the modern concept of joint-product pricing.

refashioned:
The less that is paid for one component, the more must be paid for the other. How this total price is divided among the different parts of the animal is a matter of indifference to landlords and farmers, so long as the full amount is paid to them. In an improved country, therefore, their interests as landlords and farmers cannot be much affected by such regulations, though their interests as consumers may be, through higher provision prices.

It would be quite different, however, in an unimproved and uncultivated country, where most of the land could serve no purpose other than feeding cattle, and where wool and hide constituted the principal value of those cattle. In that case, their interest as landlords and farmers would be deeply affected by such regulations, while their interest as consumers would be affected very little.
elegant: Landlords and farmers are indifferent to how price is split between carcass and by-products, so long as the total covers their costs. In developed countries, regulations depressing wool and hide prices merely shift value to the carcass, harming them only as consumers of pricier meat. In undeveloped countries where most land can only support grazing and by-products are the main value, such regulations would devastate their income as producers.
summary: In developed countries, artificially low wool and hide prices simply shift value to meat, affecting landowners only as consumers. In undeveloped pastoral economies, the same regulations would devastate producer incomes since by-products are the main source of value.
distilled: Joint-product price regulations are harmless to producers in developed countries where costs shift to meat, but devastating in pastoral economies where by-products are the primary value.
notes: Dual role of economic actors -- producers vs. consumers. Stage-of-development contingency in policy impact. The developed vs. undeveloped country distinction shows Smith's awareness that identical policies have radically different effects depending on economic structure. Cross-ref 1.11.236.

refashioned: In an undeveloped country, the fall in wool and hide prices would not raise the price of the carcass, because the land, being suitable for nothing but grazing, would continue to support the same number of cattle. The same quantity of meat would still come to market. Demand for it would be no greater than before. Its price would therefore remain unchanged. The entire price of cattle would fall, and with it both the rent and profit of all the lands whose principal product was cattle -- that is, the greater part of the country's land.
elegant: In an undeveloped pastoral country, lower wool and hide prices would not raise meat prices because the land has no alternative use -- the same number of cattle would be raised, the same meat would reach market, and demand would be unchanged. Instead, the total value of cattle would simply fall, dragging down the rent and profit of most of the country's land.
summary: In undeveloped pastoral economies, depressing wool and hide prices would not raise meat prices because land has no alternative use. Instead, overall cattle value would decline, reducing rents and profits across most of the country.
distilled: Where land can only support grazing, lower by-product prices cannot be offset by higher meat prices -- they simply reduce the total value of cattle and the income from land.
notes: Land-use rigidity as a key variable -- when there is no opportunity cost for land (no alternative crops), the zero-sum joint-product logic breaks down. Supply remains fixed regardless of price, so the full burden falls on producer income. Cross-ref 1.11.236-237. Anticipates the concept of price inelasticity of supply.

refashioned: The perpetual prohibition on wool exports, commonly but falsely attributed to Edward III, would have been the most destructive regulation imaginable under the circumstances of that era. It would not only have reduced the actual value of most of the kingdom's land, but by lowering the price of the most important type of small livestock, it would have greatly retarded subsequent agricultural improvement.
