elegant: A permanent wool export ban -- falsely attributed to Edward III -- would have been devastating in that era: it would have reduced land values across most of the kingdom and, by depressing small livestock prices, severely retarded agricultural improvement.
summary: A permanent wool export ban, wrongly attributed to Edward III, would have been catastrophic for medieval England by reducing land values and retarding agricultural development through lower livestock prices.
distilled: Banning wool exports in medieval England would have devastated land values and agricultural progress by collapsing the price of small livestock.
notes: Historical correction -- the export ban is 'commonly but very falsely ascribed to Edward III.' Policy timing matters: the same regulation has different effects depending on the stage of development. Cross-ref 1.11.237-238 on undeveloped-country impacts. Links livestock prices to land improvement incentives.

refashioned: Scottish wool fell considerably in price following the union with England, which excluded it from the great European market and confined it to the narrow British one. The value of most land in the southern Scottish counties -- primarily sheep country -- would have been severely damaged by this event, had the rise in butcher's meat prices not fully compensated for the fall in wool prices.
elegant: After the Anglo-Scottish union, Scottish wool lost access to European markets and was confined to Britain. Southern Scotland's land values -- a sheep-rearing region -- would have collapsed if rising meat prices had not offset the wool price decline.
summary: The union with England confined Scottish wool to the British market, depressing its price. Southern Scotland's land values survived only because rising meat prices compensated for the wool price decline.
distilled: The Anglo-Scottish union depressed Scottish wool prices by restricting its market, but rising meat prices offset the damage to southern Scottish land values.
notes: The 1707 Act of Union as a natural experiment in market restriction. Southern Scotland as sheep country. Demonstrates the joint-product offset mechanism from 1.11.236-237 operating in practice. Cross-ref 1.11.231 on trade restrictions depressing wool prices.

refashioned: Human industry's ability to increase the supply of wool or raw hides is limited insofar as it depends on domestic production, and uncertain insofar as it depends on the production of other countries. It depends not so much on how much those other countries produce, but on how much they do not manufacture domestically -- and on whatever export restrictions they may impose on such raw materials. These circumstances, being entirely outside domestic control, necessarily make the results of domestic efforts more or less uncertain. In multiplying this type of raw produce, therefore, the effectiveness of human industry is not only limited but uncertain.
elegant: A country's ability to increase its wool and hide supply is limited by domestic land and uncertain because it also depends on what other countries export. Foreign supply hinges not on total foreign production but on how much remains unmanufactured and what export restrictions apply -- factors entirely beyond domestic control.
summary: The domestic supply of wool and hides is constrained by land, while the international supply depends on foreign countries' manufacturing capacity and export policies -- factors beyond any nation's control.
distilled: The supply of wool and hides is limited by domestic land and made uncertain by foreign countries' unpredictable manufacturing and export decisions.
notes: Transition paragraph -- moves from wool and hides to the broader category of raw materials whose supply is both limited and uncertain. Introduces foreign policy as a source of supply-side uncertainty. Cross-ref 1.11.227-240. Foreshadows the fish and minerals discussion that follows.

refashioned: In multiplying another very important type of raw produce -- the quantity of fish brought to market -- human industry is likewise both limited and uncertain. It is limited by the country's geography: its proximity to the sea, the number of its lakes and rivers, and what might be called the fertility or barrenness of those waters. As population increases and the annual produce of land and labor grows, more buyers appear for fish, and those buyers have a greater quantity and variety of other goods -- or equivalently, more money -- to spend. But supplying a greatly expanded market generally requires a disproportionate increase in labor. A market that grows from requiring one thousand to ten thousand tons of fish annually can seldom be supplied with merely ten times the previous labor. The fish must generally be sought at greater distances, larger vessels must be employed, and more expensive equipment of every kind must be used. The real price of fish therefore naturally rises as an economy develops. This has happened, I believe, to a greater or lesser degree in every country.
elegant: The fish supply is limited by geography -- coastline, lakes, rivers, and the productivity of those waters. As population and wealth grow, fish demand increases, but supplying a larger market requires disproportionately more labor: fish must be sought farther away, in larger vessels, with costlier equipment. The real price of fish therefore naturally rises with economic development.
summary: Fish supply is limited by geography and rises in cost with economic development, because expanding the catch requires disproportionately more labor, larger vessels, and costlier equipment as nearby sources are depleted.
distilled: Fish prices naturally rise with development because expanding supply requires disproportionately more labor and capital as nearby fishing grounds are exhausted.
notes: Diminishing returns in extractive industries -- a classic example. The disproportionate labor requirement anticipates the concept of increasing marginal cost. Geography as a binding constraint on supply. Cross-ref 1.11.241 on limited and uncertain raw produce. Parallels the later discussion of mining (1.11.244).

refashioned: Although the success of any particular day's fishing may be highly uncertain, the general effectiveness of the fishing industry in bringing a certain quantity to market over a year or several years -- given the country's geographic situation -- may be considered reasonably certain. But because it depends more on geography than on wealth and industry, and because geography can produce the same fishing output at very different stages of development and very different output at the same stage, the connection between fishing and economic progress is uncertain. It is this kind of uncertainty I am discussing here.
elegant: A single day's catch is unpredictable, but the annual fishing output, given a country's geography, is fairly reliable. However, since fishing depends more on location than on wealth or industry, identical geographies may produce the same catch at different stages of development. The connection between fishing output and economic progress is therefore uncertain.
summary: While annual fish catch is fairly predictable for a given geography, the relationship between fishing output and economic development is uncertain because geography matters more than wealth or industry in determining fish supply.
distilled: Fishing output depends more on geography than on economic development, making the connection between the two inherently uncertain.
notes: Distinguishes between statistical predictability (law of large numbers over a year) and structural uncertainty (no reliable link to development stage). Clarifies the type of uncertainty Smith is analyzing -- not randomness but structural disconnection from progress. Cross-ref 1.11.241-242.

refashioned:
In increasing the supply of minerals and metals drawn from the earth -- particularly the precious metals -- the effectiveness of human industry seems not merely limited, but altogether uncertain.

The quantity of precious metals found in any country is not determined by its local geology or the productivity of its own mines. These metals are frequently abundant in countries with no mines at all. A country's supply depends on two factors: first, its purchasing power -- the state of its industry and the annual output of its land and labor, which determines how much labor and resources it can devote to acquiring such luxuries as gold and silver, whether from domestic mines or foreign ones; and second, the productivity of whichever mines happen at any given time to supply the commercial world. Even the most remote countries feel the effects of mine productivity, because precious metals are easily and cheaply transported given their small bulk and great value. The quantity of gold and silver in China and India, for instance, must have been affected by the abundance of the American mines.
elegant: The supply of precious metals is entirely uncertain. A country's gold and silver stock depends not on its own mines but on two things: its purchasing power (which determines how much labor it can devote to acquiring these luxuries) and the productivity of whatever mines currently supply the world. Because precious metals are small, valuable, and cheap to transport, even distant countries like China and India are affected by the abundance of American mines.
summary: A country's supply of precious metals depends on its purchasing power and on the productivity of the world's mines, not on domestic geology. Because gold and silver are easily transported, the American mines affect precious metal stocks even in China and India.
distilled: Precious metal supply depends on a country's purchasing power and the productivity of the world's mines, not on domestic mining, because these metals transport cheaply across any distance.
notes: Two determinants of precious metal supply: demand-side (purchasing power from domestic output) and supply-side (global mine productivity). High value-to-weight ratio enables global market integration. American mines as a supply shock to the entire world system. China and India examples. Cross-ref 1.11.241-243 on categories of raw produce. Foreshadows the silver price digression conclusions.

refashioned: Insofar as a country's precious metal supply depends on its purchasing power, the real price of gold and silver -- like that of all luxuries and superfluities -- is likely to rise with the country's wealth and improvement, and fall with its poverty and decline. Countries with more labor and subsistence to spare can afford to purchase any given quantity of these metals at the expense of a greater quantity of labor and subsistence than countries with less to spare.
elegant: When precious metal supply depends on a country's purchasing power, their real price rises with wealth -- richer countries can afford to devote more labor and resources to acquiring these luxuries than poorer ones can.
summary: The demand-driven component of precious metal pricing means their real price rises with national wealth, since richer countries can devote more resources to acquiring luxuries like gold and silver.
distilled: Precious metals' real price rises with national wealth because richer countries can afford to spend more labor acquiring them.
notes: Demand-side determinant of precious metal prices -- treats gold and silver as luxury goods whose demand rises with income. Implicit income elasticity argument. Cross-ref 1.11.244 on the two determinants. Anticipates the Engel curve concept for luxury goods.

refashioned: Insofar as a country's precious metal supply depends on the productivity of the mines supplying the commercial world, their real price -- the real quantity of labor and subsistence they can buy -- will fall in proportion to the mines' productivity and rise in proportion to their barrenness.
elegant: When precious metal supply depends on mine productivity, their real price falls as mines become more productive and rises as they become less so.
summary: The supply-side component of precious metal pricing is straightforward: more productive mines lower real prices, less productive mines raise them.
distilled: More productive mines lower the real price of precious metals; less productive mines raise it.
notes: Supply-side determinant -- simple inverse relationship between mine productivity and metal prices. Completes the two-factor framework from 1.11.244-245. Cross-ref 1.11.244.

refashioned: The productivity of the mines supplying the commercial world at any given time evidently has no necessary connection to the state of industry in any particular country. It seems to have no very strong connection even to the state of the world economy in general. As arts and commerce gradually spread across more of the earth, the search for new mines -- extending over a wider area -- may have a somewhat better chance of success than when confined within narrower bounds.
elegant: Mine productivity has no necessary connection to any country's industrial development, nor even to the global economy. The only link is that as commerce spreads geographically, the search for new mines covers more ground and may be somewhat more likely to succeed.
summary: The productivity of precious metal mines is essentially unconnected to economic development, either national or global. The only indirect link is that expanding commerce extends the geographic search for new deposits.
distilled: Mine productivity is largely independent of economic development -- only the geographic expansion of commerce slightly improves the odds of discovering new deposits.
notes: Decoupling mine productivity from economic development -- a key argument against mercantilism's equation of precious metals with wealth. The geographic-search argument is a minor concession. Cross-ref 1.11.244-246. Builds toward the conclusion that precious metal abundance says nothing about a country's real prosperity.

refashioned: The discovery of new mines, as old ones are gradually exhausted, is a matter of the greatest uncertainty -- one that no human skill or industry can guarantee. All geological indicators are acknowledged to be doubtful; only the actual discovery and successful operation of a new mine can confirm its value or even its existence. In this search, there appear to be no certain limits to either the possible success or the possible disappointment of human effort. Within a century or two, it is entirely possible that mines more productive than any yet known may be discovered. It is equally possible that the most productive mine then known may be less fertile than any worked before the discovery of the American mines.
elegant: Discovering new mines is radically uncertain -- no skill or geological knowledge can guarantee success. Only actual discovery and operation prove a mine's worth. There are no limits to either the possible success or the possible failure: future centuries may yield mines richer than any known, or the best remaining mines may be poorer than anything worked before the Americas were found.
summary: Mine discovery is fundamentally uncertain, beyond the reach of human skill or prediction. Future mines could be vastly richer or poorer than anything yet known.
distilled: The discovery of new mines is radically uncertain, with no guaranteed limits on either future abundance or future scarcity of precious metals.
notes: Radical uncertainty vs. calculable risk -- Smith describes what Frank Knight would later formalize as 'true uncertainty.' No geological indicators are reliable. Symmetry of possible outcomes -- equally likely to find richer or poorer mines. American mines as the historical benchmark. Cross-ref 1.11.247.

refashioned: Whether richer or poorer mines are discovered matters very little to the real wealth and prosperity of the world -- to the real value of the annual produce of the land and labor of mankind. The nominal value of that output -- the quantity of gold and silver used to express or represent it -- would certainly be very different in each case. But the real value -- the actual quantity of labor it could purchase or command -- would be precisely the same. A shilling might, in one case, represent no more labor than a penny does today; and a penny, in the other case, might represent as much as a shilling does now.
elegant: Whether future mines are richer or poorer makes no difference to real global wealth. Nominal values -- the gold and silver used to express output -- would change dramatically, but real values -- the actual labor that output commands -- would remain the same. A shilling might buy only a penny's worth of labor, or a penny might buy a shilling's worth.
summary: The productivity of future mines is irrelevant to real global wealth. Only nominal values would change -- a shilling might represent a penny's labor or vice versa -- while the real purchasing power of total output would remain the same.
distilled: Mine productivity affects only the nominal expression of wealth in gold and silver, not the real wealth measured by labor and output.
notes: Core anti-mercantilist insight: the quantity of precious metals is irrelevant to real wealth. Real vs. nominal distinction applied to global output. The shilling/penny thought experiment makes the abstraction vivid. Cross-ref 1.11.244-248. Central to Book IV's critique of mercantilism.

refashioned: In one case, the man with a shilling in his pocket would be no richer than someone with a penny today; in the other, the man with a penny would be just as rich as someone with a shilling now. The sole advantage the world could gain from discovering richer mines would be cheaper and more abundant gold and silver plate. The only inconvenience from poorer mines would be the dearness and scarcity of those trifling luxuries.
elegant: Abundant mines would only make gold and silver plate cheaper; scarce mines would only make those trivial luxuries dearer. No real wealth would be gained or lost either way.
summary: Richer mines would only cheapen gold and silver decorative goods; poorer mines would only make them scarcer. Neither outcome would affect real wealth.
distilled: The only real consequence of mine productivity is the price of gold and silver plate -- a trivial luxury.
notes: Reduces the entire precious metals question to the price of decorative plate -- a deliberate rhetorical deflation of mercantilist concerns. 'Trifling superfluities' -- Smith's dismissive framing. Cross-ref 1.11.249. Completes the argument that mine productivity is economically inconsequential for real welfare.

refashioned:
Conclusion of the Digression concerning the Variations in the Value of Silver.

Most writers who have collected the money prices of things in ancient times seem to have regarded the low money price of grain and goods in general -- or equivalently, the high value of gold and silver -- as proof not only of the scarcity of those metals, but of the poverty and barbarism of the country at that time. This notion is connected to a system of political economy that identifies national wealth with the abundance of gold and silver, and national poverty with their scarcity -- a system I shall explain and examine at length in the fourth book of this inquiry. For now, I shall only observe that the high value of precious metals can be no proof of the poverty or barbarism of any particular country at the time it occurred.
elegant: Most writers treat low ancient money prices as proof of both metal scarcity and national poverty. This conflation stems from the mercantilist system that equates wealth with gold and silver abundance -- a system examined in Book IV. But the high value of precious metals proves nothing about a country's prosperity or barbarism.
summary: Writers who see low ancient money prices as proof of poverty are confusing metal scarcity with economic backwardness -- a mercantilist error. The high value of precious metals reflects only the state of the mines, not the wealth of nations.
distilled: The high value of precious metals in ancient times proves nothing about a country's poverty -- only about the scarcity of the metals themselves.
notes: Conclusion to the silver digression. Attacks the mercantilist equation of gold/silver abundance with national wealth. Forward reference to Book IV's systematic critique of mercantilism. Cross-ref 1.11.244-250 on the irrelevance of metal quantities to real wealth.

refashioned:
The high value of precious metals proves only the barrenness of the mines that happened to supply the commercial world at that time. A poor country can no more afford to pay a premium for gold and silver than a rich one can, so the value of those metals is not likely to be higher in a poor country than in a rich one. In China, a country much richer than any part of Europe, the value of precious metals is much higher than anywhere in Europe.

As Europe's wealth has grown enormously since the discovery of the American mines, the value of gold and silver has gradually declined. But this decline was not caused by the increase in Europe's real wealth -- the annual output of its land and labor. It was caused by the accidental discovery of mines more abundant than any previously known.
elegant: High metal values reflect barren mines, not national poverty -- poor countries cannot afford to bid up metal prices any more than rich ones. China, richer than Europe, has higher precious metal values. Europe's falling metal values since the American discoveries resulted not from growing wealth but from the accidental abundance of new mines.
summary: The value of precious metals reflects mine productivity, not national wealth. Poor countries cannot outbid rich ones for metals. Europe's declining metal values since the American mine discoveries were caused by mine abundance, not by rising real wealth.
distilled: Precious metal values reflect mine productivity, not national wealth -- as proven by China's high metal values despite being richer than Europe.
notes: China as a counterexample to the mercantilist thesis -- rich country with high metal values. Separates the accidental cause (American mines) from the structural cause (rising European wealth). Cross-ref 1.11.251. The China comparison recurs throughout the Wealth of Nations as a benchmark.

refashioned: The increase in Europe's gold and silver supply and the increase in its manufactures and agriculture are two events that, though roughly simultaneous, arose from entirely different causes and have almost no natural connection. The influx of precious metals arose from a mere accident in which neither prudence nor policy played any part. The growth of manufactures and agriculture arose from the fall of the feudal system and the establishment of a government that gave industry the only encouragement it truly needs: some reasonable security that it will enjoy the fruits of its own labor. Poland, where the feudal system still persists, remains as impoverished today as it was before the discovery of America.
elegant: Europe's gold and silver increase and its economic growth were simultaneous but unconnected. The metals came from the accident of discovering American mines. The economic growth came from the fall of feudalism and the establishment of governments that secured people's right to enjoy the fruits of their labor. Poland, still feudal, remains as poor as before America was discovered.
summary: Europe's precious metal influx and its economic growth were coincidental, not causally connected. Metals came from accidental mine discoveries; real growth came from replacing feudalism with governments that protected property rights. Feudal Poland's persistent poverty proves the point.
distilled: Europe's economic growth came from the fall of feudalism and the security of property rights, not from the accidental influx of American gold and silver.
notes: Causal separation of two simultaneous phenomena -- a key methodological move. Identifies the true cause of European growth: institutional reform (property security) rather than monetary expansion. Poland as the counter-case: received metals but remained feudal and poor. 'Some tolerable security that it shall enjoy the fruits of its own labour' -- one of Smith's most famous formulations of the institutional basis of growth. Cross-ref 1.11.251-252.

refashioned: The money price of grain has risen in Poland, and the real value of precious metals has fallen there, just as in other parts of Europe. Their quantity must therefore have increased in Poland as elsewhere, in roughly the same proportion to the annual output of its land and labor. Yet this increase in metals has not increased that annual output, has neither improved the country's manufactures and agriculture, nor bettered the circumstances of its people. Spain and Portugal, the countries that actually possess the mines, are -- after Poland -- perhaps the two poorest countries in Europe.
elegant: Poland received precious metals like the rest of Europe -- its grain prices rose and metal values fell. Yet this metal influx produced no improvement in its output, manufactures, agriculture, or living standards. Spain and Portugal, which own the mines themselves, are after Poland perhaps Europe's poorest countries.
summary: Poland received precious metals proportionally like other European countries, yet experienced no economic improvement. Spain and Portugal, owners of the mines, are among Europe's poorest -- proving that metal abundance does not create real wealth.
distilled: Poland, Spain, and Portugal prove that an abundance of precious metals produces no economic improvement without the right institutions.
notes: Three empirical counter-cases to mercantilism: Poland (feudal recipient of metals), Spain and Portugal (mine owners). All metal-rich, all poor. The argument is devastating to the mercantilist thesis. Cross-ref 1.11.253 on institutions vs. metals. Foreshadows Book IV.

refashioned: The value of precious metals must actually be lower in Spain and Portugal than anywhere else in Europe, since metals flow from those countries to all others burdened not only with freight and insurance costs but also with the expense of smuggling -- their export being either prohibited or taxed. Relative to annual output, the quantity of precious metals must therefore be greater in Spain and Portugal than anywhere else in Europe. Yet those countries are poorer than most of the continent. Although the feudal system has been abolished in Spain and Portugal, it has not been replaced by anything much better.
elegant: Spain and Portugal should have the lowest metal values in Europe, since metals flow out from there bearing freight, insurance, and smuggling costs. They therefore hold proportionally more precious metals than any other European country -- yet they remain poorer than most. Abolishing feudalism did not help because it was replaced by an equally deficient system.
summary: Spain and Portugal have Europe's lowest precious metal values and highest metal stocks relative to output, yet remain among the continent's poorest nations because they replaced feudalism with an equally poor institutional system.
distilled: Spain and Portugal have the most precious metals relative to output in Europe yet remain among its poorest countries, proving that metals without good institutions produce no prosperity.
notes: Transport costs and smuggling costs as evidence of metal abundance in source countries. Institutional diagnosis: Spain and Portugal abolished feudalism but replaced it with similarly dysfunctional governance. Cross-ref 1.11.253-254. The export prohibition/smuggling detail adds empirical texture.

refashioned:
Therefore, just as the low value of gold and silver is no proof of a country's wealth and prosperity, neither is their high value -- or the low money price of goods in general or grain in particular -- any proof of its poverty and barbarism.

However, while the low money price of goods in general or grain in particular proves nothing about a country's condition, the low money price of certain specific goods -- such as cattle, poultry, and game -- relative to grain is a decisive indicator. It clearly demonstrates, first, the great abundance of such goods relative to grain, and consequently the vast extent of land devoted to them compared to cropland; and second, the low value of that land relative to cropland, and consequently the uncultivated and unimproved state of most of the country's land. It shows that the country's capital and population did not bear the proportion to its territory that they typically do in civilized countries -- that society was still in its infancy.

From high or low money prices of goods in general, or grain in particular, we can infer only whether the mines supplying the world were productive or barren -- not whether a country was rich or poor. But from the high or low money price of certain goods relative to others, we can infer with near certainty whether a country was rich or poor, improved or unimproved, barbarous or civilized.
elegant: Low metal values do not prove wealth; high metal values do not prove poverty. These only reflect mine productivity. But the relative money prices of different goods -- specifically, cheap cattle, poultry, and game compared to grain -- are a decisive indicator of development. Low prices for these goods relative to grain prove vast uncultivated land, sparse population, and an early stage of civilization. Absolute money prices reveal nothing about prosperity; relative prices reveal almost everything.
summary: Absolute money prices reflect only mine productivity, not national wealth. But relative prices -- particularly cheap livestock and game compared to grain -- are a reliable indicator of economic development, revealing the extent of uncultivated land and the stage of civilization.
distilled: Absolute money prices tell us about mine productivity; relative prices of livestock to grain tell us about a country's stage of economic development.
notes: Crucial methodological distinction: absolute vs. relative prices as development indicators. Absolute prices reflect monetary conditions; relative prices reflect real economic structure. Anticipates modern development economics use of relative price ratios. The livestock-to-grain price ratio as a development index. Cross-ref 1.11.251-255. Synthesizes the entire silver digression into an actionable analytical framework.

refashioned: Any rise in the money price of goods caused entirely by the declining value of silver would affect all goods equally -- raising prices universally by a third, a fourth, or a fifth, depending on how much silver had lost. But the actual rise in provision prices, which has been the subject of so much discussion, has not affected all provisions equally. Even those who attribute this rise to silver's declining value acknowledge that the price of grain has risen much less than that of certain other provisions. The rise in those other provisions, therefore, cannot be explained entirely by the fall in silver's value. Other causes must be involved, and those I have already identified will, I believe, sufficiently explain the rise in the specific provisions whose price has increased relative to grain -- without resorting to the supposed decline in silver's value.
elegant: If silver's decline were the sole cause of rising prices, all goods would rise equally. But provision prices have risen unequally -- grain much less than meat and other animal products. The unequal rise therefore cannot be attributed to silver alone. The causes previously identified -- expanding cultivation and population -- adequately explain the relative price shifts without invoking silver depreciation.
summary: Rising provision prices cannot be attributed solely to declining silver value because the rise is unequal across goods. Grain prices have risen far less than meat prices, pointing to real causes like expanding cultivation rather than monetary depreciation.
distilled: The unequal rise in provision prices -- grain rising less than meat -- proves that real economic changes, not silver depreciation, are the primary cause.
notes: Empirical test of the silver-depreciation hypothesis: if true, all prices rise equally; they do not, so the hypothesis fails as a complete explanation. Uses the relative price framework from 1.11.256. The real causes identified earlier: expanding cultivation converting pasture to cropland (1.11.229, 1.11.263). Cross-ref 1.11.256.

refashioned: As for the price of grain itself, during the first sixty-four years of the present century -- before the recent extraordinary run of bad seasons -- it was actually somewhat lower than during the last sixty-four years of the previous century. This is confirmed not only by the records of Windsor market, but by the official price assessments of all the different Scottish counties, and by accounts from several French markets, collected with great care and accuracy by Messance and Dupre de St. Maur. The evidence is more thorough than one might expect for a matter naturally so difficult to establish.
elegant: Grain prices in the first sixty-four years of the eighteenth century were actually lower than in the last sixty-four years of the seventeenth -- confirmed by Windsor market records, Scottish county price assessments, and French market data collected by Messance and Dupre de St. Maur.
summary: Grain prices in the early eighteenth century were lower than in the late seventeenth century, as confirmed by market records from England, Scotland, and France.
distilled: Grain prices were lower in 1700-1764 than in 1636-1700, based on evidence from English, Scottish, and French market records.
notes: Empirical evidence against the silver-depreciation hypothesis for grain. Multiple independent data sources: Windsor market, Scottish fiars (official county price assessments), French market data. Messance and Dupre de St. Maur -- French statistical economists. Cross-ref 1.11.257.

refashioned:
As for the high grain prices of the last ten or twelve years, these can be adequately explained by bad harvests, without supposing any decline in the value of silver.

The opinion that silver is continually losing value, therefore, appears to rest on no solid evidence -- neither from grain prices nor from the prices of other provisions.
elegant: Recent high grain prices are explained by bad harvests, not by silver depreciation. The theory that silver continually loses value is unsupported by evidence from either grain or other provision prices.
summary: High recent grain prices are explained by bad seasons, not declining silver value. The entire theory of continuous silver depreciation lacks empirical support.
distilled: Bad harvests, not silver depreciation, explain recent high grain prices, and the theory of continuously declining silver value is empirically unfounded.
notes: Concludes the empirical case against the silver-depreciation theory. Weather/harvest variability as an alternative explanation for short-term price spikes. Cross-ref 1.11.257-258. Clean summary rejection of a widespread contemporary belief.

refashioned: It may be objected that silver does buy less of many provisions now than it did in the previous century, even by the account given here, and that distinguishing whether this reflects rising goods or falling silver is a vain and useless exercise -- of no practical help to someone going to market with a fixed quantity of silver or a fixed money income. I certainly do not claim that understanding this distinction will help anyone buy cheaper. But it may not, on that account, be altogether useless.
elegant: Some may say the distinction between rising goods prices and falling silver value is useless to someone with a fixed income -- it will not help them buy cheaper. True enough. But the distinction is not therefore without all use.
summary: While the distinction between rising real prices and declining silver value does not help individual buyers, it is not entirely useless for other purposes.
distilled: The distinction between rising real prices and falling silver value has no practical use for individual consumers but serves broader analytical purposes.
notes: Anticipates and addresses the practical-relevance objection. Pivots from individual utility to public utility of the analysis. Sets up the arguments in 1.11.261-262. Cross-ref 1.11.257-259.

refashioned: The distinction may be useful to the public by providing an easy proof of the country's prosperity. If provision prices are rising solely because silver is losing value, that tells us nothing except that the American mines are productive. The country's real wealth -- its annual output -- may still be declining, as in Portugal and Poland, or advancing, as in most of Europe. But if provision prices are rising because land has become more valuable -- either through greater fertility or because improvement and cultivation have made it fit for growing grain -- that indicates, in the clearest possible terms, a prosperous and advancing country. Land is by far the greatest, most important, and most durable part of any large country's wealth. It is surely of some use -- or at least some satisfaction -- to the public to have such decisive proof that the value of this, the most important part of national wealth, is increasing.
elegant: If rising provision prices reflect only falling silver, they reveal nothing about a country's condition -- it could be declining or advancing. But if prices rise because land has become more productive and valuable through cultivation, that decisively proves national prosperity. Land is the greatest, most important, and most durable component of national wealth, and evidence of its rising value is evidence of national progress.
summary: Rising provision prices caused by improving land values prove national prosperity, while prices rising from silver depreciation prove nothing. Since land is the most important component of national wealth, evidence of its increasing value is genuinely useful to the public.
distilled: Rising provision prices driven by improving land productivity prove national prosperity, while those driven by silver depreciation prove nothing about a country's economic condition.
notes: Public-interest justification for the real-vs-nominal distinction. Land as the greatest component of national wealth -- a physiocratic-leaning claim. Diagnostic value: the same observed price rise can indicate either progress or monetary disturbance. Cross-ref 1.11.260, 1.11.253-254 (Poland and Portugal as negative cases).

refashioned: The distinction may also be useful to the public in setting the pay of its lower-ranking employees. If provision prices rise because silver has lost value, then monetary wages -- provided they were not already excessive -- should certainly be increased in proportion to that decline. If they are not, real compensation will be visibly diminished. But if prices rise because of the increased value of land resulting from improved productivity, it becomes a much more delicate matter to judge whether monetary wages should be raised at all, and if so, by how much.
elegant: If rising prices come from silver depreciation, public servants' wages should rise proportionally or their real pay falls. But if prices rise from improved land productivity, the case for wage increases is far more complex and uncertain.
summary: The real-versus-nominal price distinction has practical implications for setting public-sector wages: silver depreciation clearly justifies proportional raises, but price increases from improved land values make the appropriate wage response far less obvious.
distilled: Whether rising prices stem from silver depreciation or land improvement determines whether public servants' wages should be raised and by how much.
notes: Practical policy application of the real-vs-nominal distinction: public-sector wage setting. Anticipates modern debates about inflation indexing of government pay. The asymmetry: silver-caused inflation has a clear remedy (proportional raise), but productivity-caused price shifts do not. Cross-ref 1.11.260-261.

refashioned: The extension of agricultural improvement and cultivation necessarily raises the price of every kind of animal food, roughly in proportion to the price of grain, while necessarily lowering the price of virtually every kind of vegetable food. It raises animal food prices because much of the land that formerly supported livestock, being now suitable for growing grain, must generate the rent and profit of cropland. It lowers vegetable food prices because improved cultivation increases the fertility and abundance of the land. Agricultural improvements also introduce many types of vegetable food that require less land and no more labor than grain, and therefore reach market much more cheaply.
elegant: Agricultural improvement raises animal food prices -- because land converted to crops must earn crop-level returns -- while lowering vegetable food prices through increased fertility and new crop varieties that require less land. Development pushes animal and vegetable food prices in opposite directions.
summary: Agricultural improvement drives animal food prices up (because grazing land converts to higher-return cropland) and vegetable food prices down (through increased fertility and new crops requiring less land).
distilled: Agricultural progress raises animal food prices by converting grazing land to crops, while lowering vegetable food prices through improved yields and new crop varieties.
notes: Opposite price effects of agricultural development on animal vs. vegetable food -- a key structural prediction. Opportunity-cost mechanism for animal food: land must earn crop-equivalent returns. Abundance mechanism for vegetable food: improved yields and new varieties. Cross-ref 1.11.236 on the rent-floor logic. Sets up the offsetting effects discussed in 1.11.264-265.

refashioned: Potatoes and maize, or Indian corn, are the two most important such innovations -- perhaps the greatest contributions that the expansion of Europe's commerce and navigation has made to European agriculture, or indeed to Europe itself. Many other vegetables that were confined to kitchen gardens in primitive agriculture, raised only by hand with a spade, become in advanced agriculture common field crops raised by the plough -- turnips, carrots, cabbages, and the like. If the progress of improvement necessarily raises the real price of one type of food, it just as necessarily lowers that of another, and it becomes a delicate matter to judge how far the rise in one is offset by the fall in the other.
elegant: Potatoes and maize -- perhaps Europe's greatest gains from the age of exploration -- exemplify how agricultural progress introduces cheaper vegetable foods. Turnips, carrots, and cabbages have similarly moved from garden spade to field plough. Since development simultaneously raises meat prices and lowers vegetable prices, judging the net effect on living costs requires careful balancing.
summary: Potatoes and maize from the New World, along with field crops like turnips and carrots, have dramatically expanded cheap vegetable food. Since development raises meat prices while lowering vegetable prices, the net effect on consumers is complex.
distilled: Potatoes, maize, and other field vegetables offset rising meat prices as economies develop, making the net effect on food costs a complex calculation.
notes: Potatoes and maize as transformative New World imports -- Smith calls them perhaps Europe's greatest gain from exploration. The spade-to-plough transition lowers production costs. Offsetting price movements create analytical difficulty. Cross-ref 1.11.263. Anticipates the potato's role in the population debate (Malthus).

refashioned: Once the real price of butcher's meat reaches its ceiling -- which, for most types except perhaps pork, it seems to have done across much of England more than a century ago -- any further rise in the price of other animal foods like poultry, fish, wild fowl, or venison cannot greatly affect the circumstances of the poor. The poor across much of England cannot be as much harmed by rising prices for poultry, fish, and game as they must be helped by falling potato prices.
elegant: Once meat prices reach their natural ceiling -- as they have in much of England for over a century -- further rises in poultry, fish, and game prices cannot much hurt the poor. The fall in potato prices helps them far more than any such rises could harm them.
summary: With meat prices already at their ceiling in England, rising prices for poultry, fish, and game matter less to the poor than the offsetting benefit of cheaper potatoes.
distilled: Cheap potatoes benefit the poor more than rising prices for secondary animal foods like poultry and game could harm them.
notes: Ceiling on meat prices -- once all convertible land is under crops, the opportunity-cost pressure on meat is exhausted. Potatoes as the decisive offsetting factor for the poor. Pork as an exception -- pigs are not pasture-dependent. Cross-ref 1.11.263-264. Social welfare focus on 'the inferior ranks of people.'

refashioned: In the current season of scarcity, high grain prices undoubtedly cause hardship for the poor. But in times of moderate plenty, when grain is at its ordinary price, the natural rise in the price of other raw produce cannot greatly affect them. They probably suffer more from the artificial price increases that taxes have imposed on manufactured necessities -- salt, soap, leather, candles, malt, beer, ale, and the like.
elegant: High grain prices during scarcity genuinely hurt the poor, but in normal times, naturally rising raw produce prices matter less to them than the artificial price increases that taxes impose on everyday necessities like salt, soap, leather, candles, and beer.
summary: In normal times, the poor suffer more from taxes on manufactured necessities like salt, soap, candles, and beer than from naturally rising raw produce prices. High grain prices hurt mainly during scarcity.
distilled: Taxes on everyday manufactured goods like salt, soap, and beer harm the poor more than naturally rising food prices do in times of normal harvest.
notes: Distinguishes natural price rises (structural, from development) from artificial ones (from taxation). Excise taxes on necessities as regressive taxation -- a theme Smith develops in Book V. The listed goods (salt, soap, leather, candles, malt, beer, ale) were all subject to excise duties. Cross-ref 1.11.265. Pivots toward the manufacturing price discussion.

refashioned:
Effects of the Progress of Improvement upon the Real Price of Manufactures.

The natural effect of economic improvement is to gradually reduce the real price of almost all manufactured goods. The cost of manufacturing labor decreases, perhaps without exception, in all of them. Thanks to better machinery, greater worker skill, and a more efficient division and distribution of work -- all natural consequences of improvement -- far less labor is needed to complete any given piece of work. Even though the real price of labor may rise considerably as society prospers, the enormous reduction in the quantity of labor required will generally more than compensate for even the greatest rise in its price.
elegant: Economic improvement naturally lowers the real price of nearly all manufactures. Better machinery, greater skill, and improved division of labor -- all consequences of development -- dramatically reduce the labor needed for any product. Even as wages rise with prosperity, the reduction in labor quantity more than offsets the rise in labor cost.
summary: Economic development naturally reduces manufactured goods' real prices because improvements in machinery, skill, and labor division cut the required labor so dramatically that even rising wages cannot offset the savings.
distilled: Technological progress and the division of labor reduce manufacturing costs faster than rising wages can increase them, so manufactured goods become cheaper over time.
notes: Opens the section on manufacturing prices -- the third category of goods after food and raw materials. The productivity-wage race: productivity wins because the labor-quantity reduction exceeds the labor-price increase. Three drivers: machinery, skill, division of labor. Cross-ref Book I, Chapters 1-3 on division of labor. Fundamental optimism about industrial progress.

refashioned: There are, however, a few manufactures where the necessary rise in the real price of raw materials will more than offset all the advantages that improvement can bring to the production process. In carpentry, joinery, and the coarser grades of cabinet-making, the necessary rise in the real price of timber -- as land improvement makes forests more valuable -- will more than offset all the gains from better machinery, greater skill, and more efficient work organization.
elegant: A few manufactures are exceptions: where raw materials become much more expensive with development, no amount of production improvement can compensate. In woodworking trades -- carpentry, joinery, and coarse cabinet-making -- the rising real price of timber as land is improved outweighs all gains from better machinery and work methods.
summary: In wood-based manufactures like carpentry and cabinet-making, the rising real price of timber due to land improvement exceeds the savings from better machinery and division of labor.
distilled: Rising timber prices due to land development can outpace manufacturing efficiency gains, making wood-based products an exception to the general trend of falling manufactured goods prices.
notes: Exception to the manufacturing price-decline rule: when raw material prices rise faster than productivity improves. Timber as a non-reproducible resource whose price rises with land improvement (opportunity cost of forest land). Cross-ref 1.11.267 on the general rule. Parallels the animal food price logic from 1.11.263.

refashioned:
But in all cases where the real price of raw materials either stays flat or rises only modestly, the price of the manufactured product falls very considerably.

This price decline has been most dramatic over the past two centuries in manufactures based on the coarser metals. A watch movement better than what could have been bought for twenty pounds around the middle of the last century can now perhaps be had for twenty shillings. In cutlery and locksmithing, in all metal toys, and in all those goods commonly known as Birmingham and Sheffield ware, prices have fallen enormously over the same period -- though not quite as dramatically as in watchmaking. The reduction has nevertheless been sufficient to astonish craftsmen across the rest of Europe, who in many cases admit they cannot produce work of equal quality for double or even triple the price. There are perhaps no manufactures where the division of labor can be carried further, or where the machinery admits of a greater variety of improvements, than those using the coarser metals.
elegant: Where raw material prices are stable, manufactured goods prices fall dramatically. The most striking examples are metal manufactures: a watch that cost twenty pounds a century ago now costs twenty shillings. Birmingham and Sheffield goods have fallen almost as sharply, astonishing European craftsmen who cannot match the quality at double or triple the price. Metal manufactures allow the greatest scope for division of labor and machinery improvements.
summary: Manufactured goods prices fall dramatically when raw material costs are stable. Metal goods show the greatest decline -- watches falling from twenty pounds to twenty shillings -- because metal manufactures allow the most extensive division of labor and machinery improvements.
distilled: Metal manufactures show the most dramatic price declines because they allow the greatest scope for division of labor and machinery innovation.
notes: Watch prices: 20 pounds to 20 shillings -- a 95% decline in a century. Birmingham and Sheffield as the industrial heartland of metal goods. European craftsmen's astonishment as evidence of Britain's manufacturing lead. Division of labor and machinery improvements as the twin drivers. Cross-ref 1.11.267 on the general mechanism. Cross-ref Book I, Chapter 1 on the division of labor in pin-making.

refashioned: In the clothing industry, there has been no such dramatic price reduction over the same period. The price of superfine cloth has actually risen somewhat relative to its quality over the past twenty-five to thirty years, reportedly due to a considerable increase in the price of the raw material -- entirely Spanish wool. The price of Yorkshire cloth, made entirely from English wool, is said to have fallen a good deal relative to its quality during the present century. Quality, however, is so disputable a matter that I regard all such comparisons as somewhat uncertain. In clothing manufacture, the division of labor remains nearly the same as a century ago, and the machinery is not very different. There may have been some small improvements in both, which may account for some price reduction.
elegant: Clothing manufacture shows no comparable price decline. Superfine cloth has even risen in price due to costlier Spanish wool, while Yorkshire cloth may have fallen somewhat -- though quality comparisons are inherently uncertain. Unlike metal trades, clothing manufacture has seen little change in its division of labor or machinery over the past century.
summary: Clothing prices have not fallen like metal goods prices because the division of labor and machinery in textile production have barely changed. Superfine cloth prices have even risen due to costlier Spanish wool, though quality-adjusted comparisons are unreliable.
distilled: Clothing manufacture has seen little price decline because its division of labor and machinery have changed far less than in the metal trades.
notes: Comparative stagnation of textile vs. metal manufacturing technology. Spanish wool as the raw material for superfine cloth. Quality adjustment problem acknowledged -- Smith is methodologically cautious. Yorkshire cloth from English wool as the domestic product. Cross-ref 1.11.269 on metal goods. The stagnation diagnosis would soon be overturned by the spinning jenny and water frame in the late 1770s.

refashioned:
The reduction becomes much more visible and undeniable when we compare present cloth prices with those of the late fifteenth century, when labor was far less subdivided and machinery much more primitive.

In 1487, under Henry VII, a law decreed that whoever sold by retail a broad yard of the finest scarlet or other dyed cloth of the finest make above sixteen shillings would forfeit forty shillings per yard. Sixteen shillings then, containing about the same silver as twenty-four shillings today, was considered a reasonable price for the finest cloth. Since this was a sumptuary law, such cloth had probably usually sold for somewhat more. A guinea may be considered the highest present price. Even assuming equal quality -- though modern cloth is almost certainly superior -- the money price of the finest cloth has fallen considerably since the fifteenth century.

But the real price has fallen far more. Six shillings and eightpence was then the standard price of a quarter of wheat. Sixteen shillings therefore equaled the price of more than two quarters and three bushels of wheat. At twenty-eight shillings per quarter, the real price of a yard of fine cloth then equaled at least three pounds, six shillings, and sixpence in today's money. The buyer was parting with command over as much labor and subsistence as that sum would purchase today.
elegant: Compared to the fifteenth century, the decline is unmistakable. In 1487, a sumptuary law capped fine cloth at sixteen shillings (twenty-four present shillings) per yard -- and it probably sold for more. Today a guinea is the top price. Even assuming equal quality, the money price has fallen. The real price has fallen far more: sixteen shillings then bought over two quarters of wheat, making the real cost equivalent to over three pounds six shillings in modern money -- several times today's price.
summary: Comparing cloth prices between the fifteenth century and the present shows a dramatic decline in both nominal and real terms. A yard of fine cloth that cost the wheat-equivalent of over three pounds then costs about a guinea now.
distilled: The real price of fine cloth has fallen from over three pounds six shillings in fifteenth-century wheat-equivalents to about one guinea today.
notes: Henry VII sumptuary law (1487, 4 Henry VII) as a price benchmark. Sumptuary laws set maximum prices, implying actual prices were higher. Silver-content and wheat-equivalence methods both applied. The real-price decline is far greater than the nominal decline. Cross-ref 1.11.270 on recent stagnation -- the long-run decline is still large. Fine scarlet cloth ('grained' = dyed with kermes or cochineal).

refashioned:
The reduction in the real price of coarse cloth, though considerable, has not been as great as for fine cloth.

In 1463, under Edward IV, a law decreed that no farm servant, common laborer, or servant to any artisan outside a city or borough should wear cloth costing more than two shillings per broad yard. Two shillings then contained nearly the same silver as four shillings today. But Yorkshire cloth now sold at four shillings per yard is probably much superior to anything made then for the poorest servants. Even the money price of their clothing, relative to quality, may be somewhat cheaper now. The real price is certainly far cheaper. Tenpence was then the standard price for a bushel of wheat. Two shillings therefore equaled the price of about two bushels and two pecks, which at today's three shillings and sixpence per bushel would cost eight shillings and ninepence. For a yard of this cloth, the poor servant was paying the equivalent of what eight shillings and ninepence purchases today. Since this was also a sumptuary law restricting expenditure, their actual clothing had commonly been much more expensive still.
elegant: Coarse cloth prices have fallen less dramatically than fine cloth but still substantially. In 1463, a sumptuary law capped servants' cloth at two shillings per yard (four present shillings in silver). Today's four-shilling Yorkshire cloth is probably better quality. In real terms, two shillings then bought two and a half bushels of wheat -- equivalent to eight shillings and ninepence now. Poor servants were actually paying even more, since the sumptuary law set a ceiling they apparently exceeded.
summary: Coarse cloth has also become much cheaper in real terms since the fifteenth century, though the decline is less dramatic than for fine cloth. A yard of cloth that cost a medieval servant the wheat-equivalent of eight shillings ninepence -- and likely more -- now costs four shillings for better quality.
distilled: Coarse cloth's real price has fallen substantially since the fifteenth century, though less dramatically than fine cloth's.
notes: Edward IV sumptuary law (1463, 3 Edward IV). Sumptuary laws as evidence that actual prices exceeded the caps. Yorkshire cloth as the modern benchmark. Quality improvement makes the real decline even larger than price data alone suggest. Cross-ref 1.11.271 on fine cloth. Social history: clothing costs as a significant burden on the medieval poor.

refashioned: The same law prohibited the same class of workers from wearing stockings costing more than fourteenpence per pair, equal to about twenty-eightpence in our present money. But fourteenpence was then the price of a bushel and nearly two pecks of wheat, which at today's three shillings and sixpence per bushel would cost five shillings and threepence. We would consider five shillings and threepence a very high price for a pair of stockings for the poorest servant. Yet in those times, they were paying the equivalent of that amount.
elegant: The same law capped stockings for servants at fourteenpence -- but that was then worth nearly a bushel and a half of wheat, equivalent to five shillings and threepence today. We would consider that absurdly expensive for a poor servant's stockings.
summary: Medieval stockings cost servants the wheat-equivalent of five shillings and threepence in modern money -- a price we would consider extremely high for the cheapest hosiery today.
distilled: Medieval servants paid the equivalent of five shillings threepence in wheat-purchasing power for a pair of stockings -- a price we would find astonishing today.
notes: Stocking prices as further evidence of the dramatic long-run decline in clothing costs. Same Edward IV sumptuary law as 1.11.272. Cross-ref 1.11.272. Sets up the explanation for why medieval clothing was so expensive (1.11.274-275).

refashioned: In the time of Edward IV, the art of knitting stockings was probably unknown anywhere in Europe. Stockings were made from common cloth, which may partly explain their high cost. The first person to wear knitted stockings in England is said to have been Queen Elizabeth, who received them as a gift from the Spanish ambassador.
elegant: Knitted stockings were unknown in Edward IV's time -- they were made from cut cloth, which was much more expensive. Queen Elizabeth is said to have been the first person in England to wear knitted stockings, received as a gift from the Spanish ambassador.
summary: Medieval stockings were expensive partly because knitting was unknown -- they were cut from cloth. Knitted stockings reportedly first appeared in England when Queen Elizabeth received a pair from Spain.
distilled: Medieval stockings were costly because knitting was unknown and they were made from cut cloth -- knitted stockings first reached England as a gift to Queen Elizabeth.
notes: Technological change as a driver of price decline -- the invention of knitting as a transformative production method. Queen Elizabeth anecdote -- the diffusion of knitting technology from Spain to England. Cross-ref 1.11.273. Illustrates the theme from 1.11.267 that manufacturing improvement reduces prices.

refashioned: In both coarse and fine woolen manufacture, the machinery used in those ancient times was far more primitive than it is today. It has since received three major improvements, along with probably many smaller ones that are difficult to count or assess. The three major improvements are: first, the replacement of the rock and spindle by the spinning wheel, which performs more than double the work with the same labor; second, the introduction of several ingenious machines that greatly speed up the winding of yarn and the arrangement of the warp and weft before they are placed in the loom -- operations that had previously been extremely tedious and laborious; and third, the use of the fulling mill to thicken cloth, replacing the old method of treading it in water. Neither wind nor water mills of any kind were known in England as early as the beginning of the sixteenth century, nor, as far as I know, in any other part of Europe north of the Alps. They had been introduced in Italy somewhat earlier.
elegant: Woolen manufacture has received three major technological improvements since the medieval period: the spinning wheel replaced the rock and spindle, doubling output per worker; ingenious machines streamlined yarn-winding and loom preparation; and the fulling mill replaced manual treading of cloth. Wind and water mills were unknown in England before the sixteenth century, though Italy had them earlier.
summary: Three major innovations transformed woolen manufacture: the spinning wheel (doubling productivity), yarn-winding machines, and the fulling mill. These technologies, unknown in England before the sixteenth century, explain much of the decline in cloth prices.
distilled: The spinning wheel, yarn-winding machines, and fulling mills -- three major innovations -- explain the dramatic long-run decline in cloth manufacturing costs.
notes: Three specific technological innovations identified and their productivity impact assessed. Rock and spindle to spinning wheel = 2x productivity gain. Yarn preparation machines. Fulling mill replacing manual cloth-treading. Diffusion from Italy northward. Cross-ref 1.11.271-274 on the price decline these innovations explain. Cross-ref 1.11.267 on the general mechanism of manufacturing improvement.

refashioned: These considerations may help explain why the real price of both coarse and fine cloth was so much higher in those ancient times than it is today. It took a greater quantity of labor to bring the goods to market. When they arrived, therefore, they had to purchase, or exchange for, a correspondingly greater quantity of labor.
elegant: Higher ancient cloth prices are explained by higher labor requirements. More labor to produce means a higher price in terms of what the product can command in exchange.
summary: Ancient cloth was expensive because it required far more labor to produce, and the price of any good reflects the labor required to bring it to market.
distilled: Ancient cloth was costly because primitive technology required far more labor to produce it, and prices reflect embodied labor.
notes: Labor theory of value reasoning -- prices reflect embodied labor. Summary explanation linking the technological evidence (1.11.275) to the price evidence (1.11.271-274). Cross-ref 1.11.267 on the general principle.

refashioned:
In those ancient times, the coarse manufacture was probably carried on in England as it has always been in countries where arts and manufactures are in their infancy. It was likely a household enterprise in which various family members performed different parts of the work when they had nothing else to do -- not as their main occupation or primary source of income. As noted earlier, work done this way always reaches market much more cheaply than work that is a craftsman's sole livelihood.

The fine manufacture, on the other hand, was not carried on in England at all but in the rich and commercially advanced country of Flanders, and was probably conducted then as now by workers who derived all or most of their income from it. Being a foreign product, it also had to pay some duty -- at minimum the ancient customs of tonnage and poundage -- though this was probably not very large. In those times, European policy was not to restrict foreign manufactures with high duties, but rather to encourage their import so that merchants could supply the wealthy with the comforts and luxuries they wanted at the lowest possible prices, which domestic industry could not yet provide.
elegant: Coarse cloth was a household by-product -- made by family members in spare time, reaching market cheaply. Fine cloth was produced in Flanders by specialized workers as their primary occupation, and imported into England with a small customs duty. European policy at the time encouraged imports of foreign manufactures to supply the wealthy with luxuries domestic industry could not yet produce.
summary: Ancient coarse cloth was cheap relative to fine cloth because it was a household by-product of spare-time labor, while fine cloth was professionally manufactured in Flanders and imported. European trade policy then favored easy import of luxury manufactures.
distilled: Medieval coarse cloth was relatively cheap because it was household spare-time production, while fine cloth was a professional Flemish import -- European policy then encouraged rather than restricted such imports.
notes: Household manufacture vs. specialized production -- a key distinction in manufacturing evolution. Flanders as the medieval center of fine cloth production. Tonnage and poundage -- ancient English customs duties. Pre-mercantilist trade policy: encouraging imports of manufactures rather than restricting them. Cross-ref 1.11.276 and Book I Chapter 1 on division of labor. Contrasts with later protectionist policy critiqued in Book IV.

refashioned:
These considerations may help explain why, in ancient times, the real price of coarse cloth was so much lower relative to fine cloth than it is today.

Conclusion of the Chapter.

I shall conclude this very long chapter by observing that every improvement in society's circumstances tends, either directly or indirectly, to raise the real rent of land -- to increase the landlord's real wealth and his power of purchasing the labor, or the products of labor, of other people.
elegant:
These factors explain why coarse cloth was historically much cheaper relative to fine cloth than it is today.

To conclude this chapter: every improvement in the conditions of society tends to raise the real rent of land, increasing the landlord's wealth and purchasing power over the labor of others.
summary: The ancient price gap between coarse and fine cloth is explained by differences in production methods and trade. The chapter's conclusion states that all social and economic improvement ultimately raises real land rents and landlords' wealth.
distilled: Every economic improvement tends to raise real land rents, increasing landlords' purchasing power over other people's labor.
notes: Chapter conclusion -- synthesizes the entire chapter's argument into a single principle: development benefits landlords. The landlord class as the ultimate beneficiary of progress. Cross-ref 1.11.276-277 on the cloth price explanation. Transition to the final summary of how each factor raises rent (1.11.279-282).

refashioned:
The expansion of agricultural improvement and cultivation tends to raise rent directly. The landlord's share of output necessarily increases as total output increases.

The rise in the real price of those types of raw produce that is first caused by expanded improvement and cultivation -- and then itself becomes the cause of still further expansion, such as the rise in cattle prices -- also tends to raise rent directly, and in an even greater proportion. The real value of the landlord's share -- his real command over other people's labor -- rises not only because the total output is worth more, but because his proportion of that output rises with it.
elegant: Expanded cultivation raises rent directly: as output grows, the landlord's share grows with it. Rising raw produce prices -- especially cattle -- raise rent in an even greater proportion, because the landlord's share of the total product rises along with its value.
summary: Agricultural improvement raises rents directly through increased output, and the rise in raw produce prices like cattle raises rents even more because the landlord's percentage share also increases.
distilled: Agricultural improvement raises rents both by increasing output and by raising the landlord's proportional share of that output.
notes: Two channels through which development raises rent: absolute output increase and rising landlord share. The cattle price mechanism: rising produce prices that themselves encourage further improvement create a positive feedback loop. Cross-ref 1.11.278. Anticipates Ricardo's theory of rent.

refashioned:
After the rise in its real price, that produce requires no more labor to harvest than before. A smaller proportion of it will therefore suffice to replace, with ordinary profit, the capital that employs that labor. A greater proportion must consequently go to the landlord.

All improvements in the productive powers of labor that directly reduce the real price of manufactures tend indirectly to raise the real rent of land. The landlord exchanges his surplus raw produce -- or its price -- for manufactured goods. Whatever lowers the real price of manufactures raises the real value of his raw produce. An equal quantity of raw produce thereby becomes equivalent to a greater quantity of manufactured goods, and the landlord can purchase more of the conveniences, ornaments, and luxuries he desires.
elegant: When produce prices rise but labor costs do not, the surplus above wages and profit -- the landlord's rent -- necessarily grows. Additionally, every fall in manufacturing prices raises the landlord's real purchasing power: his same quantity of raw produce now commands more manufactured goods.
summary: Rising produce prices increase rent because harvest labor costs stay the same while the surplus grows. Falling manufacturing prices also raise landlords' real income by increasing what their produce can buy in manufactured goods.
distilled: Rising produce prices and falling manufacturing prices both increase landlords' real income -- the first by expanding rent directly, the second by increasing its purchasing power over manufactured goods.
notes: Two indirect channels for rent increase: (1) rising produce prices with unchanged labor costs increase the residual (rent); (2) falling manufacture prices increase the real exchange value of agricultural surplus. The landlord as the ultimate beneficiary of both agricultural and industrial progress. Cross-ref 1.11.267 on falling manufacturing prices, 1.11.279 on direct rent increases.

refashioned: Every increase in the real wealth of society -- every increase in the quantity of useful labor employed within it -- tends indirectly to raise the real rent of land. A certain proportion of this labor naturally goes to agriculture. A greater number of workers and draft animals are employed in cultivating the land, the output increases with the capital devoted to it, and the rent rises with the output.
elegant: Every increase in society's real wealth directs more labor and capital toward agriculture, increasing output and therefore rent. General economic growth indirectly raises land rents.
summary: General economic growth raises land rents indirectly by directing more labor and capital toward agriculture, which increases output.
distilled: Economic growth raises land rents by channeling more labor and capital into agriculture, increasing output and the surplus accruing to landlords.
notes: Third indirect channel: general growth increases agricultural investment. Capital accumulation as the driver -- more stock employed in farming. Cross-ref 1.11.279-280. Completes the three-channel explanation of how development raises rent.

refashioned: The opposite circumstances -- neglect of cultivation and improvement, falling real prices for raw produce, rising real prices for manufactures due to decaying manufacturing skill and industry, and declining real wealth of society -- all tend to lower the real rent of land, reduce the landlord's real wealth, and diminish his power to purchase either labor or the products of other people's labor.
elegant: The reverse conditions -- agricultural neglect, falling raw produce prices, rising manufacturing costs, and declining wealth -- all lower real rents and reduce the landlord's purchasing power.
summary: Economic decline lowers land rents through the exact reverse of the mechanisms that raise them during development: neglected agriculture, falling produce prices, rising manufacturing costs, and shrinking national wealth.
distilled: Economic decline reverses all the mechanisms of rent growth: neglected agriculture, falling produce prices, and rising manufacturing costs all reduce real land rents.
notes: Mirror image of 1.11.279-281 -- every mechanism works in reverse during decline. Symmetry of the argument. Cross-ref 1.11.278-281. Transition to the three orders of society (1.11.283).

refashioned: The total annual output of every country's land and labor -- or equivalently, the total price of that output -- naturally divides itself, as already noted, into three parts: the rent of land, the wages of labor, and the profits of capital. It constitutes the revenue of three different orders of people: those who live by rent, those who live by wages, and those who live by profit. These are the three great, original, and fundamental orders of every civilized society, from whose revenue the income of every other group is ultimately derived.
elegant: National output divides into three shares: rent, wages, and profits -- the revenues of three fundamental orders: landlords, laborers, and capitalists. Every other group's income derives ultimately from these three.
summary: National income divides into rent, wages, and profits, supporting three fundamental social orders -- landlords, laborers, and capitalists -- from whose revenue all other incomes ultimately derive.
distilled: Every civilized society's income divides into rent, wages, and profits, supporting the three fundamental orders of landlords, laborers, and capitalists.
notes: The tripartite income division and the three orders of society -- a foundational framework for classical political economy. Recapitulates Book I, Chapters 6-8. 'Great, original, and constituent orders' -- Smith's social taxonomy. Sets up the analysis of each order's interest relative to the public interest (1.11.284-289). Cross-ref 1.7 (natural price), 1.8-1.10 (wages, profit, rent).

refashioned:
The interest of the first order -- the landlords -- is, as we have just seen, strictly and inseparably connected with the general interest of society. Whatever promotes or obstructs the one necessarily promotes or obstructs the other. When the public deliberates on matters of trade or regulation, landowners can never mislead it by advocating their own class interest -- at least, not if they have a tolerable understanding of that interest.

They are, however, too often lacking in even this basic understanding. They are the only order whose revenue costs them neither labor nor care, arriving, as it were, on its own, independent of any plan or effort of their own. The indolence that naturally results from the ease and security of their position too often renders them not only ignorant but incapable of the sustained attention needed to foresee and understand the consequences of any public regulation.
elegant: Landlords' interests are inseparably aligned with society's: what benefits society benefits them. They should therefore be the most reliable guides on public policy. Yet they rarely are. Their income arrives without effort, breeding an indolence that leaves them ignorant of their own interests and incapable of sustained policy analysis.
summary: Landlords' interests naturally align with society's, but their effortless income breeds indolence that leaves them too ignorant and inattentive to effectively advocate for the public good.
distilled: Landlords' interests align with society's, but their effortless income breeds an indolence that renders them poor guides on public policy.
notes: First order analyzed: landlords. Interest aligned with public good (from 1.11.278-281) but capability lacking. The indolence argument -- unearned income produces inattention. A striking critique from someone often miscast as a defender of the landed class. Cross-ref 1.11.283. Sets up the contrast with merchants and manufacturers (1.11.286-289).

refashioned:
The interest of the second order -- wage earners -- is as strictly connected with society's general interest as the landlords'. Workers' wages, as already shown, are highest when the demand for labor is continually rising, or when the employed workforce is growing considerably. When society's real wealth stops growing, wages quickly fall to what barely sustains a family -- just enough to continue the supply of laborers. When society declines, wages fall even below this level. The order of proprietors may gain more from prosperity than laborers do, but no order suffers as cruelly from decline.
