Yet although the laborer's interest is strictly bound to society's, he is incapable of either understanding that interest or seeing its connection to his own. His circumstances leave him no time to acquire the necessary information, and his education and habits typically make him unfit to judge, even if fully informed. In public deliberations, therefore, his voice is little heard and less regarded -- except when his complaints are orchestrated, encouraged, and supported by his employers, serving not his purposes, but theirs.
elegant: Laborers' interests are as tightly linked to general prosperity as landlords'. Wages rise with economic growth, fall to subsistence when growth stops, and drop below subsistence in decline -- no class suffers more from economic deterioration. Yet laborers cannot comprehend or articulate this connection: they lack the time, education, and habits needed for policy analysis. Their voice in public debate is heard only when their employers organize it for their own purposes.
summary: Workers' interests align perfectly with society's -- they benefit most from growth and suffer most from decline. But lack of education and time leaves them unable to understand or advocate for their own interests in public debate, where they are heard only when employers use them as instruments.
distilled: Workers benefit most from economic growth and suffer most from decline, yet lack the education and time to advocate their own interests -- their voice is heard only when employers exploit it for their own purposes.
notes: Second order analyzed: laborers. Interest aligned with public good but voice marginalized. Wages as a function of growth rate, not wealth level (cross-ref 1.8). The subsistence wage as a floor. Laborers as political pawns of employers -- a remarkably modern observation about organized labor being co-opted by capital. Cross-ref 1.11.283-284.

refashioned: Their employers constitute the third order -- those who live by profit. It is capital employed for profit that sets the greater part of useful labor in motion in every society. The plans and projects of business owners regulate and direct all the most important operations of labor, and profit is the end proposed by all those plans. But the rate of profit does not, like rent and wages, rise with society's prosperity and fall with its decline. On the contrary, profit is naturally low in rich countries and high in poor ones, and it is always highest in the countries heading fastest toward ruin.
elegant: The third order -- employers and capitalists -- direct society's labor through their pursuit of profit. But unlike rent and wages, profit does not rise with prosperity: it is naturally low in rich countries, high in poor ones, and highest in countries racing toward ruin.
summary: The capitalist order directs most of society's labor in pursuit of profit, but profit rates move inversely to national prosperity -- low in rich countries, high in poor ones, and highest in declining ones.
distilled: Profit rates move inversely to national prosperity -- low where society thrives, high where it stagnates, and highest where it declines -- making capitalists' interests misaligned with the public good.
notes: Third order analyzed: capitalists/employers. Critical divergence: unlike rent and wages, profit rates are inversely correlated with national prosperity. 'Highest in the countries which are going fastest to ruin' -- one of Smith's most striking formulations. Implies that capitalists' class interest is structurally opposed to the public interest. Cross-ref 1.8, 1.9, 1.10 on wages and profits. Cross-ref 1.11.283-285.

refashioned: The interest of this third order, therefore, does not share the same connection with society's general interest as the other two. Merchants and master manufacturers are the two groups within this order who typically employ the largest amounts of capital and who, by their wealth, command the greatest share of public attention. Since they spend their entire lives devising plans and projects, they often possess sharper analytical minds than most country gentlemen. Their thinking, however, is typically focused on the interests of their own particular line of business rather than on society's interests. Their judgment, even when offered with the greatest sincerity -- which it has not always been -- is much more reliable regarding their own business than regarding the public good. Their advantage over the country gentleman lies not in a better understanding of the public interest, but in a better understanding of their own.
elegant: Merchants and manufacturers -- the most influential members of the capitalist order -- are sharper than most landowners because business life sharpens the mind. But their thinking focuses on their own trade, not the public interest. Their superior knowledge is of their own advantage, not society's. Even their most candid advice is more reliable about their business than about the public good.
summary: Merchants and manufacturers are intellectually sharper than landowners but focus on their own business interests, not the public interest. Their policy advice is more reliable about their own advantage than about the general welfare.
distilled: Merchants and manufacturers understand their own interests better than any other class, but this gives them no special insight into the public interest -- and frequently sets them against it.
notes: Asymmetric knowledge: capitalists understand their own interests but not the public interest. The country gentleman comparison -- landowners are less sharp but more aligned. 'Which it has not been upon every occasion' -- Smith's pointed aside about disingenuous business lobbying. Cross-ref 1.11.284-286. Key passage for Smith's political economy: distrust of business policy advice.

refashioned: It is through this superior knowledge of their own interest that they have frequently imposed on the generosity of landowners and persuaded them to sacrifice both their own interest and the public's, based on the simple but honest conviction that the merchants' interest, and not their own, was the public interest. The interest of dealers in any particular trade or manufacture is always in some respects different from, and even opposed to, that of the public. To widen the market and narrow the competition is always the dealers' interest. Widening the market may often serve the public interest well enough, but narrowing competition must always work against it, serving only to enable dealers to raise their profits above natural levels and levy, for their own benefit, an unjust tax upon the rest of their fellow citizens.
elegant: Merchants exploit their superior self-knowledge to persuade naive landowners that business interests are the public interest. But dealers always seek to widen their market and narrow competition. Wider markets may serve the public; narrower competition never does -- it only lets dealers levy an unjust private tax on everyone else by inflating profits above natural levels.
summary: Merchants manipulate the politically naive landed class into equating business interests with the public good. Dealers always want wider markets and less competition -- and while wider markets can benefit the public, restricted competition never does.
distilled: Merchants always seek to widen markets and restrict competition -- the first may serve the public, but the second always harms it by enabling dealers to levy an unjust private tax through inflated profits.
notes: One of Smith's most famous and politically charged passages. 'To widen the market and to narrow the competition' -- the twin goals of business lobbying. Only market-widening can align with public interest; competition-narrowing never does. The 'absurd tax' metaphor for monopoly profits. Cross-ref 1.11.284-287. Central to the free-market interpretation of Smith -- he distrusts business as much as government.

refashioned: Any proposal for a new law or commercial regulation that comes from this order should always be listened to with great caution, and should never be adopted until after long and careful examination -- with not only the most thorough but the most skeptical scrutiny. It comes from a class of men whose interest is never exactly the same as the public's, who generally have an interest in deceiving and even oppressing the public, and who have accordingly, on many occasions, done both.
elegant: Any legislative proposal from merchants and manufacturers should be received with the greatest suspicion and never adopted without prolonged, skeptical examination. It comes from men whose interests diverge from the public's, who generally profit from deceiving and oppressing the public, and who have repeatedly done so.
summary: Commercial legislation proposed by merchants and manufacturers should be treated with maximum suspicion, since this class has interests opposed to the public and a demonstrated history of deceiving and oppressing it.
distilled: Any commercial regulation proposed by merchants and manufacturers should be presumed to serve their private interests against the public, and examined with the deepest suspicion.
notes: Perhaps Smith's most radical political statement in the entire Wealth of Nations. Direct warning against regulatory capture. 'An interest to deceive and even to oppress the public' -- extraordinarily strong language. 'Upon many occasions, both deceived and oppressed it' -- empirical claim based on the trade restrictions analyzed throughout Book I. Cross-ref 1.11.286-288. Foundational text for the public-choice critique of business lobbying. Often cited as evidence that Smith was no apologist for capitalist interests.

distilled: The Great Famine of 1316-1317 produced peak wheat prices exceeding 2 pounds per quarter.
notes: Great Famine of 1315-1322 -- one of the worst subsistence crises in European history. Cross-ref 1.11.297.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1317-1338: 1317 entries averaging 1 pound 19 shillings 6 pence; subsequent low prices in 1336 (2 shillings) and 1338 (3 shillings 4 pence). Period total of 23 pounds 4 shillings 11.25 pence, averaging 1 pound 18 shillings 8 pence.
elegant: [TABLE] 1317 averaged L1 19s 6d; prices collapsed to 2s by 1336. Period average: L1 18s 8d -- heavily skewed by famine-era peaks.
summary: Wheat prices after the 1317 famine peak collapsed to as low as 2 shillings by 1336. The period average of about 2 pounds was skewed upward by the extreme famine prices.
distilled: Post-famine wheat prices collapsed from nearly 2 pounds to 2 shillings, with the period average skewed high by the crisis years.
notes: Post-famine price collapse -- markets normalize after supply crisis. Period average calculation. The 2s price in 1336 represents a return to abundance. Cross-ref 1.11.297-298.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1339-1369: Entries include 1339 (9 shillings), 1349 (2 shillings), 1359 (1 pound 6 shillings 8 pence), 1361 (2 shillings), 1363 (15 shillings), and 1369 entries averaging 1 pound 2 shillings. In 1776 money, these range from 4 shillings 8 pence to 3 pounds 2 shillings 2 pence.
elegant: [TABLE] Wheat prices 1339-1369: ranging from 2s to L1 6s 8d, with continued volatility through the Black Death era.
summary: Mid-fourteenth-century wheat prices ranged widely, with the 1349 low of 2 shillings coinciding with the Black Death's devastating population reduction.
distilled: Wheat prices from 1339-1369 show extreme variation, with the Black Death year of 1349 producing very low prices due to population collapse.
notes: 1349 -- the Black Death. Low prices likely reflect massive population decline reducing demand while land remained abundant. Cross-ref 1.11.299. Edward III's reign (referenced in 1.11.230) spans this period.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1379-1390: 1379 at 4 shillings, 1387 at 2 shillings, 1390 entries averaging 14 shillings 5 pence. In 1776 money, these range from 4 shillings 8 pence to 1 pound 13 shillings 7 pence.
elegant: [TABLE] Wheat prices 1379-1390: ranging from 2s (1387) to about 14s 5d (1390 average).
summary: Late fourteenth-century wheat prices remained relatively low, ranging from 2 shillings to about 14 shillings per quarter.
distilled: Wheat prices in 1379-1390 were generally low, reflecting post-Black Death conditions of abundant land and reduced population.
notes: Post-Black Death era -- continued low prices from reduced population pressure on food supply. Cross-ref 1.11.300.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1401 and 1407: 1401 at 16 shillings (equivalent to 1 pound 17 shillings 6 pence in 1776 money); 1407 entries averaging 3 shillings 10 pence (equivalent to 8 shillings 10 pence in 1776 money).
elegant: [TABLE] 1401: 16s (= L1 17s 6d in 1776 money); 1407 averaged 3s 10d (= 8s 10d in 1776 money).
summary: Early fifteenth-century wheat prices: 16 shillings in 1401 dropping to under 4 shillings in 1407.
distilled: Wheat prices in the early fifteenth century fluctuated between 4 shillings and 16 shillings per quarter.
notes: Early Lancastrian period. Continued price volatility. Cross-ref 1.11.301.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1416-1439: 1416 at 16 shillings. Period total of 15 pounds 9 shillings 4 pence, averaging 1 pound 5 shillings 9.5 pence. Subsequent entries: 1423 (8 shillings), 1425 (4 shillings), 1434 (1 pound 6 shillings 8 pence), 1435 (5 shillings 4 pence), 1439 (1 pound).
elegant: [TABLE] 1416-1439: period average L1 5s 9.5d. Prices ranged from 4s (1425) to L1 6s 8d (1434).
summary: Wheat prices from 1416 to 1439 averaged about 1 pound 6 shillings, with sharp swings from 4 shillings to over 1 pound 6 shillings in individual years.
distilled: Mid-fifteenth-century wheat prices averaged about 1 pound 6 shillings per quarter with wide annual variation.
notes: Period average calculation. The 1425 price of 4 shillings is the year used for the Burcester Priory hide valuations in 1.11.232. Cross-ref 1.11.302.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1439-1444: 1439 entries averaging 1 pound 3 shillings 4 pence (equivalent to 2 pounds 6 shillings 8 pence in 1776 money); 1440 at 1 pound 4 shillings; 1444 entries averaging 4 shillings 2 pence (equivalent to 4 shillings 8 pence in 1776 money).
elegant: [TABLE] 1439 averaged L1 3s 4d (= L2 6s 8d in 1776 money); 1440 at L1 4s; 1444 at just 4s 2d.
summary: Wheat prices around 1440 showed the typical medieval pattern of sharp fluctuation, from over 1 pound to just 4 shillings within a few years.
distilled: Wheat prices dropped from over 1 pound in 1439-1440 to just 4 shillings in 1444.
notes: Continued medieval price volatility. Cross-ref 1.11.303.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1445-1451: Entries at 4 shillings 6 pence (1445), 8 shillings (1447), 6 shillings 8 pence (1448), 5 shillings (1449), and 8 shillings (1451). Period total of 12 pounds 15 shillings 4 pence, averaging 1 pound 1 shilling 3 and one-third pence.
elegant: [TABLE] 1445-1451: prices between 4s 6d and 8s. Period average: L1 1s 3.33d.
summary: Wheat prices in the late 1440s settled into a relatively moderate and stable range of 4 to 8 shillings per quarter.
distilled: Late 1440s wheat prices stabilized at 4-8 shillings per quarter, with a period average of about 1 pound 1 shilling.
notes: Relatively stable period in wheat markets. Period average calculation. Cross-ref 1.11.303-304.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1453-1463: Entries include 1453 (5 shillings 4 pence), 1455 (1 shilling 2 pence), 1457 (7 shillings 8 pence), 1459 (5 shillings), 1460 (8 shillings), and 1463 entries averaging 1 shilling 10 pence. In 1776 money equivalents provided.
elegant: [TABLE] 1453-1463: prices from as low as 1s 2d (1455) to 8s (1460). The 1463 price of under 2s is remarkably low.
summary: Wheat prices from 1453 to 1463 varied widely, with the extraordinary low of just over 1 shilling in 1455 and 1463.
distilled: Mid-fifteenth-century wheat prices included extraordinary lows of about 1-2 shillings, suggesting periods of great abundance.
notes: The 1455 price of 1s 2d is among the lowest in the entire series. Wars of the Roses period (1455-1487). The 1463 sumptuary law price referenced in 1.11.272 falls in this period. Cross-ref 1.11.305.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1464-1499 plus early sixteenth century: 1464-1497 entries with period total of 8 pounds 9 shillings, averaging 14 shillings 1 pence. Subsequent entries from 1499 to 1557, with prices generally between 4 and 8 shillings before rising to 1 pound or more from 1521.
elegant: [TABLE] 1464-1497 averaged 14s 1d. From 1499-1557, prices were mostly 4-8s, with a notable L1 in 1521 marking the beginning of the Tudor price rise.
summary: Wheat prices averaged 14 shillings from 1464-1497, then remained low through the early sixteenth century before beginning to rise in the 1520s as the Tudor price revolution began.
distilled: Wheat prices averaged 14 shillings in the late fifteenth century, with the Tudor price revolution beginning to push prices upward from the 1520s.
notes: Period average at 14s 1d. The early sixteenth-century price stability gives way to the Tudor price revolution, driven partly by the influx of American silver discussed in 1.11.253. Cross-ref 1.11.306.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1557-1560: Various entries for 1557 averaging 17 shillings 8.5 pence; 1558-1560 all at 8 shillings. Period total of 6 pounds 0 shillings 2.5 pence, averaging 10 shillings 0.5 pence.
elegant: [TABLE] 1557 averaged 17s 8.5d; 1558-1560 stable at 8s each. Period average: 10s 0.5d.
summary: Wheat prices in the late 1550s included a spike in 1557 before stabilizing at 8 shillings for 1558-1560, with a period average of 10 shillings.
distilled: Late 1550s wheat prices stabilized at 8 shillings after a 1557 spike, averaging 10 shillings for the period.
notes: 1557 price spike may reflect the famine of 1556-1557 during Mary I's reign. Cross-ref 1.11.307.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1561-1574: 1561 and 1562 both at 8 shillings; 1574 entries averaging 2 pounds (equivalent to 2 pounds in 1776 money, as debasement was complete by this period).
elegant: [TABLE] 1561-62 at 8s; 1574 averaged L2 -- prices rising sharply as the Elizabethan price revolution accelerated.
summary: Wheat prices jumped from 8 shillings in 1561-1562 to 2 pounds in 1574 as Elizabethan-era price inflation accelerated.
distilled: The sharp rise from 8 shillings to 2 pounds between 1562 and 1574 reflects the accelerating Elizabethan price revolution.
notes: Major price increase in the Elizabethan period. Silver debasement largely complete by this point, so 1776-money conversions are closer to 1:1. Cross-ref 1.11.307-308. The price revolution discussed in 1.11.253.

refashioned: [TABLE] Wheat prices for 1587-1597: Prices at 3 pounds 4 shillings (1587), 2 pounds 16 shillings (1594), 2 pounds 13 shillings (1595), 4 pounds (1596), and 1597 entries averaging 4 pounds 12 shillings. These late Elizabethan prices are dramatically higher than earlier in the century.
elegant: [TABLE] 1587-1597: prices ranged from L2 13s to L4 12s -- late Elizabethan crisis-era peaks reflecting bad harvests and wartime disruption.
summary: Late Elizabethan wheat prices reached extraordinary levels of 3 to nearly 5 pounds per quarter during the crisis years of 1587-1597.
distilled: Late Elizabethan wheat prices of 3-5 pounds per quarter reflected compounding effects of bad harvests, war, and the ongoing price revolution.
notes: 1590s harvest failures combined with the Spanish war. Some of the highest prices in the entire series. Cross-ref 1.11.309. These prices feed into the Windsor market series that follows.

refashioned:
[TABLE] Wheat prices for 1598-1601 and period summary: 1598 at 2 pounds 16 shillings 8 pence, 1599 at 1 pound 19 shillings 2 pence, 1600 at 1 pound 17 shillings 8 pence, 1601 at 1 pound 14 shillings 10 pence. Period total of 28 pounds 9 shillings 4 pence, averaging 2 pounds 7 shillings 5.5 pence.

Followed by the header: Prices of the quarter of nine bushels of the best or highest-priced wheat at Windsor market, on Lady Day and Michaelmas, from 1595 to 1764, both inclusive; the price of each year being the medium between the highest prices of these two market days.
elegant: [TABLE] 1598-1601 prices declining from L2 16s 8d to L1 14s 10d. Period average: L2 7s 5.5d. Introduces the Windsor market series (1595-1764) -- best wheat prices at Lady Day and Michaelmas.
summary: Wheat prices fell from nearly 3 pounds to under 2 pounds between 1598 and 1601. This section introduces the more systematic Windsor market series covering 1595-1764.
distilled: The Windsor market wheat price series (1595-1764) begins here, providing the most systematic historical price data in the chapter.
notes: Transition from scattered historical records to the systematic Windsor market series. Lady Day (March 25) and Michaelmas (September 29) -- the two principal English quarter days. 'Nine bushels' = one quarter (Winchester measure). Cross-ref 1.11.258 on Windsor market evidence. This is the dataset underlying Smith's empirical arguments about silver and grain prices.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1595-1620: Beginning at 2 pounds in 1595, peaking at 3 pounds 9 shillings 6 pence in 1597, then fluctuating between about 1 pound 10 shillings and 2 pounds 16 shillings 8 pence through 1620.
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1595-1620: crisis peak of L3 9s 6d in 1597, then settling to L1 10s-L2 17s range.
summary: The Windsor market series begins with the 1590s crisis, peaks at over 3 pounds in 1597, then settles into a range of roughly 1.5 to 2.5 pounds through 1620.
distilled: Windsor wheat prices peaked at over 3 pounds during the 1597 crisis and settled to 1.5-2.5 pounds through 1620.
notes: First 26 years of the Windsor series. The 1597 peak reflects the nationwide harvest crisis. Prices stabilize under James I. Cross-ref 1.11.310-311.

refashioned: [TABLE] Period summary for 1595-1620: Total of 54 pounds 0 shillings 6.5 pence across 26 years, averaging 2 pounds 1 shilling 6.75 pence per quarter.
elegant: [TABLE] 1595-1620 average: L2 1s 6.75d per quarter over 26 years.
summary: The average wheat price from 1595-1620 was about 2 pounds 1 shilling 7 pence per quarter at Windsor market.
distilled: Average Windsor wheat price for 1595-1620 was approximately 2 pounds 2 shillings per quarter.
notes: Period average calculation. This average includes the 1590s crisis prices which pull the average up. Cross-ref 1.11.312.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1621-1636: Ranging from 1 pound 8 shillings (1628) to 3 pounds 8 shillings (1631), with most prices between 2 and 3 pounds. The 1630s show generally higher prices.
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1621-1636: L1 8s to L3 8s range, generally rising through the 1630s.
summary: Wheat prices from 1621-1636 ranged from about 1.5 to 3.5 pounds, trending upward into the 1630s.
distilled: Windsor wheat prices trended upward through the 1620s-1630s, ranging from 1.5 to 3.5 pounds per quarter.
notes: Early Stuart period through the lead-up to the English Civil War. Rising prices reflect both monetary factors and agricultural conditions. Cross-ref 1.11.313.

refashioned: [TABLE] Period summary for 1621-1636: Total of 40 pounds 0 shillings 0 pence across 16 years, averaging 2 pounds 10 shillings per quarter.
elegant: [TABLE] 1621-1636 average: L2 10s per quarter over 16 years -- higher than the previous period.
summary: The average wheat price for 1621-1636 was 2 pounds 10 shillings -- notably higher than the 1595-1620 average of about 2 pounds 2 shillings.
distilled: Average Windsor wheat price rose from about 2 pounds 2 shillings (1595-1620) to 2 pounds 10 shillings (1621-1636).
notes: Rising period averages. The 8-shilling increase per quarter between periods is consistent with ongoing price-level adjustment. Cross-ref 1.11.313-314.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1637-1700: A 64-year span covering the English Civil War, Interregnum, Restoration, and Glorious Revolution. Prices peaked during the Civil War era (4 pounds 5 shillings in 1648, 4 pounds in 1649) and showed wide variation from 1 pound 5 shillings 2 pence (1687) to 3 pounds 14 shillings (1662). The 60-year total (excluding the Civil War gap of 1642-1645) was 153 pounds 1 shilling 8 pence, averaging 2 pounds 11 shillings and one-third of a penny.
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1637-1700: Civil War peaks of L4+ in 1648-49, post-Restoration variation from L1 5s to L3 14s. 60-year average: L2 11s 0.33d.
summary: Wheat prices from 1637-1700 peaked during the Civil War at over 4 pounds, varied widely through the Restoration, and averaged about 2 pounds 11 shillings over 60 recorded years.
distilled: The 1637-1700 wheat price average of 2 pounds 11 shillings includes Civil War peaks above 4 pounds and Restoration-era lows near 1 pound 5 shillings.
notes: Major historical events reflected in prices: English Civil War (1642-1651), Restoration (1660), Glorious Revolution (1688). Gap in the series for 1642-1645 (Civil War disruption to Windsor market). Highest recorded price: L4 5s in 1648. Period average of L2 11s 0.33d. Cross-ref 1.11.314-315.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1701-1740: Prices ranged from 1 pound 6 shillings (1706) to 3 pounds 18 shillings 6 pence (1709), with a general trend of moderate prices averaging around 2 pounds. The decade 1731-1740 shows a 10-year total of 18 pounds 12 shillings 8 pence, averaging 1 pound 17 shillings 3.5 pence.
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1701-1740: mostly L1 6s to L2 15s, with a 1709 spike to L3 18s 6d. The 1731-1740 decade averaged L1 17s 3.5d -- below earlier periods.
summary: Early eighteenth-century wheat prices were generally moderate, ranging from about 1.5 to 2.5 pounds with occasional spikes. The 1731-1740 decade average fell to about 1 pound 17 shillings -- below the seventeenth-century averages.
distilled: Early eighteenth-century wheat prices were lower than seventeenth-century levels, with the 1731-1740 decade averaging about 1 pound 17 shillings per quarter.
notes: Declining wheat prices in the early 18th century -- this is the evidence Smith cites in 1.11.258 against the silver-depreciation theory. The 1709 spike coincides with the Great Frost of 1709 -- the coldest winter in 500 years. 1731-1740 decade marks the beginning of detailed sub-period calculations. Cross-ref 1.11.258, 1.11.316.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1741-1750: Decade total of 16 pounds 18 shillings 2 pence, averaging 1 pound 13 shillings 9.75 pence. Prices ranged from 1 pound 4 shillings 10 pence (1743-1744) to 2 pounds 6 shillings 8 pence (1741).
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1741-1750: decade average L1 13s 9.75d -- the lowest decade average in the series. Range: L1 5s to L2 7s.
summary: The 1741-1750 decade had the lowest average wheat prices in the entire Windsor series at about 1 pound 14 shillings, consistent with Smith's argument that grain was cheaper in the eighteenth century.
distilled: The 1741-1750 decade produced the lowest average wheat prices in the Windsor series, supporting Smith's argument against silver depreciation.
notes: Key evidence for Smith's thesis in 1.11.258 -- wheat prices were lower in the mid-18th century than the mid-17th. The low decade average of L1 13s 9.75d compares to L2 11s in the 1637-1700 period. Cross-ref 1.11.258-259, 1.11.317.

refashioned: [TABLE] Windsor market wheat prices, 1751-1764, and grand average: Decade-plus prices ranged from 1 pound 10 shillings 3 pence (1761) to 3 pounds (1757). The 64-year total from 1701-1764 was 129 pounds 13 shillings 6 pence, averaging 2 pounds 0 shillings 6.75 pence per quarter.
elegant: [TABLE] Windsor wheat 1751-1764: prices rising to L3 (1757) but averaging L2 0s 6.75d for the full 64-year span of 1701-1764.
summary: The final entries of the Windsor series (1751-1764) show moderately rising prices. The 64-year average for 1701-1764 was 2 pounds and about 7 pence -- lower than the seventeenth-century average, confirming Smith's argument.
distilled: The 64-year Windsor wheat average of 2 pounds 0 shillings 7 pence for 1701-1764 was lower than the preceding century, confirming that grain prices had not risen.
notes: Grand average for the 18th-century portion: L2 0s 6.75d vs. L2 11s for the 1637-1700 period -- a clear decline. This is the empirical backbone of Smith's argument in 1.11.258-259 that silver was not continuously depreciating. The 1757 spike to L3 reflects the poor harvests Smith discusses in 1.11.259. Final entry of Book I. Cross-ref 1.11.258-259, 1.11.317-318.
